webTitle: Scare stories blamed for fall in visitors from overseas

fields.headline: Scare stories blamed for fall in visitors from overseas
fields.standfirst:
Tourism £100m a week lost as bookings plummet

www.guardian.co.uk/footandmouth
fields.trailText: Huddled at the gates of Buckingham Palace, the hood of his yellow Pacamac pulled up to keep out the London drizzle, Antonio Cardona explained why he was shunning Lakeland scenery this year.
fields.body:
Huddled at the gates of Buckingham Palace, the hood of his yellow Pacamac pulled up to keep out the London drizzle, Antonio Cardona explained why he was shunning Lakeland scenery this year.

"We were hoping to go to the countryside, going rambling in the north," said the Californian, who had promised to show his granddaughters rural delights as well as the London Eye and Westminster Abbey.

"But it doesn't seem wise now. We don't want to take hoof and mouth back with us or spread it around this country, so we'll be staying on the main highways," he added.

"Our daughter's a vet so we realise how serious this is," chipped in his wife, Lois. "Some of our friends were even telling us we shouldn't eat any meat over here."

Such rumours seem mild compared with many of the foot and mouth tales doing the rounds in the US. The stories are potentially so damaging in the UK's biggest tourist market - 4m Americans visit this country each year - that Janet Anderson, the tourism minister, even flew to New York in an effort to dispel them.

British representatives in the US report a distinct chill in the special relationship as potential holidaymakers inquire whether we are in quarantine, whether our water is safe to drink, and even whether they should bring dried food supplies with them.

"The overseas media have been putting out stories that have been totally inaccurate," said Richard Tobias, chief executive of the British Incoming Tour Operators Association. "Our major task is to get the message out that Britain is safe to visit, there's plenty of food, and if you eat it you won't keel over."

The government as well as the industry is attempting to ram home that message to both overseas and domestic tourists this week. Tony Blair and his ministers have put the trade at the top of the agenda, with good reason. Tourism is worth £63bn a year in Britain and supports 1.7m jobs - but not, at this rate, for long.

Spring is the peak time for holiday bookings, but they have dropped by 20% to 30% in many markets. Rural tourism, worth £12bn a year, is losing £100m a week; the south-west and Cumbria are particularly hard hit because they are disease hot spots. The London tourist board has warned that urban destinations are likely to suffer knock-on effects.

With Easter only a fortnight away, restoring trade is a matter of urgency. British urbanites have been just as confused as overseas visitors and, wary of spreading disease, have tried to help rural communities by staying away. The government's twin-pronged approach is to urge them back while pressing organisations to open up more land.

High profile attractions such as Chatsworth House in Derbyshire and Stonehenge in Wiltshire remain closed, but many sites are reopening after risk assessments. The National Trust plans to open 200 of its properties over the next few days, although in some cases the grounds of buildings will still be out of bounds, while English Heritage will have opened almost half of its 409 properties by Monday.

British waterways closed 70% of its network at the start of March, but says that almost 95% of it will be up and running again by the end of Sunday, although fishing and walking will still be banned. Ministers are also urging local authorities to follow the lead of Suffolk and Lincolnshire in reopening bridleways and footpaths away from infected areas. Music festivals are now set to go ahead with appropriate precautions.

On top of this, the British Incoming Tour Operators Association is launching a Great Value Britain scheme, advertising cut price deals to tempt wary visitors back to the country.

Yet business people are becoming increasingly nervous as Easter approaches. In Wales, a spokeswoman for the tourist board said that estimated losses of £10m a week were likely to double in April.

In Cumbria, industry chiefs have warned that losses of £8m to £10m a week could easily rise to £30m over Easter, when the season should begin in earnest. Dumfries and Galloway has seen a 60% drop in bookings. In Northern Ireland, hotel and B&B bookings are said to have halved.

Until the crisis developed, tourism was a growth industry, accounting for a quarter of all new jobs in the past 10 years.

The British Tourist Authority had estimated that spending by overseas visitors would rise to over £18bn by 2003, a 44% increase from 1997. Now it is revising those predictions as spring receipts tumble and Britain begins to be seen as a land where piles of rotting carcasses mar the views. "The image of cattle burning has probably been the single most damaging thing," admitted Ms Anderson.

As MP for the rural Rossendale and Darwen constituency in Lancashire, she knows how vital the trade is to the country's future. Most tourism-based businesses are small and depend on a regular cashflow. Four-fifths of them have a turnover of less than £250,000 a year. The rural recovery task force has announced moratoria for small businesses on rates and taxes and similar measures are being introduced in Wales; some banks have extended credit.

Most industry leaders seem to accept the government line that the best way to boost the sector will be via promotional campaigns once the disease is under control. Although ministers have not agreed exact figures, insiders hope the BTA will receive £10m to market the country, while the English tourist council could get £3m.

But the longer the crisis lasts, the longer it will take tourism to rally.

The scorching summer which has been promised by forecasters may help, but every hotelier and caterer knows that the tourist industry is in for a long haul.

webTitle: Reviews: London Walking: A Handbook For Survival by Simon Pope, and Walking Literary London by Roger Tagholm

fields.headline: London's brilliant parade
fields.standfirst: Exhaust, brickdust, endless semis:  Andy Beckett  samples the difficult pleasures of city walking with London Walking: A Handbook For Survival by Simon Pope, and Walking Literary London by Roger Tagholm
fields.trailText: Exhaust, brickdust, endless semis: Andy Beckett samples the difficult pleasures of city walking with London Walking: A Handbook For Survival by Simon Pope, and Walking Literary London by Roger Tagholm
fields.body:
London Walking: A Handbook For Survival
Simon Pope
256pp, Ellipsis, £10
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Walking Literary London: 25 Original Walks Through London's Literary Heritage
Roger Tagholm
176pp, New Holland, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Five minutes after finishing these books, on a winter lunchtime perfect for walking, I was halfway over a pedestrian crossing on my way out of central London when it became clear that the white van in the near distance was not going to stop. The sun caught its high sides as it crested the hill. The van was approaching fast enough to sway a little.

But the road was straight. I was as easy to see as the van was. The driver slowed for a second, and looked at me through his dusty windscreen. His harassed deliveryman's eyes assessed the crossing. And then he accelerated. I had to stand very still to let him past. As he rattled off downhill in a slipstream of litter and exhaust fumes, another pedestrian, who had also been waiting to cross, caught my eye from the safety of the opposite kerb. There was a life of near-misses in his raised eyebrow.

Walking in British cities is a mixed business. In some ways, it is increasingly encouraged, even mildly fashionable. The countryside is gated and poisonous, urban transport is clogged and unreliable; modern architects are in love with pedestrian schemes. Property developers heavily favour the phrase "walking distance". Meanwhile, writers such as Iain Sinclair have made the value of nosing around Britain's brick labyrinths into something close to an orthodoxy. The following manifesto of his from 1997, included in last year's Vintage Book of Walking edited by Duncan Minshull, could today come from an estate agent's catalogue: "Walking is the best way to explore and exploit the city . . . Drifting purposefully is the recommended mode, trampling asphalted earth in alert reverie . . . noticing everything . Alignments of telephone kiosks, maps made from moss on the slopes of Victorian sepulchres . . ."

Yet while some people have been busily rediscovering this sort of pleasure, as old as the city itself, other people - a much greater number - have been driving around in their cars. Traffic in cities is getting heavier and more impatient. Deliveries are more frequent and more urgent. And developers, for all their talk of pedestrians, are still colonising pavements with their hoardings, blocking off river walks with their fortresses of apartments and attaching car parks to everything they can get away with. The air the urban walker breathes is exhaust and brickdust. The ground beneath his or her feet is uneven and ill-maintained. And then there's the dogshit, the trespassing cyclists . . .

If you want to sense the British uncertainty about cities and how to use them - whether we want to be urban Europeans or suburban Americans; whether we can love gasometers and minicab offices as our national landscape as much as we used to love fields of cows - then you could try walking across a regenerated city centre such as Leeds or Hoxton in east London, and be half-murdered by their one-way systems. Or you could stay out of the rain, and read these books. Walking Literary London is the more traditional, and the more pessimistic: it presents the capital as a series of sights, with strolls kept to a minimum. "The roar of traffic gets you down," Tagholm warns early on. His suggested routes twist nervously away from main roads and towards any green space available. He never mentions Sinclair; one of that author's favourite gothic East End flatlands is dismissed as merely "a godforsaken place". The guidebook prefers to spot Dickens landmarks and the "former site of JM Dent Publishers".

Perhaps this is a rational response to the capital's present condition. But it feels a bit cowardly: there is an underground map on the inside cover for when the cracked pavements get too much. London Walking is altogether bolder. Part self-help book, part anti-car polemic, philosophy tract, trendy art spinoff and amateur work of sociology - and a satire, probably, of all of these - it celebrates strolling the same shabby alleys and high streets that Tagholm tries so hard to avoid.

As with many walks, there is a certain amount of faffing around before we set off. The author describes himself as a slippery mixture of artist, lecturer, software designer and "co-founder" of something called "Ice Cream for Everyone", which turns out to be a sort of catering company with manifestos for London art parties. The first few pages of this tiny, heavily designed paperback are so busy with deadpan silliness that you wonder whether it is just a prank. "How to recognise the kerb", "vital advice to consider before you cross a road": the writing is mock-serious and relentlessly flat, with lots of lists and chapters in fragments, in the style of today's trendier young novelists. Pope's frame of reference wants to be cool, too. Hoxton Square and Bar Italia in Soho get namedropped; his bibliography proudly lists every vogueish wanderer's speculation on the capital, from Martin Amis's London Fields to a recent Historical Psychogeographical Report on Notting Hill ; there is much early showing off about "liminal zones" and London's "lived experience".

But beneath the in-jokes, jargon and faux-naïf sketches of paving slabs and which trainers to tread them with - all of which become quite addictive, as if Pope was the obsessive protagonist of some novel - a more universally applicable enthusiasm for snooping emerges. If country ramblers can play at being naturalists, why can't their urban counterparts pretend to be sociologists? Pope suggests judging areas by dropped sweet wrappers, offers tips for looking over fences, and gives droll warnings: "Beware The White Van Bearing Gifts". And then, 90 pages in, he and a friend set out across London.

They start in windswept Canning Town, way out to the east, on a freezing December morning. The idea is to reach west London by nightfall. It is too cold and dark to do anything but set off, so they head into the wind. At first, the scenery seems bleak to Pope's sharp metropolitan eye: "On the south side of the road, a recently built 'call centre'. This could be any other province: Wales, Scotland . . ." Then the cold air, the low sun and the rhythm of feet on concrete begin to intoxicate. His writing loses its jerky cleverness for a calmer forward motion. "We could make it as far as Reading by sunset," Pope declares grandly after stopping for breakfast.

Walking can encourage delusions. The Vintage anthology, which is honest and eclectic enough to include embarrassments, has several examples of Bruce Chatwin at his baggiest, speculating unconvincingly about all people being natural nomads - the hoped-for great theory that the great travel writer endlessly and vainly spent his journeys refining, but never managed to publish. A melancholy extract from the German sociologist Walter Benjamin points out that urban walking, for all its pretensions to free-thinking and independence, is often dependent for points of interest on passing shops, billboards and other traces of the consumer capitalism it claims to spurn. It is noticeable that Pope's route, after its austere start, bends towards "the recently established Nike Town outpost on the Oxford Circus".

But the shop is closed. They walk on, the chill beginning to penetrate, knees beginning to grumble. There are brief ecstasies of defrosting next to hot-air vents, their locations carefully noted in advance. By Shepherd's Bush, Pope is still alert enough to note the black smudges on the underside of the Westway caused by errant footballs from the local all-weather pitches. Then the city turns suburban, and his interest fades: semis rarely have much allure for Sinclair's disciples. Besides, the streets are too looping and long - built for the car. Exhausted, Pope and his friend just make it onto a footbridge with a view back across London. As the sun sets, his gaze traces their route between the city's bland tower blocks; of such small epiphanies are urban walks made.

Striding big distances across damp, dirty cities such as Britain's is probably always going to be a minority occupation. It may be better that way. The columns of heads-down London walkers on tube-strike days, crowding your favourite short cuts, remove the potential for solitude and adventure pretty quickly. Walking, like writing, can be a selfish pleasure. Pope, you may notice, for all his perky advice and pro-pedestrian sloganeering, gives details of only one journey.

webTitle: Stroke leaves Margaret's left side paralysed

fields.headline: Stroke leaves Margaret's left side paralysed
fields.standfirst: Special report: Princess Margaret
fields.trailText: Princess Margaret's left side has been paralysed by her stroke earlier this week, Buckingham Palace confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Princess Margaret's left side has been paralysed by her stroke earlier this week, Buckingham Palace confirmed yesterday.

The 70-year-old, who has had three strokes in three years, suffered her latest attack while in bed in her apartment at Kensington Palace, west London, on Tuesday.

She is receiving physiotherapy and has apparently been visited by a faith healer, but a spokesman said that it may be some time before the extent of her recovery is known.

The palace statement said: "The princess's left side has been affected by her recent minor stroke ... There will be no other bulletins unless there is a further development as Princess Margaret continues to recover."

Contradicting reports that the princess was listless and had given up the will to live, a friend, the novelist Angela Huth, was reported as saying that she had not given up on life.

Ms Huth said: "She is a fighter. We had lunch on Saturday and although she looked fragile she was in very good spirits. The princess talked about the theatre, films and books, and was making plans for the future."

The following year she severely scalded her feet when she stepped into a hot bath, also while on holiday on the island, and has been restricted in her mobility ever since.

Over Christmas she is thought to have suffered another mild stroke either shortly before or while staying with the rest of the royal family at Sandringham, their Norfolk home. Medical experts say that the risk of further strokes is increased with each episode though one suggested yesterday that the princess's family could assist her recovery.

David Cohen, of the Harrow stroke unit at Northwick Park hospital, in north-west London, said: "The patient needs to perform actions and exercises to teach the body how to work again. Relatives can often help with these exercises and encourage the patient to keep at them."

fields.headline: Oxygen struggles for breathing space
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Oxygen, the internet incubator that floated at the height of the dot.com boom, yesterday said it was down to its last £600,000 and "evolving its strategy" to cope with the downturn in the technology sector.
fields.body:
Oxygen, the internet incubator that floated at the height of the dot.com boom, yesterday said it was down to its last £600,000 and "evolving its strategy" to cope with the downturn in the technology sector.

The London-based firm, whose advisers include media executive Elisabeth Murdoch and PR chief Matthew Freud, insists it has enough cash to last another 15 months and that three of its investments should float later in the year, freeing funds. Shares in the embattled company have fallen from a high of 57.5p to last night's close of 1.275p.

"Oxygen's results reflect the effects of the recent euphoria and subsequent depression in hi-tech stocks," said chairman Michael Edelson, adding that the focus will now be on controlling costs. "We have learnt from our mistakes and have modified our strategy to take into account changing market conditions."

Oxygen emphasised that its strategy continues to be investment in early stage companies. "The focus will also be on companies with a clear path to profit," Edelson said.

The group posted a £4.5m loss for the year to the end of September. Investments sold during the period generated proceeds of £328,000.

Oxygen, which was set up to provide seed capital and consultancy support to young businesses within the internet, new media and hi-tech sectors, has taken £1.75m in provisions against bad investments. Several start-ups in which Oxygen invested - Toyzone.co.uk, M-Dex and Yellow Turtle - have failed.

The company, which has invested in 14 ventures, has seen three of them float, and Crushguide.com, a website that provides entertainment information on pubs and clubs in London and Paris, expects to join them by mid-May.

fields.headline: Taxpayer stumps up £1.5bn for rail
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government is to give Railtrack up to £1.5bn of taxpayers' money by next week to help it to restore the decay of its network exposed after the Hatfield rail crash last October.
fields.body:
The government is to give Railtrack up to £1.5bn of taxpayers' money by next week to help it to restore the decay of its network exposed after the Hatfield rail crash last October.

The money will be given on account by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, from the £15bn already allocated to the industry over the next five years.

The move will form part of a package from the government as a demonstration of its faith in the industry, amid increasing support for the renationalisation of Railtrack.

The prime minister was originally due to reveal the package in what ministers regard as a positive move before the election, but he has been diverted by the foot and mouth epidemic and the announcement may be left to Mr Prescott.

To meet criticism that the money is being thrown at Railtrack without adequate regulation, ministers will insist that the Strategic Rail Authority closely monitor the expenditure. They will insist that the money is spent only on restoring the infrastructure to pre-Hatfield standards.

Railtrack is a private company and is not answerable to ministers. Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, has insisted that the money is not extra to Railtrack's normal requirements agreed with Tom Winsor, the rail regulator. But on previous evidence Railtrack will find it difficult to balance the books.

Ministers will also announce the award of a new 20-year £3.5bn deal with Stagecoach to operate the South West Trains franchise from Waterloo to the west country. Stagecoach has pledged to start introducing a new train fleet within 15 months.

Mr Prescott has also intervened to insist that Great North Eastern Railway and Stagecoach-Virgin should re-submit their bids to modernise the east coast main line between Scotland and King's Cross, London.

fields.headline: Eta threat to tourists
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office yesterday issued a warning to British tourists planning holidays in Spain this year after the armed Basque separatist group Eta threatened holidaymakers.
fields.byline: Giles Tremlett in Madrid and Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
The Foreign Office yesterday issued a warning to British tourists planning holidays in Spain this year after the armed Basque separatist group Eta threatened holidaymakers.

In a communique published by several Basque newspapers, Eta said it would continue its bombing campaign of resort towns and told tourists to stay away or face "undesirable consequences".

The threat came two weeks after a police officer was killed in the Costa Brava resort town of Roses, eastern Spain, when an Eta car bomb exploded outside a hotel.

On the same day police discovered a second car bomb in the coastal resort of Gandia, near Valencia.

Eta's aim is to undermine Spain's tourist industry, the third biggest in the world. Twelve million visitors from Britain are expected this year in addition to the 700,000 Britons who live in the country.

After the Eta statement, the Foreign Office revised its travel advice. It said: "Statistically, the threat to British citizens in Spain remains very low but British nationals, residents and visitors throughout Spain should be aware there is a risk, albeit very small."

A spokesperson said: "We are not telling people not to go but calling people's attention to the small risk."

Judith Watson, a spokesperson for the Association of British Tourist Agents, said Eta had been around for 40 years and "fortunately there have been no serious incidents in volving tourists". She said that although she could not be 100% sure that someone would not be in "the wrong place at the wrong time", the chances of tourists ending up as casualties of terrorism were remote.

Thomson said it "takes the safety of its customers extremely seriously and is currently monitoring the situation closely", but added: "There is no reason why customers' holidays should be in any way affected. Normal booking conditions for amendments and cancellations apply.

"The only official advice is, as normal, that customers should be alert and report anything suspicious to the police immediately. The advice applies to many destinations."

The tourist trade can be vulnerable to terrorist attack. The Egyptian trade is only now be ginning to recover from a massacre and Turkey too has been hit by threats. A previous Eta campaign to plant bombs on beaches did not deter tourists, according to the industry.

In 1996, a bomb exploded in Reus airport, a resort town in north-eastern Spain, injuring 35 tourists. Most were British.

Half a dozen bombs were also planted on the Costa del Sol and other southern resorts that year, without harming anyone. The next year tourist resorts on the Costa Brava, including Lloret del Mar and Malgrat del Mar, were targeted. Again nobody was harmed. Police have warned that Eta is now preparing its car bombs in France, making resorts in the north of Spain more likely to be targeted.

webTitle: Superclub closed for lax drugs security

fields.headline: Superclub closed for lax drugs security
fields.standfirst:
Detectives claim ecstasy was given away at dance venue which hoped to become the best in the world

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Detectives claim ecstasy was given away at dance venue which hoped to become the best in the world.
fields.body:
An £8m seven floor London "superclub" that opened with hopes of becoming the best dance venue in the world was ordered to close yesterday amid police claims that it has a serious drug problem.

The decision to revoke the music and dance licence of Leicester Square nightclub Home was taken by Westminster city council during an emergency session in which detectives claimed ecstasy was being given away free at the club, and that staff had ignored repeated warnings to tighten up security.

Although class A drug dealing was taking place openly at Home, staff had managed to make only 74 seizures in the past seven months, the police report said. Yet at Heaven, another London nightclub with a smaller capacity, staff had managed 945 seizures over the same period.

The move to close Home, which has a capacity of 2,500, has come 18 months after an opening night attended by Brad Pitt and Whitney Houston, and a publicity blitz which claimed it would take the capital's clubland by storm.

With three dance floors, a private members' bar and restaurant, and boasting "cutting edge modern design with 21st century technological chutzpah", the club hoped to appeal to everyone.

Although there were rumours that Home had not pulled in the crowds it had hoped for, the club had signed major DJs, including Paul Oakenfold and Dope Smugglaz, and had sets broadcast live on Radio 1.

Among the regular guests, however, were undercover officers from Scotland Yard's clubs and vice unit, who were more concerned with the level of drug dealing than the quality of the music.

One ecstasy supplier was arrested by detectives last December, and warning letters were sent to the manager.

Officers gave a talk to security staff on February 8, and returned undercover the following night to find nothing had changed. One dealer had offered the detectives free sample pills. Police were also astonished that only six people had been caught by staff and subsequently arrested for drug possession over the past seven months, even though the club has a closed circuit TV system.

Deputy assistant commissioner Tarique Ghaffur wrote to the council warning that "Home has a serious drug problem and there is no evidence of vigorous or effective security, despite repeated and continuing police advice .. the management seems to have scant regard of their responsibilities to self-police their premises in so far as drugs are concerned".

Chief Inspector Chris Bradford said yesterday: "Our actions should act as a warning to other premises. We are prepared to take every step in our power to solve the problem."

Westminster's licensing sub-committee agreed to revoke the club's licence "in the interests of public safety".

"There was clear evidence of open drug dealing at the club," said Carl Powell, director of planning and transportation. "The decision to revoke the licence was not taken lightly. It was based on unequivocal police evidence and police concern about drug dealers who prey on vulnerable young people."

Although the music and dance licence has been taken away, Home will still be able to serve drinks and food in the private members' area until 11pm.

"Background music can be played, but nothing more," said a council spokesman. "This ban will be rigorously enforced."

The club has 21 days to appeal, and was last night attempting to challenge the revocation through a magistrates court.

Ron McCulloch, the owner of Home, said: "The decision is incredible. The police are making an example of us. We have one of the best records of any club in the country for helping the police do their job and having a hard anti-drugs policy.

"The action is unwarranted in my view. It has jeopardised a significant clubbing venue in the heart of London."

fields.headline: Can women be bishops?
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: For some, the possibility of women bishops in the Church of England is to be resisted. For others, it would be a natural progression from women's ordination, first as deacons and then as priests.
fields.body:
For some, the possibility of women bishops in the Church of England is to be resisted. For others, it would be a natural progression from women's ordination, first as deacons and then as priests.

Last year, General Synod called on the House of Bishops to initiate further theological study on the episcopate in preparation for a debate on the ordination of women as bishops. The resulting working party, which I am to chair, will report during 2002. But what are the theological issues with which we have to grapple?

In at least some of the early churches, the bishop emerged as a presiding-presbyter from a council of presbyters. If such is the case, the order of bishops cannot be seen as an entirely different order from that of priests, the presbyterate. The argument that there are "no theological reasons against the ordination of women to the priesthood" would also hold for their ordination as bishops.

The same would then be true of all the reasons given for ordaining women to the priesthood. Lord Runcie, when Archbishop of Canterbury, said the incarnation involves solidarity with the whole human race for, "what he did not become, he did not save". The humanity of the Risen and Glorified Lord, moreover, is a humanity that includes all believers; people of every race and both genders. Because of this, the ministerial priesthood, which represents not only the Church but also Christ as Head and High Priest, should also be inclusive. If bishops are seen as presiding presbyters, such an argument would be true of episcopal ministry as well.

There is, however, another tradition in the Church which sees bishops not so much as presidents of a college but as successors, even if in a limited way, of the apostles themselves. While the western churches seem to have been mainly "presbyteral", the churches of south western Asia appear to have been "episcopal" from the start. Ignatius certainly regarded the episcopate (along with the presbyterate and diaconate) as essential to the Church and he also thought of it as already universal. Scholars, such as Bishop Charles Gore, have suggested that before a localised episcopate emerged in the "presbyteral" churches, there were peripatetic apostolic figures - prophets and teachers - exercising oversight, even in relation to the council of presbyters. Eventually, their ministry became localised in the person of the bishop, who may also have been the presiding-presbyter.

Such a derivation of episcopal order may require that discussion about the ordination of women bishops in volves more than a repetition of the arguments for their ordination to the priesthood. Should apostolic, teaching and prophetic ministry be as inclusive as presbyteral and pastoral ministry?

Certainly, the argument that any ministry that claims to represent the Risen and Ascended Lord must be inclusive appears to hold in this case also. Are there indications, however, to support such a conclusion in an admittedly patriarchal tradition?

There are "apostolic" women in the New Testament itself. Tradition refers to Mary Magdalene as "the apostle to the apostles" because she took news of the Resurrection to them. The feminist theologian, Elisabeth Schussler Fiorenza, speaks of the missionary couples mentioned in the Acts of the Apostles and in the Pauline epistles. Later, there are accounts of women like Thecla, commissioned by the apostles themselves to preach the word of God. The "House Churches" were important centres in early Christianity, and the New Testament specifically refers to the role of women in their leadership.

The Acts of the Apostles refers to women prophets and in 1 Corinthians the apostle Paul attempts to regulate the activities of women prophets, though not to prevent them. Charles Gore tells us that just as there were "prophetesses" in the apostolic Church, so there were in the 2nd and 3rd centuries. Gore himself derives the episcopal office from the ministries of apostles, teachers and prophets.

In delegating their oversight to priests, are bishops delegating only the pastoral task, or are the apostolic, teaching and prophetic tasks also delegated? The ordination service makes it clear that the latter are included. If women priests can be delegated these aspects of the episcopal office, why should they not exercise them in their own right? In a divided Church, and with disagreement within the Anglican Communion, there are practical difficulties. Dr Carey pointed out, when Bishop of Bath and Wells, that if women bishops are not recognised throughout the Communion, or within a province, this would place strains on episcopal collegiality.

With some Anglican provinces not recognising the orders of women priests, the difficulty becomes even more acute in the case of women bishops. Some will not recognise the orders of both men and women ordained by them. There will be repercussions, too, on links between dioceses and provinces. Dr Carey recognises that communion is impaired in these cases, but then asks if it is not more impaired by excluding women.

A bishop is also a focus of unity in the local church. Those unable to recognise a woman as bishop would feel excluded. In particular, some priests will feel they cannot belong to a college with a woman as its head. Some, clergy and lay, who disagree with the ordination of women priests, feel they can still join in church life because the bishop remains male. With women bishops, they would be further marginalised.

Ecumenically, too, there would be serious consequences. At present, mostly male Anglican bishops can meet with their Roman Catholic and Orthodox counterparts. If more Anglican provinces open the episcopate to women, agreements made in recent years may be jeopardised. Models of unity that see a gradual "growing together" as a way forward may be halted and some developments perhaps reversed.

The Church of England will have to decide whether or not the theological arguments for inclusivity are so great that the difficulties produced by the ordination of women bishops will have to be tolerated. Some will argue that such a price has to be paid if theological integrity demands it. Others may mourn the passing of an ecumenical age.

 The Rt Rev Dr Michael Nazir-Ali is Bishop of Rochester

In delegating their oversight to priests, are bishops delegating only the pastoral task, or are the apostolic, teaching and prophetic tasks also delegated? The ordination service makes it clear that the latter are included. If women priests can be delegated these aspects of the episcopal office, why should they not exercise them in their own right? In a divided Church, and with disagreement within the Anglican Communion, there are practical difficulties. Dr Carey pointed out, when Bishop of Bath and Wells, that if women bishops are not recognised throughout the Communion, or within a province, this would place strains on episcopal collegiality. With some Anglican provinces not recognising the orders of women priests, the difficulty becomes even more acute in the case of women bishops. Some will not recognise the orders of both men and women ordained by them. There will be repercussions, too, on links between dioceses and provinces. Dr Carey recognises that communion is impaired in these cases, but then asks if it is not more impaired by excluding women. A bishop is also a focus of unity in the local church. Those unable to recognise a woman as bishop would feel excluded. In particular, some priests will feel they cannot belong to a college with a woman as its head. Some, clergy and lay, who disagree with the ordination of women priests, feel they can still join in church life because the bishop remains male. With women bishops, they would be further marginalised. Ecumenically, too, there would be serious consequences. At present, mostly male Anglican bishops can meet with their Roman Catholic and Orthodox counterparts. If more Anglican provinces open the episcopate to women, agreements made in recent years may be jeopardised. Models of unity that see a gradual "growing together" as a way forward may be halted and some developments perhaps reversed. The Church of England will have to decide whether or not the theological arguments for inclusivity are so great that the difficulties produced by the ordination of women bishops will have to be tolerated. Some will argue that such a price has to be paid if theological integrity demands it. Others may mourn the passing of an ecumenical age.  The Rt Rev Dr Michael Nazir-Ali is Bishop of Rochester

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Royal Navy rescues Rosyth | British Bio pays directors £5m | Napp fined for drug discount
fields.body:
Royal Navy rescues Rosyth

Hopes for the future of the Royal Navy dockyard at Rosyth, Fife, were given a big boost with the announcement of a £75m contract to refit five type 23 frigates. Defence secretary Geoff Hoon said the deal would secure work for the next four years.

The announcement was welcomed by union leaders, who last month claimed there were plans to run down the yard. They said the owner, Babcock, was willing to cut Rosyth's workload in return for securing the Ministry of Defence contract to run the Faslane submarine base on the Clyde.

British Bio pays directors £5m

Struggling drug development firm British Biotech spent £5m on directors' pay last year, including £552,000 for chief executive Elliot Goldstein.

Retiring development director Peder Jensen was awarded £400,000 for loss of office, while departing research chief Alan Drummond received £192,000.

The firm made a pretax loss of £25.4m last year.

Napp fined for drug discount

Napp Pharmaceuticals was fined £3.2m in a ruling by the office of fair trading.

Cambridge-based Napp was accused of supplying a morphine product to patients at excessively high prices while discounting the product for hospitals in a way that blocked competition.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers described the ruling as an "important milestone in UK competition history".

Champion performance

The owner of Leeds United football club last night reported a 67% jump in half-year turnover after the team's strong performance in the European Champions League.

Leeds Sporting said operating profit had more than doubled to £6.2m, but pretax profits fell from £5m to £95,000 owing to fewer sales of players.

Chairman Peter Ridsdale said player wages remained under strict control and represented 46.4% of sales. Shares climbed 6% to 12p.

webTitle: Lloyds TSB claims round one of bid hearing

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB claims round one of bid hearing
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB yesterday scored a points victory in the latest round of its hostile £18bn takeover bid for Abbey National.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB yesterday scored a points victory in the latest round of its hostile £18bn takeover bid for Abbey National in front of an unprecedented public hearing called by the government's competition watchdog.

The two banks, plus representatives from unions, customers, small businesses and shareholders, packed a London hotel to debate the takeover, watched closely by inquiry chairman Denise Kingsmill, who will advise trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers whether the deal should go ahead.

Lloyds TSB deputy chief executive Mike Fairey opened the hearing by attacking Abbey National's claim that it is a credible independent "fifth force" in banking. He said Abbey had lost market share amid intense competition, and claims about barriers put in the way of current account customers switching banks were nonsense, with 90% of Lloyds customers satisfied with its service.

Abbey National chief executive Ian Harley countered that the "big four" banks created "considerable barriers" to switching. He added that Abbey was an attractive alternative to the big four, had doubled its customer base since 1989 and not cut total branch numbers in the past 10 years.

Lloyds TSB executives were jubilant after Professor David Llewellyn of Loughborough University, an independent banking expert called in by the competition commission, appeared to endorse the Lloyds TSB bid. The internet and outsourcing has cut barriers to entry and brought a rash of new players into the market, he said.

"Scale is becoming less significant in retail financial services simply because you can buy it in ... the public policy concern about mergers is correspondingly less," he said in comments widely supported by City analysts at the hearing.

Lloyds TSB also won support from rival First Direct. Its chairman, David Mills, told the hearing: "We have grown purely on switches and have not had any problems on that front. Indeed, we find that other banks are more efficient than Abbey National at switching people."

Staff unions clashed at the hearing, with the Abbey National Staff Association claiming that Lloyds TSB's forecast of 9,000 jobs cuts was a "gross underestimate". Compulsory redundancies and 600-plus branch closures would take the true figure to 20,000, akin to job cuts at Corus.

The Lloyds TSB staff union said it supported the merger and had negotiated "robust" job security and severance terms. Branch closure claims were a "serious misrepresentation" and projected job losses "bear no comparison with jobs losses in the steel or car industry."

The clash continued at a briefing given by Mr Fairey. Abbey's claim that branch numbers had been steady for 10 years was "disingenuous" because it shut 40% of National & Provincial's network after taking it over. He also queried Abbey's claims of business growth. "On current accounts they have been losing share for two or three years. This is not a business that is growing and firing on all fronts."

An Abbey spokesman retorted: "We are surprised they raised these issues after the meeting. If they had something to say, they could have said it in the public hearing."

fields.headline: Bonus bonanza - then bust
fields.standfirst: EuroTelecom directors benefited by extra £150,000 weeks before firm collapsed
fields.trailText: EuroTelecom directors benefited by extra £150,000 weeks before firm collapsed.
fields.body:
Three executive directors of EuroTelecom were awarded bonuses totalling £150,000 weeks before it called in the receivers, an independent report claims.

Fees amounting to £164,000 were also paid to companies related to directors including the chief executive, Phil Derry, and finance director, David Linell, accountants BDO Stoy Hayward say in documents lodged with the high court in Leeds.

BDO, which was called in by the board after non-executive directors of the fibre optics company became alarmed at the rate at which the company was spending money, also found £50,000 worth of company credit card bills had been paid "for which no supporting invoices have been received by the accounts department".

The accountants discovered that two months after it floated, EuroTelecom received "a final warning" from the in land revenue over £280,000 of unpaid PAYE and national insurance payments. The debt was cleared seven days later and the bonuses have been partially repaid.

EuroTelecom collapsed in February, 11 months after raising £15m through an AIM flotation, provoking a Stock Exchange investigation and fury among shareholders.

The DTI is also understood to be looking into the circumstances surrounding EuroTelecom's collapse and there may be a further investigation into dealings in the company's shares.

EuroTelecom's failure has been an embarrassment to two high profile non-executive directors of the firm - the entrepreneurs Chris Akers and Amanda Staveley - as well Beeson Gregory, the well-known stockbroking firm that co-ordinated the float.

Mr Akers and Ms Staveley are thought to have been involved in a series of rows with Mr Derry and Mr Linell in the months preceding the collapse and they are battling hard to restore their reputations.

The BDO report paints a damning picture of the way the firm was managed and its lack of clear financial records.

It discloses that on November 6, 2000 three cheques of £50,000 were made out and entered in the cash book as "directors' bonuses in favour of" Mr Derry, Mr Linell and another director, Andy Krawchuk.

Less than two months later, BDO's investigation concluded: "In the absence of new external funding lines being obtained by the business, it is considered unlikely that the EuroTelecom Group will be able to meet its debts as and when they fall.

"This represents a serious situation facing the directors for EuroTelecom and one which needs a considered and detailed response to avoid the insolvency of the EuroTelecom group in its entirety."

Mr Derry claimed the bonuses were due to the three directors as part of "a verbal agreement that was never fully documented" on the completion of an important contract. They claim that EuroTelecom would never have collapsed had a company controlled by Ms Staveley paid up a debt. The payment remains a point of dispute.

Non-executive directors are understood to have been furious when they discovered the bonuses had been awarded at a time when the company was struggling.

Mr Krawchuk asked for his £50,000 cheque to be cancelled and, after a meeting of the remuneration committee, Mr Derry said he and Mr Linell agreed to repay their bonuses.

BDO's report also shows that RL & Associates, an accountancy firm which had worked for EuroTelecom for five years and where Mr Linell is a director, received a £75,000 payment from EuroTelecom "for which no supporting invoices have yet been received".

In the year to June 30, 2000, RL & Associates received £273,000 for professional fees.

Mr Linell could not be reached for comment but Mr Derry said the payments were cleared by the board and related to the handling the EuroTelecom flotation and accountancy fees.

Co-Ordinated Development Through Leisure, a company which rents a property in Wales from Mr Derry, was paid £29,000 as part of a retainer agreement with EuroTelecom which "may require disclosure", BDO said.

Mr Derry said the arrangement had been endorsed by the board and was declared in the flotation prospectus. "We have acted completely honestly," he said.

webTitle: Hampel falls foul of US boardroom rules

fields.headline: Hampel falls foul of US boardroom rules
fields.trailText: Sir Ronald Hampel, who led an official report into corporate governance in Britain, has been reported for failing to meet boardroom standards in the US.
fields.body:
Sir Ronald Hampel, who led an official report into corporate governance in Britain, has been reported for failing to meet boardroom standards in the US.

The author of the 1998 Hampel report attended just 60% of last year's board meetings at Alcoa, the US aluminium group where he is a non-executive director.

Under boardroom regulations set by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the US, companies must report any director who failed to attend more than 75% of its meetings. Sir Ronald was the only one of 11 board members who failed to meet the standards, according to the company's 2001 proxy statement and a report in Global Proxy Watch, a weekly newsletter on corporate governance.

When told of the report, Sir Ronald, the 68-year-old former head of ICI, said: "I don't know whether to laugh or cry."

He pointed out that he had attended five of the six regular board meetings last year, an attendance that would have avoided any filing. He missed two board meetings that were held over the telephone at short notice to discuss single resolutions, and it is because of this that he failed to satisfy the rule. He also missed one other committee meeting held on the same day as the regular board session he could not attend because of a commitment clash.

"I have never, ever been accused of failing to meet governance standards before," he said. His six-year record at Alcoa suggests a strong attendance until last year.

His corporate governance report urged non-executive directors to take a more active role in policing corporate behaviour.

Alcoa defended Sir Ronald's record and said it had received no complaints from shareholders as a result of the proxy filing.

fields.headline: Bad business
fields.standfirst:
The end of 68 years of wickedness
Inspectors fear for the fate of report that took ten years
How blue chips failed to tame Captain Bob
The men who made it possible
fields.trailText: • The Department of Trade and Industry criticised Maxwell in 1971, saying he could not be "relied on to exercise a proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company".
fields.body:
 The Department of Trade and Industry criticised Maxwell in 1971, saying he could not be "relied on to exercise a proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company".

 Maxwell bought Mirror Group Newspapers for £113m in 1984

 When MGN needed £34m, in 1986, it was provided by a "loan" from pension funds

 The pension funds were used to buy Maxwell House in Holborn, central London, in 1986

 From May 1989, Maxwell began manipulating the stock market by secretly buying shares in his own companies

 MGN was floated on the London Stock Exchange in 1991, raising £235m

 By 1991 his secret share-buying meant he controlled an extra 8% of MCC, bringing his total holding to 76%

 By October 1991 shares in MGN and Maxwell Communications, and some property, were the Maxwell empire's only substantial assets, and loan repayments were being demanded

 On November 5 1991, Maxwell died by falling off his yacht

The report ceases to document events after the death, except the financial aftermath of the empire's collapse

 Kevin Maxwell was appointed chairman of the empire but had to put the businesses into administration a month later, amid revelations that £450m was missing from the pension funds

 By February 1992 the Serious Fraud Office had five investigations running

 Kevin and Ian Maxwell were arrested in June 1992 but were found not guilty of fraud in January 1996

 A subsequent prosecution alleging that Kevin Maxwell defrauded banks of £100m failed when the judge threw out the charge

 Kevin Maxwell was declared Britain's biggest bankrupt, with debts of more than £400m.

 In March 1999 the high court said he was not guilty of contempt of court, after claims he failed to cooperate with the DTI inquiry. He met the inspectors last August

webTitle: The men who made it possible

fields.headline: The men who made it possible
fields.standfirst:
The end of 68 years of wickedness
Inspectors fear for the fate of report that took ten years
How blue chips failed to tame Captain Bob
Bad business
fields.trailText: Kevin Maxwell
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell

The DTI inspectors describe the conduct of Kevin Maxwell as "inexcusable". He knew that disclosures to bankers and regulators "lacked frankness" and that his father was plundering the Mirror Group's pension funds.

Ian Maxwell

Bears a smaller degree of blame than his brother but, as a board member of many Maxwell companies, he "signed many documents without considering their implications and failed to carry out all the duties he had undertaken as a director".

Now works for a public relations company Westbourne Communications.

Lord Donoughue

Former agriculture minister Lord Donoughue, who was a director of Maxwell's London & Bishopsgate investment company, "ought, as a director, to have ascertained sufficient information about the way Maxwell was moving funds around his business empire". If he had done so, he "might have identified the abuse of funds".

Lord Donoughue, 66, served in Tony Blair's government from 1997 to 1999.

Coopers & Lybrand

Bears a "major responsibility" for failing to report abuses of funds to the trustees of the Mirror Group's pension schemes. Failed to ascertain Mirror Group's management structure ahead of its flotation, and criticised for inadequate audit work.Now part of PricewaterhouseCoopers, which says: "We're quite clear that we fell short and we regret that."

It was fined £3.4m for its conduct in the Maxwell affair. It contributed £60m towards making good the shortfall in pension funds.

Goldman Sachs

As a key financial adviser to Maxwell, the report says the US investment bank bears a "substantial responsibility" for the manipulation of Mirror Group's shares. Eric Sheinberg, a partner who has since retired, is singled out for blame, although the report concludes he was "motivated by the large profits" he could make from Maxwell's share dealing, rather than acting in league with him.

Samuel Montagu

The stockbroker, which sponsored Mirror Group's flotation, failed to ensure that the company was "suitable for listing". It overlooked deficiencies in the firm's financial controls and did not take "reasonable care" in preparing a prospectus for the public offering.

Now part of HSBC, it admitted to inspectors that, "with hindsight", Mirror Group was unsuitable for listing.

Non-executive directors

Sir Robert Clark, Lord Williams of Elwel and Alan Clements are all criticised for failing to stand up to Maxwell. The report says they should have "insisted proper disciplines were applied", pointing out that their presence was used to convey the impression that Mirror Group was a "properly run listed company".

Others

Law firms Clifford Chance and Linklaters are criticised, as are investment banks Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Salomon Brothers, and stockbrokers Smith New Court and Capel Cure Myers. Maxwell's close associates share some of the blame, particularly his finance chief, Robert Bunn. There is criticism of directors of Maxwell's London & Bishopsgate offshoot, including Larry Trachtenberg and Andrew Smith.

If he had done so, he "might have identified the abuse of funds". Lord Donoughue, 66, served in Tony Blair's government from 1997 to 1999. Coopers & Lybrand Bears a "major responsibility" for failing to report abuses of funds to the trustees of the Mirror Group's pension schemes. Failed to ascertain Mirror Group's management structure ahead of its flotation, and criticised for inadequate audit work.Now part of PricewaterhouseCoopers, which says: "We're quite clear that we fell short and we regret that." It was fined £3.4m for its conduct in the Maxwell affair. It contributed £60m towards making good the shortfall in pension funds. Goldman Sachs As a key financial adviser to Maxwell, the report says the US investment bank bears a "substantial responsibility" for the manipulation of Mirror Group's shares. Eric Sheinberg, a partner who has since retired, is singled out for blame, although the report concludes he was "motivated by the large profits" he could make from Maxwell's share dealing, rather than acting in league with him. Samuel Montagu The stockbroker, which sponsored Mirror Group's flotation, failed to ensure that the company was "suitable for listing". It overlooked deficiencies in the firm's financial controls and did not take "reasonable care" in preparing a prospectus for the public offering. Now part of HSBC, it admitted to inspectors that, "with hindsight", Mirror Group was unsuitable for listing. Non-executive directors Sir Robert Clark, Lord Williams of Elwel and Alan Clements are all criticised for failing to stand up to Maxwell. The report says they should have "insisted proper disciplines were applied", pointing out that their presence was used to convey the impression that Mirror Group was a "properly run listed company". Others Law firms Clifford Chance and Linklaters are criticised, as are investment banks Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Salomon Brothers, and stockbrokers Smith New Court and Capel Cure Myers. Maxwell's close associates share some of the blame, particularly his finance chief, Robert Bunn. There is criticism of directors of Maxwell's London & Bishopsgate offshoot, including Larry Trachtenberg and Andrew Smith.

fields.headline: At this price?  Bentalls
fields.trailText: Sales in women's fashion lines, which have proved so difficult for many retailers this year, have been driving growth at Bentalls.
fields.body:
Sales in women's fashion lines, which have proved so difficult for many retailers this year, have been driving growth at Bentalls.

The department store group, which was looking rather bearish a year ago, now appears to be well on the way to recovery.

Bentalls stock yesterday rose 11p to 77.5p on the back of a 9% increase in like-for-like sales in the eight weeks since the end of January, boosted by strong sales in fashion goods. Fashion sales grew by 5.9%, partly due to the introduction of high-profile brands including Max Mara, Nicole Farhi, Joseph and DKNY Collection.

The figures posted by the company all looked strong, with like-for-like sales for the year to the end of January rising 4% from the previous year, underlying operating profits climbing to £2.9m from £2.4m in 1999 and a turnover of £108.2m, compared with £104m for the year before.

"Sales of fashion goods have been particularly strong, supporting the board's view that the company is set on a path of sustainable improvement in its retail performance," said Edward Bentall, the company's chairman.

According to George Elliott, Bentalls' chief executive, sales have risen because the strategy the management team put in place is starting to pay off.

That strategy - which has included extensive surveying of customers - appears to be working. The management team is also strong and the company's financial fortunes have been given a boost.

Bentalls sold its loss-making Bristol store to House of Fraser for £16.35m in January. The sale enabled Bentalls to wipe out its debt and leave £10m in the bank, which will be used to upgrade existing stores.

Analysts are impressed with the management's decisions, the improvements being made to stores and are positive on the stock, which has outperformed the FTSE by 17% in the past year. Buy.

fields.headline: Megalomania, the Maxwells and me
fields.standfirst: Corporate lessons to be learned from misgivings about the man behind the mask
fields.trailText: Corporate lessons to be learned from misgivings about the man behind the mask.
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell kept us waiting outside his office for well over an hour. His secretary apologised repeatedly, in a manner suggesting that this happened all the time. At last her boss emerged to shake our hands perfunctorily and to confirm that he was giving Thornton Investment Managers the mandate to manage £10m of the Mirror Group pension fund.

Within 30 seconds he was gone. I'd not met him before and I have not met him since. But I've not forgotten.

A year or so later I took a call from one of Mr Maxwell's staff to tell me that he was withdrawing our mandate as the Mirror had lost confidence in our investment style. I was mortified. Its portfolio's performance had been fine, and 12 months counts as very short term in the world of pension fund management.

It was only as the Mirror Group empire imploded in the aftermath of Robert Maxwell's death that all became clear. When the charges were prepared for the court case in which Kevin and Ian Maxwell were eventually acquitted, one related to improper use of the slice of the Mirror pension fund that my firm had so briefly managed. I've often wondered why we were prepared to take on Mirror's business at the time. Our misgivings went much deeper than Kevin Maxwell's apparent lack of social graces.

The pension fund's administrators, on the Maxwell payroll, chose not to use a custodian bank to hold its investments. Instead they kept all records, and share certificates, themselves. This was a highly unusual arrangement. In retrospect it is easy to see how the fund's assets could be diverted in an attempt to shore up the Maxwell family's crumbling empire.

So why did we make such a monumental misjudgment of character? In part it was to please our chairman, Lord Walker - an appointee of our parent, Dresdner Bank and the source of our introduction to Kevin Maxwell. In part, also, it was the charm of his underlings. But most important, I guess, was a natural desire to further our own business.

I was reminded of these salutary lessons of a decade past by two incidents this week. One, obviously, was the publication of the Department of Trade & Industry report into the conduct of Robert Maxwell's business affairs - no surprises there, on my first swift perusal.

The other was a meeting with colleagues to decide whether or not to take on a potential new corporate client. One of our team expressed concerns about the company's management, but couldn't quite articulate what made him feel uncomfortable. My colleague came under some pressure to explain what for him was essentially a gut feeling. It was easy to see both sides of the debate. A logical examination of the available facts gave one answer; one man's hunch another.

The financial world has been lucky not to be cursed by the cult of celebrity. I bumped into a literary agent this week who insisted that, contrary to charges laid against her profession, the photogenic quality of authors is not a determinant of publishing rosters. "I didn't know what Robert Ludlum looked like until I read his obit."

The same can be said of commerce. Few industrialists are household names - old stagers such as Richard Branson and Anita Roddick, and parvenus such as Hans Snook, are the exceptions.

The same is true of investment managers. Rarely do they make the front pages. One remembers Nicola Horlick storming the Deutsche Bank bastion in Frankfurt, the cross-dressing David Young in the dock, and, this week, the departure of one of the greatest names of British fund management, Carol Galley.

The confinement of professional investors and captains of industry to the financial pages must be a good thing. When their personality transcends their performance then the system is at risk of distortion. This is not a charge that could be levelled at Ms Galley, and it is fitting that she should make headlines only on stepping down.

Fund managers, half-jokingly, cite warning signals of impending megalomania among industrialists - the fountain in the lobby, or the corporate jet. These are unlikely to unearth fraud, however, merely overweening ambition.

A more practical safeguard against megalomania and malpractice is the pressure exerted by investors to ensure that corporate boards are correctly balanced - in particular, that the chairman and chief executive are not the same individual.

Many leading companies continue to re sist this pressure - misguidedly in my view - but the debate alone is a healthy sign that corporate governance is near the top of the agenda for companies and their shareholders alike.

Little can be done, however, to avert sustained, wilful wrongdoing, especially if it is undertaken with intelligence, daring and a complete absence of conscience. Which leaves the whole system critically reliant on character judgments and gut feelings.

So take time out to listen to the rumblings in your stomach.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

fields.headline: Rumour mill grinds Cookson
fields.trailText: With 50% of sales coming from the slowing US economy, Cookson, the electronics and precious metals firm, was under attack from short sellers yesterday on rumours that a profits warning is on the way.
fields.body:
With 50% of sales coming from the slowing US economy, Cookson, the electronics and precious metals firm, was under attack from short sellers yesterday on rumours that a profits warning is on the way.

The speculation coincided with publication of a bearish note from SG Securities and helped drive Cookson's shares 5p lower to 147.5p.

According to traders, the case against Cookson centres on the performance of its electronics division, which supplies chemicals and equipment for printed circuit board makers, mainly in the US. The bears claim demand has fallen sharply since Cookson reported fiscal 2000 results at the end of February.

In its note, SG Securities made the same point. Citing concerns about the division, it cut its profits forecast by £45 to £132m and said Cookson's annual meeting statement on April 26 would highlight the tough conditions facing the group.

Cookson was not the only company to suffer from an association with the US.

Chemicals specialist ICI dipped 19.5p to 429p as word spread that first-quarter figures could fall significantly short of expectations. Apparently US sales slowed dramatically in March.

The City's top ICI watcher, Martin Evans of broker Credit Lyonnais, said he would not be surprised if the figures, due on May 3, reflected a difficult trading period. "We are likely to see profit downgrades in the meantime."

Glass manufacturer Pilkington slid 7p to 106p on news that two of North America's biggest automotive parts suppliers, Delphi Automotive and Federal-Mogul, had warned on profits. Dealers said the warnings had unsettled Pilkington because of its exposure to the car windscreen market.

Window dressing by City institutions anxious to add strong performers to their portfolios, combined with a 30-point spike in the closing auction process, helped leading shares end an otherwise bleak quarter on a positive note.

With drugs firms GlaxoSmithKline (48p better at £18.41) and AstraZeneca (116p stronger at £33.60) spearheading the advance, the FTSE 100 closed up 45.3 points at 5,633.7. Although dealers were encouraged by the FTSE's performance - it managed to climb 195.7 points over the week - they were not getting too excited. After all, the blue chip index had just posted a 9.5% decline in the first quarter.

Things were still grim in new economy, too, the FTSE Techmark 100 falling 15.64 points to 1,927.58, taking its loss for the quarter to 25%.

Software and telecom stocks were again the market's laggards.

A weak opening by the Nasdaq in New York was responsible for CMG dipping 38.5p to 599.5p and Sage surrendering 8p to 247p.

Downgrades from Morgan Stanley and Schroder Salomon hit telecoms equipment maker Marconi, off 15p to 340p, while Energis, down 16.5p to 279p, was rocked by reports that the heir to the Saudi throne, Crown Prince Abdullah, is considering selling all or part of his 2.35% stake.

Lower down, the picture was noticeably brighter, with Carphone Warehouse moving forward 11.5p to 133p on the back of a UBS Warburg upgrade and directors' share buying. Chief executive Charles Dunstone picked up £250,000 worth of shares and operating officer David Ross £200,000.

Money broker Garban Intercapital was also helped by director share-buying, as chief executive Michael Spencer revealed he had snapped up 15,000 for a cool £65,000. Garban closed 19p higher at 477.5p.

Meanwhile, rekindled management buyout speculation hoisted leisure conglomerate Rank to 183.75p, up 13.25p.

In the smaller company world European Telecom gained 13p, or 70%, to 31.5p as stock overhang was finally cleared.

fields.headline: Regus unfettered in US
fields.trailText: The short sellers who have helped to wipe £400m off the value of Mark Dixon's 61% stake in Regus may not want to hear it but demand for serviced office space continues to be strong.
fields.body:
The short sellers who have helped to wipe £400m off the value of Mark Dixon's 61% stake in Regus may not want to hear it but demand for serviced office space continues to be strong.

Feedback from a series of end-quarter meetings with analysts suggests Regus is not seeing any signs of a general slowdown in the US, with inquiries up and prices being maintained.

Fears about the US have been responsible for the recent weakness in Regus's share price. Although Regus has only 18% of its business in North America, it plans to increase that figure to 50% in the next two years.

Apart from a few areas - south-west California and Austin, Texas - that market is said to be performing well.

Several brokers including Deutsche Bank say the recent weakness provides an excellent buying opportunity. Regus closed 8.5p higher at 275.5p yesterday.

fields.headline: Oh so pretty blatant
fields.standfirst: Stephen Marks, chairman and chief executive, French Connection
fields.trailText: Interview with Stephen Marks, chairman and chief executive, French Connection
fields.body:
Stephen Marks is making a fortune out of the f-word. Not the expletive, but "fcuk" - a clever and coincidental trademark and anagram. He has plastered the country with the nudge-nudge four letter logo on adverts as controversial, and publicity-generating, as Benetton in its heyday. The logo is a masterpiece of branding that has helped transform the 25-year-old French Connection from just another shop to an international name.

The naughty label has not done all the work - the clothes are suitably edgy and spot-on their target market in quality and price, while the stores are light, bright and sharp. But the f-word has more than done its job.

Since 1997, when the first fcuk campaign was launched, French Connection's profits have soared from £6.4m to £19m and its share price has rocketed from around 300p to 775p. Mr Marks' 61% stake in the company is now worth some £90m.

The fcuk brand was dreamed up in-house. The company used to send faxes back and forth between its London and Hong Kong offices using the abbreviations FCUK and FCHK. "There was no thought of it being rude," insists Mr Marks, but advertising executive Trevor Beattie picked up on the abbreviation and came up with the "fcuk fashion" slogan.

"I thought it was bloody marvellous," say Mr Marks. "We didn't even have an advertising budget at that time, but within four weeks we had the posters up and the rest is history."

The hidden expletive has caused a good deal of huffing and puffing from self-appointed moral guardians and advertising watchdogs. The latest run-in with the authorities, last month, centred on the "fcukinkybugger" campaign, which Mr Marks had hoped to put on TV.

The ads feature a couple peeling off their clothes and use straplines like "full frontal collision until knackered" and "forefinger carefully undoing kecks".

The advertising watchdogs were having none of it. Not only did the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre, which vets TV commercials, highlight the "unacceptable level of innuendo," it also went on to say it was shocked the company "had the gall to send the script in".

Resultant publicity probably caused almost as much of a furore as the advert would have generated and it is running on the company website, with useful pointers in the shop windows for anyone in need of a bit of forbidden titillation.

Mr Marks - casual in jeans, fleece and leather and with a trim beard - feigns surprise at the reaction. "It sounds crazy, but it wasn't the intention to push the limits of acceptability. To us (the phrase) kinky bugger is the same as cheeky monkey. Had I thought about it meaning anal sex I wouldn't have done it. In retrospect we should have changed it."

That doesn't reconcile with his other, more strident, views about his advertising. "If people think that sex doesn't sell then they are living in the stone age. My audience is 18-30s and I'm not upsetting them."

Indeed not. He has sold 1m T-shirts emblazoned "fcuk" at £20 a throw. "The people I am upsetting are not my customers," he adds. "Take Lynda Lee-Potter. She said she would never wear any of our clothes again. Well I say: 'Thank God for that'."

Is he not concerned about parents facing awkward questions from their children about the more raunchy billboards? "That's their problem. I'm pushing my clothes. My daughter is six and is learning to read. She thinks it says F-cuck".

'The Hotpants King'

Born and brought up in Harrow in north London, Mr Marks, now 54, has spent most of his life in the rag trade. Had he been born a few years later it could all have been so different. His first love was tennis and in 1964 he won the plate at Junior Wimbledon. But the game was still amateur, "and I had to earn a living, so I went to work for a coat manufacturer. They gave me the most wonderful training, although I didn't realise it at the time, learning about everything from cloth buying to designing."

He joined Louis Feraud to launch a Miss Feraud label. When the collection succeeded he was offered a directorship. "I asked if that meant I got a share of the company and they said: 'No, you just get called a director.' That made me very depressed, because I wanted to get on in life. I didn't care what I was called."

A friend, who was willing to provide backing, suggested he go it alone. His first success was with an unforgettable fad.

"I was in Paris and saw some hotpants. I came back to London, had some run up and showed them to a buyer at Miss Selfridge. She took 36 pairs and sold them all in a day. She came back for 2,000 pairs and I became the Hotpants King."

His next venture was his own label, making coats and suits. By year three he was racking up sales of £700,000 "and I thought I must be doing something right here".

In 1972, he volunteered to go to Hong Kong to sort out a business problem for a friend. "Once I saw Hong Kong I realised the potential of the far east. It was like a shining light in terms of price and quality. And so French Connection was born."

His first order was for cheesecloth shirts. "I ordered half long-sleeved and half short-sleeved. When they arrived they were a lovely black, white and red - but they all had one short sleeve and one long. But we cut off all the long sleeves and they sold out."

His first shop, in London's Walton Street, stocked cane furniture and cheesecloth and was called Cane. The second, in South Molton Street, was called Friends. French Connection - a name "thought up in a car parked at the back of the Palladium" - started trading in the late 1970s with one outlet inside Top Shop.

Today French Connection has 65 UK stores, plus an equal number of concessions in larger stores, and 25 in the US. Mr Marks believes there is potential for 300 in the US and will soon open his first outlet in Japan.

French Connection is not his only fashion interest. At the top end of the market he also controls the Nicole Farhi label. In the 1970s Mr Marks and Ms Farhi were an item. But "she was always criticising my designs and saying she could do better. So in the end I said 'bloody get on with it then', and she did."

The couple had a baby - a daughter now aged 25 - "but after 15 years we went our separate ways". They still work together - he masterminds the development of her brand and her stores, including a New York store and a new one being planned for San Francisco - and they get on "just like we always did".

He is now married with two young children, and another due in May, to Alisa, a former Elle fashion editor who now works at French Connection's headquarters in the heart of the West End rag trade, north of Oxford Street.

Even some of his pastimes are profitable. With a friend he put up £600,000 to co-finance the Guy Ritchie movie Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. He then backed its sequel, Snatch.

The company is producing growth - sales up 24% last year - and is planning a new fragrance, a range of homewares and - it is a surprise he hasn't done it before - an Fcuk condom.

Marks & Spencer can only dream of such performance. Mr Marks says he doesn't like to criticise anyone in the fashion business. He makes an exception for the ailing M&S. "They need a revolution and someone who understands product."

Much of the problem, he fears, comes from lack of leadership. "In other companies, people are more interested in their titles and where they sit than what is in the shop. If you are not passionate, why bother? I love what I do and we do the best we can. But then I'm not your normal businessman."
