"There was no thought of it being rude," insists Mr Marks, but advertising executive Trevor Beattie picked up on the abbreviation and came up with the "fcuk fashion" slogan. "I thought it was bloody marvellous," say Mr Marks. "We didn't even have an advertising budget at that time, but within four weeks we had the posters up and the rest is history." The hidden expletive has caused a good deal of huffing and puffing from self-appointed moral guardians and advertising watchdogs. The latest run-in with the authorities, last month, centred on the "fcukinkybugger" campaign, which Mr Marks had hoped to put on TV. The ads feature a couple peeling off their clothes and use straplines like "full frontal collision until knackered" and "forefinger carefully undoing kecks". The advertising watchdogs were having none of it. Not only did the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre, which vets TV commercials, highlight the "unacceptable level of innuendo," it also went on to say it was shocked the company "had the gall to send the script in". Resultant publicity probably caused almost as much of a furore as the advert would have generated and it is running on the company website, with useful pointers in the shop windows for anyone in need of a bit of forbidden titillation. Mr Marks - casual in jeans, fleece and leather and with a trim beard - feigns surprise at the reaction. "It sounds crazy, but it wasn't the intention to push the limits of acceptability. To us (the phrase) kinky bugger is the same as cheeky monkey. Had I thought about it meaning anal sex I wouldn't have done it. In retrospect we should have changed it." That doesn't reconcile with his other, more strident, views about his advertising. "If people think that sex doesn't sell then they are living in the stone age. My audience is 18-30s and I'm not upsetting them." Indeed not. He has sold 1m T-shirts emblazoned "fcuk" at £20 a throw. "The people I am upsetting are not my customers," he adds. "Take Lynda Lee-Potter. She said she would never wear any of our clothes again. Well I say: 'Thank God for that'." Is he not concerned about parents facing awkward questions from their children about the more raunchy billboards? "That's their problem. I'm pushing my clothes. My daughter is six and is learning to read. She thinks it says F-cuck". 'The Hotpants King' Born and brought up in Harrow in north London, Mr Marks, now 54, has spent most of his life in the rag trade. Had he been born a few years later it could all have been so different. His first love was tennis and in 1964 he won the plate at Junior Wimbledon. But the game was still amateur, "and I had to earn a living, so I went to work for a coat manufacturer. They gave me the most wonderful training, although I didn't realise it at the time, learning about everything from cloth buying to designing." He joined Louis Feraud to launch a Miss Feraud label. When the collection succeeded he was offered a directorship. "I asked if that meant I got a share of the company and they said: 'No, you just get called a director.' That made me very depressed, because I wanted to get on in life. I didn't care what I was called." A friend, who was willing to provide backing, suggested he go it alone. His first success was with an unforgettable fad. "I was in Paris and saw some hotpants. I came back to London, had some run up and showed them to a buyer at Miss Selfridge. She took 36 pairs and sold them all in a day. She came back for 2,000 pairs and I became the Hotpants King." His next venture was his own label, making coats and suits. By year three he was racking up sales of £700,000 "and I thought I must be doing something right here". In 1972, he volunteered to go to Hong Kong to sort out a business problem for a friend. "Once I saw Hong Kong I realised the potential of the far east. It was like a shining light in terms of price and quality. And so French Connection was born." His first order was for cheesecloth shirts. "I ordered half long-sleeved and half short-sleeved. When they arrived they were a lovely black, white and red - but they all had one short sleeve and one long. But we cut off all the long sleeves and they sold out." His first shop, in London's Walton Street, stocked cane furniture and cheesecloth and was called Cane. The second, in South Molton Street, was called Friends. French Connection - a name "thought up in a car parked at the back of the Palladium" - started trading in the late 1970s with one outlet inside Top Shop. Today French Connection has 65 UK stores, plus an equal number of concessions in larger stores, and 25 in the US. Mr Marks believes there is potential for 300 in the US and will soon open his first outlet in Japan. French Connection is not his only fashion interest. At the top end of the market he also controls the Nicole Farhi label. In the 1970s Mr Marks and Ms Farhi were an item. But "she was always criticising my designs and saying she could do better. So in the end I said 'bloody get on with it then', and she did." The couple had a baby - a daughter now aged 25 - "but after 15 years we went our separate ways". They still work together - he masterminds the development of her brand and her stores, including a New York store and a new one being planned for San Francisco - and they get on "just like we always did". He is now married with two young children, and another due in May, to Alisa, a former Elle fashion editor who now works at French Connection's headquarters in the heart of the West End rag trade, north of Oxford Street. Even some of his pastimes are profitable. With a friend he put up £600,000 to co-finance the Guy Ritchie movie Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. He then backed its sequel, Snatch. The company is producing growth - sales up 24% last year - and is planning a new fragrance, a range of homewares and - it is a surprise he hasn't done it before - an Fcuk condom. Marks & Spencer can only dream of such performance. Mr Marks says he doesn't like to criticise anyone in the fashion business. He makes an exception for the ailing M&S. "They need a revolution and someone who understands product." Much of the problem, he fears, comes from lack of leadership. "In other companies, people are more interested in their titles and where they sit than what is in the shop. If you are not passionate, why bother? I love what I do and we do the best we can. But then I'm not your normal businessman."

webTitle: Viacom grabs a chunk of Robot Wars

fields.headline: Viacom grabs a chunk of Robot Wars
fields.trailText: Television Corporation, the sport and entertainment production house, yesterday landed a potentially lucrative contract with Viacom that will lead to cult programme, Robot Wars, being shown on three of the US group's TV channels.
fields.body:
Television Corporation, the sport and entertainment production house, yesterday landed a potentially lucrative contract with Viacom that will lead to cult programme, Robot Wars, being shown on three of the US group's TV channels.

Financial details of the deal, which gives Television Corporation a share of the sales of programme-related merchandising in the US, were not disclosed but chief executive Chris Rowlands said it should generate significant income.

Robot Wars, which involves amateur mechanics building robots that smash each other to pieces, attracts more than 5m viewers each week on BBC2.

The BBC has commissioned 64 new shows and several old episodes will be aired in the US as part of the arrangement.

This week Television Corporation secured a £10m contract with Sky Sports to provide the broadcast facilities for more than 100 Premier League football games each season.

Two-thirds of the company's revenue comes from content production, including Channel 4's cricket coverage. This season it will introduce a gadget based on missile-tracking technology developed by Siemens that claims to determine whether a batsman is out LBW.

Turnover for the year ended December rose 37% to £44m and profit before goodwill was up 35% to £5.89m. The dividend rises from 4.5p to 4.8p. Shares slipped 0.5p to 419.5p.

fields.headline: Postal strike will hit City
fields.trailText: City banks and businesses face serious disruption early next week when postal workers stage a 24-hour strike at a main east London sorting office over management plans to introduce a streamlined system across the country.
fields.body:
City banks and businesses face serious disruption early next week when postal workers stage a 24-hour strike at a main east London sorting office over management plans to introduce a streamlined system across the country.

The strike at the eastern district office in Whitechapel is the latest in a series of disputes, many of them unofficial, to dog the Post Office, rebranding as Consignia, as it seeks greater efficiency and a better customer service in the run-up to competition in delivering mail. Consignia stoppages account for more than half the days lost through industrial action in the whole of Britain.

The east London dispute, involving 634 staff and approved in a ballot by 187-121, will deprive big financial institutions and companies, including national media operations in Canary Wharf and other parts of the City, of mail for 24 hours from Monday afternoon.

Consignia officials, "alarmed and shocked" by the threat of more action, insisted they had not been given the statutory seven days' notice and expressed hope that the strike would not go ahead. They see it as a gift to potential rival operators.

Postal workers accused "bullying" management of imposing a system known as "simplified sorting" without consultation in an effort to meet performance targets. The system reduces the number of sections or roads to give a greater geographical spread.

The anonymous staff who contacted the Guardian said the new system would be rolled out across Britain and would simply transfer the bulk of work further down the line to smaller sorting offices. "The management is using the threat of competition - which doesn't exist - to ram through change," one said.

Consumer bodies are pressing Consignia to get a grip on its industrial relations problems or risk losing hundreds of thousands of customers when genuine competition, launched earlier this week, gets under way. They want the corporation to scrap outmoded practices, including the second daily delivery, in a new cost-cutting drive.

Consignia officials said the east London dispute involved national plans agreed by the postal workers union, the CWU, and by a ballot. The plans, known as the Way Forward, are designed to offset a shorter working week and increased basic pay with greater efficiency and productivity.

"We are not going to be deflected. A deal has been struck and we will go ahead and implement it," they said. "We are going to honour our side of the bargain and the union should honour its side of the deal. We have to become more customer-orientated, more competitive; we're getting the business into shape to face competitors."

Consignia lost its monopoly over mail costing less than £1 this week and could see its overall monopoly on mail weighing 350 grammes or less reduced to 50g or even 20g. "Competitors are watching to see where they can step in and say industrial action is disrupting services to consumers."

The CWU, according to some consumer bodies, has lost control of its members - as witnessed by a spate of wildcat strikes the union leadership has haplessly condemned. The CWU, which was unavailable for comment, wants the government to impose an independent arbitrator over the disputes.

webTitle: How blue chips failed to tame Captain Bob

fields.headline: How blue chips failed to tame Captain Bob
fields.standfirst:
'Bully' threw his weight around from day one

The end of 68 years of wickedness
Inspectors fear for the fate of report that took ten years
Bad business
The men who made it possible
fields.trailText: Within minutes of taking ownership of Mirror Group Newspapers in 1984, Robert Maxwell made it clear who was boss
fields.body:
Within minutes of taking ownership of Mirror Group Newspapers in 1984, Robert Maxwell made it clear who was boss. The Czech-born farm labourer's son arrived at the company's offices at midnight and convened a board meeting at 2.45am.

At that meeting, he demanded a change in the company's mandates allowing him to sign cheques or make transfers of the Mirror Group's money, based on his sole signature, for any amount.

In a departure from their usual legalistic language, the Department of Trade and Industry's inspectors describe Maxwell as a "bully and a domineering personality". Their 374-page report details the failure of anyone around him to keep him in check.

Maxwell bought the Mirror Group from Reed International for £113m, as part of his stated ambition to build a global communications company with revenues of £3bn to £5bn - he wanted to be a media baron to rival Rupert Murdoch.

He quickly restored the business's profitability by ending restrictive labour practices. But, by 1986, there were signs of trouble ahead - when the Mirror Group needed £34m cash, Maxwell "borrowed" the money from the firm's pension fund in return for shares that the firm held in Reuters. When these shares were transferred back in 1989, the fund made a significant loss on the transaction.

This pattern of plundering the pension fund became common practice. At a meeting with trade unions, Maxwell once referred to "his" fund. When this was queried by union officials, he turned to his company secretary and demanded who owned the pension trustee company. He was told that it was ultimately held by his private firm Pergamon Press, as parent company of the Mirror. Maxwell said: "Exactly. So I own the pension scheme."

Towards the end of the 1980s, Maxwell's financial position deteriorated as he bor rowed money for increasingly expensive acquisitions - including Quebecor Printing, Donohue and AGB Research. By 1989, Maxwell's private businesses owed nearly £1bn and his listed vehicle, Maxwell Communications Corporation, had debts of £2bn.

When recession bit in 1990, he faced a squeeze to keep up repayments. So he decided to float a 49% stake in Mirror Group - a move that eventually raised £235m from the public and from institutions.

A list of blue-chip advisers agreed to advise on the flotation - including stockbroker Samuel Montagu, investment bank Goldman Sachs and accountancy firm Coopers & Lybrand. The DTI inspectors express surprise at their willingness, given that Maxwell had been branded unfit to "exercise proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company" in a DTI investigation in the 1970s.

They comment that there was no evidence Maxwell had "changed his spots", adding that there was no justification for acting towards him "without a high degree of circumspection and care".

The prospectus for the flotation, the inspectors find, was "materially inaccurate and misleading" - it did not reveal the true reason for the offering, which was to provide cash and publicly quoted shares for use in bailing out the rest of Maxwell's business empire.

Coopers & Lybrand, the Mirror Group's auditor, told the DTI it watched Maxwell "like a hawk", placing him in the highest category of difficult clients. But the inspectors point out that the firm's "limited review" entirely missed the "serious financial position" of his "private side".

No checks

Once Mirror Group became a private company, there was no effective "ring fence" to keep a check on Maxwell's use of its cashflow. There was an ineffectual performance from heavyweight non-executive directors such as former TSB chairman Sir Robert Clark and former attorney-general Lord Williams of Elvel.

A typical incident concerned a board meeting to approve the company's half-year results in July 1991. Robert Maxwell changed the date of the meeting at the last minute, with the result that six senior directors could not attend. No papers were made available to board members in advance, the discussion was "brief" and none of those present objected to the way the meeting was arranged or conducted. Maxwell's right-hand man was his son, Kevin, whose business ethics were learnt from his father and whose conduct is condemned in the report as "inexcusable".

In September and October 1991, Maxwell borrowed £80m from banks as pressure from his struggling private businesses became acute. This was partly through a series of foreign-exchange transactions - Mirror Group settled each one a few days late, so that each transaction was effectively a short-term loan.

To sustain his ballooning overdrafts, Maxwell offered the banks Mirror shares as security. But he became agitated as the share price fell, devaluing this "currency".

Maxwell wanted to buy Mirror Group shares to try to support the price. But at the flotation, he had given an undertaking to Samuel Montagu that he would not do so. To avoid this, he arranged for purchases in the names of a series of related companies. The purchase of £26m of Mirror shares was carried out by Eric Sheinberg, a senior partner at Goldman Sachs, who comes in for severe criticism for failing to ask questions. The inspectors say: "Mr Sheinberg must have come to appreciate in due course that Maxwell was in fact the purchaser."

Over the course of 1990 and 1991, Maxwell spent £344m on buying shares in Mirror Group and his other quoted vehicle, Maxwell Communications Corporation. His borrowings became so acute that he pledged his entire 51% stake in the Mirror Group to banks as security for loans.

In August 1991, the position became unsustainable. Maxwell's lenders were hav ing doubts. NatWest, for instance, felt he was becoming "unpredictable" and believed he had not dealt "fully and frankly" with the bank.

First sign

On August 12, Maxwell phoned Sheinberg and admitted he could not repay a $35m loan from Goldman Sachs that was due the next day. This was the first time he had reneged on a such a deal. Goldman was obliged by Stock Exchange rules to announce that it had a claim over 10% of Mirror Group and 4.8% of Maxwell Communications.

This was the first public sign that Maxwell was in trouble. US bank Lehman Brothers demanded repayment of several large loans shortly afterwards. Maxwell obtained short-term help of £50m from Bankers Trust, but he also began selling his treasured stakes in a series of promising Israeli companies.

Spotting these transactions, Goldman concluded that Maxwell was in trouble, and lost hope of any repayment of its loans. It decided to sell the Mirror Group shares that Maxwell had offered as security - a move which would signal to other banks that it considered him a bad risk.

On November 4, a senior Goldman executive telephoned Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, to inform him that these sales were imminent.

Maxwell had been monitoring these events from his yacht, the Lady Ghislaine. In the early hours of November 5, he disappeared overboard. His death was announced that afternoon to Mirror Group's board, which asked the Stock Exchange to suspend dealing in the company's shares.

Maxwell's sons, Kevin and Ian, were left in charge as the Maxwell empire unravelled with frightening speed. Within weeks, huge shortfalls in the Mirror Group's pension fund emerged, and the Serious Fraud Office began the task of unpicking Maxwell's tangled financial web.

fields.headline: Bank stakeholders whisper their views
fields.standfirst: Abbey inquiry doors open - a bit
fields.trailText: Abbey inquiry doors open - a bit
fields.body:
Gladiator-style combat was expected at London's Strand Palace Hotel yesterday morning with Lloyds TSB in the blue corner and Abbey National in the red corner.

But there were no Oscar-winning performances as the two banks slugged it out in front of competition commissioner Denise Kingsmill in the first ever public hearing on a contested takeover.

The hearing was pitched as an opportunity for "stakeholders" - customers, unions, employees - to air their views in what is traditionally a behind-closed-doors affair. But judging from the 200 attending the hearing, 95% of people who bank with Lloyds or Abbey are male, most work in the City and 100% are white.

Ms Kingsmill won plaudits for best supporting actress, and, to be fair, this is her first stab at opening the process up to a wider audience. But she was perhaps too efficient in weeding out (in her own words) the "nutters" who turn up at bank annual meetings with crackpot problems.

Instead, the hearing focused too much on esoteric items such as net interest margins and too little on the very real concerns of consumers and small businesses. Remarkably, there was no voice whatsoever from the host of small-business federations.

The real debate will now return to where it has always really been decided - behind those closed doors. Over the next fortnight Ms Kingsmill will spend two days each at Lloyds TSB and Abbey National. Ian Harley of Abbey National in particular will want to provide a more robust performance than he managed yesterday. He will need to convince the commission that the influx of new entrants into the banking market - Egg, Smile, IF and others were repeatedly mentioned yesterday - do not give Lloyds a legitimate and compelling case for arguing that competition is not threatened by the proposed takeover.

Questions were asked as to why Peter Ellwood, Lloyds TSB's chief executive, was not present, and the excuses given - "he's a terribly busy guy, you know" - were lame, to say the least.

Lloyds TSB has far from won the battle, even if it has won round one. Its weakest link is small businesses. Deputy chief executive Mike Fairey may deride Abbey's 1% share of the small-business market (Lloyds has more than 30%) but Abbey does give small businesses another choice in what is a very limited market; you don't go to Smile or IF with your business bank account.

In the absence of a small-business organisation, a rather large business organisation, the Somerfield supermarkets group, spoke up. It told the hearing that in 10 years' experience of syndicated loans it had not found the big four to be running a truly competitive market. To lose Abbey National would be highly unfortunate, it argued.

The irony of the hearing, somewhat lost on Lloyds TSB, was the very fact that it was spending so much effort lambasting Abbey's business, its growth prospects, its branch network and its products.

So just why on earth does it want to splash out £18bn on buying it?

Oxygen bubble

Oxygen, the internet incubator fund, was dreamed up to breathe life into new online ventures.

The company was the brainchild of Manchester United director and serial entrepreneur Michael Edelson, who has a handy knack of whipping up useful big-name backers and high-profile publicity.

Its board of directors included Mr Edelson's 26-year-old daughter, Emma - whose stake in the company was fleetingly worth £8m on the day the company made its Aim debut - together with PR guru Matthew Freud and his then partner, Elisabeth Murdoch. Footballers Alan Hansen and Steve Bruce bought shares, along with former Manchester United FC chairman Martin Edwards.

Like Knutsford - where four businessmen headed by the erstwhile Asda boss Archie Norman whipped up an investor frenzy by promising to buy up an underperforming retailer and turn it into gold - Oxygen looked like a company made in heaven.

Oxygen's idea sounded good at the height of dot.com euphoria - to trawl universities and find the bright young things who were going to come up with the next Yahoo! It was a cracking story to sell to private investors who had gone dot.com dotty.

The shares rocketed, climbing 3,250% on day one, valuing the company at £250m. The shares were 57.5p.

But like Yahoo! and, indeed, Knutsford - also an Edelson company, by the way - Oxygen has run out of steam.

fields.bodyText: Gladiator-style combat was expected at London's Strand Palace Hotel yesterday morning with Lloyds TSB in the blue corner and Abbey National in the red corner. But there were no Oscar-winning performances as the two banks slugged it out in front of competition commissioner Denise Kingsmill in the first ever public hearing on a contested takeover. The hearing was pitched as an opportunity for "stakeholders" - customers, unions, employees - to air their views in what is traditionally a behind-closed-doors affair. But judging from the 200 attending the hearing, 95% of people who bank with Lloyds or Abbey are male, most work in the City and 100% are white. Ms Kingsmill won plaudits for best supporting actress, and, to be fair, this is her first stab at opening the process up to a wider audience. But she was perhaps too efficient in weeding out (in her own words) the "nutters" who turn up at bank annual meetings with crackpot problems. Instead, the hearing focused too much on esoteric items such as net interest margins and too little on the very real concerns of consumers and small businesses. Remarkably, there was no voice whatsoever from the host of small-business federations. The real debate will now return to where it has always really been decided - behind those closed doors. Over the next fortnight Ms Kingsmill will spend two days each at Lloyds TSB and Abbey National. Ian Harley of Abbey National in particular will want to provide a more robust performance than he managed yesterday. He will need to convince the commission that the influx of new entrants into the banking market - Egg, Smile, IF and others were repeatedly mentioned yesterday - do not give Lloyds a legitimate and compelling case for arguing that competition is not threatened by the proposed takeover. Questions were asked as to why Peter Ellwood, Lloyds TSB's chief executive, was not present, and the excuses given - "he's a terribly busy guy, you know" - were lame, to say the least. Lloyds TSB has far from won the battle, even if it has won round one. Its weakest link is small businesses. It told the hearing that in 10 years' experience of syndicated loans it had not found the big four to be running a truly competitive market. fields.headline: New Boeing cruiser
fields.trailText: British Airways revealed yesterday that it is closely monitoring the development of Boeing's new 750mph "sonic cruiser", which will be the fastest plane in the world apart from Concorde when it starts flying by 2008.
fields.body:
British Airways revealed yesterday that it is closely monitoring the development of Boeing's new 750mph "sonic cruiser", which will be the fastest plane in the world apart from Concorde when it starts flying by 2008.

The delta wing plane has seating for between 100 and 300 passengers. It has been submitted to 10 leading airlines, including BA.

Randy Baesler, Boeing's commercial planes director, said journey times across the Atlantic would be reduced by 90 minutes with a flight between London and Sydney cut by four hours to 16 hours.

He said the aircraft's extra speed, at Mach 0.95 or above, was possible because of its sleek design. It was planned to sell it in America, Asia and Europe.

 British Airways is facing "economic pressures" to get Concorde flying again almost nine months after the Air France Concorde crash in Paris, sources close to the Anglo-French talks disclosed yesterday.

BA has so far spent £31m mothballing its fleet and paying its Concorde team. The timetable for restarting services has been slipping away and sources involved in the inter-governmental talks said yesterday that BA would not be able to launch the aircraft before August. BA last night dismissed reports that it faced economic problems as "ludicrous".

webTitle: Robert Maxwell inquiry condemns son's conduct

fields.headline: Robert Maxwell inquiry condemns son's conduct
fields.trailText: Kevin Maxwell, son of the late newspaper tycoon Robert Maxwell, yesterday threatened to invoke human rights legislation to fight disqualification as a director after a government inquiry accused him of "inexcusable conduct" in the collapse of his father's business empire.
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell, son of the late newspaper tycoon Robert Maxwell, yesterday threatened to invoke human rights legislation to fight disqualification as a director after a government inquiry accused him of "inexcusable conduct" in the collapse of his father's business empire.

A long-awaited report from the Department of Trade and Industry criticised a list of blue-chip City institutions for failing to keep Robert Maxwell in check.

It attacked the stockbroker Coopers & Lybrand and the investment bank Goldman Sachs for failing to stop the entrepreneur manipulating Mirror Group's shares. As advisers to Maxwell, the report says they should have noticed him plundering nearly £400m from employees' pension funds.

However, it singled out Kevin Maxwell for particular blame, saying that he gave "very substantial assistance" to his father and "bears a heavy responsibility" for the abuse of pensioners' money.

Now the chairman of a telecom company, Kevin Maxwell, 42, said: "I accept my share of responsibility without reservation. But I don't accept the word 'inexcusable'.

"If you've given as many answers to as many people as I have, to the police, to the DTI, to lawyers and to investigators, I think you'll agree that I've accounted for my actions."

He rejected calls for his disqualification as a director, pointing out that he had given a commitment to regulators that he would no longer be involved in investment businesses, and had already served a period of disqualification while bankrupt.

He said: "What is the purpose of further action? What is it going to add? The human rights legislation which was recently enshrined in British law gives everyone a right to work. I am entitled to earn a living."

Kevin Maxwell was a director of six of the pension scheme companies from which his father transferred money. The funds were used to repay debts owed by other Maxwell businesses. He was cleared of fraud in a high court case that delayed completion of the DTI's report, which was commissioned in 1992.

Robert Maxwell's elder son, Ian, also sat on many of these boards. The DTI's independent inspectors found he played a smaller role but accused him of signing many documents "without considering their implications".

Several City institutions apologised for their roles in the Maxwell affair. PricewaterhouseCoopers, which owns Coopers & Lybrand, accepted that its conduct "fell short", while Goldman Sachs issued a statement expressing "deep regret".

The stockbroker Samuel Montagu, banks Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley and the law firm Clifford Chance were also criticised.

Lord Donoughue, who served as a junior agriculture minister from 1997 to 1999, was accused of failing to ask questions while serving on the board of one of Maxwell's companies. The report attacked other non-executive directors including Sir Robert Clark, a former director of the Bank of England. Sir Robert refused to apologise for his conduct. He said the report was written "with the benefit of hindsight", adding that as a non-executive director of the Mirror Group, he could not "ask the finance director every five minutes" what was going on.

The report called on the DTI to formally publish how it has responded to investigations such as this one. It said: "Recommendations are sometimes implemented, sometimes rejected, sometimes considered for long periods and sometimes ignored."

The DTI said it was taking legal advice before deciding if directors' disqualification proceedings were appropriate.

 Read the report in full at MediaGuardian.co.uk

webTitle: The end of 68 years of wickedness

fields.headline: The end of 68 years of wickedness
fields.standfirst:
The teenage victim, the British army officer, the businessman ... he discovered the power of perpetual reinvention

Inspectors fear for the fate of report that took ten years
How blue chips failed to tame Captain Bob
Bad business
The men who made it possible
fields.trailText: I am breaking a solemn promise to myself. I had hoped never to type the words Robert Maxwell again. I am Maxwelled out. I was in his life for almost two years, laboured over his death for a year after that and spent weeks at the trials of his two sons, Kevin and Ian.
fields.body:
I am breaking a solemn promise to myself. I had hoped never to type the words Robert Maxwell again. I am Maxwelled out. I was in his life for almost two years, laboured over his death for a year after that and spent weeks at the trials of his two sons, Kevin and Ian.

At the conclusion of that case, in which both were acquitted, I decided enough was enough. My days as "the Maxwell correspondent" were over. There was nothing else to say.

In truth, with the publication of the Department of Trade and Industry report, that situation has not changed. It is no surprise that Maxwell emerges as a monster. However many people contradict this or that detail, that central fact is undeniable.

Language is important here: he was not a rogue, bounder or cad. He was not a maverick or even a villain. To say he was larger than life is a pathetic excuse for a description. Maxwell was a thief, a bully, a confidence trickster and quite possibly a psychopath. He obeyed no rules, whether driving cars, handling pension funds or playing at being a father.

His life was a series of roles, acted out in separate compartments, little fantasies de signed to fool the next sucker: son, wife, lover, editor, fund manager, stockbroker, banker, accountant, prime minister, president, secretary, pensioner, everyone he ever met.

All that mattered to Robert Maxwell was Robert Maxwell. Somewhere along the way from his birth in a Ruthenian Jewish shtetl as Abraham Lajbi Hoch, through his teenage flight across Europe to escape the Nazis who wiped out most of his family, to his new persona as a British army officer and then businessman, Maxwell discovered the power of perpetual reinvention.

His lack of a moral compass allowed him to do as he pleased. He could play good cop and bad cop virtually at the same time, embracing his victims with an all-encompassing charm one minute and menacing them with dire threats the next. He had to get what he wanted.

But none of this should blind us to the faults of those people - including me - who chose to sup with the devil. We were adults. We had read the notorious DTI inspectors' criticism in 1971 that he was unfit to steward a public company. We knew he was an impossible man.

There is a difference, though, for employees whose companies he bought, and who therefore had no choice but to work for him. Similarly, journalists were not involved in his financial chicanery.

Anyway, it did not take any of us who spent time with him long to realise that we had made a mistake. He was even worse than we had expected and, at some stage, after being expected to make one compromise too many, we walked away.

For all sorts of reasons, his young sons were not able to do that and their culpability is surely mitigated by the ties of blood which made their position intolerable.

It is altogether less easy to ignore the faults of those people who worked for City institutions - particularly the investment bank Goldman Sachs and the auditor Coopers & Lybrand - and who well knew that they were dealing, if not with a crook, with a very dodgy operator.

They, and some of the men who worked closely in Maxwell's private investment fund companies, cannot convince us that Maxwell took them in, because they could see what he was doing, especially in his final 18 months.

That was the period in which those compartments in Maxwell's mind began to disintegrate as he tried in vain to keep his insolvent empire afloat. He knew the game was up.

I remain convinced that when he set sail from Tenerife on the night of November 4 1991 he knew what he was going to do. After 68 years of wickedness, he realised he could not win. So, in the reverse of the coroner's court mantra, Maxwell took his own life while, for the first time in his life, the balance of his mind was totally undisturbed.

Roy Greenslade, editor of the Daily Mirror, 1990-91, is the author of Maxwell's Fall (Simon & Schuster)

webTitle: Inspectors fear for the fate of report that took 10 years

fields.headline: Inspectors fear for the fate of report that took 10 years
fields.standfirst:
Damning report muted by time

The end of 68 years of wickedness
How blue chips failed to tame Captain Bob
Bad business
The men who made it possible
fields.trailText: On the evening of November 6, 1991, Kevin Maxwell and his brother Ian faced the media for the first time following their father's death, confirmed 24 hours earlier.
fields.body:
On the evening of November 6, 1991, Kevin Maxwell and his brother Ian faced the media for the first time following their father's death, confirmed 24 hours earlier.

The brothers looked tired and drawn and emotionally damaged. Kevin did all the speaking, offering thanks for the many messages of condolence which he and Ian had received. It was not a moment for direct questions, but one was levelled nevertheless: "Do you feel confident you can unravel the spaghetti which your father's business interests clearly amounted to?"

The brothers both laughed: "Well, it's not a corner shop . . . But the business is sound and we will be working with our advisers over the coming days to show that."

In fact, it has taken the DTI inspectors charged with tackling the Maxwell spaghetti the best part of a decade to produce their version of what went on and where blame lies.

The two volumes published yesterday amount to the most damning assessment of professional ineptitude and incompetence involving the City of London ever produced. Yet its impact has been muted by the passage of time; the inspectors, Sir Roger Thomas and Raymond Turner, might have had the whole matter wrapped up by 1995, but for the criminal proceedings at which the Maxwell brothers and an associate, Larry Trachtenberg, were acquitted.

The belated publication of their findings yesterday was accompanied by just a short list of recommendations, amounting to little more than a few broad-brush principles on the conduct of business, regulation and the stock market.

But the power of the report lies in the simplicity of the inspectors' conclusions from an affair which snared the world's most influential investment bank (Goldman Sachs), a member of the accountancy elite (Cooper & Lybrand, now part of PricewaterhouseCoopers), an ultra-blue blooded law firm (Linklaters & Paines), together with a host of other supposedly pukka professional advisers and City individuals.

The power is also in the detail. Buried away in the middle of the report, for example, is the account of how two of Britain's most respected businessmen, Alan Clements (former finance director of ICI) and Sir Robert Clark (then deputy chairman of TSB), became non-executive directors of Mirror Group ahead of its stock market flotation. They were hired to add prestige -- and to keep Robert Maxwell in check.

But the inspectors observe: "Apart from a brief visit to the Watford plant and the Mirror building and their attendance at two formal board meetings . . . Mr Clements and Sir Robert did not take the opportunity to get to know any of the executive directors of MGN nor to attend any meetings concerned with the business or management of MGN until after the flotation."

Not content at chronicling the shortcomings of everyone from the London stock exchange to Lord Williams (the Labour peer appointed to the Mirror board on the basis that he would not "rock the boat"), the inspectors finish with a final pop at their own paymaster, the Department of Trade.

"Recommendations in reports such as this are sometimes implemented, sometimes rejected, sometimes considered for long periods and sometimes ignored," they observe, before going on to recommend that the DTI formally publish how it has responded to investigations such as this one.

That would be a step forward, especially when predecessors of Sir Roger and Mr Turner, conducting an earlier DTI investigation stated famously: "We regret having to conclude that, notwithstanding Mr Maxwell's acknowledged abilities and energy, he is not in our opinion a person who can be relied on to exercise proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company."

Buried away in the middle of the report, for example, is the account of how two of Britain's most respected businessmen, Alan Clements (former finance director of ICI) and Sir Robert Clark (then deputy chairman of TSB), became non-executive directors of Mirror Group ahead of its stock market flotation. They were hired to add prestige -- and to keep Robert Maxwell in check. But the inspectors observe: "Apart from a brief visit to the Watford plant and the Mirror building and their attendance at two formal board meetings . . . Mr Clements and Sir Robert did not take the opportunity to get to know any of the executive directors of MGN nor to attend any meetings concerned with the business or management of MGN until after the flotation." Not content at chronicling the shortcomings of everyone from the London stock exchange to Lord Williams (the Labour peer appointed to the Mirror board on the basis that he would not "rock the boat"), the inspectors finish with a final pop at their own paymaster, the Department of Trade. "Recommendations in reports such as this are sometimes implemented, sometimes rejected, sometimes considered for long periods and sometimes ignored," they observe, before going on to recommend that the DTI formally publish how it has responded to investigations such as this one. That would be a step forward, especially when predecessors of Sir Roger and Mr Turner, conducting an earlier DTI investigation stated famously: "We regret having to conclude that, notwithstanding Mr Maxwell's acknowledged abilities and energy, he is not in our opinion a person who can be relied on to exercise proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company."

webTitle: Not a fair cop: Rome riddled with blond bias

fields.headline: Not a fair cop: Rome riddled with blond bias
fields.trailText: Once Romans regarded blonds as barbarous inferiors with criminal tendencies. Then they deemed females of that species objects of desire and success. Now they can't decide.
fields.body:
Once Romans regarded blonds as barbarous inferiors with criminal tendencies. Then they deemed females of that species objects of desire and success. Now they can't decide.

Antiquity, aesthetics and prejudice are colliding in a confused debate. Being blondish, I have an interest in the outcome.

The customs officers at Rome's Fiumicino airport were not confused. I spoke imperfect Italian, was flying to Tirana and had a laptop computer: I was a thief.

"Where is your export licence?" demanded the chief. "Where is your receipt?" demanded his deputy. "Where did you steal it?" demanded the deputy's deputy.

Other passengers with laptops booked on the same flight were sailing through customs; they were dark and presumed to be Italian. I was presumed to be Albanian, returning home to sell my plunder.

A wave of a passport dissolved suspicion but east Europeans living in Rome do not have such an option.

Contrary to stereotype, many Moldovans, Albanians, Russians, Romanians and people from the former Yugoslavia are blue-eyed and fair-haired. Romans know that.

Contrary to stereotype, the vast majority work hard to make an honest living. Some Romans appear not to know that.

A supposed crime wave is sweeping the land. Burglaries, muggings, prostitution, car thefts and murders are routinely attributed to illegal immigrants from across the Adriatic. To be a (natural) blonde can invite suspicion.

A blonde female friend from Belgrade, a student, has twice been offered money for sex by strangers who heard her accent.

An alternative fate is to be granted honourary membership of the new underclass - babysitters, porters, bag-carriers, cleaners, waitresses and cooks.

Tales of cheap labour pepper dinner-party conversations, just as Italian skivvies were once the talk of New York salons.

More than one commentator has compared the situation to ancient Rome, when Vandals and Goths made useful slaves - when they weren't pillaging. In films at least they tended to be blonde.

For today's Romans it is all rather perplexing. In recent times, blondes have been associated with sexiness and wealth; they oozed fun, luxury and glamour.

Where Hollywood led, Italian television followed, turning blondes into presenters, actors and showgirls. To be bionda was to be bella.

No one sniggered when football coaches, business executives and politicians became fairer-haired. The wannabe rich and famous have been having highlights ever since.

But now that moral suspicion also attaches to blondness, the options are polarised: go all the way for platinum showbiz blond or stay dark. To hover between, where sandy meets ginger, is an authenticity that risks provoking disdain.

fields.headline: Oil menace
fields.standfirst: Wildfowl die in Danish haven
fields.trailText: Wildfowl die in Danish haven.
fields.body:
People on the "green island" of Bogoe watched helplessly yesterday as oil turned idyllic Danish beaches black and seabirds floated into viscous patches of fuel when a 1,900-tonne slick from a tanker holed in the Baltic struck Bogoe and Fanster, in the Storstroemmen archipelago about 75 miles south of Copenhagen.

As the morning mist cleared to reveal the desolate sight, army conscripts were set to work with spades to remove the black waste, metre by metre.

"It's hard because the oil is heavy and is 15 to 20cms thick in places," said Claus Munch, the officer in charge of the operation on one stretch of coast.

Calm weather made it relatively easy to spot and control the patches of oil, hosever, so later in the day a Danish navy spokesman was able to say: "This is a very serious accident, but not yet a catastrophe."

Offshore, boats sucked oil from the sea's surface.

About 80 birds have died and many more have been found covered in fuel and unable to move.

Martin Soendergaard, watching the clean-up, predicted that hundreds more would die.

"Spring is the time when migrating birds arrive here from the south. Bogoe is one of their favourite places, there is a bird haven here."

AFP

webTitle: Gangsters rule in lawless Kurd heartland

fields.headline: Gangsters rule in lawless Kurd heartland
fields.standfirst:
Turks protest against hidden forces in the south-east

Special report: the Kurds
fields.trailText: Turks protest against hidden forces in the south-east.
fields.body:
More than two years after the capture of the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan, many people living in south-eastern Turkey are convinced that influential forces in the region are determined to maintain a permanent sense of instability.

"They like it this way," Hamdullah Aktas said in his tiny flat in the back streets of Diyarbakir. "It gives them the freedom to do what they like."

The war between the Turkish state and the Kurdistan Worker's party (PKK) has all but come to an end, and there are growing demands for political and social change. But the long years of conflict have made some people very rich, and they are reluctant to let democratisation get in the way.

"They are a minority, but they are very strong," Cuneyt Ulsever, a columnist with the newspaper Hurriyet, said.

"Peace could be bad for business."

In the south-east, the profiteers smuggle guns, migrants and, above all, drugs. It is a vastly lucrative business which produces billions of pounds in profits annually.

According to US government estimates, between four and six tonnes of heroin passes through Turkey every month on its way to Europe.

Powerful gangs control the trade and have the money to recruit whoever they choose, apparently including renegade members of the security forces, the PKK, and the Village Guards - private armies funded by the state and controlled by feudal Kurdish lords. They thrive in an unstable environment where guns wield more power than the law of the land.

Turkey's law enforcement agencies have stepped up their efforts against the smuggling, but their honest members are often overwhelmed. Last year they made more than 6,000 drug-related arrests and confiscated nearly six tonnes of heroin and 25 tonnes of hashish.

At the beginning of this year, there was a series of troubling incidents in Diyarkabir. Its popular police chief, Gaffar Okkan, who was trying to rebuild trust between the local people and the state, was assassinated in a professional ambush in the city centre.

In the same week two political activists who were about to open a branch office of the pro-Kurdish party People's Democracy in Silopi, a town near the Iraqi border, disappeared after being summoned to a local gendarmerie base. They have not been seen since.

The official explanation is that Okkan was murdered by the radical Islamic group Turkish Hizbullah. On the streets of Diyarbakir, however, nearly everyone seems convinced that what they call the "deep state" was involved.

"These incidents caused tensions among the people," the Kurdish mayor of Diyarbakir, Feridun Celik, said. "But there have also been big protests against what happened, and that is just as important. People are speaking out."

Thousands of Kurds paid their respects at Okkan's funeral in January: a rare tribute to a Turkish policeman in a part of the country which remains under emergency rule.

But protest meetings linked to the disappearance of the two Kurdish activists have also been supported by like-minded Turks in other parts of the country.

In Diyarbakir and elsewhere there is a desire for change. Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in support of peaceful reform during the traditional Newroz spring festival last week.

Standing against them, however, is a multi-billion pound smuggling network which will not give up its privileged position without a fight.

"There could be more efforts to destabilise our region," Mr Celik said. "We all have to stand together."

webTitle: War orphans: better futures or stolen lives?

fields.headline: War orphans: better futures or stolen lives?
fields.standfirst: Broken families of 1994 genocide want loved ones home
fields.trailText: Broken families of 1994 genocide want loved ones home.
fields.body:
Josephine is 29, a barefoot peasant farmer with a smiling husband and three small children. The whole family spend the day in the fields, hoeing the dark red earth around their cassava plants, going home at dusk to their adobe house in one of the hundreds of new settlements built after the 1994 genocide and the displacement of 4m people.

They are one of the dozens of truncated families whose children or siblings were taken to Europe during the genocide when tens of thousands were orphaned or lost their families.

Josephine's parents and two siblings were killed in the genocide and their old house is a burned-out ruin. Her new home's small windows let in little daylight, but it is possible to make out the handful of cooking pots and the sleeping mat which constitute the bulk of her possessions.

Her most treasured belonging is produced with a radiant smile of pride. It is a worn plastic album containing four photos and letters from her sister Beata, who was taken with dozens of other children from an Italian-run orphanage in south-east Rwanda in 1994.

"I would love to see you, I would thank God if I could ... Tell Granny I'll come to see her if God wishes ... If only we could see each other eye to eye, and hug each other, talk, laugh and sing," Beata writes in Kinyarwanda (the local language) from Belgium.

Josephine says she did not know her sister had been taken from the orphanage where she was being cared for after an accident. Nor did she know that her sister was in Belgium, not in Italy, like others from nearby villages which she had heard about.

Appeals

Forty-one families in Gashora are still missing their sons and daughters, though 92 children were returned to Rwanda from Italy in 1997 after a government delegation to Rome got the UN involved.

President Paul Kagame has made personal appeals to the Italian government for the return of the remaining children, without success.

"These blocks, of the government, of the justice system, these are the kind of injustices which made us take up arms in the first place," he says.

Pascal is also 29, and lives with his wife Perpetua and three small children in the tiny house he built himself on the edge of a dusty village trading centre.

He wants his sister Margaret Nkakirutimana back from Italy, "now, now, now". His parents were "killed as Tutsis" in 1992, before the main genocide got underway. Pascal was looking after four younger siblings when a neighbour who worked in the church suggested that he needed help and that Margaret, two years old and the youngest, could be looked after by the Italian priests.

"It was just because of poverty," explained the neighbour's wife, Matayo Nduhura. "Now my husband is in prison, accused of genocide, so he can't come to say how responsible he feels. The girl was taken away without anyone knowing." Pascal said there has mot been a letter or a photo from his sister, who will now be 10.

Red Cross

Eveniana Mukamurenzi has lost her 10-year-old son too. Volens was nearly three when he broke his hip and was being cared for by the priests. "I miss him a lot, he is my son ... I would be very happy if I could see him." Eveniana is a widow.

Emmanuel Basota has lost Alex, his eldest son. He took him to the orphanage when his wife died in childbirth. Now he has married again and has five more children. He also has three brothers and a sister, and he wants Alex to be with them all.

The Red Cross once brought him a photograph of Alex, but they took it away again, he says. He doesn't know why, nor does he know where Alex is.

Some of the families walked 10 miles or more to a meeting about the children at the commune headquarters. They are among the most powerless people in the world, with none of the tools of education or communication to fight for their rights, and, like all survivors of the genocide, haunted by family loss.

Odette Nyiramilimo is the minister for local administration and social affairs, a mother, and as is common in Rwanda, has several orphans of the genocide absorbed into her family.

"So the Italians want to keep them because here they are poor - we are all poor, do they want to take all the children of Rwanda? Would my children prefer to live with Bill Clinton because he's rich? How can we say that living in a rich family is better?

"These children may be called Italians, but they will never feel Italian, there is discrimination and racism everywhere. What is their future sense of identity? You are looking at children with very complex and individual needs, the young ones of course speaking no Kinyarwanda."

In April 1994, when the priests arrived at the border, the soldiers let them through on the promise that they would bring the children back after the war. It ended in three months, but today many of the children have been adopted, told they are Italian, and given new names.

The story of the lost children of Gashora goes to the heart of the poisoned relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the murder of 800,000 people in three months of 1994 and its continued denial.

The church at Nyamata, near Gashora, is a memorial to 20,000 people killed inside it or in the next door priests' compound. Skulls are piled neatly in great pyramids, the blood on the altar cloth is dark brown, and the walls and ceilings where blood spurted are blackened. Four Belgian priests left, saying they could not protect the people, the guardian says.

Some Rwandan priests killed in the genocide, others were complicit in rounding up thousands of terrified Tutsis for killing. Today many of them are protected by their orders in France, Italy and Belgium from returning to face justice in what has become a very different society from the one they left.

webTitle: Rwanda remembered: 'I would love to go back'

fields.headline: 'I would love to go back'
fields.standfirst: Seven years parted from her sister
fields.trailText: Josephine's sister Beata, who was a young girl when she left Rwanda in 1994, lives in the Belgian town of Namur, on a bend of the picturesque river Meuse river in the rolling hills of French-speaking Wallonia.
fields.body:
Josephine's sister Beata, who was a young girl when she left Rwanda in 1994, lives in the Belgian town of Namur, on a bend of the picturesque river Meuse river in the rolling hills of French-speaking Wallonia.

Her voice at the other end of the phone goes quiet when Josephine is mentioned. After a few minutes she agrees to meet in a cafe, clearly anxious for news of the sister she has not seen for seven years.

She sparkles with life. If circumstances had been different she might have been a model, for her fine features are strikingly beautiful. But she also wears the anxious expression of someone who has seen and been through a lot.

She pulls hard on a cigarette as she walks to the cafe with a friend who has come along for moral support. Wearing a Puffa jacket and all the latest gear, she could be any 19-year-old out on the town.

But as she clambers up the cafe's steep wooden stairs her right leg struggles to keep up with the rest of her and makes a sharp tapping sound as it strikes the steps: she was living in the orphanage at Gashora because of a leg injury.

She cannot bring herself to speak about what happened in 1994: the murder of her parents and two siblings. When she hears about Josephine, tears well up in her soft, troubled eyes.

"I haven't talked about what happened for seven years," she says in perfect French. "It's so personal and so hard. I can't just blurt it out all like that. I'm sorry but I don't know you.

"I want to have more news about my sister and what her life is like, not just to know that she is doing OK."

She did not know that her letters to Kigali, carrying Josephine's name and her remote commune, had reached her sister.

Still at school, Beata says she will probably stick at her studies for another year. She seems well settled in this quiet provincial Belgian town. She has many friends, she explains, most of them from Rwanda or Congo.

But it is clear that her thoughts and memories, sometimes terrible, are often of Rwanda. When asked if she would like to visit her old home, she does not hesitate for a second. "I would love to go back, but I haven't the means."

webTitle: Moulding little Lombards in the land of Ronaldo

fields.headline: Moulding little Lombards in the land of Ronaldo
fields.standfirst: Adoptive families wean children from their past
fields.trailText: Adoptive families wean children from their past.
fields.body:
The parents of Castenedolo would rather not trust the world beyond their gates and walls. They use security codes, burglar alarms and guard dogs to keep it out. Their latest defence is silence.

No one is to speak of the little black faces which peer from car windows on the way to and from school. Or to say how these children came to be in a drizzly, moneyed town on the Lombardy plain. A careless word might give outsiders a chance to take them away.

Forty-one Rwandan orphans found sanctuary here and in nearby towns in 1994. They were supposed to return after the genocide but each was adopted by a local family.

The news that most are not orphans, that mothers, fathers, siblings, uncles, aunts and grandparents survived and want them back, has not gone down well. "Leave us, we have nothing to say," a woman's voice quavers from a speaker-phone at the home of Jean-Dominique, who is being sought by his father.

"My baby is fine, he is happy here, everything was done properly. Please go."

Neighbours echo the refrain, because Castenedolo is a town united: here African infants learned to become Italians and here they will stay.

Aged between seven and 11, they are said to be too young to remember their lives before paved streets, sleek cars, risotto and villas in pastel peach, cream and yellow. Living an hour's drive south-east of Milan, they speak only the Brescian dialect and Italian.

The attempts of the Rwandan government to return them to blood relatives have shaken the adoptive parents.

Gruppo Museke, the Roman Catholic charity which evacuated the children, is accused of concealing the fact that relatives survive.

Hailed by the president of Italy for its compassion in 1994, Castenedolo has collectively decided to keep its head down and wait for the storm to pass. More than two dozen families were asked but only two fathers agreed to be interviewed.

Stroking his adopted son's head, Francesco - not his real name - asked not to be identified. He was proud of Angelo and had nothing to hide, he said, but he feared the other parents' disapproval.

It had been a largely trouble-free upbringing. Angelo, seven, had many friends, was doing well at school and learning the flute. "His passion is football. He's going to play for Italy."

Angelo grinned and rolled a ball past his dog, snoozing on the sofa.

"I support Inter Milan because of Ronaldo," He said. Several Rwandans play in the school team with him every Sunday.

He remembered nothing of Rwanda and had had no contact with relatives. Like the other children, he had been told all about the genocide. He thought Rwanda was still dangerous.

There were no visible mementos of Africa in the flat. "This is home," he shrugged. Later, in a cafe, a barmaid hailed him by name and handed an ice cream with Smarties, swiftly demolished.

Francesco repeated a Castenedolo mantra: Rwanda's fuss about the adoptions was a ploy to extract international aid. "It's the only explanation," he said.

At 4pm parents scooped up children spilling out of the school. Even when home is 10 minutes on foot, many prefer to drive - the sort of caution which is typical of northern Italy.

A black face peeked from curtains while Dr Madella, sheltering under an umbrella, ambled from his red-tiled villa to speak behind a locked three-metre-high gate.

Media distortions had forced the families into silence, he said. The children were formally adopted under Italian law and only liars said they had been bought.

Dr Madella distanced the families from Gruppo Museke, saying the Italian state took over the matter five years ago.

Blood fathers might exist, but the doctor doubted they would have the documents to prove it.

In any case they were guilty of abandoning their babies in order to remarry. "The second wife wouldn't have accepted the kids. It's an ethnic thing."

The streets of Castenedolo, population 2,000, tend to be spotless, deserted and peaceful, except for the hum of distant tractors.

The mayor, Gianbattista Groli, did not return phone calls. At the parish house beside the church a priest leaned out of a second-floor window but would not come to the door. "Nothing to do with me," he said, and withdrew.

His colleague, Father Roberto Lombardi, was instrumental in arranging the adoptions. The man who answered his mobile phone said he was a friend who would speak anonymously on the priest's behalf.

"Thanks to God, the children are well. They were adopted, they were not stolen. They have had seven happy years and are better off here. If they return to Rwanda they could be killed."

webTitle: Historic cloisters make way for museum expansion

fields.headline: Historic cloisters make way for museum expansion
fields.trailText: From his fourth floor flat Alfredo Zaragoza watched yesterday as workmen tore down one of Madrid's few 17th-century edifices, the cloisters of the monastery of San Jeronimo el Real.
fields.body:
From his fourth floor flat Alfredo Zaragoza watched yesterday as workmen tore down one of Madrid's few 17th-century edifices, the cloisters of the monastery of San Jeronimo el Real.

"They are hacking it to pieces, destroying it. They are even using pneumatic drills," he said.

The cloisters lie between the Retiro park and the Prado Museum, which wants the land for expansion.

The government says it is simply taking the cloisters away, granite block by granite block, to restore them.

But architects' plans show that only the arches will be conserved, and they will be hidden inside a red-brick, cube-shaped museum extension.

Madrid is by no means an ancient city, and these cloisters, together with the San Jeronimo el Real monastery and church, are part of a building begun more than six centuries ago.

Mr Zaragora is not the only person in the city looking on in amazement and with increasing anger as they disappear.

An architect on the site admitted yesterday that within weeks there would be nothing left.

A hole big enough to drive as truck through has already been knocked through the outer wall.

The roof of the ground-floor gallery has been pulled down.

Yesterday workers could be seen taking down the crests and shields that decorate the two stories of arches lining the inside of the cloisters.

The demolition raises serious questions about the Spanish government's ability and political will to protect historic monuments.

"We have so few historic buildings in Madrid. If this one goes, then we are lost," said Paloma Gomez Embuena, president of the residents' association in this exclusive district, who has fought for seven years to save the building.

The decision to wipe the cloisters from the landscape has come directly from the culture ministry.

The building is being sacrificed so the Prado museum can expand. Its exhibition space will increased by half.

In the architect Rafael Moneo's scheme the space occupied by the cloisters will be divided into a shop, restaurant, cloakroom, reading room, restoration centre and auditorium for visitors and academics.

The arches will mostly become the reading room's walls, visible only to a privileged few.

The rest of the building, including what are believed to be the buried remains of some 12th-century cloisters, will be bulldozed and thrown away.

From the outside, visitors to Madrid will see only the Moneo cube.

The architect is not to blame. The government commissioned him to build on the cloisters site after it declared void an international architectural contest for the Prado expansion which attracted more than 400 entries.

Challenged in court, the government argued that the cloisters, partially partly destroyed by invading French troops 200 years ago and largely untended since then, are not a protected monument.

The Royal Academy of History has protested.

"This is totally contrary to both the letter and the spirit of the laws protecting Spain's historical buildings," it said in a recent letter to the culture ministry.

But the supreme court has ruled that removal of the cloisters and restoration of a part of them should be allowed.

In recent days, however, the regional government of Madrid has finally admitted that the building and space around it are "cultural heritage" areas.

Campaigners have also turned up previously unseen culture ministry orders that the building should not be touched.

A new petition is before the supreme court, but it will take more than a week to be heard. By then there will be very little left.

webTitle: Five Palestinians die in day of rage at Israelis

fields.headline: Five Palestinians die in day of rage at Israelis
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Thousands of Palestinians battled Israeli troops with stones and guns in a "day of rage" yesterday and drew heavy Israeli fire that killed five protesters and injured more than 130.
fields.body:
Thousands of Palestinians battled Israeli troops with stones and guns in a "day of rage" yesterday and drew heavy Israeli fire that killed five protesters and injured more than 130.

In West Bank towns, youths hurled rocks at soldiers who fired live rounds from jeeps and fortified outposts. Palestinian gunmen shot at a Jewish enclave in divided Hebron, and Israeli tanks shelled Arab neighbourhoods there.

In Israel, meanwhile, tens of thousands of Israeli Arabs marched peacefully in the northern Galilee town of Sakhnin in an annual commemoration of protests at land expropriations in 1976 in which six Israeli Arabs were killed by police. Nearby, others mourned three town residents shot dead by Israeli police in anti-government protests last autumn. For the first time yesterday, Israeli Jews joined the march against Israel's confiscation of 5,000 acres of fields and olive groves near the town.

Yesterday's clashes in the West Bank and Gaza capped a tumultuous week that began with the killing of a 10-month Jewish baby, by a Palestinian sniper, and was followed by suicide bombings, shootings and rocket attacks.

In Sakhnin, the epicentre of the Land Day protests, a woman in a blue headscarf huddled over a new grave in the town cemetery, heaped with wreaths of flowers and placards.

Imad Ghaniam, aged 25, a salesman, was among 13 Israeli Palestinians killed by police last autumn when the Arab towns of the Galilee went out into the streets to support the intifada in the West Bank and Gaza.

"He was one of God's angels walking on earth," said his mother, Rukiya Ghaniam.

For Israel's 1m Arab citizens, this Land Day had particular resonance. Scarred by the killing of the 13 protesters, and deeply suspicious of Israel's hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, the community is caught between its own struggle for civil rights inside the Jewish state and its sympathies for the Palestinians.

But they are growing increasingly assertive. When Abid al-Munaim Abu Saleh arrived here yesterday to visit the grave of his son, Walid, aged 21, who was also shot dead by police last October, he was treated as a minor hero.

Mr Abu Saleh wore a plaster cast on his right arm, fractured when he punched a policeman who was testifying last week at a judicial inquiry into the killings of the 13 protesters. He broke the policeman's nose, forcing the suspension of the inquiry.

In the West Bank city of Nablus, where angry crowds began collecting after Friday afternoon prayers, four men were killed by Israeli forces. Hospital sources said that at least two were shot in the head.

Israeli forces shot a fifth man in the head in Ramallah, firing straight into hundreds of protesters with live fire, and eventually machine guns. In Hebron, five protesters were wounded with live bullets.

webTitle: Marrow transplant hope for heart patients

fields.headline: Marrow transplant hope for heart patients
fields.trailText: Transplants from a patient's own bone marrow could be used to repair scarred hearts within three years.
fields.body:
Transplants from a patient's own bone marrow could be used to repair scarred hearts within three years.

Two teams of researchers in New York announce today that in separate experiments stem cells from adult bone marrow turned into heart tissue and restored the heart's ability to pump blood.

Heart attacks are the leading cause of death in the western world. There are more than a million each year in the US, and 300,000 in Britain. More than a third are fatal. The New York transplant experiments worked only in laboratory rats and mice. But if the treatment succeeds in humans, it could repair damaged hearts, get patients back on their feet and save tens of thousands of lives every year.

"This study offers hope that we might one day be able to actually reverse the damage caused by a heart attack," said Francis Collins, director of the US national human genome research institute. "The apparent ability of stem cells in the bone marrow of adult animals to rebuild the heart reveals nature's remarkably flexible response to disease."

One group, from the genome institute and New York Medical College, will report in next week's Nature that stem cell therapy could provide new blood vessels and new muscle to damaged hearts. The second team, from the Columbia-Presbyterian medical centre, reports in Nature Medicine today that the treatment has the potential to significantly reduce sickness and death associated with heart attack.

The research is certain to re-open the sometimes bitter debate about the use of embryo stem cells for research. In January, the House of Lords gave the final green light for the use of 14-day-old embryos, not needed for fertility treatment, for transplant research.

Such embryos would provide - before they were destroyed - the stem cells that are the source of all of the 200-300 different cell types in a human body. The first promise would be of treatments for nerve regeneration, and the reversal of neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's.

Britain is the first country to formally permit such experiments. But opponents see embryo stem cells as an ethical minefield. They have argued that adult stem cells could also be "reprogrammed" to provide perfect tissue matches for other types of cell.

There has been limited but tantalising evidence that this can happen. Bone marrow stem cells are a source of blood cells. In a series of experiments, they have also been shown to turn into liver cells, and even to brain cells. Skin cells have been shown to change to brain cells; brain cells have been reported as becoming heart cells. The latest findings from New York will be seen to add support to the argument that embryos may not be needed.

Piero Anversa of the New York college and his team injected mouse bone marrow stem cells stained with a fluorescent marker into the hearts of mice damaged by the kind of attack known as infarction. Normally, even if someone survives a heart attack, there are serious problems.

The heart muscle is starved of oxygen, the tissue dies, scars form, the heart is permanently damaged and there is greater risk of heart failure. But the mice with stem cells were different. Nine days after the treatment, the scientists found new cells growing in 68% of the damaged ventricle.

The Columbia-Presbyterian team, led by Silviu Itescu, injected human stem cells not into the heart muscle but the tails of rats that had survived a heart attack. Later, they found that new human-type capillaries had grown within the damaged parts of the heart. Because blood supply had improved, fewer heart cells had died than in untreated rats.

The successes with animals suggest that bone marrow stem cells could be taken from the patient, cultured and then transplanted, without risk of immune rejection.

Because bone marrow cells provide both heart muscle and blood vessels, they could literally put new heart into patients. "Cardiac stem cells have been the Holy Grail of cardiovascular researchers working to find a way to replace damaged heart tissue," says Mark Sussman, of the Children's Hospital medical centre in Cincinnati, in next week's Nature.

webTitle: Fishes' friend completes epic row across Pacific

fields.headline: Fishes' friend completes epic row across Pacific
fields.trailText: Cursing "bloody boat" as he staggered on to the shores of North Stradbroke Island, the arthritic British adventurer Jim Shekhdar yesterday became the first person to row unaided across the Pacific.
fields.body:
Cursing "bloody boat" as he staggered on to the shores of North Stradbroke Island, the arthritic British adventurer Jim Shekhdar yesterday became the first person to row unaided across the Pacific.

Huge waves flung the bedraggled 54-year-old from his 10-metre vessel and into the surf, forcing him to swim the final 400 metres to be met by his wife, two daughters and a can of cold beer on the beach, 10 miles east of Brisbane.

"I had no doubt I'd make it, I just thought I'd make it with the boat instead of going separately," said Mr Shekhdar as he stepped on to dry land for the first time in 274 days.

Browned by the sun and sporting wild grey hair and a long beard, the former civil engineer from Northwood, west London, survived treacherous seas, the attentions of a Great White shark, and a close shave with an oil tanker to complete his 10,652-mile journey.

An eccentric and showman according to his wife, Jane, Mr Shekhdar cancelled a hip replacement operation weeks before he left Britain last year, to set off from Ilo, Peru, in his tiny vessel on June 29. He said he enjoyed the solitude at first, reading philosophical works and, when he could get a dialling tone, communicating via satellite telephone, fax and email with his family.

The former England international water polo player, who was banned for life after throwing a referee into the water, revealed how he chatted to fish on his epic journey. However, he drew the line at conversing with sharks. "The sharks seemed to be quite malevolent out there," he said. "The boat is called Le Shark so maybe they thought they were mating or something."

The record-breaking rower fended off one curious three-and-a-half metre Great White with a harpoon made out of a broken oar and a fishing knife. "He wasn't biting the boat, but he was head-butting it and hitting it with his tail and I didn't understand why," said Mr Shekhdar. "He didn't stop but he desisted for a bit."

Mr Shekhdar's colourful career includes stints as a civil engineer in Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and Las Vegas. After founding a computer company and working for Xerox, he tired of being a "corporate animal" and took to ocean rowing, crossing the Atlantic in a rowing boat with fellow adventurer David Jackson four years ago.

Rowing an average of nearly 40 miles a day on his solo trip, he crossed the Pacific 20 days faster than Peter Bird, a British adventurer who rowed from San Francisco to the Great Barrier Reef in 1983 with the help of fresh food supplies halfway. Bird died attempting another crossing of the Pacific in 1996.

Despite having run out of cooking gas and using up the last of his porridge and soup supplies a week ago, fish remained off the menu for a famished Mr Shekhdar. A 30kg yellowfin tuna jumped into his half-covered boat, but he threw it back. "I don't like killing my friends," he said.

The adventure had got off to bad start when the Chilean authorities forbade his departure. Judging it too dangerous, they forced him to travel north to Peru to find more lenient officials.

"I've learned that nothing is as difficult as it seems at the start," he said. "I've always believed that if you are going to do something you've got to start and then it will get done but I think you can do anything if you want to."

The only time he had been seriously unnerved, he said, was when he drifted within 10 metres of an oil tanker early one morning. "It's the only thing that made me wobbly," he said. "I couldn't sleep for a week after that."
