Huge waves flung the bedraggled 54-year-old from his 10-metre vessel and into the surf, forcing him to swim the final 400 metres to be met by his wife, two daughters and a can of cold beer on the beach, 10 miles east of Brisbane. "I had no doubt I'd make it, I just thought I'd make it with the boat instead of going separately," said Mr Shekhdar as he stepped on to dry land for the first time in 274 days. Browned by the sun and sporting wild grey hair and a long beard, the former civil engineer from Northwood, west London, survived treacherous seas, the attentions of a Great White shark, and a close shave with an oil tanker to complete his 10,652-mile journey. An eccentric and showman according to his wife, Jane, Mr Shekhdar cancelled a hip replacement operation weeks before he left Britain last year, to set off from Ilo, Peru, in his tiny vessel on June 29. He said he enjoyed the solitude at first, reading philosophical works and, when he could get a dialling tone, communicating via satellite telephone, fax and email with his family. The former England international water polo player, who was banned for life after throwing a referee into the water, revealed how he chatted to fish on his epic journey. However, he drew the line at conversing with sharks. "The sharks seemed to be quite malevolent out there," he said. "The boat is called Le Shark so maybe they thought they were mating or something." The record-breaking rower fended off one curious three-and-a-half metre Great White with a harpoon made out of a broken oar and a fishing knife. "He wasn't biting the boat, but he was head-butting it and hitting it with his tail and I didn't understand why," said Mr Shekhdar. "He didn't stop but he desisted for a bit." Mr Shekhdar's colourful career includes stints as a civil engineer in Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and Las Vegas. After founding a computer company and working for Xerox, he tired of being a "corporate animal" and took to ocean rowing, crossing the Atlantic in a rowing boat with fellow adventurer David Jackson four years ago. Rowing an average of nearly 40 miles a day on his solo trip, he crossed the Pacific 20 days faster than Peter Bird, a British adventurer who rowed from San Francisco to the Great Barrier Reef in 1983 with the help of fresh food supplies halfway. Bird died attempting another crossing of the Pacific in 1996. Despite having run out of cooking gas and using up the last of his porridge and soup supplies a week ago, fish remained off the menu for a famished Mr Shekhdar. A 30kg yellowfin tuna jumped into his half-covered boat, but he threw it back. "I don't like killing my friends," he said. The adventure had got off to bad start when the Chilean authorities forbade his departure. Judging it too dangerous, they forced him to travel north to Peru to find more lenient officials. "I've learned that nothing is as difficult as it seems at the start," he said. "I've always believed that if you are going to do something you've got to start and then it will get done but I think you can do anything if you want to." The only time he had been seriously unnerved, he said, was when he drifted within 10 metres of an oil tanker early one morning. "It's the only thing that made me wobbly," he said. "I couldn't sleep for a week after that." www.pacific-challenge-2000.com Pacific challenge 2000 www.oceanrowing.com The Ocean Rowing Society

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 44 Albanian 'guerrillas' held
fields.body:
44 Albanian 'guerrillas' held

German soldiers in the Nato-led K-For peacekeeping force have detained 44 suspected Albanian guerrillas for illegally crossing into southern Kosovo from Macedonia and possessing arms, and handed them over to the UN police in the province, UN officials said yesterday.

The group was arrested just as Macedonia ended its latest offensive against ethnic Albanian guerrillas near the border with Kosovo, bar mopping up operations such as a search for mines.

AFP, Pristina and Reuters, Skopje

Swedes offer asylum to wolf

Sweden has granted "political asylum" to the last surviving wolf of a 10-strong pack hunted down in neighbouring Norway.

The Swedish environ ment ministry yesterday welcomed "Mr Martin" - the name given the wolf by animal rights activists. If he crosses the border "he won't be killed", it said.

AFP, Stockholm

China detains US academic

China has detained an American business professor from Hong Kong, the second academic with US ties to be picked up in the past six weeks, it emerged yesterday.

Li Shaomin, who teaches at the City University of Hong Kong, was detained on February 25 after crossing the border into China, a Hong-Kong-based human rights group said.

AP, Beijing

Two aid workers freed, says UN

Two UN aid workers kidnapped by Somali gunmen were being released in the capital, Mogadishu, and transported to safety in Kenya, but two others remained in captivity, according to the UN last night.

No contact had been made with the two men that remain captive, both Britons kidnapped on Tuesday, the source said.

Reuters, Nairobi

fields.headline: Republican dissident charged in Dublin
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A leading republican dissident was last night charged with directing terrorism and membership of the Real IRA.
fields.body:
A leading republican dissident was last night charged with directing terrorism and membership of the Real IRA.

Michael McKevitt, 51, of Blackrock, near Dundalk, Co Louth, was charged with directing paramilitary activity between August 29, 1999, and October 23, 2000, and belonging to an illegal organisation between August 29,1999 and March 28, 2001.

He spoke only once to confirm his name during the 15-minute hearing at a late sitting at Dublin's non-jury special criminal court, and was remanded in custody to appear again on Tuesday. He is expected to apply for bail.

Irish police arrested Mr McKevitt and his wife, Bernadette, the sister of hunger striker, Bobby Sands, in a dawn swoop on on Thursday morning.

Two other men were also arrested in the Dundalk area in the same operation.

The four were held under special anti-terrorist legislation, which would have allowed them to be detained for 72 hours without charge. But Mrs McKevitt and the two other men have now been released without charge.

Mr and Mrs McKevitt are members of the 32-County Sovereignty Committee, which security sources say is the political wing of the Real IRA, the renegade republican group opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process.

The British and Irish governments introduced tough new anti-terrorist laws after the Omagh bombing in August 1998, in which 29 people died.

Both governments are stepping up their offensive against the Real IRA in the light of increased activity, such as the car bomb outside BBC headquarters in London on March 4, the rocket attack on the MI6 building last September.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: North Yorkshire
fields.body:
Only two anglers have braved the biting, cold wind to cast flies over the waters at Bellflask fishery, north of Ripon. There are no foot and mouth restrictions; the still water fishery is in old gravel pits, surrounded by arable farmland. It has its own access track. The manager, Brian Moreland, is still cheerful, despite the lower number of customers. He tells me of his latest discovery, that badgers are cleaner and tidier creatures than even he had thought. They dig holes a few yards from the sett entrance and use them as regular latrines. Whilst in use, over several days, the latrines remain open, but once full, Brian has noticed that the badgers carefully cover them with earth. He leads me off into the alder carr woodland to show off his discovery.

Inside the wood the badger sett shows signs of recent activity, the latrines are just as Brian has described. Rabbits have grazed off the top points of almost every wild garlic leaf, and we gaze across a sea of truncated spear points. It looks odd.

Our talk turns inevitably to foot and mouth disease and its effects. Brian has been expressing concern at the amount of disinfectant being sloshed around, both in rural villages and the wider countryside. "Folks' natural inclination is to use it at a stronger concentration, just for luck," he says. "A lot of it is running off hard surfaces into ditches and streams. The danger is that it gets into the river system."

Brian remembers the outbreak of 1967. He also recalls that, in the year after, fish such as roach, gudgeon, perch and ruffe disappeared from the river Ure where he lives. "We were told that the roach had died through disease, yet I didn't see a single dead roach floating downstream," he tells me. "I think that phenol-based disinfectant destroyed a lot of the invertebrates."

Maybe Brian is right. Ruffe, a smaller relation of perch, has just started to return to the river Ure. He reckons it has taken 30 years for the river to recover, and that the same could happen again.

fields.headline: Last bid for freedom
fields.standfirst: When the drugs that enabled Michael Holman to function with ParkinsonÕs disease stopped working, he knew time was running out. SO he went to France to undergo pioneering brain surgery, performed without anaesthetic. His friend Michela Wrong witnessed the 11-hour operation Ð and its aftermath
fields.trailText: When the drugs that enabled Michael Holman to function with ParkinsonÕs disease stopped working, he knew time was running out. SO he went to France to undergo pioneering brain surgery, performed without anaesthetic. His friend Michela Wrong witnessed the 11-hour operation Ð and its aftermathv
fields.body:
The neurosurgeon stepped back from the control panel and, for a moment, all went still as we listened to the strange music filling the operating bloc. A river was rushing down a mountain, tumbling in a white frenzy over rocks, cascading into icy green pools. Or so it sounded. In fact we were sharing what must surely count as one of the most intimate of human experiences, more intimate than sex or childbirth: we were listening to Michael's mind, its electrical activity picked up by electrodes plunged deep into his brain.

It sounded like a force of nature: tireless, ceaseless, burbling with energy. But the impression was misleading. For at least the past 16 years, Michael Holman's brain has not functioned as those of other people. That fact explained why we were gathered in a room in Grenoble's university hospital last month, unrecognisable and anonymous in our blue gowns and white masks, listening to his cerebral concerto.

In his late 30s, Michael was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease, an illness which causes the brain to gradually stop producing dopamine, the chemical that transmits the brain's motor instructions to nerves and muscles. For years, like the 120,000 other Parkinson's sufferers in Britain, he had been allowed to lead something approaching a normal life by taking levodopa, the miracle drug discovered in the 1960s which acts as a partial substitute for dopamine.

Watching Michael take levodopa was like witnessing a Jekyll and Hyde metamorphosis. One moment he seemed 100 years old, shaking uncontrollably, shuffling as he walked, a fragile figure just asking to get mugged. Minutes later, as the drug kicked in, he straightened to become the man his friends remembered of old - dynamic, humorous, frighteningly incisive. With one bound, he was free.

Parkinson's, which affects one in 100 people over 65, doesn't kill you. It doesn't - in most cases - even affect your mental faculties. It just destroys your life. The longer you take levodopa, the less effect it has. Side-effects - a squirming known as "dyskinesia", which produces convulsive leg kicks and head movements worthy of a BSE-stricken Friesian - become more pronounced. By last year, Michael's "off" moments, when he would be stuck in a chair, trembling uncontrollably, were heavily outnumbering his "on" moments. Dr Jekyll was making his excuses, and Mr Hyde was taking over.

Early retirement from his job as Africa editor of the Financial Times loomed. Woken in the early hours by his own shuddering, Michael fantasised about a full night's sleep. I would cajole him into going out, only to regret such Panglossian optimism. It is not much fun watching your dining companion becoming rooted to their chair, incapable of lifting fork to mouth without flicking food at the wall. At the cinema, I could feel the split-second when his medication wore off: a gentle trembling would escalate to a full-throttle judder rippling down the row of seats. "One of these days," I'd think, "someone is going to accuse him of wanking and there will be a scene."

Increasingly, Michael simply avoided such awkwardness by staying at home, embarrassed by the stares of strangers who assumed he was drunk. With even holding a book requiring effort, existence was shrinking to a living room and a television screen.

Time was running out, yet none of the available alternatives seemed viable. A lot of excitement was being generated by research into foetal stem cells, injected into patients' brains in the hope that they would start producing dopamine. Earlier this month, crushing the hopes of millions of sufferers around the world, a Columbia University study showed that in 15% of those treated in this way, the outcome was worse than the disease, with the stem cells producing so much dopamine that patients went into uncontrollable, permanent spasms.

Another path was surgery. As far back as the 50s, doctors discovered that destroying part of the brain's basal ganglia, or thalamus, known as "lesioning", relieved many of the symptoms of Parkinson's. But Michael's specialist had long counselled him against this. Once destroyed, the brain cells would be gone for ever, ruling out any possibility of future revival.

Just as this unpalatable prospect was becoming to seem the only option, Michael began hearing about a groundbreaking surgical alternative. Getting details proved extremely difficult. But eventually we learned that neurosurgeon Alim Louis Benabid and neurologist Pierre Pollak, professors based in the French city of Grenoble, had perfected a technique in which two electrodes were inserted inside the subthalamic nucleus, an area deep inside the brain. A battery - installed in the chest like a pacemaker - then sent a low-voltage current into surrounding tissue. For reasons that remained tantalisingly unclear, such stimulation had a similar effect to dopamine.

Crucially, the treatment didn't involve burning away precious brain cells. It was reversible, which meant Michael could benefit if stem-cell treatment proved effective in a few years' time. This wasn't a cure for Parkinson's, we were repeatedly warned. But if it could alleviate the main symptoms, it would already have worked a miracle.

Why go to France? Neurosurgeons in Oxford, Bristol and Dundee were just beginning to carry out deep-brain stimulation. But Professor Benabid was undisputed master in his field, and British operations numbered in the dozens, while Grenoble had carried out over 150. If the waiting list loomed as a major issue - most French patients waited three years for the operation - funding did not. To our complete lack of surprise, Michael had been told by his specialist that the NHS would not pay for the operation, available for free under the French public health system. Whether carried out in Britain or France, the £20,000 procedure would have to be privately funded - in this case by generous FT management.

With Michael ensconced in a room in Grenoble's university hospital, boasting telephone, cable television and a view of the snow-topped Alps, it was swiftly clear we had fallen on our feet. There was none of the bureaucratic chaos or plain, old-fashioned filth experienced in a recent encounter with a London hospital. Wards were spotlessly clean, and staff consideration far greater than strictly necessary. When they said a procedure would be carried out on a particular day, it was - if not the day before. There was a special budget hostel for people visiting patients, a hospital hairdresser selling an impressive range of wigs for the newly operated, a hospital travel agency organising return trips; my God, even the food at the hospital cafe was decent.

"Be prepared. It's no cakewalk," warned a colleague who had watched a friend's father go through the procedure. She was right. But it was actually to prove far less gruelling than expected, an intense, uplifting experience which left me as rapturous and moved as a new father reeling punch-drunk from the delivery room.

In the first of the three operations involved, Michael had his head shaved and five bolts, a little like the screws provided with Ikea shelving, drilled into his skull. The bolts meant he could be literally screwed into a rigid metal frame, ensuring his head was kept stationary during both the main operation itself and a preliminary scan to establish the exact location of Michael's brain structures.

The second operation was the big one; the one teeth were gritted for and spines stiffened over. We had been warned to expect anything up to 20 hours. The previous week, a surgical team had emerged exhausted at three in the morning. Michael would have to be conscious throughout, guiding the surgeons to exactly the right spot with a running commentary on his sensations. The comforting oblivion of anaesthesia was not on offer, but Michael should not feel pain: the brain, paradoxically, does not have much sensation.

With the surgeons' blessing, we had asked if a film director friend could video the procedure and I could take notes. It was a very journalistic way of dealing with personal crisis. But there was also a practical point to the request: a video logged with the Parkinson's Society would help to ensure that others did not repeat our tedious trawl for information. In any case, I wanted to be there as possible interpreter, should Michael find himself struggling to communicate with French staff.

I stayed out of the operating bloc for the first few hours, warned that queasiness was most likely to strike at the start, when the surgeons used a high-pitched drill to pierce the skull. But I was called inside in time to hear the white noise of Michael's mind, picked up by five test electrodes delicately inserted through the hole in one side of his head. It is a sobering experience seeing someone you know splayed on a surgeon's table, blue-shrouded figures hovering, scalpels laid in neat rows. But there was not much blood: after all, not many tissues had been sliced into. Locked into his frame, with a physiotherapist massaging his limbs, Michael seemed cheerful and alert enough.

Over the next few hours it became clear just why the operation took so long. Using what looked like the gadget for lowering a garage door, the neurophysicians sent currents to varying depths along each electrode, painstakingly monitoring Michael's reactions and the suppleness of his joints - floppy when sensitive cells were hit, stiff when the electrode was in the wrong place. "I feel nauseous," he would say. Or: "That was like a strong electric jolt."

For minutes at a time, they would peer at his lips, watching for the slightest of tremors. The area of the brain controlling facial movement is just beyond the target area, so a trembling there was a helpful clue, indicating they had overshot. Once all electrodes had been tested, the team decided which was best positioned, then inserted a permanent one in its place. Working with the delicate precision of a sushi chef, the surgeon first patched the skull hole, then sealed it with dental cement.

If the first insertion went swimmingly, the second seemed more alarming. With one side "fixed", Michael's second side became far more sensitive. The electrical jolts sent his body flipping around on the table like a fish on a marble slab, convulsions rippling down his face. "He's not going be able to take much more of this," I thought as he wiggled and slithered. But as far as the surgeons were concerned, things were going just fine.

Indeed, we finished in just 11 hours - an ultra speedy operation. As he realised that the end was near, Michael got a second wind. Euphoric, he chattered excitedly with the surgeon stitching him about French politics, and as they finally unbolted the metal frame, he was seemingly beside himself with relief, seizing the hands of those he was convinced had released him from a 16-year hell. "The men and women who have imprisoned me have set me free," he said, and I found I had tears in my eyes. I had witnessed something very like a birth - the granting of a new life to a man who had nearly given up.

That night, leaving a hyped-up Michael to rest, I celebrated at a local brasserie with the friend who had videoed the procedure and his French soundman, who impressed us both by coolly ordering tete de veau. Deposited in front of him with a flourish, the tranche of calf's brain was an exact replica of the X-rays of Michael's brain that we had spent the day gazing at with the medical profession's finest. "Don't you think that's a bit inappropriate?" we asked him, aghast.

There was one last operation to go: the installing of a battery the size of a cigarette-lighter below Michael's collarbone, linked to the electrodes via wires snaking invisibly under his skin. Michael then spent a few weeks roaming the hospital in a wrinkled cream cap that made him look rather like an over-sized condom, as the doctors tinkered with medication and battery voltage, adjusted using a mouse held over Michael's chest.

He's not quite there yet. Boasting scars that make it look as though a shark took his head in its mouth, then thought better of it, he still has a slight tremor and does a lot of sleeping. But the dyskinesia is gone, and the interminable periods where Michael shuddered and sweated, unresponsive to drugs, are a thing of the past. He has stopped taking dopamine entirely, and dropped two of his three other key drugs: a change that in itself will save the NHS over £3,000 a year. The fact that a well-paid professional remains a taxpayer, rather than retiring early to claim disability benefit, also means the operation begins to pay its way.

Michael goes back to Grenoble in three months for fine-tuning, by which time his chicklet's fuzz will have grown into real hair. But his voice has already become more forceful: he raps out questions at machine-gun speed, as though determined to make up for years of lost time. He radiates well-being and his joie de vivre has spilled over on to those who love him. "In a way, I feel as though we've all been liberated," a Dutch friend in Kenya said over the phone the other day.

Freedom looms, and with it huge questions. Given the chance to start again, where does a 56-year-old workaholic begin? Will Michael simply put in more hours at the office? Or will he discover Buddhism, go round the world with a backpack, learn to play the piano? Anything seems possible. For the moment, he is planning to retake a long-defunct driving test and talks of a driving holiday. Where would he like to go first? Why, France, of course.

There was a special budget hostel for people visiting patients, a hospital hairdresser selling an impressive range of wigs for the newly operated, a hospital travel agency organising return trips; my God, even the food at the hospital cafe was decent. "Be prepared. It's no cakewalk," warned a colleague who had watched a friend's father go through the procedure. She was right. But it was actually to prove far less gruelling than expected, an intense, uplifting experience which left me as rapturous and moved as a new father reeling punch-drunk from the delivery room. In the first of the three operations involved, Michael had his head shaved and five bolts, a little like the screws provided with Ikea shelving, drilled into his skull. The bolts meant he could be literally screwed into a rigid metal frame, ensuring his head was kept stationary during both the main operation itself and a preliminary scan to establish the exact location of Michael's brain structures. The second operation was the big one; the one teeth were gritted for and spines stiffened over. We had been warned to expect anything up to 20 hours. The previous week, a surgical team had emerged exhausted at three in the morning. Michael would have to be conscious throughout, guiding the surgeons to exactly the right spot with a running commentary on his sensations. The comforting oblivion of anaesthesia was not on offer, but Michael should not feel pain: the brain, paradoxically, does not have much sensation. With the surgeons' blessing, we had asked if a film director friend could video the procedure and I could take notes. It was a very journalistic way of dealing with personal crisis. But there was also a practical point to the request: a video logged with the Parkinson's Society would help to ensure that others did not repeat our tedious trawl for information. In any case, I wanted to be there as possible interpreter, should Michael find himself struggling to communicate with French staff. I stayed out of the operating bloc for the first few hours, warned that queasiness was most likely to strike at the start, when the surgeons used a high-pitched drill to pierce the skull. But I was called inside in time to hear the white noise of Michael's mind, picked up by five test electrodes delicately inserted through the hole in one side of his head. It is a sobering experience seeing someone you know splayed on a surgeon's table, blue-shrouded figures hovering, scalpels laid in neat rows. But there was not much blood: after all, not many tissues had been sliced into. Locked into his frame, with a physiotherapist massaging his limbs, Michael seemed cheerful and alert enough. Over the next few hours it became clear just why the operation took so long. Using what looked like the gadget for lowering a garage door, the neurophysicians sent currents to varying depths along each electrode, painstakingly monitoring Michael's reactions and the suppleness of his joints - floppy when sensitive cells were hit, stiff when the electrode was in the wrong place. "I feel nauseous," he would say. Or: "That was like a strong electric jolt." For minutes at a time, they would peer at his lips, watching for the slightest of tremors. The area of the brain controlling facial movement is just beyond the target area, so a trembling there was a helpful clue, indicating they had overshot. Once all electrodes had been tested, the team decided which was best positioned, then inserted a permanent one in its place. Working with the delicate precision of a sushi chef, the surgeon first patched the skull hole, then sealed it with dental cement. If the first insertion went swimmingly, the second seemed more alarming. With one side "fixed", Michael's second side became far more sensitive. The electrical jolts sent his body flipping around on the table like a fish on a marble slab, convulsions rippling down his face. "He's not going be able to take much more of this," I thought as he wiggled and slithered. But as far as the surgeons were concerned, things were going just fine. Indeed, we finished in just 11 hours - an ultra speedy operation. As he realised that the end was near, Michael got a second wind. Euphoric, he chattered excitedly with the surgeon stitching him about French politics, and as they finally unbolted the metal frame, he was seemingly beside himself with relief, seizing the hands of those he was convinced had released him from a 16-year hell. "The men and women who have imprisoned me have set me free," he said, and I found I had tears in my eyes. I had witnessed something very like a birth - the granting of a new life to a man who had nearly given up. That night, leaving a hyped-up Michael to rest, I celebrated at a local brasserie with the friend who had videoed the procedure and his French soundman, who impressed us both by coolly ordering tete de veau. Deposited in front of him with a flourish, the tranche of calf's brain was an exact replica of the X-rays of Michael's brain that we had spent the day gazing at with the medical profession's finest. "Don't you think that's a bit inappropriate?" we asked him, aghast. There was one last operation to go: the installing of a battery the size of a cigarette-lighter below Michael's collarbone, linked to the electrodes via wires snaking invisibly under his skin. Michael then spent a few weeks roaming the hospital in a wrinkled cream cap that made him look rather like an over-sized condom, as the doctors tinkered with medication and battery voltage, adjusted using a mouse held over Michael's chest. He's not quite there yet. Boasting scars that make it look as though a shark took his head in its mouth, then thought better of it, he still has a slight tremor and does a lot of sleeping. But the dyskinesia is gone, and the interminable periods where Michael shuddered and sweated, unresponsive to drugs, are a thing of the past. He has stopped taking dopamine entirely, and dropped two of his three other key drugs: a change that in itself will save the NHS over £3,000 a year. The fact that a well-paid professional remains a taxpayer, rather than retiring early to claim disability benefit, also means the operation begins to pay its way. Michael goes back to Grenoble in three months for fine-tuning, by which time his chicklet's fuzz will have grown into real hair. But his voice has already become more forceful: he raps out questions at machine-gun speed, as though determined to make up for years of lost time. He radiates well-being and his joie de vivre has spilled over on to those who love him. "In a way, I feel as though we've all been liberated," a Dutch friend in Kenya said over the phone the other day. Freedom looms, and with it huge questions. Given the chance to start again, where does a 56-year-old workaholic begin? Will Michael simply put in more hours at the office? Or will he discover Buddhism, go round the world with a backpack, learn to play the piano? Anything seems possible. For the moment, he is planning to retake a long-defunct driving test and talks of a driving holiday. Where would he like to go first? Why, France, of course.

fields.headline: Sleeping MPs
fields.standfirst: Smallweed on the strange case of  Rip van Howarth
fields.trailText: On the strange case of Rip van Howarth.
fields.body:
Tell you what: this week I discovered a quite amazing story which all the soi-disant investigative journalists seem to have missed: the tale of the Tory MP who fell asleep and stayed that way for a decade. His name is Gerald Howarth. He used to represent Cannock until local people tired of him, and then Aldershot. This Howarth revealed his extraordinary feat last weekend when questioned about the alleged interference of the Queen in the matter of the date of the coming election. "She," said Howarth, "has the prerogative as sovereign to warn the prime minister. The trouble is, we are faced with the most arrogant prime minister I have seen."

So here is a man who never saw Margaret Thatcher! There is only one explanation. When she invented the poll tax, when she steamrollered the wretched thing through despite the fears and warnings of more sensible people, when she abolished great chunks of local government simply because they would not do as they were told, when she told her subjects,"Rejoice! And stop asking awkward questions about what's going on in the Falklands", all of this passed poor old Rip van Howarth by.

JH Judge (Worplesdon, Surrey) writes: I know we have no choice but to stand idly by and endure Smallweed's disgraceful bien-pensant strictures on a great English lady, but is this not a case of straining at a gnat while swallowing a thumping great dromedary? Why does this so-called long-haired soi-disant fail to apply the lash to a Tory MP who refers to our monarch as "she"? As my dear old mother used to say, if I dared to use this formula in referring to her in the third person: " She is the cat's mother."

Smallweed replies with exemplary patience: I'm obliged.

Tell you what: the village of Knapcroft, a mere seven miles from Lutterworth, Leicestershire, has a mineral spring...

A pedant writes: I deprecate Smallweed's practice of constantly repeating the worn-out phrase: tell you what. Can he explain why he is doing it?

Smallweed replies with a sunny smile which reminds us that summer is not far away: Gladly. I have caught it off the football on television. There was a time when the great Alan Hansen was alone in prefacing every fourth or fifth sentence with the words: "tell you what". Then it spread to his centre-back partner, Mark Lawrenson. I have not so far heard it seep from the lips of Lineker, but the practice is clearly infectious, so that's only a matter of time. It cropped up again on the radio commentary on England v Albania. I only wish I had £100 for every time it was used on the airwaves.

Curious (Northowram) writes: What would you do with the money so garnered?

Smallweed replies with his wonted generosity: Why, I'd give it to Halifax Town to purchase a midfield generalissimo to save them from relegation.

Tell you what: from time to time I burrow into the world of dead musicians, usually to investigate the strange way they died. The programme for a recent concert by the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment remarked that Francois-André Danican Phildor, whose work they were playing, was unique amomg composers for being more celebrated as a chess-player than as a musician. To this day, it maintained, Philidor's Defence - a double pawn opening in which Black follows P K-4 with P-Q3 - was widely used and discussed. As to his death, one London newspaper had begun its obituary thus: "On Monday last, Mr Philidor, the celebrated chess player, made his last move, into the other world."

Which reminds me that a curious tale appeared last week of a US expert called Teresa Marrin Nakra who has made a jacket for conductors to wear while they learn to conduct. When a novice performs correctly, all is well. When he or she departs from best practice (which Dr Nakra has very rightly defined as that adopted by Sir Simon Rattle) discomfort will follow. I have to say I dislike this kind of behaviour, which encourages crass conformity. The apprentice conductor, we're told, must use the left hand to signal volume and expression, and the right hand to bear time. Is this not unncessarily limiting (especially for those who conduct left-handed, like Penderecki?). I weep to think how such straitjacketing might have constrained the great, if eccentric, Austrian composer Hans von Krug, whose conducting style was so heavily influenced by his passion - unusual in any Austrian - for cricket. The great cartwheeling of his right arm, his principal trademark, was based, he used to telladmirers, on the bowling action of the great Australian Clarrie Grimmett, while the sudden violent thrusts of his outsize baton, one of which in a Queen's Hall concert in 1937 pierced the handsome embonpoint of one of his first violins, were based on the batting of Bradman. Moreover...

A pedant writes: Are we not in the realms of fantasy here?

Smallweed meekly concedes: Perhaps. You may, however, trust every golden word of what I say about Philidor.

The symbol consists of a foot (left) and a quaver. Semiquavers may be used if preferred, or even demisemiquavers, but the use of a breve is not recommended.

Smallweed@theguardian.com

fields.headline: A star is born
fields.standfirst: Alina Cojocaru, the Royal Ballet's hottest property, talks to  Judith Mackrell
fields.trailText: Alina Cojocaru, the Royal Ballet's hottest property, talks to Judith Mackrell
fields.body:
In a huge rehearsal studio at the Royal Opera House, Alina Cojocaru is learning the choreography of her latest role, Giselle. Dominated by the vastness of the room, she seems more like an earnest student than one of the company's most hotly tipped ballerinas. One leg of her training pants is rolled to the knee showing a disregarded ladder snaking down the tights beneath. Her serious face is scrubbed as plain as an old-fashioned school girl. But as soon as she dances the choreography full out, her tiny body grows with the music. Her delicate arms lengthen, her legs soar and hover. It is the kind of transformation that makes thosewatching guess she could be fabulous on the night.

The fact that Cojocaru is dancing this iconic role aged only 19 might in itself seem newsworthy, given that she last appeared in the ballet several months ago as an anonymous member of the corps de ballet. But for anyone who has followed her career since she joined the Royal Ballet in November 1999, this is just one more debut to add to a remarkable list.

The first came 13 months ago when Cojocaru suddenly appeared in the lead role of Frederick Ashton's Symphonic Variations - taking over at five day's notice. No one knew who she was but by the interval everyone in the theatre was asking how to pronounce her name. Not only had she just demonstrated a rare instinct for the poetry and music of this elusive role, but the quality of her stage presence was uncannily reminiscent of the ballerina who had created it, Margot Fonteyn.

Last December another injured dancer caused Cojocaru to be bumped up the cast lists - dancing Clara on the opening night of The Nutcracker in a performance that was also televised. Yet another injury in February resulted in her making a debut as Juliet, learning this huge role in only eight days.

By then it was not only apparent that Cojocaru was a quick study but that technically there was little she could not do. All of this makes Cojocaru's story sound as if it has been scripted for a little girl's ballet book, as if she has been marked out by the ballet fairies for stardom. Off stage, she has the demeanour of a deserving Cinderella, so modest that when she walks down the corridor with me after rehearsal she ducks her head slightly as if apologising for taking up space. But as soon as she starts talking, it is obvious that ambition runs down her spine like solid steel. She is a dancer in control of her destiny.

Cojocaru first took ballet classes in her native Romania, but when she was nine talent scouts offered her a place at the Kiev Ballet School. Even though this was a 27-hour train ride away, Cojocaru and her parents did not hesitate and she went to study there for the next seven years.

At 17 she won an award at the Prix de Lausanne, which paid for six months' study at the Royal Ballet School in London. But the Ukrainians kept an eye on their prodigy and before Cojocaru's time in London was over asked her to dance with the Kiev Ballet. The Royal offered her a contract too. But while Britain was inviting her to join only at corps de ballet level, Ukraine was offering her principal status. For an ambitious teenager there was no contest.

Cojocaru thus spent a year dancing a repertoire that most dancers only fantasise about - Aurora, Kitri, Cinderella - but being centre stage was not her only aim. She was hungry for a much wider range of ballets, and knowing the Royal Ballet's varied repertory she sent her CV asking for an audition.

Monica Mason, the Royal's assistant director, says that "when Alina was in the school, everyone obviously recognised she was a special talent, so of course we were delighted when she wanted to come back to us". Cojocaru still had to enter at corps de ballet level but while she admits it was odd for her to be dancing in line for the first time - "it is very difficult trying to be in the same style as everyone else, but still keeping your individuality" - she maintains it was never a blow to her ego. "You get a much bigger sense of the stage, of the whole ballet when you are in the corps than when you are a soloist." And it is clear that she never expected to be in the corps for long. While some dancers use their daily class as a gentle warm up, Cojocaru treated it as a performance. "I danced class, I didn't just do it. I worked really hard so I supposed I would be noticed." And so she was, getting her first principal role within three months.

Cojocaru was scared her rapid success might cause resentment in the corps, but even though ballet is predicated on a climate of open competition, dancers always respect hard work. As Mason says, "when a talent is really special, everyone recognises it". So when Cojocaru performed her first Juliet she says she "never felt so much support" in her life. "The wings were crowded with people watching me and everyone wished me luck." She loses herself momentarily in the memory. "It had always been my dream to dance this role. I loved everything in it. I don't have words to describe how I felt."

The only flaw in that perfect night was the absence of her family, who had no time to arrange a visa. Cojocaru's physical delicacy makes her look too young to be cut off from her sister and parents. You want to put her in your pocket. Her English is fluent and she has good friends with whom she goes to the cinema and out for meals. But much of her free time is spent reading, listening to music and watching films. Everything feeds in to her work, especially studying the way actors work. "I want to make my acting as natural as possible," she says. When she was preparing for Juliet she went through the whole ballet making up dialogue for each scene and acting it out in front of the mirror.

Cojocaru would talk all day about ballet if you let her - about why she is trying to wean herself off hard pointe shoes, about why she prefers act one of Giselle to act two. But she is neither a bore nor a prig. She is funny, animated and happy about her work - it is her hobby as well her cause. She loves the fact that it allows her "to be so many things on stage" - not only the virginal maidens of classical ballet but most recently a sluttish babe in Ashley Page's This House Will Burn. ("I was so happy to be in that ballet, to get the chance to show that there was another way for me.") All she asks now is to remain in the Royal and learn many new roles. Later on she hopes to guest with other companies to meet new people and be around different companies even if they are very small".

Technically, it is easy to imagine Cojocaru maturing into a dancer who could pick and choose whatever role she wanted. Barring injury, burnout or personal wobbles she could well be phenomenal. What is harder to imagine is Cojocaru flaunting all the trappings that would come with international stardom. The fairy-tale successes of modern ballerinas are now coupled with photo shoots in Vogue, glossy advertising deals and spreads in Hello, none of which seem remotely part of her world. Cojocaru's modesty, stoicism and passion are unfashionable virtues, learned in the austerity of eastern Europe. It could be fascinating to see how they adapt to the fashion-led climate of western celebrity.

 Alina Cojocaru makes her debut in Giselle at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020-7304 4000), on April 14.

fields.headline: Keep your hands to yourselves
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Once, admitting to being a sex maniac meant a sojourn at a psychiatric hospital where the only things guaranteed to brighten up your day were bromide enemas. Sex maniacs, often dressed in raincoats, ravished unsuspecting women on country paths or flashed at them on secluded side streets. They lured children from swing parks with promises of sweets. They lurked in dark alleys and hung about at bus stations.

Now, confessing to being a sex maniac is greeted with whoops of delight. Sex mania is the new chastity. If you are not a sex maniac, there is something suspect about you. In fact, you might as well be Ann Widdecombe because if you don't start going at it, you are going to start looking like her. Then no one will want you and you will have to take refuge in a bottle of gin with only a house full of cats and towers of newspapers for company. Not liking sex is akin to not liking chips or Harry Potter. In short, it is wrong.

Hence, Stuart and Emma admit with great glee to being "self-confessed sex maniacs". The couple, who have only been married six months after a three year relationship, have agreed to take part in Can You Live Without... Sex? (Channel 4) to ascertain whether they rely too much on sex within their relationship. So a film crew move in, set up CCTV cameras in their boudoir, build them single beds just far enough apart to prevent midnight fumbling (unless Stuart is secretly Inspector Gadget) and film the results. In the end we watched cheap voyeurism masquerading as a social experiment. They are pretty predictable, though not without some jollity.

With no physical contact allowed, the couple resort to age-old coping mechanisms. Stuart spends a lot of time with his male friends playing snooker and on an exercise bike talking about sex, while Emma eats lots of chocolate and stops brushing her hair (thus proving the Ann Widdecombe thesis). While Emma becomes snappish and sullen, Stuart shows his male fear of growing old. He does this, rather strangely, by holding a winceyette nightie up to himself. We can only assume he is also frightened of becoming a transvestite in later life.

Firstly, the whole premise of the format is to see whether individuals can do without something they view as essential. With sex, this premise is undermined when you realise that in another 12 months the pair will stop having sex - with each other, at least - entirely of their own volition because they will have been married for 18 months. The people who tried to live without their secretaries or their make-up will still be employing them.

Secondly, who would agree to participate in such a programme? Sure, Stuart is a mobile phone salesman but he can't be completely devoid of shame. Emma looks like a nice girl, albeit one with dodgy tastes in decor. What possible motive could you have for going on television to proclaim you are not having sex (other than to maintain that you had loads of sex before)? Could it be that the pair will go to any lengths to get on the telly? Will they do anything for their 22 minutes of fame? One thing is certain - if either of them ever pops up on Michael Barrymore's My Kind of Music, we will know it was all a scam.

But lastly, the biggest flaw of all with Can You Live Without... Sex? is this: Stuart and Emma say they spend around 25 hours a month having sex. Does that really qualify as sex mania? Young people today - no stamina.

Nell McAndrew narrated from the back of a moped in her best 0898 voice, but the "red-hot lipstick lesbian action" (pole dancing, snogging, wearing not very much and posing on a motorbike) was as appealing as sticking pins in your eyes. Surely there can't be anyone who seriously gets their kicks from stuff like this? For goodness' sake, buy yourself some proper porn.

webTitle: Ian Mayes on mass email campaigns

fields.headline: Lobby fodder
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the use of mass email campaigns
fields.trailText: On the use of mass email campaigns.
fields.body:
With the electronic media has come the electronic lobby. We are still not quite sure how to respond to it. We have encountered it now in a number of causes: the Guardian's alleged unfairness to the Blair government in the early months after the election (I dispute that there was a significant lobby at work there but some of my colleagues disagree); the alleged demonisation of the Serbian people in our coverage of the war over Kosovo; and most recently and most vigorously the paper's alleged anti-Israeli prejudice. The pro-Arab or pro-Palestinian lobby, which exists, is not on anything like such a large scale.

The pro-Israel lobby - that is what it is in intent if not always in effect - can mean two or three hundred organised emails piling into a queue in the paper in the space of a few hours and threatening to clog up the works.

Lobby emails, on any issue, are usually easy to recognise. Very often they simply follow a pattern provided by the organiser, but variations usually retain headings or phrases from the original which clearly indicate their source. Some newspapers after sampling a couple erase the rest unread.

The New York Times, which I visited recently, has been coping with one lobby accusing the paper of minimising "the protests surrounding the presidential inauguration". The paper's recorded message on its reader comment line, says: "If you're calling as an individual about a correction, or with a coverage question we can answer - and not as part of a group campaign - we will try to reply."

The comment editor of the Guardian wrote about the pro-Israel lobby on his pages a few weeks ago tracing one significant part of it to an organisation based in London. His section is a favourite target. The letters page of the Guardian is another. In both cases, you might fairly say, well, they would be. Individual journalists who write about the Middle East in the Guardian are also bombarded with emails, some abusive in the extreme. The most abusive are reserved for colleagues who are Jewish.

The comment editor is now reluctant to provide email addresses at the end of pieces which might provoke what he calls hate mail. He feels that the experience of the past weeks has strengthened the case for a parallel email network to ensure that messaging around the office is not jeopardised by the mass invasion of personal queues.

The lesson of lobbies of this kind, on this scale, is that they are perceived by most of those on the receiving end, not as the bearers of reasonable argument but as bullying and inhibiting to real debate. The message is seen to be the threatening weight of numbers.

These lobbies have been described to me as potentially counter-productive by others seeking to promote Israeli views by different means. One said that the noise created by this stimulated clamour of voices crowding in all together was drowning out attempts at more reasonable discourse. An organisation which seeks to promote Arab views, and which uses what might be called selective email lobbying, says that if it saw signs that the mass-email lobby was succeeding, it would certainly change its own tactics to do the same.

Each side in the present conflict in the Middle East has accused the Guardian of favouring the other. Some journalists say, that is OK then, we must be getting it right if both sides are complaining. The other possibility, as another colleague pointed out, was that we were getting it wrong in both directions.

One of the problems for the paper is that lobbies, large or small, almost always include a great many people who do not normally read the Guardian, whose attention has been drawn to a particular report or article in the paper and who therefore see it removed from the context of the Guardian's coverage as a whole. They are unaware, perhaps, of one important fact, that the comment pages always, but especially with reference to conflicts (the Gulf war, the wars in former Yugoslavia for example), seek to provide a platform for the widest range of opinion. They do that independently of the Guardian's leader line.

The editor had this in mind when he formulated a model email of his own, to be used at the discretion of Guardian journalists, to reply to senders of emails criticising the paper's Israel coverage. In it he rejects any accusation that the coverage "indicates a strong bias against Israel". He lists commentators from all sides of the conflict, and concludes: "I believe the paper has distinguished itself in the depth, range and breadth of its reporting and commentary."

Whether we like it or not, the email lobby is here to stay. It is a natural product of a democratic medium. If I thought it worth saying in a situation which generates such high passion, I would add, "But please, let's be reasonable."

webTitle: An exotic link to the KGB's toxic umbrella

fields.headline: An exotic link to the KGB's toxic umbrella
fields.trailText: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.body:
The popular and interesting tropical look that has returned to our gardens, giving a place for certain flamboyant plants which might previously have failed a taste test, is the result of an ingenious mix and match. It does not resemble a real tropical garden very closely. Rather, it gives an impression of lush colourfulness and rampant growth, using whatever plant material suits the fantasy of the designer.

When an actual habitation is established in your actual tropics, the first plants to surround the house will be economic staples such as coconut, banana, bamboo and papaya. None of these will perform for us in their tropical varieties, although papaya grows so fast from seed it would be worth trying in the conservatory. Real bananas are always grown from offsets.

The first ornamental plants to grace an actual tropical garden are the same the whole world round (tropical gardens can pall after a while): bougainvillea, hibiscus and some sort of impatiens will be sure evidence of human habitation. Orchids hanging under the eaves, or tied on to tree trunks, will show that the garden has passed stage one. But often this is as far as things will go. Barrio gardens are seldom very elaborate, just as cottage gardens, in the days of cottagers, were much less fancy than legend suggests.

Two flowers of use in the temperate garden, both of which can be grown from seed, are widespread in the tropics. The first is Lantana camara , a small shrub with bright flower heads in a mixture of red, orange and yellow. A kind of verbena, it has become a roadside weed in the tropics. Thompson and Morgan offers , Lantana Camara Mixed Hybrids (no 86) while Chiltern Seeds has a dwarf version. The second is No 87, the familiar Thunbergia alata , Black-eyed Susan, available from both catalogues, a small climber sold here for hanging baskets. The best easily available photographic reference book for tropical flowers is the two-volume Conservatory and Indoor Plants by Roger Phillips and Martyn Rix (Pan), a work somewhat mislabelled since it is full of photographs of plants in their natural habitats. Two pages of Thunbergias here are enough to provoke the appetite for a flower, climbing or trailing, which turns out, surprisingly, to be an acanthus relative.

Fundamental to any genuine tropical look are the banana-like, large-leaved heliconias, cannas and ginger lilies. The normal way would be to buy these as plants, but cannas in particular can be raised from seed: Canna indica , Indian Shot (no 88), is offered again by both catalogues. Cannas don't have to be grown in borders. In the tropics they grow in water very happily, for instance, at the edge of a pond, and this is where they can be placed during summers here. Cannas started from fresh seed collected in a garden last summer look fair to flower for us this year.

Last year a friend of mine planted a packet of Melianthus major (no 89) seed from Chilterns. Of 12, 10 germinated. She kept two plants, gave one to us and sold the rest, thereby ending the year both popular and in profit. Melianthus is grown in these "tropical" schemes for its glaucous foliage. Left out of doors it may well survive the winter but it will not flower: the English year does not offer enough heat for it.

But Phillips and Rix shows us what it looks like flowering in California, with tall spikes of chocolate flowers in spring (August-September in its native South Africa). What gardeners in England have turned into a herbaceous perennial is by nature a tall, rangy shrub beloved of sunbirds. We are now experimenting with other members of the family, including M comosus (Chilterns). They germinate easily.

Naranjilla (no 90) another of the lost crops of the Incas I mentioned last week, will grow out of doors if given a good start in the greenhouse. Solanum quitoense (Chilterns) is its name, and you want it to grow to six feet. But even if it doesn't get that far, it will interest you with its bright, purple-veined leaves. Supposing it to have ripened its golfball-sized fruit, you can spread the unstrained pulp on your Guatemalan-style cheesecake!

Another Solanum, No 91, goes under the name of Poroporo or Large Kangaroo Apple. This is S laciniatum , a raffish, cut-leaved job with egg-shaped fruit, also edible. The whole solanum family seems to have this ambiguous, not entirely respectable, either edible or poisonous (or both, like the potato) character.

Distinctly poisonous is the castor oil plant (no 92), Ricinus communis , source of the poison (ricin) in the famous umbrella murder by the KGB of Georgi Markov, a Bulgarian novelist and journalist in London in 1978. Mrs M Grieve, in A Modern Herbal (Penguin reprint), gives a vivid Victorian account of a scientist inadvertently half killing himself with it. It is a Mediterranean plant which has been in English gardens for perhaps half a millennium, but that doesn't stop it looking tropical. We have had best success with a variety called gibsoni .

Marvel of Peru, Mirabilis jalapa (no 93) was deemed marvellous for producing different coloured flowers on the same plant. It gave its other name, Four O'Clock, to the family of Nyctaginaceae . Unless you can grow bougainvillea, which is improbable in Britain, you won't have many other Nyctaginaceae in your collection, so why not this easy subtropical weed?

A tropical-style border featured in the current issue of the Garden features the Chinese foxglove, Rehmannia angulata (no 94). We grow this among the roses, where it does not look out of place. Along the same lines, and perhaps more exciting, is Isoplexis isabelliana (no 95) (Chilterns) or, from Thompson and Morgan, I sceptrum . The last three share a page in Phillips and Rix, volume two.

 Thompson & Morgan, Poplar Lane, Ipswich, Suffolk IP8 3BU or www.thompson-morgan.com. Chiltern Seeds, Bortree Stile, Ulverston, Cumbria LA12 7PB or www.chilternseeds.co.uk

webTitle: MPs call for reuse of old graves

fields.headline: MPs call for reuse of old graves
fields.standfirst: Burying up to five bodies in each plot is the only way to beat overcrowding in cemeteries, says Commons committee
fields.trailText: Burying up to five bodies in each plot is the only way to beat overcrowding in cemeteries, says Commons committee.
fields.body:
Old graves should be reused to solve the looming crisis of overcrowding in cemeteries, a committee of MPs said yesterday after conducting the first inquiry into burials and cemeteries for 150 years. Their chairman accused the government of neglecting a problem which "shamed" society and showed a "lack of respect for the dead".

The controversial practice - common in other European countries but illegal in Britain - should be legislated for immediately, the Commons environment sub-committee said. Several London boroughs had run out of burial spaces while others would soon be full.

A system known as "lift and deepen" would mean remains were exhumed after a set period and then reinterred with up to five burials on top. The Home Office - which refused to publish a 1998 consultation paper on the issue - has shied away from it out of concern for public sensitivity.

The committee said there was no alternative to the proposal. Its report criticised local government minister Hilary Armstrong, who told the committee it was "difficult to come to the conclusion that there is a problem everywhere" and suggested it was not established there was a serious problem.

The report said: "[She] did not seem particularly keen to impress upon us that her department was taking the issues surrounding cemeteries seriously as part of the government's vision of an urban renaissance. The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions should make clear its recognition that the problems facing cemeteries should be addressed, and their contribution appreciated, when developing urban policy."

The committee chairman, Andrew Bennett, Labour MP for Denton and Reddish, said: "We were taken aback by the sheer magnitude of the problems facing our cemeteries.

"The problem of underfunding has been exacerbated by poorly trained staff, confused legislative responsibility, and neglect by both central and local government. The result is unsafe, littered, vandalised and unkempt cemeteries which shame all society in their lack of respect for the dead and the bereaved."

Describing the almost complete failure of public authorities to rectify this as inexcusable, the report also attacked ministers' "hands-off approach" for giving local authorities "carte blanche to treat cemeteries as the lowest of low priorities."

"The Home Office and the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions cannot be allowed to abdicate responsibility for ensuring that this service is managed in an effective manner and the most basic standards met."

Last night, the Home Office said it would be launching a wider consultation exercise this year to research public attitudes into the issues surrounding burials and establishing an advisory group before looking at whether to change the law. The department said any change would come from the Home Office, while responsibility for cemeteries lay with local and not central government.

During the inquiry, the committee heard from 120 organisations and individuals concerned with the burial business, including a chartered town planner from the Greater London authority, Giles Dolphin, who warned the problem of overcrowding was "urgent in two thirds of Greater London and in some parts, past urgent. There's a crisis looming."

With 28% of the population still opting to be buried rather than cremated, reuse of graves that were at least 75 years old "would virtually guarantee that London could bury its dead within existing cemetery boundaries," he added.

But Douglas Davies, a theology professor from Durham University, told the committee graves should be reused after 50 years, favoured by 23% in a survey of 1,600 people.

Yesterday's report also advised people to apply for National Lottery funding to improve their local graveyards and called for an inspectorate to be established.

The committee chairman, Andrew Bennett, Labour MP for Denton and Reddish, said: "We were taken aback by the sheer magnitude of the problems facing our cemeteries. "The problem of underfunding has been exacerbated by poorly trained staff, confused legislative responsibility, and neglect by both central and local government. The result is unsafe, littered, vandalised and unkempt cemeteries which shame all society in their lack of respect for the dead and the bereaved." Last night, the Home Office said it would be launching a wider consultation exercise this year to research public attitudes into the issues surrounding burials and establishing an advisory group before looking at whether to change the law. The department said any change would come from the Home Office, while responsibility for cemeteries lay with local and not central government. During the inquiry, the committee heard from 120 organisations and individuals concerned with the burial business, including a chartered town planner from the Greater London authority, Giles Dolphin, who warned the problem of overcrowding was "urgent in two thirds of Greater London and in some parts, past urgent. There's a crisis looming." With 28% of the population still opting to be buried rather than cremated, reuse of graves that were at least 75 years old "would virtually guarantee that London could bury its dead within existing cemetery boundaries," he added. But Douglas Davies, a theology professor from Durham University, told the committee graves should be reused after 50 years, favoured by 23% in a survey of 1,600 people. Yesterday's report also advised people to apply for National Lottery funding to improve their local graveyards and called for an inspectorate to be established.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: 'I'll be back one day, never fear,' trills Fred, relieved now he has dumped me
fields.trailText: 'I'll be back one day, never fear,' trills Fred, relieved now he has dumped me
fields.body:
Once upon a time, there was a boy called Harry who...' No! Wait! Name Harry off-limits, obviously. My agent is expecting me to send him a children's story. I must try - without unfortunate overtones - to think of an animal and a child having an adventure. Come to think of it, that describes with spooky accuracy the early years of my marriage.

I was a mere child when I wed. Sigh over old photo of our wedding. Gordon in loons, kipper tie and yard-long hair, myself in medieval-style Biba gown and panda eyes. If only I was 23 again! I'd cancel the wedding, for a start. Gordon's subsequent marriage - to Elaine - seems to be giving the odd palsied twitch. Perhaps it is not moribund after all. Once it became clear that Elaine's old house and outbuildings might be of interest to a developer, Gordon went off with her to see people about it. When a man says "I could never go back to that bloody woman", it usually means he's just about to.

Aunt Elspeth brings out her photos, too, and pores over curling sepia imagery. "Look, Dulcie: herrre I am on my motherrr's knee." Peer through the shadowy grains of time at teenage girl holding bonny babe. "She was so young." Aunt strokes the image of her mother with an ancient, twig-like finger. Women are like Russian dolls, each containing generations. "I'd give anything to talk to motherrr again." Aunt brushes away a tear. "Perhaps you will, Elspeth."

Intrigued by accounts of near death experiences in which people meet their grannies, then make an excuse and leave, so they can get back to the life of the body. Quite like visiting Granny when she was still alive. Admire Great Aunt in her babyhood, bald in cotton frock. Recall delicious floury, milky smell of babies' heads. Can't wait for grandchild to dandle, or failing that, co-operative ginger kitten.

"Once upon a time there was a little girl called Elspeth..." But then what? I used to be able to write children's stories, when Henry and Harriet were small. But they have made the transition from folksongs to fucksongs. Perhaps when I am a granny I shall rediscover Once Upon A Time. But now, experience sudden urge to clean the windows.

"Mum?" Harriet approaches me as I am shaking the Windolene. We are alone in the kitchen. She leans in close and whispers, "I think I'm, like, pregnant." "What?! Are you sure? Have you done a pregnancy test?" "Yeah, it was, like, positive." Collapse on to chair and gasp violently. "Hey! Mum! No need for stress!" I turn on her: "No need for stress?! Giimmeeaglassawater!" Harriet obliges, looking pale. "Who's the father?" I croak.

Harriet cringes. "It was just an April Fool, Mum. Honest! Right?" Mind reels. "We're all telling our mums, just for a laugh. I didn't know you'd freak out." Give her withering look, and stride out clutching my Windolene. Attempt to remove fossilised deposits of birdshit from windows by frantic scrubbing. Therapeutic after my pregnancy scare. No grandchild yet, thank God! Forget all that about the smell of babies' heads. Give myself aversion therapy by recalling the smell of their arses.

"Mum! Fred's on the phone!" Rush indoors. Perhaps Fred is now recovered enough from his appendix operation to offer me a convalescent weekend in, say, Bath. After thanking me for the flowers and get well card, he hesitates and sounds a bit shifty. "Listen, Dulcie, I'm, er, going to be out of the country for a while. This guy in San Francisco has a gallery and he's in urgent need of a bit of inward investment." Not sure whether this is some gay sex code or a financial deal, but wish him well. "I'll be back one day, never fear!" trills Fred, relieved now he has dumped me.

Hang up pretending I'm relieved. What next? Children's story or housework? Decide to clean the mirrors, though irritated by old hag trying to help from the other side. "Wipe it on, Windolene, Wipe it off, Windolene..." Fragment of folksong haunts the memory. Mirror looks worse than before: bleary and smeary. Realise I have deposited birdshit on it from the windows outside. Sigh, and return, without confidence, to Once Upon A Time...

fields.headline: Bob Huntley
fields.standfirst: Detective whose 'close England' order captured IRA bombers
fields.trailText: Commander Bob Huntley, who has died aged 81, was an heroic figure within the Metropolitan police. A classic "thief-taker", the accolade most prized by officers, his exploits led the Daily Express to hail him in 1972 as the "Nation's Number One Gangbuster".
fields.body:
During the chaos of the early 1970s, when England was under seige from a concerted IRA bombing campaign, a quietly spoken detective from a mining village in Northumberland became the best known policeman in the country and embodied Scotland Yard's determination to tackle terrorism head on.

Commander Bob Huntley, who has died aged 81, was an heroic figure within the Metropolitan police. A classic "thief-taker", the accolade most prized by officers, his exploits led the Daily Express to hail him in 1972 as the "Nation's Number One Gangbuster".

He was also in charge of the anti-terrorist squad in 1973 when 10 people were arrested hours after leaving four huge car bombs in the capital, becoming famous for his "close England" edict which caught the culprits before they fled the country.

He was peripherally involved in the investigations into the Guildford pub bombings, and the blowing up of an army coach on the M62 in 1972, which led to the jailing of Judith Ward.

Though not responsible for either investigation, his faith that the terrorists had been caught, and his withering assessments of their acumen, were anathema to miscarriage of justice campaigners.

In his book, Bomb Squad, which was published after he left the service in 1975, Huntley controversially described the zeal with which terrorist suspects had squealed on each other, and ridiculed them for their silly errors and amateurish mistakes. He denied that torture and beating had ever been used by the police to extract a confession.

Born in Ashington, Northumberland, Huntley left school at 14 and started work as a time-keeper at the local colliery, rising to chief clerk two years later.

He moved to London to join the Met, but his early career was interrupted by the second world war. He spent four years in the RAF as a navigator and flew 40 missions, mainly dropping supplies in Europe and the Middle East.

Returning to the police in 1945, he rose steadily up the ranks to become a detective inspector, and ultimately a commander in 1967.

By then, he had already been awarded the British Empire Medal for tackling a gunman in the Cuckoo Club, Fulham, who had threatened to shoot guests. Huntley threw himself over a table to grab the gunman's arm before he had a chance to pull the trigger. The pistol was loaded with three bullets.

This incident led Huntley to believe that arming the police was unnecessary.

During his career, he received 26 commissioner's commendations and one high commendation.

When Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist division, then known as the Bomb Squad, was formed in 1971 under his supervision, Huntley was already in charge of "CI Department", which dealt with murder, arsons, rackets, fraud and forgery.

He admitted he liked a good murder. "That's the big one," he said. "There is a particular satisfaction about solving a tricky murder case. For a start you must go into it with an open mind. You must never neglect the obvious and chase red-herrings."

It was Huntley's order to "close England" which won him most fame.

In the early hours of March 8 1973, IRA terrorists had planted four bombs in London - outside New Scotland Yard, the Old Bailey, the army recruiting office at Great Scotland Yard and the British Forces Broadcasting Services Offices in Dean Stanley Street.

The vehicles, which had been driven to the capital from Liverpool docks, were due to detonate at 3pm, giving the terrorists enough time to flee Heathrow on a 9am flight to Dublin.

During a routine patrol, officers noticed that a car containing one of the devices did not have a tax disc and seemed to have false number plates. The bomb was defused and Huntley, suspecting other bombs had been planted in London, ordered every force in the UK to effectively "close England" to catch the terrorists before they got away.

Special Branch officers at Heathrow boarded a Dublin-bound flight shortly before it was due to take off and arrested two men. Other members of the group, which became known as the Belfast Ten, were waiting for a later flight and were also seized.

A telephone warning which gave muddled details about the location of the other three bombs, was received at 2pm, but the police could not find and defuse them in time. More than 220 people were injured in the blasts, some seriously.

Nine of the Belfast Ten were convicted. Huntley was not in favour of capital punishment. "Hang an IRA man, and you spawn a martyr," he said.

Though he was at the sharp end of policing for 30 years, he never seemed to lose his appetite for the next case. "I'm not supposed to acknowledge criminal brilliance," he said. "But there are times when even we have to admire the ingenuity of a well-planned crime. That's exactly why we can't afford to sit on our past glories."

His wife, Dorothy Kelly, died last year. They had one son.

 Commander Robert Huntley, policeman, born August 1 1919; died March 5 2001
