fields.headline: Estate of grace
fields.standfirst: Goodbye grim tower block; so long seedy low-rise - modern social housing is enjoying a wondrous renaissance. About time, too, says Pamela Buxton
fields.trailText: Goodbye grim tower block; so long seedy low-rise - modern social housing is enjoying a wondrous renaissance. About time, too, says Pamela Buxton
fields.body:
"You feel like you're guinea pigs," says Ronald Woolston, one of the first inhabitants of the Greenwich Millennium Village, which is taking shape rapidly on the once-barren peninsula cupping the Millennium Dome.

Not that he nor his wife Janice mind being experiments - they're too busy enjoying the benefits of their state-of-the-art, energy-conscious home, complete with hi-tech power points which provide instant internet plus television and telephone through a single socket, floor-to-ceiling windows and double-glazing.

But this is not one of the many luxury penthouses that pepper London's Docklands. It is social housing, for rent at just £75.58 per week - no more than the Woolstons paid for their council house on a hectic nearby estate.

Social housing has finally started to challenge the traditional stereotypes. Local authorities, in partnership with housing associations, have taken the best lessons learnt by architects and realised them as an investment. Forget the grim tower blocks and bland, shoddy, low-rises of the past. This new social housing is typified by contemporary design, energy-efficiency and "flexible living" (the buzzwords of modern architecture) within a high-quality environment.

The change has been social, as well as architectural. Social housing is no longer segregated off on estates; it is "pepper-potted" in among private homes. Adjustment has to come from both sides.

At the Greenwich Millennium Village, social housing will eventually make up 20% of the properties. The Woolstons' house, rented through Moat Housing Association, is one of the first to be built. It is one of eight, two- and three-bed homes with identical designs to some of the nearby private homes on the market. The Woolstons' timber-framed house, designed by London architects Proctor Matthews, is clad in a colourful combination of modular aluminium, cedar and blue render panels, and topped with an aluminium roof.

Ceilings are 20cm higher than average to give a more spacious interior - also helped by the generous glazed windows that blur the boundary with the outside. Everything is built around an open-plan design, to accommodate changing tenants' needs throughout their lives. There are wide corridors and doorways to allow wheelchairs, and a rubber-floored toilet downstairs, plumbed to take a shower if the ground floor needs to be converted to include a bedroom.

For the Woolstons, who are coming up to retirement age, the new two-bedroom house is a blessing after their three-storey council house where the kitchen was on a different floor to the dining room.

"We just wanted a smaller place. We're not getting any younger and I don't want all those stairs," says Janice, tired of putting her dinner on a tray to carry up to the lounge and delighted with the spacious layout of her new home.

"It's the best house we've had," adds Ronald. "It's a step up from what councils normally build - a bit more thought has gone into it."

Despite living on a construction site while the rest of the village is built, the couple are glad of the peace and quiet after the rowdy estate they lived on before. "It's so lovely and warm, even when it's cold outside. We've only used two radiators since we've been here," says Janice. The heating bills are only £70 a quarter, thanks to good insulation, energy-efficient appliances and low-cost electricity from a combined heat and power plant.

This kind of energy-efficient design has infiltrated social housing across the country. At the recently completed Millennium Homes development, in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, green issues were at the heart of a design for 15 new houses built for Tewkesbury Borough Council and Gloucestershire Housing Association. Architects Cater Day won awards for a design featuring a "sunspace" on each house that resembles a giant conservatory. This acts as a passive solar collector, supplemented by solar panels in the steel roof that help to heat the water. Heat is retained in the highly-insulated timber-framed structure. These measures, along with water-saving bathroom equipment and energy-saving lighting, have already yielded dividends for the tenants.

Resident Sharon Deniss is delighted with her new home, especially her bills, which like the Woolstons' are much lower than she'd been used to. "The houses are absolutely super - there's plenty of space in them. I've had my first gas bill and it's certainly a lot cheaper."

With two daughters, she appreciates the flexibility of the spacious 6.4m by 4.2m living room, and plans to put in glass partitions to create play and quiet areas. The house abuts the pavement, and she feels happier with her 3.3m sun porch now that she has put up some blinds for greater privacy.

An interplay between indoor and outdoor space was also a feature of the stunning social housing within Glasgow's Homes For The Future development, at Glasgow Green: a medley of apartments and houses designed by different architects as part of the city's 1999 Year Of Architecture & Design festival.

Designed by the acclaimed firm Ian Ritchie Architects, for the New Housing Association, the block of 12 two-bed flats is every inch the contemporary urban development, with glass and copper facade, and great views over Glasgow Green from a generous outdoor terrace running around each flat.

"Everyone thought I'd landed loads of money when I got the flat because no one could believe that housing of that standard is rented," says Lucy Kennedy, a co-tenant of one of the top-floor flats, who moved in a few months ago. "People think that if it's social housing, it won't be that good. I really like it - its location and the view of the city, and how it's really modern."

Again, Kennedy enjoys a large, flexible living space which runs the length of the flat, intended by the architects to be customised according to different tenants' needs. "Every person has their flat a different way. We have the eating area in the middle, the living room at one end and a quiet area at the other," says Kennedy. While the Glasgow development is on a relatively small scale, high-quality contemporary architecture is also finding its way into mass social housing. Regeneration of the once-notorious Stonebridge estate, in Brent, north London, by the Stonebridge Housing Action Trust, seeks to restore a human scale and sense of place to the properties under the auspices of master planners and lead architects, Shepheard Epstein Hunter.

When consulted, tenants rejected another dense, high-rise design and voted for less open space but more houses, and so the grim towers are gradually being replaced by 1,400 low-rise houses and apartments in a variety of styles by different architects, intended to break down the previously monotonous character of the estate.

Alain Head, director of Shepheard Epstein Hunter, says that while the regeneration is in some ways playing safe by going back to traditional street patterns of terraced housing and small apartment blocks, at least it is a formula that works. "There's nothing pretentious," he says. "We're not trying to be experimental. You make a mistake here and you do it 1,400 times. The thing that really is innovative is that while many developments are very monotone - with the same brick - here suddenly you turn a corner and there's something different."

David Richards, a long-time resident of Stonebridge, was one of the first to move into one of the new houses with his daughter and granddaughter. It is a low-built, three-bedroom house. "I used to live in Haskell House, one of the worst of the tower blocks, so it's a big difference," he says, appreciating having his own front door and garden after nine years of high-rise living. "It's not what we expected. The house almost feels like you're not on Stonebridge. It's very quiet, very peaceful. Before, there were disturbances, but we're completely out of that now."

It's not surprising that he and tenants of other innovative housing projects are feeling the change to their lives so soon after moving in. Perhaps the whole ethos of social housing, which was once to provide pleasant, thriving communities for people who had been marginalised by the high-earning, house-buying populace, is finally coming to fruition. Perhaps the 21st century will make up for some of the post-war mistakes we made on our council estates.

An interplay between indoor and outdoor space was also a feature of the stunning social housing within Glasgow's Homes For The Future development, at Glasgow Green: a medley of apartments and houses designed by different architects as part of the city's 1999 Year Of Architecture & Design festival. Designed by the acclaimed firm Ian Ritchie Architects, for the New Housing Association, the block of 12 two-bed flats is every inch the contemporary urban development, with glass and copper facade, and great views over Glasgow Green from a generous outdoor terrace running around each flat. "Everyone thought I'd landed loads of money when I got the flat because no one could believe that housing of that standard is rented," says Lucy Kennedy, a co-tenant of one of the top-floor flats, who moved in a few months ago. "People think that if it's social housing, it won't be that good. I really like it - its location and the view of the city, and how it's really modern." Again, Kennedy enjoys a large, flexible living space which runs the length of the flat, intended by the architects to be customised according to different tenants' needs. "Every person has their flat a different way. We have the eating area in the middle, the living room at one end and a quiet area at the other," says Kennedy. While the Glasgow development is on a relatively small scale, high-quality contemporary architecture is also finding its way into mass social housing. Regeneration of the once-notorious Stonebridge estate, in Brent, north London, by the Stonebridge Housing Action Trust, seeks to restore a human scale and sense of place to the properties under the auspices of master planners and lead architects, Shepheard Epstein Hunter. When consulted, tenants rejected another dense, high-rise design and voted for less open space but more houses, and so the grim towers are gradually being replaced by 1,400 low-rise houses and apartments in a variety of styles by different architects, intended to break down the previously monotonous character of the estate. Alain Head, director of Shepheard Epstein Hunter, says that while the regeneration is in some ways playing safe by going back to traditional street patterns of terraced housing and small apartment blocks, at least it is a formula that works. "There's nothing pretentious," he says. "We're not trying to be experimental. You make a mistake here and you do it 1,400 times. The thing that really is innovative is that while many developments are very monotone - with the same brick - here suddenly you turn a corner and there's something different." David Richards, a long-time resident of Stonebridge, was one of the first to move into one of the new houses with his daughter and granddaughter. It is a low-built, three-bedroom house. "I used to live in Haskell House, one of the worst of the tower blocks, so it's a big difference," he says, appreciating having his own front door and garden after nine years of high-rise living. "It's not what we expected. The house almost feels like you're not on Stonebridge. It's very quiet, very peaceful. Before, there were disturbances, but we're completely out of that now." It's not surprising that he and tenants of other innovative housing projects are feeling the change to their lives so soon after moving in. Perhaps the whole ethos of social housing, which was once to provide pleasant, thriving communities for people who had been marginalised by the high-earning, house-buying populace, is finally coming to fruition. Perhaps the 21st century will make up for some of the post-war mistakes we made on our council estates.

fields.headline: Leaving home alone
fields.standfirst: Thousands of apparently happy people walk out of apparently happy homes every year, many preferring a bedsit to a deluxe padded cell
fields.trailText: Thousands of apparently happy people walk out of apparently happy homes every year, many preferring a bedsit to a deluxe padded cell.
fields.body:
In this month's Talk, a reader by the unlikely name of Frank D Troutman (mind you, with such splendidly Runyonesque types as Michael Q Bullerdick, Steven Henry Madoff and Mike Fish on their staff, they're kind of asking for it) gets very excited by a recent profile of the young film actor Matt Damon which ran under the strapline MATT DAMON NEEDS A BED. In it, Mr Damon says, rather unconvincinglyâ "I literally have nowhere to sleep." In response, Mr Troutman rages, "That someone of Damon's financial status would make such a statement is unacceptable. Poverty and homelessness are significant problems in this country and not to be taken lightly. All anyone has to do," he trails off rather disappointingly, "is pick up a newspaper to see the number of people in this country who truly have nowhere to sleep..." But building up to a fine finish, he thunders, "It was thoughtless, untrue and inconsiderate towards those less fortunate."

But oh, so cool! I, for one, fear for the viability of Mr Troutman's writing hand this month, for everywhere one looks in the exceedingly small world of glossy newsprint there seem to be glowing young actors boasting about their homelessness. A piece in Premiere starts "Paul Walker is homeless", and goes on to tell us that the 27-year-old star of Pleasantville and Varsity Blues likes it fine that way: "I'd feel restricted." Elsewhere, Johnny Depp, who earns a fortune per picture, talks yearningly of a life on the open road with one bag and a guitar as the highest state of grace available to modern man.

As if to rub in how very tiny-minded and uncool having a home is, the Daily Mail (whose manifesto might best be summed up as the overwhelming fear that someone, somewhere, is having fun) is full of its current Ideal Home Show. Europeans are always surprised at the English obsession with buying rather than renting the place where you live. The phrase "an Englishman's home is his castle" is invariably used favourably by us, but I can't help thinking it might secretly have been made up by a snooty Frenchman as an insult, a likely stablemate for Napoleon's "the English are a nation of shopkeepers". To me, the idea of millions of Englishmen waddling proudly like Strasbourg geese on their privatised patios and feeling like king of all they survey is a pathetic one, not a cause for celebration.

No one could call the French less grounded, nationalistic, bourgeois or arrogant than us, yet their unshakeable self-belief doesn't seem to depend on being deep in hock to some mortgage company. ("Mortgage": even the word reeks of morbidity and the downward slide to old age and the grave; le petit mortgage!) Perhaps this is the point; the more insecure the man/country, the more "home" takes on a mythic status, becomes an icon of cleanliness rather than a convenient place to hang one's hat and grab some zzzz's.

Since Mrs Thatcher's sell-off of council houses in the 80s, it is possible for all but the very poorest of Englishmen to own his own little pile of bricks and mortar. But the gap between rich and poor grows ever greater, and the nation's collective sense of well-being drops with every new survey. Council tenants who might once have demanded rehousing find themselves stuck on sink estates or in the path of repeatedly flooding rivers, and find that their home is not so much their castle as their millstone and their jail.

Homelessness, vide the angry Mr Troutman, is generally seen as the worst thing that can happen to anyone. Yet a good many of the homeless people we pass in the street once had homes - poor, abusive or whatever they might have been - and decided that it was preferable to spend their days sitting on a cold pavement begging and their nights sleeping in underpasses. Once you've admitted that home is not always where the heart is, everything becomes relative, and what it takes to drive us out simply a matter of taste. Moreover, thousands of affluent, comfortable and apparently happy people, mostly men, walk out of apparently happy homes every year - many of them homes lovely enough to be featured by the Mail - having decided that a lonely new life in a bedsit is preferable to sitting in your detached, deluxe padded cell for one more night with someone who just doesn't understand you.

For home can be as confining and claustrophobic as it can be comforting, and over-keenness on home ownership can actually signal drowning-not-waving neuroticism rather than well-balanced normality. The reason why many women remain uncomfortable about the Nigella Lawson phenomenon is not that (just) we are green-eyed bitches jealous of her biblical beauty, but because the whole Domestic Goddess shtick would never even have occurred to any contemporary woman who hadn't suffered such a sadly disrupted life - famously broken home, tragically early deaths of mother and sister, very famously and tragically dying husband. Of course Nigella wanted to play house on such a grand scale - it was probably the only thing that kept her sane. But I find it as uncomfortable to watch as I would a stranger acting out an extreme sex fantasy. It's just too raw and personal. And for women without such trauma to overcome actively to aspire to this condition seems as strange as volunteering for an STD.

There is also, stylistically - bringing us right back to Matt Damon, Johnny Depp and their footloose friends - the fact that to care overmuch about one's immediate environment is horribly, risibly naff. Oscar Wilde famously said that a gentleman never looks out of the window - he certainly doesn't plump up the Mao cushions and invite OK! into his "beautiful home". No, when we think house-proud, we think Hyacinth Bucket - or her real-life counterpart, the ultra-naff Peter Mandelson, whose beautiful home was to prove his Achilles heel. Interestingly, when it comes to commonly caring about interiors, gays are even naffer than straights.

Putting one's money into property is, no matter how we dress it up - and I speak as a home-owner myself - a sign of defeat, not confidence; a signal that we are already looking towards the withered future rather than living in the luscious moment. Confidence, for good or ill, is Johnny Depp spending £4,000 on a bottle of wine, knowing that he can make it back in a minute, or those ultra-rich people who have bought up every berth of that floating kingdom that will transport them from hotspot to hotspot and never see them put down roots anywhere long enough to pay tax. Home is all well and good - but at many times in our lives, rejecting one can be as vital to our growing up as clinging to one.

fields.headline: Spiky plants
fields.standfirst: Like most prickly customers, spiky plants like to make their presence felt, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Like most prickly customers, spiky plants like to make their presence felt, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
It is essential to have spiky plants in any British garden, where most of the vegetation is soft-looking. They give an immediate lift (much like the first glass of champagne on a Sunday morning). The eye homes in on them, and only then seeks out the supporting cast. When I begin to think about them individually, they all seem to have one fault or another, but then thatÕs no worse than with people.

One of the trickiest is hardiness. But this is a good time of the year to be writing about less hardy plants. We can worry about how to carry them over once we have enjoyed them through the summer. Grasses obviously qualify as spiky plants, but many of them have too narrow a leaf to look truly noble. Exceptionally, Setaria palmifolia has quite a broad leaf with handsome parallel ridges along its entire length. By the end of the season it will have made a large clump and youÕll be tremendously proud of it, but it is tender and must be potted up and overwintered under frost-free glass Ñ well worth the trouble, I assure you. It will grow about 0.5m tall, but more than double that height if it decides to flower in the autumn.

Of course, there are many other grasses. Stipa gigantea is one of the best, flowering at 2.5m in June and remaining presentable for at least three months if not exposed to fierce winds. But here, it is the flowering stalks rather than the spiky leaves that holds our attention. The leaves themselves are pretty mundane. I am a great protagonist of blue lyme grass, Leymus arenarius (0.7m), which is tough as they come and very blue on its young foliage in early summer; either harmonise it with blue flowers (siting it at the borderÕs front) or contrast it with red. I find that one clump is generally enough and it is the devil of a spreader, like a nightmare version of couch. Every spring, you need to dig it out and trace all runners that have strayed a metre or more; then replant the core material, cutting it back so that all its foliage is young and fresh. Fergus does this willingly, but not everyone would.

The desert-loving agaves from North America have a wonderful presence, the best known being Agave americana, which is glaucous, and, even more popular, ÔVariegataÕ, which has a broad yellow stripe either side of its long, fleshy leaves. These leaves, arranged in a loose rosette, take on seductive curves, and they are intriguingly marked with the shadow, so to speak, of the neighbouring leaf, left on it when the two were tightly furled together. These agaves are hardy only on our coastal resorts, but it is well worth growing a few of them in pots and plunging these in key positions for the summer, as Beth Chatto does in her gravel garden, where the flattened domes of Sedum ÔAutumn JoyÕ make a telling background.

Another way to use an agave is in a cluster of pots arranged for summer display on your patio or outside your entrance porch. Other plants around it can then be as soft as you like but the agave will hold everything together. Yuccas, also from North America, are as spiky as they come. Boldest, stiffest and as hardy as any is Yucca gloriosa. This makes a large globe of rather dangerously spiky leaves, and when a rosette is large enough it will flower dramatically, at 2m, with a huge candelabrum of waxy, cream-coloured bells. They may be borne any time from July to October. This yucca is so domineering that some people resent its overbearing presence, but it certainly makes its mark. It needs looking after; feed it well if you want flowers, and do not allow too many competing foliar crowns. It is also important, for the sake of smartness, to pull off old, dead foliage. The variegated form is a lot less solemn; also less vast.

Furcraea longaeva bears a strong resemblance to a yucca, but has a notably blue bloom on its leaves which are neither stiff nor sharply pointed. But it is not hardy and must be transferred in and out of doors as and when the weather demands. Given milder winters, many phormiums have proved hardy. This is the New Zealand flax. Phormium tenax and its many named cultivars will make huge clumps, 2m or more high, which are, I have to say, rather awkward to manage. A clump can outgrow its allotted space and need reducing, but this is easier said than done. Even if you donÕt kill yourself lifting a colony and dividing it, the phormium itself will take a dim view of the proceedings and sulk for a long while afterwards. Still, you canÕt be ruled by your plants forever.

P. cookianum is hardier and has flexible, not stiff, foliage. I am fond of P. c. ÔTricolorÕ, which has green, purple and cream striping. It also flowers regularly, which is quite an event, although unconventional. On a low scale, Sisyrinchium striatum (0.5m), with spiky, iris-like leaves, makes a pretty plant in youth and has pale yellow flowers in early summer, but plants age badly, their leaves turning black. The variegated ÔAunt MayÕ is a charmer in youth, but must be frequently renewed.

Irises themselves, especially the bearded kinds, are notably spiky, but generally become an eyesore once they have flowered. They do in my garden, anyway, whatever your claims (which I donÕt have to believe). If you repeatedly replant Iris pallida ÔArgentea VariegataÕ (white variegated) and ÔVariegataÕ (yellow-variegated) in spring, forgetting about their flowers, they will remain smart foliage plants right through summer and autumn

fields.headline: Sweet Pain
fields.standfirst: Is it wrong to take pleasure from the depiction of pain? Nowhere is the moral dilemma more confusing than in the scores of images of the gently forbearing St Sebastian - both a sacred icon and an object of desire since the time of the Renaissance masters.
fields.trailText: Is it wrong to take pleasure from the depiction of pain? Nowhere is the moral dilemma more confusing than in the scores of images of the gently forbearing St Sebastian - both a sacred icon and an object of desire since the time of the Renaissance masters.
fields.body:
He juts; he pouts; he poses. The flimsiest of loincloths struggles to stay around the top of his thighs. We never glimpse him more or less than teasingly stripped. Boyish, yet muscular. Pale-skinned; slender, soft and taut. And by further schematic consent, his attitude is one of mild gyration at the midriff - just enough to make his hips incline. So he invites as he recoils. He flaunts an allure of delicious vulnerability.

And, indeed, he is wounded. Quite severely, we should say. Pierced by arrows - through his lungs, his legs, his torso, his brow, and more. Sometimes the arrows are so densely clustered into his flesh he can look like a porcupine. Yet he does not split the skies with anything so unseemly as an agonised howl. He may concede a gasp or a wince. More often, though, he just purses his lips - as if for a kiss.

This is the typical image of St Sebastian and it is no revelation to hail it as a gay icon. How could it not be? But the image goes far beyond that. It brings us to the bewildering place where beauty and wretchedness, delight and disgust, ecstasy and torment, all conspire to lose their normal polar opposition.

A painting of St Sebastian is put on display as a work of art, an object of admiration, connoisseurship. Gallery labels tell of an artist; they may supply a provenance, too. Because this is the image of a saint, its original position to viewers was invariably in some sacred setting, with prayer or reverence the appropriate attitude of respect. But to be aware of that fact only doubles our sense of bewilderment.

Pious as it once was, every picture of St Sebastian remains a full-tilt assault upon aesthetic complacency. The sort of language routinely applied to the S&M photography of Robert Mapplethorpe or the art-stunts of 'Brit Art' belongs no less to the hallowed iconography of this Christian martyr. It is sensational, deplorable, macabre, and morally confused. And yet it is exquisite, too.

It is a paradox that beauty can cohabit with, or arise from, grievous bodily harm, but it is not a novel problem. In the 18th century, men of letters earnestly debated whether it was right to take aesthetic delight in a classical statue showing a man and his two sons beset by giant serpents. In our own time, it is almost an annual Hollywood routine that someone in or out of the film industry will flagellate the moguls for their excess of entertaining violence. A few centuries ago, the prospect of a public execution would have emptied any London theatre. Cameramen have to work harder to conjure the same thrill of horror now; but it is all the more memorable when they do. Are we sick, to take pleasure from pain? What is the good of ghastly art? Let us see if he has the answers - this pouting, punctured Saint Sebastian.
Was there ever such a person as the 'historical' Sebastian? Presumably; but - in common with the many sanctified heroes and heroines of early Christian witness - not definitively. The tale of Sebastian's testimony - the passionate insubordination of one of the emperor's close bodyguards - is chronologically located in the reign of the Roman tetrarch Diocletian, who in AD303 conducted the last campaign of Christian persecutions by imperial Rome. Sebastian, a Christian member of the elite cohort known as the Praetorian Guard, serves with honour in a promising military career, yet ultimately is forced to put his loyalty to Christ before obedience to his superiors (the joint emperors Diocletian and Maximian). His punishment is be used as target practice by his fellow guardsmen; yet Sebastian survives, and is nursed back to health by a co-believer called Irene, only to reaffirm his faith with extra vigour.

Diocletian then has him flogged, or pulverised, to death within imperial precincts, and his body flung into the great sewer of Rome, the Cloaca Maxima. Somehow the corpse is recovered. Final defilement only proves another step toward the accolade of sainthood. No classical author records the episode, but this narrative is to be found in The Golden Legend (Legenda aurea) of one Jacobus da Voragine (1230-98) whose omnibus collection of saintly lives was one of the world's first best-sellers, rolling off prototype presses throughout Europe (personally translated by pioneer printer William Caxton, The Golden Legend went through nine editions in English alone between 1483 and 1527).

It is true that when The Golden Legend became exposed to the learned scrutiny of Italian humanists in the late 15th century, it was held up to ridicule as a farrago of improbable evangelising antics. webTitle: Kitchen doctor: A lads' night in

fields.headline: A lads'  night in
fields.standfirst: It seemed too good to be true: three male twenty-somethings eager for Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes to pep up their diet. And it was, says Bob Granleese. But only just.
fields.trailText: It seemed too good to be true: three male twenty-somethings eager for Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes to pep up their diet. And it was, says Bob Granleese. But only just.
fields.body:
It's not every day that you come across three boys in their early 20s who want to invigorate their diet and are willing to give up valuable drinking and lounging time to do so. But that's exactly what Tom Sabin, Chris Crookes and Neil O'Donnell wanted Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, to do for them. "I'm one of three hard-working lads," wrote Tom, "and like to cook when I have time. Our problem is having nutritious meals available for us all to feast on at short notice due to our differing schedules. If we could have great food in the fridge to pick up and reheat, or quick, fresh cooking, that would be great."

No sooner had she finished reading than the KD was making her way to the boys' flat in Hulme, Manchester, eager to meet such rare examples of post-teen manhood. For once, all three were home: Tom, a student, doesn't really need an excuse not to study; Chris, an architect, has a day's holiday; and Neil, a barber, is off sick with a git of a cold and taking swigs from a bottle of Benylin in a forlorn attempt to make himself feel better.

"So," asks Rosie excitedly, "you all cook then?"

"Nah," replies a bunged-up Neil.

"I usually eat out, Chinese takeaway, or something." Ah, so they're not such paragons, thinks Rosie, an observation backed up by the withered pot plants in the front room.

"Tom fancies himself as a bit of a cook," says Chris, "but us two can't do a thing, and eat anything he makes."

"Which is why we need your help," adds Tom, "so I can make stuff that we can all eat as and when."

"Very commendable," says Rosie, before adding with motherly concern, "those plants could do with a good watering, though."

"Oh, so that's what is wrong with them," says Chris, enlightened.

"Er, yes," says Rosie. "But we're not here to talk horticulture; we've got some serious cooking to do."

"Anything you need help with?" asks Tom eagerly as Neil and Chris take up positions on the sofa with bottles of beer and the TV remote.

"Sure," says Rosie, "there's lots to prepare. You start with the plantain and veg for tamale pie." Tom sets to, while Rosie busies herself with prepping the meat dishes. "Um, that looks a bit... rude," she says of Tom's rather phallic plantain-holding technique. "How does it feel?"

"Pardon!" exclaims Tom.

"I didn't mean it like that," says Rosie. "Is it hard or soft?"

"You're doing it deliberately now," replies Tom.

"Honest, I'm not," says a blushing Rosie, then admits that she's never cooked plantain and is inquisitive as to its texture. "It looks quite woody." Tom raises an eyebrow. "I mean, it looks like an unripe banana."

"It's sticky, too," says Tom.

"See!" says Rosie triumphantly. "It's not that easy to avoid, is it?"

Before the dialogue descends any further into smut, Rosie volunteers Chris for the next job: "You make the cornbread," she says authoritatively.

Chris looks worried, Tom looks relieved, Neil looks ill. "But I can't cook," moans Chris. "I was Poynton's Crusty King Junior Masterchef of 1989, but that was a long time ago, and all I made was jelly."

"Cornbread's a cinch," says Rosie, rummaging in the cupboards and emerging with a worried look on her face. "There seems to be a lack of basic implements, such as whisks, bowls and the like." The boys turn to each other nonplussed. "Never mind," says Rosie, "we'll just have to make do." With that, she guides Chris through the "cinch" that is making cornbread with none of the right equipment, then enlists Neil to complete the final stages of pie-making, amalgamating the dough and pouring it over the cooked veg; 45 minutes later, an impressive-looking pie emerges from the oven.

"Neil, look what you've made!" says an amazed Tom. Neil seems rather pleased with himself, but then pleads sickness and heads back to collapse on the sofa. Rosie, charitably, does not summon him back for further chores, and instead gets Chris and Tom to prepare a salad for roast belly pork, and herbs for a spicy chicken dish. Tom, grinning, brandishes the cucumber suggestively. "Oi, behave!" says Rosie.

"Okay," says Tom, and changes the subject: "So, this chicken, is it Thai, what with the chilli and coconut?"

"More Balinese," says Rosie. "The the concept is a bit fusiony, which I don't usually go in for because most of it is so silly. It's for when you want to impress the 'birds'."

"Like we did the other night," says Tom nudging Chris.

"Not sure they'd agree," says Chris.

He and Tom sidle off to join Neil on the couch to drink yet more beer, watch daytime TV and slag off Manchester United, as you do. The abandoned KD doesn't seem to mind being left to finish off, and is soon serving up the chicken and pork dishes, along with sumptuous steak sandwiches. The three flatmates descend on the food as if they haven't eaten in a week.

"You should have stirred the salsa," says a startled Rosie.

"I did," says Tom. "I gave it a really good toss."

"Now don't start that again!"

Tamale Pie
This recipe comes from my brother, and is, as I recall, a great pre- or post- pub dinner. He adds kidney beans to the filling, but I left them out because one of the other dishes I made for the boys has pulses in it. Serves four.

For the filling
2 onions, finely sliced
3 cloves garlic, crushed
1 half tbsp olive oil
half tsp chilli powder
2 large chilli peppers (ie, the ones that are sweet and not very hot), de-seeded and finely sliced
2 sticks celery, chopped
1 plantain (optional), peeled, sliced down the middle and chopped
100g sweetcorn
45g green olives, chopped
600g chopped tinned tomatoes
1 heaped tbsp parsley, chopped
Salt and pepper

For the cornbread topping
185g polenta
1? tbsp plain flour
75g salt
3 tsp baking powder
2 eggs, beaten
135ml milk
1? tbsp olive oil
75g cheddar, grated
2 spring onions, finely chopped
1 tbsp fresh coriander, chopped

First, make the filling. Heat the oil in a big pan, add the onion, garlic and chilli powder, and soften for 10 minutes. Add the chilli peppers, celery and plantain, and saut for the same time. Add the olives, sweetcorn and tomatoes, and bring to a simmer. Season to taste, and add the parsley. Cook gently while you preheat the oven to 200C/400F/ gas mark 6 and make the topping.

In a bowl, mix the dry ingredients, including the herb, onion and cheese. Beat the egg, milk and oil together in a jug. Make a well in the centre of the dry mix, pour in the liquid and stir until you have a good dough.

Pour the filling into a large oven dish, pour over the cornbread mix and smooth out. Bake in the middle of the oven for about 45 minutes, until the bread topping is golden and set.

Spicy fried chicken
This should appeal to anyone who likes crispy fried chicken. Also, most of the preparation is done in advance. These quantities will serve four, or six if served with one of the accompaniments listed afterwards.

420ml tinned coconut milk
1 lime, zest grated
2 lime leaves (optional)
15g fresh ginger, peeled and diced
4 cloves garlic, crushed
4 shallots, finely chopped
5 small green chillies, de-seeded and chopped fine
6 coriander stalks
1 half tsp turmeric
Big pinch salt
8 free-range organic chicken thighs, skin on
Sunflower oil, for frying

Pour the coconut milk into a large pan, then add one and a half times the amount of water. Add the lime zest, lime leaves, ginger, garlic, shallots, chillies, coriander and turmeric, and bring up to a simmer. Season the chicken with salt, and poach gently in the liquor until just cooked, about 20 minutes. Remove the meat with a slotted spoon, and set aside to cool.

When it's time to eat, heat enough oil in a frying pan to shallow fry the chicken (around 1-2cm). Lay in the thighs skin-side down, turn after five or so minutes, when crisp and golden, and cook for a few minutes more until done. Serve with the following two dishes and a bowl of chilli sauce.

Coconut rice and beans
It would be a real waste not to make use of the delicious cooking liquor from the chicken, so I came up with this simple and tasty side dish to do complement the crispy fowl. Serves six.

1 onion, sliced
1 small green pepper, sliced
1 tbsp groundnut oil
400g long grain rice
400g tin black-eye beans
1 big handful each fresh coriander and parsley, roughly chopped
Salt

Heat the oil in a big pan, add the onion and pepper, and soften for 10 minutes. Add the rice and stir. Measure out one litre of the chicken cooking liquor, bits and all. Check for seasoning, add to the pan, stir, and simmer, covered, for 12 minutes. Test the rice, and if it's almost ready (which it should be; if not, carry on cooking a little longer), stir in the beans, together with a little more cooking liquor if the rice is on the dry side. Allow the beans a few minutes to heat through, then stir in the herbs and serve straight away.

Avocado salad
The idea for this dish came to me when I was reading a recipe for Caribbean rice that suggested serving radishes, cucumber and avocado alongside.

1 red onion, finely diced
1 lime, zested
1 and a half limes, juiced
half tsp salt
6 radishes, diced
1 small piece cucumber, de-seeded and finely chopped
1 large ripe avocado, peeled and finely chopped
1 handful fresh coriander

Place the lime juice in a bowl, add the salt, stirring to dissolve, then add the lime zest and onion. Five minutes before serving, add the remaining ingredients, give it all a good stir, a grind of black pepper and a little more salt, if needed.

Marinated steak sandwich with onions and peppers
The beef can be marinated for several days and cooked as and when. Ditto the onions, which can be reheated in the steak pan while the meat rests.

The good thing about marinating meat is that you can use an inexpensive cut. I'd favour skirt, but I had to buy something called 'frying steak' from Chris, Tom and Neil's local supermarket. Serves four.

950g steak
1 bottle hefty red wine
6 cloves garlic, crushed
Salt and pepper
1 loaf crusty white bread, sliced
3 tbsp olive oil
4 onions
3 red onions
1 tsp sugar
100g roasted red peppers (buy a jar to save time)
1 tbsp balsamic vinegar
1 sprig thyme
1 small bayleaf

Mix together the wine, garlic, half a tablespoon of olive oil, bayleaf and lots of black pepper, and then add alternate layers of steak and onions. Cover and marinate for a couple of hours. Lift out the onions, and turn over the meat so it gets a good even dip.

Heat one and a half tablespoons of oil in a large frying pan, add the onions and thyme, cover with a tight lid and leave to sweat down over a very gentle heat for about 40 minutes, stirring from time to time, until the onions are very soft). Add the sugar, raise the heat for a few minutes to caramelise a little, then add a couple of tablespoons of the marinade and the vinegar. Reduce the liquor until it just coats the onions. Taste for seasoning, stir in the peppers and it is ready to serve or store in the fridge.

Now for the meat. If you have left it in the marinade for a day or two, take it out of the fridge at least 30 minutes before cooking. Lift the meat from the marinade, season to taste, then lay in a very hot griddle pan or heavy-based frying pan. The idea is to sear the meat until it has a nice brown exterior, then flip it over and do the same on the other side. Remove from the pan, and leave to rest in a warm place while you reheat the oniony gear.

Drizzle olive oil over your slices of bread (put a few rocket leaves on the base, too, if you want), then slice the steak, pour any juices over the bread, lay in some meat and onions, and top with another slice of oil-drizzled bread.

Crisp pork belly salad with blood oranges
I came across blood oranges in Unicorn, a wonderful organic shop we found in Chorlton, 10 minutes from the boys' flat, and just had to buy some. Serves four.

500g belly pork
3 blood oranges
1-2 tbsp fresh basil
2 medium waxy potatoes, peeled and cut into cubes
100g French beans
15g pinenuts, toasted; watch them very carefully as they burn easily
1 tbsp Dijon mustard
Salt and pepper
100ml olive oil
Selection of salad leaves (watercress, in particular, is a fine complement to orange)

Slash the skin of the pork with a knife and rub it with a generous amount of coarse salt. Grate the zest of one orange over the meat, strew over a few torn basil leaves, and press them in gently. If possible, leave the meat to sit for an hour or two before cooking.

Blanch the beans for a couple of minutes in salted water, then drain, refresh in cold water and set to one side. Preheat the oven to 225C/425F/ gas mark 7. Put the meat on a baking tray, skin-side up, and cook at the top of the oven for about 40 minutes, until the skin is good and crispy, then leave to rest. About 25 minutes into roasting, drain off the fat, pass it through a fine sieve and add a couple of tablespoons to a frying pan. In this, saut the potato over a medium heat for about 15 minutes, and season.

Meanwhile, make the dressing: peel the two remaining oranges, and cut the flesh into segments, reserving any juices. Juice the grated orange and add this to the juice from preparing the others: you should have around 50ml. Put the mustard in a bowl, stir in the juice, then gradually add the oil. Season, and add the rest of the basil. If the dressing is too sweet, add a tablespoon of vinegar (cider would be best).

To serve, place the leaves, pinenuts, beans and orange segments in a large bowl, season and mix gently. Drain the potatoes on kitchen paper, and add these to the salad mixture along with a generous amount of dressing, and toss. Slice the pork into good-sized chunks, and lay on top of the salad

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Gary Kemp
fields.trailText: Gary Kemp
fields.body:
Gary Kemp, 41, grew up in north London. His father was a printer, his mother a dinner lady. At 11, he won a grammar school place. He started touring pubs with a band at 14, and five years later formed Spandau Ballet with his brother, Martin. Gary wrote lyrics and music, and the band were together for 10 years. In 1990, the brothers starred in the film The Krays. Gary is appearing in Art at Wyndham's Theatre, London, until April 14. He has a son by his former wife, Sadie Frost.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Standing on top of a mountain with Finlay, my son.

What is your greatest fear?
Currently, it's drying on stage, but as a parent, the fear for your child's health overrides any other.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
My public displays of overenthusiasm, and trying to speak before others have finished.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
The other night, performing in Art, I realised that my flies had been undone for quite a while. Wondered why they were laughing so hard.


What makes you depressed?
Daytime television.

What is your greatest extravagance?
A rare chair from 1870. A treat after I won a court case. Good for writing future songs in.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
I've always had a battle with my receding hairline. I've recently given in to my genes.

What is your favourite fantasy?
To see an electric guitar on Top Of The Pops.

Should the royal family be scrapped?
They're already on their way out  the sooner the better.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
Of course not!

Do you believe in monogamy?
That depends who you're with.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?

Self love - now seen as a modern virtue!

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?

Never. It's a word too easily said, and where do you go from there?

What is your greatest regret?

Not going to university. I'd love the process and experience.

How often do you have sex?
Whenever I'm alone.

Knowing more stuff.

What keeps you awake at night?
Radio Five Live and learning lines.

fields.trailText: Vaz stays in hospital | 111-year-old whisky sold | Road risk to Asian children
fields.body:
Vaz stays in hospital

The Europe minister Keith Vaz was due to spend a second night in St Thomas's hospital, south London, after further "routine investigations", the Foreign Office said yesterday. Mr Vaz, 44, who collapsed at his office on Thursday after a television interview, is in "a very stable condition".

111-year-old whisky sold

A 111-year-old bottle of Bowmore whisky could break the Scottish record of £8,500 set in 1999 for a 60-year-old McCallan at a Glasgow auction next week.

Road risk to Asian children

Asian children, particularly those whose families are recent arrivals, are involved in up to twice as many pedestrian accidents as the national average, according to the Department of the Environment. Almost 6,000 children are killed or seriously injured on roads each year.

Neil Young at festival

Veteran rocker Neil Young and his band Crazy Horse will headline the Fleadh music festival in Finsbury Park, north London, in June. Also on the bill are the re-formed Waterboys and Teenage Fanclub.

Glastonbury owner fined

Organiser Michael Eavis, who yesterday admitted breaching his licence for last year's Glastonbury music festival when thousands of gatecrashers went on to the site without tickets, was fined £6,000 with £9,000 costs by magistrates in Frome, Somerset.

Body found in hunt for pilot

Searchers looking for a second US fighter pilot after two F-15 jets crashed in the Scottish Highlands on Monday have found a body near the wreckage close to the summit of Ben Macdui in the Cairngorm mountains, police said yesterday. A formal identification will be conducted to see if it is that of Captain Kirk Jones, based at Lakenheath, Suffolk.

webTitle: Sale of Gielgud mementoes may raise over £500,000

fields.headline: Gielgud mementoes
fields.standfirst: Sale expected to raise over £500,000
fields.trailText: The earliest of his mementoes to be sold at next week's auction is a battered pocket edition of Henry V signed on the flyleaf in schoolboyish script AJ Gielgud.
fields.body:
The earliest of his mementoes to be sold at next week's auction is a battered pocket edition of Henry V signed on the flyleaf in schoolboyish script AJ Gielgud.

"Old Vic," it continues, "An English herald. My first appearance on any stage. November, 1921".

The final item in the sale of Sir John Gielgud's collection at Sotheby's in London on Thursday is the film script of his last substantial part in Prospero's Books, made 74 years later. Sir John died last May, aged 96. In between these two mementoes are nearly 600 more of the professional and personal treasures of an acting life which spanned 79 years.

They are the relics of a man who put all his artistry and flair into his work - and into his choice of paintings, antique furniture, brass, silver, and carpets for his mansion at Wotton Underwood, Buckinghamshire.

The exceptions are his Panama hat - the trademark of his jaunty old age - his gloves and his cigarette case. These together are expected to fetch up to £700.

The sale is forecast to raise between £500,000 and £700,000. Much of this, plus the proceeds from selling the mansion, is expected to go into a fund for scholarships for student actors. More than half the cash value of Gielgud's collection springs from his outstanding array of modern paintings.

The top-priced item is Sir William Nicholson's still life The Little Lustre Mug, expected to sell for up to £50,000.

fields.headline: Faslane nuclear ruling overturned
fields.trailText: A high court ruled that Britain's nuclear deterrent is not illegal following the acquittal of three women peace campaigners of damaging a laboratory at Coulport.
fields.body:
A high court ruled that Britain's nuclear deterrent is not illegal following the acquittal of three women peace campaigners, in October 1999, of damaging a laboratory at Coulport, part of the Trident nuclear submarine installation at Faslane naval base on the Clyde.

Greenock sheriff Margaret Gimblett accepted the women's argument that nuclear weapons were illegal under international law and that they had a right to commit crimes to prevent their use or deployment. But at the court of session in Edinburgh yesterday, Lords Prosser, Kirkwood and Penrose ruled against her judgment. The acquittal of the three protesters still stands, however.

Angie Zelter, one of the women arrested and later freed after the Coulport incident, said she was disappointed. She was part of a group of peace campaigners who held an all-night vigil out side the court. "Even if the result had been yes, we would still have had to continue with our campaign."

The crown had challenged Sheriff Gimblett's ruling and a reference hearing was held at the high court in Edinburgh last October.

Yesterday Lord Prosser said: "The reference contains four questions for the court. The first raises a question of competency in law and we find in the negative.

"Each of the other three questions raises an issue of substantive law. All of these issues concern different aspects of possible defences to criminal charges on the basis that the act charged might be justified either as a matter of customary international law or as a matter of Scots law necessity.

"We answered each of these three questions in the negative."

A Ministry of Defence spokesman said the legality of Trident was never "in the dock".
Press Association

fields.headline: 'Forgotten' illness of 1m adults
fields.standfirst: Forensic psychologist says that crippling disorder can push sufferers into social problems and crime
fields.trailText: More than a million adults who are suffering from a crippling disorder which can lead to criminal behaviour are being overlooked because doctors believe the condition is confined to childhood, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
More than a million adults who are suffering from a crippling disorder which can lead to criminal behaviour are being overlooked because doctors believe the condition is confined to childhood, it was claimed yesterday.

A leading forensic psychologist, Susan Young, told the British Psychological Society's annual conference in Glasgow yesterday that as much as 3% of the adult population could have attention defecit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

These people, however, are not receiving essential treatment and medication because many psychiatrists and psychologists believe children grow out of the disorder.

Dr Young, of the Institute of Psychiatry, said some studies estimate the condition - which is characterised by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsiveness - may affect up to 25% of the prison population.

Little work has been done on the prevalence of ADHD in adulthood, but Dr Young said that 6% of children have the disorder and around half of them will carry it through to adulthood. "I think what we are seeing is the tip of the iceberg. We cannot possibly have identified all the adults in the population with ADHD."

ADHD in adults can be treated successfully with the controversial drug Ritalin - which has been heavily criticised over its effect on children - but adult patients can often become depressed and need additional psychological help.

Dr Young studied 30 adults who had been diagnosed with ADHD later in life and compared their progress with a group of 30 adults who had other personality problems, but not ADHD, and a group of 30 "normal" adults.

All of the people involved in the survey were from middle class backgrounds and were of average intelligence. But Dr Young found "huge differences" in their lifestyles.

Around one third of ADHD sufferers had attended special schools for children with learning difficulties against only 7% of those with other personality disorders. No one from the "normal" group had gone to a special school.

People with ADHD also found it much more difficult to hold down jobs and two thirds were unemployed, compared to only 3% of the "normal" group. They also had severe social problems and had difficulty forming friendships.

Dr Young also found that 25% of people with ADHD had been to prison. "They were stealing, fire-setting, being cruel to animals - all the way up to homicide," she added.

Dr Young set up the first clinic for adults with ADHD at Maudsley hospital, south London, in 1994. There is only one other specialist clinic in the UK.

 Simple relaxation and hypnotherapy techniques could extend the lives of lymphatic cancer patients by up to 32 months, according to new research by a team of psychologists led by Leslie Walker, of Hull University.

The psychological therapies were administered to help the patients deal with nausea, vomiting and other side effects inherent in chemotherapy. But the researchers found that, not only did the treatments reduce nausea and vomiting, the patients also survived longer.

When they looked at the patients 13 years on, those who had been given relaxation therapy survived for an average of 104.5 months and those who had hypnotherapy and relaxation therapy survived for 125.8 months. Patients who received only conventional help survived for only 93.8 months.

webTitle: French dictionary says pants to the past

fields.headline: French dictionary says pants to the past
fields.trailText: The more style-conscious residents of Paris would probably prefer never even to have to contemplate such vulgar British inventions as alcopops, or ladettes, and certainly not visible panty lines.
fields.body:
The more style-conscious residents of Paris would probably prefer never even to have to contemplate such vulgar British inventions as alcopops, or ladettes, and certainly not visible panty lines.

But a new French-English dictionary which embraces an unprecedented number of terms from British popular culture leaves them little choice - although, with a certain hauteur, it defines VPL as marque disgracieuse de la culotte - or "unbecoming mark of the knickers".

The updated Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary gives French speakers all the tools they need to talk about alcopops (sodas alcoolisés), designer drugs (drogues de synthèse) and email spamming (le spamming).

But in a reminder of the cultural Channel gap, many British concepts find no snappy translation. Thus ladette becomes jeune femme qui se comporte comme un homme machiste - "young woman who behaves like a macho man".

The 2,144-page dictionary is the first of its kind to be constructed using a corpus - a vast assemblage of examples of how language is actually used in everything from scholarly journals to supermarket magazines - and as such it is bound to offend those defenders of the French language who see the lexicographer's task as to legislate on what can and cannot be written or said.

"The examples we give for the definitions are the real, natural language, whereas when in the past they were written by lexicographers they could sometimes seem unnatural and stilted," said Vivien Marr, publishing manager of bilingual dictionaries at Oxford University Press.

"It is in the more British tradition of lexicography: we don't proscribe language in any way - we record how it is used."

But if British lad culture sends the Francophone world into a state of confusion, the dictionary reveals a burgeoning French vocabulary relating to the internet. Among the nearly 4,000 new words and phrases included are translations for dot.com company (société point com) and hot-desking (bureau tournant).

The New Labour approach to politics does not fare too well. "Focus group" is rendered as "groupe de discussion", while "joined-up government" is translated as "initiative de coordination gouvernementale pour simplifier la vie des personnes et des entreprises".

fields.headline: How archbishop's voice thundered unexpectedly
fields.standfirst: Hope propelled into crisis debate
fields.trailText: Hope propelled into crisis debate.
fields.body:
When he accepted an invitation to lunch on Wednesday, along with Dame Thora Hird, from senior editorial staff at the Times, it is a fair bet that David Hope, the Archbishop of York, did not expect his views on postponing the general election to end up plastered all over the paper's front page yesterday.

The 60-year-old archbishop, second in the hierarchy and the leading member of its high church Anglo-Catholic wing, is known to be concerned about the church's media marginalisation. But he may not have anticipated propelling the Church of England into the foot and mouth debate or leading the BBC morning news bulletins 36 hours later.

Dr Hope thought he was discussing the Times' Easter supplement and may have considered 90-year-old Dame Thora's remarks on the crisis as being as likely to lead the Thunderer as his views that many people would be disenfranchised if an election was held while the disease was still prevalent. Such is the church's lack of ambition these days that "we thought it might make the bottom of page seven", said one of his staff.

Dr Hope, a dapper bachelor, has hitherto been best known for conceding six years ago when he was bishop of London that his sexuality was a "grey area" although he was celibate, in response to threats of outing from the gay campaigner Peter Tatchell.

Dr Hope's concerns for the plight of farmers in his diocese, and those in the archbishopric's wider province across the whole of the north of England is genuine. They - and he - have had a rough winter.

The last time the archbishop made national waves was when he was pictured in his wellington boots trying to salvage his wine cellar from the autumn floods lapping up to his 13th century official residence, Bishopthorpe palace, near York.

His remarks certainly dragged the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey - there is little love lost between him and Dr Hope - in their wake. Dr Carey yesterday issued a rare media statement emphasising that it was not for the church to dictate the timing of the election.

There is a debate among bishops about the desirability of an election. Yesterday the bishops of Oxford, Durham and Salisbury - all with rural dioceses - suggested that it should go ahead as soon as possible.

webTitle: Judge lets woman die eight years after stroke

fields.headline: Judge lets woman die eight years after stroke
fields.trailText: An elderly stroke victim who was kept alive artificially for eight years while her family pleaded with doctors to abandon their efforts will finally be allowed to die in peace after a high court hearing yesterday.
fields.body:
An elderly stroke victim who was kept alive artificially for eight years while her family pleaded with doctors to abandon their efforts will finally be allowed to die in peace after a high court hearing yesterday.

Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division, granted the NHS trust caring for the 73-year-old woman a declaration that doctors may lawfully withdraw artificial feeding and hydration from her and let her die with dignity.

The woman is in a persistent vegetative state (PVS), described as a living death, in which patients are unaware of their surroundings and can be kept alive only by artificial feeding.

Dame Elizabeth banned the media from identifying the patient or the hospital trust until after her death, expected in around two weeks. She was anxious to protect hospital staff from being troubled by "various groups who hold strong feelings on the subject of life and death".

She made a permanent order banning identification of the hospital - one of nine run by the trust - and the doctors and medical staff caring for the patient. She said the woman's daughter had the right to speak to the media but urged her not to do so until after her mother's death.

Last January Dame Elizabeth made an unprecedented order banning the media for life from reporting on the new identities or whereabouts of Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the young killers of the Merseyside two-year-old James Bulger. She ruled that their lives would be at risk from reprisals.

Claire Johnston, for the official solicitor, told the court that the patient's daughter felt "her mother was treated in a way that was inappropriate and that the views of the family were not given enough weight".

Dame Elizabeth said the woman suffered a stroke 13 years ago, but continued to have a worthwhile quality of life. In 1993 she was struck down by a brain haemorrhage and had remained unconscious in hospital, being fed through a tube.

In June 1995 her son first approached the hospital asking for feeding to be discontinued. Another request was made later that year but the treating doctor said it was not appropriate at that time.

The case was finally referred to the high court after an examination last June indicated that the patient showed virtually no awareness of her surroundings.

Dame Elizabeth sympathised with the cautious approach adopted by the hospital and the patient's carers but said it was now appropriate to seek guidance from the court. "I think that they might, if I may say so, have come rather sooner."

A leading neurologist who examined the patient had felt she displayed minimal consciousness. He sought guidance from a report on PVS by the Royal College of Physicians, but that report was "not at all clear" in some respects. The college is shortly to issue new guidelines.

Evidence was given by two professors of neurology, who confirmed that the patient was now in a persistent vegetative state, having no awareness of her environment and unable to respond properly to stimuli.

One explained that although she did still show occasional signs of flickering eye movement, these were not proper eye-tracking motions or "menace responses". The judge said she was satisfied there was now "no evidence of a working mind".

Nutrition and hydration should be withdrawn as a matter of urgency. There was no question of recovery and the protracted vigil was extremely distressing for the patient's family, said the judge.

"In my judgment it is entirely proper that the tube should not be replaced and that artificial nutrition be brought to an end and she be permitted to die peacefully."

webTitle: Archives lost as arson wrecks ballet's temporary HQ

fields.headline: Archives lost as arson wrecks ballet's temporary HQ
fields.trailText: Arsonists have wrecked the headquarters of one of Britain's leading ballet companies in a blaze which destroyed historic archives and left thousand of pounds' worth of costumes soaked and smoke-damaged.
fields.body:
Arsonists have wrecked the headquarters of one of Britain's leading ballet companies in a blaze which destroyed historic archives and left thousand of pounds' worth of costumes soaked and smoke-damaged.

Petty thieves are suspected of setting alight the former school in Leeds which is housing the Northern Ballet Theatre temporarily until a £6m new base in the city's arts quarter is finished in two years. Hundreds of letters - some from past performers, critics and the ballet's late director, Christopher Gable - have been lost, along with contracts and other details for forthcoming productions and tours.

Eighty firefighters fought the blaze at the former West Park girls high school in north Leeds, where the nearby Horsforth comprehensive lost five mobile classrooms to arsonists last week.

"I have seen all my administration go up in smoke, including every file in my computer which just melted," said Mark Skipper, chief executive of Northern Ballet, whose touring production of Jekyll and Hyde is about to be replaced by the company's setting of Romeo and Juliet.

"We have now got three weeks to replace or repair all the Romeo and Juliet costumes," said Mr Skipper.

"We are not sure yet what state the wardrobe's in, because we have not been allowed back into the building, but they're certainly badly damaged by smoke, water and the ceiling falling in."

webTitle: Sad tale of an affair that ended and an abortion row that goes on and on

fields.headline: Sad tale of an affair that ended and an abortion row that goes on and on
fields.trailText: The story of Claire Hansell's abortion has danced its way across the tabloids with a spurned ex-boyfriend in hot pursuit. It is a sad and complicated tale of a brief relationship gone wrong, of a man who left his wife and was then left by his pregnant lover, and the eager involvement of the anti-abortion lobby.
fields.body:
The story of Claire Hansell's abortion has danced its way across the tabloids with a spurned ex-boyfriend in hot pursuit. It is a sad and complicated tale of a brief relationship gone wrong, of a man who left his wife and was then left by his pregnant lover, and the eager involvement of the anti-abortion lobby.

It has spawned guest television appearances for Stephen Hone, Ms Hansell's former lover, who told of his court attempt to stop the abortion on Richard and Judy, on Tricia and other local television programmes in the Midlands, where the sorry story unfolded.

Mr Hone, who had said he planned to take court action to claim the foetal remains from his ex-girlfriend's termination, learned last night that they had been destroyed. He had planned a funeral for the nine-week-old foetus.

The remains were removed from the Marie Stopes clinic where the abortion took place on March 19 and cremated as foetal waste a day later.

Mr Hone, 24, had sought a high court injunction to stop Ms Hansell, 31, from having an abortion. The clinic where she had been due to have the termination gave a guarantee that it would wait for further court investigation, but Ms Hansell - who is legally entitled to an abortion - simply went to another clinic.

She is now seeking a restraining order against Mr Hone after he persisted in telephoning and sending her text messages. She contends that Mr Hone has been parking his car outside her house and hanging around her daughter's school playground.

Birthday

Mr Hone, a sales consultant, and Ms Hansell, a business development manager at a hotel, began their affair sometime before Christmas last year. He says it was after her birthday in November; she says it was in December when she agreed to meet him at a hotel after he went to his work's party. Whatever the case, by New Year's Day, he had walked out on his wife and young daughter and son. The two families, who lived side by side in a terraced row, had been close and Mr Hone had built a pathway linking both gardens, so that their children could play together.

The pair began a sexual relationship and used only the withdrawal method during intercourse. Soon Ms Hansell, who has a four-year-old daughter from a previous relationship, was pregnant. Mr Hone says he was overjoyed. She says she was not. Mr Hone maintains that she changed her mind "all the time" about the abortion, but she is adamant that she had wanted one from the start.

She says: "He knew my decision. He said, 'At the end of the day it's your body. I am not particularly keen on abortion but if that's what you want then it's up to you.' Everything was fine until I finished with him."

He says: "We sat down and talked about it and basically we agreed that we would keep the child. I offered to give up my job and my career."

Mr Hone says they had split up "once, no twice", but had still been together until he decided to take the matter to court. She says they split up five weeks ago.

Each of them threatened to kill themselves and each now says it was a ploy. Hers, "to get him out of the house"; his, "I just wanted to give her a bit of pain." Neither planned to go through with it.

Mr Hone had gone to the clinic where Ms Hansell asked for a termination. The pair sat through all the interviews together, and she signed the consent form for the abortion. He claims that he believed they were just confirming the pregnancy; she says he has had children before and knows that this is "nonsense".

After the visit to the clinic, Mr Hone began to read books on abortion and studied American anti-abortion websites. He contacted the anti-abortion group Life, which put him in touch with the Pro-Life Alliance. "If it hadn't been for the Pro-Life Alliance I would never have been in court," he says. "I wasn't so vocally anti-abortion. It was after I read more about it. When I found out about the abortion I couldn't believe it. She has murdered our child. It's not just her body, it's the child's body as well - it's an innocent child's body."

Last week, when Mr Hone discovered that the abortion had taken place, he decided to pursue the foetal remains. Sitting in a deckchair in his rented house, where a picture of a baby sits on the mantelpiece in a silver frame, he says: "I want to be able to bury my son or daughter. I want to know that it's not going to some lab rat to be tested on or chucked in a skip. I will have a funeral and say goodbye to it and then get on with my life. My child was murdered and he has a right to a decent burial. I don't think Claire should have any rights."

Macabre

Yesterday, Ms Hansell said she was pleased to learn that the foetus had been disposed of, as she felt Mr Hone's pursuit of it was macabre. "I was awake during the whole thing [she had a local anaesthetic]. It's just a bloody mess. It's like a big clot. There's nothing like a baby at all. He's probably actually done me a favour. I don't feel emotional now. After I had done it I almost breathed a sigh of relief."

She says she is scared at the prospect of Mr Hone returning to live next door, but is resolute about the decisions she made. "He wants to have superior right. He wants to overrule my decision," she says. "His ultimate mission is that men get the final say. When I made my decision he felt he was able to overrule it. I never wanted to have the child."

Mr Hone says he will go on "fighting for children" and will set up websites and try to get an anti-abortion video shown on television. "I want to help men who are unfortunately going through this," he says.

He admits that he has phoned and sent text messages to Ms Hansell, but says: "I phoned her and said, 'Look, I still love you anyway.' I am not harassing her. I called her twice. I own the house next door and I could go there and park my car outside. Just because I think what she is doing is wrong doesn't mean I don't care for her.

"I had no choice. You cannot blame me that the law says I don't have any rights. Ask any parent whose child has died and they would want to know where their baby is. I am having to face the reality of how that child felt having its arms and leg ripped off."

fields.headline: Tory prayer
fields.trailText: It is hardly surprising that the prime minister's foray into religion should be matched by a call by bishops of the Church of England to delay the election (Milk supply 'under threat', March 30).
fields.body:
It is hardly surprising that the prime minister's foray into religion should be matched by a call by bishops of the Church of England to delay the election (Milk supply 'under threat', March 30). Most of them were appointed under Tory prime ministers and Mr Hague recently made his views on the matter very clear. But if the government does decide on postponement, extra parliamentary time could be used to push through two issues which the bishops consistently oppose - a ban on fox hunting and the repeal of section 28.
Rev Dr David L Gosling
Cambridge

fields.headline: Serb plight
fields.trailText: The Taliban's destruction of enormous statues of Buddha has generated international outrage (Taliban unlock museum to show destroyed statues, March 23). By way of contrast, a deafening silence surrounds the plight of Serbian Orthodox churches in Kosovo.
fields.body:
The Taliban's destruction of enormous statues of Buddha has generated international outrage (Kabul collection: Taliban unlock museum to show destroyed statues, March 23). By way of contrast, a deafening silence surrounds the plight of Serbian Orthodox churches in Kosovo. Over 100 churches, many medieval, have been either destroyed or severely damaged since the start of Nato's occupation. There is a concerted campaign by Kosovo Albanian extremists to eradicate the province's 1,000-year-old Serbian legacy. Fortunately, the three most important medieval monasteries - Gracanica, Decani and Pec - have so far been spared, but what will be their fate when K-For eventually departs?
Misha Simic
Bedford

fields.headline: If you could only give poetry more space
fields.trailText: Your article about favourite poems and poetry tastes (Lines to live by, March 27) was intended to be a laugh, but it was snide and superior.
fields.body:
Your article about favourite poems and poetry tastes (Lines to live by, March 27) was intended to be a laugh, but it was snide and superior. It also concealed something important - few people in Britain now read poetry of any kind and, of those, the majority are locked into the sounds, rhymes, rhythms and tastes of their schooldays.

As a published poet, I don't blame them for this, since they are rarely offered any information or encouragement to help them discover and enjoy contemporary poetry. The Guardian and Observer, for example, give us many interesting and informed articles and reviews on contemporary art, architecture, dance, films, music, novels, opera, plays, pop - but very rarely anything about poetry. Even when the subject does appear, it's generally for some token or incidental reason. Occasionally, as you recently demonstrated, it's brought in just to have a bit of fun.

As a poet, I'm all for fun, and wouldn't want to take myself too seriously. But the English language and its literature are pre-eminent in the world and I would think that contemporary poetry in English could be of interest to a lot of people everywhere. Since newspapers are the main source of information and education on the arts, why do they ignore poetry? The usual reply is because it's too difficult and obscure, or that it doesn't rhyme, but this is only said because poetry has found new and varied forms of expression, subjects, voices and sensibilities. The real problem is that people have not been popularly exposed or educated to these changes. Poems on the Underground is, perhaps, the exception, but it's sad that poetry can only be openly displayed and encouraged when it is underground.
Brian Hughes
Lausanne, Switzerland
brian_hughes@bluewin.ch

 Iain Finlayson criticises Kipling for "chauvinism, racism and misogyny" and thinks he would be in prison today. Sheila Cassidy, imprisoned in Chile with many revolutionary women who had fallen foul of one of the worst of modern dictators, reported in Audacity to Believe that these women loved the poem If. "It is curious to think of Kipling, who seems almost scorned in England, being read and loved by fiery young Latin Americans so many years after his death and so far away from England."

She adds that maybe the fact that these young women had undergone torture at the hands of Pinochet's men, "made them claim for their own" the lines: If you can force your heart and nerve and sinew/To serve your turn long after they are gone,/And so hold on when there is nothing in you/Except the Will which says to them: "Hold on!"

Perhaps a case of the poem being greater than the poet.
Liz Callister
Sheffield
Callisters@care4free.net

fields.headline: Washed-up utopias
fields.trailText: What are the socialist principles your correspondent talks about (Letters, March 30)? Are they the principles followed by countries such as Russia, Yugoslavia, Zimbabwe et al; principles that have led to terror and corruption.
fields.body:
What are the socialist principles your correspondent talks about (Letters, March 30)? Are they the principles followed by countries such as Russia, Yugoslavia, Zimbabwe et al; principles that have led to terror and corruption. She should follow the creed of the party she now despises, which she describes as standing for fairness, social justice and opportunity for all; of a party which has recognised the futility of seeking the socialist utopia.
Ernie Gordon
Swaffham, Norfolk

 Our local Tory party news-letter claims Oxford is a "soft touch" for asylum seekers. This makes it difficult for Conservative central office to claim the Dagenham Tories' leaflet is an isolated incident (Tory leaflets inflame race issue, March 29).
Dominic and Lucy Vickers
Oxford

 Presumably the reason the plague of foot and mouth has been visited upon us is that the prime minister has been skimping on his prayers (Blair puts his faith in religious partners, March 30).
David Ross
London

 Is there any significance in the fact that former MI5 director general Stella Rimington is a director of Marks and Spencer - a floundering entity with a glorious past but, apparently, no future?
David Northmore
London

 "But a diagnosis of pneumonia need not be a cause for panic. Fatalities tend to be among elderly patients ..." (G2, March 29). That's all right then.
Ian Woolf (age 65)
Brighton

 One thing is certain, even if reading the paper in the loo doesn't save your life (Letters, March 30), you're sure to wash your hands just to get the ink off.
Kieron Farrow
Hornchurch, Essex
