fields.headline: Shepherding our forces
fields.trailText: If what Robin Cook says is true (Hackers could halt UK, March 30) and hackers could cripple Britain faster than a military strike, can we now expect a more thorough "defence" review?
fields.body:
If what Robin Cook says is true (Hackers could halt UK, March 30) and hackers could cripple Britain faster than a military strike, can we now expect a more thorough "defence" review? Perhaps starting by scrapping Britain's militarily useless and politically dangerous nuclear force. Other military resources could then be gradually converted to serve socially useful functions. The army's work rounding up and burying sheep gives a hint of the possibilities while the release of skilled men and women would go a long way to fill the skills shortage in industry.
Jan Melichar
Peace Pledge Union
jan@ppu.org.uk

 I'm shocked that Mr Blair has deployed the army to manage the foot and mouth crisis. I thought he had learned from Mrs Thatcher that greed is the only route to efficiency and that the private sector will always be more competent than public services. He should return the army to barracks and call upon Group 4, PWC, EDS, Capita and Railtrack - they will soon restore the situation and their fees will put the costs of the cull in perspective.
Roger Marston
Craven Arms, Shropshire
RmClun@aol.com

 There is a very large enclosed storage space in Greenwich; recently vacated, seldom visited, built on contaminated land and costing a fortune in upkeep. Used as a repository for animal carcasses, it would bring the countryside to urban areas.
Mike Richards
Milton Keynes
mikerichards@cwcom.net

fields.headline: Kyoto pros and cons
fields.trailText: Just because the US administration says that it has "no interest" in implementing the Kyoto protocol to control climate change doesn't mean it's dead (Bush kills global warming treaty, March 29).
fields.body:
Just because the US administration says that it has "no interest" in implementing the Kyoto protocol to control climate change doesn't mean it's dead (Bush kills global warming treaty, March 29). In fact, US extremism clarifies the task now facing the EU - it has to ratify the protocol and launch a diplomatic offensive to secure the necessary support from other nations to bring it into legal effect. This would send a powerful message that America cannot hold the world to ransom. But it would also exclude the US and its business community from Kyoto's innovative schemes (such as emissions trading and the clean development mechanism). These new carbon markets will bring commercial opportunities and there is no reason why America should be allowed to participate if it will not reduce its disproportionate emissions.
Ritu Kumar
London

 I am happy that the US has finally tumbled to the UK/Euro three-card trick that is the Kyoto protocol. With a dependence on nuclear power, plenty of North Sea gas and hydro-power in Scandinavia, the UK/Euro bloc found it easy to commit to CO2 reductions that they could meet with little effort and no discernible economic effect.

The US targets would give UK/Euro bloc a massive economic advantage for nothing. Australia, barely 2% of the world economy, had to sign up to targets that would hurt its industries and citizens with their total reliance on oil, gas and coal. Developing nations were to suffer because the UK/Euro bloc deigned that they must not pursue the standards of living that we enjoy.

Perhaps now the UK/Euro bloc will realise there are no easy options in reducing our impact on this natural process of climate change.
Stan Coveney
Bromley, Kent
stan.coveney@legalservices.gov.uk

In fact, US extremism clarifies the task now facing the EU - it has to ratify the protocol and launch a diplomatic offensive to secure the necessary support from other nations to bring it into legal effect. This would send a powerful message that America cannot hold the world to ransom. But it would also exclude the US and its business community from Kyoto's innovative schemes (such as emissions trading and the clean development mechanism). These new carbon markets will bring commercial opportunities and there is no reason why America should be allowed to participate if it will not reduce its disproportionate emissions. Ritu Kumar London  I am happy that the US has finally tumbled to the UK/Euro three-card trick that is the Kyoto protocol. With a dependence on nuclear power, plenty of North Sea gas and hydro-power in Scandinavia, the UK/Euro bloc found it easy to commit to CO2 reductions that they could meet with little effort and no discernible economic effect. The US targets would give UK/Euro bloc a massive economic advantage for nothing. Australia, barely 2% of the world economy, had to sign up to targets that would hurt its industries and citizens with their total reliance on oil, gas and coal. Developing nations were to suffer because the UK/Euro bloc deigned that they must not pursue the standards of living that we enjoy. Perhaps now the UK/Euro bloc will realise there are no easy options in reducing our impact on this natural process of climate change. Stan Coveney Bromley, Kent stan.coveney@legalservices.gov.uk

fields.headline: Ugly facts about fiction
fields.trailText: So, now we know, those of us who have been sending in manuscripts for years and being told "thanks but no thanks" (The route to literary success: be young, gifted and very good looking, March 28).
fields.body:
So, now we know, those of us who have been sending in manuscripts for years and being told "thanks but no thanks" (The route to literary success: be young, gifted and very good looking, March 28). The fact I am grizzled, with a face like a worn out armchair, bow-legged, short and hairy, has obviously been a bigger drawback than I feared. You gave us a brief glimpse of what really turns agents and publishers on.

I have considered plastic surgery, leg stretching, a hair transplant and a loft conversion, but at the end of the day it's my age I can't alter much. I can only knock 10 years off, not 40. But I have a cunning plan. I will pretend that one of my handsome sons wrote my books, send in his photo with it - exchanging the idea of a ghost writer for a ghost poser: if you can get someone to write your books for you, why not get someone to smile their way into the style magazines for you? The hilarity of the present system, where things which come from the mind are sold by using the body as a sales tool will soon wear off. It has to. Doesn't it?
Liz Whittaker
Brighouse, W Yorks

 Why didn't you print photographs of "Deborah Moggach, 52" and "short, fat and bald" Louis de Bernières among your gallery of authors? Is it because the Guardian agrees that only very young good-looking people are valuable? Though actually, Deborah Moggach is very beautiful and Louis de Bernières notoriously attractive to women. How sad lack of imagination is. Specially in so-called literary people.
Louisa Young
louisa@louisayoung.demon.co.uk

 I read the piece by Linda Grant (Losing the plot in the slushpile, G2, March 29), on whether writers have to be beautiful, with horror. Am I, as a reader, really being denied the chance to read books I might enjoy because their authors have failed some beauty contest? I am interested only in the content of a book and don't care a straw whether the author is Apollo, Cleopatra, a chimpanzee with acne or a geriatric Martian. However, I know many people like books written about and by their own age group. A growing proportion of the population is now over 50 and some are well off. It is hardly a good sales strategy to ignore a potentially lucrative market.

As a writer: no, I shall not be lying about my age or submitting out-of-date photographs. I like my lived-in face. Yours, unashamedly 63 years young.
Valerie Anand
Mitcham, Surrey
valerie.anand@virgin.net

 It may be difficult for middle-aged provincial writers to get published, but it can be done. I am close to the hopeless example: a 50-ish ex-science teacher living in the Midlands. Yet I got my first novel published last year by sending it to publishers until I found one who liked it. They published my second novel this year, and I am now writing a third. It is true that I have not been featured in Vogue, but my books have been favourably reviewed, and are selling quite well.
Christopher Harris
Birmingham

 In the last six months three recent students from my weekly creating fiction class at the City Lit, in London, have had their first novels published. One is a grandmother and, as far as I know, none of the three writers had any previous media or literary connections.
John Petherbridge
The City Lit
Petherwrite@compuserve.com

 Thanks, Linda Grant. My partner, aged 50, has received identical rejection slips to those you quote. Your article has given him fresh hope and the motivation to try overseas agents and publishers (an Antipodean background does have some uses ...)
Heather Dale
Keighley, W Yorks
h.dale@brad.ac.uk

webTitle: Leader: City unshaken by Maxwell report

fields.headline: Could it happen again?
fields.standfirst: The Maxwell report will not shake the City
fields.trailText: Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, Kevin Maxwell and the accountants Coopers & Lybrand can thank their lucky stars that they are not social workers.
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, Kevin Maxwell and the accountants Coopers & Lybrand can thank their lucky stars that they are not social workers. Not only would they be earning less money than they do, they would also have suffered far more dire consequences as a result of a devastating report like that produced yesterday by the government's inspectors.

The Maxwell scandal, in which the disgraced tycoon milked £400m from his employees' pension funds and ran his interlocking private and public companies like a personal fiefdom, was one of the worst City scandals of the 20th century. He did it with complete contempt for the rules of the City, let alone the retirement plans of his employees, many of whom - notwithstanding partial compensation - are living out the remainder of their lives on greatly reduced pensions.

After an investigation lasting - ludicrously- nearly 10 years, the inspectors concluded that the most important lesson from all the events is that "high ethical and professional standards must always be put before commercial advantage" (Oh, and apple pie is good for you). That conclusion would have sounded less platitudinous if there was any serious sign that the City has changed its spots. Many of the loopholes arising from the Maxwell affair have, to be fair, been closed (and there are more perfectly sensible recommendations in the report), but the underlying culture of the City, with its excessive bonuses and inflated salaries compared with the manufacturing sector, will always make it vulnerable to fresh scandals in the future. The mis-selling of pension plans and the troubles of Equitable Life are merely among the most recent examples.

What will outrage most people is that no one appears to be punishable. Some people used to claim that malpractice in the City was a "victimless crime" just because there were no bodies on the ground. They do not say that any longer. In the Maxwell case, he plundered his own pension fund of £400m, leaving thousands of victims still rubbing their wounds. But it looks highly likely that everyone involved will escape serious punishment.

Kevin Maxwell was found by the inspectors to bear a "heavy responsibility" for what his father did, but since he has already been acquitted on charges brought by the serious fraud office, there is unlikely to be any further prosecution. Goldman Sachs was found to bear "substantial responsibility" for allowing Robert Maxwell to manipulate the stock market.

Goldman says it was "intentionally and successfully deceived" and adds that with the benefit of hindsight the company would have acted differently. If it had used hindsight at the time of its action, the company would have recalled that an earlier inspectors' report found Robert Maxwell was an unsuitable person to hold the stewardship of a public company.

If words like these do not alert all concerned to be doubly vigilant, then what is the point of an inspectors' report in the first place? Coopers & Lybrand, Maxwell's auditors, knew what the mogul was doing with the group's pension funds but did nothing to blow the whistle. Cynics must be wondering whether Maxwell himself, had he lived, would have escaped jail with the help of a good lawyer and and his sanctimonious charm.

Meanwhile, ordinary folk used to seeing people put in jail for relatively trivial offences and social workers castigated for failing in their duty must wonder just what you have to do wrong in the City to get sent to jail. You will not get the answer from this report.

webTitle: Leader: The name of the game

fields.headline: The name of the game
fields.standfirst: In English football, it seems to be Cole
fields.trailText: The entertainer known as Puff Daddy (real name Sean Combs) is to change his name to P Diddy.
fields.body:
The entertainer known as Puff Daddy (real name Sean Combs) is to change his name to P Diddy. Not, according to sources close to him, out of respect for Ken Dodd and his Diddymen, nor even as a tribute to Bo Diddley, but out of the love and respect Mr Daddy is believed to feel for his hero Biggie (the rapper B.I.G).

Such changes of name are far from unusual in show business. Sting was not born Sting, but Gordon Sumner, while Engelbert Humperdinck (the 20th century version) was once Arnold Dorsey; though curiously the artist known as Prince - until recently known as the artist formerly known as Prince - was born Prince Rogers Nelson.

Many famous movie stars were required by their studios to transform their original names into something more tasty. Olivia de Havilland may have been born that way, but Cary Grant was originally plain Archie Leach, while beneath the sheeny surface of Judy Garland there lurked a Frances Gumm. Certainly in the heyday of Samuel Goldwyn, the big Hollywood studios would never have allowed one of their stars to ply her trade under so simple, even prosaic, a name as Minnie Driver. (Sam's real name, by the way, was Goldfish.)

It is odd that this practice has never spread into British sport. Leeds United once had a player called Bottom who, transferred to a London club, adopted the name of Langley, but the tactic of playing under a grubby sobriquet like Pele or Juninho has yet to catch on among such home-grown performers as still get into premiership sides. But that could change under new England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson.

His record so far - his persistence with Andy, his blooding of Ashley at 20, his known enthusiasm for the yet uncapped Joe - hints at an ambition to make up an England side entirely of players called Cole. Let ambitious young players once pick up that message and the registrar general's office will be run off its feet.

fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.standfirst: Got a problem? We want to hear about it. Get in touch with us here at Jobs & Money and we will try to help
fields.trailText: Got a problem? We want to hear about it. Get in touch with us here at Jobs & Money and we will try to help.
fields.body:
Why online bank transfer has put me off

I recently moved some funds from an on-line account at NatWest to an e-savings account at Nationwide. The NatWest website told me that I first had to add the Nationwide account to my list of "beneficiaries".

This took two days. I then tried to pay the funds to my new beneficiary, only to be told that the amount to be transferred "exceeded the payment limit", without saying what the limit was, or why! Eventually, by trial and error I managed to break the sum down into three separate payments, acceptable even though all three were sanctioned within a minute of each other. The website then told me that these payments would take four days to reach their destination.

What it didn't add was that my NatWest account would be debited immediately, the money sent to languish in cyberspace or, I suspect, in an interest-bearing holding account. The transfer took me six days, I lost four days interest on the money, and I did all the work. Online banking? We're being taken for a ride!
IB
Leicestershire

 At NatWest, there are two ways that an online banking customer can set up a payment to a third party. The first is via an online 'form' that generally takes 24-48 hours to set up as the details are checked first in the back office.

The other way is by telephone banking and is generally slightly faster as the details are checked while the customer is on the phone. So if you want to speed things up next time, you know what to do.

The bank's payment limit, which it says is sufficient for over 95% of its personal and small business customers, is not publicised for security reasons.

But, you are right, it does not have system limits for multiple payments so customers can get round this by breaking up a large sum that exceeds the payment limit into several smaller payments.

On the four-day transfer, NatWest says the payment goes through the normal three-day clearing cycle just as a cheque would and is processed by BACS.

What savings plan for a grandchild

I am shortly to become a grandparent for the first time. I want to set up a savings plan for the baby that can't be touched until she or he reaches 18 or 21. I can only afford £25 a month so our independent financial adviser is not interested.
KS
North Yorkshire

 A friendly society plan would suit your book - and your budget. They have a maximum £25 a month, are totally tax free, and can be arranged so that the child cannot touch the money until adulthood. They must run for at least 10 years.

If your IFA is not interested, try another. They earn around £60 from the sale. Leading friendly society names include Family Assurance, Tunbridge Wells, Homeowners and Shepherds - the last named offers free "treats" such as visits to theme parks and Christmas parties to young policyholders.

Is mortgage exit penalty correct?

A close friend has had a £27,000 Halifax mortgage since 1996. Now she's married with a child, they need a larger home. With her husband, she applied to the Halifax for a £90,000 loan. But the Halifax branch said she would have to pay a £1,000 exit penalty as she was "breaking her original agreement". Please tell me this is a mistake!
IW
Somerset

 It is a mistake. She would only have to fork out the £1,000 if she left the Halifax. Halifax loans with penalties are "portable" - they move with you. Borrowers who want to trade up can mix'n'match - in this case, your friend could keep her £27,000 fixed rate and take out another £63,000 Halifax loan from the bank's range. This second loan could be variable rate, discounted, capped or fixed.

Daily v. annual rates of interest

There has been a lot of fuss in some newspapers about how we're being ripped off by mortgage lenders who charge annual interest. We're told daily interest is better. But surely it all depends on interest rates and how you repay?
TK
Birmingham

 You're right. If the interest rates are the same, "daily rest" - to use the trade term - is cheaper. But if the annual interest rate is 0.15% or more lower - on your current mortgage - you save money with the old method unless you make several small irregular payments. Even banks using the annual method will reduce the balance outstanding if you deposit a minimum extra sum - usually £250 or £500. For most people, it is the monthly bill rather than the interest rate or method of computation that counts.

How can I combat windfall loss?

My Standard Life 10-year endowment is about to mature. One option is continuing with Standard Life via a with-profits bond. I would keep voting rights but that would mean I could lose out on a future windfall as these are based on the length of the policy. How can you combat this unfairness?
AH
Derbyshire

 If you stick with Standard Life, your membership would be reborn rather than continued. The rule banning new policyholders from windfalls would not apply to you. Any payments are compensation for the remaining life of a contract because demutualisation typically reduces with-profits payouts by 10%. The bond has no set life and no contractual period so the basis for compensation would be different in this case.

Egg that's taken months to boil

Attracted by seeing the Boots Advantage Egg Visa Card featured consistently on your "best buy" table, I applied for one online just after Xmas. I was given the OK almost instantaneously and a paper application form followed within several days, which I returned by mid January.

After four weeks having heard nothing I contacted Egg, which told me that the paper application must have got lost. It sent me another which I returned by mid February. Boots Egg advertising says that the card will be delivered within 10 working days of them receiving the forms.

The direct debit instruction was set up on February 22 and a PIN arrived the next week. On enquiring again, I was told that my card should arrive by March 8 which it did not. When I contacted Egg again on March 11, it said it would order me another card.

It's now March 21 and I still have no card. I wonder if Boots Egg is a victim of its own success and unable to keep up with the demand for this card? I also wonder whether the offer of six months at 0% interest will be two months by the time I receive mine!
GL
Sheffield

 Boots and Egg extend their apologies and are emphatic that cases like yours are extremely rare. They say they are coping well with demand and are generally having no problem getting cards to applicants within the promised 10 days.

What's more worrying in your case, however, is that it's almost unheard of for a customer to receive a PIN before they receive their card. For security reasons, Egg always sends out a card before the associated PIN, so the implication is that someone could have intercepted your card. For this reason an Egg official will be contacting you and sorting out your case personally. And rest assured, the six months at 0% introductory offer will start only once you have received your card.

Tax on estate when you die abroad

My father moved to Australia four years before his death and took out two Australian pension schemes. One of them (scheme A) was a private scheme and the other (scheme B) was operated via his employer. The trustees of scheme A accepted that my father's partner was an eligible dependant and paid her a lump sum at their discretion.

But the trustees of scheme B did not accept this and, there being no other dependants, the payment was made to the estate. Though he died abroad, he was UK domiciled and therefore his estate is being taxed here. The Capital Tax Office argue that the benefits paid under both schemes are liable for inheritance tax because they were not UK-approved schemes and therefore are treated as gifts with reservation.

Is its argument correct or do you think some or all of the money should be exempt from tax?
RM
Hertfordshire

 Inheritance tax specialists at accountants Ernst & Young say the Capital Tax Office's decision sounds correct.

Whether the pension in question is Australian or UK based is largely irrelevant. It all boils down to the powers the trustees do or don't have to give pension benefits to a specified person. If this is not in their remit, the money becomes part of the estate and consequently liable to inheritance tax, provided of course that the estate exceeds the IHT threshold (£234,000 in the 2000/2001 tax year).

It sounds as if the Inland Revenue may have challenged the discretionary power of the scheme A trustees to pay benefits to your father's partner. But, without knowing all the details, it is impossible to say whether this challenge is worth questioning. To take things further you would need to get professional help from a qualified tax adviser.

Should we dump our endowment?

We've got an Equitable Life endowment to pay off our mortgage - taken out in December 1997. My shaky knowledge of the Halifax takeover is that it hasn't taken over the endowments bit. Our instinct is to sell up, change to a repayment mortgage and get term assurance instead.
BW
Brighton

&149; # In fact, Halifax swallowed Equitable Life's entire with-profits fund, including endowments, which will be handled by its subsidiary, Clerical Medical. The fund is currently invested largely in gilts. You should wait to see if it is allowed to invest more in equities again before making a decision. Selling up will realise very little return. You could switch to a repayment mortgage and keep your endowment free standing, but you stand to lose almost all your three-year investment.

For most people, it is the monthly bill rather than the interest rate or method of computation that counts. How can I combat windfall loss? My Standard Life 10-year endowment is about to mature. One option is continuing with Standard Life via a with-profits bond. I would keep voting rights but that would mean I could lose out on a future windfall as these are based on the length of the policy. How can you combat this unfairness? AH Derbyshire  If you stick with Standard Life, your membership would be reborn rather than continued. The rule banning new policyholders from windfalls would not apply to you. Any payments are compensation for the remaining life of a contract because demutualisation typically reduces with-profits payouts by 10%. The bond has no set life and no contractual period so the basis for compensation would be different in this case. Egg that's taken months to boil Attracted by seeing the Boots Advantage Egg Visa Card featured consistently on your "best buy" table, I applied for one online just after Xmas. I was given the OK almost instantaneously and a paper application form followed within several days, which I returned by mid January. After four weeks having heard nothing I contacted Egg, which told me that the paper application must have got lost. It sent me another which I returned by mid February. Boots Egg advertising says that the card will be delivered within 10 working days of them receiving the forms. The direct debit instruction was set up on February 22 and a PIN arrived the next week. On enquiring again, I was told that my card should arrive by March 8 which it did not. When I contacted Egg again on March 11, it said it would order me another card. It's now March 21 and I still have no card. I wonder if Boots Egg is a victim of its own success and unable to keep up with the demand for this card? I also wonder whether the offer of six months at 0% interest will be two months by the time I receive mine! GL Sheffield  Boots and Egg extend their apologies and are emphatic that cases like yours are extremely rare. They say they are coping well with demand and are generally having no problem getting cards to applicants within the promised 10 days. What's more worrying in your case, however, is that it's almost unheard of for a customer to receive a PIN before they receive their card. For security reasons, Egg always sends out a card before the associated PIN, so the implication is that someone could have intercepted your card. For this reason an Egg official will be contacting you and sorting out your case personally. And rest assured, the six months at 0% introductory offer will start only once you have received your card. Tax on estate when you die abroad My father moved to Australia four years before his death and took out two Australian pension schemes. One of them (scheme A) was a private scheme and the other (scheme B) was operated via his employer. The trustees of scheme A accepted that my father's partner was an eligible dependant and paid her a lump sum at their discretion. But the trustees of scheme B did not accept this and, there being no other dependants, the payment was made to the estate. Is its argument correct or do you think some or all of the money should be exempt from tax? RM Hertfordshire  Inheritance tax specialists at accountants Ernst & Young say the Capital Tax Office's decision sounds correct. If this is not in their remit, the money becomes part of the estate and consequently liable to inheritance tax, provided of course that the estate exceeds the IHT threshold (£234,000 in the 2000/2001 tax year). Should we dump our endowment? We've got an Equitable Life endowment to pay off our mortgage - taken out in December 1997. BW Brighton &149; # In fact, Halifax swallowed Equitable Life's entire with-profits fund, including endowments, which will be handled by its subsidiary, Clerical Medical. The fund is currently invested largely in gilts. You should wait to see if it is allowed to invest more in equities again before making a decision. Selling up will realise very little return. You could switch to a repayment mortgage and keep your endowment free standing, but you stand to lose almost all your three-year investment.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Collapsing stock markets and slowing growth rates have changed the economic climate dramatically over the past few weeks. A downturn forces people to question their strategies, policies and ability to cope.
fields.body:
Collapsing stock markets and slowing growth rates have changed the economic climate dramatically over the past few weeks. A downturn forces people to question their strategies, policies and ability to cope.

A review of previous, similar conditions is illuminating. Even during the worst conditions, quality counts. Great companies survive difficult conditions by creating and maintaining an organisational culture that builds quality. These values are embedded in the way they treat their employees, customers and communities.

During good times, it is easy to tell people how important they are, spend money on training and provide incentives for outstanding performance. As conditions get tough, bosses often retreat. They worry about the possible implications of keeping people informed or praising people whose role is under scrutiny.

This produces a progressive decline in morale, which saps performance. Good managers, in contrast, trust their colleagues, keep them informed and give them a chance to play a role in solving problems.

Training budgets are often among the first items to be reviewed when conditions tighten. Sharp cutbacks can harm performance in the short and long term. Precious skills erode, while talented people see the writing on the wall and seek better outlets for their abilities.

The first victims of any decline in capability are customers. Just when they expect more for their money, they get less. Customer care is vital as markets tighten. Many firms, however, make the mistake of conceding quality for quantity in busi ness development. This creates opportunities for "vulture marketing". Vulture marketers seek out rivals that ignore the needs of existing, quality clients in favour of new customers. They circle above, watching as buyers become impatient with deteriorating service - then strike.

A powerful market focus calls for more than direct customer care. Innovation is perhaps even more important. One of the oldest, recorded examples of success during difficult conditions is the story of Vickers during the recession of the 1880s.

Tom Vickers, the founder, was asked why the company prospered, when so many of its rivals failed. He replied that they had "innovated a way through it, exploiting rather than mislaying their technical strengths".

New value-added products and services allied to the constant improvement in production processes are essential.

Innovation is a crucial factor in business success, but it cannot be confined to products, processes or markets. Organisations play a vital role in the communities they serve. Last week's Association of Chartered Certified Accountants UK environmental reporting awards showed how large companies such as Shell International and small firms like Bovince combined good business performance with environmental responsibility.

In a global marketplace, this challenge to business goes further. The recent African Leaders programme organised by the British Council highlighted the potential of the new generation of African leaders and their need for help in transforming their economies. The acid test of globalisation is whether organisations sustain their investment.

Evidence from the past is that these people-centred attitudes are jettisoned when conditions get tough. Harsher times shifted the emphasis to resource management, budgets and controls.

The test of the new leaders is their ability to balance these priorities.

Professor Tom Cannon is chief executive of Respect London

webTitle: British space boffins are in demand

fields.headline: Plenty of space in a thriving industry
fields.standfirst: There's no need to boldly go to Nassa if you have a passion for the cosmos. British boffins are in demand at home in this fast growing sector reports Martyn Seal
fields.trailText: There's no need to boldly go to Nassa if you have a passion for the cosmos. British boffins are in demand at home in this fast growing sector reports Martyn Seal.
fields.body:
Say the words space industry and many would picture an astronaut sticking an American flag in the moon. The same people may also imagine that getting a job in this area would involve emigrating to the US or at least to the continent.

Well, unpack those suitcases because, believe it or not, Britain has a thriving space industry. It may not involve manned space missions, but it has plenty of work for those with a science or technical background, or even those who are just fascinated by what's up there in the cosmos.

The basic objective of any space project is, of course, to send a machine into space to collect scientific data or serve a commercial purpose such as telecommunications.

Space stations with people floating around in them are still part of the overall scheme despite the recent burn up of the Russian space station Mir. But the glamour of the old Apollo missions is largely out and practical investigations are in.

Commercial endeavours in this area will be funded by industry. Science research travels a more complicated path. Dr Colin Pillinger, head of the planetary and space institute at the Open University, says: "Scientists think up a project they want to do and write a scientific proposal. That has to be accepted by funding bodies such as the European Space Agency or the British Research Council. Then it passes over to the engineers who do the building. You bring students into these projects at all levels both as engineers and as scientists and they get trained and become the next generation."

One thing from this is clear: be it for scientific or commercial purposes, someone has to build these machines. So for any who have a knack for the technical there are satellites, telescopes, rockets and probes all built in this country and, as Alistair Scott, director of communications at engineering firm Astrium in Stevenage, Hertfordshire, points out, employment is readily available. "We're looking for 400 people in the UK at the moment," he says. "We're undergoing a massive recruitment campaign because we've got so much work on, we're desperate for the right people."

The work can involve anything from anticipating the trajectory of rockets to designing computer software. Obviously, good qualifications are essential but, once they have been achieved, what's the best way to secure a position?

Helen Robinson, human resource manager at Astrium, which was formed out of the space-related businesses of BAe Systems and the old GEC, thinks those with a broad perspective are more likely to succeed.

"Quite often they'll be working on a very small element of a satellite or a system and it's useful if they are able to take the wider view, not just focus on their little bit," she explains. "Obviously computer literacy is important because our work is very hi-tech. Our candidates have got to be pretty flexible and have good communication and presentation skills."

But, for those with a love of pure science, a job as an astronomer (someone who studies the scientific aspects of the cosmos) or an astrophysicist (someone who applies the laws of physics to the study of the stars) may be a better employment bet.

Andre Balogh has made it to the top of his profession and is now professor of space physics at the University of London, Imperial College. "It involves running a research group that is involved in interpreting the data that's returned by the various instruments from the space missions in terms of the physical phenomena and processes that take place in the solar system."

So how do you become a professor of space physics? "I started as a research assistant and was involved in various space projects," recalls Balogh. "The successes of these eventually built up in such a way that the university decided to offer me a chair. But it took 10 years for that to happen."

His projects were collaborations with the European Space Agency monitoring solar winds, exploring comets and sending a probe called Ulysses around the poles of the sun. Ulysses was a project he started 24 years ago and is still working on today.

"It was first conceived in 1977 and was built in the late 70s. We launched it in 1990 and it's now operating in space until 2004. It is fascinating to build instruments and test them on the ground to make sure that they will work in space, but the real payoff is when they are up there in space, working."

If your strong point is your passion for the cosmos, rather than your qualifications, there is a burgeoning space related leisure industry with increasing numbers of jobs.

Take Teresa Grafton, who is responsible for running the education programme at the London Planetarium. "I certainly don't have a science degree; I'm a trained teacher with a life long interest in astronomy," she explains. "That's how I got into this work. And there are plenty of people like me around."

She believes there now are more physics and astronomy graduates who don't just want to rush to the nearest university to work or even get an industry related job.

"They don't want to do pure research or go to the world's big observatories or do PhDs in astronomy. They want to communicate to the public the excitement of what's happening in space science and research. Although there was always Patrick Moore, of course, and he was never a scientist. He's a wonderful example of someone with a life long interest in something who's worked it into a reputable career."

Her job involves making sure that the show at the London Planetarium is scientifically accurate. "Where I'm not certain I bring in people I know. I have a great network of contacts at the international planetarium society. Then there is the internet and a vast library here."

A young man's game

Mother of two Dr Alice Breeveld, 34, works at the Mullard Space Science Laboratory (MSSL). She earns £24,000 and made her first inroads into space science when she went on a six-month trip to Australia.

"I went to the university of New South Wales to be a laboratory assistant. I was thinking of being a physicist but, while I was there, I bumped into a bunch of astronomers who showed me the big radio telescope in New South Wales and the Anglo-Australian telescope. They got me really enthusiastic about astronomy. So I ended up going to University College London and did a degree in astronomy and physics. I really enjoyed the course so when I finished it I got a job here."

So what's involved in working as an astrophysicist? Is it all plain sailing once you've got a PhD and a position?

"I've always been on contract. Once you've got a PhD you could go out into industry and earn quite good money, but people don't really do it for that in the academic arena. Which doesn't mean it isn't very competitive, because we're all on contracts so every three years you could be out on your ear. The only way you can maintain your job is to produce science papers with original data and ideas and that can be very hard work.

"The people who tend to get on are young men who don't have any other requirements on their time. They'll work all the hours god sends, but people like me with a family, find it difficult to give that sort of time.

"I think that means a balance is lost, particularly when people get promoted to the higher ranks of senior lecturers and professors since these jobs need people who can communicate and have more experience of life."

So be warned, science jobs can be tough on those wanting a family life.

webTitle: New space centre herlads major lift off

fields.headline: New centre heralds major lift off
fields.trailText: In Leicester, the soon to be unveiled millennium commission-backed National Space Centre will provide another employment opportunity. Prior to its opening, Helen Osbourn, 24, has been working for the centre as a picture researcher for 18 months earning £15,500. It's her first job after university, and she found that her work experience paid off.
fields.body:
In Leicester, the soon to be unveiled millennium commission-backed National Space Centre will provide another employment opportunity. Prior to its opening, Helen Osbourn, 24, has been working for the centre as a picture researcher for 18 months earning £15,500. It's her first job after university, and she found that her work experience paid off.

"I found the job on the internet. I'd got a lot of work experience in picture libraries, I joined the photographers gallery in London for a few months and I'd also done some video work.

"The space centre needed someone who knew how to get more unusual pictures not only from Nasa but from diverse picture libraries. Because of my work experience I had the knowledge and the contacts and knew where to go for them. So that really helped."

And her picture researching has led to another interesting career break.

"My job ends very soon but I've been offered work as a production assistant here, helping the producer with the opening show of the planetarium. So that will be video work making a space show."

webTitle: A pioneering training scheme for executives

fields.headline: Turning a mirror on management style
fields.standfirst: A pioneering training scheme is allowing executives from different companies to learn by swapping roles, writes Eileen Sheridan
fields.trailText: A pioneering training scheme is allowing executives from different companies to learn by swapping roles, writes Eileen Sheridan.
fields.body:
The simplest ideas are often the best, but not always the most obvious, so getting managers from one firm to slip into another manager's shoes in a different company is one of those blindingly obvious moves which leaves everyone wondering why it has never been done before.

The simple idea behind lead2lead is a ground-breaker in management training. It grew out of Lancaster University Management School's International Masters in Practising Management (IMPM).

Managers swap roles with other managers, join them at their work and then act as hosts in return, giving each side an insight into how the other works. So the scheme offers "learning from difference, learning from each other, learning from reflection".

Lancaster's IMPM programme is run in conjunction with four first-ranking business schools around the world but with each school developing its own idiom.

Professor Jonathan Gosling explains: "We attempted to get away from the formulaic management school stuff and put people in the midst of practice to think about their own and other people's techniques.

"As part of that programme we discovered that people found the best part to be what they learned from each other. So we developed the exchange idea rather than just field visits."

Once the exchange programme was up and running people who took part started to describe it as a life-changing experience; not merely observing someone else at work, but actually thinking themselves into the other manager's role.

"Now we can offer this as a learning experience outside the IMPM programme and developed lead2lead last summer," says Gosling. "We work on these assumptions; leaders learn more from each other than from educators and learning on the job is far more powerful and relevant than learning in a classroom or through a case study.

"The exchanges offer the opportunity to watch another leader in action. This gives the visitor a chance to learn from the host and also gives them direct feedback on how they take up their role. Together they can work as partners sharing their joint experience to look for best practice, compare and contrast different leadership styles and to solve key business challenges. People in one function in a company are often blinkered and need to broaden their horizons."

Before managers embark on a lead2lead exchange they are given individual coaching with emphasis on role analysis so that they are encouraged to think about how they affect their leadership - how they influence others and how they communicate.

This is followed by training in observation, which clarifies for the manager how they construct their observations about other people and what they read into situations.

For a manager facing change, a merger or takeover, for example, lead2lead can give experience with another manager who has already faced and dealt with the same issues.

Gosling cites managers from a European power company who were facing deregulation and who learned from others who had already been through this change and were now operating in the commercial world.

James Patterson, who is in charge of management development programmes at AstraZeneca, took part in an exchange with human resources executive Kerry Chandler while they were both doing their IMPM.

"You have to decide what kind of experience would be useful for you," he explains. "I was running a large department with 70 people and I was interested in meeting someone who had had to deal with lots of change. Kerry was in charge of HR at Motorola at the time. She was interested in our career plan and personal development."

He spent five days in the US with Kerry - she has since moved on to IBM - and describes the experience as "particularly special". He explains: "The idea is that you go and literally sit in with them and live with them doing their job. You get an insight into the company's culture and the hierarchy and real insights into how the other person sees their role in the organisation and how the organisation sees their role."

As close observers, the exchange managers can assist each other with suggestions and Patterson says that if the partners are reasonably perceptive and responsive, a genuine bond is created. The companies also benefit from close links and ongoing relationships with other companies that have been involved in the exchange. AstraZeneca has since developed connections with IBM through Kerry and the Royal Bank of Canada.

 For further information visit Lead2lead or write to Jonathan Gosling, director, Lancaster University Management School, Lancaster LA1 4YX or email gosling@lead2lead.net

This is followed by training in observation, which clarifies for the manager how they construct their observations about other people and what they read into situations. For a manager facing change, a merger or takeover, for example, lead2lead can give experience with another manager who has already faced and dealt with the same issues. Gosling cites managers from a European power company who were facing deregulation and who learned from others who had already been through this change and were now operating in the commercial world. James Patterson, who is in charge of management development programmes at AstraZeneca, took part in an exchange with human resources executive Kerry Chandler while they were both doing their IMPM. "You have to decide what kind of experience would be useful for you," he explains. "I was running a large department with 70 people and I was interested in meeting someone who had had to deal with lots of change. Kerry was in charge of HR at Motorola at the time. She was interested in our career plan and personal development." He spent five days in the US with Kerry - she has since moved on to IBM - and describes the experience as "particularly special". He explains: "The idea is that you go and literally sit in with them and live with them doing their job. You get an insight into the company's culture and the hierarchy and real insights into how the other person sees their role in the organisation and how the organisation sees their role." As close observers, the exchange managers can assist each other with suggestions and Patterson says that if the partners are reasonably perceptive and responsive, a genuine bond is created. The companies also benefit from close links and ongoing relationships with other companies that have been involved in the exchange. AstraZeneca has since developed connections with IBM through Kerry and the Royal Bank of Canada.  For further information visit Lead2lead or write to Jonathan Gosling, director, Lancaster University Management School, Lancaster LA1 4YX or email gosling@lead2lead.net

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Mark Blythe's big break

fields.headline: A careering success
fields.standfirst: Mark Blythe was still at university when he started publishing jobs titles. Wendy Smith finds how he turned a hobby into a thriving business
fields.trailText: Mark Blythe was still at university when he started publishing jobs titles. Wendy Smith finds how he turned a hobby into a thriving business.
fields.body:
Mark Blythe was a busy chap during his student days. Busy rowing, busy having fun and, oh yes, busy laying down the foundations of his future publishing businesses. And all this before he sat his finals.

Blythe was not impressed with the calibre of careers guidance he received as a land management student at Reading University. The most it usually amounted to was the odd prospective employer posting up a job spec on the noticeboard. In the booming mid-80s there was a huge demand for land management graduates and hungry recruiters were not finding their fodder.

Blythe, the type of man who bounds into a room rather than enters, saw a gap in the careers market. He formed the germ of an idea that would eventually lead to the thriving specialist careers guide publishing business GTI, which today employs 65 people and has a £5m turnover. It produces 50 individual titles, including Target Law, Target Construction and Target Engineer; 650,000 copies of careers guides are distributed in total.

His idea was simply to come up with a careers advice publication that would be the vehicle for prospective employers, alongside independent editorial, which would be distributed to appropriate university careers offices and undergraduates around the UK. The publication would be targeted to a specific career. Employers would pay to advertise in them and the students would get free careers advice.

The thing about good ideas is that you often need to share them - with the right people. Blythe says: "I had lots of big breaks but I think the best one was meeting Adrian Wood, a fellow rower at the university rowing club, and telling him about my plans. I can remember sitting on the ramp of the boathouse talking with Adrian about an idea, which initially was to do a general publication for all students. Adrian was a perfect foil for me. He brought solid Yorkshire principles of thinking things through."

A third partner was co-opted because he owned a computer. Blythe's then girlfriend and now wife Jo got roped in to do the typing. "We believe that we were the first people to really target specific groups with what they wanted rather than bundle it all together in big careers directories."

They each invested £200 earned from holiday work. They carried on their lectures in the day and planned their company by night. "To be quite honest, none of us could necessarily write but we briefed other people to do it and we edited. We managed to blag a design student from university to do the desktop publishing," recalls Blythe.

The next big break was Blythe's summer job. His property company employers loved the idea so much that they let him work from their offices to drum up business. The first issue, aimed at chartered surveyors, was put together at the beginning of their final year. They drove around the country delivering it by hand to the universities to save money on postage.

At that stage Blythe admits the thought of making a real business wasn't uppermost in their minds. "It was still a bit of a laugh, just something to do," he recalls. But the career guide for chartered surveyors made an agreeable profit and they began to realise that this idea could be rolled out into other subject areas. In between doing their finals they added construction, civil engineering and food titles to their list.

Did they work every hour? "We did work very hard and our social lives suffered," says Blythe. After university, both Blythe and Wood were offered jobs by clients who had advertised in their publications. But they turned them down and carried on playing with GTI.

Blythe, 34, feels the defining moment which transformed GTI from a hobby into a proper business was when it entered the legal market in 1993. "This was an area with masses of competitors and 10 times as many students. We decided to give it a crack and for three weeks we didn't sell a single ad. Then the phone began to ring and we booked five ads in one afternoon. Suddenly we went from little titles into a much bigger league."

Today GTI's titles include those covering school leavers, business schools and French and German, as well as the website doctorjob.com. Student bedsits have been replaced by impressive offices, housed in a huge converted barn in the Oxfordshire countryside.

webTitle: Jags put thorny times behind them

fields.headline: Jags put thorny times behind them
fields.trailText: Partick Thistle's domination of the Scottish Second Division has been such that, with a fifth of the season still remaining, they are poised to become the first league club in Britain to secure promotion.
fields.body:
For months, it has been a question not of if but when? Partick Thistle's domination of the Scottish Second Division has been such that, with a fifth of the season still remaining, they are poised to become the first league club in Britain to secure promotion.

It is said of their Glasgow home, Firhill, that it is the "place for thrills". That may or may not be the case in the modest environs of lower league football, but Firhill has certainly been among the places this season for the most predictable three points.

This afternoon, the Jags are on their travels, a point required at bottom club, Stirling Albion, to secure the step up.

It makes a welcome change. Partick Thistle - beloved of the Glasgow intelligentsia who find the Old Firm beyond the pale - have been more used these last few years to peering into the abyss. The banter of the Jags was less dandy, more disbelieving, when they dropped from the Premier Division five years ago and continued their freefall two seasons later, in 1998, by tumbling out of the First Division.

It was, hardly surprisingly, a downward spiral played to the beat of financial problems, one Save the Jags plan being an unsuccessful attempt to convince Robert Carlyle, alleged Thistle fan and star of the hit movie The Full Monty, to do a sponsored strip.

By small turns of fortune can seasons of despair be unleashed. Required to play off against Dundee United to ensure their Premier Division survival in May 1996, Partick Thistle were just seconds from an aggregate 2-1 win over the two legs when Brian Welsh headed in injury time to take the tie into extra-time. The nail in the coffin duly arrived with Owen Coyle's 115th minute strike to send Thistle down.

Three managers later, an old friend was required to steady nerves. In the late spring of 1999, John Lambie was enjoying a sabbatical from football, licking his wounds from a bruising spell at Falkirk, feeding his pigeons and smoking his favourite cigars. The club looked destined for the Third Division when the SOS call came for Lambie to become the Jags' manager for a third time. There could only be one answer. Lambie turned to experienced players on modest wages.

"Two clubs are in my blood," he says, "Hamilton Academical, because they gave me my first chance in management, in 1984, and Partick Thistle.

"The fans are brilliant and I took the club from second bottom of the First Division to promotion to the Premier Division and kept them there for four years. They were in the Premier Division when I left."

The chief executive and secretary Alan Dick adds: "The expectations of supporters have been as high of Partick in the Second Division these last three seasons as those of Rangers and Celtic fans in the Scottish Premier League: to win week in, week out. For two seasons, it just didn't happen.

"The drop out of the top flight, plus big wages and a brand new stand took Partick Thistle as close to the brink as any club. What we have done is set a budget, keep to it and spend only what we bring in."

webTitle: Albania in the dock over Cole missile

fields.headline: Albania in the dock over Cole missile
fields.trailText: Albania will face disciplinary action after England's debutant Ashley Cole was struck by a missile in the World Cup qualifier in Tirana.
fields.body:
Albania will face disciplinary action after England's debutant Ashley Cole was struck by a missile in the World Cup qualifier in Tirana.

Fifa's communications director Keith Cooper said yesterday: "The incident was mentioned in the reports of both the match observer and the referee. We will now investigate the matter further."

It is almost certain the case will be heard by Fifa's disciplinary committee on April 26. Albania are likely to be fined.

Rio Ferdinand said rocks, bottles and cigarette lighters were hurled at England players but Cole was the only one struck, apparently by a lipstick case.

The Scotland captain Colin Hendry's chances of receiving an international ban have risen, with Fifa revealing it has been notified by the match observer of the elbowing incident that put San Marino's Nicola Albani in hospital.

Heinz-Herbert Kreh did not see the incident but subsequently viewed it on television. But Fifa is awaiting the report of the referee Petteri Kari, who also did not see it at the time.

The FA has announced measures aimed to avoid travel chaos in Cardiff on FA Cup final day, May 12. There will be 10 Saturday morning trains from London, twice the normal number, with Arsenal or Tottenham in the final. Rail engineering works in the Severn tunnel will be suspended, and roadworks in Cardiff and on surrounding trunk routes will be reduced to a minimum.

fields.headline: Child's play for Sven
fields.trailText: Much has been made this week of the sophistication of England's new football coach but Sven's selections match those of the nation's prepubescent youth.
fields.body:
Much has been made this week of the sophistication of England's new football coach. Gone are the days of gung-ho hit-and-hope, gone are dressing-room readings from Henry V and requests to midfielders to drop incendiary devices around the pitch. Now we have a grown-up in charge.

Interesting, then, that a survey of football fans under the age of 10 taken before Wednesday's game with Albania has revealed uncanny parallels between the ideas of England's new professorial top man and the nation's prepubescent youth.

Before Sven-Goran Eriksson had announced his team for the midweek fixture, the website for junior football enthusiasts, Footy365.com, polled more than 1500 youngsters as to who should play. The overwhelming consensus was the following: Seaman; Neville, Ferdinand, Campbell, Ashley Cole; Scholes, Butt, Beckham; Andy Cole, Owen, Heskey. Only one selection different from the Tirana team and, but for an injury to Campbell, exactly the one that started the second half.

Coincidence maybe. But if I was Steve McManaman's agent I'd be trying to find out why his man is failing to appeal to the squeaky-voiced constituency.

Reg plans to call tune at Old Trafford

A white-label CD arrives on the desk, called nothing more than Give Us One More Goal. On further investigation it turns out, as the title might suggest, to be a song dedicated to football, which opens with the following lines:

"We will climb the highest mountain,

We will sail the seven seas

Just to be there at the finals

And to claim our victories."

Tim Rice can probably rest easy in his bed; his claim to be Britain's finest lyricist is unlikely to be challenged. So who is the perpetrator of the piece? There is a clue in the other two tracks on the disc: Wild Thing and Love Is All Around. Yes, it's Reg Presley, the UFO-loving leader of the Troggs, the man who has spent much of his fortune hoping to prove that crop circles are created by visitors from another planet.

"I wrote it originally for Euro 2000," he tells me. "What I wanted was a tribal effort, something people could relate to in the primordial state they get into at football matches. Trouble was the company I was releasing it through went into liquidation before the tournament and it was too late to release it with someone else. So I was left with it. I was wondering what to do with it when a friend who was into football told me Manchester United have about 50m fans. I'm never shy of an opportunity so I thought they might like to make it their official song. It's got this penny whistle and drum vibe about it, which I imagine in my mind as your red coats marching into battle. Now wouldn't that look terrific on the pitch before a big game?"

And you imagine Sir Alex would be thrilled to watch a few hundred drummers in fancy dress re-enacting the American war of independence while churning up his greensward. Still, if Fergie is taken by the number's naggingly catchy chorus, maybe Reg could use the royalties to combine his two interests and fund research into the most compelling question of our times: when aliens arrive from Planet Zorg to stamp around in the corn making those esoteric patterns from the cover of Led Zeppelin albums, will they turn out to be Manchester United fans?

fields.headline: Gemmill a dancing queen? Tell that to the Cossacks!
fields.trailText: Gemmill a dancing queen? Tell that to the Cossacks!
fields.body:
Name Ron's "Odd One Out!": the Valley , the Dell, the Glen ... yes, you've got it! ... the odd one's off to Spurs! ... ho ho! ... marvellous!

Well, there's no easy games nowadays, hmm? ... even at home ... an awkward leg ... hmm? ... Finally abandoned my Saturday afternoon "Buckaroo" session in favour of the football! ... After all the question-marks about David Beckham ... he answers his critics the best way possible! ... On the pitch!

Fierce debate raging last week on one of the Manchester United websites - sir.alex@ blastofthehairdryer.com ... Was the new England captain suffering a dip in form ... or had opponents "sussed" how to deal with him?

Ho ho! ... cometh the hour ... cometh ... er ... Becks ... reminiscent of the young Ron Manager in his pomp! ... many eerie parallels ... hmm? ... Like him, I burst on to the scene ... a precocious talent causing mayhem amongst defenders unaccustomed to my game!

... Taking up threatening positions on the left ... bamboozling opponents ... turning up unexpectedly on the right ... tearing down the wing ... a change of pace ... a little shimmy ... hmm? ... an unexpected change of direction ... drop of the shoulder ... sudden burst of speed ... causing utter confusion as I stormed through the middle ... But eventually opponents got wise, and three games into the season ... tended to leave me to my own devices and concentrate on the man with the ball.

Subsequently "rested" for a number of games, then pitched back into the fray to contest a fierce local derby! ... leaving the field to the chant "There's only one Ron Manager" from fans who would normally consider me their sworn enemy ... Ho ho! I'll always remember the "Gaffer's" comments: "Maybe I should rest him before every game!" ... and he promptly did so for the rest of the season ... marvellous!

Well, England are back on track! ... There's one in the eye for those who say you need a captain with a big gruff voice!

What about "Squeaky" Stein at Fulham! ... a fearsome man! We came in at half-time trailing 3-0 ... down to 10 men ... no bawling from Squeaky ... ho ho! ... You got the general drift! ... taking to the field for the second half, I even tucked my shorts into my underwear ... and was promptly dismissed for lewd and offensive behaviour!

And a reader's letter! ... Mark Pitts of Chiswick writes: "Ron, settle an argument, can you ... where exactly is your loins?"

... Eh? ... ho ho! ... "Gird" question! ... isn't it? ... er ... it's easy on a pig! ... hmm? ... loin of pork ... apple sauce ... bit of crackling ... Mrs Manager on a Sunday lunchtime ... But seriously, your loins are next to your brisket! ... the medical term is "the nether regions" ... isn't it? ... The Greeks have a word for it ... "Hades" ... isn't it? ... Anusol! ... that's your man! ... ask Mrs Manager! ... right! ... cleared that up ...

... And a reader's letter! ... "Ron, I've just heard somebody's made up a dance commemorating Archie Gemmill scoring a goal! That's daft isn't it? Dancing's for fairies!" (Name withheld.)

Ho ho! ... nothing new, really ... takes me back to a memorable European night against Dynamo Kiev ... I'm as popular there as Norman Wisdom is in Albania ... used to be a 50ft stone effigy of me there ... until a night of high-jinks with a coach party of Taliban tourists got a little out of hand ...

But that night in Ukraine ... I hit a rich seam of form ... setting off on wave after wave of mazy dribbles ... in my then little-imitated but effective style ... elbows tucked in ... keeping a low centre of gravity ... long athletic strides ... the ball seemingly glued to my feet as I weaved through the entire defence at breakneck speed ... Played a blinder!

At a civic reception after the game ... a local dance troupe announced a tribute! ... and blow me! ... one of those little Cossack dancers comes belting on to the stage ... a large pom-pom tied to one of his boots ... and proceeds to give a stunningly accurate depiction of my inadvertent own goal which clinched it for Kiev! ... marvellous! ... Ron Manager in full flow! ... in his pomp!

This week's One to Watch! ... Andy Goram! ho ho ! ... the last "hurrah" ... isn't it? ... If you thought Barthez was the wild man of the six-yard area ... wait till Andy gets to Manchester!

Wears his heart on his sleeve! ... sanctioned by the SFA! ... a Scot fighting for the pride of the English? ... er, "awa' ye go"! ... Andy's got no prejudices! ... loyal to a fault! ... at 37 he goes marching on! If anyone will bang the drum for United it's Andy ... hats off to Fergie! ... some managers wouldn't have touched him with a bargepole! ... er ... at 37 ... marvellous!

But seriously, your loins are next to your brisket! ... the medical term is "the nether regions" ... isn't it? ... The Greeks have a word for it ... "Hades" ... isn't it? ... Anusol! ... that's your man! ... ask Mrs Manager! ... right! ... cleared that up ... ... And a reader's letter! ... "Ron, I've just heard somebody's made up a dance commemorating Archie Gemmill scoring a goal! That's daft isn't it? Dancing's for fairies!" (Name withheld.) Ho ho! ... nothing new, really ... takes me back to a memorable European night against Dynamo Kiev ... I'm as popular there as Norman Wisdom is in Albania ... used to be a 50ft stone effigy of me there ... until a night of high-jinks with a coach party of Taliban tourists got a little out of hand ... But that night in Ukraine ... I hit a rich seam of form ... setting off on wave after wave of mazy dribbles ... in my then little-imitated but effective style ... elbows tucked in ... keeping a low centre of gravity ... long athletic strides ... the ball seemingly glued to my feet as I weaved through the entire defence at breakneck speed ... Played a blinder! At a civic reception after the game ... a local dance troupe announced a tribute! ... and blow me! ... one of those little Cossack dancers comes belting on to the stage ... a large pom-pom tied to one of his boots ... and proceeds to give a stunningly accurate depiction of my inadvertent own goal which clinched it for Kiev! ... marvellous! ... Ron Manager in full flow! ... in his pomp! This week's One to Watch! ... Andy Goram! ho ho ! ... the last "hurrah" ... isn't it? ... If you thought Barthez was the wild man of the six-yard area ... wait till Andy gets to Manchester! Wears his heart on his sleeve! ... sanctioned by the SFA! ... a Scot fighting for the pride of the English? ... er, "awa' ye go"! ... Andy's got no prejudices! ... loyal to a fault! ... at 37 he goes marching on! If anyone will bang the drum for United it's Andy ... hats off to Fergie! ... some managers wouldn't have touched him with a bargepole! ... er ... at 37 ... marvellous!

fields.headline: Le Saux forgets early blues
fields.trailText: Graeme Le Saux will remain eternally grateful for the foreign imports at Chelsea and the more serious and cultured approach they have instilled in the other players; so effectively has the laddish spirit been flushed out that, in the twilight of his career, he finally feels he belongs.
fields.body:
Graeme Le Saux will remain eternally grateful for the foreign imports at Chelsea and the more serious and cultured approach they have instilled in the other players; so effectively has the laddish spirit been flushed out that, in the twilight of his career, he finally feels he belongs.

In his first incarnation at Chelsea, Le Saux's cerebral ways made him seem like a foreigner in an era when grey matter was almost as implausible as grey hair among the confederacy of dunces in the dressing room. His team-mates felt threatened by someone they perceived to be flaunting his intellectualism by reading The Guardian and expressing an interest in antiques.

He was reduced to such loneliness that it became, he recalls, a case of get out or give up. He says: "I felt like the boy at school wearing glasses who is picked on all the time.

"Every day I went in for training, there was something new someone would mention about me to increase my problems. I am what I am.

"I wasn't trying to create an image. It was a very unhappy situation because I've always loved being part of a team and I wanted to fit in."

Now, ironically, Le Saux's wisdom is so valued at Stamford Bridge that he has become an unofficial Dear Deirdre for team mates with problems on or off the field. And as a footballer whose political views are un-stereotypically pinkish, he is naturally Chelsea's PFA representative.

Yet it is probably his intelligence, as much as his somewhat effete looks, that encourages supporters, and on one disgraceful occasion his England colleague Robbie Fowler, to question his sexuality. He accepts that the consequence of him rising to the bait on so many occasions is that opponents now set out to provoke him.

He says: "Sometimes you go out there and nothing can upset you, nothing can touch you. But I have an overwhelming sense of justice and when I know I'm right and don't get the decision, I can't restrain myself. When you see me having a go at a linesman, though, I am not swearing at him or abusing him, so it looks a lot worse than it is.

"Away from the pitch, when the adrenalin's not pumping, I would laugh if someone gave me any homophobic abuse. But I would love to sit down with those fans who do it at games and ask them why. We're trying to attract families and raise the image of the sport and their disgusting chants do nothing to help."

Le Saux, after 18 months fighting injury, is the only player in Britain complaining of too few games at the moment. Of course, he had no idea he would be saying that when he was diagnosed with a bone spur on his heel in October 1999 and told to expect a three-month absence.

That dragged on for 10 months and after returning for five games earlier this season, he developed an Achilles tendon problem, which he blames on the inefficient way he was strapping his ankle.

If he had not been so close to tears, he might have laughed, though when he returned four months later, against Newcastle in January, he was not amused when "Warren Barton poleaxed me in the first few minutes. He studded me on the hip and though I struggled on for 30 minutes, I had to come off".

That led to another three-game absence though he has now played three matches in a row and could make it four against Middlesbrough today.

After such a long period on the sidelines, had Sven-Goran Eriksson called Le Saux into his England squad he might have injured himself again falling off his chair, particularly as so many candidates have suddenly emerged for his left back position. Gareth Barry was briefly flavour of the month under Kevin Keegan, Chris Powell shone against Spain and Arsenal's Ashley Cole was luminous against Albania on Wednesday.

Le Saux, 32, was impressed by Cole, if not England's defensive qualities. He says: "We looked good going forward but my concern was how we defended as a team because Finland and Albania both got through us very quickly, they got to the dangerous parts of the pitch with relative ease. Now that Tony Adams has gone, they need another voice in defence."

If he thought he was no longer capable of playing at international level, Le Saux says he would make an Adams-style announcement himself. And he welcomes the competition, saying: "If I get back into the England team, I want to do it on merit.

"I would hate to be thought of as the England left back because there was no one else." In any case, he says, there is an order to things and if he gets to wear the three lions again it will be a reward for performing consistently well for Chelsea.

Some cynics might suggest that is unlikely when he cannot even rely on a consistent role in a Chelsea side whose shape is often drastically rearranged mid-match by their coach, Claudio Ranieri, whose favourite toy as a child must have been a kaleidoscope.

Le Saux admits: "It is difficult for players when formations change two or three times in a game, it can be quite confusing. I've never played in a team that has had the changes we have had."

If he thought it would guarantee his place, Le Saux would doubtless volunteer for a spell in goal since, during those monotonous months on crutches or in physio, he wondered not only whether his career was over but whether he should attempt a comeback at all.

Like all new parents, he and his wife Mariana have experienced a dramatic shift in priorities since daughter Georgina was born two years ago. And, he says, if there had been any danger of his injury becoming chronic and threatening his chances of playing a full, active part in her upbringing, he would have seriously considered retirement.

As it is, he is ensuring the adult Georgina will have a greater understanding of the world she grew up in by collecting this newspaper's weekly section, the Editor. Revealing such a thing in the bad old days would have invited more ridicule from his Chelsea team-mates, though one suspects the current crop, including new father Dennis Wise, will find the story enchanting.

Le Saux's catalogue of injuries

Nov 2000 Breaks down in training with persistent achilles tendon problem. Out for 10 weeks.

Oct 2000 Substituted with calf injury in first international for 16 months, against Germany at Wembley.

Oct 1999 Ruptures ankle tendons against Arsenal. Out for rest of season and also misses Euro 2000. Phil Neville "fills in" at left-back for the tournament.

April 1999 Damages knee in training. Out for eight weeks.

Oct 1997 Breaks elbow against Leicester. Out for five weeks.

Dec 1995 Breaks tibia, dislocates ankle, ruptures tendons against Middlesbrough. Misses rest of season and first 10 weeks of the 1996-97 season.

Career

St Paul's Jersey Aug 1 1986 - Dec 9 1987

Chelsea (free) Dec 9 1987 - Mar 25 1993

Blackburn Rovers (£700,000) Mar 25 1993 - Aug 8 1997

Chelsea (£5m) Aug 8 1997 -

England

International caps 36

International goals 1
