fields.headline: Hoddle unveiled by Spurs
fields.trailText: Returning hero signs a five-year contract and prepares for a baptism of fire - the FA Cup semi-final against Arsenal on April 8.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle was finally unveiled as Tottenham's new manager last night. Hoddle, who has signed a five-year contract, left Southampton on Wednesday with the Saints chairman Rupert Lowe demanding £800,000 compensation for the loss his manager who had 15 months left on his contract at the Dell.

The Spurs director of football David Pleat is expected to be at the helm for today's Premiership meeting with Arsenal at Highbury. Hoddle will begin work at Tottenham on Monday morning.

One of the former England manager's first tasks at White Hart Lane will be to persuade his England players Sol Campbell and Darren Anderton to stay at the club. Both have been unhappy under previous manager George Graham.

News of the appointment came as Tottenham's owners, Enic, yesterday witnessed a 20% fall in their share price to 47p, a five-year low. The drop came in the wake of reports that the company is making £50m available to Spurs for transfer funds.

Hoddle met Enic officials earlier this week, where the amount of money he will have available for new players was discussed. But City analysts have queried the figure of £50m.

According to Nigel Hawkins, an analyst at Williams de Broe: "Short of fund raising outside what Enic has at present, I think £50m sounds somewhat excessive. I would doubt the authenticity of that figure, and it would be difficult to reconcile that with their existing financial situation."

Meanwhile, Southampton confirmed yesterday that Stuart Gray is to be their caretaker manager until the end of the season.

Gray, who declined an opportunity to join Hoddle and his assistant John Gorman at Tottenham said: "It is a great honour. I have had a few roles at the club, and now the chairman and directors have asked me to step in. It is a huge disappointment that Glenn has left but that is gone now. We have nine games left and we have to be positive."

With Tottenham and Arsenal meeting again on April 8 in the FA Cup semi-final - now to be Hoddle's first game in charge - the Gunners' manager Arsene Wenger yesterday praised his former charge at Monaco.

Wenger said he had encouraged Hoddle to go into football management. "I like to keep a check on the progress of good people I have worked with," he said, "and Glenn has done well as I knew he would because he is good, calm analyser of the game."

Wenger also said that neither side needed motivating for the forthcoming north London derbies.

"If there were ever two games when Tottenham didn't need a manager at all then it is for two games against Arsenal. The motivation is already there because of the traditional rivalry and we know we will only get three points tomorrow if we produce a great performance."

Wenger said that he had no intention of leaving Arsenal to join Barcelona and that he was going to honour his contract which runs out in June 2002.

Wenger said: "We will go to 2002 and then see what happens after that. My job is to do well with Arsenal and so long as I feel the club has ambition I am very happy to be here.

"I can't wipe out speculation because it happens all the time. If there are questions every time I speak to somebody from another club there would be stories all the time. Some things should always be kept secret. I will fulfil my contract because I am committed to Arsenal. It would be a waste of time for any other club to approach me before 2002."

Barcelona, meanwhile, have reached agreement with Boca Juniors to sign the midfielder Juan Roman Riquelme for a reported $25.73m (£18m). The fee would be an Argentine transfer record.

webTitle: McClaren forced to put United ahead of England

fields.headline: McClaren forced to put United ahead of England
fields.trailText: Steve McClaren's role with England was ended by mutual consent last night after Manchester United made it clear they regard him as the front runner to succeed Sir Alex Ferguson as manager.
fields.body:
Steve McClaren's role with England was ended by mutual consent last night after Manchester United made it clear they wanted him to concentrate on his work at Old Trafford, with a view to succeeding Sir Alex Ferguson as manager.

The Football Association confirmed that McClaren would no longer be a member of Sven-Goran Eriksson's backroom staff, after being deployed for four matches in the wake of Kevin Keegan's departure.

"Steve has played a key part in allowing me to adapt to my new role with the England team," said Eriksson. "He has tremendous ability as a coach and I am sure he will continue to enjoy sustained success with Manchester United."

Although McClaren was keen to extend his role until the end of England's World Cup qualifying campaign, United made it clear they regard him as the front runner to fill the void that will be left by Ferguson's retirement in 14 months' time. The FA was told in talks with the United hierarchy that the club wanted McClaren to concentrate solely on his club career.

An FA spokesman said the decision had been agreed by all parties and that Eriksson, the national coach, understood United's reasons. "Steve's commitment has helped at a very difficult time since he became involved last year and his involvement has been greatly appreciated," said the spokesman.

McClaren has always insisted that United are his main priority, but if a compromise could have been found he would have liked to remain in the England set-up.

However, it was always clear that his availability would be in question after this week's World Cup qualifying match in Albania. If United reach the Champions League final, it takes place in Milan on May 23, only two days before England's friendly against Mexico at Derby's Pride Park.

A long-standing family commitment also means that he would not have been available for the build-up to England's qualifying tie against Greece in Athens on June 6.

Peter Taylor will continue to work alongside Eriksson and Tord Grip after assuring the Leicester board that his work for the national side was not interfering with his managerial duties at Filbert Street.

Meanwhile, Ferguson's relationship with the Trinidad and Tobago Football Federation has come under new strain, after another club v country dispute about Dwight Yorke.

Ferguson was expecting Yorke to arrive in England on Thursday night after playing in the international against Costa Rica on Wednesday, but the jet-lagged striker did not report back until yesterday afternoon and has been ruled out of today's game at Liverpool.

Although Ferguson exonerated Yorke, it was clear he was far from satisfied with the Trinidadian authorities for their part in the mix-up. "I cannot believe Dwight's not been able to get back more quickly, I really cannot believe it," he said. "But it's not his fault, it's purely down to the arrangements for the national team."

The Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier is "optimistic" that his injury-prone midfielder Steven Gerrard will be available to face United today at Anfield.

webTitle: Wise owl sees beyond local scrap

fields.headline: Wise owl sees beyond local scrap
fields.trailText: Peter Shreeves has mastered the Wednesday job, says Dominic Fifield.
fields.body:
As Owl and Blade prepare to joust in the Steel City's 100th league derby, it was strangely appropriate that Peter Shreeves, Sheffield Wednesday's perennial caretaker manager, spent yesterday being overshadowed once again. "You can sit next to me," he said to his midfielder Trond Egil Soltvedt before facing the press, "but you'll show me up. You're too good-looking."

Having assisted David Pleat and Ron Atkinson in south Yorkshire, Shreeves has more recently become Wednesday's own temporary Red Adair. Yet the majority of tomorrow's 39,800 sell-out crowd, the biggest of the Nationwide League season, will be singing the caretaker's name. The second fiddle is on the verge of being given an orchestra to lead.

"I think I'm making a fair fist of the job," said the 60-year-old who, from near certainties for a second successive relegation, has inspired Wednesday to six wins in eight. "First and foremost I have to keep the club up and, whatever the result on Sunday, that will not be determined. Many a favourite has come round Tattenham Corner in the derby only to finish sixth. So my future won't be decided, but I'm comfortable with that situation."

The supporters clearly are not. "He should be at least given first refusal on the job and it should be done now," said Barry Birks, chairman of the Wednesday Independent Supporters' Association. "Any delay could be represented as a real slap in the face and he's done a superb job. He should have been given the position before Paul Jewell."

The Owls' transformation has been remarkable. On being promoted from assistant manager after Jewell's dismissal six weeks ago, Shreeves was set the goal of First Division survival. For a club who had just spent nine seasons in the top flight, that should not have sounded outlandish but, crippled by debt and playing to a half-empty stadium, Wednesday appeared to be sinking fast.

A horrendous start to the campaign left them at the foot; a brief revival towards the end of October flickered and died, swamped in gloomy defeats made all the more galling by Sheffield United's surge towards the play-offs.

The shambles in which Shreeves found the team smacked of last season's traumas, when he oversaw the last 11 games of Wednesday's doomed Premiership existence. Now, after 19 points from a possible 24, Wednesday look down on the relegation scrap from the giddy heights of 15th.

"They were heading for the Conference with no money under Jewell," said Joe Ashton, MP for Bassetlaw whose public criticism of the then manager Danny Wilson polarised the Owls' support last season. "But everyone expected things to get better under Peter. His record at Wednesday has been exemplary - he was Pleat's assistant when we finished seventh in the Premiership - and he never had any problem handling Paolo di Canio or Benito Carbone. They knew Peter was good.

"The old coaches survive in the game because they know their stuff. When people like Danny Wilson talk to players some of them must just ask: 'What do you know? You're younger than my dad'."

"Players always want you to get the job when you are winning," cautioned Shreeves. "It's when you're getting beaten that there are whispers in the corridor. The biggest factor in the turnaround has been our determination not to come second. We've got stickability."

Thankfully such obduracy comes cheap. With the club still an estimated £12m in debt, Andy Booth was sold for £200,000 on deadline day and Wim Jonk, Gilles de Bilde, Kevin Pressman and Andy Hinchcliffe will leave on Bosman transfers in the summer. But Shreeves persuaded Coventry to loan him Carlton Palmer, who played 205 games for Wednesday earlier in his career, and Soltvedt arrived from Southampton for free.

"They have been massive for us," said the manager. "I remember the bus journey back from Wimbledon - Paul's last game in charge - after we'd been beaten 4-1 and were on the floor. We were on our mobiles desperately trying to get Trond and Carlton in. They make my job so much easier. If a player appears to be slacking, he gets a verbal torrent from Carlton."

One suspects there will be no shortage of gee-ups from the former England midfielder tomorrow as United, still in contention for a play-off place, storm Hillsborough. Although it will be Shreeves's first all-Sheffield affair in sole charge, it is by no means his first derby: in 1985 he took his Tottenham side to Arsenal and won 2-1 to stay top of the league.

"It's normally a frenzy of local pride and passion," he said. "But it's the quieter moments, the flashes of skill, that win you derby games. "You can sit next to me," he said to his midfielder Trond Egil Soltvedt before facing the press, "but you'll show me up. You're too good-looking." Having assisted David Pleat and Ron Atkinson in south Yorkshire, Shreeves has more recently become Wednesday's own temporary Red Adair. Yet the majority of tomorrow's 39,800 sell-out crowd, the biggest of the Nationwide League season, will be singing the caretaker's name. The second fiddle is on the verge of being given an orchestra to lead. "I think I'm making a fair fist of the job," said the 60-year-old who, from near certainties for a second successive relegation, has inspired Wednesday to six wins in eight. "First and foremost I have to keep the club up and, whatever the result on Sunday, that will not be determined. Many a favourite has come round Tattenham Corner in the derby only to finish sixth. So my future won't be decided, but I'm comfortable with that situation." The supporters clearly are not. "He should be at least given first refusal on the job and it should be done now," said Barry Birks, chairman of the Wednesday Independent Supporters' Association. "Any delay could be represented as a real slap in the face and he's done a superb job. He should have been given the position before Paul Jewell." The Owls' transformation has been remarkable. On being promoted from assistant manager after Jewell's dismissal six weeks ago, Shreeves was set the goal of First Division survival. For a club who had just spent nine seasons in the top flight, that should not have sounded outlandish but, crippled by debt and playing to a half-empty stadium, Wednesday appeared to be sinking fast. A horrendous start to the campaign left them at the foot; a brief revival towards the end of October flickered and died, swamped in gloomy defeats made all the more galling by Sheffield United's surge towards the play-offs. The shambles in which Shreeves found the team smacked of last season's traumas, when he oversaw the last 11 games of Wednesday's doomed Premiership existence. Now, after 19 points from a possible 24, Wednesday look down on the relegation scrap from the giddy heights of 15th. "They were heading for the Conference with no money under Jewell," said Joe Ashton, MP for Bassetlaw whose public criticism of the then manager Danny Wilson polarised the Owls' support last season. "But everyone expected things to get better under Peter. fields.headline: Taylor calls time on his career, but who cares?
fields.trailText: Taylor calls time on his career, but who cares?
fields.body:
Graham Taylor was one of several football personalities asked to design a "celebrity clock" for an internet charity auction this week (list.auctions.yahoo.com/uk, though his was sold last night). He said: "Too many people in today's world never have enough time to stop and think about anyone but themselves and, hopefully, this clock may remind us all that there are more important things in life than clock-watching." Taylor's design places the numbers in random order and includes the handwritten legend: "Who cares? We do." He'll be missed.

The air will be thick with innuendo at Highfield Road on April 26 when Cynthia Payne is the guest at Ladies' Evening in the Premier Suite (or possibly by then the Nationwide Suite). Fans are invited to "join the 'English madam' for an unforgettable evening full of stories from the woman the establishment loved to hate - author, politician, inmate and more famously the best hostess in London." The Diary, of course, would never stoop so low as to point out Coventry's current inability to score in one of Ms Payne's establishments.

Word of the week comes from a surprising source. Full marks to Strathclyde police for the first recorded use of "Sammarinese" in a UK press statement. Obviously they don't read the Scotsman, where "San Marinans" is the preferred usage.

Terry McDermott, interviewed in Tuesday's Newcastle Evening Chronicle, claims controversially that Alan Shearer "can appear desperately boring on telly". However, he may soon reveal more of his vivacious off-screen personality. "He's working at things," Terry reveals. "He phones me when I'm in bed now to say: 'Did you see that telly interview? I cracked a couple of funnies!'" A fantastic Diary prize will go to any reader who can send us an example of a Shearer TV "funny".

Ian Joyce writes to share memories of inappropriate pre-match music at Hereford. The players' entry to the field, he says, used to be announced by Lobo's Me And You And a Dog Named Boo. A sarcastic nod to the size of the crowd, perhaps.

Last week we claimed that Bury had played God Save The Queen before their memorable Festival of Britain match against Rapid Vienna. Reader Dave Goodacre correctly chides us that 1951 was, in fact, before the old King died. "I do not suppose for one minute that I am the only sad anorak among your readers to point this out," he says. Actually Dave, you are.

A notable contribution to the annals of quirky football violence last weekend, as 40 fans of Gresford Athletic and Cogan Coronation battled it out when their teams met in the FAW Trophy semi-finals at Caersws. It all started, it seems, after a Gresford fan hit someone over the head with his crutch. Things then got rapidly out of hand. "A police dog was dispatched to the ground to try and deal with the trouble," one report said, although without mentioning how it found its way there. Gresford won (the match) 4-3 and meet Ragged School in the final. Could be an untidy affair.

Chelsea and Arsenal fans may remember the Cup-Winners' Cup exploits of Real Zaragoza's Juan Esnaider in 1995. The Argentine striker, now back at Zaragoza on loan from Juventus, was seen having lunch at the house of the eccentric Atletico Madrid president Jesus Gil this week, sparking rumours that he might be about to move to the fallen Madrid giants. Esnaider's denial, however could hardly have been more convincing. "I haven't even thought about the possibility of going back to Atletico," he insisted. "I was there to pick up a horse."

mike.ticher@theguardian.com

webTitle: Spurs dig deep to bring their hero Hoddle home

fields.headline: Spurs dig deep to bring their hero Hoddle home
fields.trailText: New manager and his assistant John Gorman will cost Tottenham £1m in compensation. Hoddle will formally take charge on Monday, and his first game as manager will be the FA Cup semi-final clash with Arsenal on April 8. Tottenham's director of football David Pleat will select the team for today's Premiership meeting with Arsenal at Highbury.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle was finally unveiled as the manager of Tottenham Hotspur last night after three days of negotiations over compensation for his former club Southampton.

Representatives from both sides concluded negotiations shortly after 7pm, and it is believed the south coast club have received almost £1m to compensate for the loss of Hoddle and his assistant John Gorman, who has also moved to Spurs.

Speaking at a White Hart Lane press conference moments after signing his five-year contract worth an estimated £5m, a visibly pleased Hoddle - one of Tottenham's greatest heroes and a lifelong supporter of the club - said it felt like coming home.

"It is an emotional time for John (Gorman) and myself because we spent so many years at Spurs. There is a feeling of coming home. The supporters have given us a fantastic reception. I walked through the turnstiles of the club for the first time when I was eight and I left when I was 29. It is a massive part of my career, and I know how the fans feel."

Hoddle will formally take charge on Monday, and his first game as manager will be the FA Cup semi-final clash with Arsenal on April 8. Tottenham's director of football David Pleat will select the team for today's Premiership meeting with Arsenal at Highbury.

Hoddle announced his resignation from Southampton last Tuesday but the remainder of the week has been taken up mainly by negotiations over compensation. Rupert Lowe, the Saints' chairman, had threatened to withhold Hoddle's registration if a satisfactory figure could not be agreed and demanded a mimimum of £800,000. The final £1m figure accounts for the loss of both Hoddle and Gorman.

The Premier League held talks with both sides in an attempt to resolve the compensation issue but was not involved in settling the final figure on the remaining 15 months of Hoddle's contract at Southampton.

Spurs' executive vice-chairman David Buchler revealed that the compensation money had been placed with the Premier League and would be passed on to Southampton.

Buchler added that Hoddle was the only candidate on their list of managers to replace George Graham, who was sacked three weeks ago. When asked about the delay in announcing the appointment, Buchler said: "There were terms that Glenn had to agree with Southampton as well, and we were waiting for documentation to come through so we could agree to it all. We agreed that documentation, and the finality will be on Monday morning - and that will be an end of it."

Hoddle said he was surprised when Lowe this week gave him permission to talk to Spurs.

"I am very surprised to be here," he admitted. "I got a call from Rupert Lowe to say I had been given permission to speak to Tottenham. I thought about it and wanted the option. It has gone from there.

"I have signed for five years. That is proof that this is not a short-term decision; we have to build from the academy onwards. The goal ahead of us and every club in the Premiership would be thinking about winning it, and we are no different. We have a semi-final of the FA Cup against Arsenal, and games don't come much bigger than that."

The arrival of Hoddle may yet persuade key Tottenham players such as the captain Sol Campbell and Darren Anderton, whose contracts expire this summer, to stay. Buchler revealed that money would be available to Hoddle for the buying of new players, but that funds would also have to be directed to other areas of the club to ensure long-term development.

"There is money available, and we have talked about what we want to do and how to do it," said Buchler. "The talks were not different to the ones I had with George Graham, but the effect is different. We have to invest not only in the first-team squad but also in other areas, like the academy."

Buchler also revealed that the appointment of Hoddle was an attempt to forge new unity at Tottenham after years of turmoil among fans and officals over the direction the club was taking.

"When the supporters chant 'We want our Tottenham back' it is clear there are divisions, and only the fans can tell you what it means," claimed Buchler.

"The fans have been castigated for wanting quick results and being critical but they are only critical when it is needed. This club is going to get closer to its supporters and we are committed to opening a communication route with fans and hopefully we can all work together as a team to build something for the future."

Hoddle, who won two FA Cups during his time at Spurs, is worshipped by its fans. At White Hart Lane he scored 132 goals in 566 games. But he said that the club needed to strike the right balance between style and success. He also praised the former manager Graham.

"George Graham has to be applauded for getting the team where they are. I have to produce the goods over the next five years starting next Sunday."

Given the anger expressed by Southampton's chairman Lowe at Hoddle's departure, he said that he had nothing to feel guilty about. "It wasn't an easy decision to leave Southampton because I have put in a lot of hard work.

"I have heard there is some bitterness and resentment towards me from the Southampton fans but I have left them in a very strong position. I could understand it if they were at the bottom.

"I have no qualms about the glare of attention, it comes with football management. I want to enjoy that side of the job. The biggest person putting pressure on will be me. I set high standards. There is an added pressure because I am a supporter. If you are a supporter of a club, in your heart it is for life. I am overwhelmed and delighted to be back as manager."

Meanwhile, Southamptonconfirmed yesterday that Stuart Gray will be their caretaker manager until the end of the season. Gray had declined an opportunity to join Hoddle and Gorman at Spurs.

The words of Hod

On leaving Southampton

"I have heard there is some bitterness and resentment towards me from the Southampton fans, but I have left them in a very strong position. I could understand it if they were at the bottom. I don't feel guilty."

On returning to Spurs

"I am overwhelmed to be back as manager. I walked through the turnstiles of the club for the first time when I was eight and left when I was 29. I know the feeling of the club, what the fans like and what they don't like. That is nothing false, it is already there and it is a major advantage."

On his predecessor

"Everyone was surprised when George Graham was sacked, but it is not for me to go into the reasons. He must be applauded for getting the team where they are."

On the club's unsettled stars

"I know there have been talks with Sol [Campbell] and Darren [Anderton], and I will be part of persuading them that there is a future at Tottenham."

On next Sunday's FA Cup semi-final

"When you play against the Arsenal there is extra spice: supporters are going to go to work to have a jibe against the rival team. It has got to be better to have that game as my first one than just seeing the season out."

On Tottenham's future

"Spurs have slipped a little bit and there is a lot of hard work to be done. They have always had a style and ideally that is what we want. Spurs can be the club they once were."

webTitle: Review: Audio: Things Can Only Get Better, written and read by John O'Farrell

fields.headline: Things Can Only Get Better, written and read by John O'Farrell
fields.standfirst:
(Random House, £8.99, 150mn)
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: On the cover O'Farrell is billed as having written for "the Rt Hon Gordon Brown MP", which seems to be missing the point of blurb
fields.body: On the cover O'Farrell is billed as having written for "the Rt Hon Gordon Brown MP", which seems to be missing the point of blurb. But it is entirely in keeping with this account of a Labour activist's depressing experiences of 18 Conservative years, doubly disheartening if you grew up in Maidenhead and then worked for the cause in Wandsworth, as he did. His account of Labour's litany of disasters woven with his own misfortunes sounds like Carry On Politics, but this was what it was like. O'Farrell nobly recants his days in the Taliban faction of the left, the ghastly killjoy language police who saw right-wing sin in everything and frightened ordinary folk off Labour. His pleasant breezy delivery retains a youthful zest, which was sorely tested on many a Battersea doorstep. And it reveals an (unconscious?) respect for John Major: O'Farrell also pronounces "want" as "wunt".

fields.headline: Descent of man
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery looks at  Ben, in the World by Doris Lessing, Ovid Metamorphosed ed Philip Terry, American by Blood by Andrew Huebner, and The Chase by Lorna Fergusson
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery looks at Ben, in the World by Doris Lessing, Ovid Metamorphosed ed Philip Terry, American by Blood by Andrew Huebner, and The Chase by Lorna Fergusson
fields.body:
Ben, in the World
Doris Lessing
(Flamingo, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Lessing first introduced us to Ben as "The Fifth Child", a destructive antithesis of infant innocence who tore the Lovatt family apart. Now she has allowed him to grow into adulthood, and the oddities of this horrifying changeling have an explanation. Barrel-chested, hirsute and a creature of instinct, not intellect, he is a genetic throwback, a noble neanderthal. Poor, uncomprehending Ben is abused by the author as well as her characters. Grunting his way through a series of highly improbable scenarios, he is bent clumsily to Lessing's enumeration of the ways in which homo sapiens has sinned against nature. The result is a crude fictionalised lecture on ethics.

Ovid Metamorphosed
ed Philip Terry
(Vintage, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

With A S Byatt, Joyce Carol Oates and Margaret Atwood agreeing to contribute to the anthology, it is hard to imagine that Terry had trouble finding a publisher for this score of stories inspired by Ovid's Metamorphoses . So few everyday readers know the original, but they can always refer to Ted Hughes's bestselling Tales From Ovid . The brief here provides a well-defined space for everyone to stretch, change or redefine the original. Sure, some contrivances work better than others, and there are more monsters from the subconscious than beautiful spirits of the imagination, but this is a clever conception that is both cerebral and enjoyable.

American by Blood
Andrew Huebner
(Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The story of how the west was won has been told as victor's history and guilty tragedy, but Huebner's account is rather more messy. His starting point is the true story of how his great-great-grandfather, August Huebner, turned up late for Custer's last stand. Huebner sends his ancestor off as a scout, first to report back on Little Bighorn, then to hunt down the Cheyenne and Sioux armies. Until he mans a Gatling gun against an Indian encampment, Huebner's anger at the rout of the white man is subdued, whereas his two companions alternate between apocalyptic despair and murderous violence. Sparse and graphic, Huebner's is a very impressive debut.

The Chase
Lorna Fergusson
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

France, in fiction as in life, offers the English a bolt-hole from reality. But reality is inescapable, and so Fergusson makes Gerald and Netty pack their skeletons when they move to Le Sanglier, a hunting lodge in the Dordogne. Netty knows the moment she steps through the French windows that this place is no panacea for her marital ills. The Salle de Chasse, all pagan bloodlust, gives her the shivers, and soon le tout district knows about the Feldwicks' tragedy. Fergusson evocatively disabuses all notions of buying into idyllic France, but Netty's myriad problems, and too many subsidiary characters, crowd the plot.

Barrel-chested, hirsute and a creature of instinct, not intellect, he is a genetic throwback, a noble neanderthal. Poor, uncomprehending Ben is abused by the author as well as her characters. Grunting his way through a series of highly improbable scenarios, he is bent clumsily to Lessing's enumeration of the ways in which homo sapiens has sinned against nature. The result is a crude fictionalised lecture on ethics. Ovid Metamorphosed ed Philip Terry (Vintage, £7.99) Buy it at a discount at BOL With A S Byatt, Joyce Carol Oates and Margaret Atwood agreeing to contribute to the anthology, it is hard to imagine that Terry had trouble finding a publisher for this score of stories inspired by Ovid's Metamorphoses . So few everyday readers know the original, but they can always refer to Ted Hughes's bestselling Tales From Ovid . The brief here provides a well-defined space for everyone to stretch, change or redefine the original. Sure, some contrivances work better than others, and there are more monsters from the subconscious than beautiful spirits of the imagination, but this is a clever conception that is both cerebral and enjoyable. American by Blood Andrew Huebner (Black Swan, £6.99) Buy it at a discount at BOL The story of how the west was won has been told as victor's history and guilty tragedy, but Huebner's account is rather more messy. His starting point is the true story of how his great-great-grandfather, August Huebner, turned up late for Custer's last stand. Huebner sends his ancestor off as a scout, first to report back on Little Bighorn, then to hunt down the Cheyenne and Sioux armies. Until he mans a Gatling gun against an Indian encampment, Huebner's anger at the rout of the white man is subdued, whereas his two companions alternate between apocalyptic despair and murderous violence. Sparse and graphic, Huebner's is a very impressive debut. The Chase Lorna Fergusson (Bloomsbury, £6.99) Buy it at a discount at BOL France, in fiction as in life, offers the English a bolt-hole from reality. But reality is inescapable, and so Fergusson makes Gerald and Netty pack their skeletons when they move to Le Sanglier, a hunting lodge in the Dordogne. Netty knows the moment she steps through the French windows that this place is no panacea for her marital ills. The Salle de Chasse, all pagan bloodlust, gives her the shivers, and soon le tout district knows about the Feldwicks' tragedy. Fergusson evocatively disabuses all notions of buying into idyllic France, but Netty's myriad problems, and too many subsidiary characters, crowd the plot.

fields.headline: On the box
fields.trailText: John Dugdale looks at Mrs Slocombe's Pussy: Growing Up in Front of the Telly, by Stuart Jeffries, and The Most of S J Perelman
fields.body:
Mrs Slocombe's Pussy: Growing Up in Front of the Telly
Stuart Jeffries
(Flamingo, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Television is normally covered in one of two forms: the ephemeral, egocentric review and the dry, academic book tackling the history of genres or the health of the medium. No one before has found a way to fuse the experiential and the analytical, jokey responses to specific programmes and a cogent 20-year overview of the transition from three-channel austerity to 200-channel excess. Just as funny as Clive James when evoking TV's icons and idiocies, Jeffries adroitly uses his autobiographical approach to blend this wry nostalgia with Eeyore-ish reflections on the cultural penalties of digital fragmentation.

The Most of S J Perelman
(Methuen, £10.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Perelman was a New Yorker writer who also contributed to two of the Marx brothers' films; his influence can still be discerned today in writers as diverse as Woody Allen, Alan Coren and Bill Bryson. In his foreword to this reissued collection, Bryson rates him as the wittiest of the 1920s Manhattan humorists, citing the inventiveness of his parodies and his ability to juggle street slang with learned lexicons. Quite a claim: Perelman's contemporaries included Robert Benchley, Dorothy Parker and James Thurber. Once you've read his Raymond Chandler spoof ("Farewell, My Lovely Appetizer"), though, Bryson's verdict no longer seems extravagant.

webTitle: Review: Hellish Nell: Last of Britain's Witches by Malcolm Gaskill

fields.headline: Charmed, I'm sure
fields.standfirst:
Julie Myerson meets Britain's ectoplasmic last witch in Hellish Nell: Last of Britain's Witches by Malcolm Gaskill
Offical Helen Duncan website
fields.trailText: Julie Myerson meets Britain's ectoplasmic last witch in Hellish Nell: Last of Britain's Witches by Malcolm Gaskill
fields.body:
Hellish Nell: Last of Britain's Witches
Malcolm Gaskill
400pp, Fourth Estate, £15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

An obese Scottish mother of six was Britain's most celebrated medium throughout the 1930s and 1940s. Her name was Helen Duncan, and at five foot six and 25 stone, fond of her tea and fags (though with a weak enough pelvic floor to leave puddles at seances), she was clearly all woman.

She had the usual medium's knack of summoning up the dead, but for her encore, she produced ectoplasm: a "cool, clammy and malodorous" jelly in which spirits would cloak themselves in order to assume tangible form. Other mediums (or should that be media?) did it too, but Mrs Duncan produced buckets of the stuff, from all orifices (yes, all). Sceptics suspected that she must simply be pulling out tightly packed yards of diaphanous material previously secreted in vaginal, rectal or nasal cavities. The fact that the alleged ectoplasm often emerged damp, soggy and horribly smelly apparently added weight to this theory, as well as a whole new level of meaning to the phrase "Here's one I made earlier".

But, despite the fact that he devotes pages to its description, it is not mere love of ectoplasm that drives Malcolm Gaskill's "biography of sorts". Duncan is on the historians' map because, in 1944, she was tried at the Old Bailey under the 1735 Witchcraft Act and sentenced to nine months in jail. This was more than unusual. Media (I can't resist) usually got off with a light fine for scaring the horses.

So why was MI5 so worried about her? It seems that ectoplasm wasn't the only thing that flowed from Mrs Duncan: so did information. Somehow she was able to tell relatives about the sinking of a Portsmouth ship before the Admiralty confirmed it. And is it really so weird to hear that MI5 was fretting over a big fat lady with a fanny full of chiffon? Gaskill aptly reminds us that the War Office actually employed an astrologer to cast Hitler's horoscope (Aries: a bad month to invade Poland, enjoy withdrawing from Stalingrad).

Yet why, when its social context is so unnerving, its gynaecological detail so thorough, is Gaskill's book so dull? The first clue lurks in his careful preface, where he goes to great pains to state what the book is not about - now that's what I call hitting the ground running. Apparently it is not an attempt to explain or justify Duncan's art or to talk about witchcraft. He's more interested, he says, in the "cluster of ideas and values" that surrounded these practices. He has, he insists, done his best to "vanish" in the presence of his subjects.

Point taken, but he has vanished a tad too determinedly. Of course, to some extent his cautiousness about the whole malarkey is understandable - we need books that don't come down on either side of the supernatural debate. But on the other hand, this is such downright weird material. When Duncan's husband goes into a trance one night in bed and travels 64 miles to call on his sister (who happily confirms the visit), you do need to know where Gaskill stands. Trance or hangover? Diaphanous manifestation or Awayday Supersaver? Equally, when dead ectoplasmic flappers and babes come trooping out of Helen's nostrils like something from an Esther Williams finale, it's a bit much to expect us to read on without asking the obvious question. So Houdini-ishly has the author disappeared from his narrative that he has left us with something as amorphous and slippery as the outpourings from Duncan's own front bottom.

It's a shame because, embedded in all this rambling, inconclusive prose is a sharp, acrid sense of how and why spiritualism took off after the Great War. So many dead, so many bereaved, such crowds queuing noisily on the Other Side. It is not that I doubt for a moment Gaskill's grip on his subject, more that I lament his inability to communicate it. I almost wept at his verbal knitting, his ostentatious wordiness. Whether you're a Cambridge don or a Huntingdon taxi driver, it's no good knowing lots of long words if you can't use them to bring your meaning alive. So I leave you with this 62-worder about Houdini: "A passion for debunking was fuelled by failure to contact his beloved mother, disappointment which peaked in Atlantic City in June 1922 when the entranced wife of his friend Sir Arthur Conan Doyle acted as amanuensis for a letter from a spirit which used the correct idiom but the wrong language: English rather than an inimitable mishmash of Hungarian, German and Yiddish." If that isn't uncontrolled ectoplasm, what is?

webTitle: Pick of the week: The Age of Cardboard and String, by Charles Boyle

fields.headline: Cheeky alibis
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard on poems with real humour in The Age of Cardboard and String by Charles Boyle
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on poems with real humour in The Age of Cardboard and String by Charles Boyle
fields.body:
The Age of Cardboard and String
Charles Boyle
(Faber, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

One hesitates to review slim vols these days - the poetry world seems to be getting tighter all the time, what with that frightening near-parity of audience and practice (everyone who reads the stuff seems to write it, too), and that in-depth familiarity that poetry critics tend to have for their subject. And one wearies of poems where the poet is obliged to strangle an animal he has just run over in his car.

But this is the business. From the start, you realise that you are in the presence of a sharp, subversive and observant intelligence, a writer with an ear for a story and the easy narrative manner of someone who - it comes as an instant relief to notice this - isn't going to bore you once.

Now, the whole point of criticism is to explain why certain poems are good, but sometimes only quotation will do; and this is a very quotable book. It passes both of the supreme tests of poetry: a) that someone reading it in bed feels an immediate and pressing need to read it out to his or her not notably poetry-friendly spouse; and b) that the spouse laughs at the poet's lines, in the manner and place the poet intended an audience to laugh. The first poem, "A Respectable Neighbourhood", begins:

I was walking with irregular strides, avoiding

the cracks in the pavement and keeping a weather eye open

for the humdrum but telling detail -

the one I could never make up, the proof that I tell no lie -

when this woman starts screaming blue murder

from an upper window. Fuck you!

she was yelling, and meaning it, and only stopped

to draw breath when I came to a stop myself.

Firstly, I hope that reading that makes you want to wonder what happens next. Many of Boyle's poems in this collection - or sequence, they hang so well together - revolve around ideas for stories, collisions between the quotidian and the unhinged that could themselves serve as the opening scenes of extraordinary films. Secondly, notice the artfully concealed control of the metre; it looks like bog-standard chopped-up prose, but note the smile behind the words "irregular strides" which alludes to this very effect, and the almost corny poise with which the line steps over the crack of the break in "avoiding / the cracks" (the draw of breath you make at the words "stopped / to draw breath" is another masterly touch). And thirdly, relish the cheek with which both poet and poem boldly announce their own technique and mission, as if daring you to see the operation of the muscles beneath the face: "keeping a weather eye open / for the humdrum but telling detail". As a frank statement of intent, and coming where it does - at the beginning - it is as welcoming as a handshake. (That the whole episode itself may, of course, be invented, makes it all even funnier.) And you know what? The poem gets even better. I won't spoil it for you by saying what happens next. (Can you imagine saying that about any other contemporary poet?)

Boyle's poems aren't all fun and games, though. There are moments of sinister import, murderous hints recalling, now I come to think of it, Eliot's Sweeney; a series of poems called, fascinatingly, "Alibis"; and, overall, a mind continually on the qui vive , not quite vexed but, as it were, considering it. The voice is quite beguiling: completely unpretentious yet still resonant and lyrical; linguistically precise and emotionally evasive, often at the same time. We like that.

webTitle: Review: The Paymaster: Geoffrey Robinson, Maxwell and New Labour by Tom Bower

fields.headline: The high price of free speech
fields.standfirst: David Leigh  defends the endangered art of the investigative biography with The Paymaster: Geoffrey Robinson, Maxwell and New Labour by Tom Bower
fields.trailText: David Leigh defends the endangered art of the investigative biography with The Paymaster: Geoffrey Robinson, Maxwell and New Labour by Tom Bower
fields.body:
The Paymaster: Geoffrey Robinson, Maxwell and New Labour
Tom Bower
272pp, Simon & Schuster, £17.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There are far too few investigative books written in Britain, but publishers' appetite for them is hardly likely to increase with the news that yet another powerful person has been trying to intimidate bookshops out of stocking the latest work by Tom Bower. The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, offended by what Bower has written about him in The Paymaster , resorted rapidly to the libel lawyers.

The high-priced firm Goodman Derrick banged off letters to WHSmith and Waterstone's, demanding they "cease distribution" of the book and enclosing threatening letters they had sent to the publishers and to the Daily Mail (which had serialised the bits that reflected worst on the Labour government). These letters were a bit misleading because they did not contain a writ, which would have committed Mr Byers to an expensive and bruising bout of real litigation. But they did contain a lot of threats and a demand for apologies and money with menaces: £15,000 to charity and "reasonable" legal costs.

The upshot is that Tom Bower's sales are hit, whether he turns out to be right or wrong. The bookshops, which ought to be treated as common carriers, like telephone companies, are caught in an unfair squeeze. They can't check the contents of all their stock for possible libel, and have no interest in the dispute between Bower and Byers. But they have been put on notice that they are getting sucked into a situation that could cost them money. Byers's behaviour in authorising this is grubby. If I were to call it hypocritical, or even contemptible, would Mr Byers and his lawyers now pursue with similar threats all the newsagents who sell this issue of the Guardian ?

Bower has been attacked in this way before. His fine biography of Robert Maxwell, that fat villain whose shilling was taken by so many Labour apparatchiks, emerged surrounded by Captain Bob's slavering libel lawyers like a pack of stray cats around a fish-head. Maxwell also went for the distributors. Bower's plans for his last book, about the pullovered Virgin boss Richard Branson, led to a dispatch rider pulling up at the author's door with a writ over a separate Evening Standard article he had written. The writ was peculiar, being directed solely at Bower. As Bower notes: "The plan was obvious. Confronted by the impossibility of matching Branson's self-proclaimed fortune to finance a team of lawyers, I would have been forced to capitulate and apologise, and inevitably discredit my own book." Luckily it was saved by a pledge from the Standard 's editor to finance his defence.

Bower is a man with so much support behind him that we don't need to get our handkerchiefs out: however much he is persecuted by the state and its bully boys, he is unlikely ever to end up reduced to street-sweeping like a Soviet-style Czech dissident.

It is a useful compliment to an author, of course, that some of his subjects are so frightened and resentful of what he writes that they should call on the creative expertise of teams of lawyers charging up to £400 an hour merely to try to shut him up.

Nevertheless, the things that happen to him are damaging to everyone. Because of Britain's libel laws, the legal bill is unreasonably high on an investigative text of this kind. I know Tom is a careful researcher from my own experience: he consulted me when he was writing Rebel Tycoon , his colourful book on Tiny Rowland, the Rhodesian-born businessman who bought the Observer . Tiny was an international criminal who bribed his way around Africa and the more complaisant parts of the British establishment; he brought the Observer virtually to its knees as an independent paper in pursuit of his commercial interests and an increasingly demented quarrel with the equally unsavoury Mohamed Al Fayed. Bower's account of my traumatic resignation as investigations editor was highly entertaining; it was also crisp and fair.

This is the kind of work that ought to be protected by British libel law, not made vulnerable by it. Bower's book is utterly in the public interest - even if it contains honest mistakes. There are three interesting fresh allegations. The first is that Robinson, cash cow to his influential Labour friends, himself got £200,000 from the crooked Robert Maxwell and has been deceitful about it ever since. The second is that Robinson was using a tax-dodging offshore trust in a hypocritical way, which the then Treasury permanent secretary, Terry Burns, was reluctant publicly to endorse. And the third is that Byers, as the responsible minister, suppressed a DTI report that revealed evidence about the Maxwell money.

Only the last point is at legal issue. Bower is self-righteously harsh, detailing Byers's reluctance to give the opposition information, claiming he wanted "to bury" the issue and announcing: "Faced with a choice between the public interest and the interests of New Labour, Byers would unhesitatingly care for his party." Byers now says he was deliberately kept out of the whole affair by his officials, who would not even allow him to know the contents of the report on his political colleague. He does not appear to have told any of his questioners this important fact before - that a cabinet minister was so compromised by conflict of interest that he could not be allowed to manage his own department. Even if Bower was wrong (which he does not concede), it was provoked by Byers's stonewalling. And it has flushed out some more of the truth. This is what free speech is all about.

Bower is self-righteously harsh, detailing Byers's reluctance to give the opposition information, claiming he wanted "to bury" the issue and announcing: "Faced with a choice between the public interest and the interests of New Labour, Byers would unhesitatingly care for his party." Byers now says he was deliberately kept out of the whole affair by his officials, who would not even allow him to know the contents of the report on his political colleague. He does not appear to have told any of his questioners this important fact before - that a cabinet minister was so compromised by conflict of interest that he could not be allowed to manage his own department. Even if Bower was wrong (which he does not concede), it was provoked by Byers's stonewalling. And it has flushed out some more of the truth. This is what free speech is all about.

webTitle: Review: The Queen's Conjuror: The Science and Magic of Dr Dee by Benjamin Woolley

fields.headline: The science of spiritualism
fields.standfirst:
Lisa Jardine discovers a dubious doctor in The Queen's Conjuror: The Science and Magic of Dr Dee by Benjamin Woolley
The John Dee Society
fields.trailText: Lisa Jardine discovers a dubious doctor in The Queen's Conjuror: The Science and Magic of Dr Dee by Benjamin Woolley
fields.body:
The Queen's Conjuror: The Science and Magic of Dr Dee
Benjamin Woolley
394pp, HarperCollins, £15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Dr John Dee is a Jekyll and Hyde kind of historical figure - intellectual giant or shady charlatan, depending on your point of view. Born in 1527, when England was enjoying that flowering of art and learning we call the Renaissance, he trained with the scientist and technical instrument-maker Gemma Frisius at Louvain in the Low Countries, and went on to become a mathematician of distinction.

A personal adviser and official writer of technical "position papers" on navigational and maritime policy matters to Queen Elizabeth I, his opinion was sought by the Tudor government on investment in new technologies and projects to smelt metals . He was a consultant to Martin Frobisher's 1576 attempt to discover the Northwest Passage (a northerly trading route by sea to the lucrative markets in Russia and beyond), and trained Frobisher's team of adventurers in navigational techniques. Dee's preface to the first English-language edition of the Greek mathematician Euclid's Elementes of Geometrie (1570), edited by Sir Henry Billingsley, is regarded as a landmark piece of writing on the applications of pure mathematics in science and technology.

On the other hand, Dee associated with disreputable "skryvers", or spiritual mediums, such as William Backhouse and Edward Kelley, and was widely known in his lifetime as a "notorious conjuror". He cast horoscopes, dabbled in alchemy and participated in elaborate attempts to acquire knowledge by consulting spirits summoned with the aid of crystal balls, spells and incantations derived from mysterious manuscripts. Many of those he associated with in these activities were well-known con-artists and fraudsters; some were religious dissidents and informers, others out-and-out criminals.

Benjamin Woolley has woven together the often contradictory evidence from the fragmentary remains concerning the life of Dee with considerable circumspection, so that the reader can make up his or her own mind over which Dr Dee they would rather believe in. This in itself makes The Queen's Conjuror an important book. All earlier biographers of Dee have plumped for their favourite version and suppressed material that fails to support it. If their inclination is towards serious history of science and mathematics, they mould from the fragments a serious Dee, who occasionally (like Newton) lost his head and dabbled in angel-summoning and alchemy. If their own tendency is towards communing with spirits or prophesying the future with the help of astrology, pentangles and magical stones, then they faithfully transcribe the fantastic visions relayed by Kelley to Dee and recorded in the latter's diary. There have been, it has to be said, a good number of these, with the result that Dee has become a popular-culture "magician" - he makes a cameo appearance in Derek Jarman's movie Jubilee , granting Elizabeth I a vision of what London will be like in the 1970s.

Of course, in allowing the reader to judge, Woolley does have to fudge a little. Lurid visions described by skryver Kelley at a seance and recorded by Dee in his diaries are reported by Woolley as though both men actually saw the apparition. Dee writes that "Suddenly, there seemed to come out of my Oratory a Spiritual Creature, like a pretty girl of seven or nine years of age, attired on her head with her hair rolled up before, and hanging down very long behind, with a gown of Sey changeable green and red, and with a train . . . And so I considered . . . the divers reports which Edward Kelley made to me of this pretty maiden." Here Woolley lets us believe Dee too saw (or thought he saw) her skipping about the room. In fact, as always, Kelley was the medium through whom Dee addressed the supposed spirit presence and who answered through Kelley's mouth.

Nonetheless, Woolley's level-headed, meticulously researched and readable book does allow us to stand back from the jumble of evidence - rescued, as Woolley elegantly shows via his preface and epilogue, by several partisan 17th-century scholars and mystical sympathisers - to assess the historical figure afresh. What stands out is Dee's steady association with known intelligence-gatherers - spies - as he moved between England, the Low Countries, Poland and Bohemia in the 1580s and 1590s. Whatever else Dee was doing as he crisscrossed Europe, trying, with increasing desperation, to realise the material wealth to which he believed his arcane knowledge entitled him, it looks as though he was collecting and sending back to Protestant England sensitive information from Catholic territories wherever he stopped.

Wealth, in the end, eluded him. In a final irony, it was the fraudulent Kelley who, for a time, lived the life of a lord under the patronage of Rudolph II in Prague. Dee eked out a meagre living back in London, petitioning unsuccessfully again and again to clear his reputation of the slur of "conjuror" and trying to regain his position as the distinguished early scientist and mathematician he probably was.

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.trailText: Maxim Jakubowski looks at Mystic River by Dennis Lehane, Robbers by Christopher Cook, The Killing Kind by John Connolly, At End of Day by George V Higgins, Foiled Again by Peter Guttridge and Lights, Camera, Angel by Mike Ripley
fields.body:
After five impressive novels dissecting the fraught relationship between a couple of private eyes, Dennis Lehane establishes himself as one of the greats of crime writing with Mystic River (Bantam, £9.99). Spanning 25 years in the lives of three friends growing up in the working-class neighbourhoods of Boston, it begins with a childhood incident that returns to haunt them when, as adults, one of their own children is brutally murdered. As all three struggle to confront their inner demons, the breathtaking plot races towards an inevitable and tragic conclusion. Lehane's deceptive art lies not just in the exemplary investigative thriller but in a moving portrait of flawed people caught in a web of pain, told in lyrical prose that brings damaged lives and rundown cities to vivid life without a hint of forced sentimentality.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Robbers by Christopher Cook (No Exit Press, £10) is a stunning American hard-boiled debut in the tradition of Elmore Leonard, James Crumley and Natural Born Killers . Two drifters pull into a Texas 7 Eleven to buy a pack of cigarettes and shoot a guy over a penny. In the spiral of violence that follows, the killers are joined by a beautician and race down a road to nowhere, with their Texas Ranger nemesis never far behind. A bullet-riddled odyssey of jaded rednecks in search of illusory redemption, this is a hell of a debut.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Irish journalist John Connolly brings his haunted lawman Charlie Parker back for a third all-inclusive holiday in hell in The Killing Kind (Hodder & Stoughton, £12.99). Connolly is becoming the unrivalled master of Maine noir, as he takes the damaged Parker into a maelstrom of evil when the mass grave of a religious community that disappeared 40 years earlier is linked with a death in high places. Menace has never been so seductive.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Sadly, George V Higgins's At End of Day (Robinson, £17.99) is the final novel by the master of American lowlife, who died shortly after its completion. Every local police officer knows that McKeach and Cistaro are the most prolific and ruthless practitioners of extortion, fraud, assault and murder in Massachusetts. What no one knows is how to stop these Michelangelos of crime, who have avoided jail for 30 years. Higgins's dissection of criminal life lays bare the corruption at the heart of US law enforcement: one to be savoured from an author who will be sorely missed.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Away from the doom and gloom, two British comedic writers are at their best and most mischievous. Peter Guttridge's Foiled Again (Headline, £17.99) sees the ineffable Nick Martini mixed up in Nazi gold, fencing tournaments and Fleet Street shenanigans, racing from Florida to darkest Lancashire in an intoxicating mix of one-liners and breakneck comic action.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Meanwhile, Mike Ripley's rogue cab driver Angel creates havoc on the set of an American movie being shot in Buckinghamshire in Lights, Camera, Angel (Constable, £16.99). Mayhem blends with gentle satire as the jokes and one-liners cascade among stalkers, internet villains and the obligatory femmes fatales . Farce of the highest calibre.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

webTitle: Review:  The Comedy Man by D J Taylor

fields.headline: I say, I say, I say...
fields.standfirst: Bob Monkhouse applauds a tale of postwar stand-up in The Comedy Man by D J Taylor
fields.trailText: Bob Monkhouse applauds a tale of postwar stand-up in The Comedy Man by D J Taylor
fields.body:
The Comedy Man
D J Taylor
306pp, Duck Editions, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

'Nostalgia," says Mr Murgatroyd to Mr Winterbottom, "is not what it used to be." "It never was," sighs Mr Winterbottom in return. It is 60 years or so since I heard this exchange on my family's bulky HMV radiogram, which commanded more space in our dining room than the table and chairs did.

The protagonists were a fictitious crosstalk team invented by fellow comedians Tommy Handley and Ronald Frankau, partly for fun and partly to lampoon the more conventional double acts that had spread throughout the seaside and variety theatres like a rash since the great success of The Crazy Gang at the London Palladium.

In the 1930s, comedy duos were the old rock'n'roll. Flanagan had Allen, Naughton had Gold, Nervo had Knox, and it must have seemed to every struggling solo comic that greater success could be found with a straight man to bully him through his jokes.

So it is with the patter comic Arthur Upward in D J Taylor's new novel, The Comedy Man . Upward is a penetratingly observed funnyman who is as alarming as he is amusing; improbably, he chooses his old army pal Ted King, who has no stage experience, to play Hamlet to his gravedigger, and they find immediate favour with television audiences.

Quite how, I'm uncertain. That's where this otherwise sure-handed remembrance of things past loses some of its touch with gloomy reality - and its early gloom seems very real indeed. The pin-sharp and painful evocation of a youth spent aimlessly in the grey austerity of 1950s Norfolk never falters except when the author, distrustful of his readers' credulity, pauses again and again to assure us that, no matter how odd we think it is, this is how things were in those days. I grew up in wartime Worthing and so I know that things were exactly like that; the small-minded priorities and prejudices, the formal courtships, the divisions of class and "knowing one's place".

For Upward's future partner Ted King, a lanky, likeable lad, the fret-bound coast and the church spires of Great Yarmouth are world enough outside his father's steadily failing sweetshop. Ted knows his place all right, and is content with his weekly wage of five shillings for filing addresses in an insurance office and the occasional opportunities to grope the outside of a nice girl's blouse.

Conscription shows him Cyprus, but Ted's mind grows no broader. If he senses his comic destiny upon encountering the wayward soldier Upward, that's not unusual; such premonitions of fate seem to occur to him quite frequently. He gets forebodings when his parents fall out with relatives, when Upward is transferred to another unit, even when he visits the farm of the wonderfully unsophisticated Parmenters and knows with fatalistic resignation that he'll wind up in bed with their bovine daughter. All this is with the benefit of hindsight, mind you: Ted is telling us his story as an elderly dad, and he's agonisingly accurate in his critical detail.

This makes the sudden triumph of Upward & King all the harder to accept. Ten million people watch their TV shows; Kenneth Tynan gives them a rave review. Occasionally such stunning success does happen, and perhaps disbelief could have been suspended if only the author hadn't given in to temptation and showed us their comedy routines. Oh, dear. Even the most accomplished novelists, and Taylor is utterly enthralling in memoir mode, can seldom write gags. Alas, Upward & King's comic dialogues would disgrace even Skinner and Baddiel Unplanned . But never mind, a few bum notes need not ruin a rhapsody.

People often speak of the good old days. These reminiscences are rueful, truthful and achingly lonely. It's just as Mr Murgatroyd and Mr Winterbottom agreed so long ago - nostalgia isn't what it used to be.

webTitle: Review: The Oversight by Will Eaves

fields.headline: Optical allusions
fields.standfirst: Justine Jordan  on The Oversight, Will Eaves's witty coming-of-age debut
fields.trailText: Justine Jordan on The Oversight, Will Eaves's witty coming-of-age debut
fields.body:
The Oversight
Will Eaves
258pp, Picador, £12
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Despite the narrator's supernatural powers and a plot that hinges upon the secret compartment of an antique writing box, the achievement of Will Eaves's first novel lies in its recognisable coming-of-age detail and delicate attunement to domestic compromise. The narrative shuttles between 1980s Bath and present-day south London with an almost soapily realist texture, catching Daniel Rathbone as gawky, isolated teenager coming to terms with his sexuality and as reserved, seen-it-all twentysomething facing up to family secrets.

Eaves touches the constituent parts of Daniel's schooldays - those ubiquitous "boluses of masticated paper and crisp-scented saliva" known as flob-bombs, the "perfect displacement activity" of Rubik's Cubes and the teacherly cries of "find a partner and get out your rough books" - with a confident, exact hand. Isolated from the ranks of the effortlessly cool by his cleverness, gangly physique and unspoken feelings for Gregory Bray, on a field trip to a disused railway tunnel Daniel discovers another point of difference: he can see in the dark. However, having bestowed his diffident subject with superhero powers, Eaves seems unsure what to do with them: though Daniel's glimpses of what is usually veiled make for nice stylistic effect and fertile metaphorical contrast with his emotional blindness, the overall impression is haltingly novelistic. The only optician who would shrug off a visual freak of nature with the words "if it ain't broke . . ." is a compliantly fictional one.

The box of secrets presented to Daniel on his 25th birthday - once a favourite possession of his dead father, who has slipped into it a clue to the family mystery from which everyone averts their eyes - also sticks out like a sore plot device. Daniel's attempts to jettison this symbol of the past are thwarted by insistent coincidence: when he leaves the box at a municipal dump it is instantly reclaimed by his passing neighbour, who brings it straight back up the garden path.

By contrast, Eaves orders the structural intrusions of the past with understated ease, intersplicing a memoir of Daniel's parents' youth with moving letters from his dying father (counterpointed by his mother's anxious spin on events and loaded response to his coming-out visit: a model of maternal subtext grasping at words like "adult", "sensible", "level-headed"). Eaves traces Daniel's own teenage progression with wit and warmth, from the desperate early need to belong - his night vision switches on when he cruelly rebuffs Carey, the nerdy tagalong friend who is closer to him than he could want or guess - to the later secrets and ties of forbearance and attraction. The novel catches perfectly the cusp of maturity at which self-consciousness becomes self-awareness, spurned geek morphs into dignified individualist and Daniel can at last tell Gregory he wants him and receive the easy riposte, "Not with the zits on my back, you don't". Why, Daniel wonders to the cheerily bisexual Craig, now that the embargo has been lifted on such subjects, did he never get to join in the group masturbation sessions? "Probably because we thought you was a poof."

These sections shine with such convincing immediacy that the constant jumpcutting to the 1960s or the present forces our attention from the book's emotional heart. Adulthood becomes an arena for Eaves to tie up his themes, so that the reappearance of Carey, beautiful, rich, but with a white stick, forms a frozen contrast with Daniel's bedraggled second sight. Craig, now a pilot, meets his end testing virtual-navigation technology while Carey shows off his Gibsonesque goggles ("half VR, half AI") developed to orient the blind within a preprogrammed landscape.

Eaves relates his tableaux in an intensely visual, at times surreal slow-motion close-up, so that a lunch with Daniel's mother takes in the "comma of elastic saliva flexing away in the corner of [her] mouth" and the "squeezed-out sports car" reflected on the underside of her spoon, the style mimicking both Daniel's visual acuity and his reluctance to focus on the messy relationships played out before him. "Anxious to get to the point, I missed it," he admits of his teenage years; although Eaves tries too hard at times to hammer his material into a stilted elegance, his warm appraisal of fallibility, motive and mishap makes for a promising debut.

"Probably because we thought you was a poof." These sections shine with such convincing immediacy that the constant jumpcutting to the 1960s or the present forces our attention from the book's emotional heart. Adulthood becomes an arena for Eaves to tie up his themes, so that the reappearance of Carey, beautiful, rich, but with a white stick, forms a frozen contrast with Daniel's bedraggled second sight. Craig, now a pilot, meets his end testing virtual-navigation technology while Carey shows off his Gibsonesque goggles ("half VR, half AI") developed to orient the blind within a preprogrammed landscape. Eaves relates his tableaux in an intensely visual, at times surreal slow-motion close-up, so that a lunch with Daniel's mother takes in the "comma of elastic saliva flexing away in the corner of [her] mouth" and the "squeezed-out sports car" reflected on the underside of her spoon, the style mimicking both Daniel's visual acuity and his reluctance to focus on the messy relationships played out before him. "Anxious to get to the point, I missed it," he admits of his teenage years; although Eaves tries too hard at times to hammer his material into a stilted elegance, his warm appraisal of fallibility, motive and mishap makes for a promising debut.

fields.headline: Friendly fire
fields.trailText: Oh dear. Debut author Carole Stone, on a mission to share the secrets of her social success in Networking: The Art of Making Friends, is in danger of being a little too frank
fields.body:
 Oh dear. Debut author Carole Stone, on a mission to share the secrets of her social success in Networking: The Art of Making Friends, is in danger of being a little too frank. In her Diary for the New Statesman, she confides that she just can't resist rushing into every bookshop she sees to buy a copy of her precious baby, and "doing all those naff things like ordering dozens of copies for myself". They all do it, Carole, but the smart ones keep it to themselves.

 Read on at your peril: we're all sick in the head here. The Anthony Powell Society, miffed at "politically correct obituarists" keen to cast their boy as a toff - the Guardian comes in for particular criticism for daring to mention silver spoons - has enlisted the services of a psychologist to fight back. "The slightly hysterical response to Powell's death says more about some of his critics than it does of the author or his work," he sniffs. "What we are witnessing is an attempt to denigrate a writer greatly admired by his peers for a bias that isn't even there. It is a textbook case of projection." In the interests of balance, the Loafer scurried to the obituary in question - and was surprised to find not only a lengthy elaboration of Powell's august career but a comparison with Proust. But perhaps that's just denial.

 One person's "inspired act of literary invention" is another's "blatant and wholesale theft", apparently. Over in the States, Margaret Mitchell's estate has taken out a restraining order against Alice Randall, a one-time C&W songwriter who has turned to novel-writing with the ominously familiar-sounding The Wind Done Gone. Told from the point of view of Cynara, ex-plantation slave and half-sister to Scarlett O'Hara, the book is, according to its author, "an antidote" to the white-centred world of Mitchell's classic. But Mitchell's descendants, who have previously authorised sequels - for a share of the royalties - don't quite see it that way. The courts, heaven help them, will judge.

 Harry Potter continues to spin his magic, raising Bloomsbury's profits (published earlier this week) by 120% to £5.8m. But which little souls were buying £150-£200 tranches of shares before the announcement? It's hardly likely to be giant institutional investors. Maybe those on the inside were better informed than the rest of us.

fields.headline: Twilight of the lads
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  on Birthday by Alan Sillitoe - a long-overdue sequel
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on Birthday by Alan Sillitoe - a long-overdue sequel
fields.body:
Birthday
Alan Sillitoe
249pp, Flamingo, £16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

No less a literary grandee than Anthony Burgess, selecting 99 choice post-war novels in ominous old 1984, threw his weight behind Alan Sillitoe's Saturday Night and Sunday Morning . Despite its "faults of form", he maintained, its vitality and freshness demanded that it be hailed as "a rare example of genuine proletarian fiction"; that the other candidates for 1958 included Iris Murdoch's surreal, poetic novel The Bell and T H White's Arthurian fantasy The Once and Future King rather supports his argument.

Saturday Night and Sunday Morning , the tale of Nottingham Jack-the-lad Arthur Seaton, whose leisure from the noisy bike factory where he works is spent largely in drinking binges and sneaky forays into married women's beds, was nothing if not furiously true to a certain type of life, marked, in Sillitoe's words, by "the sweat of writing clearly and truthfully, the work of trying to portray ordinary people as I knew them". In Arthur, freed from poverty by increasingly skilled factory work and from deference by the quietude of peacetime, Sillitoe created a hero both articulate and cynical, hedonistic and hard-working, an angry joker who voted communist in the spirit of supporting the underdog, bucked against the "capital G of government" and toyed with raffling off the Houses of Parliament.

But Seaton's most memorable exploits and rebellions were always sexual, and if his many fans dreamt of a future for him, it would surely have been a world away from the uxorious attentiveness we encounter in Birthday , which is billed as a long-overdue sequel to Saturday Night . "One day you'll really cop it," an enraged husband told Arthur in that book. "And you'll ask for it as well." Forty-odd years later, and Arthur is indeed copping it: his beloved second wife Avril is slowly dying of cancer, the son who grew up without him scorns his tales of "how much you suffered as a kid, when you only had a donkey's foreskin between the seven of you for Sunday dinner", and the Nottingham he knew as a boy has all but disappeared.

If his home town has changed - its trams, collieries and ironmongers replaced by saunas, cellphone shops and halal grocers - then so too has Arthur. Now his appetites seem unswervingly domestic, redirected towards gargantuan meals and soothing, mundane routines. His bile is still there, its withering invective occasionally political - the "fuckpigs" Blair, Cook and Robertson "yammering about Nato winning the war when they've never heard the whistle of a bomb" - but more frequently personal, surfacing in grumbles about high-rise flats, social workers and the idle young who stalk the city pubs and whinge about the privations of the dole.

Arthur's encroaching misery frames the novel as Avril edges closer towards death, but its focus shifts to his elder brother Brian, a successful TV sitcom writer absent from the pages of Saturday Night, and invoked here as the one who got away. The birthday of the title is that of Jenny, Brian's childhood sweetheart, whose life has been martyred away caring for a husband paralysed in an industrial accident. As the novel opens, Brian, Arthur and Avril are en route to her surprise 70th celebrations, providing Brian with ample opportunity for nostalgia-filled speculation about what might have been had the seductions of Highgate not claimed him.

It is hard not to detect a note of personal ambivalence in Sillitoe's depiction of Brian's solitary life: the book-lined study and easy money, imported cigars and arty London dinner parties. We learn that he has contemplated life as a novelist, "but every proud-arsed bullshitting bowler-hatted toffee-nosed publisher with his rolled umbrella, idly indulging in his parasitical occupation for a so-called gentleman, had turned lily-white thumbs down on everything he wrote". Instead, he plies his patter for the liquid medium of television, comforting himself with infrequently realised dreams of taking to the open road and - like Arthur before him - randy imaginings that seem to latch on to almost every woman he encounters.

If Sillitoe's message is that you can take the boy out of Nottingham but you can't take Nottingham out of the boy, then he conveys it strongly: Brian's London life is only sketchily drawn, and the insistent pull that sends him back up the motorway seen as altogether more understandable. Hand in hand with Avril's lingering, understated death goes Brian's halting resumption of his relationship with Jenny, fatally compromised by their tacit agreement that they are both in love with the past rather than one another.

In keeping with the atmosphere of missed chances and terminal decline, Sillitoe's prose is slow and ruminative, painstakingly tracking the decreasing circles of memory. Where Saturday Night and Sunday Morning was primed to capture the chaotic energy of youth, Birthday embodies the slackening of age and its poignant mixture of acceptance and resistance. Naturally, this results in a narrative far less charged and chancy than its predecessor, its small-scale tragedies unfolding without great show or overt passion. But in its depiction of brotherly love, it achieves much that is touching and unexpected. In youth, Arthur's constant refrain was a variation on the saying "It's a great life if you don't weaken"; Birthday shows us that weakening is inevitable, but not always fatal.
