webTitle: Review: The Girls: Sappho Goes to Hollywood by Diana McLellan

fields.headline: Screen Sapphos
fields.standfirst:
Julie Burchill on The Girls: Sappho Goes to Hollywood, Diana McLellan's look at love among the leading ladies
Read the first chapter
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill on The Girls: Sappho Goes to Hollywood, Diana McLellan's look at love among the leading ladies
fields.body:
The Girls: Sappho Goes to Hollywood
Diana McLellan
440pp, Robson Books, £17.95

If you drew a Venn diagram of Man's Best Fantasy and Man's Worst Nightmare, the middle bit would simply say Lesbians. On the one hand, no piece of porn, however soft, is safe from the prying digits and silky skills of the Sapphic seducer; on the other, the tabloids pant lewdly after butch pieces who have boldly stolen wives and mothers. They say that the test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two directly opposing points of view at the same time, in which case every man in the nearest pub is a genius, believing as he does that a) whenever two women have sex, they'd always secretly prefer it if a man was there and b) if your wife/girlfriend has sex with a woman she'll be ruined for ever, because only a woman knows what another woman really, really wants. And it's not crusty socks, beer breath and wind-breaking, for starters.

Any old dyke will do when a man and his fist are looking for fun; imagine, then, finding out that a good number of the world's most beautiful women - Hollywood film stars - have always been at it like knives. Just as today, when the Popbitch website (www.popbitch.com) hums with rumours about modern dreamgirls such as Natalie Imbruglia and Cat Deeley, there is a particular sort of male sexual masochism that is unhealthily titillated by the idea of his love object being exquisitely repelled by him. This book should do him nicely.

Diana McLellan is a "reformed gossip columnist" and a contributor to the Ladies Home Journal . In case you're thinking that the latter sounds a bit "Bostonian", the press release hilariously tells us rather more about her husband and her "married daughter Fiona" than we are used to on such occasions. As you might deduce from this, her style is racy and pacy, with little darts of starchiness. And her story is a sparkling, sad one.

The golden age of Hollywood Saphhism ran for three decades - from the 1920s, with the influx of the decadent Europeans (the mainstays of the Sewing Circle, as it was archly known, were Greta Garbo, Marlene Dietrich and the Spanish playgirl Mercedes de Acosta, the Warren Beatty of her day), to the 1950s, when the vicious snooping of the House Un-American Activities Committee (led, ironically, by the closeted gay lawyer Roy Cohn, who would die of Aids in the 1980s) crucified communists, liberals and the sexually flexible alike.

McCarthy was not even searching out Anti-American activities, but Un-American ones; and what could be more the antithesis of American Mom than a smoky-voiced European Sapphic? (Though in her own sweet way, Dietrich was proud of her hausfrau streak, often greeting guests with her sleeves rolled up and her hair in a bandanna, having been suddenly overcome by a wild desire to scrub the kitchen floor.) The city Garbo described in 1926 as "the one place in the world where you can live as you like and nobody will say anything about it, no matter what you do" had become a snakepit of spite and neurotic conformity.

This is not to say that the American girls didn't catch on quickly: Garbo ended up a prisoner of her ruined beauty, spending her days "rousting the dead, brooding, making slipcovers and watching TV in bed", when she wasn't dreaming of a remake of The Picture of Dorian Gray opposite Marilyn Monroe. Marilyn, we are told, "rewarded herself" with women to make up for all the joyless career sex she suffered with men. In the 1946 film The Strange Love of Martha Ivers, all three leading ladies - Barbara Stanwyck, Judith Anderson and Lizabeth Scott - were gay; a distaff version of Giant , where all three male leads, Rock Hudson, James Dean and Sal Mineo, were friends of Dorothy. At one point, it might have been easier to list the Hollywood squares who didn't dabble; gloriously, even the great costume designer Edith Head, whose cheeky name graces some 90% of Hollywood classics, indulged, sparking the inevitable quip: "Edith Head gives good wardrobe."

In the 1940s, a sexy young star like Lizabeth Scott - half Lauren Bacall, half Veronica Lake, but so much darker that her nickname was "The Threat" - could happily reveal in interviews with fan magazines that she always wore male cologne and pyjamas. By the 1950s she was revealed as an habituée of top-flight brothels by the truly horrendous Confidential magazine, whose amazing habit it was to "offer" stories for "buy-back" to their victims, running them only if the required fee was not forthcoming. It was largely due to Confidential that the Sewing Circle eventually scattered, mostly to Europe and Latin America, often accompanied by the gay husbands with whom they had been set up by the sympathetic studios and with whom they enjoyed long and happy arrangements or "twilight tandems".

Interestingly, some of the greatest persecutors of homosexuality in America were Freudian analysts, whose declaration that queerness was a sickness that could poison society was pounced upon by right-wing bigots as much-needed intellectual ballast. The American Psychiatric Association did not remove homosexuality from its list of psychiatric disorders until the 1970s, when McLellan imagines Garbo pacing the streets of Manhattan dressed as a man, tormented by the young female lovers openly holding hands.

In theory, the story should end on an upswing, with the passionate attachments, clammy jealousies and rather rank-sounding "ranch vacations" of the golden age replaced by the twice-the-fun bisexuality of stars such as Drew Barrymore ("Let's just say I like women sexually. I love a woman's body and I think a woman and a woman together are beautiful"). A group called Lesbians in Film and Television is 1,000 strong. But the downside is that lesbianism is today almost excusively used to titillate men - and, to keep it non-threatening, is purely about sex.

In the past, lesbianism was about many things - mentoring, companionship, emotional sustenance. Now, for Hollywood at least, it's about looking good in a camisole. Women's declining power there (a creeping phenomenon since the 1950s, as if to punish them for the power they were slowly achieving in the real world) means that more than ever they are judged solely on their youth, beauty and appeal to men; being bisexual, as in the case of Barrymore, just makes them more interesting fantasies. Queen Victoria didn't understand how lesbians could have sex; present-day Hollywood doesn't understand how they can do anything but, preferably in glorious Technicolor. It's progress of a kind, I suppose - but not half as much seditious, transgressive fun.

fields.headline: Rough guide to Cuba
fields.standfirst: After scaling the heights with Jerry Maguire, Cuba Gooding Jr is now plumbing the depths as a racial pioneer, and finding new ways to suffer for his art
fields.trailText: After scaling the heights with Jerry Maguire, Cuba Gooding Jr is now plumbing the depths as a racial pioneer, and finding new ways to suffer for his art
fields.body:
Hollywood's Mr Enthusiasm really put his positive energy to the test in Men Of Honor. In the true-life military drama, Cuba Gooding Jr plays Carl Brashear, the first African-American ever to become a Master Chief diver, back in the 50s. This not only involved learning how to manoeuvre, on land and in the sea, in the clunky, heavy diving suits of the time, but having Robert De Niro constantly in his face as his racist petty officer. Not unexpectedly, 33-year-old Gooding came through the experience without complaint. Well, with minimal complaint.

Guess you learned some useful new skills for Men Of Honor.

I learned how to hold my breath pretty good, that's for sure.

Along with?

First, we trained for a couple of weeks at the Diving Institute in Seattle. Then they'd actually stick us in the suits, which weighed about 200 pounds. They'd strap us in with belts and leather and weights. It's very restrictive; if you're claustrophobic, just give it up. It takes 45 minutes to get in or out of these suits. And then they lower that 90-pound metal helmet onto your head, and you hear that air from the lifeline coming in at a high-pitched whistle. It hurts your ears.

And when they weren't physically hurting, your ears were being assaulted by racial slurs.

It was a necessary evil, for sure. Nobody should have to deal with such negative remarks, first of all. But you're talking to a man who grew up in the High Desert [northeast of Los Angeles], where there was a big faction of the Ku Klux Klan, so I was called "boy" and "nigger" more than I can tell you. I guess I finally put myself in the mentality of, if I can't change the way you think about people of my race, I can at least make you respect who I am through my actions. So for this movie, in the way my character responds to racism, I didn't want to play him as an angry man. Actually, this was the first script I'd been sent in which a black man faced racial aggression, came out above it and didn't have to kill somebody to do it.

Did you spend much time with Carl Brashear?

He was there every single day we were filming. At first I thought, "Oh no, how's this gonna go?" But he was so supportive. You never even knew he was on the set. webTitle: A life in writing: Sean O'Brien

fields.headline: The reclaimed land of England
fields.standfirst:
Sean O'Brien tells Robert Potts why good poetry can be political
Read 'The Genre', a poem by Sean O'Brien
fields.trailText: Sean O'Brien tells Robert Potts why good poetry can be political
fields.body:
To anyone interested in "the writer's life", Sean O'Brien's poetry already offers a number of glimpses of what it entails; "Hours of carry-outs, hours of rain; / Hours of indolence mired in gloom - / I've tried and I've tried. I've even tried prose. / But the money's no good, and I don't like the room," he writes in the despairingly hilarious "In Residency: A Worst Case Scenario".

Nor has anyone written better about the soul-destroying properties of libraries - or, indeed, librarians, like "grim Miss McNair", with her task "to ensure, with her book-burner's glare, / That no one will add to what's already there". He has also written chillingly on the belittling aspects of literary biography. So he is unsurprisingly laconic about his own life: "I was born in London and grew up in Hull, and read English at the University of Cambridge. That's basically all that has ever happened to me as far as I can see. I spent some years as a schoolteacher in Sussex, teaching at a comprehensive school. But I've been writing full time really for about 12 years now. I don't think there's anything else to say." And then, simply, "I live in Newcastle."

But there is more to say, of course, and much of it stems from those geographical movements. A passionate northerner, O'Brien, whose latest volume of poetry, Downriver , is about to be published, writes a poetry of England - from its declining ports through its run-down railways, in (and, muckily, under) its towns, and winding through its Platonic suburbs - that reclaims Larkinland but with the informed political vision that its founder so lacked. O'Brien was first published in the 1980s, during the fiercest years of Thatcherism, although he had been writing since the mid-1960s, when he was 14. As with so many writers, the stimulus was "a good English teacher, Mr Grayson, who used to put interesting work in front of us - Eliot, Ted Hughes, and others - and Macbeth , which I thought was the most interesting thing I'd ever seen, so I wanted to have a go at it".

But the mature writing came with his career as a teacher, when he moved to live on the Kent-Sussex border in 1980-81: "It was the high period of Thatcherism and the social contrasts between south and north were very marked, not just economically but at the level of attitude. It introduced a kind of political education into the poems; that and the miner's strike . . . I had a feeling that poetry ought to be able to deal with political subjects. There's still a suspicion in English poetry that you defile yourself as with pitch if you go near politics. I don't think that has to be the case; politics is just as susceptible to the verbal imagination as any subject."

O'Brien's poetry of the 1980s - in The Frighteners and HMS Glasshouse - uses formal and stylistic devices to evoke the divides and disappointments of the period, from the traditional ballad (scathing, satirical, direct) to a subtle wavering between detailed realism and dark surrealism. He also makes poetry of the terrain of his childhood: his 1950s upbringing, and the world war that preceded it. "We felt the influence that there'd been a war very strongly just in the conduct of everyday life - rationing, National Service, a general sense of sobriety and restraint. Some supposedly radical critics see any attempt to examine the past as a kind of soft nostalgia - which I think is to misinterpret what poets are doing, which is to note points where other possibilities might have come into play." By Ghost Train , written during and after the 1992 election, O'Brien seems to have drawn a line between the political promise of the post-war contract and the bleakness of Thatcherite and Majorite Britain. Despite its humour - and O'Brien is one of the funniest, laugh-out-loud poets writing - it was a despairing volume.

O'Brien believes that the current wisdom, that what is popular must therefore be good, is "a self-denying ordinance about being able to read serious literature; which is really depressing, because when something good is put in front of people, they do find it interesting." O'Brien tackles this situation on a number of fronts; he is a critic for the Sunday Times and the Times Literary Supplement ("an excellent critic", says one of his editors); he edits a political and literary magazine, The Devil ; he teaches creative writing at Sheffield Hallam University; and now, in a sense, he is taking his argument to the country.

The Poetry Book Society has organized a tour, named "A Fine Excess", kicking off in May, in which O'Brien and fellow poet Michael Donaghy will not only read their own work, but discuss themes in poetry and read poems by other writers. "The idea is to talk about serious topics in a way that doesn't require the audience to be experts but doesn't assume them to be idiots either. The general reader and listener should find it good fun." Will there be T-shirts? O'Brien, a humorous and genial man, guffaws. "Yeah, we're having one made saying No Sleep Till Basingstoke . . ."

He has also moved into drama: a verse play about politics called Laughter When We're Dead led on to other projects, including Downriver , a musical-theatre work, with the jazz composer Keith Morris; it ran at the Playhouse in Newcastle, and they are now working on a full-length version. That early delight in Macbeth has come full circle. O'Brien points out that the form is enjoying a small renaissance - Tony Harrison, Simon Armitage, Glyn Maxwell, and others have all written verse dramas in the past 10 years. "I think its a good opportunity," he says: and then, perhaps remembering the hours of carry-outs and rain, "Well, it gets you out of the house, for one thing."

fields.headline: You can't wait 'til the midnight hour
fields.standfirst: Get your skates on, or you may miss out on this year's savings tax perk, says Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: Get your skates on, or you may miss out on this year's savings tax perk, says Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
The clock is ticking away if you want to shelter your savings from the taxman. Up to £3,000 can be put in a cash Isa or £7,000 in a shares Isa completely free of income and capital gains tax. But hurry; you only have until Thursday at midnight - the end of the 2000/01 tax year - or you will lose the tax benefit for ever.

Amid recent stock market turmoil, most people are opting for cash Isas this year; Halifax says that the number of people opening cash Isas at its branches is averaging 80,000 per month, an increase of around 20% on the same period last year. Meanwhile, sales of more risky share Isas are down by 30%-40% on last year.

However, Halifax's general manager (savings) Paul Duffin says: "There is no doubt that the recent stock market volatility has encouraged many last-minute investors to opt for cash Isas.

"We have argued continuously that the right investment approach is 'cash first, equities later' for the majority of private investors."

Your choice of cash Isa should depend purely on the interest rate offered and your confidence that the bank will keep rates competitive. The big banks are currently offering rates of around 5.5% to 6%, but shopping around will enable you to pick up a rate of up to 6.5%.

Check the best buy tables in Jobs & Money or log on to www.moneyfacts.co.uk for the current best Isa rates.

As important as this over the next few days will be whether you will be able to open an account in time. All that is needed to open an account is two suitable forms of identification, such as a passport or a UK driving licence, plus something which gives proof of address, such as a utility bill, credit card or bank statement.

Abbey National and Halifax, the two biggest cash Isa sellers, will not be making any special arrangements to keep branches open later this week, and will be observing their usual 5pm closing time. But shoppers at Safeway supermarkets where there are in-store Abbey National branches can open an account in most cases until 8pm on Thursday.

Alliance & Leicester is going a step further with its 6.15% cash Isa account. It is keeping six branches open until midnight on Thursday to accept Isa applications and all this week it will be keeping 80 branches open until 8pm.

Not to be outdone, the sellers of share Isas are also taking exceptional measures to avoid a slump in sales. For example, brokers Killik & Co says that it is keeping its London Piccadilly branch open until 9pm on the last two days of the tax year, with independent advisers at hand to help you choose which is the best Isa for you.

Because of money laundering rules, investors need to be able to prove their identity and address, and should have their national insurance number with them.

Killik partner Sasha Ewart says: "Current market conditions are making many people nervous and whilst they understand the merit of an Isa they are unsure about their investment decisions. With the option of holding cash for a while, no one should miss out on their chance of a tax-free £7,000 investment."

Eight of the biggest share Isa sellers, including Henderson and Jupiter, are allowing investors to drop off last-minute applications at hotel collection points around the UK including Manchester, Birmingham and Glasgow. Most are also keeping their London offices open until 11.55pm on Thursday.

ABN Amro is opening an Isa cafe on Thursday night where investors will be able to choose a fund until 8pm.

But for most last-minute investors the best option - and one of the cheapest - is to go on to the internet.

One of the best sites is www.fundsnetwork.co.uk, which gives investors access to 32 fund management groups and hundreds of funds. The site is operated by Fidelity Investments but runs like a supermarket, with both branded and own-brand Isas.

Before buying a share Isa, take time to check out its performance statistics. Most managers will be able to find one period of performance where their fund shines, but for a fuller picture go to www.funds-sp.com.

This website, operated by Standard & Poor's, gives you free access to a remarkable amount of data on past performance of all unit and investment trusts. It also gives a star rating of funds, from one to five stars, plus an independent review of the biggest trusts supplied by Fund Research. Fund Research, which awards trusts a rating from single-A to its top triple-A grade, is used by a large number of financial advisers as the basis of their recommendations.

One tip; don't pay the 3% to 5% initial fee that many funds charge. The money is paid directly on to financial advisers, and can be easily avoided. Funds network will discount the charge back to between 2% and 0%. Remember also that your £7,000 Isa is not limited to just shares; it can be invested in lower risk corporate bonds, or, as reported below, even in commercial property.

Anthony Yadgaroff of brokers Allenbridge says: "People are understandably nervous about what to buy at the moment. For those looking for minimum risk, I suggest that they put their money into a corporate bond fund, which can be transferred once the market settles down."

He recommends the bond funds offered by Norwich Union and Threadneedle Investments, and the gilt bond offered by Dresdner.

But even if you are applying on the internet, don't leave it until the very last minute; 11.30pm on Thursday is when most net providers will accept applications.

 The Guardian guide to Isas, sponsored by the David Aaron Partnership, is available free of charge by calling 0870-909-0264.

webTitle: Jobs & Money: National Savings reduces premium bond pay-out

fields.headline: National Savings reduces premium bond pay-out
fields.trailText: National Savings, the state-controlled bank, will cut a quarter of a percentage point from the premium bond prize fund next week. As a result, the number of £100 prizes will fall, while the amount of smaller £50 prizes will rise.
fields.body:
National Savings, the state-controlled bank, will cut a quarter of a percentage point from the premium bond prize fund next week. As a result, the number of £100 prizes will fall, while the amount of smaller £50 prizes will rise.

The bondholders will see the payout drop from 4.25% to 4% of the total invested, with the total prize fund falling from £52.9m in March to around £50m in April.

National Savings defends the move by pointing to the downward drfit in market interest rates in recent months. However, in June 1996, when the Bank of England base rate was the same as today's 5.75%, the prize fund stood at 4.75% of money invested in the bonds.

The cut comes at a time when the number of £1 units in the draw is close to breaking the 15bn barrier. The 0.25% reduction announced last December becomes effective when the Electronic Random Number Indicator Equipment (Ernie) powers its circuits to pick another premium bond millionaire for the April draw next week.

Around 23m punters have more than £14.9bn invested in these bonds, which are National Savings' star attraction, with sales of around £300m a month. After the cut in the prize fund, the odds of winning a monthly prize stays at 20,000 to one. But, this time round, bondholders have a higher chance of winning £50 rather than £100.

Premium bonds work by ploughing money, equivalent to one month's interest on all the bonds, into a monthly prize fund. In theory each £1 unit has an equal chance of winning. The minimum investment is set at £100 and new buyers are eligible for prize draws once they have held their bonds for one complete calendar month, following the month in which they are bought.

The £1m jackpot is announced to the lucky winner on the first working day of the month, followed by the other prizes in order of size. By the end of the month all the prize notifications for that month's draw should have reached the winners.

National Savings estimates that it has £19m in unclaimed prizes from 325,341 bondholders, with the largest unclaimed prize worth £25,000. Unclaimed prizes can be checked by using the prize checker on the National Savings website at www.nationalsavings.co.uk or by visiting a main post office and asking for the supplement to the London Gazette.

Unlike losing a lottery ticket, losing a bond is not a traumatic experience. Anyone who has lost bonds or had them stolen, can call 0845 964 5000 or write to Premium Bonds , National Savings, Lytham St Annes, Lancs, FYO 1YN, with their account or bond numbers, for a duplicate.

fields.headline: Scottish Provident delays windfalls
fields.standfirst: Policyholders will have to wait longer than they expected to receive a payment of around £5,000, reports Phillip Inman
fields.trailText: Policyholders will have to wait longer than they expected to receive a payment of around £5,000, reports Phillip Inman.
fields.body:
Scottish Provident admitted this week that its demutualisation plans had suffered delays and windfall payouts to 450,000 members would be put back to the winter.

The mutual insurer said it was still going ahead with the sale of the business to Abbey National, but the deal was more complicated than first thought and it could not meet the original timetable, which had pencilled in windfall payouts for the autumn.

Policyholders were informed of the decision in a letter this week setting out their bonus payments, which have been cut to 2% following poor stock market returns. The letter said that details of the sale to Abbey National will appear in a circular to members at the end of May.

The firm will hand out £500 to all members and an undisclosed bonus to the 90% of members who hold with-profits policies, mainly endowments and pensions. Estimates of average bonus payments range from £4,500 to £6,000. About 300,000 policyholders will miss out entirely as they only hold "protection" policies, such as critical illness insurance.

With-profit policyholders will find a list of criteria in the circular that will allow them to judge how much they are likely to receive in their payout. A spokeswoman for Scottish Provident says the criteria has yet to be finalised, but Jobs & Money understands it will follow the pattern of other in surance company demutualisations and will depend on the size of the policyholders' funds, the number of policies held and the number of years they have left to run.

The circular will contain a voting form, but the final tally of votes is likely to take place in the autumn, rather than the summer as originally planned.

"It is a very complex process with lots of variables," says the spokeswoman. "When we first announced the deal we made our best guess about the length of the process, but recently it has become clear that payments will be going out later than the autumn."

Mutual insurer Friends Provident is going ahead later this year with its flotation, which is due to benefit 1.7m members with a flat windfall payment - yet to be decided. The 650,000 with-profits policyholders and a number of unitised investment holders in the with-profits fund will receive an additional payment. Like the Scottish Provident payout, the size of the bonus will depend on the size of their fund and the length of time they have been members.

Scottish Life is being sold to Royal London for £1.1bn this year and is paying windfalls to all with-profits policyholders through enhanced bonuses. Pension specialist National Mutual has put itself up for sale and is in talks with several potential bidders, it says. But the firm has yet to inform members if any deal has been struck and the level of potential payouts.

fields.headline: LSO/Davis
fields.standfirst:
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Few works have had quite so bizarre a performance history as Ma Vlast, Smetana's cycle of six thematically related symphonic poems, which forms the national epic of Czech music. Interweaving archetypal legend with a depiction of the Bohemian landscape, it ranks among the towering achievements of 19th-century music, though its reception outside the Czech-speaking world has been mixed, largely due to an irritating revisionist attitude to much of Smetana's work.

Generations of musicians and audiences have fought shy of the mythic elements in Smetana's music, seeing him as primarily folksy and cute. Just as The Bartered Bride is erroneously deemed typical of an operatic output that frequently aspires to Wagnerian resonance, so we find a hefty over-emphasis put on the two landscape portraits in Ma Vlast - Vltava and From Bohemia's Woods and Fields - which are often played separately, out of context.

We hear the complete cycle all too rarely in the UK. Colin Davis's performance with the London Symphony Orchestra was eagerly awaited, though it was hampered by what can only be described as a perverse halfway-house approach. Someone inserted an interval, dangerously undermining the cumulative impact. It also came at the most inopportune point, at the end of Sarka, Smetana's portrait of the psychotic Amazonian warrior who seduces her enemies in order to slaughter them. Sarka does, it is true, whip up a frenzied climax at the centre of the work, but if you stop at this point, you miss Smetana's extraordinary plunge from its violence into the luxuriant opulence of From Bohemia's Woods and Fields, one of the most powerfully affecting structural juxtapositions in all music.

The overall effect was of six separate pieces rather than a cohesive whole. This was a shame, for Davis's approach is often admirable. Unlike many interpreters he seems happiest with the mythic rather than the pictorial. The first section, Vysehrad (the ancient fortress in Prague), had a magisterial beauty and the sadomasochistic oscillations of Sarka had a dangerous, tingly sexuality, with its great clarinet solo - first erotic, then rearing in hideous triumph - played to perfection.

From Bohemia's Woods and Fields, however, had a glitzy quality that occasionally detracted from its mixture of sensual indolence and riotous fun. The great river Vltava, meanwhile, didn't so much flow as be occasionally subject to some rather strange gear changes, though its central section had a wonderfully lustrous sensuousness. The playing throughout was immaculate.

webTitle: Tories' election pledge to drop annuity rules

fields.headline: Tories' election pledge to drop annuity rules
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The Conservatives said this week that if they win the general election they would scrap the rules that force people to use most of their pension fund to buy an annuity when they retire.
fields.body:
The Conservatives said this week that if they win the general election they would scrap the rules that force people to use most of their pension fund to buy an annuity when they retire.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, also said his party would revamp the pension rules so that in certain limited situations such as very poor health, people could access the cash in their pension pots.

The Conservatives are seeking to exploit what was generally regarded as a pre-election Budget that offered little of benefit to savers and investors.

While Gordon Brown rejected calls to cut or abolish the 0.5% stamp duty on share purchases, Mr Portillo pledged that he would review the duty.

The Chancellor left many older people incensed by his lack of action on annuities. He turned down calls to reform the current regime which requires everyone with a personal pension or who belongs to a money purchase company scheme to use most of their pension savings to buy an annuity (which gives them an income for the rest of their life) by the age of 75.

Mr Portillo says that if his party is elected, it will change the system so that people are only required to buy an annuity large enough to keep them above the state support threshold, leaving them free to use the rest of their money in other ways.

However, you wouldn't be completely free to do whatever you want with this money - the Tories would put in place a "simple retirement account mechanism" within which the individual can choose their own investment strategy "within prescribed guidelines".

Crucially, any capital remaining on the death of the retiree and their spouse will pass to the individual's estate, subject to a 35% tax charge.

Mr Portillo says he wants to "put more trust in people" to enable them to keep more of their gains, and adds: "Buying an annuity at the moment represents very poor value for the person concerned."

He also wants to revamp the "individual pension account" (Ipa), which was unveiled by the government last summer and is supposed to allow people to put their pension money into collective investments such as unit trusts.

Ipas will work in a similar way to Isas, operating as a tax-efficient container for collective investments, and will be available from next week to stakeholder pensions, personal pensions and money purchase occupational schemes.

The Tories would remove the requirement to invest in an Ipa through a pension scheme, but would retain the tax rules applying to pension saving and may allow people to have limited access to their accounts - for example, in cases of "acute healthcare need".

fields.headline: Tom's Midnight Garden
fields.standfirst:
Cochrane Theatre
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Cochrane Theatre
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Some children's stories transcend childhood and mean as much to adults as they do to children. They can mean something different, even something more. Philippa Pearce's tale of young Tom is one such story. Tom is unwillingly sent to stay with his childless aunt and uncle because of his brother's measles, but finds that his quarantine turns into a liberating adventure when he slips back in time and meets the isolated Victorian girl Hatty. Like Peter Pan, this is as much about the aching loss of childhood as it is about growing up and finding your own place in the garden.

Tony Graham's production for the Unicorn Theatre captures both the loss and the wonder of childhood. After an initial choppiness, the production develops into a seamless whole, and past and present collide in the hall of Mrs Bartholomew's house as Tom hears the clock strike 13.

A lot of the success of this quality stage adaptation comes from Russell Craig's ingenious design, which lends the production its necessary fluidity, allowing for time to dissolve, the house to turn to garden and Tom to pass through solid walls. At its best there are moments when this piece of theatre makes you shiver and look for the ghosts all around you.

As is often the case with Graham's work, there is a genuine sense of release and resolution, as well as some wonderful stage pictures. It is a tribute to the actors that the adults playing children pretty soon make you forget that they are really grown-up. One of the great things about the evening is the way it does something rare - shows us the intimate relationship between the very young and the very old.

At the very least, this production will engender an interest in time, but it is just as likely to make children see the wonder of live performance. Most of all, it is a production for the over-eights to share with adults. It is a close-run thing as to whether you or your child will enjoy it more.

Funding bodies are currently debating the Unicorn's plans to create a purpose-built children's theatre in central London. With this production, the company couldn't have come up with a better reason for being given the dosh straight away.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 020-7242 7040. Then touring to Brighton and around Britain until June 2.

fields.headline: The Cornershop
fields.standfirst:
MacRobert Arts Centre
Stirling
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
MacRobert Arts Centre
Stirling
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Three stories of three families and religions make up this bill of new plays exploring British-Asian identities. Each one is dramatically structured around conflict between generations, with grandfathers, uncles and fathers clinging on to codes of behaviour, such as duty, honour, loyalty and female subservience, that are now under severe threat. The plays are set in cornershops, the small businesses opened by Asian families new to Britain, now also under the same pressure of change. "They don't want to work in shops any more," one father says of his children as he prepares to close down.

Beyond these structural similarities, the plays have very different moods, deftly handled by a cast of five. Wish, by Ravi Mangat, is a whimsically sweet tale of a son trying to stop his father from selling the family shop, where all their memories of life in Britain lie. This emotional pull becomes stronger as the son develops a strange kind of telepathy: he sees, for example, that a friend's mother will make a miraculous recovery from cancer. As drama, it's not totally successful - there's a tension between the play's realism and fantasy, and the son's enacting of film scenes isn't balanced by any day-to-day reality of shop life.

There is almost too much realism in Ashok Patel's Jeevan Sathi, the strongest of the three. A tolerant father waits for his 26-year-old daughter to decide the time is right to marry, but his older brother discovers her hesitancy is because of a relationship with another woman. Bigotry and intolerance spill out into violence, and the daughter has to choose between lover and family as they all end up in court. What Patel does so well is to make this a genuinely tough choice: the pull of family loyalty and the attractions of a close-knit community are not disregarded.

Yasmin Khan's Resham confronts the issue of honour killings in a bleak piece lightened by some good comic observation. Sameena, a young Pakistani Muslim, has never conformed to tradition, choosing to work as an air hostess and moving away from the family home to London. Now pregnant by her black boyfriend, she goes home to tell her mother, and her grandfather takes the ultimate action to protect the family's "honour". The play ends suddenly and savagely in death. Like each of the three dramas, it gives us no easy answers to the issues it raises.

 At St Bride's Centre, Edinburgh (0131-346 1405), on Monday. Details: 020-8692 3292.

webTitle: Have you got a stake in the pension revolution?

fields.headline: Have you got a stake in the pension revolution?
fields.standfirst: Next week sees a radical change in the way we can tackle an issue that the government sees as one of this country's top priorities - saving for retirement. Rupert Jones and Phillip Inman report
fields.trailText: Next week sees a radical change in the way we can tackle an issue that the government sees as one of this country's top priorities - saving for retirement. Rupert Jones and Phillip Inman report.
fields.body:
The way millions of people save for the future is about to undergo a major transformation. On Friday a new type of private pension plan - the stakeholder pension - will go on sale for the first time. Over the coming months the government and pension firms will be bombarding us with ads designed to hammer home the message that saving for your retirement is one of the most important things you'll ever do.

In the light of a new survey that has found that nearly a third of adults have made no pension provision at all, ministers are determined to get us to put aside more money for our old age.

They have come up with stakeholder pensions, which have been described as a much more user-friendly version of personal pensions. They will be offered by all the companies that offer pensions now, plus probably quite a few others. The government promises they will be simple to understand, good value and flexible. And they will be open to everyone, not just those in work.

The big carrot being dangled in front of us is "free money". Everyone, even non-taxpayers, will get at least basic-rate tax relief on their pension payments. That means that for every £100 a typical individual contributes to a stakeholder, the government will cough up an extra £28 into your fund.

The main downside is that you cannot withdraw any money before you take your pension, and you can't do that until you are at least 50. Also, like personal pensions, stakeholder pensions will be money purchase schemes - when you retire you must use most of your pension fund to buy an annuity, which then gives you an income for life.

Even if they don't prove as big a hit as the government would like, stakeholders have already succeeded in sweeping away the old regime of high-charging, inflexible pension plans. In the past, taking out a personal pension could well have meant being stung by an initial charge of 5%-7%, an annual charge of perhaps 2% and maybe extra fees such as a £2 a month policy charge. With a stakeholder, the most a company will be able to charge for managing your money is an all-in 1% a year.

Here we look to see whether a stakeholder pension will benefit you.

Your company doesn't offer a pension scheme

Millions of people in this position will be winners because under the new rules all businesses employing five or more people which do not already have a pension scheme in place will have to offer staff access to a stakeholder scheme. That means the boss will have to select a scheme for workers to pay into and will also have to arrange for people's pension contributions to be deducted directly from their earnings if that's what staff request. The government has warned that if businesses don't comply with these rules they could face a fine of up to £50,000.

The more decent employers will not only set up a stakeholder scheme but will also make a regular contribution to your plan. Some may offer to match your contributions, so if you contribute 3% of your salary they will put in 3% too, says insurer Legal & General.

However, you're a stakeholder loser if you work for a company employing fewer than five staff because the government has exempted them from the requirement of having to give workers access to a stakeholder scheme. People who work for these companies will still be able to buy a stakeholder pension direct from a provider but the suspicion is that, faced with sorting it out themselves, many of these people are likely to simply do nothing.

There was some hope for people working for very small firms this week - a survey showed that 22% of them are planning to do the decent thing and offer their staff access to a stakeholder scheme, even though they are not obliged to do this.

You already belong to a company scheme

If you belong to your employer's company pension scheme, you should stick with it as this will almost certainly be the best way of saving for your retirement.

That's because most employers will contribute to the scheme on your behalf or will provide extra benefits such as free life insurance.

If there is a company pension scheme where you work and you haven't joined it, check it out before doing anything as again this will probably be the best place to be.

Meanwhile many workers will have already amassed a motley collection of personal and company pensions. Anyone who moves job often freezes their old pension and starts paying into a new one. The arrival of stakeholder begs the question: should all previous pensions be moved into a low-charging stakeholder alternative?

The answer is: possibly. First you must check on the transfer charges that will be imposed by your current pension providers. Many providers that pass on high management and admin charges to pension scheme members will also be the kind of nasty pension provider that slaps huge transfer penalties on anyone who dares switch. It still might be worth it if you are young and the low-charging stakeholder has time to make up the difference.

You are excluded from taking out a pension

Stakeholder pensions are genuinely innovative because they will be available to millions of people who have up until now been barred from taking out a pension. These people include carers, mature students and those taking career breaks as well as those who have recently been made redundant or who have got divorced and may have a lump sum available to put into a pension. People who work only periodically will for the first time be able to use savings or other money to continue to make contributions during the times they are not working. This also applies to women who are taking time out of the workplace to raise a family.

Another group of winners are children. Any non-taxpayer can benefit from them, including youngsters. Chartered accountants Hacker Young say stakeholder pensions will give parents or grandparents a great way to take care of their child's future financial security. Paying in £50 a month from the birth of a child until he or she hits 18 would produce a fund worth an estimated £256,000 by the time the child reaches 60, says Legal & General.

Parents who can afford it may wish to redirect child benefit into a stakeholder for their son or daughter. If a parent decides to invest the £15.50 a week child benefit currently paid by the state, once the tax relief is added this means £86 a month will go into their pension, says pension consultants Alexander Forbes.

But the benefits of stakeholder could be slim for savers who are only able to put away small sums each month.

According to figures from the main City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority, a single 30-year-old who starts saving £20 a month into a pension will receive a monthly payment of £98 when they retire at 65. This figure can be added to the state pension, which is likely to continue rising in line with inflation after this year's boost.

At the moment, income from savings or investments are deducted from benefits after retirement on a pound for pound basis. Next year, for instance, pensioners are entitled to the state pension of £72.50 a week and top-up income support payments up to the level £92.15, called the minimum income guarantee.

So pensioners will find that benefits will be deducted from extra income up to £19.35 a week or £85.15 a month, which wipes out almost all of the £8,400 saved up over 35 years by our hypothetical saver.

To overcome this problem the government has invented the pension credit. The credit will operate from 2003 and will effectively deduct 40p from benefits for every pound of extra income. That means for every £1 you save you keep 60p until the benefit runs out. Critics argue it is a complicated answer to the problem, but ministers believe it is fair.

Whatever the answer, the pension credit will be increasingly important. While the state pension rises with inflation, the minimum income guarantee is set to rise with earnings and will become a significant element of pensioner income in future years.

You are self-employed

Self-employed workers already know that governments, whatever their political colour, expect them to look after number one. State benefits, no matter how much national insurance they pay, are not for them.

Yet while personal pensions with stakeholder rules will be a boon for most, not all self-employed people should jump aboard.

More affluent workers who stash away large sums in their pension funds can negotiate big cuts in their charges below the government's 1% ceiling. If they are automatically switched to a stakeholder pension they should check their charges have not actually increased.

Old "226" contracts taken out before June 1988 will also be jealously guarded by the affluent. While the 226 contracts restrict the percentage of income they can put into their pension each year according to age, that is the only cap.

They escape the cap on tax relief for people who earn more than £91,800 (£95,400 next year). It means they can pour in as much money from their gross income as they like into their pension, restricted only by the age-related per centage. Anyone else should tell their insurer they want to switch. Standard Life and several other life companies are switching members automatically, while others such as Legal & General are not.

You are well-off

Stakeholder pensions represent a fantastic tax perk for the rich. It's not the government's aim at all, but the new scheme will allow the well-off to benefit in a variety of ways.

For example, a highly paid boss with a wife who doesn't work and who already puts the maximum amount into his pension can now shovel a further £3,600 a year into a stakeholder pension in his wife's name, and benefit from tax relief on the contributions. Over 20 years that means he's been able to tuck away £72,000 - £15,840 of which will have come out of the government's coffers.

Likewise, stakeholder pensions represent a great inheritance tax dodge for rich parents and grandparents. They will be able to get an immediate tax benefit by making regular payments into a stakeholder plan on behalf of children or grandchildren. The payments will be regarded as "regular gifts out of income" so they will not be liable for inheritance tax. And, of course, the donor is receiving tax relief on the payments.
fields.bodyText: The way millions of people save for the future is about to undergo a major transformation. On Friday a new type of private pension plan - the stakeholder pension - will go on sale for the first time. Over the coming months the government and pension firms will be bombarding us with ads designed to hammer home the message that saving for your retirement is one of the most important things you'll ever do. In the light of a new survey that has found that nearly a third of adults have made no pension provision at all, ministers are determined to get us to put aside more money for our old age. They have come up with stakeholder pensions, which have been described as a much more user-friendly version of personal pensions. They will be offered by all the companies that offer pensions now, plus probably quite a few others. The government promises they will be simple to understand, good value and flexible. And they will be open to everyone, not just those in work. The big carrot being dangled in front of us is "free money". Everyone, even non-taxpayers, will get at least basic-rate tax relief on their pension payments. That means that for every £100 a typical individual contributes to a stakeholder, the government will cough up an extra £28 into your fund. The main downside is that you cannot withdraw any money before you take your pension, and you can't do that until you are at least 50. Also, like personal pensions, stakeholder pensions will be money purchase schemes - when you retire you must use most of your pension fund to buy an annuity, which then gives you an income for life. Even if they don't prove as big a hit as the government would like, stakeholders have already succeeded in sweeping away the old regime of high-charging, inflexible pension plans. In the past, taking out a personal pension could well have meant being stung by an initial charge of 5%-7%, an annual charge of perhaps 2% and maybe extra fees such as a £2 a month policy charge. With a stakeholder, the most a company will be able to charge for managing your money is an all-in 1% a year. Here we look to see whether a stakeholder pension will benefit you. Your company doesn't offer a pension scheme Millions of people in this position will be winners because under the new rules all businesses employing five or more people which do not already have a pension scheme in place will have to offer staff access to a stakeholder scheme. That means the boss will have to select a scheme for workers to pay into and will also have to arrange for people's pension contributions to be deducted directly from their earnings if that's what staff request. The government has warned that if businesses don't comply with these rules they could face a fine of up to £50,000. The more decent employers will not only set up a stakeholder scheme but will also make a regular contribution to your plan. Some may offer to match your contributions, so if you contribute 3% of your salary they will put in 3% too, says insurer Legal & General. However, you're a stakeholder loser if you work for a company employing fewer than five staff because the government has exempted them from the requirement of having to give workers access to a stakeholder scheme. That's because most employers will contribute to the scheme on your behalf or will provide extra benefits such as free life insurance. If there is a company pension scheme where you work and you haven't joined it, check it out before doing anything as again this will probably be the best place to be. Meanwhile many workers will have already amassed a motley collection of personal and company pensions. Anyone who moves job often freezes their old pension and starts paying into a new one. The arrival of stakeholder begs the question: should all previous pensions be moved into a low-charging stakeholder alternative? The answer is: possibly. First you must check on the transfer charges that will be imposed by your current pension providers. Many providers that pass on high management and admin charges to pension scheme members will also be the kind of nasty pension provider that slaps huge transfer penalties on anyone who dares switch. It still might be worth it if you are young and the low-charging stakeholder has time to make up the difference. These people include carers, mature students and those taking career breaks as well as those who have recently been made redundant or who have got divorced and may have a lump sum available to put into a pension. People who work only periodically will for the first time be able to use savings or other money to continue to make contributions during the times they are not working. This also applies to women who are taking time out of the workplace to raise a family. Another group of winners are children. Any non-taxpayer can benefit from them, including youngsters. Chartered accountants Hacker Young say stakeholder pensions will give parents or grandparents a great way to take care of their child's future financial security. Paying in £50 a month from the birth of a child until he or she hits 18 would produce a fund worth an estimated £256,000 by the time the child reaches 60, says Legal & General. Parents who can afford it may wish to redirect child benefit into a stakeholder for their son or daughter. If a parent decides to invest the £15.50 a week child benefit currently paid by the state, once the tax relief is added this means £86 a month will go into their pension, says pension consultants Alexander Forbes. According to figures from the main City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority, a single 30-year-old who starts saving £20 a month into a pension will receive a monthly payment of £98 when they retire at 65. This figure can be added to the state pension, which is likely to continue rising in line with inflation after this year's boost. At the moment, income from savings or investments are deducted from benefits after retirement on a pound for pound basis. Next year, for instance, pensioners are entitled to the state pension of £72.50 a week and top-up income support payments up to the level £92.15, called the minimum income guarantee. So pensioners will find that benefits will be deducted from extra income up to £19.35 a week or £85.15 a month, which wipes out almost all of the £8,400 saved up over 35 years by our hypothetical saver. To overcome this problem the government has invented the pension credit. The credit will operate from 2003 and will effectively deduct 40p from benefits for every pound of extra income. That means for every £1 you save you keep 60p until the benefit runs out. Critics argue it is a complicated answer to the problem, but ministers believe it is fair. Whatever the answer, the pension credit will be increasingly important. While the state pension rises with inflation, the minimum income guarantee is set to rise with earnings and will become a significant element of pensioner income in future years. You are self-employed Self-employed workers already know that governments, whatever their political colour, expect them to look after number one. State benefits, no matter how much national insurance they pay, are not for them. More affluent workers who stash away large sums in their pension funds can negotiate big cuts in their charges below the government's 1% ceiling. If they are automatically switched to a stakeholder pension they should check their charges have not actually increased. While the 226 contracts restrict the percentage of income they can put into their pension each year according to age, that is the only cap. They escape the cap on tax relief for people who earn more than £91,800 (£95,400 next year). It means they can pour in as much money from their gross income as they like into their pension, restricted only by the age-related per centage. fields.headline: Fixed-rate credit cards have arrived
fields.trailText: We're used to fixed-rate mortgages, personal loans and savings bonds, but now the concept is being extended to credit cards. This week saw the Co-operative Bank launch a credit card with a rate fixed for five years.
fields.body:
We're used to fixed-rate mortgages, personal loans and savings bonds, but now the concept is being extended to credit cards.

This week saw the Co-operative Bank launch a credit card with a rate fixed for five years. The annual percentage rate (APR) on purchases and balance transfers is a competitive 9.8 until April 30, 2006. It comes hard on the heels of a card launched last month by Capital One with a rate of 9.84 APR fixed for life.

The Co-op Bank reckons this new type of card will shake up the market as it believes some people will find it more attractive than cards with low introductory rates that often only last for six months before jumping to a higher rate.

"Just as with fixed-rate personal loans and mortgages, this credit card will allow customers to manage their finances in the medium term, with complete certainty on the rate of interest that will be charged," says Mick Firth at the bank.

The Co-op's platinum Visa card has no annual fee and you get a credit limit of at least £3,500, but you have to be over 25 and earning more than £25,000 to take it out. Meanwhile, Capital One's card is available in standard and platinum form, and the 9.84 APR rate also applies to purchases and balance transfers. There's no annual fee and the minimum income required for the platinum card is £10,000.

Liz Chettleburgh at financial data providers Moneyfacts says a fixed-rate credit card is "a very interesting concept" and adds that 9.8 APR is a very low standard rate. However, it is worth pointing out that while other cards' rates may not be fixed, in reality dramatic fluctuations in credit card interest rates are very unusual.

The rates on most cards seem to bear little relation to what is happening to bank base rates - something that is particularly annoying when interest rates are falling, as they are now. So, while these cards do offer you the security of knowing exactly what you're going to be charged, don't get carried away by the fixed rate pledge.

If you're on the look-out for a new credit card you should make your decision based on the way you tend to use plastic. If you don't usually pay off your balance at the end of each month, the number one priority should be a low interest rate on purchases. Cards offering a very low introductory rate for purchases include Boots Advantage (0 APR for the first six months, then rises to 10.9 APR), Capital One (0 APR for the first six months, then 12.9 APR), RBS Advanta (1.9 APR until January 1 2002, then 17.9 APR) and Nationwide (3.5 APR for the first six months, then 14.6 APR).

However, if you don't fancy switching again once the special offer rate ends, you may be better off going for a low-ish standard rate that doesn't disappear after a few months. The Co-op Bank and Capital One offerings clearly score well on this front, and others offering competitive standard rates include Intelligent Finance and Northern Rock (9.9 APR and 10.5 APR respectively).

If you pay off your credit card bill in full each month, you don't need to worry about the interest rate, so go for a card that gives you some sort of reward or perk.

According to the Credit Card Research Group many people, especially younger age groups, were keen on the idea of a "celebrity" credit card which would carry the star's picture and possibly give the holder discounts on products, memorabilia or concerts. Perhaps predictably, Robbie Williams was the celebrity most people wanted to carry in their pockets.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Moving the goalposts

fields.headline: Moving the goalposts
fields.standfirst: The launch by Alliance & Leicester of a retail chain offering financial services for buyers and details on reliable tradespeople is a welcome fillip as spring house-hunting season gets underway, reports Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: The launch by Alliance & Leicester of a retail chain offering financial services for buyers and details on reliable tradespeople is a welcome fillip as spring house-hunting season gets underway, reports Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
The traditional spring house-hunting season is now under way and this week saw the opening of the first two branches of movingimproving, a retail outlet aimed at buyers and those planning to carry out home improvements.

The company behind this new high street name is former building society Alliance & Leicester. However, A&L is not trying to muscle in on B&Q's territory - rather than stocking paint brushes and stepladders, the stores will offer financial advice on its mortgages, personal loans and credit cards. They will also provide a range of information services, including details of local tradespeople such as builders, plumbers and surveyors, along with information on new housing developments, schools and health facilities.

Flamboyant interior design guru Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen, star of BBC2's Home Front, this week cut the opening ribbon at the first two movingimproving stores in Banbury, Oxfordshire; and Leamington Spa, Warwickshire.

Alliance & Leicester chose these locations because demographic research shows they are areas where a lot of new housing is being built and which are seeing an influx of young families moving in.

The plan is to roll the stores out across the country. A&L says they are not intended to replace traditional branches "but will provide a new chain of outlets focused specifically on the homebuyer and homeowner".

Each store will include an internet kiosk so people can come in and surf the net for useful information relevant to property buying or home improvements. "The stores have been designed to provide an informal and relaxed atmosphere and have a modern, home-style layout, with breakfast bar/coffee area and a lounge area with comfy sofas," says a spokeswoman. But don't bother popping in if you simply want to pay in a cheque or pay bills, they will not include a counter for banking transactions.

The launch of movingimproving comes as a new survey this week re vealed that more than 3m people say they wouldn't have bought their current home if they had done more research.

A third of Britain's 17m homeowners fail to carry out any research into their new area before signing the deal and only one in 10 bother to check local crime rates, according to the study from insurer Norwich Union, which has produced a free guide called Making the Move aimed at people looking to move house. Available by calling 0800 093 0303, it includes sections on local amenities, environmental factors and crime, and lists several useful websites and phone numbers.

For those people looking to buy a home, a website definitely worth a visit is UpMyStreet (www.upmystreet.com), which calls itself "the real-life guide to your neighbourhood". Simply key in the postcode of the location you plan to move to, or where you live now, and the system throws up a wealth of statistics about the area including a breakdown of property prices (unfortunately they're not fantastically up to date), a neighbourhood profile, details of the council tax and how the council scores on a range of topics, details of the top schools and other local facilities, crime statistics and even a what's on guide.

If you're looking to get some work carried out on your home and don't know a good firm, try logging on to Improveline (www.improveline.com), which aims to put people looking to get home improvements done in touch with "reliable and recommended" professionals - builders, plumbers, electricians, decorators, roofers and so on.

You can search their database of tradespeople, who are ranked by a star-rating system based on customer feedback and other factors. Or you can key in your requirements and the service will contact a number of approved contractors in the local area to see if they are interested in quoting for the job. Up to three of them will then call you back. In both cases you don't have to pay a fee for using Improveline, the service makes its money by charging the firms a fee.

webTitle: How to stay afloat when  the market takes a dive

fields.headline: How to stay afloat when  the market takes a dive
fields.standfirst: As the value of shares in Britain and overseas plummets, investment plans with a safety margin are looking increasingly more attractive. John Edwards examines some of the options
fields.trailText: As the value of shares in Britain and overseas plummets, investment plans with a safety margin are looking increasingly more attractive. John Edwards examines some of the options.
fields.body:
Turn the crash into cash. That is the rather crude slogan being used by AIG Life to promote its High Income Stockmarket Bond. But it highlights the fact that the fall in the markets is good news for the so-called "guaranteed" investment plans or bonds currently on offer.

The promised returns look very tempting. Two of the plans, offered by GE Life and Scottish Widows, guarantee a fixed annual income of 10.25% gross over a three-year period, or capital growth of 33%.

However, it is important to remember that, while the income or capital growth returns are genuinely guaranteed, the return of your original capital is dependent on the performance of stock market indices over the period. If the indices fail to meet the specified target, then you could lose a big slice of the capital invested - in effect using your own capital to provide the guaranteed returns.

However, the lower the starting point, the better the chance of obtaining a full return of your original capital plus the high returns.

For example, the GE Life Income & Growth Plan IV, which runs for just over three years, offers a full return of capital unless the Dow Jones Euro Stoxx 50 index, which tracks the share price performance of the biggest 50 publicly quoted companies in euroland, falls by more than 20% below the starting level at the beginning of the investment period in May.

This safety margin looks a lot better after the recent shake-out in the European stock markets.

Scottish Widows Extra Income and Growth Plan offers similar fixed income or capital growth returns. But it is more complicated in that the return of original capital is linked to the performance of 30 individual shares currently included in the FTSE l00.

The investment is split into 30 equal parts. There is a reduction in the return of original capital if the market price of any share falls by more than 33% below the starting level at any time during the investment period and fails to recover to its initial starting value by the maturity date.

In that event the capital return will be reduced by 1/30th for each share that has fallen by more than 33% and remained below the starting price level, based on the value of the share at the maturity date.

For example, if a share was to end 50% below the starting level, the return of original capital would be reduced by 50% of l/30th - ie 1.66%. If half the shares - ie l5 shares - were all to suffer price losses of 50% then the original capital would be cut by just under 25%.

Once again the recent shake-out in share values means a lower starting point, making a further 33% more unlikely.

In both cases investors have the choice of either taking the fixed annual income of 10.25% for three years or receive monthly income at a slightly lower rate of 0.78% (GE Life) or quarterly income of 2.50% (Scottish Widows).

The capital growth option of 33% is not a particularly attractive compounded rate, but it has the advantage of being subject to capital gains tax, which is only payable if you have used up your full exemption in the tax year when the plans mature - ie 2004/2005. The majority of investors tend not to use this exemption.

The income options are subject to income tax. But because the plans are based on the performance of specially created companies, quoted on the Dublin Stock Exchange, they are subject to the special Schedule F income tax imposed on dividends of foreign companies at the lower rate of 10% for standard rate taxpayers and 32.5% for high-rate taxpayers.

In addition the plans are eligible for inclusion in an Isa - subject to the maximum of £7,000 - or for transfers from Peps or existing Isas, where there is no limit on the amount that can be invested.

Unfortunately, the Pep/Isa transfer deadline for the Scottish Widows Extra Income & Growth plan has already passed because the deadline for applications is April 4, and extra time is needed to process transfers.

However, the GE Life High Income & Growth Plan IV, which comes on to the market from April 2, is scheduled to close on May 11, if it is not oversubscribed before that date and the Pep/Isa deadline is April 27.

Another "guaranteed" product currently available (until April 30) is the NDF Extra Bonus Plan 2, which offers a fixed return over a 13-month period of 10%, with a full return of capital if the Dow Jones Euro Stoxx index does not fall by more than 25%.

Alternatively, the return can be boosted to 12% if you are prepared to only receive a full return of capital if the Euro Stoxx index doesn't fall at all. In both cases there is only one payment on maturity and this will be subject to capital gains tax.

It should be borne in mind that, in theory, the shorter the time period, the greater the risk, since the markets have less time to recover. The advantage, however, is that you don't have to lock your money away for very long.

For those prepared to lock their money away for five and a half years, and not receive any income, the Inora Offshore Accumulator Growth Fund, series l, available until April 12, offers a guaranteed minimum return of 20% plus a maximum return of 110% dependent on the performance of the highly volatile Nasdaq index.

The investment period is divided into 11 separate periods of six months each, with a maximum possible return of l0% for each period.

The final return will be based on the average performance of the index over the 11 periods compared with the starting level. There is not much chance of achieving the maximum return of 110%, since the index would, therefore, have to rise consistently throughout the whole five and a half years.

But there should be a very good chance of exceeding the minimum of 20%, assuming the index starts from a low level.

Inora is a new offshore company, recently formed by the French-based Societe General group, so it should have more than adequate financial resources to meet any commitments. As an offshore bond, the return for UK investors will be subject to income tax at their highest marginal rate. However, it could be used for Sipp or Sass pension plans or as a long-term savings plan for children.

Finally the Crash for Cash bond from AIG Life. The High Income Stockmarket Bond is continuously available with the terms adjusted in line with market conditions. At present it offers a fixed annual return of 6.75%, net of standard rate tax, over a four-year investment period, with a full return of original capital if the FTSE l00 index is higher than the starting level on maturity in four years' time.

With all these products, there are no extra charges since these have been taken into account when calculating the promised returns.

There has been considerable criticism of "guaranteed" products over the past few years, since they came into vogue, on the grounds that many investors don't know what they are buying - and in particular that, while the fixed returns are guaranteed, there is a real risk of losing a large slice of original capital.

Nevertheless it can be argued that, with built-in safety margins before there is any loss of capital, they are less risky than investing in shares or unit trusts, where a big fall in the markets would bring even greater capital losses.

The main problem with "guaranteed" products is the inflexibility. Early surrender almost certainly means a loss of capital. Furthermore the potential return is fixed at the outset, so you would miss out on any large gain in the stock markets or increases in interest rates.

At the moment, however, a fixed return during a period when interest rates are declining, plus some protection against highly volatile share prices, makes them look pretty attractive. The main danger is a sharp recovery in the markets before the investment period begins. So good news for potential investors would be a further sharp fall in share prices during the next month or so.
