For example, the GE Life Income & Growth Plan IV, which runs for just over three years, offers a full return of capital unless the Dow Jones Euro Stoxx 50 index, which tracks the share price performance of the biggest 50 publicly quoted companies in euroland, falls by more than 20% below the starting level at the beginning of the investment period in May. This safety margin looks a lot better after the recent shake-out in the European stock markets. Scottish Widows Extra Income and Growth Plan offers similar fixed income or capital growth returns. But it is more complicated in that the return of original capital is linked to the performance of 30 individual shares currently included in the FTSE l00. The investment is split into 30 equal parts. There is a reduction in the return of original capital if the market price of any share falls by more than 33% below the starting level at any time during the investment period and fails to recover to its initial starting value by the maturity date. In that event the capital return will be reduced by 1/30th for each share that has fallen by more than 33% and remained below the starting price level, based on the value of the share at the maturity date. For example, if a share was to end 50% below the starting level, the return of original capital would be reduced by 50% of l/30th - ie 1.66%. If half the shares - ie l5 shares - were all to suffer price losses of 50% then the original capital would be cut by just under 25%. Once again the recent shake-out in share values means a lower starting point, making a further 33% more unlikely. In both cases investors have the choice of either taking the fixed annual income of 10.25% for three years or receive monthly income at a slightly lower rate of 0.78% (GE Life) or quarterly income of 2.50% (Scottish Widows). The capital growth option of 33% is not a particularly attractive compounded rate, but it has the advantage of being subject to capital gains tax, which is only payable if you have used up your full exemption in the tax year when the plans mature - ie 2004/2005. The majority of investors tend not to use this exemption. The income options are subject to income tax. But because the plans are based on the performance of specially created companies, quoted on the Dublin Stock Exchange, they are subject to the special Schedule F income tax imposed on dividends of foreign companies at the lower rate of 10% for standard rate taxpayers and 32.5% for high-rate taxpayers. In addition the plans are eligible for inclusion in an Isa - subject to the maximum of £7,000 - or for transfers from Peps or existing Isas, where there is no limit on the amount that can be invested. Unfortunately, the Pep/Isa transfer deadline for the Scottish Widows Extra Income & Growth plan has already passed because the deadline for applications is April 4, and extra time is needed to process transfers. However, the GE Life High Income & Growth Plan IV, which comes on to the market from April 2, is scheduled to close on May 11, if it is not oversubscribed before that date and the Pep/Isa deadline is April 27. Another "guaranteed" product currently available (until April 30) is the NDF Extra Bonus Plan 2, which offers a fixed return over a 13-month period of 10%, with a full return of capital if the Dow Jones Euro Stoxx index does not fall by more than 25%. Alternatively, the return can be boosted to 12% if you are prepared to only receive a full return of capital if the Euro Stoxx index doesn't fall at all. In both cases there is only one payment on maturity and this will be subject to capital gains tax. It should be borne in mind that, in theory, the shorter the time period, the greater the risk, since the markets have less time to recover. The advantage, however, is that you don't have to lock your money away for very long. For those prepared to lock their money away for five and a half years, and not receive any income, the Inora Offshore Accumulator Growth Fund, series l, available until April 12, offers a guaranteed minimum return of 20% plus a maximum return of 110% dependent on the performance of the highly volatile Nasdaq index. The investment period is divided into 11 separate periods of six months each, with a maximum possible return of l0% for each period. The final return will be based on the average performance of the index over the 11 periods compared with the starting level. There is not much chance of achieving the maximum return of 110%, since the index would, therefore, have to rise consistently throughout the whole five and a half years. But there should be a very good chance of exceeding the minimum of 20%, assuming the index starts from a low level. Inora is a new offshore company, recently formed by the French-based Societe General group, so it should have more than adequate financial resources to meet any commitments. As an offshore bond, the return for UK investors will be subject to income tax at their highest marginal rate. However, it could be used for Sipp or Sass pension plans or as a long-term savings plan for children. Finally the Crash for Cash bond from AIG Life. The High Income Stockmarket Bond is continuously available with the terms adjusted in line with market conditions. At present it offers a fixed annual return of 6.75%, net of standard rate tax, over a four-year investment period, with a full return of original capital if the FTSE l00 index is higher than the starting level on maturity in four years' time. With all these products, there are no extra charges since these have been taken into account when calculating the promised returns. There has been considerable criticism of "guaranteed" products over the past few years, since they came into vogue, on the grounds that many investors don't know what they are buying - and in particular that, while the fixed returns are guaranteed, there is a real risk of losing a large slice of original capital. Nevertheless it can be argued that, with built-in safety margins before there is any loss of capital, they are less risky than investing in shares or unit trusts, where a big fall in the markets would bring even greater capital losses. The main problem with "guaranteed" products is the inflexibility. Early surrender almost certainly means a loss of capital. Furthermore the potential return is fixed at the outset, so you would miss out on any large gain in the stock markets or increases in interest rates. At the moment, however, a fixed return during a period when interest rates are declining, plus some protection against highly volatile share prices, makes them look pretty attractive. The main danger is a sharp recovery in the markets before the investment period begins. So good news for potential investors would be a further sharp fall in share prices during the next month or so.

webTitle: Jobs & Money: As farming dies, banks need to feed growth

fields.headline: As farming dies, banks need to feed growth
fields.standfirst: Barring a surge in bad debts as growth slows, the financial sector should be able to prop up  the UK economy, says Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: Barring a surge in bad debts as growth slows, the financial sector should be able to prop up the UK economy, says Robin Stoddart.
fields.body:
Confidence ebbed and flowed back in a tidal wave over the last week on world share markets. As a main determinant of economic growth, financial confidence promotes boom and bust cycles. Like a piece of flotsam on a sea of change, Britain still goes with the current.

If confidence in job creation, low inflation and education slips, the country and currency could be on a slippery slope of long duration.

Considering the blows it has sustained over the past year, the UK must certainly be credited with robustness. Although manufacturing has suffered, growth in the service sector has continued to accelerate, with many jobs being created at call centres.

However, when falling production overshadows the boom in entertainment, legal, financial and other services, a crisis of confidence is on the cards. And bankers set the tone with their loan activity.

The catastrophe in upland farming and some other areas of agriculture directly affects only a few tens of thousands of workers and landowners. But it is the heaviest possible thrust to the heart of the country.

The change wrought by the industrial revolution depended on coal and textiles, but agriculture and shipping remained important, particularly after they installed advanced equipment.

All are now pale shadows of their former prosperity. The dependence on imported food, feed and household goods made by foreign-owned manufacturers loyal only to the most efficient sites and costings is virtually complete.

A serious shortage of native managerial ability has been apparent for years. After the reversals at M&S, Napoleon's gibe that we are a nation of shopkeepers hardly applies any longer. The supply of trained, dedicated people seems appallingly short, necessitating a reliance on immigration, often from countries that are themselves at an early stage of development.

But business confidence remains remarkably resilient. Warnings of recession are coming mainly from abroad. Although many smaller or newer firms are suffering as the availability of funds diminishes, few giants have come out with depressing forecasts.

But what of the banks, that vast, pervasive area of the modern economy that has left farming, engineering and much of the rest of traditional business far behind in terms of employment and profitability?

A flood of brokers' surveys this week urges investment in the sector, with targets set for much higher individual valuations for all of the largest banks.

There was a short-lived rebound in their prices, though it was less than among a handful of technology issues, especially in software, where banks are big spenders.

Excluding a resurgence in bad debts - the ultimate crunch for an economy - the big high street banking names with large back offices catering for wealthy investors and newer savers under the government's incentive schemes are sitting pretty.

Good margins are achievable on mortgages as interest rates come down - faster for savers than borrowers, of course.

Above all, the rise in the wealth of older people and some highly successful business founders and leisure stars has opened up income flows from commissions and pension provision.

Deposits are being overtaken by investment activity as lucrative earnings providers.

Although moves into bancassurance have not been as fast as expected - except perhaps in the case of Lloyds TSB, the most profitable bank - the trend is strongly upward.

Certainly, the foreign-owned competition has become particularly strong in fund management and broking, but a dozen UK banks still do well in an area, which is more advanced than in other large European countries, despite the much greater power of their universal banks on the international scene.

The snag is that the banks already constitute a much higher proportion of the UK economy than in other industrial countries, as reflected even in off-peak stock market valuations.

This bears out the dominance of the services sector as production goes down the drain. On a more cynical note, no sector of the economy has more of a vested interest in reasonably steady conditions at the end of the fiscal year than the banks and other institutions offering tax-free savings vehicles.

Even though small investors' confidence has been shaken, they should seize the opportunity and take up some of the simpler offers.

The inflow into Isas may still exceed the billions being lost to the economy by the livestock disaster and tourist slump. There is a wide choice of holdings, including some resort to other currencies.

If confidence in UK plc takes a tumble and/or recession spreads round the world, a safety-first approach and a larger and wider spread of investments is called for.

As for national identity, the UK is starting to look more like wheeler-dealing, densely populated Hong Kong than any nearby country.

That means volatility in financial markets could become normal.

fields.headline: The right answers to your stakeholder pension questions
fields.trailText: Stakeholders are a new type of cheap and simple private pension plan with government-imposed maximum charges and minimum standards.
fields.body:
Stakeholders are a new type of cheap and simple private pension plan with government-imposed maximum charges and minimum standards.

They go on sale on April 6, with charges capped at 1% per year and no initial charges. You can make payments from just £20 per month and stop, start and change them at will. You can take your stakeholder pension with you when you change jobs, and transfer between providers at no cost.

Are they a better deal than traditional personal pensions?

You bet. Personal pensions had initial charges of 5%-10% plus annual charges of 1%-3%, enough to pay big commissions to salespeople and big profits for providers.

Should I take one out?

Only if your employer does not already offer a company pension.

Stakeholders are aimed at the 40% of workers who earn between £10,000 and £20,000 a year but, perhaps because they are on contract or self-employed, or work in small companies, are not offered a company scheme.

Do I have to be in work to take one out?

No. One of the big innovations in stakeholder is that you can earn tax relief on the money you put in even if you are not working. This means that, for the first time, people without employment will be able to contribute to a pension or get someone else to contribute on their behalf and obtain basic-rate tax relief on the contributions.

Why don't I buy an Isa or invest in property for my retirement instead?

Because of the tax relief on stakeholder pensions. You can make payments of up to £3,600 a year (£300 per month) into a stakeholder and earn full tax relief on all the money.

This means the government is giving you a 22% or 40% bonus depending on your tax band.

I already have a company pension. Should I switch?

Almost certainly not. The contributions that an employer makes into your pension far outweigh any benefits that an individual stakeholder pension will give you. But you may be able to buy a stakeholder as well. The rules allow anyone in a company scheme earning less than £30,000 a year to invest in a stakeholder too. And the £3,600 allowance comes on top of the maximum 15% of salary you are allowed to contribute each year into an occupational scheme.

I already have a personal pension. Should I switch to a stakeholder?

As stakeholders are designed to be cheaper and more flexible than personal pensions, you should look into doing so. Your decision should rest on the size of exit penalty you might face and the length of time you have contributed to a personal pension. The longer you have saved, the less worthwhile it will be to switch.

If my employer offers a stakeholder, should I take it?

It depends on whether your employer is offering to pay any contributions into the plan. If they are, it will usually be a good idea to join this plan rather than go elsewhere. But do oppose any move by your employer to close down an existing company pension scheme and offer a stakeholder instead.

Will I still get the state pension?

Yes. The aim of stakeholder is to give a top-up pension to people on lower and middle incomes.

Will I pay tax on the income from my stakeholder pension, and will it hit my benefits?

Yes and yes. The income from your stakeholder will be treated like any other income (and any other pension) and will be taxable.

A much thornier issue is the benefits problem. For poorer people, the income earned from the stakeholder pension may simply mean that other income, such as housing benefit, will be reduced pound-for-pound.

Will all stakeholder pensions be the same?

Not quite. The rules mean they all charge no more than 1% a year, but the final pension pot you receive will depend on how successful they are at investing your money.

 A government-backed helpline run by the Pensions Advisory Service (Opas) on 084-601-2923 (www.stakeholderhelpline.org.uk) offers free information on stakeholder pensions from 8.30am to 6.30pm, Monday to Friday with calls charged at local rates. Impartial information on stakeholders is also available from the Financial Services Authority, the main watchdog, on its consumer helpline 0845-606-1234 or website www.fsa.gov.uk/consumer. Also online is the government's impartial pensions website at www.pensionguide.gov.uk.

webTitle: A tough message to get across

fields.headline: A tough message to get across
fields.trailText: Next week marks the end of one financial year and the beginning of another. The ad campaigns, which have been urging small investors to make full use of their tax free Isa allowances will be pulled. Then, before anyone has time to take a deep breath, you will be bombarded with ads promoting stakeholder pensions - a key plank in the government's bid to make us save more money for our old age.
fields.body:
Next week marks the end of one financial year and the beginning of another. The ad campaigns, which have been urging small investors to make full use of their tax free Isa allowances will be pulled. Then, before anyone has time to take a deep breath, you will be bombarded with ads promoting stakeholder pensions - a key plank in the government's bid to make us save more money for our old age.

But judging by the response so far to the £6.5m ad campaign, which the government itself launched in early January, people are going to take a lot of persuading. For, acccording to research published this week by IFA Promotion, those talking collies are failing in their mission as well over half the population still hasn't a clue what a stakeholder is. Which isn't surprising, as stimulating interest in pensions is difficult at the best of times. For most people it only becomes an issue as they approach retirement when, all too often, they are horrified to see how little they will have to live on in their sunset years. And, after the Equitable Life scandal, these are hardly the best of times.

Stakeholder pensions have several pluses, not least the low charges and the fact that you don't have to be working to buy one. You can even put money into a stakeholder for the benefit of your children or grandchildren. But, like personal pensions and money purchase company schemes, the big drawback is that when you come to retire you don't get your hands on all your money. Most of it has to be used to buy an annuity to provide your income in retirement. And, as anyone who has retired in recent years - when annuity rates have hit rock bottom - will have learned, that income can be paltry. If the government really wants its stakeholder mission to succeed, it should bow to increasing pressure and change that rule.

fields.headline: Sugababes prove they can sing
fields.standfirst:
Notre Dame Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Notre Dame Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
It is, as has often been noted, difficult being a teenager, particularly a teenage member of yet another girl group who must sing live to distinguish themselves from their peers. Quite correctly, licensing restrictions make it legally unwise for minors to perform in places where alcohol is sold. Seemingly lacking sufficient confidence in their act to allow them to perform before sober audiences, Sugababes' handlers hit upon the brainwave of making their show a private party, with tickets distributed via competitions.

There is much that is uncomfortable about three London schoolgirls performing a set of sexually-charged songs. Mercifully, they opt for cheap, comfortable trousers and tops rather than out-and-out glamour. Their introductions are awkward although, good corporate lasses that they are, they do remember to thank the show's sponsors and their record label. Keisha Buchanan, Mutya Buena and Siobhan Donaghy also look terrified - as they should.

All is not wholly well. The sound - and no group needs clarity of sound as desperately as a harmony vocal trio - is a murky sludge, while the clunky four-piece band manage to be both overbearing and uninterested. Yet, from the moment they walk on stage, already singing Look At Me, to the final harmonic crescendo of Run For Cover 40 minutes later, Sugababes just about transcend their youth, their sound and their band.

They are not, Buena aside, natural movers, so the choreography is simple; nor do they have overwhelming presence. Everything rests on the vocals and, simply, Sugababes can sing. The songs, all from their One Touch album, are hardly spectacular, but they are all showcases for vocalising.

The trio are equals, sharing leads and harmonies, often within the same song. What makes them potentially special is the way that they work together: in Soul Sound, say, where they create a tidal wave of melody, or in Run For Cover, where Buena and Buchanan squat on either side of the stage belting out different melody lines, while Donaghy prowls between them singing a third. By the close their fear has evaporated and they are even beginning to smile.

Already Sugababes are not as risible as All Saints. Nor are they as divine as En Vogue, but time is on their side. Hopefully, they are in it for the long haul.

fields.headline: The Orb's sonic terrorism
fields.standfirst:
Leeds Metropolitan University
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Leeds Metropolitan University
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The most pressing question about this concert was "Where are all the Orb fans?" The acid house revellers who enjoyed the fabled second summer of love in the late 1980s were conspicuous by their absence. In their place was a seething throng of youths, most of whom looked as if they'd be just as happy - if not happier - whirling about in front of a DJ's podium. It's uncertain what these impatient, foot-stomping ravers were expecting from cerebral old Alex Paterson, but he made it clear from the start that his job was not to provide a thudding soundtrack for a crowd of loved-up students.

This is not to say the show lacked energy. In fact, the good news is that Paterson has awoken from the ambient haze in which he lost himself for the second half of the last decade. He's clearly been absorbing some modern influences, but rather than striving to imitate Orbital's swelling cathedral of electronic emotion, he's opted for the Chemical Brothers' disorienting, cut'n'paste sonic terrorism.

The first half-hour consisted of a bewildering surge of noise, followed by some propulsive live bass guitar and a dizzying, kaleidoscopic groove. It wasn't long, however, before things turned a bit scary. Having spent years voyaging into space, the good ship Orb has gone into orbit around a strange-looking planet, blasted a tunnel into its core, and embarked on an interior journey of claustrophobic mystery. This meant extended passages of anonymous gloom-trance, drawling dub'n'bass, and moments of disturbing aural contradictions.

Old nuggets from 1992's Uf.Orb were brutally dismembered and thrown into a blender with tracks from the new album, Cydonia, along with the sound of broken mandolins, distressed dogs and malfunctioning music boxes. It all made for a sinister noise that was often riveting, but also left us longing for a patch of blue sky, or maybe even the odd little fluffy cloud.

In light of the musical terror inflicted this evening it's perhaps fortunate that Paterson's old hippie fans have already jumped ship. It remains to be seen how his new passengers cope under the pressure.

The acid house revellers who enjoyed the fabled second summer of love in the late 1980s were conspicuous by their absence. In their place was a seething throng of youths, most of whom looked as if they'd be just as happy - if not happier - whirling about in front of a DJ's podium. webTitle: Enjoy a fair chance in the antiques world

fields.headline: Enjoy a fair chance in the antiques world
fields.standfirst: Stewart Dalby checks out the fine art offered by dealers at annual shows and discovers that contributors are vetted to ensure goods are genuine, while prices are broadly in line with those at auction
fields.trailText: Stewart Dalby checks out the fine art offered by dealers at annual shows and discovers that contributors are vetted to ensure goods are genuine, while prices are broadly in line with those at auction.
fields.body:
Last week, I spent some time at the British Antiques Dealers Association (Bada) annual Antiques & Fine Art Fair at the Duke of York's Headquarters off London's Kings Road. Earlier this year, the Bada gathering was voted Fair of the Year at the British Antiques and Collectables Awards.

The shortlist included the Grosvenor House Art and Antiques Fair and The Olympia Fine Art and Antiques Fair.

The Bada fair is probably less elitist than the Grosvenor House Fair and more relaxed than the Olympia Fair. Perhaps akin to what the Provincial Booksellers Fair is to, say, the Antiquarian Booksellers Fair - rather more affordable and less rarified.

But this comparison does not really hold up since the Bada is a far more diverse event than any book fair. Around 90 dealers (from a membership of about 400) gather over a broad range of antiques and fine art including furniture, paintings, drawings, glass, ceramics, clocks and barometers, textiles, silver and jewellery.

Each participant is a carefully vetted contributor, so all the items are genuine antiques and a cut above charity shops and wares from car boot sales.

Having said that, goods were affordable though there was also some very fancy prices. A massive and very heavy French parcel - a gilt jewel casket, made for Charles X of France with scenes from the life of Don Quixote was priced at £350,000.

There were no Old Masters or Expressionist paintings, but an oil painting by John Duncan Ferguson, one of the Scottish colourists who had such a successful exhibition at the Royal Academy last year, did appear. Through the Trees, South of France, painted circa 1924, was on sale for £85,000.

Leaving aside these top items, I wanted to see how prices stacked up against those in London auctions in the past year or so.

It was a fairly meaningless exercise. Auctions are gladiatorial. If two collectors desperately want an item then prices can do anything at all, really taking off into the stratosphere.

There was no bargaining at Bada and, broadly speaking, prices were in line with what you might pay at auction. Georgian furniture such as George III mahogany bureaus or tables were anything from £10,000 to £85,000, which is in line with what such pieces fetched at a spate of country house sales by Christie's earlier this year.

A dinner set of Staffordshire ceramics would sell for at least £3,000, with individual pieces commanding from the high hundreds of pounds to the low thousands.

Clocks and barometers from the 18th-century onwards, which are in great demand just now, were on sale from anything from £3,000 to £15,000, again what you would expect to pay in the main salerooms.

As I cannot afford to pay anything like these prices until I have cleared another 10 years of school fees and probably not even then, I decided to award myself a notional £20,000, like one of those fantasy share columns, and see what I could purchase. It was not so much to add to collections but to buy things I liked that I also thought would appreciate in value.

My first port of call was Duncan Miller, an art dealer with galleries in London's Hampstead and St James. It was he who had the John Duncan Ferguson along with a number of other Scottish colourists, including an oil painting by Samuel Peploe (1871-1935) called Landscape, Near Comrie. This was a small, 6ins, mellow view and I thought it a bargain at £14,000.

I moved on to glass. I do very much like heavy Georgian pieces. Mark West had some lovely early 18th-century balusters. But he persuaded me to look at Victorian engraved glass.

He said: "Of all things, I think I have been most fascinated by this. The glass was made in England, but the engravers usually came from Germany. The pieces are not often named, but Joseph Keller is on this one."

The glass is lighter than Georgian wares, but not too fine, and the engravings are ornate. I paid a notional £2,000 for a champagne breakfast set, a decanter and two glasses. Mark West told me that, five years ago, I could have purchased it for £500.

I thought about buying some Victorian watercolours, which started at £450, but decided I had enough of these and settled on some knick-knacks. Anybody who likes Treen would have a field day at Bernard Gulley's display. Treen is defined in the dictionary as "to do with wood"; it usually means carved wood. I bought, or at least notionally bought, a flat pronged, metal vegetable fork, with a handle carved from ash for £125.

A mahogany bootjack was £85 and, finally, there was a lovely Burr Birch Scandace bowl, which was honey coloured, for £280, and looked like a Lucy Rie sculpture ceramic, only in wood.

 For further information about the fair or the dealers mentioned telephone Cawdell-Douglas on 020-7439-2822.

webTitle: Transport: Connex trains has no credibility

fields.headline: Never mind  the credibility gap, then
fields.standfirst:
Connex now has a zero tolerance policy towards its passengers. Richard Colbey is astounded

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Connex now has a zero tolerance policy towards its passengers. Richard Colbey is astounded.
fields.body:
Commuters were amazed last week to learn that Connex, a rail company whose raison d' &#ecirc;tre seems to be the making of excuses for its consistently poor services - was adopting a "zero tolerance, no excuses" policy towards its passengers.

The company announced that it would attempt to prosecute anyone caught without a valid ticket on its trains and platforms, whatever their reason. In reality the threat is an empty one, as a prosecution can only take place where the traveller tries to evade payment altogether.

People are more likely to be without tickets having made a mistake, or because broken-down machines or long queues at ticket windows mean they cannot buy one in advance.

The company shamelessly, and with scant regard to the legal consequences, accepted that the policy it was adopting this week would lead to further delays. Not only will there be longer queues to buy tickets, but also there will be hold-ups leaving stations as every ticket is carefully scrutinised.

The company's zero tolerance of miscreant passengers is in striking contrast to how it treats staff. When ticket inspector Keith Sparrow attacked a passenger at Bromley station causing permanent spinal injuries, he was merely transferred to another station.

When first questioned about the incident, which will lead to a substantial award of damages, the company was quoted - it now claims out of context - as describing it as, "a tiny thing in a day of the life of Connex".

Last October, the Strategic Rail Authority announced that Connex was to lose the South Central franchise between London and Brighton. Even before the problems arising out of the Hatfield disaster, 17% of its trains were more than 10 minutes late.

It hangs on by the skin of its teeth to its other franchise, in Kent. This was subject to one of the most severe fare rise curbs ever imposed by the Authority. In December that franchise suffered the further indignity of a £2.38m fine for its poor services.

Despite these sanctions, Connex still boasts a profit of 2% on turnover.

Whether fare evasion is akin to stealing, as Connex would argue, or to merely parking at a meter without paying, is debatable, but in any case it is indefensible.

A spokeswoman claimed this week: "Ticketless travel contributes to overcrowding and costs us and honest passengers considerable sums. There is a definite link between it and vandalism and rowdiness. We feel justified in doing all we can to prevent it."

However, there is little evidence of the company distinguishing between evasion and honest ticketless travel.

The company does have the sanction of attempting to impose £10 penalty fares when people ride without a ticket. Passengers are, though, under no obligation to pay these. They can only be enforced through the county court. It is not cost-effective for rail companies to do this, particularly if they know their entitlement to the money will be contested.

The spokeswoman did say this week that if a penalty fare remained unpaid, the company would then threaten to prosecute for evasion in the magistrates court. This assertion seemed unlikely, and perhaps reflected confusion between civil and criminal liability.

Using the threat of prosecution to ensure payment of a disputed civil debt could offend against s21 of the Theft Act 1968, which prohibits making an unwarranted demand for gain with menaces, and would amount to blackmail.

Connex's deliberate delaying of passengers leaving stations could make it liable in the civil courts. A person who places a constraint on someone else's freedom of movement from a particular place can be liable for false imprisonment.

This can be a relatively trivial interference with the victim's freedom, and doesn't have to involve imprisoning them in the conventional sense. A frequently cited example is the actions in 1982 of a PC Tracey Wilcock, who held on to the arm of a woman whom she was trying to question about being a prostitute to stop her walking away.

The courts have generally sided with transport companies against whom such claims have been brought by passengers.

The leading case involved a man who attempted to leave the wharf at Sydney harbour without putting the required coin in the turnstile. Although the wharf owner's refusal to let him out could have amounted to false im prisonment, the fact that he had the option of paying the fee was sufficient to prevent the company being liable.

Connex passengers, though, will simply be stuck. Ultimately, claims by irate passengers would turn on whether the way the company was operating its exits was reasonable.

The damages awarded for a few minutes' hold-up would normally be negligible. On the other hand, someone who missed an important meeting because of that delay, and suffered a financial loss as a result, would have a substantial claim.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister. He does not commute on Connex trains.

fields.headline: The bases are loaded
fields.standfirst: As overdrafts join some slightly more unusual items in the retail price index it pays to shop around, writes Liz Stuart
fields.trailText: As overdrafts join some slightly more unusual items in the retail price index it pays to shop around, writes Liz Stuart.
fields.body:
Hidden behind the hype of baseball caps being included in the basket of goods used to measure inflation was the news that overdrafts, too, will also feature in the calculations for the first time.

"People are spending more on overdrafts, so it is important they are included on the index," says the Office of National Statistics, referring to the Retail Price Index. Inclusion of new goods and services in the index is seen as a measure of the zeitgeist; in the 60s, for instance, it was sliced bread and fish fingers that made it on to the list, and the cost of mortgages has long been part of the RPI.

Jim McCook, general manager, banking and consumer finance at Halifax, thinks the move is further evidence that current accounts are increasingly coming under the government's scrutiny. "The decision this week by the ONS to include the cost of overdrafts makes the rate charged on them more important than ever in determining the inflation rate. Lower interest rates for overdrafts will ultimately feed through into lower inflation rates, which will benefit millions of borrowers and savers."

In fact, spending on overdrafts increased by more than £400m during 2000, taking the amount we spend on servicing this form of debt to £5.9bn. According to NatWest, the average amount by which people go overdrawn each month is around £1,500, or one month's salary, and people who do use their overdraft facility tend to do so every month, with December being the only month when borrowing tends to do down. "Presumably people are either getting paid earlier or receiving their bonuses. But overdrafts shoot up dramatically in January as people pay off credit card bills," says Neil Harrison, head of personal products at NatWest. Research by NOP, commissioned by Halifax, shows that 11.5m customers of HSBC, Barclays, Lloyds TSB and NatWest have overdrafts and are overdrawn for an average of 80 days in a year.

With interest rates for the big four banks averaging 18%, this gives these customers an average interest bill totalling almost £150m a year. Huge sums could, therefore, be saved by switching to lenders with lower overdraft rates.

There is a wide discrepancy between rates charged by different lenders. The most expensive on the high street is Barclays, which charges 18.8% on pre-agreed overdrafts. This compares with just 9.9% from Smile, the Cooperative Bank's internet banking service, and 8% from Cahoot.

Unauthorised lending is even more expensive: Clydesdale Bank charges 34% on its extra current accounts that are in the red without prior agreement and NatWest charges 33.8% on its current, current plus and advantage gold accounts. Even the cheaper lenders hit hard those who borrow money without agreement with the bank: Smile charges 22%.

A spokesman for NatWest says: "In the case of arranged overdrafts, we are a bit cheaper than the rest of the big four, and there is no arrangement fee. In the case of unauthorised borrowing, we are higher than others, but people should not forget that they have a choice: they can always opt to arrange the borrowing at no cost."

He adds, however, that less than 10% of customers go overdrawn without arranging to do so first.

The majority of lenders allow an initial sum to be borrowed at no charge, which is termed an overdraft "buffer". With Smile and Citibank this is £500; at Cahoot, Abbey National's internet bank, and some First Direct accounts, the maximum amount is £250, while most lenders allow customers to go £50 into the red at no extra cost.

Some charge for setting up an overdraft agreement - the fee can be as high as 2% of the figure borrowed, with a minimum of £35 (Clydesdale). Other lenders hit the customer when they use the overdraft facility: Barclays Bank, for instance, charges £5 a month for bank account customers. Clydesdale effectively double charges its customers: not only do you have to pay to set up the arrangement, but also you must pay up to £8.50 a month to use it.

webTitle: Saving your home if you lose your job

fields.headline: Saving your home if you lose your job
fields.standfirst: Despite paltry state benefits, only one in four homeowners have mortgage payment protection insurance, Liz Stuart discovers
fields.trailText: Despite paltry state benefits, only one in four homeowners have mortgage payment protection insurance, Liz Stuart discovers
fields.body:
While travel insurance is now seen as mandatory for trips outside Europe, just a quarter of homeowners have their mortgage payments - most people's biggest monthly outgoing - covered.

This has contributed to the alarming statistic that 50% of homeowners would be unable to meet their housing costs if they lost their job. Research from the Association of British Insurers shows that most people do not realise how limited state assistance is if they do fall into arrears.

The ABI found that a "worrying proportion" of consumers - one in five - believe they could rely on the government to provide them with financial assistance if they were unable to find work.

In fact, state benefits to support mortgage repayments are means tested and even people who are eligible generally have to wait for up to nine months before they receive their first benefit payment. Also payments only cover mortgage interest and not the outstanding capital debt.

Around a third of those questioned who do not have mortgage payment protection insurance (MPPI) say they would rely on their savings if their income were to drop significantly. However, the average household has just £750 in liquid assets.

With chancellor Gordon Brown insisting that Britain will not return to boom and bust - a major feature of which was repossessions - it is understandable that the majority of people do not rate losing their job, and the effect that would have on their ability to pay their mortgage, as a major consideration. But these findings may add to the pressure on the government to make MPPI compulsory.

Mary Francis, director-general of the Association of British Insurers, says: "This report certainly gave us food for thought. One key concern is the lack of awareness of just how limited government help is for mortgage holders who become unemployed.

"Mortgage payment protection insurance has recently been given a facelift by insurers, lenders and the government through their sustainable home ownership project. Policies must now meet or exceed minimum standards in terms of the cover offered."

In 1999 an MPPIs standard was introduced in an attempt to encourage more people to take out policies. These minimum standards required all policies to pay out after 60 days - some had previously forced claimants to wait for four months.

The ABI findings also showed that a large majority of people who have taken out MPPIs, and have made a claim, have found their policy to be effective.

But a report from a mortgage industry magazine, Mortgage Finance Gazette, questions the value of payment-protection products. It shows that 41% of mortgage lenders think the products have no, or very little, impact on the arrears situation, although they do help the indebted individual.

Almost half of the companies questioned said they would press on with court action even if a borrower had MPPI cover.

John Collins, a Swansea-based lawyer and joint author of the report, says: "There are any number of reasons for a company taking such a line - the level of cover might be inadequate or the payments under the policy might go to the borrower rather than the lender, so leading to underpayment or non-payment of the mortgage."

And insurer Goodfellows says its research shows that, where MPPI payments are made, they are insufficient and fail to pay for the basic needs of food, clothing and travel. This week it has launched a protection plan which is, it says, a cover for basic living expenses, not just mortgage protection. Shelter replaces up to 75% of lost gross earnings for up to two years. fields.headline: Property Isas build in value
fields.trailText: Not sure you can face punting your savings into the stock market, but want something a bit more exciting than a deposit account? One of the steadiest and safest investments over the past year has been property.
fields.body:
Not sure you can face punting your savings into the stock market, but want something a bit more exciting than a deposit account? One of the steadiest and safest investments over the past year has been property.

Investors cannot put money into residential property as an Isa investment, but there are a couple of Isa funds which invest in commercial property such as shops and offices, which have enjoyed returns of around 10% a year.

The biggest is Norwich Union, whose £433m property fund is up 15.4% over the past year - when most other unit trusts have fallen by 5% to 10% - and has returned 71% over the past five years. Around 43% of the fund is invested in office developments, with the next largest chunk in out-of-town shopping centres, but little in high street retail.

Ten years ago, no one wanted to touch property. The 80s boom provoked a speculative building frenzy that brought millions of square feet on line just as the economy was heading fast downhill.

Norwich Union fund manager Chris Laxton, who manages a total of £2bn as NU's property investment director, says: "The years between 1990 and 1993 were desperate, with rents falling and huge oversupply."

But anyone scanning the London skyline now will see a new forest of cranes. Does it signal a market once again reaching saturation? "Yes, there are lots of cranes on the skyline, but this time round only 30% or so of new buildings are not already pre-let. In the late 80s the speculative element was far higher." Average office rents in the West End of London are now £75-£80 per square foot, in the City £55 and Docklands £40. "We have seen very strong increases across the board, but that has only taken us back to the nominal levels of the late 80s," says Mr Laxton.

The problems besetting Marks & Spencer and the rest of the retail sector are why Mr Laxton owns few high-street sites. "We are very conscious of the squeeze on margins on retailers at the moment. We think retail growth will be zero to 1% next year."

Not that all retail is in decline. Out of town centres are more prized than ever, and as council planning departments limit the mushrooming of ugly retail sheds on their outer fringes, rents on existing ones are forced up.

Although he forecasts a general slowdown in 2003/2004, Mr Laxton believes property will remain a "robust" investment. "Most of it is about yield; over the past three years the total return on the fund has been around 10% per annum with 7% from yield and only 3% from capital growth."

Mr Laxton also cautions against short-termism: "Any investor would want to stay invested over a minimum of three years. The underlying transaction costs when we buy a property are very high - in total it adds up to around 7%. As everyone knows, property is not the most liquid of investments. We always encourage long-term investment in the fund; it's not about making a quick buck and then getting out."

webTitle: Theatre review: A Russian in the Woods

fields.headline: A gripping return to the cold war era
fields.standfirst:
A Russian in the Woods
The Other Place
Stratford-upon-Avon
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
A Russian in the Woods
The Other Place
Stratford-upon-Avon
Rating: ****
fields.body:
We rightly prize young dramatists. But there's something to be said for a senior playwright blessed with a long memory, such as Peter Whelan. In this gripping, semi-autobiographical new play he recalls what it was like to be a national serviceman sent to a divided Berlin in 1950 at the height of the cold war.

Not surprisingly, Whelan's hero, Pat, cuts a convincing figure. Aged 19, part of the Education Corps and with stories by Turgenev and Chekhov in his knapsack, he finds himself in a city where the Russians have been transformed from wartime allies into peacetime enemies. In the course of an eventful weekend, he is left to guard an army education centre in Charlottenburg. First a Pandarus-like sergeant from the Kinema Corps tries to get him into bed with the centre's German secretary. But when she fails to turn up for a dance-date, Pat brings back an apparently American soldier, at which point his troubles really begin.

Whelan touches on many themes in this engrossing play. One is the contrast between the idealistic naivete of the national serviceman and the entrenched attitudes of the old sweats who have been through a war. But the play is also about the artificial barriers, sexual and political, we erect between human beings. Propositioned by the young "American", Pat is seriously tempted, only to find himself up on a charge of bringing a Soviet spy into the centre. Whelan's point is that the 1950s' demonisation of both Russians and homosexuals led to failures of understanding. The postwar world, he implies, might have been a better place if both the cold war and our sexual paranoia had been prematurely thawed.

Sometimes you feel Whelan yokes together dissimilar things: there was, after all, good reason to be suspicious of the Russians after the Berlin blockade of 1948, which led even Aneurin Bevan to call for the despatch of allied tanks. And, technically, the device of setting the action inside Pat's memory seems redundant. But this is still a wonderfully written play that conjures up, in a Le Carré-like way, the equivocal mystery of 1950s Berlin and that follows its own principles by refusing to dehumanise the enemy. Even the army intelligence sergeant, who sees reds in as well as under the bed, is a shrewd operator, who argues you have to read War and Peace to understand the thinking Russian.

Robert Delamere's atmospheric production is superbly designed by Simon Higlett, with evocative tramlines running through the centre of the broken-windowed Charlottenburg house. Anthony Flanagan, making his stage debut as Pat, shows a technical command that implies a remarkable future and there is impeccable support from Anna Madeley as the German secretary and Colin Mace as the red-hunting sergeant. Whelan has always been a good writer. Here, by excavating his own past, he has produced an exceptional play that delves deep into our collective national memory.

 Until October 10. Box office: 01789 403403.

fields.headline: Taylor will leave Watford gap
fields.trailText: In typically enigmatic style, Graham Taylor yesterday announced that he will retire at the end of this season,
fields.body:
In typically enigmatic style, Graham Taylor yesterday announced that he will retire at the end of this season, ending a 29-year managerial career which took him from Lincoln City to Lancaster Gate.

The 56-year-old Watford manager issued a statement through the club's website and said he would make no further comment "as all of my energies will be focused on our final run of matches as we try to gain promotion to the Premiership once more". Indeed he has promised to walk out of a press conference to be held this afternoon should anyone raise the matter.

But few people at Watford will be able to think of anything else. Taylor has a talismanic status at the club, having twice led them from the lower-division wilderness into the top-flight promised land. Certainly his time there has never been dull: of the 14 years he has spent in charge of the Hertfordshire club, five have ended in promotion, one in relegation and six have been spent in the highest league.

"He's probably the greatest influence they've ever had," said John Ward, who worked with him in his first spell at Watford before following him to Aston Villa and England. "When he started, there was a greyhound track at the ground that probably attracted more people than the football team. The importance of what he's done cannot be overestimated."

Taylor had planned to retire when his contract expired at the end of next season, but Watford's continuing struggles in the First Division - and his inability to correct them - have persuaded him to leave sooner. "It's like anything else, you get to a stage when you think it's time to stop, time to move on," said Ward, who will be among the favourites to take over from Taylor, although some at the club would prefer a manager with a higher profile.

Though the feeling is that, had the team continued their impressive early-season form, Taylor would have remained for another season, the announcement came as little surprise to those close to the club, who have seen his normally sunny demeanour darken in recent months.

"Personally it didn't come as a big shock," the midfielder Richard Johnson said yesterday on his website, icons.com. "I think he just wants to concentrate on other things."

In 1965 Taylor became, at 21, the youngest person to win a full FA coaching badge, and after a hip injury ended his undistinguished playing career he took over at Lincoln in 1972. After 1,020 league games, he has won seven promotions and a record 29 manager-of-the-month awards.

"It's very sad to hear that such a fine manager is going to leave the game," said the Derby manager Jim Smith, who played with Taylor at Lincoln and is one of only two other people to have overseen 1,000 league games. "He is undoubtedly one of the outstanding managers of his generation and has set a fine example for anyone aspiring to be successful in football."

Only a crisis-filled spell in charge of England, in which he lost to the United States, failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup and gave Carlton Palmer 18 caps, took the shine off his managerial career. At the height of his unpopularity a candidate for the Sack Graham Taylor Party won 80 votes in the Christchurch by-election of 1993.

Now a familiar hunt begins. The last time he left Vicarage Road Watford were relegated within 12 months, starting a 10-year period of failure as they searched desperately for an adequate replacement. In 1997 they found their man: Graham Taylor again.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Spurs can expect Hoddle delay and little investment

fields.headline: Spurs can expect Hoddle delay and little investment
fields.trailText: The problem of compensation is holding up Glenn Hoddle's move to White Hart Lane as Tottenham fans gained an insight into the prospects for future investment at the club.
fields.body:
Tottenham's chances of receiving the huge cash injection their fans believe they need to return to the glory days looked remote last night after the new owner Enic published financial results showing that it had not provided a single penny during the past six months to any of the other clubs in which it owns an interest.

However, there are signs that Daniel Levy, the Enic managing director and Spurs chairman who has committed to invest in the north London club, is building up a considerable cash armoury - up to £65m - by selling other assets to focus on football.

There was embarrassment for Enic yesterday - and another worry for Spurs fans - when plans to unveil Glenn Hoddle as Tottenham's new manager had to be cancelled at short notice because of problems working out a compensation package with Southampton.

Enic said it was confident Hoddle would be named manager by the weekend and was anxious to play down the delay. But the Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe told a local newspaper: "We are not a small club to be pushed around by the big boys. We are going to play hardball on this.

"I don't see why we should roll over and let them take what they want just like that. None of this is of our making and it is now up to them to sort things out properly.

But according to Enic: "There is no problem surrounding the appointment of Glenn Hoddle. The problem appears to be working out compensation that is acceptable to both sides."

Privately, however, there is dismay at Lowe's reaction. He has accused Tottenham of making an illegal approach and has said he intends to report the club to the Premier League.

Once compensation is settled, Hoddle is expected to sign a five-year contract along with his assistant John Gorman. Both men will take charge at Spurs on Monday with their first game against Arsenal in the FA Cup semi-final on April 8.

Enic's overall cash position looks healthy with £40m in the bank at the turn of the year despite a small operating loss. Those figures do not include the £21.9m it agreed to pay Sir Alan Sugar for his 29.9% stake in White Hart Lane.

However, Enic is planning to dispose of its 25% stake in Rangers, which is worth around £29m, and yesterday agreed to sell a restaurant complex in Orlando, Florida, for another £10m.

Levy has also asked shareholders for permission to sell Enic's £26m shareholding in a major software company.

Combined, those sales could add another £65m to Levy's financial firepower.

webTitle: Cheers for Eriksson but team are slow on uptake

fields.headline: Cheers for Eriksson but team are slow on uptake
fields.standfirst: David Lacey  on the coach's perfect start despite glaring imperfections
fields.trailText: Two wins, job done - for now. But it could all have been so different and glaring imperfections have tainted Sven-Goran Eriksson's perfect start.
fields.body:
Statistically Sven-Goran Eriksson could not have made a better start as England's coach. Three wins are three wins and, when two of them produce the maximum of six World Cup qualifying points in the space of five days, who is to complain?

"Nobody doubted me as a coach," said Eriksson after England's 3-1 victory over Albania in Tirana on Wednesday night, "they just doubted me as a foreign coach." And that sort of doubt was never worth serious consideration.

Any reservations now must concern not so much the ability of Eriksson to cope with the task in hand as whether the team can stay in touch with his thinking. From the outset he has stuck to a simple tactical plan and demanded no more from the players than that they perform for England as they play for their clubs. For some, however, this may already be too much.

Look at England's victories over Finland and Albania another way. But for David Seaman's late save from Jari Litmanen at Anfield, and the linesman's flag that denied Albania a second goal in stoppage-time to level the scores at 2-2 in the Qemal Stafa stadium, Eriksson's team might have been held to two draws.

The difference between lying a comfortable second in their World Cup qualifying group and lagging behind has been that fine. As it is, with Germany five points clear after winning their first four games, a play-off for a place in next year's tournament still looks England's best option.

It was with this in mind that one watched, awestruck, the highlights of the 2-2 draw between Portugal and Holland, an enthralling match in which the Portuguese came back from 2-0 down to deny the Dutch the win they so badly needed. A play-off with either of these sides would demand considerably more of Eriksson's team than they have produced so far.

All new teams take a while to settle in and international teams are no exception. England, remember, can no longer call on the likes of Alan Shearer and Tony Adams, players who at their best were important struts and crossbeams in the framework of the side. There is no longer a Paul Gascoigne to stun world-class defenders with his presumptuous skills, or a Paul Ince to drive the team forward through sheer strength of will.

Neither Charlton's Chris Powell nor Ashley Cole, the 20-year-old Arsenal defender capped for the first time in Albania, looks the answer to the continuing problem caused by the lack of defensive strength at left-back. Graeme le Saux, where art thou? Bring on Jamie Carragher, who may be right-footed but should at least defend competently at this level.

When Sol Campbell limped away shortly before the half-hour on Wedneday, to be replaced by Wes Brown, Gary Neville found himself the doyen of England's back four at the advanced age of 26. No wonder Eriksson's defence thereafter struggled to keep track of Albania's clever rotating of Igli Tare, Bledar Kola and the consistently dangerous Alban Bushi.

When Altin Rraklli came off the bench to begin running at the centre-backs they looked even more bemused. A bad error by Rio Ferdinand cost England one goal and the narrow, though correct, offside decision spared them another.

So far, then, it has been a case of England's excellent moments in attack staying ahead of their defensive errors, but only by a whisker. So long as Paul Scholes and Michael Owen stay fit and in form this should continue to be the case.

In Tirana, David Beckham enjoyed another thoughtful, busy game as captain. His crosses were as near to perfection as made no difference and, until England's first goal, only his free-kicks had brought Foto Strakosha into serious action.

Yet it was Scholes, solidly supported by Nicky Butt, the expected replacement for the injured Steven Gerrard, who held a bridgehead in midfield and consistently broke up opposing attacks as Albania grew more confident going forward. Steve McManaman's forward runs, and an early understanding on the left with Ashley Cole, also promised something, but after half-time McManaman gave way to Emile Heskey, as much to shore up the England left flank as to put added pressure on the Albanian right.

England still lack someone to command the ball between the penalty areas in the manner of a Johnny Haynes, a Bobby Charlton, a Glenn Hoddle or a Gascoigne. As yet there is no one to take possesion and declare that this is how it shall be. As a result the crucial element of surprise is missing from much of England's movements, and not until the 73rd minute, when Scholes's astute touch sent in Owen for his 10th international goal, were Albania's impressive back three caught out.

Eriksson's faith in Andy Cole would again have been justified even if the Manchester United forward had not scored England's third goal, his first in 13 internationals. Cole's work off the ball was again vital to England's attempts to get behind Albania's cover, witness his dash to the byline to set up Scholes for the second goal.

Now, having persevered with Andy Cole, Eriksson will have to start the qualifier in Greece on June 6 with Heskey instead, or bring in Robbie Fowler alongside Owen, since Cole will be suspended after a second booking.

At least the game in Athens will be free of ancient English comedians, unless the Greeks have a thing about Jim Davidson. A little of Norman Wisdom, the Albanian folk hero, always did go a long way.

fields.headline: La Dolce Vita
fields.standfirst: Sue rounds off her Australian odyssey with a visit to Sydney where she chills out on the beaches, meets up with a fellow netjetter and ends the week on a high note with a night at the opera house
fields.trailText: Cairns to Sydney Sue rounds off her Australian odyssey with a visit to Sydney where she chills out on the beaches, meets up with a fellow netjetter and ends the week on a high note with a night at the opera house
fields.body:
Here I am in Sydney.

It is a lovely city built around the huge harbour and sprawling along the coast to include all the famous surfing beaches. I hadn't realised before that these were part of the city. Bits of it remind me of London, but newer and cleaner, and there are lots of familiar district names - Waterloo, King's Cross, Paddington, etc. An abundance of parks make it a very green city, and it's very easy to get around by bus and train. I've never been on a double decker tube before.

On Sunday Annie, whom I'm staying with, took me up to the Blue Mountains - but cloud and drizzle obscured what is obviously a beautiful area. We kept walking to the Three Sisters rock formation from different approaches waiting for breaks in the mist so that I could get a photo. Our planned walk also had to be curtailed due to a landslide so it was not a lucky day, but enjoyable none the less.

Annie lives half way between Bondi Beach and Coogie, where Millie is, so I spent Monday exploring the area, beginning with a walk along the coastal path to Bondi and a little paddle in the surf. I don't think I'll be adding surfing to my list of new accomplishments. I then went into the city for a look around the harbour (some of the luxury riverside houses matched London in price), and later headed back to meet Milly in the evening for a meal and a drink. We had many fruitless but funny attempts to take a photo of ourselves, finally giving in and asking the barman. He was somewhat bemused to be given two identical digital cameras and asked to take a photo with each. We both agreed that the majority of travellers are about 22-25, with a lot of women in their late 20s travelling alone. The thought of travelling on my own was daunting to me - how much scarier it must be at 18.

On Tuesday I went on a day trip to Canberra.The long journey meant that I wasn't left with much time once I was there, but it was worth it to catch a glimpse of this beautiful new city, planned to include large green spaces and to blend into the surrounding countryside. We drove past all the embassies, the architecture of each reflecting their countries of origin (the British Consulate was very boring). On the green outside the old parliament building stood a rickety wooden shed ironically labelled the Aboriginal Embassy, and covered in political statements.

We then went on to the new Parliament House, built into a hill with the roof covered in grass to echo the landscape. The architecture and interior design of this building is lovely. Both houses were sitting and it was 'question time', with John Howard in full flow. One British legacy that the Australians could have abandoned but obviously did not, is the yaboo and bad manners of politicians noisily expressing their approval or otherwise of whoever is speaking.

A quick zoom into the National Art Gallery and it was off to the War Memorial. I had wondered why we were given as much time here as at Parliament House but it actually is a very beautiful place with a large and impressive exhibition centre. In former times I have painted little lead soldiers to earn an extra crust, so I was appreciative of the model diaramas depicting battles. I also found a Stubbings in the roll of honour, an airman killed in the second world war - no relation as far as I know. Any spare minutes on the trip were spent scribbling down the names of places recommended by Cheryl from California who has travelled extensively in South America. It was a long but interesting day.

On Wednesday I took myself by ferry to Taronga Zoo. I'm not a great fan of zoos but felt I couldn't leave Oz without seeing either a koala or an emu. As far as zoos go this one is good: the animals live as naturally as is possible. You could have your photo taken next to a koala lounging on a branch for two dollars, but the queue was so long that I decided the website could live without that shot.

On Thusday I was supposed to be going to Manley but, feeling lazy, I opted for a walk to the nearby Bronti Bay to chill out on the beach, watching the surfers and reading a book. Four months into this trip I am beginning to realise that I can allow myself the odd day off from travelling and sightseeing, and that this is actually a holiday. It always feels so much like a race against time to see as much as possible, knowing that I probably will not come back to many, if any, of these places. I am already in a panic about how to get round all there is to see in New Zealand in a mere three weeks.

I had a wonderful finale to my week and my stay with Annie. Following Sam and Milly's example I had to go to the Opera House, and we were lucky enough to get tickets for Kennedy - formerly known as Nigel - playing Elgar's Violin Concerto with the Sydney Symphony Orchestra. In such a magnificent theatre, with champagne on the balcony overlooking the harbour, watching Kennedy who was as ever the flamboyant virtuoso, it was a lovely evening. How many highlights can a person pack into six months?

It has been good staying with Annie, a welcome break from hostels. I have met so many kind, hospitable people over the course of the trip - in fact, I'm off to see some more this evening as I'm meeting up with Simon and his wife, who contacted me on the website. This aspect of the travelling has been a real bonus.

So - off to New Zealand on Sunday. Perhaps the secret is not to try and see everything but to concentrate on a few areas. But which ones? I think I have decided to hire a car. Perhaps by next week I will have made some decisions. (Can you tell I am a Libran?)

webTitle: Vaz taken to hospital after collapsing during interview

fields.headline: Vaz taken to hospital after collapsing during interview
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz, the troubled Europe minister, spent last night in hospital after collapsing during a television interview at the Foreign Office.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the troubled Europe minister, spent last night in hospital after collapsing during a television interview at the Foreign Office. He was taken by ambulance to St Thomas' hospital in south London for checks.

A hospital spokesman said: "Following tests Mr Vaz is being admitted overnight for routine observation."

Mr Vaz, 44, was sitting on the edge of his chair when he suddenly slumped and fell over on to the floor, apparently losing consciousness for about three minutes. He had recovered consciousness before the ambulance arrived.

John Paul Lynch, 22, an outpatient who saw Mr Vaz arrive in an ambulance, said: "He was brought in on a stretcher by about six people. He was taken inside, and he got off the stretcher, but he was quite unstable, weak in the legs. He stood up but he didn't walk, and two people were helping him stand. Then they put him in a wheelchair."

He has been under severe criticism over his handling of his personal finances and for failing to take greater personal interest in the Balkans, one of his areas of responsibility.

Although he has remained outwardly cheerful despite the intense political pressure, observers have noted that he has lost weight.

During the interview, on visas, Jane Faure-Brac, a reporter from the Foreign Office-funded British Satellite News, noted that Mr Vaz looked unwell and agreed at his request to stop filming to allow him to take a break.

After a few minutes he returned but at the end of the interview he collapsed.

Ms Faure-Brac said she loosened Mr Vaz's tie and helped him into a recovery position. "From the moment he came into the room he wasn't himself. He wasn't very focused - there were big pauses between his answers and normally he is very well briefed."

Mr Vaz was criticised earlier this month by the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, for failing to declare that he had a financial relationship with an Asian lawyer whom he recommended for a personal honour.

A complaint that he failed to declare a donation from a lawyer he recommended for a peerage was upheld by the parliamentary standards committee. He was also criticised for failing to cooperate with the inquiry, but has continued in office with the outward support of Tony Blair. The Tories have made repeated calls for his resignation but Downing Street says he has been cleared of all serious allegations.

He is now, however, facing a further investigation over his wife's involvement with the Hinduja brothers and an alleged failure to declare a relevant interest.

It was also revealed this week that Mr Vaz had approved 49 visa applications against the advice of immigration officers during the 17 months he has been in his Foreign Office job.

webTitle: The simple pleasures are the best

fields.headline: The simple pleasures are the best
fields.standfirst: A three-day break at health farm Ragdale Hall left Jill Tilden blissed out
fields.trailText: A three-day break at health farm Ragdale Hall left Jill Tilden blissed out
fields.body:
Announce you're off to a health hydro and you'll learn that to the uninitiated it still conjures up an image of eating yoghurt and greens to the backdrop of glamorous celebrities shedding pounds in the sauna. I'm not the first and probably won't be the last to set the record straight. At Ragdale Hall, near Nottingham, where my daughter and I spent a few blissful days last month, the food was delicious and plentiful, and I didn't spot anyone who looked remotely glamorous.

The point is, and this is the thing you need to get used to as soon as you arrive, everyone gets to be princess for the day. Our family annals record that when said daughter was three years old she appeared one day tastefully got up in tatters of satin, velvet and lace from the dressing up box and announced solemnly, "Today I princess Mummy. Now everybody loves me. Everybody is my friend." It's like that. Everything's there for you, from smiling Dave who materialises to take your luggage before you even open the car door, to Joanne who whisks you to comfortable sofas for cups of tea while you fill in forms about your health and what you want for tomorrow's breakfast, to dapper Paul who gives you a personal guided tour, to the personalised schedule showing when your back will be massaged and your dinner served.

Everything works like very quiet clockwork and it needs to. Ragdale Hall is a complex operation combining a traditional country hotel, all oak pannelling and comfortable chairs, an up to the minute health club with a well-equipped gym and two exercise studios for the non-stop programme of aerobic and yogic exercise, a beauty centre for facials, massages and so on, and of course a spa area with steam room, jacuzzi, sauna and swimming pool.

I didn't do too much in the beauty centre, though I loved the winter garden where you wait for your treatments, and hung out there till daughter emerged from a facial and massage, swearing that from now on she would use a proper moisturiser. The classes were great. I survived an hour's aerobic workout - how could I stop when next to me was a bloke who could give me 10 stone and 10 years? - and was convinced by the pilates tutor that this was the way forward. Admittedly it was partly because he was a Robson Greene lookalike with an irresistible no-nonsense manner, but from now on I'm going to keep that muscle tone just like he said.

I even progressed from tentative spectator in the gym to sampling (well admit it, enjoying) the walking machine, but for me the watery side of Ragdale Hall is where it's at. I lost count of how many times we slipped into the spa to swim, steam, enjoy the massage jets, interrupted only by endless hot showers, cosseted by endless fluffy white towels. Mysteriously we always seemed to have the pool to ourselves. The steam room too. I discovered that as the minutes pass and the steam creeps over you and into your skin nothing else seems to matter, and all that fuss over deadlines last week recedes to an infinite distance.

Even the drop-in exercise classes were never crowded. Obviously a law is operating. Actually I think I know what it is. We arrived exhausted but hyperactive, launched into a 24 hour flurry of trying everything, then began to slow down, pace ourselves, rest and recover. Then on the third day it was time to go. I suspect that those fortunate enough to stay longer are not littering up the action areas but have taken themselves off to one of the delicious quiet rooms where you simply do nothing, I mean nothing, in complete tranquillity until the next meal. If that wears off you can reposition yourself in one of the cafe areas and if it's not too much trouble enjoy a little light chat over a cappuccino or fruit juice. They've even thought about your evenings - each night you can relax in the privacy of your room in front of a film shown on the internal channel.

They never say no at Ragdale Hall though we tested the system. On the first night (still hyper) having made friends with Maitre D John Vickers I slipped in a request for an extra shot of olive oil. Mr Vickers's face is simply not cut out to look disapproving. He lowered his voice and gently pointed out that all the food is specially prepared to be light and healthy, but then personally brought me just the right amount in a tiny bowl.

 Guardian readers can enjoy a two-night stay between 1 May and 31 August at Ragdale Hall Health Hydro, from £199 per person based on two people sharing a superior room. The offer includes full board and use of the pool, gymnasium, sauna, steam rooms, sanarium and separate exercise classes, as well as a Nourishing Hand Treatment, Relaxing Scalp Massage, Kanebo Seasonal Make-Up Session and a Kanebo Gift worth at least £30. To book or for more information, please call 0870 843 6673 or email enquiries@ragdalehall.co.uk, quoting Guardian Unlimited.

We arrived exhausted but hyperactive, launched into a 24 hour flurry of trying everything, then began to slow down, pace ourselves, rest and recover. Then on the third day it was time to go. I suspect that those fortunate enough to stay longer are not littering up the action areas but have taken themselves off to one of the delicious quiet rooms where you simply do nothing, I mean nothing, in complete tranquillity until the next meal. If that wears off you can reposition yourself in one of the cafe areas and if it's not too much trouble enjoy a little light chat over a cappuccino or fruit juice. They've even thought about your evenings - each night you can relax in the privacy of your room in front of a film shown on the internal channel. They never say no at Ragdale Hall though we tested the system. On the first night (still hyper) having made friends with Maitre D John Vickers I slipped in a request for an extra shot of olive oil. Mr Vickers's face is simply not cut out to look disapproving. He lowered his voice and gently pointed out that all the food is specially prepared to be light and healthy, but then personally brought me just the right amount in a tiny bowl.  Guardian readers can enjoy a two-night stay between 1 May and 31 August at Ragdale Hall Health Hydro, from £199 per person based on two people sharing a superior room. The offer includes full board and use of the pool, gymnasium, sauna, steam rooms, sanarium and separate exercise classes, as well as a Nourishing Hand Treatment, Relaxing Scalp Massage, Kanebo Seasonal Make-Up Session and a Kanebo Gift worth at least £30. webTitle: Driving across Europe on a honeymoon

fields.headline: Driving across Europe on a honeymoon
fields.standfirst:
We plan to take our one-year-old daughter on our honeymoon this August. We want to drive across France, Switzerland and Italy. We've got two weeks to get down to Tuscany. Would it be foolhardy not to book hotels in advance? We like the idea of going at our own pace rather than rushing to be at the next pre-booked destination. We'd be very grateful for any advice.
Jenny Radcliffe
fields.trailText: We plan to take our one-year-old daughter on our honeymoon this August. We want to drive across France, Switzerland and Italy. We've got two weeks to get down to Tuscany. Would it be foolhardy not to book hotels in advance?
fields.body:
 We always pre-book but one year we thought we would be adventurous and more "free spirited"... We had terrible problems finding places to stay and in fact found we had to drive through the places we wanted to stay at because of lack of accommodation. With a one-year-old child I would think it advisable to book. Don't underestimate the size of France and the distances you are going to travel. We are going to Provence this summer with an 8-month-old and we will pre-book our accommodation en route.

Hope these comments are useful... have a great wedding and honeymoon.

Jan Tavill
