webTitle: Cycling from England to the south of France

fields.headline: Cycling from England to the south of France
fields.standfirst:
I wish to cycle independently from England to Narbonne in the south of France, camping en route. I wonder if there are any recommended scenic routes and whether readers would know roughly how long it would take were I to cycle an average of 50 miles a day?
Thomas Bethell
fields.trailText: I wish to cycle independently from England to Narbonne in the south of France, camping en route. I wonder if there are any recommended scenic routes and whether anyone would know roughly how long it would take were I to cycle an average of 50 miles a day?
fields.body:
 I'd strongly recommend taking a night-ferry to somewhere like Caen or St Malo; it will feel like much more of a slog from the more northerly Channel ports. Avoiding the exhaustingly hilly Massif Central, your broad options are then either to head due south, cutting through to the Mediterranean along the line of the Canal du Midi, or to head over to the Rhone-Saône valley, perhaps via the Loire. As a a first-timer and for sheer breadth of choice, I'd suggest the former.

The key to pleasant riding is to follow as far as possible the departmental roads shown in yellow on most maps: almost always well-maintained, direct and with what traffic there is refreshingly considerate to cyclists. I find the IGN 1:250,000 maps ideal, showing the terrain far better than Michelin's nearest equivalent: you'll need half a dozen to cover your route.

You can take your luck with campsites, though I find carrying a copy of the Michelin Camping-Caravanning guide invaluable towards the end of each day. Ignore any recommendations to book ahead in the holiday season, though - you need to be able to follow the mood of the day, and as a cyclist you're unlikely not to find space.

From the ports suggested, and if you stick to your 50-miles-a-day, I'd allow ten days or so in all. Bonne route!

Nat Goodden

 The Cyclists Touring Club have a touring information department who can send out detailed information on cycle touring routes in many areas, based on reports which they have received from members who have toured there previously. If you're not already a CTC member you would need to join to use this service, but having done so you would have access not only to touring advice but also to good deals on insurance, clothing and equipment and technical advice for your trip. CTC are on 01483 417217.

webTitle: Blair's 'guru' urges social action role for voluntary sector

fields.headline: Blair's 'guru' urges social action role for voluntary sector
fields.trailText: The voluntary sector has a key role in fixing the problems caused by a decline in social cohesion in the UK, community regeneration guru Robert Putnam told charity leaders today.
fields.body:
The voluntary sector has a key role in fixing the problems caused by a decline in social cohesion in the UK, community regeneration guru Robert Putnam told charity leaders today.

The Harvard University professor said voluntary organisations must be at the forefront of finding new methods of bringing communities together despite cultural and other differences.

He urged the government to create of a form of national service - a compulsory year of community work for young people - as a way of helping build up the capacity of the voluntary sector to address social problems.

Professor Putnam was addressing the Third Sector Foresight conference in London, hosted by the National Council of Voluntary Organisations.

The professor, who has been dubbed prime minister Tony Blair's "new favourite guru", said Britain had previously shown the way in tackling social breakdowns during the early 1900s, when a range of community institutions were created in the wake of the industrial revolution.

"Most social institutions such as the Boy Scouts were founded during this time and Britain led the way. We now need a similar concentrated period of civic inventiveness."

Prof Putnam has been touring Britain and Ireland this week, dropping into 10 Downing Street on Tuesday to advise Mr Blair and gaining widespread publicity for his book, Bowling Alone.

He said the debate should not be about whether social disintegration in the UK was more or less of a problem than in the US, but that effort should be made to increase what he calls "social capital" on both sides of the Atlantic.

Prof Putnam's message is that society needs to build more social capital, which he defines as "social networks, which have norms of reciprocity".

"All societies are underfunded when it comes to social capital, " he said.

Developing social capital would have a positive effect on health, wealth and democracy, he said. These networks can be anything from neighbourhood watch schemes to sports teams.

Prof Putnam added that the sector needs to assess what kinds of social capital are useful and find ways of generating them.

He warned that there is often a negative correlation between social capital and diverse communities - that the more similar a community the easier it is to create social networks. He said the challenge for Britain is to build social capital within a multi-cultural society.

fields.headline: Profile: Robert Putnam
fields.trailText: Profile: Robert Putnam
fields.body:
Who is Robert Putnam?
He is "Tony Blair's new favourite guru" according to the Daily Telegraph. He is a Harvard University professor and social analyst who has charted the collapse of civic and community values in the USA. His message, as outlined in his book Bowling Alone: the Collapse and Revival of American Community, is that unless new forms of social engagement are developed, our stock of "social capital" (the concept that community networks have an inherent value) will decline and the future for society will be bleak. What's happened in the US?
His research found that Americans are less likely than they were three decades ago to participate in community meetings and organisations. Membership of charities, churches, trade unions, and 10-pin bowling leagues has gone down; families are less likely eat dinner together, know their neighbours or even watch television together. Do we suffer from social breakdown in the same way?
Yes, suspects the professor: "Some evidence suggests that Europe is about to follow the American pattern with a lag of a few decades. Europe may have a social capital 'cold', but not yet the full-blown American 'pneumonia'." A report recently published by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations in the UK found that public involvement in clubs, societies and voluntary activities has declined over the last 10 years. Is this simply nostalgia for a lost way of life?
The professor claims there is a direct link between social involvement and quality of life: communities with high levels of civic engagement have lower crime rates, better schools, lower levels of teen pregnancy, and less child abuse, drug use and juvenile delinquency. Governments are more responsive, honest and efficient, citizens to pay taxes and fulfil other civic obligations. "Connected" people live longer, happier lives. "You tell me how many choral societies there are in an Italian region, and I will tell you plus or minus three days how long it will take you to get your health bills reimbursed by its regional government," Professor Putnam once quipped. Why is Tony Blair so interested?
The theory offers a relatively simple, cheap, organic, perhaps even miraculous solutions to seemingly intractable social ills. It also dovetails nicely with the ideology shared to varying degrees by politicians on both the right and left, that the state should not monopolise the provision of social action programmes, but that faith groups, social entrepreneurs and charities should play more of a role. Does anyone disagree with Prof Putnam?
Public health minister and new Labour rising star Yvette Cooper took him to task for "romancticising" the concept of community in a Downing Street seminar held this week. Some communities can stifle and repress, she reportedly argued: "My grandparents knew their neighbours but they were also absolutely terrified of what the neighbours thought. Social capital can become vested interests, the old boy's network." How does Prof Putnam want to rebuild social capital?
Devolve government decision making down to community and neighbourhood level, introduce family-friendly employment policies to allow people to spend more time with family and friends, and educate youth in "civic responsibilities." You explain the reference to bowling, incidentally?
Prof Putnam uses the decline of 10-pin bowling leagues in the US over the last 25 years as a metaphor for the gradual increase in social isolation. More people go bowling, he says, but they do so alone. "When you participate in a bowling league, interacting regularly with the same people week after week, you learn and practice what de Tocqueville called 'habits of the heart.' You learn the personal virtues and skills that are the prerequisites for a democracy," he said.

fields.headline: Worldwide: What the papers say
fields.standfirst: What the international press is saying on education issues around the world
fields.trailText: What the international press is saying on education issues around the world
fields.body:
So farewell then, Richard Li, financial wunderkind, distinguished graduate of Stanford University, and, at least in the view of some Asian newspapers during this past week, an educational soulmate of Jeffrey Archer.

When news broke last week that one of Hong Kong's greatest internet tycoons had not, as he had previously let it be known, "graduated with a degree in computer engineering" from the elite Californian university, reporters in the region were quick to point out that they were not the only ones ever to have been taken in on the subject of a famous person's academic pedigree.

The South China Morning Post in Hong Kong compared the latest case with the one in Britain involving Lord Archer and his apparent suggestion that he had once studied at Wellington College public school - the one in Berkshire rather than the other one in Somerset - and had a degree from one of the more prestigious American universities. That impression, of course, turned out to be a slight misunderstanding on the part of some reporters.

In the case of Mr Li, whose achievements as the founder of the highly successful Pacific Century CyberWorks have merited comparisons with those of Bill Gates, something of a similar misunderstanding took place, in the view of the newspaper that first broke the story, the International Herald-Tribune. References to the 34-year-old's fictitious Stanford degree had appeared over the years in articles published in the HT itself, the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Economist, Forbes, Time, Asiaweek, the Daily Telegraph, and, alas, the Guardian.

Poetic justice? The Seattle Times reported on another outbreak of educational foot-in-mouth between an internet darling and his favourite West Coast university, this time involving high-tech entrepreneur Ravi Desai and the University of Washington.

According to the newspaper, poets and professors alike, the university last year celebrated the high-profile Mr Desai's pledge of $2m for the school's creative writing programme by throwing a $10,000 party to announce the good news. More than a year on, however, the university has received only $6,770 of the pledge from the 31-year-old Harvard graduate, who really does hold an MBA from the University of Chicago.

And with Mr Desai having now abruptly left the two high-tech companies that were supposed to be funding the programme, the likelihood of ever seeing any more money is dim.

An editorial in The Jamaica Observer took aim, again, at Burchell Whiteman, the island nation's education minister, who earlier this week described the newspaper as unfavourable, confused and destructive in its commentary on local educational issues.

The Caribbean publication had been particularly outspoken on the theme of violence in schools, two of which recently had to suspend classes in Kingston because of death threats against teachers and students. But the fact that the paper highlighted such issues, declared the editorial, "will not cause them to worsen. More likely, it will spur people to solutions. And it is wrong to assume that this newspaper, or the press at large, focuses only on the negatives in education." Mr Whiteman's fulminations, it concluded, could only be described as "the result of fevered imaginings".

An upbeat piece on westernisation in the Middle East? Even as the papers in the region teemed with fury at the worsening violence in Israel, an op-ed piece in the Jordan Times, written by Ahmad Y Majdoubeh, paid fulsome tribute to the modernisation that has taken place at the University of Jordan under the watch of King Abdullah II.

The ruler's One Thousand Computers Project, for example, has made computer use, including internet access, available to all students at the national university. And the institution continues its push for instruction in the English vernacular to receive equal academic billing alongside Arabic, while departments across the university are all taking a more businesslike approach to producing graduates with marketable skills. The University of Jordan is being led "thoughtfully and boldly into spheres and frontiers where no one has ventured before," gushed the writer.

For Michele Tolela Myers, the president of Sarah Lawrence College in upstate New York, however, the end result of chasing such new spheres and frontiers might not hold all that it promises. Writing op-ed in the New York Times this week, Ms Myers lamented academic chatter concerning "brand value, markets, image and pricing strategy", or what she called the new lingua franca of higher education, in which "students are 'consumers of our product' in one conversation or presentation, and 'inputs' - a part of what we sell - in the next."

Educators, she wrote, "must be very careful that in the race to become wealthier, more prestigious, and to be ranked Number One, we don't lose sight of the real purpose of education, which is to make people free - to give them the grounding they need to think for themselves and participate as intelligent members of a free society." Listen up, Mr Li.

webTitle: One thousand new medical places created

fields.headline: One thousand new medical places created
fields.trailText: A thousand more doctors are to be trained annually in England and two new medical schools established, the Higher Education Funding Council for England announced today.
fields.body:
A thousand more doctors are to be trained annually in England and two new medical schools established, the Higher Education Funding Council for England announced today.

Along with the 1,100 extra places created over the past two years, the new places represent a 50% rise in medical school intakes since 1998.

Education and employment minister, Tessa Blackstone, hoped the new places would attract students from a much broader range of social and ethnic backgrounds.

Leeds and Bradford Universities, who collaborated in their bid for more medical placements, said they would recruit students from a broad range of backgrounds, and the University of Birmingham said it will seek to attract increasing numbers of students from local, socially deprived areas.

Further placements have been awarded to the Universities of Newcastle and Durham, which included in their joint bid an access strategy, based at Durham's Stockton campus.

Sir Martin Harris, chairman of Universities UK Health Committee, welcomed the additional places, but warned: "At the same time it's vital to ensure that a medical career is made sufficiently attractive for young - and middle young - people to aspire to it."

The two new schools are collaborations between the Universities of Hull and York and Sussex and Brighton. They follow the establishments last year of the Peninsula Medical School, a collaboration between Plymouth and Exeter Unviversities, and a new school at the University of East Anglia.

Their establishment reflects the government's attempt to spread medical education more evenly across the country, as well as boosting the numbers coming into the health service, the council said. It added that there is evidence that doctors, like trainee teachers, often stay in the area where they train.

Chief medical officer, Professor Liam Donaldson, said the expansions would have an impact on patient care. "New, modern curricula will mean that tomorrow's doctors will be skilled not just in the management and treatment of disease but in communicating with their patients, in assuring the quality of the care they provide, in realising the potential of e-medicine and in helping people to stay healthy."

Additional medical student places allocated in 2001:
University of Birmingham 40
University of Brighton with University of Sussex 128
University of Bristol 80
University of East Anglia 20
University of Hull with University of York 130
University of Leeds with University of Bradford 40
University of Leicester with University of Warwick 100
University of Liverpool 40
University of Manchester with University of Keele 150
University of Newcastle with University of Durham 50
University of Nottingham 90
University of Oxford 10
Peninsula Medical School (Universities of Plymouth and Exeter) 40
Queen Mary, University of London 40
St George's Hospital Medical School 35
University of Southampton 40

fields.headline: Global English: The European Lessons
fields.standfirst: Max de Lotbinière, the editor of Guardian Weekly's Learning English supplement, invites teachers to attend a debate about the role of English in Europe in Brighton on April 18
fields.trailText: Max de Lotbinière, the editor of Guardian Weekly's Learning English supplement, invites teachers to attend a debate about the role of English in Europe in Brighton on April 18
fields.body:
It is estimated that The European Union has over 180 million speakers of English, but English is the "mother tongue" of only a third of that number. For the rest it is either a tool for international communication or their second language - the linguistic equivalent of the business suit, slipped into for official occasions. According to the most recent research, nearly 70% of Europeans believe English should be the foreign language learnt by everyone in the EU*.

However English is being used, the demographics of Europe mean that no single country can claim exclusive sovereignty over the language. So does this mean that English has cut itself free from the ties that bind language to personal and national identity and is Europe mapping out a new relationship with English that could be followed in other world regions?

In a special debate on April 18, staged by Macmillan Heinemann and the Guardian Weekly, a distinguished panel of experts chaired by Will Hutton, chief executive of The Industrial Society, will explore the role of English as Europe Europe's lingua franca. The discussion will weigh the pragmatic benefits of English - a tool both for the EU and individuals - against the damage it can do to linguistic rights and diversity. It will assess how English has been assimilated into Europe and it will analyse how far the language that is being spoken and used in Europe today is distinct from British English.

For the institutions of the EU, a pragmatic decision to follow the prevailing trend and adopt English as its common language could save millions (translation between the 11 languages of the EU consumes a third of the Commission's administrative budget). For business, the prospect of trading in a European market with both a single currency and a single language is compelling (In 1999, 22% of US exports went to EU members, and 19% of US imports originated in EU countries). And for Britain, an "English speaking" Europe could reassure voters fearful of the European "super state", and boost British export of English language teaching products and skills (in 1999 EU nationals spent £345m learning English in Britain).

But these scenarios obscure a more complex picture.

While Europeans accepts the practical necessity of English there is also widespread fear about the damage it might do to their own languages (over 60% of Europeans believe that it is necessary to protect their own languages more as the EU grows*). Yet unless the EU develops an effective policy that gives equal rights to all Europe's languages, and not just 11, language tensions can only increase (Danish and Finnish are included by the EU among the 11 but Catalan is not, in spite of having more speakers than either of these "official" languages).

In business, the cost effectiveness of English for communication has not yet been accurately measured. While pressure on employees to use English mounts, few companies understand what kind of language their staff need or how to train them. And for British business the barriers to communication can only rise unless "native speakers" learn to use the language being developed by their European partners.

Now that most communication in English in Europe is between "non-native speakers" and not with native speakers, who decides what is the right or wrong way to use the language? Britain's English language teaching industry claims to be the arbiter of the language and most Europeans still believe they can learn English best from "native speakers"*, but for how long?

The speakers on the panel are:

Robert Phillipson, research professor at Copenhagen Business School and author of Linguistic Imperialism, the ground-breaking study of global English and language rights, will explore how the EU can appropriate English without being divided by it.

Juliane House, professor of applied linguistics at the University of Hamburg, will challenge the notion of English as a threat to Europe by drawing the distinction between a "language for communication" and a "language for identification".

John Walsh, editor of Eurolang, the Brussels based news agency dealing with minority language issues, will illustrate the link between language, identity and self-esteem and the changing definition of Europe's language minorities.

Barbara Seidlhofer, from Vienna University has begun the task of identifying English as a lingua franca by analysing vast amounts of electronically stored and written and spoken text, and she will reveal what impact this study will have on the way English is taught.

Jennifer Jenkins from King's College London is the author of a controversial new study of the phonology of English used among non-native speakers and she will chart the emergence of a hybrid European accent.

For more information contact Max de Lotbinière, editor Learning English, Guardian Weekly. Tel: 020 7713 4167/020 8969 1139, email: max@delotbiniere.demon.co.uk

*Source: "Europeans and Languages" Eurobarometer Report, February 2001.

webTitle: A day in the life of a teacher in Munich

fields.headline: A day in the life of a teacher in Munich
fields.standfirst: Jo Chaffer discovers plenty of opportunities, but also some drawbacks, to teaching in Munich
fields.trailText: Jo Chaffer discovers plenty of opportunities, but also some drawbacks, to teaching in Munich.
fields.body:
Those for whom Munich conjures up images of beer, bratwurst and the German Oktoberfest, will be in for a surprise. The city is safe, clean and well organised, with good opportunities for earning money, but a high cost of living and the less than friendly locals can make teaching here a sometimes frustrating experience.

6.10am: Rise and shine. Make my way through our tiny, one bed flat to the shower room. All accommodation here is measured in square metres, is very expensive and needs more connections than Don Corleone to find in the first place. Expect to compete with 90 odd other hopefuls, should you get to the viewing stage of responding to a small ad - either that or be prepared to offer a belohnung (bribe) to secure somewhere. I was lucky enough to have a resident boyfriend with a flat that we can just about both squeeze into. We pay 900DM (£284), including bills, per month, which is cheap.

After a quick review of my lesson plan I clip my briefcase onto my bike and start the half an hour cycle along the Isar, Munich's main river, to my first lesson - a one-to-one with a marketing manager at a tobacco company. I work at this company three times a week, all for different language schools, paying different wages. In total, I work for about six different language schools at any one time, juggling two-hour-long business classes with intensive courses for the Volkshochschule (VHS).

Yvonne, my first client, is a fairly typical student. She was brought up in East Germany and therefore learned Russian at school, as opposed to Germans brought up in the West, who will have had at least five years of schooling in English. She self-studied intensively so now has a good speaking level of English, but needs to work on functional, job-specific language for tasks such as presentations - the overlap between language skills and management training can be pretty big sometimes.

Munich, as the second Silicon Valley of Europe, is a rapidly expanding, very wealthy city with a booming new economy sector and a highly profitable, well established traditional sector. Having companies such as GMX, a wealth of soft and hardware firms plus old timers like Siemens, BMW, Philip Morris and a burgeoning pharmaceuticals sector all trading internationally, mean there is a massive requirement for the English language. Because of people like Yvonne, the demand for Business English trainers is huge and there are hundreds of language schools all crying out for qualified native speakers.

If you just turn up here, send your CV off to any of the language schools listed in the Gelbeseiten (yellow pages), or look in the jobs section of Munich Found, an English language journal, expect to be inundated with offers of work almost immediately. The schools vary somewhat in level of support and pay, but you should receive around 40DM per hour. Once you're established and speak some German, you can approach the companies directly and take home up to 120DM per hour. You can also use any of the EFL websites to find a job before you get here, as many schools advertise.

9:00am: The lesson went well, using some resources gleaned from a speaker at the last BESIG conference, held last autumn in Munich. Back on the bike through the traffic jammed streets to my next lesson. Biking is usually the quickest way to travel in the city and quite safe - there are kilometres of well maintained cycle ways and cyclists generally get priority over cars. There's also a fast, clean underground network (the S and U-bahns) which isn't too expensive either, but I prefer the independence of my bike.

9:20am: Head up to my beautiful new multimedia classroom in the VHS buildings. I have a class of 14 elementary adult learners, all highly motivated and enthusiastic, and all from different countries. A first glance around the immaculately dressed, white faces in Marienplatz gives the impression that Munich is not a multicultural city. But a closer listen will reveal Turks, Czechs, Slovaks, Hungarians, Italians, Poles and many other nationalities. Just as well, really, as the Bavarians are not the friendliest folk in the world. Even if you get past the language barrier, you'll find it hard to get a response that isn't grumpy. Unless you're in a beer garden, of course.

12:30pm: A task-based lesson using specially designed course books, all provided by the VHS, that was fun and productive. You are really well looked after as a teacher here: not only are there teacher's book shops galore, but the VHS and many other schools have good libraries to borrow from and there is a teacher's support group - MELTA - which puts on regular seminars and meetings.

1pm: Back home for lunch.

2pm: Time to organise my accounts. Every selbstandig (freelance) teacher has to send off accounts to the Finanzamt up to three times a year to work out your Mehrwertsteuer (VAT) and income tax liability. I would recommend getting a tax lawyer to advise you as paperwork is something of a German speciality and can be daunting. Something to be aware of is the BFA - the state pension scheme - which is demanding teachers now give over 20% of their income for a worthless pension. Also, don't forget you'll need health insurance, which can cost as much as your rent.

4:30pm: Back on the bike to my next lesson with a group at a mortgage bank. From the meeting room you get a great view of the German Alps lying 100km to the south. Munich is a great centre for skiing and other sports. The banks of the Isar and the many parks are always full of joggers, rollerbladers, frisby and football players.

7pm: Back home. This being a long winter evening, the recreational choices aren't so exciting - nights in or drinking with fellow expats in the many Irish bars around the town. Munich has loads of jazz cafes and eateries offering food from all over the globe, but unless you go with someone you may find yourself talking only to your Weissbier all night.

Teaching in Munich can be a lonely business, but there are good opportunities for making money and the city and countryside are beautiful.

fields.headline: OFT challenge on cancellation charges
fields.standfirst: OFT challenge on cancellation charges
fields.trailText: The four leading package holiday operators have been given a fortnight to respond to accusations that their cancellation charges are excessive and unfair, or face legal action from the office of fair trading.
fields.body:
The four leading package holiday operators have been given a fortnight to respond to accusations that their cancellation charges are excessive and unfair, or face legal action from the office of fair trading.

Threats of a legal challenge - which come 16 months after the OFT began its investigation into Thomson Holidays, Airtours, JMC Holidays and First Choice - are unlikely to stop holidaymakers falling victim to hefty can cellation fees this summer.

The OFT claims typical charges vary from 50% of the holiday price if it is cancelled 22-56 days before departure, to a 100% loss if cancelled seven days or fewer before departure. This compares with charges of 50% in Sweden and 60% in Denmark for cancellations within 24 hours of departure.

"There are serious questions about the cancellation charges for package holidays sold in the UK," John Vickers, director-general of Fair Trading, said. "To examine those questions the OFT needs the full facts.

"The tour companies have so far refused to supply information relating to their claim that the level of charges is justified. We are determined to get the relevant information and will take court action if necessary."

Asked why it had taken the OFT 16 months to announce it would be seeking a court order, a spokesman said: "We have been obliged to give the tour operators reasonable time to present their argument before we go to the courts."

The Federation of Tour Operators said the level of cancellation charges was "not a major consumer issue" because most operators require tourists to take out insurance on package trips to resorts such as Benidorm insurance firms.

All four of the targeted tour operators refused to disclose what proportion of cancelled packages are resold. Each said the infor mation was "commercially sensitive". The FTO said British tour operators offered competitive prices which would have to rise if they were required to reduce cancellation charges.

"You either charge the people who are doing the cancellation or you charge everybody," said Martin Brackenbury, chairman of the FTO.

First Choice was the only firm pledging to cooperate with the OFT inquiry yesterday. Others refused to comment.

fields.headline: Panorama host renews call for Sunday switch
fields.trailText:
5pm: Award-winning presenter John Ware has renewed his calls for the current affairs show to be moved from its graveyard Sunday slot. By Lisa O'Carroll.
Mar 30: Broadcasting Press Guild award-winners
Mar 1: Panorama scoops RTS award
Jan 18: Lack of investigative journalism on TV criticised
Oct 16: Panorama popularity slips
fields.body:
Panorama presenter John Ware has renewed his calls for the current affairs show to be moved from its graveyard Sunday night slot.

He said the programme had lost up to 1m viewers since it was moved from Monday night last October and urged BBC director general Greg Dyke to return it to a weekday night.

Mr Ware said the BBC's public service duty to inform and educate as well as entertain would not be fulfilled by documentaries about "dinosaurs and hospitals".

He was speaking after he picked up yet another award for his investigation into the Omagh bombing in Northern Ireland, in which he named those allegedly responsible for the atrocity.

Who Bombed Omagh?, which was the last Panorama programme to go out on a Monday night, was praised as courageous.

"This courage is at odds with the BBC's decision to downgrade the importance of what was, and I would like to think still is, the corporation's flagship programme, by moving it from Monday to Sunday," Mr Ware said.

"This means we have lost 500,000 viewers. We reach on average 500,000 fewer licence payers and in some case we probably reach about 1m fewer," he said at the Broadcasting Press Guild ceremony.

"I just wish there was a ceasefire for just one hour a week in this commercial game that is being played out every night of every week.

"And I just wish the BBC would restore serious current affairs to peaktime. We do not just fulfill that public service role with dinosaurs in primetimes and documentaries about how hospitals and prisons work.

"I hope the BBC will eventually change their mind about it although I am not sure they will," he added.

Who Bombed Omagh? picked up a Royal Television Society award last month and was watched by 4.2m when it was broadcast last October.

Following the move to Monday, ratings plummeted by 1m but BBC bosses have insisted they have no intention of moving the show back to a midweek slot.

 Nick Clarke, presenter of Radio 4's World at One said he was "thrilled" to receive the BPG's award for best Radio Broadcaster of the Year.

"When you go to the Sony Awards you see there are awards for best breakfast show and best drivetime show but there are never any awards for best lunchtime programmes.

"It is an absolute thrill doing the show. I have been doing it permanently since 1994. I never have to tell the time and there is no competition from John Humphrys," he joked.

The programme, which is considered one of the most "awkward" for politicians is to be extended to 45 minutes during the general election."

webTitle: NHS in Wales facing financial crisis

fields.headline: NHS in Wales facing financial crisis
fields.trailText: The NHS in Wales faces severe financial problems, with two-thirds of trusts in deficit, an auditor's report has revealed.
fields.body:
The NHS in Wales faces severe financial problems, with two-thirds of trusts in deficit, an auditor's report has revealed.

The report, by the auditor general for Wales, says the health service was more than £5m in the red for the last financial year, and predicts the deficit will more than double this year.

Based on an in-depth assessment of the 1999-2000 NHS accounts, the report comes as separate audit commission information reveals big variations in performance across Welsh trusts, health authorities and local health groups - the equivalent of primary care groups in England.

The auditor general says that last year, 10 out of the 15 NHS trusts in Wales were in deficit, and three - North East Wales, Carmarthenshire, and Cardiff and Vale - had debts that totalled more than £1m each.

There is still "fundamental uncertainty" surrounding Carmarthenshire trust's current and future financial position.

The report highlights the need for the Welsh national assembly and the NHS directorate to monitor the recovery plans: "It is essential that the assembly officials work with NHS Wales to improve the quality and timeliness of financial information, particularly in determining accurate forecasts of expenditure. This should go some way to enabling NHS Wales to manage its budgets more effectively."

A spokesperson for Jane Hutt, the minister for health and social security, said the minister did not want to comment because the findings have yet to be debated by the assembly's own audit committee.

A Picture of Health from the audit commission was based on a review of the operations of local health, health authorities and NHS trusts. It found significant variations in levels of performance.

The report says that across the 15 trusts in the principality there is a wide variation in critical care bed capacity.

It says there is a clear need for improvements to the way in which district nursing services are managed, resourced and delivered, and points out that district nurses in Wales see fewer patients proportionately than their colleagues in England.

Another key area for attention is the improvement of services for diabetics, with more comprehensive annual checks and improved information being made available.

The report calls for better coordination between health and social services with greater user involvement in service planning and a need to work across professional and organisational boundaries. Better leadership, it says, is likely to lead to a more focused service delivery.

"We found examples of good practice in parts of the services, particularly the improvements in waiting time in accident and emergency for elderly people with hip fractures, but the significant variations in performance need to be addressed," the report said.

The auditor general says that last year, 10 out of the 15 NHS trusts in Wales were in deficit, and three - North East Wales, Carmarthenshire, and Cardiff and Vale - had debts that totalled more than £1m each. There is still "fundamental uncertainty" surrounding Carmarthenshire trust's current and future financial position. The report highlights the need for the Welsh national assembly and the NHS directorate to monitor the recovery plans: "It is essential that the assembly officials work with NHS Wales to improve the quality and timeliness of financial information, particularly in determining accurate forecasts of expenditure. This should go some way to enabling NHS Wales to manage its budgets more effectively." A spokesperson for Jane Hutt, the minister for health and social security, said the minister did not want to comment because the findings have yet to be debated by the assembly's own audit committee. A Picture of Health from the audit commission was based on a review of the operations of local health, health authorities and NHS trusts. It found significant variations in levels of performance. The report says that across the 15 trusts in the principality there is a wide variation in critical care bed capacity. It says there is a clear need for improvements to the way in which district nursing services are managed, resourced and delivered, and points out that district nurses in Wales see fewer patients proportionately than their colleagues in England. Another key area for attention is the improvement of services for diabetics, with more comprehensive annual checks and improved information being made available. The report calls for better coordination between health and social services with greater user involvement in service planning and a need to work across professional and organisational boundaries. Better leadership, it says, is likely to lead to a more focused service delivery. "We found examples of good practice in parts of the services, particularly the improvements in waiting time in accident and emergency for elderly people with hip fractures, but the significant variations in performance need to be addressed," the report said.

fields.headline: Schofield returns to TV after two-year break
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Phillip Schofield is to front BBC1's National Lottery: Winning Lines this summer, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Phillip Schofield will return to TV screens after a two-year break to front BBC1's National Lottery: Winning Lines this summer.

Schofield, whose last TV presenting job is believed to have been on BBC Music Live in 1999, has been concentrating on theatre work with a role in Dr Dolittle.

He will front the BBC1 Saturday-night lottery show when it returns for a third series in June.

"I have been incredibly lucky over the last few years to have been able to fulfill my ambitions in the theatre," said Schofield.

"But now I am looking forward to returning to live television and the BBC to front Winning Lines."

Schofield will also be reunited with Winning Lines producer Celador Productions.

He has previously worked with Celador, the company behind Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, on ITV shows Talking Telephone Numbers and Schofield's TV Gold.

Schofield joined the BBC in 1979 at the age of 17.

He became a children's TV presenting icon, first fronting Children's BBC from the studio dubbed the "broom cupboard" and later working with Emma Forbes on Saturday morning programme Going Live.

fields.headline: Titchmarsh to champion organic gardening
fields.trailText:
5pm: The TV gardener has revealed he quit Ground Force to 'give something back to the soil', writes Claire Cozens.
Mar 29: Titchmarsh quits Ground Force
fields.body:
Alan Titchmarsh has revealed why he is quitting Ground Force after four hugely successful years as the nation's favourite gardener.

The telegenic Titchmarsh, who with co-presenter Charlie Dimmock made Ground Force one of the most watched programmes on the BBC, said he wants to "give something back to the soil".

In his first interview since quitting the show, Titchmarsh said he saw his future in promoting organic gardening and instilling an interest in all things horticultural among children.

"It is time to move on and try different things and I am passionately committed to the idea of organic gardening," he said.

"I think of every little garden as part of a massive patchwork nature reserve, with every gardener doing their bit in the bigger scheme of things."

Titchmarsh has put his name to a new range of organic plant foods.

The proceeds of the products will go towards a fund he is setting up to finance garden projects in primary schools.

webTitle: The right strikers but the wrong mixture

fields.headline: The right strikers but the wrong mixture
fields.trailText: Having earned a bit of breathing space, Sven must ponder his main quandary: what is his most effective strike force?
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson has kept England in the hunt with a pair of hard-fought wins from a couple of tricky games. But having earned a bit of breathing space, Sven must ponder his main quandary: what is his most effective strike force?

His two best scorers are still probably Michael Owen and Andy Cole, but I don't think they can gel as a partnership. They are both top-drawer forwards but they both play most comfortably as the leading striker and can't work effectively together.

Not that either has done his cause any harm. All that criticism of Cole last week was just people jumping on the bandwagon - I remember Gary Lineker and Alan Shearer going a long time without scoring for England - and the goal he slotted away on Wednesday will have taken a lot of pressure off the lad.

It's funny how his luck turned: he'd been booked and knew he was going to be suspended for the trip to Greece, so his confidence must have been shot. Then he popped up with a goal in the last few seconds and suddenly it couldn't have worked out better for him. There wasn't another kick after he tucked the ball away - a really tidy finish, the type of goal I love to see strikers snaffle, close in but clean.

But I don't think it was a coincidence that Cole perked up in the Albania game when Teddy Sheringham came on. He has always done well next to a link striker: a Peter Beardsley at Newcastle, a Sheringham or a Dwight Yorke at Manchester United. He has such great movement but he wants to be twisting and turning into space while the ball is being worked in midfield or with a linkman who can then slip him away with a cunning pass.

Owen, on the other hand, needs a target man up there with him. He's a hell of a finisher, but as a solo striker he doesn't have enough physical presence to be effective. Ask him to fight for balls in the air and he'd be completely bypassed. I know they have been encouraging him to try to drop off a little bit deeper to pick the ball up and link with Cole, something he's tried very hard to do. But he's nowhere near as effective at that as he is when he operates in the predator's area.

It might be time for the England coach to think about more natural combinations of his front men. On the one hand he could throw on a combination of the Liverpool trio: Emile Heskey and Owen or Heskey and Robbie Fowler.

I'm a little bit puzzled about this business of bringing Heskey on to play in wide areas. I know he played there for Leicester a little bit, but he doesn't seem to explode from the flank; he just stands still and passes it. Against Finland he almost played as a right-back; I can understand the principle of trying to play with three strikers and carry the fight to the opposition, but we didn't do that. It's not a system that suits him at all.

The alternative to the Liverpool connection is the Manchester United option. Eriksson could start with Cole alongside Sheringham or Paul Scholes, whom I still fancy as a link striker away from home as he allows you to supplement your midfield with an extra man who would have attacking responsibilities.

Funnily enough, I thought Scholesy ended up as our best player against Albania, but he only came into his own when Sheringham was introduced. Teddy held the ball up and his presence not only encouraged Cole but also Scholes, who had been playing very deep. With someone holding the ball up ahead of him he was able to motor upfield in support and in the last 20 minutes he dominated the game.

He's got very quick feet and links play well, but if the front players keep losing possession, or if the front lads are the type who like to turn and run at defenders, it makes it very difficult for the attacking midfielders to get up in support. They need a stopping-off place up front to give them a chance to eat up the ground.

So, even with Cole suspended for the Greece game, Eriksson has loads of options to explore. Now he can concentrate on fine-tuning his front line as we play catch-up to the Germans.

webTitle: Martin Kelner's screen take on England v Albania

fields.headline: Hoarding trouble for the armchair supporter
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner goes cross-eyed during one of the most surreal televised football games to have hit our screens in recent years.
fields.body:
A great and gratifying result, but a performance that still leaves something to be desired. Not Andrew Cole, but Channel 5, which attracted its biggest crowd so far for Wednesday's England international - a peak of 7.9m on unofficial figures - but left most of them feeling they might have seen almost as much of the action if they had watched it on Radio 5 Live.

Even when you could glimpse a little of the play from whatever surreal angle the Albanian TV director had selected for you, you had to concentrate really hard to avoid being completely distracted by the show being put on by the animated perimeter advertising hoardings.

These rolling, constantly changing electronic hoardings were being seen here for the first time, and came as something of a shock to British football fans, if the calls to Channel 5's switchboard are anything to go by - although from the station's point of view at least they stopped viewers complaining about Jonathan Pearce's commentary for a bit.

The bad news is that these electronic ads are no temporary aberration. The BBC, which is covering the World Cup qualifier from Greece in June, tells me the moving picture show will blight its coverage, too, and there is little it can do about it.

"We don't like them, but we don't have any contractual clout to stop them," a spokeswoman said, "although I gather an FA representative is looking into the possibility that players might be distracted by them, and that might be an avenue through which we could get rid of them from our screens."

The British agency that sells the advertising space, Skyville, insists however that the LCD digital boards are tilted upwards at such an angle that the players could not possibly be affected by them, and that this form of advertising is now in regular use in France and Spain.

So, despite appearances to the contrary, when Rio Ferdinand was caught dreamily surrendering the ball for the Albanians' goal, he was not lost in some sort of reverie wondering why Rainham Steels would choose this expensive medium of advertising, or what the heck the advert reading "I kiss football" was all about. It was just Rio.

It must be worth considering, though, whether a moving ball at pitch level, which is what one of the hoardings incorporated, is entirely appropriate either for spectators or participants.

Maybe the advertising would not have seemed quite so obtrusive had the pictures of the match been better. As Channel 5 never tired of reminding us, it was at the mercy of the Albanian TV director who, judging by some shots he selected - I particularly liked the close-up of the chin of one of the Albanian coaches - had recently been diverted from important work in the nation's coal mines. Either that, or he had been too heavily influenced by the oeuvre of Albania's national hero, Norman Wisdom. That film where Norman carries a big ladder through the streets of London had some strange camera angles in it, if I remember rightly.

"When we do these deals," a Channel 5 spokesman told me, "we are given certain guarantees as to the level of coverage. But at the end of the day it doesn't matter whether you have seven cameras or 20 there if the director's choice of shots is unwise." The station, he said, would tackle the Albanians on the complete absence of replays in the first half. "Albania's a funny country to deal with," he added, in what may turn out to be the understatement of the year.

The BBC, although admitting they can do little about the perimeter advertising, is confident they can avoid similar problems when they broadcast the match from Greece in June.

"We have ordered clips of Greece versus Germany for Football Focus," the spokeswoman said, "and we will be studying them very carefully between now and June to see if there are any suggestions we need to make to them, or whether we need to augment their coverage with our own cameras in any way." Mind you, if all the money has already gone into buying rights to a game, we may just have to put up with what pictures we get. And perhaps we should.

Someone moaned to me that there was no 18-yard camera to determine whether the second Albanian "goal" was offside or not, but in a country struggling to establish a free market economy after years of repressive communism, and with a war on its borders, maybe an 18-yard camera is not a priority.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Style: Profile of designer Stephen Sprouts

fields.headline: American graffiti
fields.standfirst: He has worked with US icons such as Andy Warhol and Debbie Harry, and is one half of the partnership behind this season's must-have accessory.  Charlie Porter meets designer and artist Stephen Sprouse
fields.trailText: He has worked with US icons such as Andy Warhol and Debbie Harry, and is one half of the partnership behind this season's must-have accessory. Charlie Porter meets designer and artist Stephen Sprouse.
fields.body:
Stephen Sprouse is a humble man. Ask him about the calibre of people he has worked with (Andy Warhol, Keith Haring, Debbie Harry) and he claims never to have realised that they are some of the most important image-makers of the 20th century. "Yeah, I suppose so," says the 48-year-old designer and artist at his home in New York. "I've never really thought about that." And so it is with similar lack of ego that Sprouse has collaborated with America's current style leader, Marc Jacobs, to create the must-have accessory of the season, the Louis Vuitton graffiti bag.

Even though the bag is not officially on sale till April, the waiting lists at Louis Vuitton stores worldwide are so long that most shops have stopped taking orders. But this has not stopped the dedicated elite from calling branches around the world, desperate to snap up one of these instant classics. When a few of them made it to the Paris store, they instantly sold out. So when Louis Vuitton sent the bags as presents during the shows in France a couple of weeks ago, the lucky recipients were the envy of the entire fashion pack.

The audacity of the bags, where Sprouse's trademark graffiti is slapped across the traditional LV monogram, shows the complete faith that Louis Vuitton must have in Jacobs. "It seems like they really trust Marc," agrees Sprouse. "It was totally his idea to do it."

The pair met a year ago, after Jacobs decided to use graffiti as the next stage in his successful overhaul of the Vuitton brand, and worked on the collection in both Paris and New York. The bags may have been the most visible part of the collaboration, but Sprouse worked with Jacobs on other pieces for spring/summer 2001, including prints of roses and TV static, meticulously photographed, scanned and then consolidated with outlines from his thick marker pen.

Sprouse, who arrived in New York from Indiana at the age of 16, is unique in fashion - someone who has survived without adhering to the seasonal cycle usually required by the fashion industry. But there is a good reason why he sits out the twice-yearly routine. "I've never had a great business partner," he admits. "I've got some leads. But I guess that's why I do art as well - you can be less of a part of a huge operation. I really admire Marc and the designers that do the collections. It's a major job. Nobody in the movies, nor recording artists, has got to put up with the same time schedules as fashion designers."

So, although his ad hoc approach has meant that there is no Sprouse label, he seems to work best when jumping around between commitments. And over the years this militantly freelance approach has enabled him to work on projects that would have been impossible if he had to design a new line twice a year. In the 70s, while also working as a drawing assistant for the designer Halston, he unwittingly created the look for one of rock's greatest icons, Debbie Harry. "I moved into my friend's building in New York," he remembers. "My friend also rented to Debbie, and Blondie used to rehearse in his front room. The only bathroom and kitchen in the building were on Debbie's floor, so we got to know each other. They were still playing CBGBs, but they asked me to make clothes for her, and suddenly the band got huge."

The outfits, like the video static dress Harry wears in the video for Heart of Glass, helped to build Sprouse's reputation. But it was his friend, the then aspiring photographer Steven Meisel, who brought Sprouse's clothes to the attention of American Vogue. Then, in 1984, Sprouse became friends with Andy Warhol. Eventually, Sprouse plucked up the courage to ask if he could use Warhol's images in his clothing. "Andy was always great to me, a big inspiration and supporter," he says.

"Right before he died, I asked if I could use his camouflage print for my clothes. He'd never actually done it with designers, and he wanted to do it, but he had to get permission. The week before he died, he called and said, 'I spoke to Fred [Hughes, Warhol's business partner]. It's OK to use the camouflage.' And that was the last time I spoke to him." After the success of the camouflage collection, Sprouse obtained the rights from the Warhol Foundation to work with more of Warhol's images, culminating in an acclaimed show in 1998.

Through Warhol, Sprouse became friends with Keith Haring, another New York legend. "When I got to know Andy more, I got know Keith more," he recalls. "I also collaborated with Keith. I got these images from the Bible, I painted them, then he put acetates over and did his thing, then we'd blow them up and silkscreen them on fabric." Some of the pieces were brought out of the archive for a shoot in last month's i-D magazine. Bright, optimistic and luxurious, they feature Haring's famous dancing men boogieing all over clothes made out of green velvet - an encapsulation of everything outrageous and OTT in the 80s.

Now his work with Vuitton is over, Sprouse is concentrating for the moment on his art. He is working on a painting for Nasa, following on from a recent experiment with clothes using images from the Mars Pathfinder. "They're making the space station right now," he says, "and I'm actually waiting for them to send me some more photos, because I want to use current images. It'll probably end up a photo silkscreen with realistic oil painting. And graffiti."

It's a typical on-the-spot Sprouse mix, and the designer plans to continue in this vein, working across all media and making them distinctly his own. "If you put all my stuff beside each other, there'd be something that ties it all together and makes it look like it's mine," he says. "I want to do some more clothes projects, and I'd love to do some cars." What, the whole thing, inside and out?

"Well, I'd like to design the car itself, but I'd settle for the upholstery."

And so it is with similar lack of ego that Sprouse has collaborated with America's current style leader, Marc Jacobs, to create the must-have accessory of the season, the Louis Vuitton graffiti bag. Even though the bag is not officially on sale till April, the waiting lists at Louis Vuitton stores worldwide are so long that most shops have stopped taking orders. But this has not stopped the dedicated elite from calling branches around the world, desperate to snap up one of these instant classics. When a few of them made it to the Paris store, they instantly sold out. So when Louis Vuitton sent the bags as presents during the shows in France a couple of weeks ago, the lucky recipients were the envy of the entire fashion pack. The audacity of the bags, where Sprouse's trademark graffiti is slapped across the traditional LV monogram, shows the complete faith that Louis Vuitton must have in Jacobs. "It seems like they really trust Marc," agrees Sprouse. "It was totally his idea to do it." The pair met a year ago, after Jacobs decided to use graffiti as the next stage in his successful overhaul of the Vuitton brand, and worked on the collection in both Paris and New York. The bags may have been the most visible part of the collaboration, but Sprouse worked with Jacobs on other pieces for spring/summer 2001, including prints of roses and TV static, meticulously photographed, scanned and then consolidated with outlines from his thick marker pen. Sprouse, who arrived in New York from Indiana at the age of 16, is unique in fashion - someone who has survived without adhering to the seasonal cycle usually required by the fashion industry. But there is a good reason why he sits out the twice-yearly routine. "I've never had a great business partner," he admits. "I've got some leads. But I guess that's why I do art as well - you can be less of a part of a huge operation. I really admire Marc and the designers that do the collections. It's a major job. Nobody in the movies, nor recording artists, has got to put up with the same time schedules as fashion designers." So, although his ad hoc approach has meant that there is no Sprouse label, he seems to work best when jumping around between commitments. And over the years this militantly freelance approach has enabled him to work on projects that would have been impossible if he had to design a new line twice a year. In the 70s, while also working as a drawing assistant for the designer Halston, he unwittingly created the look for one of rock's greatest icons, Debbie Harry. "I moved into my friend's building in New York," he remembers. "My friend also rented to Debbie, and Blondie used to rehearse in his front room. The only bathroom and kitchen in the building were on Debbie's floor, so we got to know each other. They were still playing CBGBs, but they asked me to make clothes for her, and suddenly the band got huge." The outfits, like the video static dress Harry wears in the video for Heart of Glass, helped to build Sprouse's reputation. But it was his friend, the then aspiring photographer Steven Meisel, who brought Sprouse's clothes to the attention of American Vogue. Then, in 1984, Sprouse became friends with Andy Warhol. Eventually, Sprouse plucked up the courage to ask if he could use Warhol's images in his clothing. "Andy was always great to me, a big inspiration and supporter," he says. "Right before he died, I asked if I could use his camouflage print for my clothes. He'd never actually done it with designers, and he wanted to do it, but he had to get permission. The week before he died, he called and said, 'I spoke to Fred [Hughes, Warhol's business partner]. It's OK to use the camouflage.' And that was the last time I spoke to him." After the success of the camouflage collection, Sprouse obtained the rights from the Warhol Foundation to work with more of Warhol's images, culminating in an acclaimed show in 1998. Through Warhol, Sprouse became friends with Keith Haring, another New York legend. "When I got to know Andy more, I got know Keith more," he recalls. "I also collaborated with Keith. I got these images from the Bible, I painted them, then he put acetates over and did his thing, then we'd blow them up and silkscreen them on fabric." Some of the pieces were brought out of the archive for a shoot in last month's i-D magazine. Bright, optimistic and luxurious, they feature Haring's famous dancing men boogieing all over clothes made out of green velvet - an encapsulation of everything outrageous and OTT in the 80s. Now his work with Vuitton is over, Sprouse is concentrating for the moment on his art. He is working on a painting for Nasa, following on from a recent experiment with clothes using images from the Mars Pathfinder. "They're making the space station right now," he says, "and I'm actually waiting for them to send me some more photos, because I want to use current images. It'll probably end up a photo silkscreen with realistic oil painting. And graffiti." It's a typical on-the-spot Sprouse mix, and the designer plans to continue in this vein, working across all media and making them distinctly his own. "If you put all my stuff beside each other, there'd be something that ties it all together and makes it look like it's mine," he says. "I want to do some more clothes projects, and I'd love to do some cars." What, the whole thing, inside and out? "Well, I'd like to design the car itself, but I'd settle for the upholstery."

webTitle: Hail the arrival of social work education

fields.headline: Hail the arrival of social work education
fields.trailText: A three-year degree to become a social worker will secure a workforce whose practice is informed by research and underpinned by theory.
fields.body:
The announcement that the qualifying level for social workers in England will be a three-year undergraduate degree, marks a watershed for social work. Together with the establishment of a general social care council and the social care institute for excellence (Scie) the new arrangements for social work education will secure a workforce whose practice is informed by research and underpinned by theory.

It is excellent news for the hundreds of thousands of people that social workers support every day. Service users deserve high standards from social workers and the minimum level of qualification in the UK has fallen below international standards.

The move toward degree-level qualifications, accompanied by a postgraduate route, will put social work on a par with the professions it works closely with such as occupational therapy, physiotherapy and nursing.

However, the announcement, while marking the conclusion of much consultation, debate and lobbying, is also the beginning of more intense discussions involving many stakeholders. A long period of planning blight has been brought to an end. Social work educators and their partner agencies can now collaborate to move the profession forward.

The announcement referred to a "greater emphasis on field experience" and rightly drew attention to the need for the basic qualification to equip social workers to meet the demands of a complex profession. The government has called for evidenced-based or, more accurately, research-informed practice. The UK-wide joint university council social work education committee (SWEC) backs the call and argues that the degree should recognise the increased knowledge base which informs practice and provides opportunities for the integration of research, theory and practice.

Members of SWEC worked closely with higher education watchdog Quality Assurance Agency (QAA) to achieve the benchmark standards - what graduates should know and be able to do - for undergraduate degrees in social work. We would expect that these would provide the starting point for discussions about the content of the degree. While remaining committed to widening access to under-represented groups in the social work profession, SWEC argues that the complexities of practice require the degree to be set at honours level.

But skill development should not occur at the expense of academic learning. In a briefing paper to the Department of Health, SWEC reiterates its commitment to a "3+1" model. This would entail a degree-level qualification that would enable students to demonstrate competence in practice, while a post-degree pre-registration year would ensure they were competent to practice. We recognise that arrangements in Scotland and Northern Ireland may evolve differently.

Emphasis on practice highlights a further concern of for social work educators. There is a recruitment crisis with a shortfall of roughly 40,000 qualified social workers. Qualifying courses have the capacity to increase numbers but this requires three components: that practice-learning opportunities are appropriately resourced; that student fees are set at a level that recognises the more intensive tutoring and skills-based teaching, and that students have appropriate levels of remuneration.

High quality, appropriately supervised opportunities to learn on the job in diverse settings are crucial to the effectiveness of qualifying education and training. The crisis in recruitment and retention of qualified social workers means these are not readily available. Practitioners qualified to supervise practice learning are (understandably) being deployed in core work, such as child protection and community care assessments because of the shortage of qualified frontline staff. SWEC has repeatedly lobbied the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) about student poverty. Recruitment to undergraduate courses has been severely affected by differential levels of funding. Student nurses and trainee teachers get a bursary and are exempt from paying fees, but the DfEE has consistently rejected SWEC's argument that social work students should be similarly treated.

The announcement of degree-level qualifying training offers the opportunity to rectify these and other anomalies in social work education. It is a unique moment for educators, employers, practitioners and service user groups to work together to achieve the modern, integrated high quality public services to which they are all committed.

 Joan Orme is professor of social work at the University of Glasgow and chair of SWEC

webTitle: Israelis kill two in Palestine protest

fields.headline: Israelis kill two in Palestine protest
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli troops have shot and killed two Palestinian men today and wounded more than 30 people as they fired live and rubber bullets into groups of stone-throwers amid large-scale protests against Israel.
fields.body:
Israeli troops have shot and killed two Palestinian men today and wounded more than 30 people as they fired live and rubber bullets into groups of stone-throwers amid large-scale protests against Israel.

Protests swept the West Bank with thousands of Palestinians hurling stones at soldiers and burning Israeli and US flags, as well as effigies of the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, in their weekly "day of rage".

In the West Bank city of Ramallah, Mohammed al-Wawi, 21, was fatally shot in the head, a medical official said. Nineteen-year-old Ayesh Zamel was also killed by a bullet to the head during unrest in the city of Nablus, according to a hospital official.

In Israel's Arab communities, thousands took to the streets peacefully to mark 'Land Day', a symbol of Israel's 1.2m-strong Arab community's struggle for equality. Land Day is the annual commemoration of 1976 protests against land expropriation in which six Israeli Arabs were killed by police.

Today's protests capped a violent week of suicide bombings, shootings and rocket attacks that killed three Israelis and eight Palestinians. In response to the violence, the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and Mr Sharon both said the violent confrontation was likely to continue for some time.

In the Gaza Strip, 30 gunmen from Mr Arafat's Fatah group led a large march, firing in the air and chanting "Sharon, wait, Fatah is going to open your grave in Gaza".

One of the gunmen, Mohammed Musallam, who was carrying a Kalashnikov assault rifle, said attacks against Israel would continue. "If Sharon thinks for a second to reoccupy the Palestinian areas, he should prepare black bags for the remains of his soldiers," he said.

Mr Mussallam was responding to warnings by Israel's defence minister, Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, that Israeli soldiers would enter Palestinian-controlled areas if necessary.

Asked about chasing militants into Palestinian territory, he said Israel would send forces to "any place we feel... is endangering us."

In the West Bank town of Nablus, 10,000 demonstrators took to the streets. Several thousand then broke away, marching toward an Israeli checkpoint where they threw stones, drawing rubber bullets and tear gas.

In the Israeli Arab town of Sakhnin, thousands of Arabs and some Jews joined Land Day commemorations. Residents said that since the 1976 round of expropriations that sparked the initial protests, more land has been taken.

"Now the fight is about the land we have to live on, our houses. It has arrived at our bedrooms. It's about the last meter," said one of the marchers, Fakri Abu-Raya, 40.

At the most sensitive spot of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the Al Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem, more than 100 Palestinians threw stones at Israeli police who responded with tear gas and rubber bullets.

webTitle: Comment: US court rules in favour of anti-abortion site

fields.headline: Caught in freedom's net
fields.standfirst:
A US court verdict allowing an anti-abortion website to publish what many believe is a 'hit list' of doctors is a step too far for freedom of speech, argues Victor Keegan
More net news
fields.trailText: A US court verdict allowing an anti-abortion website to publish what many believe is a 'hit list' of doctors is a step too far for freedom of speech, argues Victor Keegan.
fields.body:
One of the greatest attractions of the internet is that it provides a platform for anyone, big or small, articulate or inarticulate, to state their views free from censorship by government, corporations or institutions. It is a freedom that should not lightly be diluted and, should be defended to the hilt: nearly all of the time.

But no one should pretend that the web is an ethics-free zone in which normal moral judgments can be suspended. The fact that it is difficult to draw the line between what is acceptable and what isn't, doesn't mean that there isn't a line to be drawn. The decision of a federal appeals court in San Francisco upholding the right of anti-abortion groups to publish what many people believe is a "hit list of doctors" performing abortions comes into this grey area.

Of course, the court is right to start from the first amendment to the constitution guaranteeing free speech, but that doesn't mean you can say anything about anyone without reference to the consequences.

In this case three of the seven doctors murdered in the past 10 years have been mentioned on the "hit list" and there have been a further 17 attempted murders. Many doctors terminating unwanted pregnancies are forced to wear disguises and bullet proof vests against an intimidating background that has led to a sharp drop in medical students studying the subject - with all that that entails for a revival of backstreet abortionists in the future.

Anti-abortionist have every right to their views and every right to promulgate them as much as they like on the web and elsewhere. But they have no right - and especially not in the guise of being "pro-life" - to publish a list that could lead to the death of a fellow human being carrying out an operation that is supported by the majority of public opinion.

Once again - as in the constitution's right to bear arms - there is too much emphasis on "freedom to" and not enough on "freedom from".

victor.keegan@theguardian.com

webTitle: Why Britain needs a fixed term parliament

fields.headline: Why Britain needs a fixed term parliament
fields.standfirst: The prime minister should not be able to dictate when the country goes to the polls, argues Tony Wright, chairman of the public administration select committee in the Commons
fields.trailText: The prime minister should not be able to dictate when the country goes to the polls, argues Tony Wright, chairman of the public administration select committee in the Commons.
fields.body:
What we have now, with the governing party deciding when to go to the country, is both bizarre and an anachronism almost unique in the world. I think only Canada gives their government the same privilege.

Of course choosing your own date to go to the country gives the prime minister of the day a huge inbuilt advantage. For example, before the chancellor, Gordon Brown, gave the Bank of England independence, the government could rig the electoral cycle to dole out the goodies just before a general election.

But even now it should be the basic building block of a civilised and democratic constitution that we, the voters, elect our rulers for a fixed term. Since the second world war, most parliaments have lasted about four years, and so what I am proposing, in my fixed-term parliament bill, is that we make that the norm.

Unfortunately, it stands no chance of becoming law, but I think most MPs know it will happen eventually, it's just a question of when. It was even a Labour party policy until as recently as 1992.

I've actually had a letter from the Home Office telling me that if it was ever to become law, it would require the written permission of the Queen, because it gives parliament back the power of dissolution, which at the moment is the prerogative of the Queen. That raises questions about the sovereignty of parliament, but those are issues for another time.

One of the strongest reasons for pushing the case now is we have fixed terms for the Scottish parliament and for the Welsh assembly - a sensible starting point when creating a democratic structure from scratch.

If this were replicated in Westminster it would eliminate the shadow boxing we have at present between the parties simply about the date of an election, rather than the issues.

People have said to me that having fixed-term parliaments would make it difficult to get rid of governments, but motions of no confidence would still be allowed and if the government lost they would have to call a new election within a week.

And if we had fixed terms now, none of this rumpus over calling an election during the foot and mouth crisis would be a problem for Mr Blair.
