webTitle: Emma Brockes interview Guardian journalist David McKie

fields.headline: 'One of the great journalists of our time'
fields.standfirst:
Guardian columnist David McKie retires this week after 35 years on the paper. Guardian writer Emma Brockes, named Young Journalist of the Year at the 2001 British Press Awards, talked to him about his career

Audio: hear Emma Brockes interview David McKie
fields.trailText: Guardian columnist David McKie retires this week after 35 years on the paper. Guardian writer Emma Brockes, named Young Journalist of the Year at the 2001 British Press Awards, talked to him about his career.
fields.body:
When David McKie was growing up in Leeds, what mattered in life was reported in the Yorkshire Post. The Guardian, then Manchester based, existed for him as a leftwing paper on the wrong side of the Pennines. "The Post had lots about Yorkshire cricket in it" he says, "which I knew to be the most important subject in the world."

It wasn't until he was studying at Oxford in 1957 that his priorities changed. It was the time of the Suez crisis and McKie and his fellow students turned to the Guardian to articulate their unease. "It told us that we were quite right in thinking that this was an immense wickedness and a huge piece of incompetence. From then, I always wanted to work for the Guardian."

David McKie retires this week after working for the paper for 35 years and occupying every position from junior reporter to assistant news editor to Peter Preston's deputy during some of the paper's toughest times. He is known presently to readers as a political columnist and the author of the devilish weekly dispatch, Smallweed.

"He is amazingly knowledgeable on a huge range of subjects," says Alan Rusbridger, the editor. "He is painstakingly fair to people. He is fantastically punctilious about details and accuracy and he writes like a dream. There is no job in journalism that he can't do better than anyone else. He has never won a prize, but he is one of the great journalists of our time."

McKie's first day in the newsroom was on October 4 1965. The paper was 12 pages thick, cost five old pence and if you found a photograph you had reason to celebrate. McKie was given an underwhelming salary of £1,750 a year.

"They rather took the view, that if you worked for the Guardian, it was a terrific privilege and did you really expect to be paid as well? So they paid starvation rates. But if you wanted to work for a paper that was left of centre and cherished writing, then there was nowhere else you wanted to go."

His ambition was to become a political reporter and he eventually achieved it after serving time on the news and features desks. To McKie, politics represented the exact mix of the serious and the wacky that made his own writing so powerful.

"Having employed the term 'bog standard' last week," he wrote recently, in a needle sharp column, "I am now assailed with requests to explain what it means. I shall answer this in one brusque and immaculate sentence: I haven't the slightest idea."

To staff, he represents everything that justifies the peculiar loyalty that the Guardian inspires. The biggest challenge of his career came in the early 80s, with the formation of the SDP and the subsequent split, within the Guardian office, of those wanting to support it and those loyal to the ailing Labour party.

"I remember David Owen came up to me at a party conference and denounced the Guardian. 'Say what you like about the Daily Mail,' he said, 'at least it knows what side it's on.' And I said, 'we know what side we're on, we're on our side.' We're not here to be on the Labour party's side, we're not here to be on the SDP's side, we're here to define our own terms, approve those parties that come close and disapprove the rest.'"

He is the standard to which we all aspire.

David McKie retires this week after working for the paper for 35 years and occupying every position from junior reporter to assistant news editor to Peter Preston's deputy during some of the paper's toughest times. He is known presently to readers as a political columnist and the author of the devilish weekly dispatch, Smallweed. "He is amazingly knowledgeable on a huge range of subjects," says Alan Rusbridger, the editor. "He is painstakingly fair to people. He is fantastically punctilious about details and accuracy and he writes like a dream. There is no job in journalism that he can't do better than anyone else. He has never won a prize, but he is one of the great journalists of our time." McKie's first day in the newsroom was on October 4 1965. The paper was 12 pages thick, cost five old pence and if you found a photograph you had reason to celebrate. McKie was given an underwhelming salary of £1,750 a year. "They rather took the view, that if you worked for the Guardian, it was a terrific privilege and did you really expect to be paid as well? So they paid starvation rates. But if you wanted to work for a paper that was left of centre and cherished writing, then there was nowhere else you wanted to go." His ambition was to become a political reporter and he eventually achieved it after serving time on the news and features desks. To McKie, politics represented the exact mix of the serious and the wacky that made his own writing so powerful. "Having employed the term 'bog standard' last week," he wrote recently, in a needle sharp column, "I am now assailed with requests to explain what it means. I shall answer this in one brusque and immaculate sentence: I haven't the slightest idea." To staff, he represents everything that justifies the peculiar loyalty that the Guardian inspires. The biggest challenge of his career came in the early 80s, with the formation of the SDP and the subsequent split, within the Guardian office, of those wanting to support it and those loyal to the ailing Labour party. "I remember David Owen came up to me at a party conference and denounced the Guardian. 'Say what you like about the Daily Mail,' he said, 'at least it knows what side it's on.' And I said, 'we know what side we're on, we're on our side.' We're not here to be on the Labour party's side, we're not here to be on the SDP's side, we're here to define our own terms, approve those parties that come close and disapprove the rest.'" He is the standard to which we all aspire. More by David McKie Article archive

webTitle: EU dismay as Bush reneges on Kyoto

fields.headline: EU dismay as Bush reneges on Kyoto
fields.standfirst:
Blair seeks 'constructive' talks as world denounces decision to put US trade before global climate

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: European Union leaders reacted with open dismay yesterday to the confirmation of President George Bush's decision to withdraw support for the Kyoto climate change agreement. Green Euro-MPs immediately called on consumers to boycott US oil companies.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Julian Borger in Washington
fields.body:
European Union leaders reacted with open dismay yesterday to the confirmation of President George Bush's decision to withdraw support for the Kyoto climate change agreement. Green Euro-MPs immediately called on consumers to boycott US oil companies.

Margot Wallstrom, the EU's environment commissioner, said she was "extremely concerned and disappointed" and would fly to Washington next week to try to keep the US involved in the war against greenhouse gas emissions.

Ms Wallstrom hinted at trouble if the US refused to attend talks due in Bonn in July. She stopped short of threatening to impose EU trade sanctions, but insisted that the US withdrawal from the treaty would distort fair transatlantic competition.

"Why should we put European businesses under such high pressure and let American companies off the hook," she said. "Why should they play by other rules?

"The EU is willing to discuss details and problems - but not scrap the whole protocol."

Richard Boucher, a US state department spokesman, said: "Our current plan is to attend that Bonn meeting. So I would expect that we will be working on it before then."

But neither Mr Boucher nor other state department officials would specify what shape the Bonn talks would take, and whether US delegates would insist on negotiating from scratch, without reference to the Kyoto agreement.

The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said he would express his concern at yesterday's White House meeting with Mr Bush. But at a press call before the meeting Mr Bush was unrepentant.

"We have an energy shortage. I look forward to explaining this today to the leader of Germany as to why I made the decision I made," he said.

"We'll be working with Germany. We'll be working with our allies to reduce greenhouse gases, but I will not accept a plan that will harm our economy and hurt American workers."

In London, Tony Blair - always vulnerable to EU criticism that he is too close to Washington - was said to want to "engage constructively" with the US and others to try to find a way forward.

A spokesman said: "The prime minister is concerned because, obviously, he believes that climate change is a very serious problem which we need to tackle.

"He believes ... it is important that we reach an agreement to deal with a problem which is global.

"Obviously the next opportunity to do that will be in Bonn in July and I think he will then personally see President Bush at the G8 summit. But we believe that a way forward is still possible."

EU member states regard Mr Bush's position on global warming as part of a pattern of US withdrawal from multilateral action, citing Washing ton's stance on landmines, the nuclear test ban treaty, UN dues, the international criminal court and other issues.

The US is already at odds with the EU over the "son of star wars" national missile defence scheme, Nato and the European rapid reaction force, hormone-fed beef, genetically modified crops, and banana quotas.

European officials had been encouraged by Mr Bush's campaign promise to impose limits on carbon dioxide emissions. But he withdrew the promise earlier this month.

So far none of the bigger European countries has ratified the Kyoto protocol. but the EU believes it is the best framework for tackling climate change. It will come into force only when it has been ratified by 55% of the industrialised countries which signed it.

"It is possible without the US but it is much more difficult," Ms Wallstrom said. "Its about credibility and political will."

Mr Bush's decision is a particular blow to Sweden, which has made the environment one of the top priorities of its six-month tenure of the EU presidency.

Last weekend's Stockholm summit warned Mr Bush to think again about Kyoto.

In London, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, said Mr Bush's announcement was "exceptionally serious", but he did not think sanctions against the US were the answer.

"The fact is, we do have a lot of leverage," he said. "I certainly don't think we should despair or try to ostracise the US as a pariah."

Japan and Pacific island states threatened by rising seas condemned the decision, and the Australian environment minister, Robert Hill, said: "The Kyoto protocol wouldn't work without the United States."

The European parliament's environment committee said in a statement: "Europe must stand up to irresponsible US policies by rejecting them at the petrol pump. Unless the US rethinks its position, direct boycott is the only language they will understand."

fields.headline: Salmon revamps BBC sports
fields.trailText:
3pm: BBC sports chief Peter Salmon is to focus on football and boxing in his efforts to expand the corporation's coverage, writes Amy Vickers.
Mar 16: Salmon unveils sports strategy
fields.body:
Peter Salmon, the BBC's sports chief, is to focus on football and boxing in his efforts to expand the BBC's sports coverage.

Two features of the weekend sports show Grandstand will be hived off into separate programmes to boost their profile and give BBC sports programmes a greater presence on electronic programme guides, the corporation announced today.

The two shows, Football Focus and Football Final Score, will top and tail sporting events screened on Grandstand.

At the same time, Grandstand is to receive an as-yet-undisclosed "cash injection" to allow it to buy up live sports rights and bolster its programming.

And the BBC is to restructure the division into seven departments, each headed by a senior figure.

Mr Salmon's deputy Niall Sloane will head up football and boxing; Gordon Turnbull has been confirmed as head of radio; Andrew Thompson will head up new media, sports news and development; and Dominic Coles will oversee rights negotiations.

The department is to recruit a further three bosses to cover major events, programmes and planning, and general sports beyond football and boxing.

Other areas Mr Salmon is keen to exploit include interactive media and partnerships with key rights holders in tennis, golf, rugby, racing, snooker and athletics.

Earlier this month it emerged the BBC was close to securing the TV rights to England's autumn home rugby union internationals.

This will be a certain morale booster to the battered sports department, which has suffered a series of devastating rights losses over the past few years.

The restructure of the department is Mr Salmon's first major announcement since he took over the job last year.

He will reveal further details of his strategy for the department in six weeks.

fields.headline: Tory u-turn on asylum broadcast
fields.standfirst:
The leaked documents
Page 1
Page 2
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe last night admitted the Conservative party has dropped plans to run an election broadcast depicting eastern Europeans attempting to enter Britain. By Richard Moriarty.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe last night admitted that the Conservative party has dropped plans to run an election broadcast depicting a group of eastern Europeans attempting to enter Britain.

Plans for the broadcast, which was to be filmed from March 26 to April 1 at a cost of £1000, were unveiled on the Guardian Unlimited Politics website earlier this week after a fax was leaked.

Miss Widdecombe's comments were backed-up by Conservative central office this morning.

The document showed that the director of the broadcast, Paul de Freitas, was seeking a "French looking" barman, and an unspecified number of "eastern European" speaking actors aged between 25 and 70.

But last night on the BBC's Question Time programme, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said the broadcast had been dropped.

Responding to a question about the broadcast, Miss Widdecombe said: "I am assured we have no intention of deploying such a broadcast."

Today, a Conservative spokesperson told Guardian Unlimited Politics that the broadcast was never going to be to be shown.

He said: "The broadcast was never going to be done. The idea was put to us by our ad agency which we then scrapped."

But in the four days since Guardian Unlimited first revealed the leaked documents, Conservative central office had refused to deny details of the broadcast.

And when asked at what stage central office decided not to proceed with the broadcast, the spokesperson was unable to give a date.

Last night, the shadow home secretary did admit that the Tories would use the issue of asylum during the election campaign.

Ms Widdecombe said: "Quite obviously we will be raising the issue, and I make no apology for it, of the control of our aslyum and immigration system in the course of the campaign, but not through those means."

fields.headline: Mandelson wants regional assemblies
fields.trailText: The former Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, has told Guardian Unlimited exclusively of the reasoning behind his call for Labour to make a manifesto commitment on holding referendums for regional assemblies.
fields.body:
The former Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, has told Guardian Unlimited exclusively of the reasoning behind his call for Labour to make a manifesto commitment on holding referendums for regional assemblies.

He said: "In this case I think regional politics needs to catch up with regional economics and that's why I'm advocating a major step forward in regional government, at least for the north-east.

"A decentralised knowledge economy needs decentralised political structures to support it.

"People ask what you can do if you are a backbench MP - well, there are lots of issues you can take up and much debate you can begin and contribute to."

Mr Mandelson, the MP for Hartlepool, broke his self-imposed silence since his departure from the cabinet in January, to highlight the wealth gap between the south-east of England and the rest of the country.

Speaking in a lecture at Hartlepool college, Mr Mandelson said: "Some argue that there is no longer a regional problem in the UK - only a problem with areas of greater economic and social difficulties within regions.

"Certainly there are sharp differences in performance between communities within the north-east region. But the statistics show that a large performance gap between regions remains.

"London and the south-east is the richest region in the European Union, admittedly with its own pockets of poverty and social exclusion - but in every other part of the United Kingdom standards of living are below the European average."

That view was strongly contested by the prime minister in a speech in December 1999, when he declared the economic gaps within regions were as great as those between them.

On the potential role for elected regional authorities, Mr Mandelson said previously he was cautious about regional government - but his viewpoint had now changed.

He believes elected authorities would have the democratic legitimacy to shape policy, would be sharply focused on regional needs, and could take responsibility for developing regional infrastructure.

The authority, made up of an elected element chosen by proportional representation as well as appointed industrialists, trade unionists, educationalists, bankers and venture capitalists, could assume responsibility for police, fire and ambulance services.

Mr Mandelson suggested the regional authority might also nominate a small executive and first minister.

The MP told his audience: "This new arrangement could only operate after being approved by a regional referendum held during the course of the next parliament ... I believe that if we make provision for such regional referenda in the Labour party's general election manifesto, the north-east should go ahead and hold one early in the next parliament."

Mr Mandelson summed up his argument by saying: "A regional authority, as I envisage such a body, is a strategist, galvaniser, advocate and manager rolled into one."

The Tory spokesman for the regions, Tim Loughton, criticised Mr Mandelson's call for regional authorities.

He said: "The true reason why Mr Mandelson wants regional assemblies is that it will help pave the way for the creation of a 'Europe of the Regions'. Labour and their Liberal Democrat cronies want to undermine our national identity and Balkanise Britain.

"Labour have said that regional assemblies will mean the abolition of shire counties. If Peter Mandelson gets his way, the forthcoming county council elections will be the last in England's history."

fields.headline: Maxwell says sorry
fields.trailText:
3pm update: Kevin Maxwell has apologised for his role in the Mirror Group scandal, reports Dan Milmo.
DTI summary (PDF file)
Mar 30: Never again, says FSA
Mar 30: DTI slams Maxwell and Goldman
Mar 30: Report 'lacks moral courage' The Maxwell drama: the key players
From the archives: Maxwell dies at sea
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell, the son of disgraced tycoon Robert Maxwell, has apologised for his role in the Mirror Group scandal.

He spoke after a Department of Trade and Industry report said he bore "heavy responsibility" for the events that led to the collapse of his father's media empire and robbed Mirror employees of their pensions.

"I accept my share of the responsibility for the corporate disaster that befell my father's business. I live with its aftermath every day in terms of people's reaction to me as an individual in both my private and professional lives," he said.

Mr Maxwell was acquitted of fraud at a trial in 1996, during which he was accused of using Mirror Group pension funds to pay off bankers.

"I regret profoundly the impact on all those affected by the collapse of my father's business," he added.

He said he was "sorry" to all those who had suffered.

Kevin Maxwell now runs the Telemonde communcations company, which has recently clashed with financial regulators in the US and has been delisted from the New York stock exchange.

fields.headline: How Saints announced the news
fields.trailText: Statement from chairman Rupert Lowe:
fields.body:
Statement from chairman Rupert Lowe:

"The board of Southampton Football Club are pleased to announce the appointment of Stuart Gray as manager of the club until the end of the season. Dennis Rofe will assist Stuart as first-team coach.

"At the end of this season the situation will be reviewed and the long-term management solution will be addressed.

"The success of the team this season, and in particular since Christmas, results from the excellence of our players under the guidance of an enlightened staff in which Stuart Gray and Dennis Rofe have played a key role. We believe this formula should be preserved and indeed improved upon over the remaining nine games of this season.

"It will be an exciting period with much to play for, not least a possible European place.

"The game against Ipswich Town Football Club on Monday is now the main focus and will allow the Saints to show the football world that we intend to march on with purpose."

fields.headline: Telecoms firm hires new marketing boss
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Thus has appointed a former NTL executive as board-level marketing chief, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Thus, formerly Scottish Telecoms, has appointed former NTL executive Jim Reid to be its new board-level marketing chief.

Mr Reid joins on April 2 as executive director, sales and marketing.

He will take responsibility at board level for all of the company's sales and marketing activities above marketing director Cynthia Gordon and head of branding Pauline Knox.

Previously, Mr Reid was business development director at management consultancy Trinity Horne Consulting.

Before that he was director of customer services for NTL.

Prior to working at NTL he was director of customer services for Alliance & Leicester responsible for all customer services and account development functions within the bank.

He has also held several other senior sales and marketing roles at Mercury Communications, IBM and Powerhouse Communications.

"Jim's appointment is a further demonstration of our commitment to the growing importance of sales and marketing to the development and future success of Thus following completion of our national network roll-out," said Bill Allan, chief executive of Thus.

Thus operates Demon Internet and is majority owned by Scottish Power.

fields.headline: New Media Markets
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 23
fields.trailText: March 23: Advertisers scaling back campaigns on ITV will also cut down on the amount they spend on pay-TV channels.
fields.body:
Advertisers scaling back campaigns on ITV will also cut down on the amount they spend on advertising on pay-TV channels.

ONdigital is considering calling its premium sports channel ITV Sport.

A satellite channel aimed at 16- to 24-year-olds is set to launch to UK viewers on April 12.

The first set-top boxes incorporating the multimedia home platform developed by the Digital Video Broadcasting Group are expected to be unveiled at the IFA consumer electronics fair in Berlin in August.

Beca TV, the cultural and educational channel launched last year by the Planeta publishing group, will introduce a range of interactive services in April.

webTitle: Council byelections send mixed message to Labour

fields.headline: Council byelections send mixed message to Labour
fields.trailText: Labour's shock gain in the latest council byelections could tip the balance in favour of a May 3 general election - despite a mixed message from other results.
fields.body:
Labour's shock gain in the latest council byelections could tip the balance in favour of a May 3 general election - despite a mixed message from other results.

Labour candidate Peter Ward chalked up a landslide 23.9% swing to take a Larches seat at Preston borough, Lancashire.

This could give Tony Blair enough encouragement to take the plunge for May despite the foot and mouth crisis.

Elsewhere the omens were not so good for Labour. The Tories benefited most from a Plaid Cymru collapse to retain a seat in the previous four-way marginal Rhiw seat at Conwy county borough, North Wales.

This is in the knife-edge Clwyd West constituency where Labour was ahead of Conservatives by just 4.6% at the general election and 3% at the 1999's Welsh assembly polls.

Labour also saw its majority slashed by the Christian Peoples Alliance at at Beckton, Newham borough, east London in a campaign which focused on housing issues.

There were just three comparable results this week, too few to make a nationwide projection. But analysis of 15 wards throughout the whole of March suggests the Tories are 6.6% ahead. It could be that many Labour abstainers in the council contests will turn out for a general election.

However a projection based on local authority byelections in April 1997 suggested a 12.5% margin for Labour - only 0.5% less than it won on May 1 1997.

fields.headline: Government delays decision on vaccination
fields.standfirst:
« PM visits disease-hit Dumfries
« No decision yet on election date
« Bishops call for poll delay

Special report: foot and mouth disease

Sign up for our daily foot and mouth email
fields.trailText:
« PM visits disease-hit Dumfries
« No decision yet on election date
« Bishops call for poll delay Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.body:
The government is to delay a decision on a vaccination "firebreak" to try to control the spread of foot and mouth, Downing Street said today.

A spokesman for the prime minister said that a decision on an inoculating livestock was now unlikely to be reached before Monday. Only yesterday, Downing Street said that a decision would be made within 48 hours whether to press ahead with a mass vaccination programme.

Tony Blair, who today met farmers and local experts combating the outbreak in Dumfries, today also refused to indicate the likely date of the general election, saying his current priority was to concentrate on eradicating foot and mouth. "I have nothing more to say on that than I have said before," he said during his visit to Dumfries and Galloway, where all but two of Scotland's 99 confirmed cases are located.

"My priority is to concentrate on making sure we get on top of, control, and eradicate this disease and making sure we get a decent future for farmers."

Mr Blair was speaking after the Archbishop of York led senior Church of England clergy in urging the government not to hold the general election until the autumn because of the crisis.

The Right Rev David Hope said there was a "very strong feeling" in the farming community that the election should not go ahead while many people would in effect be disenfranchised.

A spokesman for the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, also said "serious thought" should be given to the fact that movement was restricted in many parts of the country, but stopped short of calling for a delay.

Meanwhile in London the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, met Ben Gill, the president of the National Farmers' Union and other farmers' leaders to press home the case for a vaccination cordon to halt the spread of foot and mouth.

Mr Blair was joined by Scotland's first minister, Henry McLeish, the Scottish secretary, Helen Liddell, and the Scottish rural affairs minister Ross Finnie in his tour of Dumfries and Galloway.

The group was also meeting representatives from the local council and the army fighting to control the disease.

Yesterday the Tory leader, William Hague, visited Lockerbie, in the Borders, as the army started to dispose of thousands of carcasses in a mass burial site.

Mr Hague told around 50 people at a meeting in Lockerbie that more needed to be done to speed up the cull and the payment of compensation and financial relief to businesses affected.

South of the border in Cumbria, England's hardest hit county, an army spokesman said this morning that the disposal of animal carcasses at Great Orton airfield near Carlisle was progressing well.

Major Guy Richardson said 50,000 animals had been buried at the site since the beginning of the week.

An abattoir in Carlisle has just been reopened to assist in the cull of sheep, he said.

In mid-Wales, 70 soldiers were deployed today to prepare the Ministry of Defence site for the burial of culled livestock.

An army spokesman said civilian contractors had been brought in to start digging trenches and the soldiers were fencing off the site, at Epynt Mountain, on the Sennybridge firing range near Brecon.

webTitle: Gender equity is crucial to parental leave

fields.headline: Gender equity is crucial to parental leave
fields.standfirst: So long as women take the prime responsibility for child care in the home they are never going to be able engage fully as equal citizens in the labour market
fields.trailText: Ruth Lister: So long as women take the prime responsibility for child care in the home they are never going to be able engage fully as equal citizens in the labour market.
fields.body:
The Department of Trade and Industry is considering responses to its green paper, Work and Parents: Competitiveness and Choice. But announcements on some of the options canvassed were made in the Budget before the consultation period had even ended. Maternity pay and leave was increased and two weeks' paid paternity leave was introduced.

Welcome as these changes are, they raise questions about the seriousness of the consultation process and the green paper itself.

One of the reasons for setting up the review of support for working parents in the first place was growing pressure to rethink the decision to introduce parental leave on an unpaid basis. Yet readers of the green paper are told: "The government does not want to reopen the debate around the regulations on parental leave at this stage."

The invitation to submit views on paid parental leave is qualified by the observation that "the costs of introducing paid parental leave are considerable for both the state and employers." The belief of employers that it is not just financial reasons that prevent working parents taking parental leave is treated as a clinching argument.

In a post-Budget comment featured on SocietyGuardian.co.uk - A role model for parental leave - Sanjiv Sachdev makes the case for paid parental leave in the context of the UK's disgraceful child poverty levels and the needs of public sector workers.

I want to do so from a different perspective - that of gender equity, also an important principle for public (and private) sector staff.

Curiously, gender equity was not one of the objectives listed in the green paper. If it had, it might have been more difficult to ignore the pressing case for paid parental leave, which is as much about encouraging fathers to take the leave as it is about supporting mothers.

My own response to the green paper - in reply to the government's consultation process - written with professors Jane Lewis and Jane Millar, argued: "Our research and reading of the cross-national evidence have convinced us that the role of fathers is crucial to the promotion of gender equity and the full and equal citizenship of women. So long as the division of responsibilities for family care is so skewed between women and men, women are not going to be able to achieve genuine labour market equality, despite their much increased economic activity."

As Mr Sachdev notes, only a tiny percentage of eligible fathers is making use of the new unpaid parental leave provision. Indeed, according to a recent survey by the Parental Leave Campaign, not many mothers are either - largely because they cannot afford to.

If we look to Europe (which our government could usefully do rather more), we find that the great majority of our neighbours provide paid leave. Moreover, all the evidence shows that for fathers to take the leave it has to be paid at a high percentage of their previous earnings.

A period designated for fathers also helps. In Norway, the introduction of a "daddy month" - leave that only the father can take - triggered a rapid increase in take-up among eligible fathers to around 70%. (If a father doesn't take the daddy month, it's not transferable to the mother, so is lost.) Of course, for a daddy month to be feasible, the period of parental leave would have to be longer than the stingy three months in total (for each child) allowed in Britain. And the inflexible rule, peculiar to the UK, that limits parental leave to a maximum of four weeks a year per child, should be scrapped.

Unfortunately, a daddy month is not considered as an option here, probably because there is still a suspicion of what is seen as "interfering" in couples' private decisions about work and care. Yet, such private decisions continue to have considerable consequences for women's public position.

So long as women take the prime responsibility for child care in the home they are never going to be able engage fully as equal citizens in the labour market.

fields.headline: MediaCentral.com set to swallow Inside.com
fields.trailText: 3pm: US media website Inside.com is on the verge of being snapped up by a rival, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The much-vaunted US media website Inside.com is on the verge of being snapped up by a rival.

MediaCentral.com, the internet portal of US trade magazine publisher Primedia, has struck a deal to buy Inside.com and its Stateside weekly magazine, according to reports.

Neither Inside.com nor MediaCentral.com would comment on the reports but an announcement is expected early next week.

The move is expected to lead to a consolidation of editorial operations, with Inside.com likely to become part of MediaCentral.com.

Staff redundancies will also be on the cards.

Inside.com launched last summer amid much publicity and quickly established itself as a website popular with the global media community.

Despite winning plaudits, the site failed to attract a sufficient number of paying subscribers or to generate a significant level of advertising revenue.

It was set up by a consortium of investors that included the Industry Standard and Morgan Stanley, which invested around £20m between them.

Just over half of this amount is believed to have been spent on venture.

webTitle: CD of the week - Baaba Maal

fields.headline: Back to brilliant basics
fields.standfirst:
Baaba Maal isn't the first musician to bring traditional African instruments to a western audience - but he's one of the best, says Robin Denselow

Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText:
Baaba Maal
Missing You (Mi Yeewnii) (Palm Pictures)
Rating: ****
£13.99
fields.body:
Baaba Maal
Missing You (Mi Yeewnii) (Palm Pictures)
Rating: ****
£13.99

It was just after midnight in London's Abbey Road Studios. In one room, the Manic Street Preachers were at work on Know Your Enemy. Up in the control room of Studio 2, a group of African musicians sat listening as guest percussionists from the Anglo-Latin band Sidestepper added the final dash of timbales and congas to what now promises to be the world-music album of the year. Song titles had been written on pieces of paper, which were shuffled around as decisions were made on the album's running order. A guitar line, recorded at a mobile studio out in a village in Senegal, burst from the speakers, followed by a flurry of notes from the kora (the west African harp), a clatter of percussion, and then the stirring, harsh-edged voice of the singer, who now sat motionless in a snakeskin jacket for the first playback of the new recordings.

On that night, back in November, it seemed clear that Baaba Maal's new album was going to be something special, and the finished product is no disappointment. It marks a bold and gently exhilarating return to basics for a man who has rightly been credited as one of the great singer-songwriters of the continent, and whose last album, a somewhat frantic effort to appeal to the western pop market, matched the stirring playing of his band Daande Lenol against poor collaborations with the likes of the Screaming Orphans, and more interesting experimental work involving Brian Eno and Howie B. This time around, there are no electric guitars, no keyboards, synthesisers or horn section, and certainly no guest appearances by Western celebrities.

Baaba Maal started off as an acoustic artist, working with his old friend Mansour Seck, with whom he recorded that gentle African classic Djam Leeli back in 1989. His more recent amplified shows have always included an acoustic segment. The new album is in some ways the long-awaited sequel to Djam Leeli, but here the acoustic songs are given a subtle, gutsy work-over by producer John Leckie, best known for his work with Radiohead. After recording the bulk of the album outdoors in a Senegalese village, Leckie said his aim had been to create an album that sounded "epic but simple". It's certainly atmospheric (though thankfully Leckie doesn't overdo those on-location sound effects), and it sounds like a gently intense live set, performed by master musicians.

The album starts with Maal's stirring solo chanting, a reminder that he was brought up in the little town of Podor, on the edge of the desert, where African and Arabic styles collide. It then builds up as acoustic guitars, kora and backing choruses join in. Some of the songs, such as Miyaabele and the exquisite, lilting love song Jamma Jenngli, are simple and melodic, driven on by the fine playing of Kante Manfila, who joins Maal himself and Mansour Seck on acoustic guitar. Elsewhere are sections of what sounds like stuttering desert blues or passages of complex rhythmic music, with the kora joined by the sound of the balafon (the local xylophone), or the hoddu, the local name for the rasping desert lute, the ngoni. These are the ancients instruments that Baaba Maal would have heard when he started out, travelling across west Africa with Mansour Seck to study its music.

It could be argued that he's not the only person to bring traditional instruments like these to a mass western market - they are used extensively by the young Malian singer Rokia Traore, the finest new female performer in Africa - but this is still a brave, confident move. That other Senegalese superstar, Youssou N'Dour, diluted his last, patchily brilliant album, Joko, by mixing African material with the now-predictable duets with Sting, Peter Gabriel or Wyclef Jean. Baaba Maal makes no such compromise here. This is an African acoustic classic - albeit with bright, classy western production values and a hint of Latin percussion - and it confirms his reputation as both songwriter and singer. The songs, performed as always in his native Fulani, are mostly personal, dealing with friendship, the changing role of African women, or his yearning for Podor. His voice is distinctive as ever, by turns intimate, passionate and rousing.

Tonight, Baaba Maal is in Podor, giving his last local show before flying to Europe for a tour of acoustic shows in small venues across Britain during April and May, followed by a grand finale with his full Daande Lenol band at London's Royal Festival Hall in June. This promises to be the African-music event of the year.

webTitle: Gray confirmed as Saints caretaker manager

fields.headline: Gray confirmed as Saints caretaker manager
fields.trailText: Stuart Gray has been confirmed as Southampton caretaker manager for the remainder of the season.
fields.body:
Stuart Gray has been confirmed as Southampton caretaker manager for the remainder of the season.

Gray was first-team coach under Glenn Hoddle, who quit as manager on Tuesday night.

Gray's first game in charge will be Monday's Premiership clash with Ipswich at The Dell.

Dennis Rofe, who was reserve team boss under the Hoddle regime, steps up to be Gray's assistant until the end of the current campaign.

"Dennis will be a full-time coach, but really that is what we both are.

"We don't walk around in suits; we will have be out on the pitch in our tracksuits with the players," he told Southampton ClubCall.

fields.headline: P Diddy
fields.standfirst: First Cat Stevens, then Prince, now Puff Daddy - it seems you're not anyone until you've changed your name. Take a look at our guide to the best sites on the rap mogul.
fields.trailText: First Cat Stevens, then Prince, now Puff Daddy - it seems you're not anyone until you've changed your name. Take a look at our guide to the best sites on the rap mogul.
fields.body:
1. Puff Daddy is no more. The hip-hop impresario, aka Sean "Puffy" Combs, yesterday told MTV that he now calls himself P Diddy.

2. He wants a fresh start. The bad times began when a breakfast cereal company used Sugar Puff Daddy for a TV advert. They got worse after a shooting incident outside Manhattan's Club New York.

3. The jury cleared him on the charges of firearms possession and bribery but, sadly for the rapper, his girlfriend, Jennifer Lopez, left him before the verdict was returned.

4. It was not the first time P Diddy looked to be in trouble. In 1995 he paid a $1,000 fine for firearms possession and, in 1999, he hit a record company executive with a bottle of champagne.

5. Born in Harlem, he became known in his early 20s, producing albums for artists such as Mary J Blige.

6. As vice president of Uptown Records (he started out as an intern) he nurtured the careers of Craig Mack and Notorious B.I.G. - who he says, and not Ken Dodd, gave him the Diddy name.

7. But his record label, Bad Boy, found it difficult to stay out of trouble. In the mid-1990s it became a focus for tensions in the long-running east v west coast rap feud.

8. LA rapper Tupac Shakur claimed its owner tried to kill him in Times Square, New York, and, later, boasted he was sleeping with Notorious BIG's wife, the singer Faith Evans.

9. Tupac was shot dead in 1996. A year later Notorious BIG was murdered. His death inspired Puffy's (as he was then) first solo hit, I'll be missing you.

10. The rest is history. Not surprisingly, P Diddy now wants to take some time off. Perhaps a little oddly, he also told MTV he needs a "leave of absence just to be Sean Combs".

fields.headline: Never again, says FSA
fields.trailText:
2.30pm update: The new super-watchdog has said it will tighten regulations to guard against repeats of the Mirror scandal, writes Dan Milmo.
Full DTI report (PDF file)
The Maxwell drama: the key players
Mar 30: DTI slams Maxwell and Goldman
Mar 30: Report 'lacks moral courage'
Mar 30: Kevin Maxwell blamed by DTI inquiry
Mar 30: Goldman takes tough line
From the archives: Maxwell dies at sea<
fields.body:
The new super-watchdog for UK companies has said it will tighten regulations to guard against repeats of the Mirror Group Newspapers scandal.

The Financial Services Authority said it would refine rules on listed companies as soon as its sweeping powers are rubber-stamped by the government at the end of the year.

"The report said that the regulatory system has changed and improved, with the FSA bringing about much needed change. Further improvements will follow as soon as the Financial Services Act is implemented," said a spokesman for the FSA.

He added that "a lot of lessons" had been learned from the Maxwell affair, which saw the Mirror Group float on the stock market in 1991 with a deeply misleading share prospectus and with the backing of several leading financial institutions.

"We are now the authority for listed companies and we are carrying out a major review of listings rules," said the spokesman.

The City firms named in the scandal, including investment banks Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers and accountancy firm Coopers & Lybrand, now part of PriceWaterHouseCoopers, privately tried to draw a line under the report today.

Sources at the companies pointed out that the failed flotation took place 10 years ago, and that the real villains of the piece were the Mirror Group board and Robert Maxwell.

"We have had our kicking all the way down the line, ever since the story broke. We have been named and shamed. But people should be looking at what the report says about the Mirror Group board. They should have been more aware of what was going on," said a senior source at one of the reprimanded firms.

The DTI report warned that ethical and professional standards in the City had slipped during the handling of the MGN flotation, and it must not happen again.

fields.headline: British rower breaks Pacific record
fields.standfirst: Picture gallery
fields.trailText: Picture gallery
fields.body:
A British adventurer today completed the first unaided row across the Pacific ocean, but only after being thrown overboard in rough seas and forced to swim the final 200 yards to dry land.

Father-of-two Jim Shekhdar, from Northwood, west London, endured cyclones, shark attacks and dwindling food supplies as he battled more than 8,000 miles through treacherous waters on his journey from Peru to Australia.

But, even with the Brisbane coastline in sight after 274 days alone at sea, the 54-year-old rower's ordeal was not over.

Huge breakers swamped his 23ft vessel, tipping him into the water and forcing him to struggle through the surf to reach his goal.

There, looking exhausted but delighted, he hugged his wife and downed a can of lager.

Mr Shekhdar, who received a message of congratulations from the prime minister, Tony Blair, said the reception in Australia was "absolutely amazing".

"There were helicopters all over the place, people, kids, television, press, all sorts," he told BBC News.

"When I said it was what I was going to do nobody believed me so I thought I'd better do it. There's a lot more attention at the end than there was at the beginning."

He said that during his trip he had struggled with several shark attacks, been hit by a fishing trawler and, most terrifying of all, narrowly avoiding being sunk by a tanker.

It was a pleasant relief to be in human company again, he added. "The first couple of months at sea were really good as it was nice to have some solitude. But eventually it gets a bit lonely out there," he said.

The former England international water-polo player left Ilo in Peru on June 29 last year to embark on the Pacific Ocean Challenge 2000 in his tiny boat, Le Shark.

The civil engineer and management consultant said that he had taken up the challenge because he knew the corporate lifestyle did not suit him and he wanted a new focus.

A few days before his departure he told Kenneth Crutchlow of the Ocean Rowing Society: "As far as I was concerned, the Pacific had never been rowed solo continent to continent and I wanted to be the first to do that."

Mr Shekhdar cancelled an NHS hip-replacement operation weeks before he left Britain.

Throughout the voyage he kept in contact with his family, friends and the Ocean Rowing Society via phone, fax and computer, and he was continually monitored using a tracking beacon.

The challenge was not his first taste of ocean voyaging: he rowed the Atlantic with fellow adventurer David Jackson in 1997.

Five-times Olympic gold medallist Steve Redgrave added his congratulations. "I'm sticking to ponds, lakes and rivers," said Sir Steve after learning of the success.

webTitle: Tories attack Labour over NHS appointment

fields.headline: Tories attack Labour over NHS appointment
fields.trailText: A senior health official criticised by the Tories as a Labour sympathiser has been put in charge of the body tasked with taking the "politics" out of NHS board appointments.
fields.body:
A senior health official criticised by the Tories as a Labour sympathiser has been put in charge of the body tasked with taking the "politics" out of NHS board appointments.

Sir William Wells has been appointed chairman of the new NHS appointments commission, which will choose chairmen and non-executives to sit on the boards of trusts and health authorities.

The commission was set up as a means of removing the constant political wrangling over the 3,000 board positions, which have in the past been seen as partisan "grace-and-favour" nominations in the gift of the health secretary.

Sir William, who is the non-executive chairman of the NHS south-east region, was earlier this month accused by Tory health spokesman Liam Fox of applying "enormous and unnaceptable political pressure" to NHS trusts.

Sir William had sent a letter to trust chairmen in the south-east region in which he said he "cannot over-emphasize the importance of achieving our manifesto commitment" of reducing waiting lists.

Dr Fox last night said Sir William's new role was "simply unacceptable" and "made a mockery of any notion of impartiality in the NHS".

He added: "It shows that willingness to comply with ministerial diktat is now best way to get on in the NHS."

Sir William told SocietyGuardian.co.uk: "I have never been a member of any political party in my entire life. I have been involved as a non-executive in the NHS under governments of all different colours."

He described Dr Fox's comments as "bizarre" and pointed out that the shadow health secretary had "never bothered to talk to me" about his political sympathies.

"What Dr Fox forgets is that it was his party that appointed me as a regional chairman in the first place."

Ironically, many in the health service believed Sir Wiliam to have been a Conservative sympathiser because of his track record as an enthusaistic proponent of the Tories' internal market NHS reforms in the early 1990s.

Sir William attracted further controversy last week when it was alleged that he had "delivered" the resignation of a trust chair in the region to Alan Milburn before she had even made the decision to part company with the NHS.

According to Health Service Journal, Sir Wiliam told Gillian Miscampbell, the chairwoman of Stoke Mandeville Hospital trust - and a Conservative councillor - to "resign or be sacked" over a waiting list scandal.

Sir William has served as a non-executive board member in various NHS organisations continuously since 1968.

He was appointed by then health secretary Kenneth Clarke as one of the 57 elite "first wave" of NHS trust chairmen in 1990 with the aim of taking forward the reforms.

He was a founder member of the NHS Trust Federation, a body set up to champion the reforms, and was knighted in 1997 by former prime minister John Major.

There was widespread surprise when he was not only retained as an NHS chairman by Labour, but became a trusted senior figure who became as enthusiastic a proponent of Labour "modernisation" as he was earlier of the Tory internal market.

Roy Lilley, a former first wave trust chair and colleague of Sir William, said he had "always found William's politics difficult to read", and that he was often privately cynical about politicians.

But he added that Sir William must have been seen as acceptable to the then Tory government to become a first wave trust chair: "Everyone had some connection through the (Tory) central office network."

fields.headline: The Maxwell drama: the key players
fields.standfirst: Who's who at the centre of the Mirror pensions scandal
fields.trailText: Who's who at the centre of the Mirror pensions scandal.
fields.body:
Robert Maxwell

Robert Maxwell was born Jan Ludwig Hoch in 1923 in Czechoslovakia. He came to England 17 years later and was decorated for bravery while serving in the British army in the second world war.

After the war he set up a business empire which, at its height, was turning over £5bn a year. Despite being labelled as unfit to run a public company by the Department of Trade in the 1970s, Maxwell progressed from scientific textbook publishing to building Europe's largest printing empire.

He bought Mirror Group Newspapers in 1984, established the Maxwell Communications Corporation and then bought the Macmillan publishing house in the US.

Despite mounting fears over the financial health of Maxwell's empire, the gregarious entrepreneur was widely admired for his energy and courage.

But following his mysterious death by drowning off the Canary Islands in November 1991 it emerged that Maxwell - crippled with debts of £3bn - had taken £450m out of the Mirror Group pension fund and used it to prop up other businesses. The Maxwell companies were immediately broken up, along with the tycoon's reputation.

Kevin Maxwell

Robert Maxwell's youngest son could be barred from holding a company directorship following the heavy criticism handed out to him in the DTI report.

Kevin has never been able to escape from his father's shadow. Along with older brother Ian, he was cleared of fraud relating to dealings at the Mirror Group in 1996.

After several abortive attempts to get back into the business world, Kevin now co-owns communications company Telemonde. The company has been taken off the stock market in the US following a clash with financial watchdogs over accounting policies.

There is no doubt Kevin Maxwell's past has hindered his comeback. He admits it has made venture capital and banking facilities hard to come by.

Ian Maxwell

Ian took over Mirror Group following his father's death and was regarded as the natural publisher of the family. But he was forced to resign as soon as the pension funds scandal grew.

He still works closely with Kevin and is helping his brother develop internet and e-commerce ideas at his Telemonde venture. Ian is also overseeing the brothers' Russian publishing interests. These centre on a company called Maximov, which produces Who's Who-style directories covering various Russian industries.

Anne Robinson

The quiz show haridan was a highly-paid columnist at the Mirror at the time of Maxwell's death, and was unstinting in her praise: 'I think he was a man of enormous courage and fearlessness and a great deal more courage than a lot of the people who were busy criticising him. He enriched many lives and mine was one." (Guardian, November 6 1991, the day after Maxwell was discovered drowned)

A month later: "By sheer brute force, a combination of charm and power, he robbed people of their judgment. However, you could understand the bankers acting as they did... it's the old story of who bullshits best." (Guardian, December 7 1991).

Anne now earns millions harassing members of the public for their poor recollection skills on BBC2's The Weakest Link.

Alastair Campbell

The most powerful man in Britain was the political editor of the Mirror when Maxwell died, and moved on to become Tony Blair's press secretary. He was famously involved in a punch-up with Michael White after the Guardian's political editor shouted: "It shows there is a God" during a trying moment on the day Maxwell died.

webTitle: Fresh nuggets in new Blair bio

fields.headline: Fresh nuggets in new Blair bio
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Labour party
fields.trailText: New insights into the man who hopes to become the first Labour leader to serve two prime ministerial terms were revealed this week with the publication of a revised biography of Tony Blair.
fields.body:
New insights into the man who hopes to become the first Labour leader to serve two prime ministerial terms were revealed this week with the publication of a revised biography of Tony Blair.

The book, by political journalist John Rentoul, contains no "smoking gun" or "killer fact" to worry Mr Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

What it does offer is a fascinating picture of Mr Blair: his rebelliousness and self-confidence at school, his battle to modernise the Labour party he became an MP for during the 1983 electoral defeat, his wife Cherie's role in his meteoric rise through the party and his own religious faith.

The book also demonstrates the ambitious streak behind the young MP for Sedgefield's rise to lead the Labour party within 11 years of entering parliament. In one instance, it claims he reduced his original secretary, Sylvia Littlejohns, to tears when he sacked her in favour of Anji Hunter in 1989.

Mr Rentoul claims that Mr Blair's relationship with Gordon Brown, in which many perceived Mr Blair as the junior party, changed after the 1992 election defeat.

Mr Brown's decision not to go for the leadership after Neil Kinnock's resignation prompted Mr Blair to think that his rival had had his chance and missed it - the book quotes an "ally of Tony Blair" as saying, "Gordon bottled it."

Mr Rentoul also claims that after John Smith's death, Gordon Brown did not decide to withdraw from the race to lead the Labour party at the infamous Granita dinner in Islington. Instead, the moment occurred at a dinner with Nick Brown and Charlie Whelan in a Covent Garden restaurant the night before.

Tony Blair's relationship with Peter Mandelson is illustrated with a nice anecdote from the 1987 election campaign: at an early morning press conference, the then opposition Treasury spokesman Mr Blair described a policy of Mrs Thatcher's as "the product of an unchecked and unbalanced mind."

Peter Mandelson, at the time Labour's head of communications, rushed over to reporter Michael Brunson to assure him that Mr Blair did not mean that Mrs Thatcher was in fact mad.

 Tony Blair: Prime Minister, by John Rentoul, is published by Little, Brown on April 5, at £20.
Buy it at BOL

The book also demonstrates the ambitious streak behind the young MP for Sedgefield's rise to lead the Labour party within 11 years of entering parliament. In one instance, it claims he reduced his original secretary, Sylvia Littlejohns, to tears when he sacked her in favour of Anji Hunter in 1989. Mr Rentoul claims that Mr Blair's relationship with Gordon Brown, in which many perceived Mr Blair as the junior party, changed after the 1992 election defeat. Mr Brown's decision not to go for the leadership after Neil Kinnock's resignation prompted Mr Blair to think that his rival had had his chance and missed it - the book quotes an "ally of Tony Blair" as saying, "Gordon bottled it." Mr Rentoul also claims that after John Smith's death, Gordon Brown did not decide to withdraw from the race to lead the Labour party at the infamous Granita dinner in Islington. Instead, the moment occurred at a dinner with Nick Brown and Charlie Whelan in a Covent Garden restaurant the night before. Tony Blair's relationship with Peter Mandelson is illustrated with a nice anecdote from the 1987 election campaign: at an early morning press conference, the then opposition Treasury spokesman Mr Blair described a policy of Mrs Thatcher's as "the product of an unchecked and unbalanced mind." Peter Mandelson, at the time Labour's head of communications, rushed over to reporter Michael Brunson to assure him that Mr Blair did not mean that Mrs Thatcher was in fact mad.  Tony Blair: Prime Minister, by John Rentoul, is published by Little, Brown on April 5, at £20. Buy it at BOL

fields.headline: Bush's foreign policy forays
fields.standfirst:
Read our guide to how the US president has caused controversy around the world.

Special report: Bush's America
fields.trailText:
Read our guide to how the US president has caused controversy around the world.
Special report: Bush's America
fields.body:
No to Kyoto
March 28 2001: Bush announces that he will ditch the Kyoto accord on global warming, saying that the US had "interest" in its implementation. America will now take steps to withdraw its signature from the landmark treaty.
Key quote: "Our economy has slowed down in our country... And the idea of placing caps on carbon dioxide does not make economic sense for America."
29.03.2001: EU dismay as Bush reneges on Kyoto
Special report: global warming

Annoying the Arabs
March 28 2001: Bush enrages Palestinians and the Arab world when the US kills off a UN security council resolution that would have opened the way for international observers to be sent to the Middle East. John Cunningham, the chief US representative to the UN, called the resolution "unbalanced and unwise".
Key quote: "The signal I'm sending to the Palestinians is stop the violence  I hope Chairman Arafat hears it loud and clear."
29.03.2001: No UN observers for Israel, US insists
Special report: Israel and the Middle East

Targeting the Chinese
March 24 2001: A sweeping defence strategy review concludes that China supplant Russia as America's No 1 enemy, supplanting Russia. The Pentagon review said the Pacific ocean should now become the most important focus of US military deployments, with China now perceived as the principal threat to American global dominance.
US to make China No 1 enemy

Spy spat
March 22 2001: Bush announces the expulsion of 50 alleged Russian spies - the largest mass expulsion since the end of the cold war. The move follows the arrest of FBI agent Robert Hanssen, accused of spying for Moscow.
Key quote: "Presented with the facts, I made the decision. It was the right thing to do."
US, Russia in tit-for-tat expulsions
Special report: Russia

Korea freeze
March 8 2001: Bush drops a nasty surprise on the president of South Korea, Kim Dae-jung, who has been trying to improve relations with North Korea. The US president says he did not favour continuing Bill Clinton's cautious rapprochement with North Korea, once described by national security adviser Condoleezza Rice as the "road-kill of history".
Bush shows cold shoulder across Pacific
Special report: Korea

First foreign visit
February 16 2001: Bush, who had only been abroad three times in his life, makes his first foreign visit as US president - across the Texan border to Mexico.
Mexico looks north for olive branch

webTitle: Simon Hatterstone on Injustice, a film about racism in the police

fields.headline: Why?
fields.standfirst: There have been 1,000 deaths in police custody in the past 30 years - and only one officer has been convicted as a result. Simon Hatterstone reports on a film that exposes persistent racism at the heart of an institution. Victoria Brittain picks other highlights from the Human Rights Film Festival
fields.trailText: There have been 1,000 deaths in police custody in the past 30 years - and only one officer has been convicted as a result. Simon Hatterstone reports on a film that exposes persistent racism at the heart of an institution. Victoria Brittain picks other highlights from the Human Rights Film Festival
fields.body:
When Ken Fero turned his camera on the funeral of Shiji Lapite, he had no idea where it would lead him. Seven years, and hundreds of hours of footage later, he has ended up with one of the most powerful and despairing films ever to have made in this country.

Injustice is the simple title and complex subject of the film that closes the Human Rights Film Festival. Fero and Tariq Mehmood's feature documents deaths in custody - mainly black deaths - over a six-year period. It is not just the stories of Shiji Lapite and Brian Douglas and Ibrahima Sey and Joy Gardner, four innocents who died at the hands of police brutality. It is about the lives of the families they have left behind, and their thwarted struggle for justice.

It was December 16 1994 when Shiji Lapite was stopped by two police officers for "acting suspiciously". Half an hour later he was dead. We see Shiji's wife wailing: "They beat him to death. They killed him. Why should they kill him? Why? Why? Why?" Each "why" is more gut-wrenching. The question never gets answered. The cause of death was asphyxia from compression of the neck consistent with the application of a neckhold.

Four months after Shiji Lapite's death, on May 3 1995, 33-year-old Brian Douglas was on his way home when he was stopped by two police officers, PC Tuffy and PC Harrison. Brian was a big, handsome, popular man. "It was hard not to like him," says his sister Brenda Weinberg. We see photos of him ironing his trousers and polishing his shoes, getting ready for a night out with his friends. Boy, he took such care of himself, says Brenda, he loved a good night out.

Brian was with his friend Stafford when he was stopped. The officers ordered them out of the car and, apparently unprovoked, hit Brian on the head with a new US-style baton. The camera zooms in slowly on a terrible picture of Brian pierced by all kinds of tubes and instruments. After a few days, barely conscious, Brian asked his brother if he could come home. His brother held him down and hugged him.

The humanity of Fero's film lies in the tiny details, the irrelevances. Brian's brother recalls how, even on his deathbed, Brian was allowed no peace: "There was too much activity in the room. That bugged me, all the activity." We see Brian's mother arrive in London from Jamaica. Her son has died a few minutes before she reaches the hospital, and she is barking, literally barking, with grief. When she collects herself, she tells a gathered crowd, "It's a very, very hard road to travel."

As the campaigns build around these two deaths, we discover more and more deaths in custody. In December 1995 Wayne Douglas was arrested for suspected burglary. He collapsed and died while detained at Brixton police station. In March 1996 Gambian asylum seeker Ibrahima Sey was forced to the ground, sprayed repeatedly with CS gas, and then held face down for 15 minutes. When he went totally limp and stopped breathing, an ambulance was called. He was dead by the time they reached the hospital.

Ken Fero says he is not interested in making objective films. He knew whose side he was on from the start. "When we started investigating the cases, the facts were so clear that it was never a question of right and wrong, it was simply wrong, and a wrong that has been hidden." There are no interviews with police officers in the film. He says he would have happily interviewed the officers if he'd been allowed to.

Fero, a former sculptor and painter, wears old-style pink Doc Martens and John Lennon glasses and a skinhead haircut. He began making films 15 years ago. He was frustrated by the people who came to see his art, felt they didn't bear much relation to the world he knew. He decided that film could be a more powerful and relevant medium - a political weapon.

Fero was one of the founders of a collective called Migrant Media. He wanted his camera to document the everyday struggles of the communities he knew and lived with. If there was an angry exchange, a riot, a burnt car, a scrap on the streets, an unwelcome exchange of batons and bodies, his camera would be there to record it.

Fero and his team of five have subsidised themselves over the seven years by making videos and doing odd jobs. He says that at the moment he can't see himself making another film because each one takes so much out of him. Not only has he been putting Injustice together, he has also been campaigning for the families involved. He says that is the only way he could have made the film - demonstrating to the families that first and foremost he was there as a friend and supporter, not just a reporter.

Fero sees Injustice as a counter to the stories put out by the police about those who have died in custody. He talks about the common pattern he has observed with all the deaths in custody - never apologise, and blacken the victim's character. So Joy Gardner, who died after police stuck 13 feet of tape round her face while trying to restrain her, was always shown in a photograph as wild and uncontrollable. Fero shows pictures of her in her true light - a gorgeous, vibrant woman. In the film, even her irrepressible mother can't hold in her grief. She breaks down at a public meeting. "I didn't believe human beings could be so cruel to each other. You don't know how much I cry. My tears will catch them," she says, talking of the officers who killed her daughter.

We see how the police profiles of the victims were taken up by the mainstream press and history was soon revised. So Shiji Lapite was no longer described as a father of two or an asylum seeker. In the public eye he became a drug dealer after an undercover officer claimed he found crack cocaine at the incident. One officer told the inquest that Shiji was "the biggest, strongest most violent black man" he'd ever seen. In fact, he was five foot 10. PC McCullum admitted kicking him twice in the head as hard as he could, and said he was using reasonable force to subdue a violent prisoner. The coroner told the jury they could only deliver a verdict of unlawful killing if they were satisfied that the criminal offence of manslaughter had been committed. The unanimous verdict was unlawful killing, which is rare in death-in-custody cases. Yet, astonish ingly, the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) ruled that there was insufficent evidence to charge the officers with manslaughter.

In August 1995, three months after the death of Brian Douglas, the family was finally allowed to bury him - without his brain. "As far as I'm concerned, we've buried him with the essential bit missing," Brenda says through her bitter tears. We have already heard at the inquest PC Tuffy claiming that he hit Brian on the shoulder and the baton slid up. Several witnesses claim they saw him raise his arm and bring the baton down on his head. Medical experts testify that the impact was the equivalent of him falling 11 times his own height on his head. The Douglas family hope for an unlawful killing verdict but the inquest jury deliver a verdict of death by misadventure.

It's October 1997, and the film's one moment of triumph. Family and friends of Ibrahima Sey celebrate the verdict of unlawful killing. Ibrahima's cousin says "I stuck my fist in the air . . . he has gone, but not in vain." At last justice is within sight. But again the CPS ignored the inquest verdict and said there was insufficient evidence to prosecute.

S ince 1969, there have been 1,000 deaths in police custody in Britain. Only one of these deaths - David Oluywale, the first black man to die in custody - has resulted in an officer being convicted of a crime. Fero says there is still an establishment belief that the British police are the best in the world and that to acknowledge they are capable of, and sometimes guilty of, crimes would undermine the system. "In France and America, you have police officers charged and convicted of manslaughter and murder. Here it doesn't happen. No matter how many people die, it seems they are not going to admit there is a problem."

Fero hopes Injustice will challenge the contemporary notion of what constitutes a British film. "People in America look at Britain and think of Four Weddings and a Funeral, with its funny, quirky characters. Well, our film is the other side of it. Our film is about four funerals."

Now he faces his next battle; to get the film shown on television or in cinemas. Channel 4, which has backed previous Migrant Media films, has refused to have anything to do with the production of Injustice. The question now is whether they will show it. Meanwhile, he refuses to cut the film to appease the lawyers of mainstream distributors - that, according to Fero, would be a betrayal of the families. But, he insists, whatever it takes, the film will get shown. "We'll take it round the country ourselves if necessary and make sure it's seen by a millinon people."

One of the most remarkable and moving aspects of Injustice is seeing how people change over time - physically, politically, spiritually. Every family starts out believing in the concept of justice, convinced that those responsible for the deaths of their loved ones will be punished. But as the years pass, they lose faith.

Brenda Weinberg, Brian Douglas's sister, says: "Brian's last words were 'sort it'. And that's what we're trying to do. Sort it." Back in 1996, Brenda was urging the angry crowds to stay calm on a demonstration. Now she's not so sure if she was right to. "I can't grieve, I can't put Brian to rest ever if I know someone's walking around out there responsible for his death and they haven't been brought to justice. The only thing that does happen is that as the time gets longer it's any justice; it can be legal justice or street justice. I don't really care any more."

 The Human Rights Watch International Film Festival opens at the Ritzy Cinema, London SW2, tonight (info: 020-7733 2229). For details of screening times for all films visit www.hrw.org/iff/london.html.

 Injustice premieres at the Ritzy next Thursday.

Just causes on film - Highlights from the Human Rights Film Festival

Terrorists in Retirement

Director Mosco Boucault, narrated by Simone Signoret

Seven elderly men in Paris, five Poles and two Romanians, tell their stories of life and death in the Resistance in Paris. Almost all were Jewish and had fled from anti-semitism to eke out a living, illegally, in France. Most were also from communist families.

They were young, 16 and 17, when they volunteered for the underground circle which carried out extremely risky assassinations of German officers, throwing bombs into the restaurants they frequented, attacking their cars and barracks. Reliving those days of more than half a century ago, these modest old men have no regrets, except perhaps that they did not do enough, they did not kill enough Nazis. "I'd willingly kill more Nazis today," says one.

The centrepiece of the film is the execution in 1944 of 24 men from the Resistance group led by the Armenian poet Manouchian. This was the tragedy which has marked these survivors of the same heroic circle. This film created a scandal in France, where it was initially banned from television because of its shocking thesis that these foreign Jews were deliberately sacrificed by the French Communist party in a struggle for power, ahead of the end of the war, between the communists and General De Gaulle. The modern-day anti-communist historians of this theory come over as something of a contrast to these strong, old men who lost everything except their political convictions.

Lumumba

Director Raoul Peck

This is a true story, warns the voice-over as the film opens on a dead man being manhandled towards the destruction of his body in acid and fire. The dead man was Congo's first prime minister, Patrice Lumumba, betrayed by the colonialists who had reluctantly granted independence to the country but who plotted to hold on to its riches through their proxies in the province of Katanga.

"I came 50 years too soon, what we wanted for the country others did not," says Lumumba in his last letter to his wife as the film ends on the same image of the dark night in Katanga where Belgians shot him after he had been beaten ruthlessly by his Congolese enemies.

This exceptional film tells a dramatic story from nearly half a century ago which today could be mistaken for highly coloured fiction. But Peck has done history proud. He shows us the crude racism and arrogant double-dealing of the Belgians - which was one trigger for the chaos which engulfed the country; and the second which was Mobutu's move for power encouraged by the American ambassador.

Eriq Ebouaney as Lumumba is uncanny in his accuracy. Every gesture seems to come straight from the iconic old photographs of him in the brief glory days of independence, then in the horror of his humiliation. Don't miss it.

Jung, In the Land of the Mujahedden

Directors Fabrizio Lazzaretti, Alberto Vendemmiati

This is an Afghanistan few outsiders have seen, but after watching this film you'll never forget it. Immense horizons of snow-topped mountains hang over dust plains emptied by a 20-year war. Desperate fighters of the north talk of the Taliban as the creatures of Pakistan and the English, and want revenge for every child's hand and foot blown off by land mines. Women, beyond desperation, are reduced to begging through their tattered, all-enveloping chadors. "Not even death wants the people of Afghanistan," says one.

The dirt-poor frontline town of Charikar - near the site of one of the greatest art finds in the world, the exquisite Begram ivories from the first and second century AD - was to have a hospital built for mine victims by an Italian medical team. The Italian surgeon chose Afghanistan as "a place where no one wants to go, it's censored from our consciousness". The film-makers, introduced by a veteran journalist who knew the Mojahadeen leaders decades before, found that they had embarked on "an excursion into human grief".

The team came back over three years and filmed an extraordinary achievement against that grief. Charikar was destroyed in a massive offensive which sent hundreds of thousands of refugees into the Panshir Valley. But against all the odds a hospital was built here in the valley, and, amid the unending stream of casualties, a team of Kurdish doctors and nurses have realised the Italian surgeon's dream of a community with the will to withstand the madness of this war.
