Every gesture seems to come straight from the iconic old photographs of him in the brief glory days of independence, then in the horror of his humiliation. Don't miss it. Jung, In the Land of the Mujahedden Directors Fabrizio Lazzaretti, Alberto Vendemmiati This is an Afghanistan few outsiders have seen, but after watching this film you'll never forget it. Immense horizons of snow-topped mountains hang over dust plains emptied by a 20-year war. Desperate fighters of the north talk of the Taliban as the creatures of Pakistan and the English, and want revenge for every child's hand and foot blown off by land mines. Women, beyond desperation, are reduced to begging through their tattered, all-enveloping chadors. "Not even death wants the people of Afghanistan," says one. The dirt-poor frontline town of Charikar - near the site of one of the greatest art finds in the world, the exquisite Begram ivories from the first and second century AD - was to have a hospital built for mine victims by an Italian medical team. The Italian surgeon chose Afghanistan as "a place where no one wants to go, it's censored from our consciousness". The film-makers, introduced by a veteran journalist who knew the Mojahadeen leaders decades before, found that they had embarked on "an excursion into human grief". The team came back over three years and filmed an extraordinary achievement against that grief. Charikar was destroyed in a massive offensive which sent hundreds of thousands of refugees into the Panshir Valley. But against all the odds a hospital was built here in the valley, and, amid the unending stream of casualties, a team of Kurdish doctors and nurses have realised the Italian surgeon's dream of a community with the will to withstand the madness of this war.

fields.headline: Bishop puts foot in mouth
fields.standfirst: After what he thought was a private conversation, the Archbishop of York has been drawn into a public debate over the timing of the general election, writes Stephen Bates
fields.trailText: After what he thought was a private conversation, the Archbishop of York has been drawn into a public debate over the timing of the general election, writes Stephen Bates.
fields.body:
The intervention of the Archbishop of York, Dr David Hope, into the government's deliberations over the putative date of the general election, by calling for the prime minister to delay naming the day until the autumn in order to conquer the foot and mouth crisis first, is an extremely rare intrusion these days.

Bishops have tended to steer clear of controversy since the routine maulings that they used to receive from the Thatcher government in the 1980s, when the likes of Norman Tebbit routinely dismissed them as a bunch of lily-livered softies, wets and Marxists.

The archbishop is certainly tapping into a vein of concern among Anglican clerics and divines - the bishop of Carlisle is reported to have locked himself up in his castle for the duration of the epidemic.

Prayers have been said the length of the kingdom and synod meetings and jumble sales have been cancelled. There is understandably huge concern among farming parishes.

But, although Dr Hope's seniority as second in the church hierarchy gives weight to his opinions, the evidence from church leaders seems to indicate that they are as divided as the rest of us. The Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, had to be dragged in his wake to voice his concerns about the disease, though not the election date.

The bishops of Oxford, Hereford and Salisbury - all rural dioceses, some with cases of foot and mouth - were today following the line that, as far as the election is concerned, if 'twere done, 'twere best got out of the way quickly on 3 May.

Touring their flocks they have heard the farmers' fears - but also those of the tourist industry, with the desolate prospect of a visitor-less summer ahead. There is no doubt that Dr Hope identifies closely with his large rural province, which stretches from the Humber to the Scottish border, and with his diocese, which includes the lush, rustic Vale of York and the Dales.

He - and they - have had a rough winter that, in the autumn saw the archbishop fishing about in his wellies at his residence, Bishopthorpe Palace, to salvage his wine cellar from the floods.

It now appears, however, that the archbishop, who thought he was having a private lunch at the Times with the editor and Dame Thora Hird in preparation for that newspaper's Easter supplement, was taken aback to find his private words splashed all over the front page next day.

With the Times's penchant for going down market these days it is perhaps a wonder that they did not splash on 90-year-old Dame Thora's opinions.

He is surely right, though, to make his views known. As archbishop, he is known to be concerned that the church's current media strategy of keeping a low profile, dictated from Lambeth Palace, is having the effect of marginalising the Church of England in its role as a central pillar of national life.

He can scarcely have thought, however, that his lunchtime chat would have such a galvanising effect.

fields.headline: Widower's House by John Bayley
fields.standfirst:
Duckworth £16.99
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount from BOL
fields.trailText: Gosh. What? Sorry, I was dozing off again. The dust has rather been gathering around me since Iris died. Actually, come to think of it, the dust was gathering while Iris was still alive. I like our dust. I've only got to look at the grime on my trouser bottoms, and I remember the laughter Iris and I shared.
fields.body:
Gosh. What? Sorry, I was dozing off again. The dust has rather been gathering around me since Iris died. Actually, come to think of it, the dust was gathering while Iris was still alive. I like our dust. I've only got to look at the grime on my trouser bottoms, and I remember the laughter Iris and I shared.

Why do people always want to look after widowers? I want to be left alone with my memories, not humoured out of them. Grief is self-centred. What was it Hardy said? No matter. It'll come back to me in a minute. Anyway, here I am in Norfolk, after a ghastly drive from Oxford, being force fed a casserole by Margot.

"You need me to tidy up your house," she barked.

I didn't need her for anything, but I was too timid to say so, and a few weeks later she swept into Oxford.

"Don't mind my being here, Johnny. I thought this might be comforting for both of us," she mewed, as her grey hair fell across my pillow. She was only trying to be kind.

There was a knock on the door. It was Mella, one of my former students. "I've brought you a pork pie," she said, before getting to work with the vacuum cleaner.

She was rather a long time upstairs, and I found her lying fully clothed on the bed. We were soon both naked. Mella was rather scrawny but I think Iris might have approved.

Mella was a single parent, and we spent many an hour discussing her son, Damian or Darren. She even became friends with Mella and I began to suspect them of a little lesbian tendresse .

"She doesn't have a son, you know," Margot confided in a letter.

Mella stormed out the house when I showed her the letter. Perhaps I should have followed, and I wondered whether she would become a prostitute or drug addict.

Still it was nice to be left to my shadowy world of bereavement.

"I'm back," said Mella, some months later. "I'm off," I replied rushing out the door. "I'm going to Lanzarote to marry Audi. If I can find my passport, that is."

Is that enough? Has the cheque from the Telegraph cleared? My memory is beginning to play tricks. Grief does that, you know. What a silly old duffer I am.

And if you really are pressed, the digested read, digested: John Bayley enjoys the comfort of strangers after Iris Murdoch's death. Or, there again, maybe he doesn't

fields.headline: Hill & Knowlton buys ProMarc Agency
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: PR network Hill & Knowlton has acquired US communciations firm the ProMarc Agency, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
WPP's public relations network Hill & Knowlton has acquired US technology communciations firm the ProMarc Agency.

Founded in 1996, the Washington DC-based company provides specialist public relations services to technology companies in the applications, infrastructure, services and wireless industries.

ProMarc's clients include Managed Objects, Vocus, Ztango, EqualFooting.com, Politec, InfoCruiser, Loral CyberStar and Facility Information Systems.

The addition of ProMarc's clients to H&K's technology accounts will create combined billings of £4m.

"The combination of H&K's established global technology presence with ProMarc's excellence and reputation creates a dynamic force in the Washington high-tech corridor," said Tom Hoog, president and chief executive of H&K USA.

This acquisition continues WPP's strategy of expanding its networks in fast-growing sectors and markets.

fields.headline: Kray loses power of persuasion
fields.trailText:
12.45pm TV overnights: BBC1's deathbed interview with Reggie Kray pulled in less than 5m last night, writes Jason Deans.
Mar 22: BBC in row over Kray film
fields.body:
BBC1's deathbed interview with the notorious gangster Reggie Kray did not prove popular with viewers, pulling in less than 5m last night.

ITV enjoyed more success with its big interview - Tonight with Trevor McDonald's encounter with Paddington rail crash survivor Pam Warren drew the show's best audience for more than two months.

The BBC was criticised for buying the exclusive final interview that formed the heart of Reggie Kray - the Final Word, which went out on BBC1 between 9pm and 10pm last night.

The documentary had 4.8m viewers and a 21% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

It was up against ITV GP drama Peak Practice, which drew an audience of 8.2m.

Last Thursday in the BBC1 9pm slot the Car Wars Special pulled in 5.2m viewers and had a 22% share.

Later last night Sir Trevor interviewed Ms Warren - who has just discarded the plastic mask she wore for 18 months to protect her burned face - on Tonight.

The programme drew 5.1m, which was a 32% share of the available audience between 10.20pm and 11.20pm.

Last night's edition of Tonight was the most watched since it moved to the 10.20pm slot in late January.

Some potential male viewers of the Kray documentary may have been tempted instead by Channel 5's 9pm movie, the John Travolta/Christian Slater action flick Broken Arrow.

Channel 5's movie repeat had an impressive 2.9m viewers and a 14% share.

Related story

fields.headline: DTI slams Kevin Maxwell and Goldman Sachs
fields.standfirst: Full DTI report (PDF file)
fields.trailText:
12.30pm update: A DTI report has criticised both Kevin Maxwell and Goldman Sachs over the pensions scandal. By Dan Milmo.
Mar 30: Report 'lacks moral courage'
Mar 30: Kevin Maxwell blamed by DTI inquiry
Mar 30: Goldman takes tough line
From the archives: Maxwell dies at sea
fields.body:
A government report into the Robert Maxwell affair has severely criticised both Kevin Maxwell and the Goldman Sachs merchant bank over their involvement in the pensions scandal.

The Department of Trade and Industry investigation into the flotation of Mirror Group Newspapers in 1991 said Goldman Sachs bears a "substantial responsibility" for allowing Maxwell to manipulate the stock market.

But the firm today said it had been "deceived" by the late tycoon and would have "acted differently" if it had known the true state of Maxwell's finances.

"We, and doubtless many other firms in the City and elsewhere, were intentionally and successfully deceived. We deeply regret this and, with the benefit of hindsight and with the information now available to us, would have acted differently," Goldman Sachs said in a statement.

Maxwell's media empire collapsed soon after his death in 1991, when it was discovered that more than £450m had disappeared from Mirror Group pension funds.

The accountancy firm Coopers & Lybrand, now part of PriceWaterhouseCoopers, was also criticised for its role as a professional adviser in the flotation, which saw investors buying shares on the back of deeply misleading assurances about MGN's finances.

"While we could argue about specific points in the report, we're not. We accept the criticisms. There is not much we can add today except to repeat that we fell short of the high standards we expect for ourselves and for that we are extremely sorry," said Roger White, director of corporate affairs of PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

The DTI also said Kevin Maxwell and elder brother Ian may yet be disqualified from running companies.

"The department is considering the report and taking legal advice before deciding on whether directors disqualification procedures are appropriate," the DTI said.

The damning report said Kevin Maxwell gave "very substantial assistance" to his father and "bore a heavy responsibility" for what happened.

Kevin and Ian Maxwell were cleared of fraud in a trial in 1996.

fields.headline: My day with Robert Maxwell
fields.standfirst: 'I clambered on to his gleaming white yacht, the very boat from which he would disappear little more than a year later'. Mark Tran recalls his day with Cap'n Bob.
fields.trailText: 'I clambered on to his gleaming white yacht, the very boat from which he would disappear little more than a year later'. Mark Tran recalls his day with Cap'n Bob.
fields.body:
In 1991, Robert Maxwell lumbered into New York as a white knight to save the ailing Daily News, one of New York's tabloids, and everyone wanted to interview this larger than life figure.

I collared him in the Art Deco lobby of the News building, then located on 42nd Street, after one of those impromptu press conferences and handed him my card. He glanced imperiously at it, then looked up and down and purred: "Yes, I know the byline, call my secretary," then strode off.

His secretary instructed me to turn up at his yacht, the Lady Ghislaine, named after his daughter, moored on the East River. So on a sunny day, I clambered on to his gleaming white yacht, the size of a small liner, the very boat from which he would disappear little more than a year later.

There were two magazine hacks ahead of me, so I waited. And waited. My appointed time came and went as I sat on a sofa surrounded by the thickest of white shaggy carpets. A couple of hours later, he sauntered out, followed by his retinue, and invited me to accompany him to the News building, where he was to make his first appearance as the new owner of the News.

During the short drive up FDR, the highway that hugs the East River, I asked him a few questions. He grew tetchy as soon I began quizzing him about the precarious finances of the News. That was the Maxwell way, at first charming, but quickly lapsing into irritability. But there was nothing new about the News's financial plight. It had been struggling for while, locked in a cut-throat circulation war with its arch-rival, the New York Post, which Rupert Murdoch once owned and would buy again a few years later. Indeed, many thought Maxwell wanted the News because his arch-rival had once owned a New York tabloid. Maxwell played up the image of white knight for all it was worth, once famously posing for the press at a newspaper kiosk, sporting a Daily News baseball cap.

At his office, a TV crew from PBS, the public TV station, had been waiting patiently to do an interview. The presenter, Charleyne Hunter-Gault, was as far in style from the blustering John Humphries as you could get. But she soon wound him up by rehashing questions about his dodgy finances. "Where did you get that from," he barked. Ms Gault told him the information had been supplied by a Financial Times journalist in Washington, Lionel Barber. I collared him in the Art Deco lobby of the News building, then located on 42nd Street, after one of those impromptu press conferences and handed him my card. He glanced imperiously at it, then looked up and down and purred: "Yes, I know the byline, call my secretary," then strode off. His secretary instructed me to turn up at his yacht, the Lady Ghislaine, named after his daughter, moored on the East River. So on a sunny day, I clambered on to his gleaming white yacht, the size of a small liner, the very boat from which he would disappear little more than a year later. There were two magazine hacks ahead of me, so I waited. And waited. My appointed time came and went as I sat on a sofa surrounded by the thickest of white shaggy carpets. A couple of hours later, he sauntered out, followed by his retinue, and invited me to accompany him to the News building, where he was to make his first appearance as the new owner of the News. During the short drive up FDR, the highway that hugs the East River, I asked him a few questions. He grew tetchy as soon I began quizzing him about the precarious finances of the News. That was the Maxwell way, at first charming, but quickly lapsing into irritability. But there was nothing new about the News's financial plight. It had been struggling for while, locked in a cut-throat circulation war with its arch-rival, the New York Post, which Rupert Murdoch once owned and would buy again a few years later. Indeed, many thought Maxwell wanted the News because his arch-rival had once owned a New York tabloid. Maxwell played up the image of white knight for all it was worth, once famously posing for the press at a newspaper kiosk, sporting a Daily News baseball cap. fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £155.54
Paul MacInnes = £55.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £48.46
Sean Ingle = £19.82

Scott Murray: Everton to win at West Ham - £5 @ 5/2

To quote the 1982 Scottish World Cup squad featuring John Gordon Sinclair and BA Robertson, I awoke in the night with a fever. The sky was the darkest blue, as well.

Suffice to say, I don't feel well. So I'm afraid you're not getting much out of me today, other than to say the Hammers are not exactly dependable sorts and Everton are unpredictable buggers not beyond posting the surprise away victory which will pull them away from the mire.

Nearly threes is good enough for me. Now I'm off to bed.

This week, Paul MacInnes is faffing around in Scotland on his holidays. Getting all drunk, we'll be bound.

James Araci from the Football Unlimited Punters Collective - £5 treble - Colchester v Luton: Luton to win @ 9/4; Arsenal v Tottenham: Tottenham to win @ 9/2; Liverpool v Man Utd: Liverpool to win @ 13/8

Being a Luton fan this season has bought home the meaning of the Chinese curse "May you live in interesting times". At the beginning of the season Ricky Hill was installed as the new Messiah, but after failing to lead us to the promised land was pushed into the wilderness. Super Lil Fucillo then stepped up to lift Luton from the abyss, but soon stepped aside for Joe Kinnear.

Big Fat Joe has bought the Wimbledon magic to the Luton team, with five wins and two draws out of nine games in charge. The pressure is still on, with Luton lying third from bottom, but there's a real spirit in the squad again. New goal celebrations are appearing thick and fast - from the conga to a risque "Ride the Poonani" number.

With new signing Steve Howard likely to partner a rejuvenated Mark Stein up front, I reckon this a banker. Young Turks like Lee Mansell and Matthew Taylor are keen to end the season on a high. And in an ideal world I'd lay five quid single down and dirty for a mighty Hatters win over a mediocre Colchester team.

With the glamour tie of the weekend banked - and because of the betting rules on singles from lower leagues - I'll put my faith in Hod's Spurs to strike down the Arsenal in the first of two Biblical encounters. I haven't been impressed with the Wenger Boys this season, but admire his fellow countryman's revolution at Liverpool. And what better way to stake a claim for the Premiership next season than to give the current aristocracy a black eye on Sky?

Sean Ingle: Juventus v Brescia - Draw half-time/Juventus to win at full-time £7.50 @ 4/1

This game looks a formality: Juventus will win, and will probably win big - and the bookies price of 2/9 reflects that. But I think there's value to be had here. Despite Brescia's poor recent run of form (they've lost three of their last four games), they were level in three of those matches (including against Lazio and Roma) so it's not inconceivable that Carlo Mazzone's men will hold out early, before going down late on.

And let's be honest: it's got a lot more chance of coming off than my planned Luton, Wimbledon and Millwall away win treble extravaganza.

fields.headline: Embracing the faiths
fields.standfirst: Mr Blair is proceeding with caution. Good
fields.trailText: In a nation like ours, with its rich traditions of scepticism, atheism and non-conformism, it is not surprising that a politician who dares talks about faith will be rewarded with an instant backlash.
fields.body:
In a nation like ours, with its rich traditions of scepticism, atheism and non-conformism, it is not surprising that a politician who dares talks about faith will be rewarded with an instant backlash. So it has been with Tony Blair - on both occasions. When the then leader of the opposition spoke of his relationship with his maker in the Easter run-up to the 1997 election, he was instantly lacerated for seeking to play the God card. Now, four years later and also in the lead-up to polling day, he has got the same response. No sooner had his date with the Christian Socialist Movement been set than he was scolded. "This is an agnostic nation," warned Roy Hattersley, fearful that Mr Blair's "evangelising" would only alienate those of a different faith or of none. "A dangerous precedent," muttered Labour MP Martin O'Neill.

In the event, did yesterday's address by the prime minister to the Christians justify the critics' fears? Not on one score. Liberals have always worried that a religious lead from a politician would frighten Britain's non-Christian minorities. Yet on yesterday's evidence, they hardly felt excluded: representatives from almost all Britain's "faith communities" were in attendance, while Mr Blair based a good part of his message on the ideas of the Chief Rabbi, Jonathan Sacks. The old notion that British multi-culturalism is threatened by a religiously inflected politics may have to be revised: Britain's ethnic minorities appear less uncomfortable with Downing Street Christianity than Britain's secularists and unaffiliated - who are, of course, the great majority.

But there are other concerns. Many worry that a new trend toward religious schools could see different communities shut off from each other, educated apart. Others fear government grants for religious agencies who would only hire people of their own faith, discriminating against others. Mr Blair avoided addressing these risks. But he did offer some reassurance. He made clear that his interest is in involving voluntary groups, including faith-based ones, in social work "as partners, not substitutes". The state will remain the chief agency and prime source of money, but it should be able to draw on both the commitment and infrastructure maintained by voluntary, including religious, groups. To want to use, rather than waste, that resource surely makes sense - whether you have a faith or not.

fields.headline: Press Gazette
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 30
fields.trailText: March 30: The watchdog panel set up at Express Newspapers is satisfied editorial integrity is being maintained.
fields.body:
The watchdog panel set up at Express Newspapers said this week it was satisfied editorial integrity was being maintained.

The BBC's business and economics journalists are next in line for the sort of shake-up that last year resulted in social affairs staff being picked for roles in either television or radio.

Marie O'Riordan, group publishing director for Emap Elan, has been poached to edit Marie Claire.

The National Magazine Company is planning to launch Cosmopolitan Bride.

A TV channel is to be launched in Hertfordshire as part of the Local Broadcasting Group's attempts to break into the market.

Journalists working for Emap Digital had their jobs threatened this week as the company announced plans to slash its online budget.

fields.headline: DTI Maxwell report 'lacks moral courage'
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Investigative journalist Tom Bower has slammed the DTI report into the Maxwell pensions scandal, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Tom Bower, the investigative journalist who was the scourge of Robert Maxwell, has lashed out at the report into the late tycoon's business dealings.

The author of Maxwell - the Final Verdict today said the DTI investigation lacked the "moral courage" to take the City of London to task over its role in Maxwell's affairs.

"It is a limited report. The inspectors did not have the moral courage to ruthlessly expose the City of London's lack of honesty. I think it is a cop-out," said Mr Bower.

Investment bank Goldman Sachs and accountancy firm Coopers & Lybrand, now part of PriceWaterhouseCoopers, were severely criticised in the report for their role in the seriously flawed flotation of Mirror Group Newspapers in 1991.

Mr Bower said he expected the Maxwell investigation to be closed, despite the fact no one had reached the bottom of the pensions scandal, which saw £450m disappear from Mirror Group pension funds.

"I think it is the end of the whole affair and it shows that nothing has changed in the 10 years since Maxwell died. Whitehall and the City are just as incompetent as they were back then," he added.

Mr Bower, who also wrote investigations into Richard Branson and Mohamed Al Fayed said the report, which heavily criticised Maxwell's sons and several City institutions, had not added to his substantial investigations into the Maxwell empire.

"You might as well rewrite what I have published. It takes nothing forward. They must have had an unspoken agenda for the whole thing," he added.

webTitle: Your views on the Glenn Hoddle affair

fields.headline: Your views on the Glenn Hoddle affair
fields.trailText: Are the Saints more sinners than sinned against in the Glenn Hoddle affair? Chris Nickson certainly thinks so.
fields.body:
Are the Saints more sinners than sinned against in the Glenn Hoddle affair? Chris Nickson certainly thinks so.

"I can't understand the way that Saints fans are vilifying their former hero, Hoddle," he says. "Southampton had absolutely no problem appointing him as manager over incumbent Dave Jones without a care about the effect on a good man who had been the subject of appalling accusations and desperately needed support.

"Even after his name was properly cleared was he reinstated? No. And that's because a better opportunity for success had presented itself. Just like it has for Glenn."

Olu Alake agrees. "I can't believe Rupert Lowe bleating on about being betrayed by Glen Hoddle - this from the man who kicked poor Davey Jones when he was down and assured him that Hoddle was only meant to be keeping his seat warm for him pending the end of his court case!

"Saints should be grateful for what Hoddle has done for them," he adds. "They are on course to finish higher than they ever have and their new stadium would not mean a thing in the First Divison where they probably would have been without Hoddle's massive contribution.

"On the other hand, I have serious reservations about Hoddle's return to White Hart Lane. We see time and again is that heroes should never go back to the scenes of their greatest triumphs. I fear another Ardiles situation for Hoddle."

Steve Evans agrees. "Hoddle was always overrated in my view," he says. "He hardly ever got in the national side, was soft, couldn't tackle, in short another Darren Anderton. Which probably explains why Anderton likes him so much. Will Eileen Drewery be the assistant manager again?"

Meanwhile Tim Kuschill can't understand the reports saying that Keegan would be a popular choice at the Dell.

"His name has been bandied around since almost the beginning of the year as a potential replacement, and I have not heard anyone at the Dell come out in his support," he says. "Yes, he's a big name, and Hoddle's appointment has raised the bar for the club, but Keegan is not seen as a good choice.

"As a player, he was at the Dell for a couple of seasons only, then deserted us, so his popularity on that score is dubious at best. In management he has always been given a huge amount of money to play with, and then has either jumped quickly when things have got rough (Newcastle and England) or something tastier has come his way (Fulham). Will it be any different at Southampton?

David Lacey takes some flak

"You invite comments on your website, so here's a simple plea I've yearned to put to the Guardian for years," writes Will Montgomery. Well, go on then Will

"Could someone, please, take David Lacey aside and ask him to stop inflicting those excruciating extended metaphors on us in his opening paragraphs?" he asks. "Once in a while they work, to be sure, but more often than not they're so creaky that they make me wince. The sense of bathos as those tortuous conceits clunk to a close is overwhelming - I've caught myself groaning aloud in packed tube carriages.

"Please, can you do anything about this?"

Well have you tried not reading Mr Lacey on the tube?

But Will's not the only one giving the Guardian's chief football writer some flak.

"Why it is that David Lacey persists in taking a rather miserable attitude whenever anything good comes along? Six points was all England could have wished for and that is what England got; well done that team," writes Michael Moore.

"And apart from taking a miserable stance, his writing suffers from too many comparisons with military matters. No this is not war, this is art; and thus managers are not 'sandbagging' the midfield and 'laying mines' for opposing players but are providing entertainment for millions of people.

"To me there appears little difference between taking the view that football is best reported as a continuation of warfare by different means and the ignorant thugs who wrap themselves in their national flags. So do yourself a favour and forget about the war mate; it's over."

Anyone else? Oh, go on then Andrew Polley

"Harping back to Johnny Haynes and Bobby Charlton is exactly what we do not want to have," he says. "Let's move forward.

"Unless Mr Lacey is deliberately pampering to that part of your readership that over 65, and needs conversational pieces as they sip their pints in retirement, why not move your own thinking forward? PS. I'm 49 years old."

There's also plenty of emails from Andy Cole supporters angry that Mr Lacey "recited the tabloid line" about the Manchester striker not scoring in his previous 12 caps. But it's also worth pointing out that David Lacey does have his supporters. Malcolm Davey calls him "a national treasure", while Mike Wilkinson - who while claiming that Mr Lacey's article today attacking England's defence is "somewhat unjustified" - still says: "Keep up the good work, your articles are always entertaining."

webTitle: Fuel payment rise a crude bribe, claims Lib Dem

fields.headline: Fuel payment rise a crude bribe, claims Lib Dem
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is being accused of increasing pensioners' winter fuel payments as a "crude bribe" amid claims that the government plans to cut the grants by one quarter later this year.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is being accused of increasing pensioners' winter fuel payments as a "crude bribe" amid claims that the government plans to cut the grants by one quarter later this year.

Research by the Liberal Democrats has indicated that the government's spending projections for 2001-2 onwards are based on fuel grants of £150 - £50 less than in the current year.

In his pre-budget statement last autumn, the chancellor raised the level of the payments, made to all pensioners, to £200, rather than the £150 ministers had previously suggested.

The Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, Steve Webb, challenged Mr Brown to make clear whether the government would maintain the grants at the increased level. He said: "This is either a pretty crude election bribe and will be cut by a quarter six months after the likely election, or they will not cut it, in which case they need to find £400m from somewhere. Either way, the chancellor has questions to answer."

The winter fuel payment was introduced in 1997-98, and for the following year was set at £20 for most pensioners and £50 for those of them on income support. The rate was increased to £100 for all pensioners in 1999-2000.

A parliamentary answer to a question tabled by Mr Webb details the rise in government spending on the payments from £200m when first introduced to £1.7bn in the current financial year. However, the reply, by social security minister Jeff Rooker, did not answer Mr Webb's call for details of planned spending on the grants.

The Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, Steve Webb, challenged Mr Brown to make clear whether the government would maintain the grants at the increased level. He said: "This is either a pretty crude election bribe and will be cut by a quarter six months after the likely election, or they will not cut it, in which case they need to find £400m from somewhere. Either way, the chancellor has questions to answer." The winter fuel payment was introduced in 1997-98, and for the following year was set at £20 for most pensioners and £50 for those of them on income support. The rate was increased to £100 for all pensioners in 1999-2000. A parliamentary answer to a question tabled by Mr Webb details the rise in government spending on the payments from £200m when first introduced to £1.7bn in the current financial year. However, the reply, by social security minister Jeff Rooker, did not answer Mr Webb's call for details of planned spending on the grants.

webTitle: Military men make a splash in Brussels

fields.headline: Military men make a splash in Brussels
fields.standfirst: The EU's defence identity is starting to take shape, as officials work out the details of a rapid reaction force, writes Ian Black
fields.trailText: The EU's defence identity is starting to take shape, as officials work out the details of a rapid reaction force, writes Ian Black.
fields.body:
It is lunchtime in the centre of Brussels and eurocrats are sitting down to steak frites in the subsidised canteen of the EU council of ministers. Dark suits are the norm for male "fonctionnaires" (officials).

It is, however, the military olive greens, blues and khakis that catch the eye, with the discreet flash of gold braid or a brightly coloured epaulette.

Until last year, nothing more exciting or secret than fishing quotas and environmental standards was discussed in the pink stone 'bunker' that houses the council - where the union's 15 governments cooperate.

Yet the gradual development of the EU's defence identity has brought scores of uniformed soldiers, sailors and airmen to the institutional heart of Europe to plan for future conflicts and crises.

None of these well-tailored chaps are fighting men with mud on their boots, but rather armchair warriors waging the battles that need to be won before the EU can add some military muscle to the economic weight of its mighty single market and single currency.

This week, another significant landmark was passed when the 15 chiefs of staff recommended their Finnish colleague, Gustav Hagglund, as the chairman of the EU military committee for the next three years.

This will take him past the union's self-imposed deadline of 2003 for deploying a 60,000-strong rapid reaction force (RRF) on peacekeeping and humanitarian duties.

Mr Hagglund - neat in grey with red flashes and an impressive array of medal ribbons - is a fit-looking 62-year-old who enjoys bear-hunting, and had flown to Brussels after a few days in Lappland, where it was a bracing minus 26.

So exactly how did his committee fit into the complex "spaghetti junction'' of interlocking bureaucracies?

"I'm just a simple general," he quipped, "you'll have to ask the politicians".

Political sensitivities are immense. No EU member state, least of all Britain, is talking about creating a "European army". British officials insist that any decision to deploy the RRF would be made by consensus. No EU member would be forced to participate in any operation.

It is also inconceivable that the EU would plunge into a crisis without the support of Nato and the US, after the atlantic alliance is given "first refusal".

It is the question of relations between the EU force and Nato that generates most anxiety - in both Brussels and Washington.

British Conservatives were quick to protest that the appointment of a neutral like Mr Hagglund - Finland sat out the cold war - was a rebuff to the alliance. (Ireland, Austria and Sweden are the only other EU members who are not in Nato).

And there was much wincing when the French chief of staff, General Jean-Pierre Kelche, insisted that Paris - always ambivalent about Nato - wanted the EU force to be independent, and operational by the end of the year.

National balances - what insiders call the "bums on seats factor" - have to be carefully maintained. Klaus Schuwirth, a German general, heads the 50-strong military staff. Graham Messervy-Whiting, a British soldier with fluent French and a background in intelligence, is his deputy. Denmark has sent a dapper official to take charge of the situation room.

Other member states are represented in key committees, where senior diplomats discuss what instructions to give the soldiers. All answer to Spain's Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo.

Mr Solana's official title is "High Representative and Secretary-General of the Council of Ministers". Translated from euro-speak, that means he works for the 15 governments, not the supranational European commission.

And here is a problem. It makes no sense, some EU-watchers argue, to have Solana answering to national capitals, which often have their own agendas, while the union's massive foreign-aid budget - and the leverage it brings - is controlled by the commission, where Britain's Chris Patten is in charge of external relations.

In the long run, argues Charles Grant of the Centre for European Reform, a London-based thinktank, a single person should replace the high representative and the external relations commissioner to represent the union more coherently to the rest of the world.

But for now, experts are more worried about the tanks, transport aircraft, satellites and other equipment that are needed if the EU is to have any divisions at all. The strongest impulse behind the whole project was the realisation of the yawning - and humiliating - gap between European and American capabilities in the 1999 Kosovo crisis, and in Bosnia before that.

Americans still get far more bang for their buck. But European defence procurement is not moving as fast as the officers taking up their positions in the new institutions in Brussels.

The crisis in Macedonia has been another sharp reminder of the need to develop the EU's military capabilities and reduce automatic dependence on Nato. "If there was ever an argument for the RRF, Macedonia was it," Mr Patten observed at the Stockholm summit.

The next big step comes in May, when the soldiers move out of the council "bunker", which Solana complained last year had as many holes as a Swiss cheese, and into specially converted, secure premises up the road. It will have dedicated computer systems for classified documents and proper guards to keep spies and terrorists at bay.

Slowly but surely, Europe is starting to get used to the novelty. "We are trying hard to help the union come to terms with the fact that there is a security and defence culture coming in," says one key figure. "We have to get used to each other."

But the generals do not want to rush things: "We are lucky we have till 2003 to become fully operational,'' laughed Owe Wagermark, the Swedish airborne commander who sits on the military committee.

"We need time, and we all need to change."

webTitle: Heidi movie brings Swiss heroine into the 21st century

fields.headline: Heidi movie brings Swiss heroine into the 21st century
fields.trailText: A new movie about Johanna Spyri's famous character has been released this week in Switzerland to mark the centenary of the author's death
fields.body:
More than 100 years after she first appeared, Heidi, probably the most famous of Swiss exports, has hit the big screen with a new, 21st-century look.

A century after the death of Heidi's author Johanna Spyri, the Alpine heroine and her goat herd (fortunately not affected by foot and mouth) are being portrayed in a world inhabited by skyscrapers and single-parent families.

"This is a modern Heidi, a young person with contemporary ideas and principles, a heroine who is a go-getter and who touches us by simple, intuitive integrity," Markus Imboden, the movie's director, told CNN.

The $3.5m (£2.45m) movie, called unsurprisingly Heidi, opened in Switzerland this week. It is one of the highlights of the events leading up to the July 7 centenary of the death of Spyri.

Heidi, one of the most successful books of all time, has sold around 20 million copies and inspired 15 films, including Shirley Temple's famous 1937 version.

 For more on Heidi and its author.

webTitle: Foot and mouth and the media

fields.headline: Day 39: foot and mouth and the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Day 39: Each of the papers takes a different tack but most run a picture of William Hague disinfecting his shoes.
fields.body:
The Sun
Classic stuff from the Sun - a gigantic close-up of a woman's breasts and a front-page splash on Popstars' "Nasty" Nigel Lythgoe - and not a dead cow in sight. Foot and mouth makes the briefest of appearances, just a small piece on Tony Blair's plea to US tourists to visit the UK. But foot and mouth "lifestyle" surfaces in an extensive piece on vegetarianism under the banner: "With CJD and F&M, no wonder everyone's going veggie".

The Mirror
The Mirror's readers obviously feel the same as the Sun's about pictures of dead animals littering their paper. Instead, there's a photo of William Hague disinfecting his shoes. An investigation into packaged beef and pork products on sale in London's Chinatown dominates the one page devoted to foot and mouth coverage.

Daily Express
The smoking pyre picture makes a return but not until page 11. The accompanying piece, however, examines the election date issue. But even General Sir Michael Jackson, he of the "panther lope and fearsome reputation", admits to being shocked by the "killing fields of Cumbria". So it's no wonder newspaper readers are feeling queasy.

The Guardian
The spectre of wartime rationing appears on the front page with Lord Haskins, chairman of Northern Foods, warning milk shortages are inevitable. On page four, foot and mouth coverage includes farmers' fears about the vaccination programme, an organic farmer's court battle to block slaughter, a piece about the drugs used to kill lambs and piglets running out and how the army is winning farmers' support. Not forgetting that picture of Mr Hague disinfecting his shoes, again. Mr Hague is, according to one of his party, "having a good war".

Daily Mail
The picture of Mr Hague disinfecting his shoes appears, accompanied by a piece about mounting pressure on Mr Blair to postpone the election. The Daily Mail's Farm Aid appeal goes glam, with the announcement of a fund-raising gala concert to be held at the Royal Albert Hall. It will star the Royal Ballet, who will pirouette to the aid of farmers nationwide.

The Independent
Gordon Brown is to finally get his chance to lead the Labour party into an election. According to the front-page story, the government is drawing up a plan for Mr Blair to play a low-key role in the party's election campaign in the face of the foot and mouth crisis. The Indy has a picture of Mr Hague's car - rather than his shoes - being disinfected.

webTitle: Through the Looking Glass by Liz Davies (II)

fields.headline: The odd couple
fields.standfirst:
Blair's sentences are often ungrammatical and littered with non sequiturs. Prescott speaks clearly and concisely. Some mistake, surely? Not according to Liz Davies, who watched the PM and his deputy in action during two years as a member of the Labour party's governing body. In the final extract from her revealing memoir, she describes an improbable double act

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Blair's sentences are often ungrammatical and littered with non sequiturs. Prescott speaks clearly and concisely. Some mistake, surely? Not according to Liz Davies, who watched the PM and his deputy in action during two years as a member of the Labour party's governing body. In the final extract from her revealing memoir, she describes an improbable double act.
fields.body:
I was rather nervous meeting John Prescott for the first time. His car pulled up outside the TUC's Congress House headquarters during an "awayday" for the national executive committee on October 27 1998. It was lunchtime and I was standing outside the building with Tribune editor Mark Seddon and Sally Powell, who represented Labour councillors on the NEC.

Prescott wandered over to us and started chatting amiably, asking how the morning had gone. Here was the deputy prime minister, gossiping informally! He was saying that he was late because he had been defending Labour MP Alan Meale, then his parliamentary private secretary. Two days previously, the papers had been full of stories about Meale lobbying ministers in Prescott's department over a planning inquiry on behalf of a wealthy Cypriot businessman.

Prescott said jovially: "We don't want to hang Alan Meale out to dry," and then, patting me on the arm and smiling, added: "It's you that we want to hang out to dry!" I was taken aback, but managed to stammer out "Good to meet you, too, John" in reply.

After that encounter I was struck by the difference between Tony Blair and John Prescott on the NEC.

Blair clearly found the national executive committee and the party machinery in general an irritating distraction. His introductory remarks were always fairly peremptory and he appeared to be on autopilot. When he replied, he gushed over the supportive questions and dismissed the difficult ones as quickly as possible. His aim seemed to be to moan about dissident Labour party members - and then to leave as soon as he decently could.

Over the next two years, I was frequently surprised at how preoccupied Blair was with what he saw as "ungrateful" Labour party members rocking the boat, and how rarely he would actually engage with any of the political issues raised at the NEC.

I also found myself struggling to make sense of some of his responses. He genuinely does speak in short, choppy sentences, often without verbs, and moves relentlessly from one non sequitur to another. Unusually for a lawyer, he seems uninterested in arguing his case. He took it for granted that the NEC was there to express appreciation - and seemed to regard it as a personal insult that some of us actually wanted to ask him questions.

Prescott, on the other hand, would usually stay for the duration of the NEC and would engage in arguments. Unlike Blair, he spoke in clear, concise sentences and his point was always understandable. Contrary to his television and parliamentary image, he appears to choose his words with care.

But he never uttered a word that deviated in the slightest from the New Labour message. During Blair's report, he would remain silent, nodding helpfully at certain key messages Blair was trying to deliver. Towards the end of of the questions to Blair, Prescott sometimes came in on subjects within his particular responsibility, such as transport. After Blair left the meetings, it was Prescott's job to put the government's or Millbank's line, which he did with total commitment.

He came over to me as someone who had spent a lifetime operating in labour movement meetings. He has a more informal, blunt style than Blair and likes to sound down-to-earth, but he knows exactly what he is doing. At an NEC held a year later, he declared, "I bloody hate PR," in what sounded like an off-the-cuff remark. When it found its way into all the newspapers the following day, I realised it had been pre-arranged and carefully calculated.

Prescott is quick-witted, and utterly cynical. He is also well-briefed by Millbank, and will suddenly take out from his papers a public comment or newspaper article written by a member of the NEC and given to him by the Millbank press office.

I have never seen a hint of the much-vaunted division between Prescott and Blair. Of course, the apparent New Labour, "old Labour" distinction between the men is useful for both of them, and for the New Labour project. Whenever New Labour is committed to a policy that appears unpalatable to ordinary Labour party members, such as cuts to benefits, or privatisation of public services, Prescott plays a useful role. He is able to use his "old Labour" image to suggest that the policy is really progressive, and deserves the party's support. He can sell the policies to constituencies that distrust Blair. In reality, however, Blair and Prescott are two sides of the same coin.

Trouble with the press, a voting fiasco, and the union reps who kept quiet

On last year's leaked Downing Street memos

When Blair arrived at the NEC in July 2000, he concentrated on his favourite themes: the press and the Tories. Unusually, the third theme, the perfidy of party members, was absent: "The press have been giving us a hard time over the last few months."

What Blair did not say, but many of us were thinking, was that the press had been giving him a hard time over the last few months - the widespread criticism of his suggestion that there should be on-the-spot fines for "hooligans", his son Euan's escapade, and leaked emails revealing how preoccupied he was with his public image. Dennis Skinner warned Blair: "You need to be careful how you carry on in memos. Don't whinge, don't whine."

On counting votes

Conference momentarily regained its old fire in 1999 when Barbara Castle was given a chance to speak on pensions. People were hanging on her every word and Millbank apparatchiks rushed around looking anxious when Brighton delegate Claire Wadey then explained her constituency was against the private finance initiative so would oppose the entire economic policy document. Veron Hince in the chair reminded conference it could not refer back part of the document and put it to the vote. Delegates, furious there was no specific vote on PFI, for once did not do as they were told and the vote was lost.

Hince became agitated and called for a revote on the ground that delegates must have not understood the purpose of the first vote. So there was a second vote - and the document was again defeated. Suddenly, conference was growling. The next morning, Michael Cashman was chairing conference. His first announcement was that conference had been "confused" the previous afternoon and he was going to take another vote.Conference then went to a vote, and, of course, enough arms had been twisted the previous evening so this time the vote went according to the Millbank script. The document was approved.

On Millbank and the unions

The trade union representatives were the only people at the national executive meetings with a real chance to challenge New Labour's agenda, and they could have made a difference if they had wanted to. Mary Turner (GMB) made her points about public sector work, Derek Hodgson (CWU) bristled over Post Office privatisation, Diana Holland (TGWU) raised employment rights and gender issues.

Although their muted criticism rarely translated into votes or any follow-up action, their interventions were uncomfortable for Millbank. None of the other trade union representatives uttered so much as a whisper of protest at privatisation, cuts to public sector workers, the low level of the minimum wage, or the government's pensions policy.

Yet nearly all of them represent unions opposed to privatisation, and in favour of an index-linked minimum wage and restoring the link between pensions and earnings. Their bargain with Millbank seemed to be that, provided Blair, Prescott and the others argued the government's case in a language of social justice, they would not press union policies at the NEC. For them, as for many others in New Labour, the height of political sophistication consists of saying what you don't believe in order to maintain some unquantifiable and virtually indiscernible "influence" over a leadership that holds you in contempt.

On leaving the NEC

I went back early to London last year from the conference in Brighton on the train, happy to miss my very last opportunity to attend the NEC. It would be the annual ritual, with both the old and the new members present. I hoped I had avoided the indignity of being officially thanked by Blair for my work on the NEC, but three weeks later, a framed certificate arrived in the post.

It was "in recognition of service on the NEC" and was signed by Blair and Margaret McDonagh [general secretary of the Labour party]. It was accompanied by a formal thank-you letter from McDonagh - the only letter I received from her (besides notices of meetings and documents) during my two years on the NEC. I've not yet decided what to do with the certificate.

I have never seen a hint of the much-vaunted division between Prescott and Blair. Of course, the apparent New Labour, "old Labour" distinction between the men is useful for both of them, and for the New Labour project. Whenever New Labour is committed to a policy that appears unpalatable to ordinary Labour party members, such as cuts to benefits, or privatisation of public services, Prescott plays a useful role. He is able to use his "old Labour" image to suggest that the policy is really progressive, and deserves the party's support. He can sell the policies to constituencies that distrust Blair. In reality, however, Blair and Prescott are two sides of the same coin. Trouble with the press, a voting fiasco, and the union reps who kept quiet On last year's leaked Downing Street memos When Blair arrived at the NEC in July 2000, he concentrated on his favourite themes: the press and the Tories. Unusually, the third theme, the perfidy of party members, was absent: "The press have been giving us a hard time over the last few months." What Blair did not say, but many of us were thinking, was that the press had been giving him a hard time over the last few months - the widespread criticism of his suggestion that there should be on-the-spot fines for "hooligans", his son Euan's escapade, and leaked emails revealing how preoccupied he was with his public image. Dennis Skinner warned Blair: "You need to be careful how you carry on in memos. Don't whinge, don't whine." On counting votes Conference momentarily regained its old fire in 1999 when Barbara Castle was given a chance to speak on pensions. People were hanging on her every word and Millbank apparatchiks rushed around looking anxious when Brighton delegate Claire Wadey then explained her constituency was against the private finance initiative so would oppose the entire economic policy document. Veron Hince in the chair reminded conference it could not refer back part of the document and put it to the vote. Delegates, furious there was no specific vote on PFI, for once did not do as they were told and the vote was lost. Hince became agitated and called for a revote on the ground that delegates must have not understood the purpose of the first vote. So there was a second vote - and the document was again defeated. Suddenly, conference was growling. The next morning, Michael Cashman was chairing conference. His first announcement was that conference had been "confused" the previous afternoon and he was going to take another vote.Conference then went to a vote, and, of course, enough arms had been twisted the previous evening so this time the vote went according to the Millbank script. The document was approved. On Millbank and the unions The trade union representatives were the only people at the national executive meetings with a real chance to challenge New Labour's agenda, and they could have made a difference if they had wanted to. Mary Turner (GMB) made her points about public sector work, Derek Hodgson (CWU) bristled over Post Office privatisation, Diana Holland (TGWU) raised employment rights and gender issues. Although their muted criticism rarely translated into votes or any follow-up action, their interventions were uncomfortable for Millbank. None of the other trade union representatives uttered so much as a whisper of protest at privatisation, cuts to public sector workers, the low level of the minimum wage, or the government's pensions policy. Yet nearly all of them represent unions opposed to privatisation, and in favour of an index-linked minimum wage and restoring the link between pensions and earnings. Their bargain with Millbank seemed to be that, provided Blair, Prescott and the others argued the government's case in a language of social justice, they would not press union policies at the NEC. For them, as for many others in New Labour, the height of political sophistication consists of saying what you don't believe in order to maintain some unquantifiable and virtually indiscernible "influence" over a leadership that holds you in contempt. On leaving the NEC I went back early to London last year from the conference in Brighton on the train, happy to miss my very last opportunity to attend the NEC. It would be the annual ritual, with both the old and the new members present. I hoped I had avoided the indignity of being officially thanked by Blair for my work on the NEC, but three weeks later, a framed certificate arrived in the post. It was "in recognition of service on the NEC" and was signed by Blair and Margaret McDonagh [general secretary of the Labour party]. It was accompanied by a formal thank-you letter from McDonagh - the only letter I received from her (besides notices of meetings and documents) during my two years on the NEC. I've not yet decided what to do with the certificate.

fields.headline: New Big Breakfast boss brought in to make show more appetising
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Big Breakfast producer Planet 24 has appointed a new executive producer to oversee the struggling show, reports Jason Deans
fields.body:
Big Breakfast producer Planet 24 has brought in a new executive producer to oversee the struggling show.

Ben Rigden will take over from Richard Hopkins, who oversaw the revamp of the daily breakfast programme following the departure of presenters Johnny Vaughan and Denise Van Outen in mid-January.

Under Mr Hopkins a new five-strong presenting team of Melanie Sykes, Paul Tonkinson, Amanda Bryam, Donna Air and Richard Bacon was brought in and a new set introduced.

But Big Breakfast's ratings are still in the doldrums at around 300,000 despite the changes introduced by Mr Hopkins.

The change of personnel was not linked to any concerns about Big Breakfast's editorial direction or ratings, according to one insider.

"It's more about contract renewal than quitting or getting sacked," the source said. "These guys tend to have six-month contracts with an option to renew. Richard just chose not to renew."

Mr Hopkins had come to the Big Breakfast job straight from Big Brother. He worked on the revamp in a separate office before taking over as executive producer when Ed Forsdick stepped down on February 2.

Mr Rigden, a Big Breakfast managing editor who has worked on the show on and off over the past four years, is not expected to make dramatic changes, but will build on the changes introduced by Mr Hopkins, according to the Big Breakfast insider.

The revamp was designed to reposition the show to attract a slightly older, 16 to 17 year-old audience, rather than 14 and 15-year-olds.

A Big Breakfast spokesman said there was no question of Channel 4 dropping the show.

"They could have axed it back in the days of Sharon Davies or Kelly Brook, but they've stuck with it. They see it as a resilient brand," he said.

fields.headline: Schools 'turn tide' after privatisation
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: Ofsted
fields.trailText: The privately-run education service in Islington yesterday won a positive report from the inspection service, Ofsted, which said the "tide had turned" in the London borough.
fields.body:
The privately-run education service in Islington yesterday won a positive report from the inspection service, Ofsted, which said the "tide had turned" in the London borough.

The local education authority had been "in disarray" when it was first inspected in 1999. But since Cambridge Education Services - the first private firm to be brought in to run an LEA - took over on a seven-year, £90m contract in April 2000, "a sense of purpose and optimism has been instilled", Ofsted said.

"The task facing the LEA has been a formidable one, but to a remarkable extent, it has been successfully accomplished. The LEA is now viable," the report said. But Ofsted also said that only just over half of the contract targets agreed between CEA and the borough were likely to be met.

Secondary head teachers remained sceptical and their targets were not set high enough. "An act of faith is now needed from the secondary schools, whose engagement is central to further progress. When that is secured, it will be possible to draw a line under the past."

The report was welcomed by Vincent McDonnell, head of CEA@Islington. "The targets set in the contract are very tough - and we have known this from the outset. But we are clearly focused on our main priority which is to raise standards for Islington's young people, who deserve the best," he said.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said: "When we embarked on our intervention policy for failing local education authorities we were entering uncharted waters. We had to ensure that the drift and uncertainty was replaced by clear vision and sound strategic management. It is clearly paying off in Islington where there had been a long history of false starts, raised hopes and new dawns."

Meanwhile, a report by Ofsted on Bristol LEA said improvements had been made but it still had "significant weaknesses".

It warned that the referendum last month in which council tax payers voted for a freeze in council tax meant that the education service faced a 1.6% cut in its budget next year. "The lack of a long-term strategy for funding education has left elected members poorly prepared to make the right decisions on where cuts must fall," Ofsted said.

Ms Morris said a new "partnership board" with key local players and an independent chairman would be brought in to oversee education strategy in the city.

 Special report on Ofsted at www.theguardian.com/education/ofsted

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Does Dennis Skinner, acclaimed absurdist and MP for Bolsover have a passport or not? In retrospect, this Diary never really cared either way when it called his Westminster office yesterday to ask.
fields.body:
 Does Dennis Skinner, acclaimed absurdist and MP for Bolsover have a passport or not? In retrospect, this Diary never really cared either way when it called his Westminster office yesterday to ask. His tortuous reply, which can be subbed down without much difficulty (he had one, it lapsed, he got another), plunges us into a nightmare universe where paranoia reigns, every other word is "pit", and Dennis is always on the phone.

"There is a lot of cynicism in the press and media," he rages. "This is just like when people say I'm against the Common Market because I'm a Little Englander". Is it? "Yes. It's rubbish - they lump it in together. I don't support handing over power to quangos in Britain, and I don't want unelected bodies in Luxembourg deciding things because we haven't elected them."

Goodbye, then, and many thanks for the no to the passport question. "Why a thank you - what's this all about? I don't know why you're doing this. I'm not a hypocrite. I deal in facts - I'm giving you the facts..." Yes, again, many thanks Dennis, and goodbye as we really must get on.

 That garrulous turncoat Sin Simon has been at it again, with a quite breathtaking apologia in yesterday's Telegraph media pages. His carpetbag barely unpacked from that Birmingham Erdington mission last week, Sin is cross that he is not singled out for his special courage in writing columns for the rightwing Telegraph and News of the World. And how right he is, for what is £100,000-plus if one isn't loved by all?

"Even more galling," he frets, "is the spectacle of all the other leftwing columnists who write for more leftwing publications. I see them counting their rosettes and polishing their medals while I'm scraping the egg and flour from my coat." Be not galled, Sin, for this extraodinary rot means you may yet have a new coat all of your own. Even Diary pundit Steptoe is dumbstruck, and has hauled you in from 66-1 to 16-1.

 Contacts book cack handedness causes the Diary to dredge up and dial Labour HQ at the old Walworth Road number, with alarming consequences. "No no no - this is not Labour," shouts an irate Greek gentleman. "How many times have I said - this is a kebab shop. Goodbye!" We hope to return to this unfortunate number reassignment next week, if only to bait Millbank with late-night doner orders.

 Lord Michael Henderson: An Apology. In yesterday's edition of the Diary, we published an item in which we erroneously referred to Telegraph cricket hack Hendo as a "renaissance man". Lord Hendo has been in touch and has asked us to point out that he is a reformation man, believing the centre of Europe to be the Rhine, and not Tuscany as our article suggested. As a gesture of goodwill, we are pleased to mention that he will be a guest on Radio 3 music show Private Passions this Saturday. "It should be worth listening to," says Hendo, "as I've completely forgotten what I said."

 Surveillance: Daily Mail writer Toby Young, looking completely bald, in a picture byline accompanying his incisive piece on why William Hague is better off without hair. Toby looked fine, though dramatically different to the wavy-haired impostor who graced the same spot in his "My friend Liz Hurley" feature in Wednesday's paper.

 Just as we are hanging the "closed" sign on the Diary's door, Dennis Skinner roars back into life with a frantic telephone call. "What is this rubbish? This is just an attempt to undermine me before the election, isn't it? You're supposed to be a Labour newspaper. What is this? Knock Dennis Skinner time? Are you going to tell more lies? Are you?" Alas there is no more space for his thoughts today, but we hope to buddy him up with Andrew Neil in our planned diary persecution complex support group.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText:
Cheapskate ... Where to eat out for under £15
K10 , 20 Copthall Ave, London EC2.
Tel: 020-7562 8510
fields.body:
Cheapskate ... Where to eat out for under £15
K10 , 20 Copthall Ave, London EC2.
Tel: 020-7562 8510

K10 is a kaiten (geddit) restaurant, which means it's another of those conveyor-belt eateries, the wonderful Japanese invention designed to appeal to the choo-choo lover inside every small City trader. Stuck down in a basement next to the smoothies of Cazenove & Co, K10 may be, but minimalist lines, snake-hipped bar, crunchy chrome, midnight neon and sexy pale shades could mean that you're in any trendy eaterie on any trendy planet this side of Mars. But the sushi and sashimi trundling past your nose is the real thing; there is also tempura and noodles and some east/west concoctions to liven up the choice. Don't get too carried away or you'll be through the £15 barrier in no time.

Quick bites ... Where to eat out in 15 minutes
St John, 26 St John Street, London EC1
Tel: 020-7251 0848

All right, I know St John is a pukka restaurant, shortlisted for top honours in the Moët et Chandon London restaurant awards and all that, but people forget that it does admirable Guzzler-priced bar meals - lamb and green sauce sandwich, brawn, trotter and mash, Welsh rarebit, dripping toast, cold duck breast and pickled damsons, celeriac and boiled egg, Eccles cake and Lancashire cheese. There's more for the unreconstructed carnivore than the epicurean veggie, but it's all very good stuff, and vfm around the £5-£8 mark. Serious bread, brilliant beers, proper wines. Why can't more restaurants do something equally intelligent?

On the menu: Beignet

Pronounced how? Bay-nyay.

Wha-hay, bay-nyay. And it is? A kind of fritter.

Explain. You take a morsel, dip it in choux pastry, deep fry it and there's a beignet.

Like fish for fish and chips, you mean? The principle is the same. The batter should be light and crisp rather than soggy as wet cardboard and oozing fat.

So if not fish, what? Oysters, bananas, jam, aubergines, goat's cheese, ham and cheese or just choux pastry.

Anything else we should know? Also known as pet de nonne or nun's fart (French), bigne (Italian), bunelos de vento (Spanish), sonhos (Portugal and Brazil)

On the net: Lakeland Limited

Lakeland Limited has been around for ages, peddling those little plastic klippits for fastening freezer bags, and baking trays galore. Nowadays they're a massive enterprise, with many stores, a mail-order service, and this rather lovely online abode. At the moment they're all shook up about Easter, and are offering egg-painting kits and hot cross bunnies alongside a curious duck-shaped popcorn dispenser. Elsewhere you'll find Madagascan bourbon vanilla extract for £4.95, pizza baking stones, recipes for oatmeal cookies, and the scarily-named "mermaid roasting trays". There's also a special collection, smiled upon by Delia, containing such essentials as olive stoners, pillivuyt ramekins and exquisite martini glasses. No silver telephone diallers though.

Just out: Momokawa Pearl Sake

Form: pale yellowy/grey, cloudy liquid.

Flavour: slightly sweet, quite creamy, distinctly fruity, extremely potent.

Verdict: unfiltered sake, brewed in US at 18% proof (strewth). Should be be served slightly chilled and is aimed at the recherché cocktail market, rather than the serious sake connoisseur. Undeniably, a smooth number and one of a whole range of Momokawa sakes in sexy bottles with "drink-me" labels; if this is the kind of thing you'll like, you'll like this kind of thing. Only available in bars and restaurants. I think it needs the sushi, myself.

Cost: Depends on bars and restaurants (Momokawa Ruby sake is available at Waitrose: £5.99 for a 750ml bottle).

The taste test: pickle

Koreans have kimchi, the Italians sottaceto. Once in China, women were judged by the quality of their pickles. Our supermarkets have their sweet pickles. What would their marriage prospects be?

Brand: Somerfield
Price: £0.55/310g
What it's like: Good, clean, upright pickle; medium cut; medium weight
Rating: *****

Brand: Waitrose Sweet
Price: £0.55/310g
What it's like:
Genteel pickle with saucy flavour medley
Rating: *****

Brand: Asda Sweet Harvest
Price: £0.79/454g
What it's like: Chunky cut and chewy; well rounded
Rating: ***

Brand: Tesco Sandwich
Price: £0.55/310g
What it's like: More push than pickle, but balanced over all
Rating: ***

Brand: Safeway
Price: £0.95/624g
What it's like: Acid indigestion
Rating: ***

fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.trailText: Oversubscribed: The Burberry corsage | Overexposed: Plaits | Pretend you know all about: Mawi | Overheard: "Hard/soft"
fields.body:
Oversubscribed: The Burberry corsage

Just as two negatives make a positive, there are times when two elements are so overexposed that combined they become, by sheer dint of their knowing irony, fabulously oversubscribed. Voila the Burberry corsage.

Corsages, as we have all been told a million times now, are just sooo Sex and the City. Even my gran knows that the Burberry check is Dead Trendy. So inevitably the Burberry corsage will be an objet de desir for style slaves ("It's Burberry! It's a corsage! OH MY GOD!"). But the fact is, it is also a jolly nice little accessory. Best of all, for those who do not prostrate themselves before the altar of Burberry check, that notorious pattern is mostly obscured by the folds of the sweet little petals.

Tragically, the corsage is not actually on sale, but was given out to a select few at a recent Burberry do (and believe me, the cat-fighting and hair-pulling among those who did not receive one was positively unseemly). But fear not. You, too, can have your precious corsage by simply making a few clever cuts and snips into your Burberry headscarf, which - as we all know - is ever so last year.

Overexposed: Plaits

"Why-oh-why-oh-why?" is the only possible response to the deluge of plaits currently plaguing west London's streets. Plaits, I tell you, on the heads of grown women. Last weekend, Notting Hill Gate looked as if it had been taken over by an enormous school group.

Now, ladies, come on. I do understand the appeal of looking a bit kooky with a dash of east end originality. But you have all fallen victim to the inexorable rise of teenage chic, which is rapidly descending into schoolgirl chic. Too-tight rugby jumpers, skewwhiff school ties, ill-fitting blazers and colourful knee-high socks are all le dernier cri on the catwalks.

It is far easier, not to mention cheaper, to achieve your homage to Pippi Longstocking with a few little twists in your hair than by buying a £300 Clements Ribeiro rugby top. So while I commend you all for your pennywise attitude, this really does not excuse adopting a hairstyle that involves terry-cloth scrunchies. The phrase "old enough to know better" comes to mind.

Overheard: "Hard/soft"

Adjective for that ever-so-now hard 80s look, but carried off with a softer, more modern spin, eg "Your brightly coloured beret pulled down over half your face is so hard/soft!"

Pretend you know all about: Mawi

"Not everyone wants to have difficult clothes and accessories, you know," says Indian-born thirtysomething designer Mawi Keivom. Quite right, too. Concept belts with sashes in all the wrong places and bags with inexplicable toggles and zippers every which way sometimes just won't quite do.

Enter the label Mawi, which, within the space of two seasons, has nosed its little way into becoming quite the name to know on the accessory market. London's chic boutiques (The Cross, Something, Boho) and department stores such as Selfridges have all snapped up Mawi's irresistibly pick-up-able accessories, from gorgeous little bags with flirty appliques and Perspex handles (so very now, you know), through 1960s-style retro cuffs, to vintage brooches. The look is elegant, girlie fun, providing quick aesthetic fixes for accessory junkies.

When Mawi and her partner Tim showed their first collection to The Cross last year, the latter liked it so much they bought the lot. Get one now before fashion fans grab them all. Sadie Frost is (probably) buying one as we speak.

 Mawi prices range from £130 to £200; enquiries 020-8888 1052.
