fields.headline: Taking orders from God
fields.standfirst: The prime minister has been talking repeatedly about his beliefs. How far will this get him?
fields.trailText: The prime minister has been talking repeatedly about his beliefs. How far will this get him?
fields.body:
Are we about to embark on the "Holier than thou" election campaign? Tony Blair disavowed any intention of vying with William Hague for the notional religious vote when he addressed a multifaith conference, organised by the Christian Socialist Movement, at Westminster Central Hall yesterday. But to see various Christian groups limbering up for the hustings, much more ostentatiously even than the political parties, is to sense that this is an opportunity neither politicians nor the churches feel they can dare to miss.

Our prime minister, probably the most overtly pious leader since Gladstone and certainly the most pro-Catholic since the glorious revolution, can be forgiven for feeling irked that William Hague, a man who proclaims a Christianity culled from the Yorkshire Dales rather than regular church attendance, has made the running in playing to a supposedly Christian constituency. Blair's pitch was rather loftier than that, but he was comfortable in advertising his belief in faith-based organisations helping to tackle social problems and in politicians promoting traditional family values.

If the two leaders do compete for a putative religious vote, none will be more delighted than the evangelical Christians who, noting the influence of religious groups on American politics, believe that might be replicated here. They have been stressing the million evangelicals in Britain who might just swing the election, always supposing they were all to vote the same way.

No wonder the Tory leader, desperate for whatever support he can find, has set up a Christian cell in Central Office and is stressing Conservative morality.

Thrilled to be thus courted, church leaders are setting out their stalls too. The Evangelical Alliance has issued its own pack, offering supporters an election prayer guide, Christian perspectives on electoral issues and suggested questions for candidates ("imagine what impact we would have on the candidates if we join together to ask probing, difficult questions that go straight to the heart of the matter and challenge conventional thinking").

The Church Society has set out its own manifesto ("Righteousness exalteth a nation but sin is a reproach to any people ... moral relativism and libertarian values which dominate public life have had disastrous consequences for our nation..."). Even the Catholic bishops have renewed their call for the electorate to vote for "the common good" - a call which, as the Catholic weekly the Tablet has pointed out is distinctly ambiguous.

Meanwhile, Ram Gidoomal, the Christian candidate who gained nearly 100,000 votes in last year's London mayoral elections, has joined the band-wagon with a little book called How Would Jesus Vote? - a title which understandably promises more than it can actually deliver, the Bible being reticent about first century voting patterns in Roman-occupied Galilee.

What distinguishes this kerfuffle is that the issues on which the religious communities are getting steamed up, abortion (of course), human embryo research, gay equality, marriage and traditional morality, are neither at the heart of the political debate nor politically partisan, except that they are deeply conservative.

Here no church leader is likely to trespass on British reticence to tell worshippers who to vote for. But some Christians cannot understand why, if Mr Blair and Mr Hague are so religiously committed, they do not insist on opposing abortion or embryo research. Nor can the leaders explain it to them as they stress the sincerity of their beliefs.

But any lessons Christian activists derive from America founder on the differences of our societies and political systems. Even the most die-hard Conservative Christian backroom boys concede privately that privatisation of welfare services would not actually work, for all Mr Hague's wishful thinking. Mr Blair's view is more sophisticated: yesterday he talked of partnership between voluntary organisations and government agencies.

The idea of handing over welfare provision even partially to religious charities would not only be unwelcome to the charities themselves but is also impractical. It has not even been outstandingly successful in Texas where they once passed children's homes to the likes of the Reverend Lester Roloff with his quaint Bible-based belief that his charges could survive on a diet of watermelon.

Here the churches themselves need to sort out their approach to politics. It is when Mr Gidoomal suggests that Christian voters should apply their morality to the beliefs of various candidates that the lobby becomes distinctly confused. How would he advise believers to vote in, say, Bromley and Chiselhurst, whose Conservative MP, Eric Forth, has just informed the Commons that all non-Protestants are potential traitors?

The former minister told the House during a debate last month that the issue of allegiance to our sovereign monarch or to a foreign power was as alive today as in the time of Henry VIII: "Indeed it might even be more potent in our multifaith society. Some people might believe that sections of our multi-faith, multicultural society have, in some circumstances, not only a divided loyalty but a greater loyalty than that given to the queen and the state..."

This new version of the Tebbit cricket test has not yet been disavowed by Mr Hague. Or how is a Christian to vote in Exeter, where the Labour MP, Ben Bradshaw, is a committed believer, son of a vicar, but gay? For the record, Mr Gidoomal suggests it might be possible to vote for a "buffoon" like Mr Forth, even though his views are bizarre, but that he could never vote for Mr Bradshaw, however otherwise attractive his policies might be.

In the end such conundrums are ir-reconcilable, which is why most churches end up advising their members to vote for whoever they deem the best candidate, just like everyone else.

But it does not answer the question why our political leaders want to wear their religious hearts on their sleeves. Perhaps they should recall John F Kennedy's dusty answer 40 years ago, when he reassured a congregation of Protestant churchmen in Houston, anxious about the prospect of having a Catholic president, that he would not be taking his orders from the Vatican.

webTitle: Giggs back for the big one

fields.headline: Giggs back for the big one
fields.trailText: Arsenal v Tottenham Hotspur
fields.body:
Arsenal v Tottenham Hotspur

Arsenal are without Dennis Bergkamp (achilles tendon), Gilles Grimandi (flu), Silvinho and Nelson Vivas (only just back from international duties) but Martin Keown returns after missing 13 games with a knee injury. Ashley Cole will replace Silvinho at left-back.

Tottenham will be without their captain Sol Campbell and their leading scorer Sergei Rebrov. Campbell injured his ankle in England's 3-1 win in Albania and Rebrov pulled a hamstring playing for Ukraine against Wales. Youngsters Stevie Ferguson and John Jackson are in the squad for the first time.

Bradford City v Newcastle United

Bradford have virtually a full squad to choose from. Central defenders David Wetherall and Robert Molenaar both return after picking up slight knocks in training this week, and full-back Andy Myers has recovered from a toe injury.

Newcastle will give their £2m central defender Andy O'Brien his debut against his former club. Alan Shearer (knee) is out, Aaron Hughes (calf) is a doubt, and Gary Speed and Nolberto Solano will undergo late fitness tests.

Chelsea v Middlesbrough

John Terry will replace Frank Leboeuf (groin) in central defence. Gianfranco Zola is likely to partner Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink in attack as Eidur Gudjohnsen has been bothered by a knee injury. Mark Bosnich may replace Carlo Cudicini in goal.

Middlesbrough have Paul Ince, Ugo Ehiogu and Phil Stamp all suspended. Curtis Fleming (toe) may also miss out but Dean Windass (back) may be fit enough to make his Boro debut.

Coventry City v Derby County

Gordon Strachan is able to name an unchanged side as Coventry's nine international players have returned unscathed. His teenage goalkeeper Chris Kirkland is likely to keep his place despite Magnus Hedman's two clean sheets for Sweden in the week. Paul Williams (flu) may not even make the bench.

Derby will be without Stefano Eranio (achilles) but will have Seth Johnson (ankle) and Chris Riggott (head) available again. Mart Poom returns as back-up goalkeeper after a shoulder injury.

Liverpool v Manchester United

Liverpool will be without Jari Litmanen, who broke a wrist playing for Finland against England, but should have Steven Gerrard, who missed the Albania game with his latest back problem, available. Patrik Berger and Nick Barmby may be on the Liverpool bench after a run-out in the reserves this week.

United can recall Ryan Giggs, who has been out since February 20 with a hamstring injury, and Andy Cole, who has been missing even longer with a three-match suspension. Fabian Barthez (thigh) is back in training.

Manchester City v Aston Villa

Manchester City have their captain Alfie Haaland back after suspension but their central defender Steve Howey faces a fitness test after tweaking a thigh in training yesterday. Paulo Wanchope does not figure despite scoring twice for Costa Rica in midweek and Shaun Wright-Phillips is dropped from the squad.

Villa are likely to stick with their new 4-4-2 formation, with George Boateng, back from an ankle injury, likely to take a central midfield spot and Steve Staunton challenging Alan Wright for the left-back berth.

Sunderland v Leeds United

Sunderland expect Gavin McCann (knee) and Kevin Kilbane (back) to be fit and their new French signing Patrice Carteron will make his home debut.

Leeds will be without Dominic Matteo, who picked up an ankle ligament injury in Scotland's 4-0 win San Marino. The captain Lucas Radebe could be forced back into action two weeks out with a knee injury. Stephen McPhail is not yet ready to make his long-awaited comeback following a five-month lay-off with an achilles tendon injury.

West Ham United v Everton

Hayden Foxe could make his long-awaited debut for West Ham after securing a work permit. He may deputise for Igor Stimac, who has a bruised bone in his leg. Craig Forrest is ruled out with a broken finger and Titi Camara has a knee problem.

Everton are still without Mark Pembridge and Paul Gascoigne, who was ruled out after having fluid drained from his knee last week. The strikers Francis Jeffers and Kevin Campbell face late fitness tests.

Sunday

Charlton Athletic v Leicester City

Charlton are likely to make a change on the left of midfield, with Graham Stuart recovered from back trouble and ready to replace John Robinson. There has been more bad news for Charlton's strikers. Andy Hunt has been ruled out for the season with post-viral fatigue and Martin Pringle faces a second shin operation.

Leicester may be without Matt Elliott (groin) and Matthew Jones (ankle) after they picked up injuries while on international duty in midweek but Gerry Taggart and Callum Davidson are available again. Tim Flowers is pushing for a return to the Leicester goal despite suffering from arthritis in his hip.

fields.headline: Election seats to watch
fields.standfirst: Even before the general election is called, the result in most constituencies can be predicted - an easy win for the party that took them last time. Some seats, thank goodness, are different. We profile eight of the battlegrounds that will help decide the result of the 2001 general election.
fields.trailText: Even before the general election is called, the result in most constituencies can be predicted - an easy win for the party that took them last time. Some seats, though, are different. We profile eight of the battlegrounds that will help decide the result of the 2001 general election.
fields.body:
Brentwood and Ongar
For reasons best known to himself, Martin Bell, the current MP for Tatton and hero of the last election, is adamant that he is standing in this seat.

"The man in the white suit" maintains that the local Conservative party has been taken over by evangelical Christians and that local Conservatives want him to stand against them.

This is a rock solid Tory seat and unlikely to change hands, despite the intense media attention that it is likely to receive. But then, that's what Neil Hamilton used to say before Mr Bell took his safe seat off him on in 1997.

Ask Aristotle: Brentwood and Ongar

Bury St Edmunds
If Labour win Bury St Edmunds in the general election, the Conservative party - and William Hague - are in big trouble. Even under John Major the party managed to hang on, just.

David Ruffley, the sitting Conservative MP gained only 38.3% of the vote in 1997 and Mark Ereira-Guyer, the Labour candidate requires a swing of just 0.3% to take the seat.

The chances are that the constituency's farms and small towns will remain loyal to the Tory cause: but watch out for an upset.

Ask Aristotle: Bury St Edmunds

Carmarthen East and Dinefwr
This seat is testament to the fact that Labour can win in rural Britain - at least in Wales. Whether the party will win again here, though, remains to be seen.

Constituents in this remote Welsh speaking seat in the south-west of the principality returned a Labour MP in 1997, but it has a history of Plaid Cymru success, too.

Plaid won the seat in the 1999 Welsh elections and has high hopes of doing so again. That would be a blow to Labour, which has to defend its coalition administration in the Welsh assembly - and would be a big boost to Plaid, which is seeking to move out of its rugged heartland seats in north-west Wales.

Ask Aristotle: Carmarthen East and Dinefwr

Hexham
The Conservative party's northernmost seat, this sprawling rural constituency has been catapulted into the news by the outbreak of foot and mouth disease - many farms locally have been affected.

This probably puts paid to any chance Labour had of winning the seat - third on Labour's target list - but also ensures it will be one to watch on polling day.

Labour needs just a 0.25% swing to oust the sitting Tory MP Peter Atkinson: but he must be confident of holding onto his job.

Ask Aristotle: Hexham

Hartlepool
Once the darling of the town, the former Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, faces a tough election battle. He'll probably win, but he'll have to work for every vote in a seat where Labour candidates usually have no problems.

And even if the electorate of Hartlepool stick by him, Mr Mandelson faces fighting an election as a backbencher, under the media spotlight. The challenge is two cornered: the Conservative party will throw everything into winning while the perennial troublemaker Arthur Scargill plans to stand for the Socialist Labour party.

Mr Scargill boasts he is the only political figure still fighting who fought Thatcher - whether he will be so confident after this foray remains to be seen.

Ask Aristotle: Hartlepool

Lewes
This constituency is represented by a parliamentary firewire: the backbench Liberal Democrat MP, Norman Baker

Mr Baker came to the fore in January 2001 when he questioned the role of the former Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, in the Hinduja passport affair.

Lauded by the Tories at the time, Mr Baker will receive no favours from the party in this close seat, situated just outside Brighton and London. A "must-win" for the Conservatives.

Ask Aristotle: Lewes

Romford
"Essex man" may have been replaced by "pebble dash people" in the focus groups, but this typical outer east London seat still matters.

It wa surprise Labour gain at the last election, a 750 year old market town-turned-suburb that eptimises middle England, with a high number of owner occupiers and white collar workers. Now it is a close fought marginal. Labour need to win if the party is to sustain its landslide majority.

A BNP candidate at the 1997 election suggests asylum may be an issue in this constituency.

Ask Aristotle: Romford

Edinburgh Pentlands
One of the smartest and most picturesque seats in Scotland, Edinburgh Pentlands was also the scene of one of the most high profile Tory casualties in the 1997 general election, when Malcolm Rifkind, then foreign secretary, saw his 4,000 majority overturned.

Lynda Clark, the current Labour MP has climbed to the first rung of the ministerial ladder and will fight Mr Rifkind again.

This seat will be a fascinating contest between a rising star in new Labour and a Tory from the old school.

Ask Aristotle: Edinburgh Pentlands

That would be a blow to Labour, which has to defend its coalition administration in the Welsh assembly - and would be a big boost to Plaid, which is seeking to move out of its rugged heartland seats in north-west Wales. Ask Aristotle: Lewes Romford "Essex man" may have been replaced by "pebble dash people" in the focus groups, but this typical outer east London seat still matters. It wa surprise Labour gain at the last election, a 750 year old market town-turned-suburb that eptimises middle England, with a high number of owner occupiers and white collar workers. Now it is a close fought marginal. Labour need to win if the party is to sustain its landslide majority. A BNP candidate at the 1997 election suggests asylum may be an issue in this constituency. Ask Aristotle: Romford Edinburgh Pentlands One of the smartest and most picturesque seats in Scotland, Edinburgh Pentlands was also the scene of one of the most high profile Tory casualties in the 1997 general election, when Malcolm Rifkind, then foreign secretary, saw his 4,000 majority overturned. webTitle: US judges rule in favour of abortion hit list

fields.headline: Seven doctors have been murdered, now judges rule in favour of abortion hit list
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Anti-abortionists in the United States have won the right to publish on the internet what amounts to a hit list of doctors who provide terminations for pregnant women.
fields.body:
Anti-abortionists in the United States have won the right to publish on the internet what amounts to a hit list of doctors who provide terminations for pregnant women.

The site, known as the Nuremberg Files, describes abortions as "Satan's food source". It prints "wanted" posters of the "baby butchers" and in some cases lists their addresses, car licence plate numbers and relatives' names. Seven doctors providing abortions in the US have been murdered in the past ten years.

The danger posed to doctors was underlined yesterday when one of the FBI's most wanted fugitives was arrested in France on suspicion of having murdered a gynaecologist in 1998. James Kopp, dubbed "Atomic Dog" by fellow anti-abortionists, was the subject of an international manhunt after Dr Barnett Slepian was shot dead at home near Buffalo, New York state.

Within hours, Slepian's name was posted on the Nuremberg Files with a cross through it.

The ruling upholding the right of the site to publish its content was upheld by a federal appeals court sitting in San Francisco.

The decision aroused despair last night among pro-choice doctors and campaigners. Warren Hern of Boulder, Colorado - one of the doctors who lodged the original lawsuit in Oregon that went on to the appeal court - said he was "shocked, disappointed and alarmed" by the decision. Dr Hern, who has been the target of an attack, said the ruling would be a "green light" for the most violent anti-abortionists.

Gloria Feldt, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, condemned the decision: "Reasonable people understand the difference between free speech and harassment that creates a violent social climate."

In making its ruling the bench pointed to the first amendment to the constitution, which guarantees free speech. One of the three judges said that "extreme rhetoric and violent action" had always played a part in American political life.

The ruling arose out of a 1999 case in Portland, Oregon where a jury awarded $107m (then worth £66.5m) in mainly punitive damages against the American Coalition of Life Activists, the Advocates for Life Ministries and 13 individuals who had put wanted posters of doctors on the web and described them as baby butchers.

The case had been brought by four doctors, a clinic and the Planned Parenthood organisation under the Freedom of Access to Clinics Act.

The identities of three of the seven doctors murdered in the past 10 years were listed on websites; there have been a further 17 attempted murders. Many such doctors now wear disguises and bullet-proof vests, live in fortified houses and vary their journeys to work.

"Political speech may not be punished just because it makes it more likely that someone will be harmed at some unknown time in the future by an unrelated third party," said Judge Alex Kozinski in the judgment.

"Extreme rhetoric and violent action have marked many political movements in American history. Patriots intimidated loyalists in both word and deed as they gathered support for American independence. John Brown and other abolitionists, convinced that God was on their side, committed murder in pursuit of their cause.

"In more modern times, the labour, anti-war, animal rights and environmental movements all have had their violent fringes," said Judge Kozinski, who was appointed under Ronald Reagan's presidency.

"As a result, much of what was said by non-violent participants acquired a tinge of menace ... If their (the websites') statements merely encouraged unrelated terrorists then their words are protected by the first amendment."

The American Civil Liberties Union agreed that the first amendment protected the right to protest against abortion, but argued that "it doesn't protect the right to threaten abortion providers with harm".

The ruling delighted anti-abortion groups. "Hallelujah!" said Neal Horsley of Carrollton, Georgia who runs the Nuremberg Files site.

Yesterday the site was posting new names of doctors, calling for fresh volunteers to carry out surveillance on doctors to protect "God's little babies". It also guided site visitors to the names of doctors killed.

"This is a reaffirmance of first amendment liberty," said Christopher Ferrara of the American Catholic Lawyers Association, an attorney in the case. "The posters do not contain any threats and in comparison to what we see in other protest movements, they are rather tame."

fields.headline: Kevin Maxwell blamed over pensions
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Kevin Maxwell, son of the late media tycoon Robert Maxwell, bears a 'heavy responsibility' for many the collapse of the family's business empire, a report said today.
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell, the son of the late media tycoon Robert Maxwell, bears a "heavy responsibility" for many of the events leading to the collapse of the family's business empire, an official report said today.

The Department of Trade and Industry report also said the Goldman Sachs merchant bank bears a "substantial responsibility" for allowing Robert Maxwell to manipulate the stock market.

Several leading City institutions are criticised in the report, although the inspectors make it clear that the primary responsibility rests with the late tycoon himself.

Goldman Sachs, the investment bank with which Robert Maxwell principally dealt when purchasing shares in his own companies, was found innocent of any wrongdoing by the criminal inquiry after Maxwell's death.

The City accountancy firm then known as Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte and other professional advisers involved with the flotation of Maxwell's Mirror Group Newspapers in 1991 were also criticised.

The long-awaited conclusions of the inquiry into the Maxwell affair come nine years after the investigation was launched.

The report was commissioned in 1992, seven months after Robert Maxwell toppled to his death from his luxury yacht in the Atlantic.

His businesses toppled soon after, as administrators took over amid revelations that some £450m was missing from pension funds.

The report makes several recommendations for ensuring that a similar collapse does not happen again.

Among them is a recommendation for severe sanctions against companies that do not report fraud, and for the provision of more detailed guidance on the audit of business "empires".

webTitle: Police send report to CPS on 'plot to kill Gadafy'

fields.headline: Police send report to CPS on 'plot to kill Gadafy'
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: The police have sent a report to the crown prosecution service about allegations by David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, that British intelligence was involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The police have sent a report to the crown prosecution service about allegations by David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, that British intelligence was involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, the Guardian has learned.

The detailed report has been sent to the CPS and although prosecution lawyers are still considering it, they hope to give advice soon to the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, on what action to take, according to a spokeswoman.

The allegations, described by Robin Cook, foreign secretary, as "pure fantasy" when they first emerged in 1998, are also being investigated by the parliamentary intelligence and security committee. Despite Mr Cook's dismissal of the claims, the committee said yesterday that it intended to submit a report to Tony Blair.

It is highly unusual for a parliamentary committee to carry out inquiries into matters which are the subject of a police investigation.

It is also significant that Mr Shayler, whose trial under the Official Secrets Act is due to open next month, has not been charged with unlawfully disclosing information about the Gadafy plot. The charges are limited to earlier disclosures he made to the Mail on Sunday about MI5 activities, including operations against a suspected Libyan intelligence officer in Britain.

Papers relating to the involvement of officers from the secret intelligence service - better known as MI6 - in the plot were handed to Scotland Yard by Annie Machon, Mr Shayler's partner, in 1999, when Mr Shayler was still living in Paris.

Police initially questioned whether MI6 officers could be prosecuted, since the plot was planned in 1995 before terrorism legislation making it a crime to conspire to commit murder abroad. However, after obtaining legal advice, police appeared to have accepted they could be prosecuted for aiding and betting.

The 1994 Intelligence Services Act protects MI6 officers from carrying out acts abroad which if they took place here would be illegal, but only with the authorisation of the foreign secretary. Sir Malcolm Rifkind, foreign secretary at the time, has made it clear he was not told about the plot.

The existence of the plot was first aired in the British press in August 1998, shortly before Mr Shayler's arrest in Paris. The government's attempt to extradite him was dismissed by a Paris court.

Shortly before Mr Shayler decided last summer to return to Britain voluntarily, Commander Roger Pearce, head of the Met's special branch, told John Wadham, Mr Shayler's lawyer, that he wanted to interview the former MI5 officer about the allegations.

After his return from France, Mr Shayler was interviewed by police. He later signed a lengthy witness statement.

Evidence of MI6's prior knowledge of the plot is contained in a secret MI6 report posted on the internet in February last year.

MI6 said it was told by a source that the plotters had obtained 250 British pistols. It stressed the MI6 source had hoped a new Libyan government could enlist British support had the coup been successful.

The plot narrowly failed to assassinate Colonel Gadafy, but killed six bystanders, according to Arab press reports.

Mr Shayler alleges that an MI6 agent, codenamed PT16B, told him of the plot.

Though the report was drawn up under the previous Conservative government, Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, demanded an immediate inquiry into the affair.

fields.headline: Pakistan's nuclear nation building
fields.standfirst: Military ruler, General Musharraf, has developed a second reactor and wants to buy fighter jets from China, writes Rory McCarthy
fields.trailText: Military ruler, General Musharraf, has developed a second reactor and wants to buy fighter jets from China, writes Rory McCarthy.
fields.body:
Pakistan has inaugurated its second nuclear power plant, in a sign of increasingly close relations with China.

With some help from the French, work began on the $600m (£400m) Chasma plant in Mianwali, in the Punjab, in the 1970s. However, France soon pulled out after Pakistan refused to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

China then became involved and, over the past decade, the China National Nuclear Corporation helped to build a plant based on the design of its own first indigenous reactor. Chasma, a pressurised water reactor, finally began producing electricity in November 1999, with a 300-megawatt capacity.

The plant was "yet another manifestation of close friendship and cooperation that exists between the two countries," Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, said.

"China is keen to extend cooperation and assistance in the nation-building process of Pakistan," he said. "We must make every effort to take advantage of Chinese cooperation and assistance."

China has long had a close alliance with Pakistan, not least because both countries want a regional balance for India's close relations with Russia.

Pakistan and India are bitter rivals who have fought three wars since partition in 1947. Both tested nuclear devices in May 1998, raising the spectre of nuclear war in South Asia.

China has been closely involved in Pakistan's missile programme, although Islamabad always insists its nuclear-capable missiles are locally designed.

Last year the US imposed sanctions on Pakistan for receiving missile technology development from China. The CIA said the development of Pakistan's 2,500-km range Shaheen II ballistic, which was on display last week during a military parade in Islamabad, relied on Chinese assistance.

Shortly after he seized power in a coup 17 months ago, General Musharraf visited China. Pakistan's air force chief, Mushaf Ali Mir, then spent a week in China last month looking at military installations. In May China's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, is due to visit Islamabad for more talks.

Pakistan is reportedly negotiating to buy 50 F-7 single-seat jet fighters from China and for at least three years has wanted to begin joint production of the Super-7 fighter jet.

Chasma, for which the Chinese paid 75% of the cost, is Pakistan's second nuclear plant.

Kanupp, a smaller 137-megawatt heavy uranium plant in Karachi, was built with Canadian help and began operating in 1972. It has since proved to be one of the worst performing nuclear power plants in the world.

With one third of the 140m people in the country still without access to electricity, Pakistan now has its sights set on a third nuclear plant.

"After the successful experience of Chasma it is vital that a decision for the construction of a third nuclear power plant for the country be taken at the earliest," said Parvez Butt, of the Pakistan atomic energy commission.

Nearly half of Pakistan's electricity is generated from imported oil but, with volatile oil prices, that dependence has damaged the country's fragile economy. Now Pakistan hopes nuclear power will be its saviour.

fields.headline: WSJ.com to cut workforce
fields.trailText: 10.45am: One of the world's most successful online news operations is to lay off staff, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
One of the world's most successful online news operations, WSJ.com, has shocked the troubled online content market by revealing it is about to lay off staff.

The Wall Street Journal is one of the few newspapers to have made money out of its online operations and the decision to cut jobs surprised the industry.

Its subscription-based news model is one of the most successful on the web.

The online unit, which employs about 250 people, declined to give details of how many staff would be affected, aside from a vague promise the decision would only apply to "a limited number".

The move is part of a cost-cutting campaign by Dow Jones, the Wall Street Journal's parent.

The job cuts are part of a move announced earlier this month to save Dow Jones £40m over the next year by reducing the media giant's overall headcount of 8,500.

The company has promised to give further details when it reports its first-quarter earnings on April 12.

WSJ.com is the latest in a string of online media operations to slash jobs in a distressed online advertising market that can no longer sustain heavily staffed websites.

But WSJ.com, one of the web's most successful subscription services, has long been the envy of internet content suppliers the world over.

The internet service has 535,000 subscribers, who pay £41 per year for the online service or £20 if they already subscribe to the Wall Street Journal.

While plans are afoot to trim the headcount at WSJ.com, Dow Jones insisted it would not scale back the size or depth of the operation.

Elsewhere in the company, Dow Jones has delayed the launch of WeekendJournal.com, an online counterpart to a weekly leisure and entertainment section of The Wall Street Journal.

It is also winding down Work.com, a site for small businesses.

fields.headline: Friday's rumours
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours have saved £6 each by not starting the 35-minute journey from Marylebone to a small station in Buckinghamshire until 9.30am
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle will be given a £50m transfer kitty at Tottenham, according to the Express, and he'll use some of it to raid his old club Southampton. Wayne Bridge, Dean Richards and James Beattie are top of his list. And if annoying one former employer isn't enough, he's nipping back to Chelsea to steal Jody Morris as well.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle will be given a £50m transfer kitty at Tottenham, according to the Express, and he'll use some of it to raid his old club Southampton. Wayne Bridge, Dean Richards and James Beattie are top of his list. And if annoying one former employer isn't enough, he's nipping back to Chelsea to steal Jody Morris as well.

Chelsea have made a "final last-ditch bid" to sign Lazio striker Marcelo Salas, claims Planet Football. Claudio Ranieri has personally spoken to Salas in an attempt to persuade the Chilean to come to Stamford Bridge.

Arsene Wenger has rejected an approach from Barcelona to become their manager. Nou Camp boss Llorenc Serra Ferrer is expected to lose his job at the end of the season, and chairman Joan Gaspart sounded out Wenger and Roma boss Fabio Capello. Both said no.

Bradford now want to retain the services of Benito Carbone. "He was always a different case from Stan Collymore and Dan Petrescu," manager Jim Jefferies explained to the Daily Mail. "We didn't want to lose him but he was down and wanted to go home. Beni seems much more settled now."

Paris St-Germain have lodged an official £2.5m bid for Middlesbrough midfielder Christian Karembeu.

Steve Bruce could become the new manager at Tranmere within the next couple of days, according to the Mirror.

And we couldn't let the Sun's sensational back-page splash pass without comment. Yesterday, David Beckham made a call using his mobile cellular telephone.

Claudio Ranieri has personally spoken to Salas in an attempt to persuade the Chilean to come to Stamford Bridge. Arsene Wenger has rejected an approach from Barcelona to become their manager. Nou Camp boss Llorenc Serra Ferrer is expected to lose his job at the end of the season, and chairman Joan Gaspart sounded out Wenger and Roma boss Fabio Capello. Both said no. Paris St-Germain have lodged an official £2.5m bid for Middlesbrough midfielder Christian Karembeu. Steve Bruce could become the new manager at Tranmere within the next couple of days, according to the Mirror. And we couldn't let the Sun's sensational back-page splash pass without comment. Yesterday, David Beckham made a call using his mobile cellular telephone.

fields.headline: Life after death for C4 legal drama
fields.standfirst: Full list of BPG award-winners
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 4 legal drama North Square may have been axed after just one series, but it won the critics' posthumous approval, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 legal drama North Square may have been axed after just one series after poor ratings, but it has received newspaper critics' posthumous seal of approval.

North Square will pick up four out of 13 Broadcasting Press Guild awards, which are chosen by media writers, at a ceremony today.

The show, which was made by Company Pictures for Channel 4 and revolved around a group of barristers working in Leeds chambers, will be named best drama series or serial in the BPG awards.

The BPG best actor and actress awards will go to North Square stars Phil Davis and Helen McCrory.

And North Square creator Peter Moffat will share the BPG writer's award with Simon Schama, for his work on BBC2 documentary series A History of Britain.

Channel 4 will have the biggest BPG awards haul, with six in all.

Longitude has won the best single drama prize and BPG members have voted Graham Norton best performer for his work on Channel 4 show So Graham Norton.

A History of Britain has won the best documentary series award and Marion and Geoff was voted best entertainment show, bringing BBC2's BPG awards tally to three.

BBC1 will pick up one BPG award, with Who Bombed Omagh? voted best documentary.

Radio programme of the year goes to BBC Radio 4's Dead Ringers; while Radio 4 World at One presenter Nick Clarke has been voted radio broadcaster of the year.

The History Channel and Cromwell Productions have won the BPG multichannel award, for Balaclava.

The BPG's Harvey Lee Award for outstanding contribution to broadcasting will go to veteran drama producer Ted Childs, whose CV runs from The Sweeney to Inspector Morse and Peak Practice.

fields.headline: Fun and games
fields.standfirst:
From Manitoba's playground noises to Chris Clark's conversations with the Clangers, this week's pop is all kid's stuff

Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText: From Manitoba's playground noises to Chris Clark's conversations with the Clangers, this week's pop is all kid's stuff
fields.body:
Matthew Jay
Draw (Parlophone)
Rating: ***
£12.99

The face that stares out from this debut CD is of a poster-pretty boy with fear in his eyes. And that just about sums up the music on Draw. Matthew Jay sings with a sadness barely obscured by the jaunty rhythms and clever use of samples and loops, using the eccentricity of his native South Wales to inform this snapshot of growing up. Held together by Jay's appealingly winsome voice are the breezy harmonica of Become Yourself, the odd uneasiness of Please Don't Send Me Away and the sublime You're Always Going Too Soon, a yearning to be reunited with a childhood friend, each song coated with a varnish of nostalgia and tears. The lyrics are contemporary - "Talking to you now, is the easiest thing in all the fuckin' hell," Jay sings in Four Minute Rebellion - but there's an early-1970s feel about the harmonies and subtle guitar work, the calmness nicely distilling the knowingness. (BC)

Abraham
On the Surface (JBO)
Rating: ****
£10.99

Most singers lucky enough to have a voice like Rachel Cuming's would make sure it graced every part of their songs. But Cuming makes her soulful sounds - sultry, pleading and desperate - all the more special by applying them to her shuffling beats and rippling bass sparingly. When her voice trembles and hits high notes it's with restrained passion, rather than a mere show of ability. Thanks to Cuming's versatility, On the Surface is awash with influences and subtle nuances, embellishing hip-hop beats with electronica, taking old-school blues and adding some phat credibility. Come Live with Me allows Cuming to shine against an acoustic guitar until the beats break up the smoky atmosphere, but Surge works as an instrumental, a downbeat orchestral sample playing off against some jazz piano. The Answer, a cover of a 1973 song by Maxayn, is pure funk, life-affirming lyrics wrapped up in soundtrack atmosphere, strutting stylishly as Cuming's double-tracked vocals meet her own harmonies in a graceful groove. Brutally cool but completely lovable. (BC)

LeAnn Rimes
I Need You (London)
Rating: **
£14.99

The press release for former country sweetheart LeAnn Rimes's second UK album makes hopeful comparisons with Britney Spears, but Celine Dion would be more apt. Rimes shares the Canadian blandstress's unerring instinct for unlikely-to-cause-insurrection stuff that only just passes for pop (as in youthful) music. In a sense, though, her strategy for crossing from the country market to a wider "demographic" has been dictated by her voice, whose innate glossiness makes it a natural vehicle for middle-aged fodder like the title track and a duet with Elton John, Written in the Stars (in which Reg sounds a good decade younger than his 18-year-old partner). By the same token, forays into dance music, such as the house mixes of Soon and the not-baddish number one single Can't Fight the Moonlight, are about as convincing as you'd expect. These are far outnumbered, however, by dribbly slowies such as Together, Forever, Always, which make the equally ballad-prone Westlife sound like Rage Against the Machine. (CS)

Manitoba
Start Breaking My Heart (Leaf)
Rating: ****
£12.99

By day, Toronto resident Dan Snaith is a masters-qualified pure mathematician. By night, he arranges masters-quality electronic sounds. Start Breaking My Heart is innovative enough to suggest a mathmetician's thought-out, even formulaic approach, but once a framework is established, Snaith's emotions and creativity run riot. This is beautiful electronic music rooted in the pastoral grace of Boards of Canada, Eno, Aphex Twin's early ambience, naive 1980s electro and very early Kraftwerk, but with its own unique vision. Titles like James' Second Haircut and an atmosphere including playground noises, harps and music boxes come as close to childlike wonderment as any 22-year-old has a right to. Aided by Snaith's jazz and classical training - not to mention his tricky home computer and guitar - drumbeats skip, discordant saxes wail and pianos plink. But however avant-garde he gets, nothing is allowed to disturb the soothing mood. He is attracting plaudits on both sides of the Atlantic, and it's surely only a matter of time before a hardened A&R bod is pleading with him to give up the day job. (DS)

Howe Gelb
Confluence (Loose)
Rating: ***
£12.99

One reliable indicator of an artist's merit is how they handle Can't Help Falling in Love. Ostensibly simple, it can be heartstopping (Elvis Presley); deep (U2); light on its feet (UB40); rambunctious (Lick the Tins) or just bonkers (the Stylistics). On his third solo album, Tucson's Howe Gelb has a most unusual crack at it. Backed by Grandaddy, Gelb croaks his way through it at a funereal pace that holds even during the wonky fadeout solo. Uniquely, it is Can't Help Falling in Love as acoustic death rattle, and with it Gelb has passed the test (although, since Gelb's band Giant Sand's finest moment remains the definitive attempt at Bob Dylan's Every Grain of Sand, the odds were loaded in his favour). Some of the remaining 16 self-penned tracks were recorded in Bristol with John Parish; and there will be no release more spartan this year. Gelb is a ghostly presence, mumbling his way through the sexually anxious Vex (Tucson), just about nailing the wispy instrumental Shadow of Where a River Was, or pulling tricks such as the French chatter throughout Vex (Paris). Too unyielding to elevate Gelb from his cult ghetto, Confluence remains evidence of a most fertile mind. (JA)

Violet Indiana
Roulette (Bella Union)
Rating: ****
£14.99

Had Cocteau Twins not so callously cluttered their music to claustrophobic, monotone effect, the commercial breakthrough they always seemed on the cusp of would surely have been theirs. Eight years after that trio's demise, chief Twin Robin Guthrie has learned his lesson and learned it well. Violet Indiana is Guthrie's collaboration with keeningly intelligent former Mono singer Siobhan De Mare, who walks softly but carries a big stick. She is a less hysterical, more sensuous singer than Cocteau Twin Liz Fraser, delivering distinctly adult lyrics with deadly calm. She is coruscating on Air Kissing ("there's got to be more to you") and Poison Gorgeous; unnervingly reminiscent of Minnie Riperton on Liar; and desolate on Little Echo's "self destruction and seduction" saga. Behind her, though, Guthrie has enrolled at the less-is-more school, twisting tones and flaunting melody to create an empathetic soundscape that harkens to Angelo Badalamenti's Twin Peaks theme. It's exactly the foil De Mare's coiled venom needs in order to shine, and shine she does. (JA)

Various Artists
Mersey Boys and Liverpool Girls: Sounds of the Mersey 1977-2001 (EMI)
Rating: ****
£15.99

Once a badge of local pride, the regional compilation has rather fallen into unlamented obscurity. Apropos of nothing, these 21 tracks celebrate Liverpool, while excluding Frankie Goes to Hollywood, Teardrop Explodes, Dead or Alive and the Yachts. It does, however, have a Beatle (Wings's pleasing but slight Deliver Your Children); the usual worthies (The Mighty Wah!'s barnstorming Heart as Big as Liverpool; Ian McNabb's daft-as-Ken-Dodd Liverpool Girl; the glorious pop of the Christians and the Lightning Seeds); and a clutch of upstarts worthy of carrying the torch for a scene that has been curiously moribund of late. Of the newer breed, Speed's Good Luck Charm is the most gorgeous duet since Tindersticks's Travelling Light; Ladytron's He Took Her to a Movie is ominous and sexually unconventional; while Steven Kennedy's Beautiful Land is part Mike Peters, part oompah band, but more engaging than such a combination promises. What, however, London-born Elvis Costello and his still splendid Oliver's Army are doing here, and why an album sub-titled Mersey Girls features only two female voices, must remain a secret to all but the compilers. (JA)

Chris Clark
Clarence Park (Warp)
Rating: ****
£8.99

Chris Clark, a 21-year-old electronica prodigy from St Albans currently studying at Bristol University, apparently sent home-recorded demos to Warp, the home of Autechre and Aphex Twin, when he was just 13. A wayward boy (the demonic red-eyed kid on the album cover is him), his biography reads like a mini-history of, if not delinquency, then impishness: he bought a drum machine to spite his drum teacher; he used to divide up his emotions into percentages; he went missing and was found by his mum strumming a harp in a cave in Wales.. A triumph of micro-programming and mind-boggling editing, the self-produced Clarence Park is, as you might expect, playful in parts - the wistful synthesiser notes scattered throughout the almost conventionally lovely Lord of the Dance could be 1970s TV puppets the Clangers talking. But if Clark is tapping into childhood memories on this album of extremes, he doesn't spare us the dark stuff, from the blue moods of Pleen 1930s, with its sorrowful piano chords, to the nightmare visions of Shrewland. Clark, like labelmate Squarepusher, re-presents "ambient" not as muzak but as the brutal soundtrack of our lives - pneumatic drills, barking dogs, low-flying aircraft, the lot.

fields.headline: On the edge releases
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText:
Mark Russell & James Young
Film Music Screencraft (RotoVision, book with CD)
Rating: ***
£29.95
fields.body:
Mark Russell & James Young
Film Music Screencraft (RotoVision, book with CD)
Rating: ***
£29.95

This fascinating if flawed book features the work and opinions of 13 composers in the movie world. Mark Russell is a composer/radio personality, James Young a musician/writer best known for Songs They Never Play on the Radio, one of the few books about rock'n'roll worth reading all the way through. Russell and Young interviewed most of the composers themselves, but the book opens with a superb essay by Mervyn Cooke about Bernard Herrmann - the film composer's film composer - who died in 1975, shortly after completing his Ellingtonian score for Martin Scorsese's Taxi Driver (1976). The interviewees include Danny Elfman (Beetlejuice, Ed Wood, Nightmare Before Christmas), Zbigniew Preisner (Three Colours Red), 007 innovator John Barry and Maurice Jarre (Witness, Laurence of Arabia), who reveals that he played theatre music for several years in a percussion duo with his compatriot Pierre Boulez.

Many of the composers have a theatrical background: an experience of the excitement of spontaneous performance that still informs the way they work. Jerry Goldsmith (Alien, Chinatown) had to write a weekly score for live TV drama: "You had to be inventive and very fast. There was a lot of music to be written in the hour between the dress rehearsal and going on air." An accompanying CD, glued awkwardly to the front cover, contains a selection of well-known themes played mainly by the City of Prague Philharmonic. It's curious to hear Philip Glass's Vessels from Koyaanisqatsi without Michael Riesman's battery of Farfisa-like keyboards, and an over-literal reading of the swaggering Goldfinger theme demonstrates how hard it is to imitate Barry's signature Bond sound. The more "classical" scores (such as Elfman's Edward Scissorhands or Herrmann's Psycho) fare better, but the CD is there more as an aide memoire than a replication of the original soundtrack. Russell and Young's carefully edited interviews yield some fantastic insights and wisely avoid the name-dropping and anecdotes that too often spoil or trivialise film books. But the subject is ill served by the book's large format and eccentric, image-heavy design, which matches the six other books in RotoVision's Screencraft series. The handwritten scores by composers and orchestrators are a fascinating resource, but the whole package isn't quite sure whether it's a serious resource for students, musicians and cinema enthusiasts, or just another glossy coffee-table object for film fans, with full-bleed images of Johnny Depp, Janet Leigh and Béatrice Dalle.

Susan Alcorn
Uma (Loveletter Recordings/ Music Stuff)
Rating: ***
£12.99

Based in Texas, Susan Alcorn is a pedal-steel guitar player with an articulate but left-field personal style on an instrument normally associated with country and western music. There are some jazz roots in her playing, demonstrated on this debut album by the inclusion of a melancholy Thelonious Monk/bebop medley, but the main sound is that of abstract free improvisation, with some of the space and introspection of Deep Listening Band, whose Pauline Oliveros is a supporter of Alcorn's. Alcorn also plays in the Ernest Tubb Memorial Band led by guitarist Eugene Chadbourne, who wrote that her work contains a deep threshold of emotion, "the purity of which is a phenomenon unique to country music". In Alcorn's hands the pedal steel is beautiful, glassy and liquid, however far she strays from pulse and conventional harmony. Her shifting chords and arpeggios are more like a pianist's than a guitarist's. Alcorn closes her long and challenging CD set with a familiar tune to send everyone home happy. It's a reharmonised waltz-time version of Amazing Grace, executed with a straight face. If she's not careful, an ad agency will snap it up it to accompany one of those sentimental scenes where rednecks and hip-hoppers embrace tearfully over tall glasses of stout.

Celloman
Aquador (SPI Music)
Rating: ***
£14.99

As a rock instrument, the cello has dangerous tendencies towards pomp, as the Finnish heavy-metal cello quartet (and breakfast TV stars) Apocalyptica demonstrate in their new single Path (Island). Celloman is the project name for the more modest Ivan Hussey, a musician who will always have a place in my heart for his moving performance on Clapham, King's Cross, Lockerbie, Zeebrugge, the apocalyptic Billy Jenkins piece "for proper cello and two crap pianos". Hussey is still a "proper cellist", but now has ambitions for clubland fame and acclaim. "It's amazing that a cellist can sound so interesting and contemporary," was the alleged reaction of Kiss FM's Patrick Forge (who clearly doesn't get out much).

The determinedly low-budget Aquador is a self-produced collection of largely instrumental tracks with a middle- eastern heart to the melodies and scales, played over a DJ-oriented throb programmed by Hussey himself. Percussionists such as Fedja Franklin and Gadi Seri, and several other guests, are mixed in to add interest and colour, and the whole confection sails along in a pleasant fashion. Beguiling patterns emerge from the multitracked cellos on tracks such as F Song and The Wailer. Hussey's arrangement of Chebba, a traditional Algerian song, is the sort of thing you can almost imagine being a freak holiday disco hit, like EBTG's Missing, New Order's Blue Monday or The Macarena.

 To order any CD call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

Her shifting chords and arpeggios are more like a pianist's than a guitarist's. Alcorn closes her long and challenging CD set with a familiar tune to send everyone home happy. It's a reharmonised waltz-time version of Amazing Grace, executed with a straight face. If she's not careful, an ad agency will snap it up it to accompany one of those sentimental scenes where rednecks and hip-hoppers embrace tearfully over tall glasses of stout. Celloman Aquador (SPI Music) Rating: *** £14.99 As a rock instrument, the cello has dangerous tendencies towards pomp, as the Finnish heavy-metal cello quartet (and breakfast TV stars) Apocalyptica demonstrate in their new single Path (Island). Celloman is the project name for the more modest Ivan Hussey, a musician who will always have a place in my heart for his moving performance on Clapham, King's Cross, Lockerbie, Zeebrugge, the apocalyptic Billy Jenkins piece "for proper cello and two crap pianos". Hussey is still a "proper cellist", but now has ambitions for clubland fame and acclaim. "It's amazing that a cellist can sound so interesting and contemporary," was the alleged reaction of Kiss FM's Patrick Forge (who clearly doesn't get out much). The determinedly low-budget Aquador is a self-produced collection of largely instrumental tracks with a middle- eastern heart to the melodies and scales, played over a DJ-oriented throb programmed by Hussey himself. Percussionists such as Fedja Franklin and Gadi Seri, and several other guests, are mixed in to add interest and colour, and the whole confection sails along in a pleasant fashion. Beguiling patterns emerge from the multitracked cellos on tracks such as F Song and The Wailer. Hussey's arrangement of Chebba, a traditional Algerian song, is the sort of thing you can almost imagine being a freak holiday disco hit, like EBTG's Missing, New Order's Blue Monday or The Macarena.  To order any CD call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

webTitle: Pop CD of the week - Nick Cave

fields.headline: A slasher romance
fields.standfirst:
Nick Cave may still be dark and wild, but on this album he also reveals an unexpectedly tender side, says Maddy Costa

Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText:
Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds
No More Shall We Part (Mute)
Rating: ****
£14.99
fields.body:
Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds
No More Shall We Part (Mute)
Rating: ****
£14.99

It's not hard to see why people find Nick Cave irritating. The reasons are stamped all over his 11th album with the Bad Seeds: in the vehement, anguished, begging cries to God; the churning gothic atmosphere; the obsession with death and the histrionic sensitivity to portents; the mere presence of a song called Oh My Lord. For these people, Cave is the equivalent of those lonely souls in tattered jumpers who stand in exposed places like Leicester Square, barking into a crackly microphone that only Jesus can save us from damnation, being ignored by teenagers and tourists, shoppers and clubbers. Like them, he's humourless, doom-mongering and misguided - and he has weird clothes and a dodgy haircut to boot.

No More Shall We Part isn't going to make born-again Cavians of them, but it's a magnificent reminder of just how wrong the nay-sayers and non-believers are. It's a majestic album, dramatic, propulsive, reeling with remarkable images, more resonant with every listen. Musically, the more muted songs (Sweetheart Come, Gates to the Garden) pick up where 1997's The Boatman's Call left off, but while that album's lyrics prickled with rejection and the raw hurt of relationships in splinters, this one radiates romance - perplexed and tentative to be sure, but more trusting of love and its possibilities. As on 1998's best-of compilation, these soft, sorrow-tinted songs alternate with violent tempests (Hallelujah), nightmare visions (Oh My Lord), bloody gashes of sound and fury more like the Cave of the 1980s. Each song, each style, is perfectly realised; Cave's two-decade career reaches its apotheosis here.

That is, in no small part, down to the Bad Seeds: it's a pleasure to hear them return from their own bands and solo incarnations to create a sound more eloquent and hauntingly beautiful than ever before. In the music's ebb and surge, its contrasts of cacophony and calm, is a precise, restrained, mature orchestration that is utterly distinctive. The title song features nothing but Cave's smoky piano, his increasingly crooner-like voice and Thomas Wydler's gentle brush drums until the song's final quarter, when drums and bass rise up wrapped in velvety swathes of violins.

Mick Harvey and Warren Ellis's string arrangements are exquisite throughout: they make Love Letter more yearning, The Sorrowful Wife more mysterious, Sweetheart Come more luxurious, with Ellis's violin softly serenading. On Oh My Lord, Ellis scrapes from his strings the fervent scrawl that makes his band Dirty Three sound so impassioned; that and Wydler's militaristic drumming drive the song into exhilarating chaos. Fifteen Feet of Pure White Snow grows equally frantic, but it's the quieter sections that really impress, where you can appreciate the interplay of Harvey's guitar with Blixa Bargeld's, warm chords punctured by tiny, fierce slashes across the guitar strings. Here and on Hallelujah, Kate and Anna McGarrigle's girlish voices exude a faintly amused calm, and play brilliantly off Cave's vehemence.

If the music ranks among the Bad Seeds' best, so too do Cave's lyrics. Much has been made in recent interviews of the fact that Cave wrote this album in an office, nine to five - the discipline sounds wholly uncharacteristic, but it has resulted in a set of songs that are striking, seductive and surprisingly entertaining, both to listen to and to read. Opening track and recent single As I Sat Sadly by Her Side is typical: the narrative - husband and wife sitting at the window, commenting on the world and God, a playful kitten leaping from lap to lap - is preposterous but absorbing, melancholy and strangely funny.

These are lyrics that sock you in the stomach, only to come back later and tickle you in the ribs. As the gap between real and surreal widens in Oh My Lord, a twisting, deliciously odd sense of humour emerges, not least when Cave visits the hairdresser and "a guy wearing plastic antlers presses his bum against the glass". God Is in the House is more amusing still: its picture of a religious community that rejects "goose-stepping 12-stepping teetotalitarianists" and "homos roaming the streets in packs / queer bashers with tyre-jacks / lesbian counter-attacks" is relentlessly, almost lovingly detailed. Cave transforms the list into an artform on this album: a love letter is "a plea, a petition, a kind of prayer"; in a graveyard lie "fugitive fathers, sickly infants, decent mothers, runaways and suicidal lovers". The peak comes at the end in Darker with the Day, with the cutting words "Amateurs, dilettantes, hacks, cowboys, clones / The streets groan with little Caesars, Napoleons and cunts": one of pop music's more accurate descriptions of London society.

But when the streets are paved with fools, that only makes the return home to the wife more welcome. Cave knows a few things about writing love songs - his wise, warm lecture on the subject proved as much - and here are some of his best. They are never simple: the image of the ring "locked upon the finger" in And No More Shall We Part has a sinister undertone; Love Letter is beset by storms, a hope that flickers beneath a "sky ready to burst"; and the relationship in The Sorrowful Wife, who sits "counting the days on her fingers", could not be more troubled. But Gates to the Garden, with its tender assessment of marriage ("God is in this hand I hold"), is a song to make the heart swell with affection, to make you run to a loved one and give them this wonderful album as a precious gift.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText:
Billy Elliot
Rental and DVD rental
Universal
Cert 15
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Billy Elliot
Rental and DVD rental
Universal
Cert 15
Rating: ***

The most-loved British film of the last year, Billy Elliot is pitched half-way between Kes - still very much the template for the grim-oop-north drama - and well-meaning old Hollywood films like How Green Was My Valley. It's effective if a bit overrated, but there's no denying a stupendous performance by Jamie Bell, just 15. To be this good as a novice actor would be impressive; to be this good as a dancer too seems miraculous. And it's the dancing scenes - especially one in the tight, claustrophobic brick surrounds that recalls East is East's exuberance - that stay with you, and more than cancel out some of the more sentimental views of northern life, as well as the uncertain plotting. It's set in Durham, 1984, a virtual war zone in the midst of the bitter miners' strike, and uses dance as an expression of frustration, something to lose yourself in, to hit back at the ugliness, strife and claustrophobia surrounding a young life. Bell makes it more than just The Full Monty with pliés.

Hollow Man
Retail and DVD rental
Columbia
Cert 18
Rating: ***

Kevin Bacon discovers the secret of invisibility and, like any self-respecting mad film scientist, gets a God complex, with a wide streak of devil to go with it. From a promising start, Paul Verhoeven's film winds up with a pretty routine Old Dark House/ Alien plot: it's mad, bad Kev vs the world. But, plot be damned, the point of Hollow Man is its effects, and they are a spectacular entrée into the world of blood, bones and tissue. Bacon goes through elaborate stages of visibility which work as a fantastic anatomy lesson as well as showing invisibility underwater or in the rain. You can't help feeling body-meister David Cronenberg would have found better uses for all this technology, but where Verhoeven's superior predecessor, Starship Troopers, had no DVD extras at all, this uses the medium properly, explaining its conception in great detail and showing the frenetic Dutchman at work, acting out each part with abandon. As Bacon says: "I have to play a mad scientist, so it's good to have one around."

Ring
Rental, retail (£15.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Tartan
Cert 15
Rating: ****

Japanese horror has had a boom year with Audition and this first film from the Ring trilogy; both this and Ring 2, the sequel, had a recent cinematic release. It's like The Blair Witch Project - thematically but not stylistically - fused with Cronenberg's Videodrome. Its scariest moments top both, but it uses subtle suggestion more than shock effects for the most part, putting flesh on the bones of a silly story about a cursed video which is followed by a phone call giving the viewer one week to live. The combination of old folk tales and new technology provides a lot of its distinctive feel. It certainly leaves you wanting to see Ring 2, shown as part two of a double bill in the east, where it was a smash-hit. If you find yourself in the horror section, you'd do far better with this than the crass, depressing Scary Movie.

The Little Vampire
Retail (£14.99) and DVD (£15.99)
Icon
Cert U
Rating: ***

At the age of 10, Jonathan Lipnicki seems to have a monopoly on good kid comedy roles. He was brother to a mouse in Stuart Little and here, showing the same winning combination of puzzlement and determination, he is a kid obsessed by vampires in another enjoyable, cheerful comedy ideal for multi-generational viewing. For kids, there's a strong identification figure in a bullied child letting his imagination run wild in Scotland, where his parents are working. For oldies, there's a lovely running joke about a herd of vampire cows, Jim Carter as a vampire slayer who is more roughie than Buffy, and Richard E Grant who always has looked vampiric, wrapping his perfect elocution round lines like "We need darkness, dampness and decay" ("and the finest wines available to humanity," you half-expect him to add since this is a medieval close relative of Withnail). The Little Vampire throws in a few film references without nudging you in the ribs too much and this is jolly stuff by Uli Edel, once the grim realist director of Christiane F and Last Exit to Brooklyn.

fields.headline: Songs around sex
fields.standfirst:
Tim Ashley investigates French composer Ernest Chausson's reputation for eroticism

Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText: Tim Ashley investigates French composer Ernest Chausson's reputation for eroticism.
fields.body:
Chausson: The Complete Songs
Lott/McGreevy/Murray/ Trakas/Chilingirian Quartet/ Johnson (Hyperion, 2 CDs)
Rating: ****
£24.99

The jury is still out on Ernest Chausson. He was killed in a cycling accident, aged 44, in 1899, and his admirers have always claimed that French music lost one of its greatest composers tragically early. Others, however, have questioned whether his individual voice had fully emerged at the time of his death, while many have portrayed him as lurking somewhere between the post-Wagnerian chromatics of César Franck and the impressionistic tonal fluidity of Debussy.

Chausson also has the reputation - based on his orchestral works - of being one of music's great eroticists, though I'm afraid that anyone looking for graphic rumpy-pumpy in his songs, recorded complete for the first time, won't find it here. This is music that is sensuous rather than sensual, written around sex instead of portraying it. Desire is represented by its initial flickerings, or retrospectively seen from a point of enervated exhaustion once relationships are over and all passion is spent.

Chausson's response to his texts is perhaps significant. Unlike Henri Duparc, he struggles when it comes to setting Baudelaire. There's nothing by his close friend Mallarmé, who so famously stalks Debussy's output. Despite his posthumous porno-reputation, Chausson was a happily married, devout Catholic, and all but one of his Verlaine songs use texts from the writer's late years, when religion rather than Rimbaud haunted his thoughts. Gautier's chiselled purity, the stagnant symbolism of Maeterlinck, and a clutch of now-forgotten writers drew from him much of his finest music.

There are some shamefully neglected works here: La Caravane, a lengthy setting of Gautier that covers a colossal range of mood with the intensity of an operatic scena; the precise, syllabic, modal cool of Hébé, which pre-empts Satie more than any of the impressionists. There are also some weird versions of Shakespeare - Ophelia's mad scene, tonally meandering in its derangement, and a brilliant, bleak setting of Feste's final song from Twelfth Night.

The accepted masterpieces continue to astonish, however: Le Temps des Lilas, which later formed the basis of the orchestral song cycle Poème de l'Amour et de la Mer; and Serres Chaudes ("Hothouses"), which, eliding images of greenhouses and hospital wards, gives us a more oppressive view of Maeterlinck than Debussy's Pelléas does. Felicity Lott sings both works with aristocratic poise and a sensuous yet troubled refinement that is second to none.

They form her only contribution to the set, however, for the bulk of the songs for female voice are taken by Ann Murray, who is less assured. There's a harshness of tone under pressure that gets in the way at times. She's at her best in the Chanson Perpétuelle, where her soft singing is ravishing and the Chilingirian Quartet spins an exquisite web of sound around her. She shares the handful of duets not with Lott, but with the shallow-voiced Geraldine McGreevy, which was perhaps a mistake.

The real find, however, is the American baritone Chris Pedro Trakas. His sound is consistently honeyed and sexy, and he has the ability to float soft high notes effortlessly. His way with words tells you that he understands French poetry as well as he understands French music. At the piano, Graham Johnson is immaculate, as always. Both in performance and content, the set is uneven - but the best of it will haunt you long after its final, beautiful chords have died away.

 To order these CDs call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

webTitle: On the edge CD of the week - Cuban deep grooves

fields.headline: Bass in the place
fields.standfirst:
John L Walters on the deep grooves of a young-at-heart Cuban

Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText:
Orlando 'Cachaito' Lopez
Cachaito (World Circuit)
Rating: ****
£13.99
fields.body:
Orlando 'Cachaito' Lopez
Cachaito (World Circuit)
Rating: ****
£13.99

Bassist Orlando "Cachaito" Lopez is one of the younger members of the Buena Vista Social Club, a tower of strength whose big tone and steady pulse have underpinned every release from the Cuban hit factory. On the more improvisational albums, such as Ruben Gonzalez's Chanchullo, he has revealed a Mingus influence in the way he holds together a jigsawed rhythm section, and his first album as a leader pushes this approach into uncharted territory, experimenting with reggae, R&B and hip-hop flavours, and a wider instrumental palette, while still sounding entirely Cuban.

The absence of a conventional drumkit is a liberating element, as the back-line of congas (Miguel "Anga" Diaz), timbales (Armadito Valdez) and bongos (Carlos Gonzalez) maintain an endlessly beguiling rhythmic lattice that still leaves space for the bass.

Cachaito is also one of the funniest, most good-humoured albums to come along for a while. You can't help grinning when Conversacion gets going with the fiery flute-playing of Policarpo "Polo" Tamayo and Manuel Galban, "the original Cuban surf guitarist", who lets loose some nice Ventures-meet-Macro-Ribot Echoplex licks throughout the album. Another important sound is the Hammond of Jamaican organist Bigga Morrison, adding yet more spice to the steaming Cuban stew.

Cachaito in Laboratory, as the title suggests, pushes the boat out further, with a beatbox, some scratching from French DJ Dee Nasty, a deliriously processed horn section and wiry stabs (Timmy Thomas style) from Morrison, capped by a blunt-scissors ending worthy of Prince. It is intriguing to hear how well the tone of the double bass adapts to contemporary, electric grooves - something Red Snapper, Hefner and others have attempted recently.

Producer Nick Gold and engineers Jerry Boys and Simon Burwell have had a lot of fun with this album, whether playing with effects and dub echoes on numbers such as Tumbanga, which features the eloquent Hugh Masekela on flugelhorn, or just catching the moment with cuts such as the free-wheeling Anais (a name shared by Lopez's wife and his granddaughter). There are strings on three tracks, but they're not there to smooth out the sound, as are the orchestrations regularly spooned on to jazz albums. If anything, they make it all sound weirder, with a small, upfront section used sparsely on Israel Lopez's Redencion and scuttling pizzicato unisons on Oracion Lucumi.

What will take Buena Vista fans by surprise is the album's self-indulgence, its freedom and its unfinished air. It is a young-sounding record: the product of someone getting a chance to make their first album at an unfeasibly old age, and getting away with murder. People used to make albums like this in the 1960s and 1970s, and even later on when people had money or free studio time to burn. But what Lopez and his team bring to this familiar party is a big dose of musicianship, and I suspect it will wear better than albums by his psychedelic forebears.

Cachaito doesn't have the smooth classiness of Charlie Haden with Joe Lovano on that bassist's Cuban dinner-jazz album Nocturne (Verve). And it lacks the Starbucks-friendly tunefulness of Omara Portuondo or the original Ry Cooder-produced Buena Vista Social Club CD. It is not really jazz, and it's not "world music" - but it has the breezy spirit of a Sunday-afternoon jazz workshop blow from another planet.

Bach: St Matthew Passion

fields.body:
Bach: St Matthew Passion
Schäfer/Röschmann/Fink/ Magnus/Prégardien/Goerne/Henschel/Vienna Boys Choir/Arnold Schoenberg Choir/Vienna Concentus Musicus/Harnoncourt (Teldec, 3 CDs)
Rating: *****
£46.99

Some may wonder why Nikolaus Harnoncourt should want to re-record the St Matthew Passion when many consider his 1970 version definitive. This performance replaces the previous disc's austerity with an anguished intensity that builds to a climax of overwhelming despair. The choral singing is urgent and flawless, the soloists superlative. Christoph Prégardien is a forthright Evangelist, in marked contrast to Matthias Goerne's deeply human yet otherworldly Jesus. The arias, divided between eight singers rather than the usual four, are all beautifully done, though Dorothea Röschmann, Elisabeth von Magnus and Dietrich Henschel are particularly outstanding. I still prefer the tragic grandeur of Klemperer's 1962 EMI recording - but this is a noble, harrowing achievement that ranks among the finest recordings of the work.

Schumann: Cello Concerto/Works for Cello and Piano
Maisky/Argerich/Orpheus Chamber Orchestra (DG)
Rating: ****
£13.99

Cultish, tousle-haired cellist Mischa Maisky is lustrously eloquent in Schumann's gorgeous concerto, particularly in the slow movement, where he is expansive without ever once sliding into sentimentality. The playing from the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, however, is scrupulous rather than committed, while the work needs a richer orchestral string tone than they can muster. The disc's main focus falls on Maisky's collaboration with Argerich for the chamber works, though the problem here is that the most substantial piece, the 5 Stücke im Volkston, isn't among Schumann's best and has a cloying cuteness that neither of them can disguise. The high points are the Op 70 Introduction and Allegro and Maisky's own transcription of part of the Märchenbilder, originally written for viola. Here, we finally get both of them at their finest - fervent, rapturous and beautiful.

Tchaikovsky: Eugene Onegin
Te Kanawa/Rosenshein/ Gedda/Hampson/Welsh National Opera Chorus and Orchestra/Mackerras (Chandos, 2 CDs)
Rating: ****
£16.99

Eugene Onegin has always proved a difficult opera to get right on disc. Originally issued by EMI in 1994, this set, albeit uneven, is better than most. Thomas Hampson's Onegin is arrogant, elegant, sexy and at times deeply disturbing. Kiri Te Kanawa, in sumptuous voice as Tatiana, is more convincing as the self-assured aristocrat of the later scenes than she is earlier on, where some artfully contrived singing doesn't always convey the impulsiveness of teenage desire. Neil Rosenshein is an intense if effortful Lensky, and as a bonus you get the unmissable Nicolai Gedda as the best of all Monsieur Triquets. Charles Mackerras, unusually, takes a while to settle, and the opera's emotional ratchet doesn't start turning until the second act. The recording is sung in English, which is preferable to the Russian-on-auto-pilot approach that has marred many versions of the work.

Wagner: Das Rheingold
Branzell/Maison/Schorr/ Habich/Metropolitan Opera Orchestra/Bodanzky (Naxos Historical, 2 CDs)
Rating: *****
£8.99

This is, quite simply, mind-blowing. Taped live in Boston during the Met's 1937 spring tour, it pairs Friedrich Schorr's Wotan - gloriously sung, noble, tragic and painfully self-deluded - with the unspeakably malignant Alberich of Eduard Habich. Neither performance has ever been bettered, though equally outstanding are Karin Branzell's Fricka - sexually manipulative rather than autocratic - and the great Belgian tenor René Maison as Loge, dangerously alluring and matchless in innuendo. The conductor, Artur Bodanzy, was controversial in his day, though his nervously urgent interpretation now seems years ahead of its time. Exhilarating, terrifying and savagely funny, the whole probes Rheingold's complex emotional and moral heart more completely than any other version I know. My only regret is that it doesn't form part of a complete Ring, since it was made at a time when the four operas were usually performed separately.

fields.headline: Robot Wars goes to America
fields.trailText: 10.45am: The BBC's Robot Wars is taking on the US after being sold to media giant Viacom, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The BBC's smash hit Robot Wars is taking on the US after its maker sold the programme to media giant Viacom.

The Television Corporation production, in which robots designed by mechanics boffins are pitted against "house robots" such as Sir Killalot, will be screened on Nickelodeon, MTV and TNN.

"Not only will this generate significant sales and production income but the exposure on US television across three channels will undoubtedly drive consumer products income," said Chris Rowlands, chief executive of The Television Corporation.

Repeats of the UK shows, which attract over 5m viewers, will be screened in the US, but Viacom will also make its own version.

The Television Corporation is determined to launch Robot Wars as an all-round product, and boasts of successful toy and internet ventures in the UK.

"Robot Wars has become an exploitable brand," said Mr Rowlands.

The announcement came as the Television Corporation, which recently bought independent producer Mentorn, reported full-year pre-tax profits of £4.6m, up from £3.8m in 1999.

Turnover climbed 37% to £43.9m boosted by the Mentorn acquisition.

The Television Corporation, which provides sports and entertainment programmes and post-production facilities, has also secured the contract to broadcast BSkyB's Premiership matches.
