webTitle: Seven doctors murdered, now US judges rule in favour of abortion hit list

fields.headline: Seven doctors murdered, now US judges rule in favour of abortion hit list
fields.trailText: Anti-abortionists in the United States have won the right to publish on the internet what amounts to a hit list of doctors who provide terminations for pregnant women.
fields.body:
Anti-abortionists in the United States have won the right to publish on the internet what amounts to a hit list of doctors who provide terminations for pregnant women.

The site, known as the Nuremberg Files, describes abortions as "Satan's food source". It prints "wanted" posters of the "baby butchers" and in some cases lists their addresses, car licence plate numbers and relatives' names. Seven doctors providing abortions in the US have been murdered in the past ten years.

The danger posed to doctors was underlined yesterday when one of the FBI's most wanted fugitives was arrested in France on suspicion of having murdered a gynaecologist in 1998. James Kopp, dubbed "Atomic Dog" by fellow anti-abortionists, was the subject of an international manhunt after Dr Barnett Slepian was shot dead at home near Buffalo, New York state.

Within hours, Slepian's name was posted on the Nuremberg Files with a cross through it.

The ruling upholding the right of the site to publish its content was upheld by a federal appeals court sitting in San Francisco.

The decision aroused despair last night among pro-choice doctors and campaigners. Warren Hern of Boulder, Colorado - one of the doctors who lodged the original lawsuit in Oregon that went on to the appeal court - said he was "shocked, disappointed and alarmed" by the decision. Dr Hern, who has been the target of an attack, said the ruling would be a "green light" for the most violent anti-abortionists.

Gloria Feldt, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, condemned the decision: "Reasonable people understand the difference between free speech and harassment that creates a violent social climate."

In making its ruling the bench pointed to the first amendment to the constitution, which guarantees free speech. One of the three judges said that "extreme rhetoric and violent action" had always played a part in American political life.

The ruling arose out of a 1999 case in Portland, Oregon where a jury awarded $107m (then worth £66.5m) in mainly punitive damages against the American Coalition of Life Activists, the Advocates for Life Ministries and 13 individuals who had put wanted posters of doctors on the web and described them as baby butchers.

The case had been brought by four doctors, a clinic and the Planned Parenthood organisation under the Freedom of Access to Clinics Act.

The identities of three of the seven doctors murdered in the past 10 years were listed on websites; there have been a further 17 attempted murders. Many such doctors now wear disguises and bullet-proof vests, live in fortified houses and vary their journeys to work.

"Political speech may not be punished just because it makes it more likely that someone will be harmed at some unknown time in the future by an unrelated third party," said Judge Alex Kozinski in the judgment.

"Extreme rhetoric and violent action have marked many political movements in American history. Patriots intimidated loyalists in both word and deed as they gathered support for American independence. John Brown and other abolitionists, convinced that God was on their side, committed murder in pursuit of their cause.

"In more modern times, the labour, anti-war, animal rights and environmental movements all have had their violent fringes," said Judge Kozinski, who was appointed under Ronald Reagan's presidency.

"As a result, much of what was said by non-violent participants acquired a tinge of menace ... If their (the websites') statements merely encouraged unrelated terrorists then their words are protected by the first amendment."

The American Civil Liberties Union agreed that the first amendment protected the right to protest against abortion, but argued that "it doesn't protect the right to threaten abortion providers with harm".

The ruling delighted anti-abortion groups. "Hallelujah!" said Neal Horsley of Carrollton, Georgia who runs the Nuremberg Files site.

Yesterday the site was posting new names of doctors, calling for fresh volunteers to carry out surveillance on doctors to protect "God's little babies". It also guided site visitors to the names of doctors killed.

"This is a reaffirmance of first amendment liberty," said Christopher Ferrara of the American Catholic Lawyers Association, an attorney in the case. "The posters do not contain any threats and in comparison to what we see in other protest movements, they are rather tame."

fields.headline: One2One hires new marketing chief
fields.trailText: 9.30am: One2One has hired Clent Richardson from Apple Computers as its new sales and marketing chief, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
One2One has hired Clent Richardson from Apple Computers as its new sales and marketing chief.

Mr Richardson joins on April 30 and will report directly to One2One managing director Harris Jones.

Tim Yates, marketing director for the brand, will report to Mr Richardson.

"I am thrilled to be joining One2One at this important time," said Mr Richardson.

"One2One is uniquely positioned to take advantage of the exciting and challenging times ahead in the world of 3G and beyond and is an integral part of Deutsche Telekom, a powerful, global, forward-looking leader in the world of communications."

"Clent joins us at a time when we are moving to a new stage in the company's development," added Mr Jones.

"With over 8m customers and a market share of around 21%, we will now become increasingly focused on retaining customers by delivering value and service excellence throughout the lifetime of their relationship with us.

"Clent is going to play a crucial role in developing and implementing this strategy."

fields.headline: Doctors breaking 'free NHS' principle
fields.standfirst: Thousands of old people in care homes charged for visit from GP
fields.trailText: Thousands of older people in care homes and sheltered housing are being forced to pay to see an NHS doctor in flagrant breach of the principle that state medical services should be free, charities claimed last night.
fields.body:
Thousands of older people in care homes and sheltered housing are being forced to pay to see an NHS doctor in flagrant breach of the principle that state medical services should be free, charities claimed last night.

An investigation of 183 charitable homes found 34% were paying retainers of up to £10,000 a year to get attention. Fees averaging £41 a year for each resident were commonly introduced at the request of GPs who were already collecting £45.05 from the NHS for each patient on their lists over the age of 75.

In some cases the fee topped £150 a year and there were extra charges for basic services such as winter flu jabs, said a report by the Association of Charity Officers.

Although the homes were meeting part of the cost from their charitable income, many were obliged to pass on charges to residents. The result was a breach of the principle that services should be provided according to need and free at the point of use.

This week the government published a strategy to improve NHS services for older people and eliminate discrimination. At a press conference on Tuesday, John Hutton, the health minister responsible for social care, said he was not aware of older people being charged for primary care. "If there is clear evidence ... bring it to my attention."

Valerie Barrow, director of the Association of Charity Officers, said yesterday: "This study clearly shows that some older people, because of where they live, are paying twice."

Tessa Harding, head of policy at Help the Aged, said: "It is outrageous that older people in residential and nursing homes are having to pay over the odds for something the rest of us get free. I cannot believe it is the government's intention that those who need healthcare most should have to pay."

The report found "damaging evidence of confusion over the definition of core NHS services". While 80% of GPs provided free winter flu jabs for residents of care homes and sheltered housing, 20% listed the inoculation as a "contracted" service.

About 10% of GPs conducted special surgeries in care homes at no extra cost, but 27% charged a retainer without offering on-site surgeries. "The blurred definition of core NHS services means many older people in residential care homes are denied healthcare free at the point of need," the report said.

The British Medical Association (BMA) said it had been asking the government for at least seven years to increase NHS cover for people in nursing homes.

Andrew Dearden, chairman of the BMA's community care committee, said: "General practitioners are left with few options. They could decide on no extra services at all. They could decide to supplement the NHS without any financial support or additional resources, but that would impact on the care of their other patients. A third option for GPs would be to say to the homes that they want to provide extra services as non-NHS services - and would the homes be willing to pay for them?"

The Department of Health said GPs were entitled to charge for services such as training staff. "That is different from direct patient services. We will investigate any allegations of abuse," a spokesman said.

In some cases the fee topped £150 a year and there were extra charges for basic services such as winter flu jabs, said a report by the Association of Charity Officers. Although the homes were meeting part of the cost from their charitable income, many were obliged to pass on charges to residents. The result was a breach of the principle that services should be provided according to need and free at the point of use. This week the government published a strategy to improve NHS services for older people and eliminate discrimination. At a press conference on Tuesday, John Hutton, the health minister responsible for social care, said he was not aware of older people being charged for primary care. "If there is clear evidence ... bring it to my attention." Valerie Barrow, director of the Association of Charity Officers, said yesterday: "This study clearly shows that some older people, because of where they live, are paying twice." Tessa Harding, head of policy at Help the Aged, said: "It is outrageous that older people in residential and nursing homes are having to pay over the odds for something the rest of us get free. I cannot believe it is the government's intention that those who need healthcare most should have to pay." The report found "damaging evidence of confusion over the definition of core NHS services". While 80% of GPs provided free winter flu jabs for residents of care homes and sheltered housing, 20% listed the inoculation as a "contracted" service. About 10% of GPs conducted special surgeries in care homes at no extra cost, but 27% charged a retainer without offering on-site surgeries. "The blurred definition of core NHS services means many older people in residential care homes are denied healthcare free at the point of need," the report said. The British Medical Association (BMA) said it had been asking the government for at least seven years to increase NHS cover for people in nursing homes. Andrew Dearden, chairman of the BMA's community care committee, said: "General practitioners are left with few options. They could decide on no extra services at all. They could decide to supplement the NHS without any financial support or additional resources, but that would impact on the care of their other patients. A third option for GPs would be to say to the homes that they want to provide extra services as non-NHS services - and would the homes be willing to pay for them?" The Department of Health said GPs were entitled to charge for services such as training staff. "That is different from direct patient services. We will investigate any allegations of abuse," a spokesman said.

webTitle: Religious leaders call for election delay

fields.headline: Religious leaders call for election delay
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Religious leaders have weighed in on the debate over the timing of the general election, today urging the prime minister, Tony Blair, to push back his preferred date of May 3 in favour of the autumn because of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Religious leaders have weighed in on the debate over the timing of the general election, today urging the prime minister, Tony Blair, to push back his preferred date of May 3 in favour of the autumn because of the foot and mouth crisis.

The archbishop of York, the Rev David Hope, told the Times that many people would be disenfranchised if an election was held while the disease was still spreading across the countryside.

"Ultimately the prime minister must make his own decision, but my view is the election ought to be postponed," Dr Hope, the second most senior bishop in the church of England, said. "There is clearly a very strong feeling in the farming community that there should not be an election at the moment."

His concerns were said to be shared by the archbishop of Canterbury, Dr George Carey.

Dr Hope's call for the election to be delayed was reported to be backed by a number of other senior bishops, including the bishop of Exeter, the Rev Michael Langrish.

"If the Government presses ahead with a May 3 election, it will be seen by many in Devon as a further lack of understanding and sensitivity to the depth of the crisis here in the county," Mr Langrish said.

The comments from religious leaders come one day after the Tory leader, William Hague, publicly said the election should not be held on May 3.

Mr Blair has set himself a deadline of Monday by which to make his decision.

The Bishops of Carlisle and Hereford were also reported to want a postponement, however the Bishops of Durham and Oxford were said to want the election to go ahead in May.

fields.headline: Disney takes gameshow to another level
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Disney is set to open the first Who Wants to be a Millionaire? theme park, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Entertainment giant Disney is set to open the first Who Wants to be a Millionaire? theme park, taking the gameshow craze on to another level.

The Hollywood giant, which operates the most successful theme parks in the world, is planning to open the attraction in Florida.

Based at Disney's MGM studios, it will enable 600 visitors at a time to take part in a special 30-minute show.

Disney has created a giant replica set with visitors playing for up to a million points which can then be converted into Disney prizes.

As well as US visitors, the theme park is designed to appeal to UK holiday-makers, who flock to Florida in their millions every year.

Disney-owned TV channel ABC has enjoyed spectacular success with the TV show format since buying it from UK production company Celador and is keen to exploit the concept further.

Although US TV audiences for the show have fallen more recently, it still regularly pulls in more than 20 million viewers on ABC.

Disney is looking at new ways of pulling in visitors to its parks in the face of falling consumer spending in the US.

Earlier this week it announced 4,000 job cuts, 3% of its workforce.

Complete Communications, parent of Celador and ultimate owner of the rights to Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has made a fortune from the concept.

Over one billion viewers worldwide now watch a version of the show in 67 countries.

Complete has already created a top-selling boardgame and a computer game format.

In the autumn ITV will be launching the first interactive TV format on the ITV2 digital channel, which is expected to effectively launch interactive TV into the mass market.

webTitle: Peter Hain: speed up compensation for miners

fields.headline: Payment due
fields.standfirst: We are speeding up the payment of compensation claims from former miners. They deserve it
fields.trailText: We are speeding up the payment of compensation claims from former miners. They deserve it.
fields.body:
After 42 years underground, Ken Herdman at 74 is trapped on the ground floor of his small home in the former pit village of Seven Sisters up the Dulais Valley in south Wales.

He talks fitfully through wheezes, gasping into his medication mask, another one hanging nearby from an oxygen cylinder, his wife hovering constantly in support. If he goes to the bathroom or moves to the dinner table he takes ages to recover from the effort.

When I visited him I was in the happy position of bringing news of a substantial payment for his crippling bronchitis and emphysema. He is owed this because his former employer, British Coal, failed to protect him from dangerous, dusty conditions. Across Britain there are tens of thousands of other former miners suffering from lung disease or vibration white finger. And, like him many have waited a very long time for compensation. Many are still waiting.

There are a quarter of a million claimants and the number has been rising at the rate of 1,000 a week, making this the biggest compensation claim in the history of Britain (and maybe the world). Over £2bn has been set aside by the government - and this is not capped so it too could rise.

On lung disease, progress has been desperately slow because the system of medical assessment to deliver fair payments is fiendishly complex. It was required to reflect the ruling by Mr Justice Turner in 1998 following a lengthy court action brought against the last Tory government and British Coal which had resisted the miners' claims for justice.

Then followed an additional 18 months of legal wrangling. Every major improvement requires agreement between the department and solicitors on both sides whose legal fees could rise to £250m. For a long time there was an adversarial relationship between the government and the miners' solicitors but, fortunately, cooperation is now good.

But it is important that the scheme is operated fairly. Taxpayers would demand nothing less. The non-smoker who has worked underground for 40 years deserves much more than the 40 cigarettes a day man who has worked below for just a year. So procedures are needed for accurate individual assessments.

The compensation scheme has been bedevilled by other problems. Both solicitors and the medical assessment contractors, Healthcall, for various reasons failed to prioritise the oldest and sickest miners. Younger, fitter men have been processed first while others tragically died. There have been long delays and mix-ups between all the key players: also mix-ups by the claims handlers, IRISC. Solicitors have been swamped by the number of claims. The government has also made mistakes.

A shortage of respiratory consultants has added to the delays. Their professional assessment includes checking pages of records on a CD-rom which for each individual can run to more than 800 pages.

And the records are often hard to trace. Teams of Land-Rovers with scanners comb the countryside, calling at surgeries and hospitals. Sometimes notes go back decades in traditional doctors' scrawl. In the mining archives at Cannock there are 30 miles of files from long-closed pits, many not even indexed and just dumped after privatisation.

Nevertheless, we have ensured that payments are now flowing more quickly, at the rate of £1m daily, and soon to rise; £360m has been paid out so far, injecting huge spending into deprived coal communities - amounts like the £140,000 recently paid to a south Wales widow or £124,979 to a Valleys miner.

But this is still not good enough. We recently cleared £400m to compensate former miners or their widows for the loss of pension entitlements because of early retirement due to illness. An additional £30m has been set aside for £2,000 interim payments to widows and between £7,000 and £14,000 to emphysema victims with asthma.

I have also asked that the oldest and those most ill are given priority. Younger and fitter men finding that their appointments have been rescheduled, I am sure will agree that men in their 70s and 80s - who can hardly breathe or move and some who may die soon - should go ahead.

We are streamlining the medical assessments. Now we not only have the capacity to do 1,000 per week but are also close to having the necessary resources in place too. This will double the rate we were achieving last year. But it will depend on finding enough doctors. I have appealed to respiratory consultants to come forward - out of retirement We have been opening new test centres.

The medical assessors, the claims handlers, solicitors and government officials have all learnt painful lessons of implementing a scheme more than double the estimated size. Over the next three months a backlog of 1,000 medical assessments each week will be progressed for payment.

fields.bodyText: After 42 years underground, Ken Herdman at 74 is trapped on the ground floor of his small home in the former pit village of Seven Sisters up the Dulais Valley in south Wales. He talks fitfully through wheezes, gasping into his medication mask, another one hanging nearby from an oxygen cylinder, his wife hovering constantly in support. If he goes to the bathroom or moves to the dinner table he takes ages to recover from the effort. When I visited him I was in the happy position of bringing news of a substantial payment for his crippling bronchitis and emphysema. He is owed this because his former employer, British Coal, failed to protect him from dangerous, dusty conditions. Across Britain there are tens of thousands of other former miners suffering from lung disease or vibration white finger. And, like him many have waited a very long time for compensation. Many are still waiting. There are a quarter of a million claimants and the number has been rising at the rate of 1,000 a week, making this the biggest compensation claim in the history of Britain (and maybe the world). Over £2bn has been set aside by the government - and this is not capped so it too could rise. On lung disease, progress has been desperately slow because the system of medical assessment to deliver fair payments is fiendishly complex. It was required to reflect the ruling by Mr Justice Turner in 1998 following a lengthy court action brought against the last Tory government and British Coal which had resisted the miners' claims for justice. Then followed an additional 18 months of legal wrangling. Every major improvement requires agreement between the department and solicitors on both sides whose legal fees could rise to £250m. For a long time there was an adversarial relationship between the government and the miners' solicitors but, fortunately, cooperation is now good. But it is important that the scheme is operated fairly. Taxpayers would demand nothing less. The non-smoker who has worked underground for 40 years deserves much more than the 40 cigarettes a day man who has worked below for just a year. So procedures are needed for accurate individual assessments. The compensation scheme has been bedevilled by other problems. Both solicitors and the medical assessment contractors, Healthcall, for various reasons failed to prioritise the oldest and sickest miners. Younger, fitter men have been processed first while others tragically died. There have been long delays and mix-ups between all the key players: also mix-ups by the claims handlers, IRISC. Solicitors have been swamped by the number of claims. The government has also made mistakes. A shortage of respiratory consultants has added to the delays. Their professional assessment includes checking pages of records on a CD-rom which for each individual can run to more than 800 pages. And the records are often hard to trace. Teams of Land-Rovers with scanners comb the countryside, calling at surgeries and hospitals. Sometimes notes go back decades in traditional doctors' scrawl. In the mining archives at Cannock there are 30 miles of files from long-closed pits, many not even indexed and just dumped after privatisation. Nevertheless, we have ensured that payments are now flowing more quickly, at the rate of £1m daily, and soon to rise; £360m has been paid out so far, injecting huge spending into deprived coal communities - amounts like the £140,000 recently paid to a south Wales widow or £124,979 to a Valleys miner. But this is still not good enough. We recently cleared £400m to compensate former miners or their widows for the loss of pension entitlements because of early retirement due to illness. An additional £30m has been set aside for £2,000 interim payments to widows and between £7,000 and £14,000 to emphysema victims with asthma. I have also asked that the oldest and those most ill are given priority. Younger and fitter men finding that their appointments have been rescheduled, I am sure will agree that men in their 70s and 80s - who can hardly breathe or move and some who may die soon - should go ahead. We are streamlining the medical assessments. Now we not only have the capacity to do 1,000 per week but are also close to having the necessary resources in place too. This will double the rate we were achieving last year. But it will depend on finding enough doctors. I have appealed to respiratory consultants to come forward - out of retirement We have been opening new test centres. Over the next three months a backlog of 1,000 medical assessments each week will be progressed for payment. fields.headline: Taking orders from God
fields.standfirst: The prime minister has been talking repeatedly about his beliefs. How far will this get him?
fields.trailText: The prime minister has been talking repeatedly about his beliefs. How far will this get him?
fields.body:
Are we about to embark on the "Holier than thou" election campaign? Tony Blair disavowed any intention of vying with William Hague for the notional religious vote when he addressed a multifaith conference, organised by the Christian Socialist Movement, at Westminster Central Hall yesterday. But to see various Christian groups limbering up for the hustings, much more ostentatiously even than the political parties, is to sense that this is an opportunity neither politicians nor the churches feel they can dare to miss.

Our prime minister, probably the most overtly pious leader since Gladstone and certainly the most pro-Catholic since the glorious revolution, can be forgiven for feeling irked that William Hague, a man who proclaims a Christianity culled from the Yorkshire Dales rather than regular church attendance, has made the running in playing to a supposedly Christian constituency. Blair's pitch was rather loftier than that, but he was comfortable in advertising his belief in faith-based organisations helping to tackle social problems and in politicians promoting traditional family values.

If the two leaders do compete for a putative religious vote, none will be more delighted than the evangelical Christians who, noting the influence of religious groups on American politics, believe that might be replicated here. They have been stressing the million evangelicals in Britain who might just swing the election, always supposing they were all to vote the same way.

No wonder the Tory leader, desperate for whatever support he can find, has set up a Christian cell in Central Office and is stressing Conservative morality.

Thrilled to be thus courted, church leaders are setting out their stalls too. The Evangelical Alliance has issued its own pack, offering supporters an election prayer guide, Christian perspectives on electoral issues and suggested questions for candidates ("imagine what impact we would have on the candidates if we join together to ask probing, difficult questions that go straight to the heart of the matter and challenge conventional thinking").

The Church Society has set out its own manifesto ("Righteousness exalteth a nation but sin is a reproach to any people ... moral relativism and libertarian values which dominate public life have had disastrous consequences for our nation..."). Even the Catholic bishops have renewed their call for the electorate to vote for "the common good" - a call which, as the Catholic weekly the Tablet has pointed out is distinctly ambiguous.

Meanwhile, Ram Gidoomal, the Christian candidate who gained nearly 100,000 votes in last year's London mayoral elections, has joined the band-wagon with a little book called How Would Jesus Vote? - a title which understandably promises more than it can actually deliver, the Bible being reticent about first century voting patterns in Roman-occupied Galilee.

What distinguishes this kerfuffle is that the issues on which the religious communities are getting steamed up, abortion (of course), human embryo research, gay equality, marriage and traditional morality, are neither at the heart of the political debate nor politically partisan, except that they are deeply conservative.

Here no church leader is likely to trespass on British reticence to tell worshippers who to vote for. But some Christians cannot understand why, if Mr Blair and Mr Hague are so religiously committed, they do not insist on opposing abortion or embryo research. Nor can the leaders explain it to them as they stress the sincerity of their beliefs.

But any lessons Christian activists derive from America founder on the differences of our societies and political systems. Even the most die-hard Conservative Christian backroom boys concede privately that privatisation of welfare services would not actually work, for all Mr Hague's wishful thinking. Mr Blair's view is more sophisticated: yesterday he talked of partnership between voluntary organisations and government agencies.

The idea of handing over welfare provision even partially to religious charities would not only be unwelcome to the charities themselves but is also impractical. It has not even been outstandingly successful in Texas where they once passed children's homes to the likes of the Reverend Lester Roloff with his quaint Bible-based belief that his charges could survive on a diet of watermelon.

Here the churches themselves need to sort out their approach to politics. It is when Mr Gidoomal suggests that Christian voters should apply their morality to the beliefs of various candidates that the lobby becomes distinctly confused. How would he advise believers to vote in, say, Bromley and Chiselhurst, whose Conservative MP, Eric Forth, has just informed the Commons that all non-Protestants are potential traitors?

The former minister told the House during a debate last month that the issue of allegiance to our sovereign monarch or to a foreign power was as alive today as in the time of Henry VIII: "Indeed it might even be more potent in our multifaith society. Some people might believe that sections of our multi-faith, multicultural society have, in some circumstances, not only a divided loyalty but a greater loyalty than that given to the queen and the state..."

This new version of the Tebbit cricket test has not yet been disavowed by Mr Hague. Or how is a Christian to vote in Exeter, where the Labour MP, Ben Bradshaw, is a committed believer, son of a vicar, but gay? For the record, Mr Gidoomal suggests it might be possible to vote for a "buffoon" like Mr Forth, even though his views are bizarre, but that he could never vote for Mr Bradshaw, however otherwise attractive his policies might be.

In the end such conundrums are ir-reconcilable, which is why most churches end up advising their members to vote for whoever they deem the best candidate, just like everyone else.

But it does not answer the question why our political leaders want to wear their religious hearts on their sleeves. Perhaps they should recall John F Kennedy's dusty answer 40 years ago, when he reassured a congregation of Protestant churchmen in Houston, anxious about the prospect of having a Catholic president, that he would not be taking his orders from the Vatican.

fields.headline: Embracing the faiths
fields.standfirst: Mr Blair is proceeding with caution. Good
fields.trailText: In a nation like ours, with its rich traditions of scepticism, atheism and non-conformism, it is not surprising that a politician who dares talks about faith will be rewarded with an instant backlash.
fields.body:
In a nation like ours, with its rich traditions of scepticism, atheism and non-conformism, it is not surprising that a politician who dares talks about faith will be rewarded with an instant backlash. So it has been with Tony Blair - on both occasions. When the then leader of the opposition spoke of his relationship with his maker in the Easter run-up to the 1997 election, he was instantly lacerated for seeking to play the God card. Now, four years later and also in the lead-up to polling day, he has got the same response. No sooner had his date with the Christian Socialist Movement been set than he was scolded. "This is an agnostic nation," warned Roy Hattersley, fearful that Mr Blair's "evangelising" would only alienate those of a different faith or of none. "A dangerous precedent," muttered Labour MP Martin O'Neill.

In the event, did yesterday's address by the prime minister to the Christians justify the critics' fears? Not on one score. Liberals have always worried that a religious lead from a politician would frighten Britain's non-Christian minorities. Yet on yesterday's evidence, they hardly felt excluded: representatives from almost all Britain's "faith communities" were in attendance, while Mr Blair based a good part of his message on the ideas of the Chief Rabbi, Jonathan Sacks. The old notion that British multi-culturalism is threatened by a religiously inflected politics may have to be revised: Britain's ethnic minorities appear less uncomfortable with Downing Street Christianity than Britain's secularists and unaffiliated - who are, of course, the great majority.

But there are other concerns. Many worry that a new trend toward religious schools could see different communities shut off from each other, educated apart. Others fear government grants for religious agencies who would only hire people of their own faith, discriminating against others. Mr Blair avoided addressing these risks. But he did offer some reassurance. He made clear that his interest is in involving voluntary groups, including faith-based ones, in social work "as partners, not substitutes". The state will remain the chief agency and prime source of money, but it should be able to draw on both the commitment and infrastructure maintained by voluntary, including religious, groups. To want to use, rather than waste, that resource surely makes sense - whether you have a faith or not.

webTitle: Sketch: Fonz tries his best to cheer up Tories' unhappy days

fields.headline: Fonz tries his best to cheer up Tories' unhappy days
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: Tories can't wait for the election. Not the general election, of course - they seem to have written that off - but the leadership election they assume will follow shortly afterwards.
fields.body:
Tories can't wait for the election. Not the general election, of course - they seem to have written that off - but the leadership election they assume will follow shortly afterwards.

Even Michael Portillo, who I suppose will be standing in that particular poll, appears to have quietly given up on his party's chances. Perhaps in his heart of hearts, or even among friends in his front room, he secretly wants them to do badly. After all, if they perform well - even if they do a little better than the polls suggest - there won't be any change of leadership.

But the ironclad tradition for a person in his position is to pretend that you are about to sweep to victory under the courageous and far-sighted leadership of whichever dork is in charge at the time and whom you privately hope to defeat in six weeks' time.

I can recall William Hague stumping the villages of North Yorkshire explaining eight vital reasons why everyone should vote for John Major, then proceeding to list all eight at every meeting, of which there were plenty.

Yesterday Mr Portillo sounded as cheerful about the coming battle as Eeyore did on his birthday. Indeed all his questions to Gordon Brown (it was the turn of the Treasury team to be in the firing line, if you call a pelting with wet sponges being in the firing line) were predicated on the assumption that Labour was going to be in power for a long time.

He didn't even bother with the ritual formulation "in the highly unlikely event of the party opposite being returned to power". He just wanted Mr Brown to promise that, when it came to a referendum on the euro, he would ask a straight question and would make sure that both sides got equal funding.

Well, of course they won't. If the next government decides to join the euro, it will rig the referendum vote in every way it can. That's what governments do. I don't know which side will win, but I do know it won't be a fair fight.

The shadow chancellor brought the famous catch to his throat, which made him sound even more like Eeyore. "I must say [stifled sob] that the chancellor is behaving disgracefully."

Mr Portillo went on: "The question will be tendentious and the funding will be rigged!"

As teenagers say these days, "and your point is?"

Meanwhile the Tory awkward squad were having a wonderful time on the backbenches. They know they've had it, they wouldn't know what to do if by some miracle they did win, and they are determined to enjoy themselves in the meantime.

Mr Brown was busy saying how important were his five economic tests for joining the euro. This is simply not true: the "tests" are one real measurement and four vague pieties. "Con man!" shouted John Bercow.

The Speaker was on his feet in seconds. This was an unparliamentary term and Mr Bercow should withdraw.

Mr Bercow offered a sarcastic, even insulting parody of an apology. "Oh, readily, Mr Speaker! I will withdraw. Of course!" His arms flailed around like an 18th-century French dancing teacher. Then he sank back into his seat and went into a great jokey, eye-rolling, search-me, what-was-all-that-about? routine for the benefit of the other MPs around him.

I realised that he was turning into the Fonz from Happy Days, the Mister Cool at the back of the class whose peer prestige depends on not caring what authority figures think about him or anything else.

I suppose that if the Tories have decided to treat the Speaker like a supply teacher in a south London comprehensive, then they probably aren't looking forward to a speedy return to government.

fields.headline: An illiterate philosopher
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has long had philosophical aspirations. And, in recent days, he has been at it again
fields.body:
Tony Blair has long had philosophical aspirations. He told a journalist that he wished he had studied political philosophy at university. He once wrote to Isaiah Berlin about his famous distinction between negative and positive liberty. He has even made philosophical claims for the "third way". And, in recent days, he has been at it again. Prior to addressing the Christian Socialists yesterday, he explained in a long interview in the Sunday Telegraph that his worldview has of late undergone a profound transformation.

"There is a very interesting debate which I used to study at university between the concept of natural law and utilitarianism. I have shifted far more towards the first, having been for a long time for the second ... I'm far more of a believer in ... the power and the necessity to make judgments about the human condition, as opposed to simply saying, well look, what's good for the greatest number is fine. I'm a great respecter of science and the ability of science to inform our perceptions of the world. But I think there is a danger sometimes that we look at everything just in terms of what its utilitarian value is."

Blair's interest in ideas strikes me as admirable. It is hard to think of a recent prime minister who would talk as if abstract ideas, rather than policies, really matter. It is courageous and sincere, and it has the great merit of making his spin doctors nervous. However, there is something a little depressing in Blair's theorising.

For our leader, despite his enthusiasm, shows a sorry degree of philosophical illiteracy. On the face of it, his statement was entirely incoherent. My philosophical dictionary tells me that to believe in natural law is to believe, with Thomas Acquinas, that there are objective moral standards written into the universe. A utilitarian, on the other hand, believes that actions are right in so far as they tend to promote happiness. There is no opposition between them. Many utilitarians, indeed, have believed very firmly in the objectivity of their moral standard.

Perhaps I am being pedantic - "You know what he means." And I think I do. Or at least I think I can detect a cluster of potential thoughts behind his words. His reflections come just after he has been talking about his reli gious faith, and are no doubt connected to it.

One of the things Blair probably meant is that he has become to believe that only God can provide ethics with a sure foundation. Perhaps he also intended to say that there is more to life than the satisfaction of our appetites. Or that the end does not always justify the means. Perhaps there was even a fourth thought: that nature is sacrosanct and that scientists should respect it.

It is odd, once you start thinking about them, how wildly off-target these beliefs are. The first and the last are pretty clearly indefensible: atheists have as strong grounds for their values as religious believers; if we are to declare nature sacrosanct, than we should ban doctors from curing patients. The second and the third, by contrast, aim at straw men: no one, not even the most fanatical utilitarian, believes that pleasure is the only value, or that the ends always justify the means. Blair is tilting at windmills.

But perhaps I am still being unfair. Perhaps he has become convinced that politicians are, by and large, too pragmatic or even cynical? Or possibly he now believes that we have, as a people, become too tolerant? These would have been significant and stimulating convictions, had our prime minister been able to articulate them.

But we should not blame Blair, for he is pretty typical. Philosophically most of us have hardly got beyond primary school. There are strong currents of scepticism, relativism, even nihilism in our thinking, but these run alongside equally strong beliefs in universal moral standards. Most of us are sceptical about God, but unsure of whether ethics can survive without him. Our views on GM crops, human clones, the censorship of pornography or the rights and wrongs of retribution veer wildly from one side to the other.

If Blair really does think philosophy is important, he could ensure that religious education, still compulsory in all schools, includes a modicum of philosophy. At the very least, pupils should be taught to think critically about the arguments surrounding God's existence. If our children are going to be made to study the Bible and the Koran, they should have to study Socrates and Hume as well. Who knows, we might one day even get a prime minister able to turn his moral gropings into words.

Ben Rogers is author of AJ Ayer, a Life (Vintage)

For our leader, despite his enthusiasm, shows a sorry degree of philosophical illiteracy. On the face of it, his statement was entirely incoherent. My philosophical dictionary tells me that to believe in natural law is to believe, with Thomas Acquinas, that there are objective moral standards written into the universe. A utilitarian, on the other hand, believes that actions are right in so far as they tend to promote happiness. There is no opposition between them. Many utilitarians, indeed, have believed very firmly in the objectivity of their moral standard. Perhaps I am being pedantic - "You know what he means." And I think I do. Or at least I think I can detect a cluster of potential thoughts behind his words. His reflections come just after he has been talking about his reli gious faith, and are no doubt connected to it. One of the things Blair probably meant is that he has become to believe that only God can provide ethics with a sure foundation. Perhaps he also intended to say that there is more to life than the satisfaction of our appetites. Or that the end does not always justify the means. Perhaps there was even a fourth thought: that nature is sacrosanct and that scientists should respect it. It is odd, once you start thinking about them, how wildly off-target these beliefs are. The first and the last are pretty clearly indefensible: atheists have as strong grounds for their values as religious believers; if we are to declare nature sacrosanct, than we should ban doctors from curing patients. The second and the third, by contrast, aim at straw men: no one, not even the most fanatical utilitarian, believes that pleasure is the only value, or that the ends always justify the means. Blair is tilting at windmills. But perhaps I am still being unfair. Perhaps he has become convinced that politicians are, by and large, too pragmatic or even cynical? Or possibly he now believes that we have, as a people, become too tolerant? These would have been significant and stimulating convictions, had our prime minister been able to articulate them. But we should not blame Blair, for he is pretty typical. Philosophically most of us have hardly got beyond primary school. There are strong currents of scepticism, relativism, even nihilism in our thinking, but these run alongside equally strong beliefs in universal moral standards. Most of us are sceptical about God, but unsure of whether ethics can survive without him. Our views on GM crops, human clones, the censorship of pornography or the rights and wrongs of retribution veer wildly from one side to the other. If Blair really does think philosophy is important, he could ensure that religious education, still compulsory in all schools, includes a modicum of philosophy. At the very least, pupils should be taught to think critically about the arguments surrounding God's existence. If our children are going to be made to study the Bible and the Koran, they should have to study Socrates and Hume as well. Who knows, we might one day even get a prime minister able to turn his moral gropings into words. Ben Rogers is author of AJ Ayer, a Life (Vintage)

fields.headline: Eurosceptic rebel leaves Tory party
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague's hopes of unity around his hard-line European policy were shattered last night when one of the leading Eurosceptic MPs Christopher Gill confirmed that he is no longer a member of the Conservative party.
fields.body:
William Hague's hopes of unity around his hard-line European policy were shattered last night when one of the leading Eurosceptic MPs Christopher Gill confirmed that he is no longer a member of the Conservative party.

The MP for Ludlow - one of the nine Maastricht rebels who had the whip withdrawn for six months by John Major - also said he would be addressing meetings of the United Kingdom Independence party, which advocates withdrawal from Europe, during the election campaign.

The UKIP is putting up candidates in around 300 marginal seats and could jeopardise any Tory recovery.

Mr Gill, who had not informed Conservative Central Office of his move, said last night that he had allowed his party membership to lapse in January when he took over the chairmanship of the right-wing Freedom Association - also an advocate of withdrawal from Europe.

But he strongly denied rumours that he would defect to the UKIP. "I shall continue to take the Conservative whip. That's the contract I have with my electorate. I don't have much to say to those who cross the floor of the House in the course of a parliament," he added in a swipe at Peter Temple Morris and Shaun Woodward, the two leftwing Tories who defected to Labour soon after the election.

At central office, where Mr Gill has not been a popular figure since he resisted attempts to get him deselected at the height of John Major's Euro-crisis, a spokesman played down the development. "Chris Gill has not resigned the Conservative whip and as far as we're concerned he's still a Conservative MP. You do not have to be a member of the party to be an MP."

Mr Gill has refused to tone down his Europe views ever since he had the whip restored in April 1995. At the end of last year he said he would stand down at the next election because he disagreed with the party's Europe policy and appealed to Mr Hague at the very least to oppose entry to the euro and to seek to regain control over agriculture and fisheries policy.

In another embarrassing sign of pre-election disarray, the Tory leader came under strong pressure from the left-leaning Reform group to expel the senior backbencher John Townend over his controversial remarks on immigration.

The 66-year-old Yorkshire East MP, who is also standing down at the general election, blamed immigrants for rising crime levels and undermining Britain's "homogeneous Anglo-Saxon society". While the group welcomed Mr Hague's rejection of Mr Townend's comments, it said that the party needed to go further.

It said that it was particularly important that it took action in the light of recent comments by the leadership - an apparent reference to Mr Hague's speech claiming that Britain was in danger of becoming a "foreign land".

Kenneth Clarke, the former chancellor and president of the Reform group, believes that Mr Hague should remove the whip from Mr Townend after he praised Enoch Powell's "rivers of blood" speech.

A statement from the group said: "The whip should now be withdrawn. Only by doing this will the party demonstrate publicly its rejection of racism in any form."

Mr Townend's successor as Tory candidate, the former whip Greg Knight, yesterday refused for a second time to condemn Mr Townend's remarks.

fields.headline: Hague's three steps to dominance
fields.standfirst:
Leader has shown shrewd political judgment in boosting his position
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Leader has shown shrewd political judgment in boosting his position
fields.body:
William Hague is, for the first time since he took over as Tory leader, setting the political weather.

Even his detractors admit that Mr Hague has judged his interventions on the foot and mouth crisis with great care, wrong-footing the government on numerous occasions. "William's having a good war," said one Tory MP, not noted for his admiration of Mr Hague.

The Tory leader managed to dominate early headlines yesterday when he finally called on Tony Blair to cancel plans for a general election on May 3. Sweeping aside fears that he might appear to be running scared of an election, Mr Hague claimed that calling an election now would place "party before country".

His intervention, during a visit to Cumbria, was the culmination of weeks of anguish over how to respond to the foot and mouth crisis. No grand Tory strategy was mapped out on day one because nobody knew how serious the disease would be. But the Hague strategy has gone through three distinct phases.

When foot and mouth was first confirmed, Mr Hague instructed the shadow cabinet to adopt a bipartisan approach and to say nothing about postponing the election.

As the number of cases increased, Mr Hague offered constructive criticisms of the government and raised doubts about holding the local elections on May 3.

In the last two weeks, the gloves came off and Mr Hague launched stinging attacks on the government for failing to take hold of the crisis and for appearing to press ahead with elections.

One shadow minister said that Mr Hague felt that it was important to adopt a bipartisan approach initially because the Tories would not be rewarded for scoring political points during a national crisis.

As the crisis deepened, Mr Hague moved away from his bipartisan approach on March 13 when he used a visit to Cheltenham to call on the government to give a six month "business rate holiday" to all businesses hit by foot and mouth.

During his Commons clash with the prime minister the following day, Mr Hague called for a policy of immediate slaughter and for the army's role to be stepped up.

As speculation intensified about the election, Mr Hague used a visit to Cumbria on March 15 to raise his first doubts about election timing. In careful language, he warned that foot and mouth was having a "devastating impact".

While the political truce had ended, open political warfare had yet to break out.

At a press conference on March 20, Mr Hague said the government should introduce legislation to allow the county council elections to be postponed.

Appearing on a platform stripped of Tory symbols, Mr Hague said: "I don't think it would be right to call an election at a time when there is a national crisis out of control."

It was at the end of last week, when an official epidemiological report forecast a possible 4,400 cases of foot and mouth by June, that Mr Hague lambasted the prime minister for mishandling the crisis.

Mr Hague used a speech in Coventry to call on the prime minister to set up a "crisis cabinet" to deal with foot and mouth. He likened the crisis in the countryside to wartime Britain.

Tory sources privately hope that foot and mouth will help them whenever the election is held. If Tony Blair opts for May 3, the Tories hope to win support from voters who share his view that an early election is inappropriate.

If foot and mouth forces the prime minister to delay the election, Tories hope the expected downturn in the economy will pay dividends.

Against this backdrop, however, the Tories' position in the polls remains as dire as ever.

webTitle: Leader: Desperate measures for foot and mouth

fields.headline: Desperate measures
fields.standfirst:
The 'last resort' may be the only choice

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Without sheep, which have been there since the 12th century, today's picturesque grasslands would be turned into shabby scrub.
fields.body:
A Downing Street spokesman yesterday promised a decision within 48 hours on whether vaccination should be used to curb the spread of the foot and mouth epidemic. Ministers were reluctant to turn to what they have described as "the last resort", but with the slaughter toll now exceeding 500,000 (plus another 300,000 already authorised), they were finally forced this week to seek permission from the EU's standing veterinary committee. Permission to vaccinate 180,000 valuable dairy cattle in Cumbria and Devon was granted on Wednesday. British scientists, vets and farmers are all divided over the value of vaccination, but so far, ministers have pursued a united line with the farmers' national leaders. Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers Union, yesterday emphasised again the limitations of vaccination: not 100% effective, requiring repeated booster injections, involving a delay of several days before it begins to work. Yet he also plainly signalled for the first time that a targeted vaccination programme might have to be introduced.

What is still missing is similar protection for sheep. Ministers were wrong to confine their application to cattle. True, a milking cow is worth about 10 times as much as a sheep, but this is to ignore the environmental contribution which sheep make to mountain, moor and dale. A government committed to assisting the tourist industry should not have ignored this fact. Earlier this week the National Trust director spoke of the devastation threatening the Lake District, where Herdwick sheep have developed a "hefting" instinct, under which fences are not necessary because individual flocks never roam from their patch. Without sheep, which have been there since the 12th century, today's picturesque grasslands would be turned into shabby scrub. Vaccination could be the only way of stopping the local outbreak spreading. Whole sheep breeds are threatened. They, too, ought to be protected.

webTitle: MPs see public stake as option

fields.headline: MPs see public stake as option
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack's performance is "woeful" and the government should seriously consider taking it back into public ownership, according to a unanimous report from the Commons transport select committee published yesterday.
fields.body:
Railtrack's performance is "woeful" and the government should seriously consider taking it back into public ownership, according to a unanimous report from the Commons transport select committee published yesterday.

The stern comments of the committee, chaired by Gwyneth Dunwoody, Labour MP for Crewe, come as the government is preparing to make a pre-election statement on Railtrack. It is expected to pledge more than an extra £1bn but will attach tight strings.

The report warns that the costs of Railtrack's mismanagement will finally land on the taxpayer. It states: "It is unacceptable that the taxpayer should be compelled to bail out a private monopoly company which has acted so incompetently, without taking any stake in the company in return."

The committee suggests the government could take a majority equity stake in the company and use it to exercise influence in the management and policies of Railtrack.

The report says that the system of managing contractors on maintenance and renewal of the railway had been shown "to have utterly failed".

It says that the regulation of Railtrack since privatisation has not been adequate. The actions of the regulator had for a long time been half-hearted and ineffectual, but had recently improved.

webTitle: Campaigners want arms bill loopholes plugged

fields.headline: Campaigners want arms bill loopholes plugged
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Arms campaigners are to press the government to close loopholes in a long-awaited bill published yesterday.
fields.body:
Arms campaigners are to press the government to close loopholes in a long-awaited bill published yesterday.

The export control and non-proliferation bill was drawn up to implement recommendations made by Lord Scott in his report on the arms-to-Iraq affair in 1996. There have been a series of rows over the past four years over sales such as Hawk jets to Indonesia, Hawk spares to Zimbabwe, and other arms to Morocco, Angola, Rwanda and Ethiopia.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, claimed the bill will go further than the Scott recommendations "to try and prevent weapons getting into the wrong hands'.'

The bill proposes:

 New controls on the trafficking and brokering of weapons . Special attention is to be paid to weapons going to countries that are the subject of embargoes, and to the sale of equipment that could be used for torture.

 Regulations on the transfer abroad of military technology by electronic means, for example fax or email.

 Controls on technical assistance to weapons of mass destruction or related missile programmes.

The draft bill follows government embarrassment at having failed to make time for it in four Queen's speeches, after making an issue of arms sales in opposition.

Mr Byers announced an eight-week consultation period. Liz Clegg, a spokesman for Saferworld, said: "Potential loopholes remain to be addressed. If unresolved, these could be exploited by unscrupulous arms dealers."

Saferworld wants restrictions to include all British passport holders to prevent them moving their operations overseas. It also wants freight companies to be covered, and for British embassies to check that weapons go where they are meant to.

The bill proposes:  New controls on the trafficking and brokering of weapons . Special attention is to be paid to weapons going to countries that are the subject of embargoes, and to the sale of equipment that could be used for torture.  Regulations on the transfer abroad of military technology by electronic means, for example fax or email.  Controls on technical assistance to weapons of mass destruction or related missile programmes. The draft bill follows government embarrassment at having failed to make time for it in four Queen's speeches, after making an issue of arms sales in opposition. Mr Byers announced an eight-week consultation period. Liz Clegg, a spokesman for Saferworld, said: "Potential loopholes remain to be addressed. If unresolved, these could be exploited by unscrupulous arms dealers." Saferworld wants restrictions to include all British passport holders to prevent them moving their operations overseas. It also wants freight companies to be covered, and for British embassies to check that weapons go where they are meant to.

webTitle: Blair puts his faith in religious partners

fields.headline: Blair puts his faith in religious partners
fields.standfirst: Prime minister stresses moral values and asks for help in promoting health and welfare
fields.trailText: Prime minister stresses moral values and asks for help in promoting health and welfare.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday called for religious charities and organisations to become partners of the government in promoting health and welfare provision.

The prime minister took advantage of an invitation to address a conference of religious organisations from both Christian and other faith backgrounds, organised by the Christian Socialist Movement at Westminster Central Hall, to outline his own religious motivation in politics and to stress the value of religion in modern society.

The speech amounted to the clearest indication yet of Mr Blair's resolve to place moral values at the heart of policy. He told the religious organisations: "We are very, very proud of you. Your role in the voluntary sector, working in partnership with central and local government, is legitimate and important and where you have the desire and ability to play a greater role, with the support of your communities, we want to see you do so ... we want you as partners, not substitutes. We want to take this partnership forward wherever we can."

In an atmosphere sometimes resembling a revivalist meeting, with a south London school choir in attendance as well as Sir Bob Geldof and an audience full of committed Christians and representatives of other faiths, including Jews, Sikhs and Muslims, there was scarcely a mention of foot and mouth for a whole hour.

Bob Geldof continued the musical theme when, speaking of Mr Blair, he told the conference: "We're of the same generation. In 1973 we shared the worst haircut in the world and we even went in for the same ploy of setting up a pop group to pull girls. Frankly he was crap and didn't make any money and I did."

Mr Blair explained his attempts to join a group at his first audition did not go well, when he was told: "You would have been good if you had any talent ... it's more or less what they have been saying in politics too."

Mr Blair, the most religiously-inclined prime minister for many years, has been generally cautious about speaking of his faith but is known to have been irked by William Hague's attempts to annexe Christian morality for the Conservatives. Both leaders have spoken to faith conferences in the last year.

The partnership idea - embraced by moderate American evangelicals such as Jim Wallis, a presidential adviser and speaker at the conference - is likely to be much more welcome to religious organisations than Mr Hague's endorsement of President Bush's ideas for handing over welfare provision completely to the private sector. Faith-based charities in Britain insist that they do not proselytise and do not have the resources to expand their existing activities.

Brushing aside reservations from some local authorities about involving religious-based organisations in welfare provision, Mr Blair conceded that Labour has often been too suspicious of enlisting such groups and maintained that it was a "misguided and outdated set of values" that demanded a straight choice between state and voluntary aid.

"Where the two do go together the impact is far greater than government acting on its own.

"We see this in countless charities, schools, health projects, youth work, provision for the elderly, the homeless, work with offenders and ex-offenders, local regeneration schemes and many other social activities," he said.

He praised faith groups for being among the main sponsors and innovators of voluntary activity: "Community by community you are engaged directly. You know the terrain. You have committed volunteers and often an infrastructure, invaluable for delivering projects speedily and effectively, with far greater originality, sensitivity and initiative than government departments."

Mr Blair also outlined proposals for an experience corps, a national organisation which will receive government funding of £19m over three years to promote participation in voluntary projects by the over 50s.

The prime minister insisted that church schools were a pillar of the education system "valued by very many parents for their faith character, their moral emphasis and the high quality of education they generally provide" and paid tribute to religious charities' contribution to delivering healthcare and education in the developing world.

He announced that an inter-faith group is being set up to look at how government consults religious groups across a range of what he described as shared interests.

But the prime minister ducked questions from his audience about making a positive case for increasing taxation as a moral good or about exempting faith groups from human rights legislation to enable them to appoint only their own adherents.

Mr Blair also attacked cynicism as the most corrosive thing in British society: "The idea that politics does not matter, that nothing changes, that everything is hopeless, is not only defeatist, but also prevents what matters most from being done.

"When cynics put a view of politics as hopeless, it is often because what they actually want is the status quo and nothing to change.

"The concept of something bigger than the self is at the heart of our religious faith. The collective sense of values and understanding between faiths is of vital importance to society."

webTitle: Deadline set for £3bn rail safety shake-up

fields.headline: Deadline set for £3bn rail safety shake-up
fields.standfirst:
Accelerated timetable for action fails to impress victims' relatives

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Accelerated timetable for action fails to impress victims' relatives.
fields.body:
The government insisted last night that it will not write a blank cheque to install a new £3bn train protection safety system over the next eight years, a task which will result in widespread disruption and line closures for passengers.

The Department of Transport agreed that it was under an obligation to make a significant contribution to plans to make the railways safer after the Southall and Paddington disasters.

Government sources said that there was no bar to the work starting and that some of the money could come from its £60bn to improve the railways over the next decade.

Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, backed an accelerated timetable for the introduction of an automatic train protection system under which drivers will eventually be directed by a central control.

It will replace line signalling on all main routes.

The radical safety shake up comes in a report produced by Lord Cullen, who presided over the inquiry into the 1999 Paddington rail crash in which 31 people died, and Professor John Uff, who chaired the inquiry into the 1997 Southall crash, which killed seven people.

Both accidents were caused by trains going through red signals. Both would have been avoided if the trains had been fitted with a form of sophisticated automatic train protection.

The industry is now working towards a new European train control system (ETCS). The first line to get it will be the London to Scotland west coast main route by 2005.

In the meantime, the Uff-Cullen report has backed the fitting of the less safe and effective train protection warning system (TPWS) at a cost of £500m, borne mainly by Rail track. It should be installed by 2003.

But the report underlined the problems associated with TPWS. It said the system had "serious shortcomings" and did not remove public concerns about the "possibility of further catastrophic accidents".

It added: "For the time being the safety of trains running up to 125 mph over the next three or four years will remain largely dependent on the vigilance and skill of the driver and the support systems which presently exist."'

Lord Cullen and Vic Coleman, chief inspector of railways, both stressed that trains might be prevented from running if the industry failed to keep to the timetable to install the automatic train protection system. Unlimited fines could be imposed on companies for failing to comply with safety improvements.

But the health and safety executive's record of taking strong action against default ing companies is not good and industry observers last night questioned how tough any punitive measures would be.

Although Prof Uff and Lord Cullen are pressing for a strict timetable, they agreed that it was open to negotiation with the companies. They also accepted that other improvements might have to be put back to allow safety work to be completed.

The Association of Train Operating Companies, representing the industry's biggest play ers, said the report's timetable was not realistic.

Relatives of the victims of the Paddington and Southall crashes were not impressed. Carol Bell, a Southall survivor, said: "Time and again the rail industry keeps putting back the timetable for implementing safety measures."

The threat of swingeing fines should be held over train companies, she said. Any disruption caused by the implementation of the new system was nothing to the lives of the injured and bereaved.

Maureen Kavanagh, who lost a son at Southall, said: "The government has got to stop pussy-footing around otherwise more people will die and people will never regain confidence in public transport."

fields.headline: Doctors breaking 'free NHS' principle
fields.standfirst: Thousands of old people in care homes charged for visit from GP
fields.trailText: Thousands of older people in care homes and sheltered housing are being forced to pay to see an NHS doctor in flagrant breach of the principle that state medical services should be free, charities claimed last night.
fields.body:
Thousands of older people in care homes and sheltered housing are being forced to pay to see an NHS doctor in flagrant breach of the principle that state medical services should be free, charities claimed last night.

An investigation of 183 charitable homes found 34% were paying retainers of up to £10,000 a year to get attention. Fees averaging £41 a year for each resident were commonly introduced at the request of GPs who were already collecting £45.05 from the NHS for each patient on their lists over the age of 75.

In some cases the fee topped £150 a year and there were extra charges for basic services such as winter flu jabs, said a report by the Association of Charity Officers.

Although the homes were meeting part of the cost from their charitable income, many were obliged to pass on charges to residents. The result was a breach of the principle that services should be provided according to need and free at the point of use.

This week the government published a strategy to improve NHS services for older people and eliminate discrimination. At a press conference on Tuesday, John Hutton, the health minister responsible for social care, said he was not aware of older people being charged for primary care. "If there is clear evidence ... bring it to my attention."

Valerie Barrow, director of the Association of Charity Officers, said yesterday: "This study clearly shows that some older people, because of where they live, are paying twice."

Tessa Harding, head of policy at Help the Aged, said: "It is outrageous that older people in residential and nursing homes are having to pay over the odds for something the rest of us get free. I cannot believe it is the government's intention that those who need healthcare most should have to pay."

The report found "damaging evidence of confusion over the definition of core NHS services". While 80% of GPs provided free winter flu jabs for residents of care homes and sheltered housing, 20% listed the inoculation as a "contracted" service.

About 10% of GPs conducted special surgeries in care homes at no extra cost, but 27% charged a retainer without offering on-site surgeries. "The blurred definition of core NHS services means many older people in residential care homes are denied healthcare free at the point of need," the report said.

The BMA said it had been asking the government for at least seven years to increase NHS cover for people in nursing homes.

Andrew Dearden, chairman of the BMA's community care committee, said: "General practitioners are left with few options. They could decide on no extra services at all. They could decide to supplement the NHS without any financial support or additional resources, but that would impact on the care of their other patients. A third option for GPs would be to say to the homes that they want to provide extra services as non-NHS services - and would the homes be willing to pay for them?"

The Department of Health said GPs were entitled to charge for services such as training staff. "That is different from direct patient services. We will investigate any allegations of abuse," a spokesman said.

webTitle: Hackers could halt UK, says Cook

fields.headline: Hackers could halt UK, says Cook
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Hacking could cripple Britain faster than a military strike now that computers were managing most of the country's "national infrastructure", including water, power, and transport, Robin Cook warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Hacking could cripple Britain faster than a military strike now that computers were managing most of the country's "national infrastructure", including water, power, and transport, Robin Cook warned yesterday.

The foreign secretary issued the warning to MPs as he lauded the work of the security and intelligence agencies whose spending has doubled since the end of the cold war, according to a study published today.

Though official figures put their total annual budget at £803m, rising to £941m by 2003, the Economist magazine said Sir Gerald Warner, a former deputy head of MI6, estimates the real cost is £2.5bn a year.

The parliamentary intelligence and security committee yesterday criticised the government for refusing to publish the individual budgets of MI5, MI6 and GCHQ. It also chastised the Treasury for refusing to disclose - even privately to committee members - its estimate of the worth of Britain's three main intelligence and security agencies.

But Mr Cook said the revolution in communications technology had created threats which the agencies had to combat. Security advisers to the British and American governments, whose computer systems have been penetrated by hackers, have warned of the threat of information warfare, or cyberwars.

Whitehall belatedly warned departments last May about the "love letter" virus which infected a large number of government computers. Mr Cook told the Commons that when the Kournikova virus struck in February, a national alert was issued within one hour.

"That speed of response can make the difference in the modern world between stability and chaos," he said.

fields.headline: Straw promises section 28 repeal
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Jack Straw last night reaffirmed the government's commitment to end confusion over the advice which teachers and local authorities can give young people about gay sexuality by promising to repeal the notorious section 28.
fields.body:
Jack Straw last night reaffirmed the government's commitment to end confusion over the advice which teachers and local authorities can give young people about gay sexuality by promising to repeal the notorious section 28.

The home secretary used a speech to an equality dinner in London organised by the mainstream gay lobby, Stonewall, to parade the government's record on human rights, disability, race relations and the lowering of the age of gay consent to 16.He went on to describe section 28 as a piece of "discrimination and prejudice" that must go.

"Specifically it has caused confusion in schools and local councils, inhibiting teachers who are unsure about their ability to provide information, guidance and support to young people who are, or think they may be, gay," he said. "More widely, it undermines our commitment to fair treatment for all, irrespective of their sexuality. The government is therefore committed to ending the discrimination it promotes," explained Mr Straw though he did not say if the pledge will be in Labour's manifesto.

But, in what may be one of the last keynote speeches he makes in his present cabinet post, the home secretary also took the chance to insist that his own approach - "being tough on prejudice and tough on crime are two sides of the same coin" that allows law-abiding people to live in peace.

He called himself a "true liberal" in contrast to people who complain that "the efforts we are making to maintain law and order as illiberal or an erosion of civil liberties".

"So-called liberalism of this kind is really a comfort blanket to avoid hard choices about the effects of some people's criminal behaviour," Mr Straw told the dinner.
