fields.headline: Lord Bellwin
fields.standfirst: Thatcherite minister behind right-to-buy scheme
fields.trailText: Lord Bellwin, who has died aged 78, left a mystery behind him when, as Margaret Thatcher's most successful workhorse minister, he suddenly departed in 1984 after five years of unequalled hard work.
fields.body:
Short, perky Lord Bellwin, who has died aged 78, left a mystery behind him when, as Margaret Thatcher's most successful workhorse minister, he suddenly departed in 1984 after five years of unequalled hard work.

As parliamentary under-secretary at the Department of the Environment from 1979-83, and then minister of state, he put through 28 bills, including three controversial ones. He piloted the right-to-buy legislation - based on a scheme he had pioneered in Leeds - and spoke 1,000 times on the local government, planning and land bill.

Then, in September 1984, he was gone, allegedly to spend more time on his Leeds golf course. The inside story was that, as a devotee of local government, he had been angered by Thatcher's determination to get rid of the six big Labour-dominated metropolitan councils. Heckling brought his speech - introducing a bill to abolish the following year's Greater London Council elections - to a humiliating halt in June 1984.

But he was too loyal to talk out of school. To give the lie to gossipers, he even became one of three Tory backbenchers who spoke up for the GLC's abolition. He was named to the New Towns Commission, and became a director of Taylor Woodrow. He spoke only occasionally in the Lords, once in favour of quangos, such as urban development corporations, pointing out that local authorities in London's East End had been unable to cope with their 6,000 acres of derelict docklands.

Bellwin's own political life was a demonstration that local authorities could do a great deal at low cost, if they were well-run by someone like himself. He had been born Irwin Bellow in Leeds, the son of Leah and Abraham Bellow, a machine designer. In Lovell Road school, he recalled, "the average size of classes was 44". He went on to Leeds grammar school and Leeds University, where he read law.

He then went into the Bellow Machine Company, a sewing-machine firm started by his father. In 1969, it was sold to Staflex International for £2.4m, with Irwin as chairman of both boards. But, after setbacks, the firm was sold to Pfaff, with Staflex itself going bust.

Irwin entered politics on a fluke: he had been elected to Leeds city council in 1966, after a colleague urged him to do something about the rates instead of just moaning. He was council leader from 1975-79, and was drawn to Thatcher's attention after he had cut rates and sold 3,000 council houses.

When she took power in 1979, she made him a life peer and a junior minister. His unassuming personality and hard work won over Tory grandees and political opponents, but he knew he could not win an argument with the iron lady.

He leaves Doreen, his wife of 53 years, a son and two daughters.

 Irwin Norman Bellow, Lord Bellwin of the City of Leeds, politician, born February 7 1923; died February 11 2001

Bellwin's own political life was a demonstration that local authorities could do a great deal at low cost, if they were well-run by someone like himself. He had been born Irwin Bellow in Leeds, the son of Leah and Abraham Bellow, a machine designer. In Lovell Road school, he recalled, "the average size of classes was 44". He went on to Leeds grammar school and Leeds University, where he read law. He then went into the Bellow Machine Company, a sewing-machine firm started by his father. In 1969, it was sold to Staflex International for £2.4m, with Irwin as chairman of both boards. But, after setbacks, the firm was sold to Pfaff, with Staflex itself going bust. Irwin entered politics on a fluke: he had been elected to Leeds city council in 1966, after a colleague urged him to do something about the rates instead of just moaning. He was council leader from 1975-79, and was drawn to Thatcher's attention after he had cut rates and sold 3,000 council houses. When she took power in 1979, she made him a life peer and a junior minister. His unassuming personality and hard work won over Tory grandees and political opponents, but he knew he could not win an argument with the iron lady. He leaves Doreen, his wife of 53 years, a son and two daughters.  Irwin Norman Bellow, Lord Bellwin of the City of Leeds, politician, born February 7 1923; died February 11 2001

fields.headline: Milk supply 'under threat'
fields.standfirst:
Blair ally warns of rationing unless vaccination begins

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government might be forced to bring in milk rationing within months unless it takes action now to vaccinate the entire national dairy herd against the spread of foot and mouth, a leading Labour peer warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The government might be forced to bring in milk rationing within months unless it takes action now to vaccinate the entire national dairy herd against the spread of foot and mouth, a leading Labour peer warned yesterday.

Many of Britain's dairy farms are close to the worst centres of the epidemic, in Devon, Cumbria and the West Midlands. Lord Haskins, the chairman of Northern Foods, warned that if the disease were to take hold on dairy farms, milk shortages were inevitable because fresh supplies cannot easily be imported. So far, more than 100 of Britain's 22,000 dairy herds have been marked for slaughter.

"The government should give serious consideration to vaccinating the entire dairy herd now," he said. "If the government's worst-case scenarios are correct, there will be rationing within two months."

The warning came as William Hague appealed for Tony Blair to "put country before party" and postpone the general election beyond May. It also emerged yesterday that the supply of drugs for the lethal injection of young animals that need to be culled are running out.

A decision on whether to vaccinate cattle as part of the "firebreak" strategy is expected in the next few days. Britain won European Union permission this week to begin a limited vaccination programme but so far it is restricted to 180,000 dairy cattle in Cumbria and Devon.

Vaccination would destroy the live export trade but Lord Haskins said it would be preferable to running short of milk. But he warned it would pose a new set of difficulties for the industry because once vaccinated, cows could still be disease reservoirs. "You would have to ban the sale of unpasteurised milk because that could spread the virus," he said. "This is nothing like as simple as people think it is."

Implementing a programme of mass vaccination of dairy herds would mean accepting that foot and mouth is endemic in the UK.

The National Farmers Union rejected Lord Haskins' fears that milk supplies could be disrupted. They said that so far, of the 14bn litres of milk Britain produces annually, just 100m litres have been lost because of the slaughter programme. "At this stage it is too early to say that we are going to run short of milk," the NFU said.

Half the annual milk quota is used for other dairy products and the NFU said this could be diverted to fresh milk if supplies ran short.

Lord Haskins' warning is a blow to the government's hopes that it has the epidemic under control and can proceed with its plans for a May election. A majority of the cabinet wants May 3. And ministers and party officials who are urging an early election will argue that the threat of milk shortages illustrates that delay will only create further problems.

Tony Blair will spend the weekend considering the options, with some MPs claiming that he feels uncomfortable at the prospect of campaigning while the animal slaughter mounts. He is also anxious about committing himself to fighting on two fronts, electoral and foot and mouth, at once.

Though Labour backbenchers are divided the dominant view of senior ministers such as John Prescott and party officials at Millbank is to go now, even though they know the finely balanced judgment is Mr Blair's alone. Privately, one Tory ex-cabinet heavyweight said: "He'd be mad to delay."

The prime minister is expected to gather his closest political intimates, including Gordon Brown, Jonathan Powell, chief of staff, and Alastair Campbell, press secretary, at Chequers on Sunday to decide between May 3 and June 7 - the only real options.

"The word now is that Tony says he won't feel comfortable out there on the stump campaigning normally," one well-placed MP said.

In his first interview on American television since the crisis broke Mr Blair told NBC: "There is no reason why your average American tourist or one from any other part of the world cannot come here and have exactly the same holiday as they have always had."

Millbank is poised to start the campaign next week, though slower than once planned. Mr Blair may stay in No 10 for most of the next two weeks, leaving Mr Brown to take the campaign lead.

Mr Hague said: "I wouldn't have an election at this point to date. That would be putting party before country. I would be concentrating on fighting this disease, not the election."

 Ben Gill, NFU president, is live online at 10.30am today. Post your questions at Special report: foot and mouth.

fields.headline: Hague's three steps to dominance
fields.standfirst:
Leader has shown shrewd political judgment in boosting his position

Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Leader has shown shrewd political judgment in boosting his position.
fields.body:
William Hague is, for the first time since he took over as Tory leader, setting the political weather.

Even his detractors admit that Mr Hague has judged his interventions on the foot and mouth crisis with great care, wrong-footing the government on numerous occasions. "William's having a good war," said one Tory MP, not noted for his admiration of Mr Hague.

The Tory leader managed to dominate early headlines yesterday when he finally called on Tony Blair to cancel plans for a general election on May 3. Sweeping aside fears that he might appear to be running scared of an election, Mr Hague claimed that calling an election now would place "party before country".

His intervention, during a visit to Cumbria, was the culmination of weeks of anguish over how to respond to the foot and mouth crisis. No grand Tory strategy was mapped out on day one because nobody knew how serious the disease would be. But the Hague strategy has gone through three distinct phases.

When foot and mouth was first confirmed, Mr Hague instructed the shadow cabinet to adopt a bipartisan approach and to say nothing about postponing the election.

As the number of cases increased, Mr Hague offered constructive criticisms of the government and raised doubts about holding the local elections on May 3.

In the last two weeks, the gloves came off and Mr Hague launched stinging attacks on the government for failing to take hold of the crisis and for appearing to press ahead with elections.

One shadow minister said that Mr Hague felt that it was important to adopt a bipartisan approach initially because the Tories would not be rewarded for scoring political points during a national crisis.

As the crisis deepened, Mr Hague moved away from his bipartisan approach on March 13 when he used a visit to Cheltenham to call on the government to give a six month "business rate holiday" to all businesses hit by foot and mouth.

During his Commons clash with the prime minister the following day, Mr Hague called for a policy of immediate slaughter and for the army's role to be stepped up.

As speculation intensified about the election, Mr Hague used a visit to Cumbria on March 15 to raise his first doubts about election timing. In careful language, he warned that foot and mouth was having a "devastating impact".

While the political truce had ended, open political warfare had yet to break out.

At a press conference on March 20, Mr Hague said the government should introduce legislation to allow the county council elections to be postponed.

Appearing on a platform stripped of Tory symbols, Mr Hague said: "I don't think it would be right to call an election at a time when there is a national crisis out of control."

It was at the end of last week, when an official epidemiological report forecast a possible 4,400 cases of foot and mouth by June, that Mr Hague lambasted the prime minister for mishandling the crisis.

Mr Hague used a speech in Coventry to call on the prime minister to set up a "crisis cabinet" to deal with foot and mouth. He likened the crisis in the countryside to wartime Britain.

Tory sources privately hope that foot and mouth will help them whenever the election is held. If Tony Blair opts for May 3, the Tories hope to win support from voters who share his view that an early election is inappropriate.

If foot and mouth forces the prime minister to delay the election, Tories hope the expected downturn in the economy will pay dividends.

Against this backdrop, however, the Tories' position in the polls remains as dire as ever.

webTitle: Fuel payment rise a crude bribe, claims Lib Dem

fields.headline: Fuel payment rise a crude bribe, claims Lib Dem
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is being accused of increasing pensioners' winter fuel payments as a "crude bribe" amid claims that the government plans to cut the grants by one quarter later this year.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is being accused of increasing pensioners' winter fuel payments as a "crude bribe" amid claims that the government plans to cut the grants by one quarter later this year.

Research by the Liberal Democrats has indicated that the government's spending projections for 2001-2 onwards are based on fuel grants of £150 - £50 less than in the current year.

In his pre-budget statement last autumn, the chancellor raised the level of the payments, made to all pensioners, to £200, rather than the £150 ministers had previously suggested.

The Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, Steve Webb, challenged Mr Brown to make clear whether the government would maintain the grants at the increased level. He said: "This is either a pretty crude election bribe and will be cut by a quarter six months after the likely election, or they will not cut it, in which case they need to find £400m from somewhere. Either way, the chancellor has questions to answer."

The winter fuel payment was introduced in 1997-98, and for the following year was set at £20 for most pensioners and £50 for those of them on income support. The rate was increased to £100 for all pensioners in 1999-2000.

A parliamentary answer to a question tabled by Mr Webb details the rise in government spending on the payments from £200m when first introduced to £1.7bn in the current financial year. However, the reply, by social security minister Jeff Rooker, did not answer Mr Webb's call for details of planned spending on the grants.

fields.headline: Channel 5 loses out to Temptation
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 5 has lost the bidding to make a UK version of the controversial Temptation Island series, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has lost the bidding to make a UK version of Temptation Island from Fox TV in America.

BSkyB is now said to be in pole position to pick up the UK rights to the controversial reality TV format.

It is said to be the only British broadcaster left in the race to secure the format, which is owned by US network Fox, which is also part of the News Corporation empire.

A BSkyB spokesman said no deal had been concluded for Temptation Island. But TV industry insiders are tipping the satellite broadcaster to pick up the format for its Sky One general entertainment channel.

Channel 5 was interested in Temptation Island, which features couples stranded on a tropical island and tempted into indiscretions with attractive single people, but was not willing to pay the Fox asking price.

"We would have liked to get it, but it was too expensive," said Dawn Airey, chief executive of Channel 5.

Sky One has already broadcast the US version of the show this year, pulling in more than 500,000 viewers for the opening episode in January.

When the show went out on Fox in the US advertisers taking slots around it came under fire from conservative pressure groups concerned it was promoting illicit sex.

It also emerged that Fox had screened Temptation Island for sexually transmitted diseases before letting them take part.

The fact that Channel 5 was interested in the raunchy format will cause raised eyebrows from some industry observers.

The broadcaster has set its sights on moving away from its image of being the purveyor of cheap imports and soft porn in recent months.

Biggest shareholder RTL is known to want to reposition Channel 5 to target a more mainstream audience.

"We would have liked to get it, but it was too expensive," said Dawn Airey, chief executive of Channel 5. Sky One has already broadcast the US version of the show this year, pulling in more than 500,000 viewers for the opening episode in January. When the show went out on Fox in the US advertisers taking slots around it came under fire from conservative pressure groups concerned it was promoting illicit sex. It also emerged that Fox had screened Temptation Island for sexually transmitted diseases before letting them take part. The fact that Channel 5 was interested in the raunchy format will cause raised eyebrows from some industry observers. The broadcaster has set its sights on moving away from its image of being the purveyor of cheap imports and soft porn in recent months. Biggest shareholder RTL is known to want to reposition Channel 5 to target a more mainstream audience.

fields.headline: Silver surfers surge ahead
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The internet is turning out to be something for the old rather than something for the young, according to research by Barclays Bank, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
The internet is turning out to be something for the old rather than something for the young, according to research by Barclays Bank.

"Silver surfers" - people aged over 55 who use and surf the internet - are coming to the fore according to the survey, which says they have grown more confident about being online than Britain's young.

The over-55s have increased their online activity over the past three months and are spending more time surfing.

According to Barclays consumer internet confidence index, which charts internet activity and confidence every three months, national levels of confidence are up by 4.7 points from 100 in December. Silver surfers are responsible for driving the growth and for 3.1 of those points.

"Although there is often a lot of hype around the internet, we are seeing a general positive trend in the scale and nature of usage on the internet", said Simon Newman, Barclays retail banking e-commerce director.

The research saw the confidence levels of 15- to 24-year olds drop by 1.6 points over the quarter and there was a decline of 9% in the use of email by this age group.

Leisure and convenience activities over the web, such as online banking, entertainment and booking holidays have increased for the over-55 age group in the last three months.

The survey also found the use of email and the internet for research dropped this quarter by about 5%, but in spite of the drop these two areas continue to dominate the bulk of British surfers' activities - 87% of internet users use email and 89% use the internet for research and information.

Barclays, which created the index with NOP Solutions, surveyed 1,000 adults, aged 15-plus, including internet and non-internet users.

webTitle: M&S banks on drastic new makeover

fields.headline: M&S banks on drastic new makeover
fields.standfirst: More than 4,000 jobs axed and 38 European stores closed in attempt to reverse slide
fields.trailText: More than 4,000 jobs have been axed and 38 European stores closed in attempt to reverse slide, writes Julia Finch.
fields.body:
The ailing Marks & Spencer store group yesterday embarked on a radical retrenchment in an attempt to restore its faded fortunes, slashing 4,390 jobs and closing its 38-strong chain of European stores.

The store chain - which has been battered by a sea change in shopping habits as consumers have deserted the middle market in favour of discounters and designer brands - is also axing its loss-making mail-order business and has put its two US businesses up for sale.

At the same time the huge new flagship M&S store in central Manchester - built after the city centre was devastated by an IRA bomb - is to be sliced in half, with the unwanted half being sold to rival Selfridges.

Chairman Luc Vandevelde said he intended to concentrate on improving the UK stores and winning back previously loyal customers. The priority, he said, would be to concentrate on "classically stylish" fashions with the quality and fit M&S was once famous for. Prices will also be cut.

The pressure on Mr Vandevelde to turn the business round is growing almost daily. When the Belgian supermarket boss was headhunted to join M&S a year ago, he said it would take two years to rebuild M&S. Halfway to that self-imposed deadline, there is still no sign of any improvements, and yesterday he admitted that M&S was in far worse shape than he thought when he took the job. "If I had known then what I know now, I would have acted earlier."

The 38 European stores, including 18 in France, will close by the end of the year at the cost of 3,350 jobs.

A further 690 jobs will be lost in the mail-order business and 350 in the group's Baker Street head office. Mr Vandevelde said he was sorry "to disappoint the large number of staff who have been doing an excellent job". It will cost £300m to close the European and mail-order operations - and save £50m a year.

The US businesses - Kings Supermarkets and Brooks Brothers, a preppie menswear chain, which cost $860m to buy - are to be sold as soon as possible. M&S said they had already received offers.

Another branch of the international business - 10 stores in Hong Kong - will be packaged up and sold to a franchise operator.

The international businesses were always viewed as a springboard to turn M&S into a global operator, and when Mr Vandevelde moved into M&S a year ago he insisted he was committed to international expansion. But yesterday he said the overseas operations were "the wrong platform" for expansion and added: "Let's get our house in order here before we do that".

Mr Vandevelde described his new plan as "a dramatic, urgent, thorough correction" to halt the decline of the group, which until 1998 was viewed as the gold standard for the retailing business. At that point, the chain's sales fell off a cliff and it has been unable to halt the slide ever since.

Its profits have slumped from more than £1bn to £557m, and City analysts are expecting M&S to bring in £100m less than that this year.

Shareholders have also been punished. The shares, which stood at 664p just over three years ago are changing hands at 266.5p. As part of the recovery plan announced yesterday, the group said it was selling half its property portfolio and will return the £2bn raised to shareholders - which will underpin the share price.

M&S has made several vain attempts to win back business - from special offers to its "I'm normal" advertising campaign last year featuring a naked size 16 model running across fields. It has changed its trademark carrier bags, started buying more clothes from abroad to cut costs and launched an expensive range of upmarket designer clothes under the Autograph label. Every member of the board has been replaced and at one point the chain had more than 30 firms of outside consultants working on improving the store.

So far, however, its efforts have had little effect. Its advertising campaign was panned and the Autograph range has fallen well short of sales targets. "We may have oversold Autograph", Mr Vandevelde conceded yesterday. Even 25 airy new "concept" stores backfired and didn't deliver the sales boosts expected.

The store is still the biggest seller of clothing in the UK. A recent report by the market research group Verdict calculated that M&S still accounts for £11 of every £100 spent on clothes in Britain - but that is down 20% since 1997, and the chain's market share is believed to have tumbled again since the Verdict figures were calculated.

Yesterday M&S said its most recent trading had again been grim. In the last nine weeks, like-for-like sales - which exclude gains from new shopfloor space - were down 0.5%. But that average hides a huge variation in performance between different departments. Food and home furnishing sales were well ahead, while sales of clothing, footwear and gifts were down 6.5% on the same time last year, when the figures were already bad. Marks & Spencer refused to divulge just how badly the core clothing business had been performing, but analysts believe recent sales are 12% down on a year ago. At the same time, rivals like Next, Selfridges, French Connection and House of Fraser have been reporting substantial increases in sales.

The chain's new answer is to concentrate on shoppers aged over 35 - who account for 70% of the clothing market. Mr Holmes said M&S will now focus on items ranging from pleated skirts and blazers to classic white shirts, sweaters and jeans.

Meanwhile, Autograph will continue to provide higher priced fashion from designers like Hussein Chalayan and milliner Philip Treacy. It has also drafted in George Davies - the man who invented the Next and George at Asda brands - to produce arange of fashion clothes for younger shoppers, like hipster jeans, crop tops and leather jackets.

Two thirds of the stores are to be given low-cost revamps. Out will go beige walls, wood and worn carpets. In their place will be bright white walls and more displays.

Trouble in store: a recovery plan

 Close 38 European stores - including 18 in France, 10 in Spain, four in Belgium and two in Germany

 In the US sell off Bros and Kings Supermarkets. In Hong Kong sell 10 stores to a franchisee. M&S already has a franchised business in 30 countries

 Close Warrington-based M&S Direct, the mail order operation. The homeware brochure and home delivery flowers will stay, as will the e-commerce business

 Sell half of Manchester superstore to Selfridges but close Torquay and West Ealing stores

 Return to selling M&S own brands only and focus on "classically stylish" fashion with better quality, fit and pricing

 Revamp all stores within two years, adding foodhalls to 50 of them, opening 30 more coffee shops and 50 more beauty shops. Increase space devoted to homewares by 30%. Open three small, convenience foodstores

 Aim to sell more personal loans and financial services, while disposing of half the group's property portfolio

webTitle: Racing: Dot.com racing under starter's orders

fields.headline: Dot.com racing under starter's orders
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: An Essex businessman yesterday unveiled plans to open Britain's first racecourse for 74 years as part of a revolutionary scheme to appeal to the burgeoning internet and offshore telephone betting industry. By Paul Weaver.
fields.body:
An Essex businessman yesterday unveiled plans to open Britain's first racecourse for 74 years as part of a revolutionary scheme to appeal to the burgeoning internet and offshore telephone betting industry.

John Holmes, a former showjumper turned entrepreneur, said the course would be built at the Essex County Showground, north of Chelmsford on the outskirts of Braintree, and should be ready to open in May next year. He has already had discussions with the British Horseracing Board, but the scheme will almost certainly bring him into conflict with the racing establishment.

Holmes plans to create a training facility at the 165-acre site for 120 horses, who will run once or twice a week in the late morning, prior to the start of other meetings. The timing would be ideal for live broadcasting to the Far East, which already generates hundreds of millions of pounds in betting revenue each year.

"So far 30 owners have expressed an interest in having a horse, or horses, based here," said Holmes. "Followers of racing don't need to be told that it is about to go through changes in promotion, control and revenue streams that could not have been imagined 10, maybe even five years ago.

"Not everyone will like the results but there is definitely a demand for the style of operation we plan at Great Leighs. Clearly it is far from being satisfied at the moment. I believe I have the right place at the right time to provide a bespoke solution. I've been approached by a few internet gaming companies and a number of off-shore bookmakers, so the odds-making side will be dealt with."

Internet business is already revolutionising racing in Britain, with punters able to bet at the push of a button instead of visiting betting shops. But whereas betting has long since outgrown the tic-tac men, most British courses remain untouched by time.

There is no racecourse nearby to rival Great Leighs, which is roughly equidistant from Newmarket and Epsom. But the new course would be a slap in the face for Fairlop Waters in Barkingside, which has BHB approval and which hopes to start racing within a few years.

Holmes claims the course is "just 35 minutes away from London, so it could be a great day out for those in the city". But the man who made a fortune trading horses in the 70s before moving into cellular airtime retailing and the dot.com world sees his media-led enterprise appealing more to a market that will not necessarily be at trackside. With the abolition of betting tax coming into force in January 2002, the global gaming market could be worth £1trillion.

Holmes said: "I don't know what the established 59 racecourses have in mind for the future. But I do think this is a most worthwhile venture. This is not a sudden whim. It has been planned for some time."

Since he bought the property in 1997, Holmes has promoted the site as an equestrian centre while continuing to stage the annual Essex Show. "The infrastructure is tried and tested. And after four years here I know all about things like public safety, hygiene and even toilet facilities. So I've learned the hard way.

"I'm planning something that should co-exist with the existing tracks. I'm not looking to fall out with anyone; I want to be part of the racing establishment. I don't expect the BHB or the Jockey Club to embrace the idea, exactly. But at the same time they have given me no indication that they will oppose it. I share their zest for the integrity of racing and for the procedures that go with it."

Holmes, whose family has a long history in equestrianism, and whose uncle Harry Holmes was a successful showjumping owner on the county circuit, said: "At the moment I cannot deliver big prize money. But I'm talking to the people who can provide it. And if I can just have the chance to prove what I can do, and then get my licence, the prize money will follow. I've got to do it this way because if I asked the BHB for permission they would have said no."

A BHB spokesman said last night: "We have had very preliminary discussions with Mr Holmes and look forward to talking to him again. But we can say nothing at this stage."

fields.headline: Newsman killed in Kosovo shelling
fields.standfirst:
Macedonia denies causing three deaths during attack on guerrillas

Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: A British television producer was among three people killed yesterday in fighting between ethnic Albanian rebels and Macedonian security forces. By Nicholas Wood.
fields.byline: Nicholas Wood in Krivenik,  Jonathan Steele  in Pristina and Matt Wells
fields.body:
A British television producer was among three people killed yesterday as fighting between ethnic Albanian rebels and Macedonian security forces spilled over the border into neighbouring Kosovo.

Kerem Lawton, a 30-year-old journalist with the Associated Press news agency was killed when a barrage of mortar shells fell on the Kosovan village of Krivenik, less than a mile from the border with the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia.

The attack followed a bombardment by the Macedonian army of a nearby ethnic Albanian guerrilla base just inside Macedonia. At least 20 other people were reported injured. Ayllejman Klokoqi, an APTN cameraman, had left the car moments earlier. "I saw people lying on the ground. I started shouting, 'Kerem! Kerem!' Then I saw Kerem in the car," he said.

Fezula Krasnici, who lives near the scene of the attack, said the mortars landed as Mr Lawton was interviewing people beside the village school. "When the explosions started he tried to run away, but another explosion went off and he was hit too," he said.

United States troops attached to the international intervention force in Kosovo (K-For) were the first to reach the injured. "When the first four mortars were fired, very quickly I took my motorbike to get K-For and they came back with me to see what was happening," said Mr Krasnici.

"I was trying to tell them to get the people out of the village, but they said we have to see what's going on first, we'll take care of that later. Ten minutes later, the mortars were hitting the middle of the village, where everyone was standing, including the television team." The other victims were Ilaz Thaci, a 33-year-old teacher, and Baki Krasniqi, 19.

Nato medics took him Mr Lawton by road to Camp Bondsteel, a US military base in Kosovo, but he was dead on arrival at the base hospital.

"We are all grief-stricken at this loss," said Louis Boccardi, president and chief executive of Associated Press. "Kerem's courage and devotion to gathering the story reached beyond any words we can say." He was the third member of APTN to lose his life in just over two years.

Mr Lawton had been based for the past several months in Pristina, the capital of the Kosovo province. He was married to a Kosovo Albanian, Elida Ramadani, 27. She is eight months pregnant and lives in Pristina.

Just before being hit yesterday, Kerem Lawton had been sitting in a cafe waiting for the arrival of British troops due to be deployed on the border with Macedonia. His plans changed, however, when news of increased fighting around Krivenik came through. Fellow members of the AP team at the same cafe, said they had suggested he should not go.

There was confusion over who fired the shells. Government spokesman Gjeorgi Tremdefilov said there was "not the remotest possibility" that Macedonian soldiers had fired the shells.

But K-For issued a statement. "K-For regrets the incident took place and that the lives of our soldiers were endangered in an area that is clearly inside Kosovo territory," said Major Axel-Bernd Jandesek, spokesman for the international peacekeepers.

The head of the UN mission in Kosovo, Hans Haekkerup, called on the Macedonian government to change tack. "I deeply regret this tragedy which has cost the lives of innocent civilians. I will be raising the urgent need for restraint by the Macedonian forces and for dialogue to replace shooting when I visit Skopje tomorrow."

The attack comes as the Macedonian government had been claiming considerable success in flushing out National Liberation Army (NLA) gunmen from villages around Tetovo. It appeared to be following a similar approach close to the border with Krivenik.

But the NLA showed little sign of caving into the Macedonian army's offensive. "For several days they've being try ing to take our positions, but there's no way they can do it. We will continue to defend ourselves," said the 25-year-old commander of the base. In the last week just three out of 200 fighters have been injured.

On the Kosovo side of the border, British troops with so phisticated night vision equipment and backed by helicopters have started patrolling near where the mortar bombs landed.

Up to 200 British soldiers and 250 from Sweden, Finland, Norway, Latvia, and the Czech republic have moved into bases close to the border.

K-For insists that the men will not cross the border into Macedonia. It has no mandate to do so, even if requested by the Macedonian government.

Mr Lawton had been based for the past several months in Pristina, the capital of the Kosovo province. He was married to a Kosovo Albanian, Elida Ramadani, 27. She is eight months pregnant and lives in Pristina. Just before being hit yesterday, Kerem Lawton had been sitting in a cafe waiting for the arrival of British troops due to be deployed on the border with Macedonia. His plans changed, however, when news of increased fighting around Krivenik came through. Fellow members of the AP team at the same cafe, said they had suggested he should not go. There was confusion over who fired the shells. Government spokesman Gjeorgi Tremdefilov said there was "not the remotest possibility" that Macedonian soldiers had fired the shells. But K-For issued a statement. "K-For regrets the incident took place and that the lives of our soldiers were endangered in an area that is clearly inside Kosovo territory," said Major Axel-Bernd Jandesek, spokesman for the international peacekeepers. The head of the UN mission in Kosovo, Hans Haekkerup, called on the Macedonian government to change tack. "I deeply regret this tragedy which has cost the lives of innocent civilians. I will be raising the urgent need for restraint by the Macedonian forces and for dialogue to replace shooting when I visit Skopje tomorrow." The attack comes as the Macedonian government had been claiming considerable success in flushing out National Liberation Army (NLA) gunmen from villages around Tetovo. It appeared to be following a similar approach close to the border with Krivenik. But the NLA showed little sign of caving into the Macedonian army's offensive. "For several days they've being try ing to take our positions, but there's no way they can do it. We will continue to defend ourselves," said the 25-year-old commander of the base. In the last week just three out of 200 fighters have been injured. On the Kosovo side of the border, British troops with so phisticated night vision equipment and backed by helicopters have started patrolling near where the mortar bombs landed. Up to 200 British soldiers and 250 from Sweden, Finland, Norway, Latvia, and the Czech republic have moved into bases close to the border. K-For insists that the men will not cross the border into Macedonia. It has no mandate to do so, even if requested by the Macedonian government. What's going on? fields.headline: 'Nasty Nigel' quits ITV
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: "Nasty" Nigel Lythgoe, the TV executive responsible for bringing Popstars to British television and turning himself into a cult figure in the process, is quitting ITV.
fields.body:
"Nasty" Nigel Lythgoe, the TV executive responsible for bringing Popstars to British television and turning himself into a cult figure in the process, is quitting ITV.

Lythgoe is leaving his job as controller of entertainment with the London ITV broadcaster LWT to take up a new position as head of the television production company set up by former Spice Girls manager, Simon Fuller.

He will be reunited with Nicky Chapman, the pop promoter who featured alongside Lythgoe as one of the judges in Popstars.

Lythgoe's association with ITV will not end, however. In his new job, his brief will include overseeing the Popstars follow-up Pop Idol, produced by Fuller's 19TV and Pearson, in which thousands of pop hopefuls will be auditioned to find a new solo artist.

Lythgoe is currently on secondment from LWT to Planet 24, working on location in Borneo for ITV's next big reality show, Survivor.

fields.headline: Women PRs are on top-spin
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A survey of PR professionals published yesterday disclosed that women earn more, drink more and smoke more than their male counterparts. By David Teather.
fields.body:
The characters in Absolutely Fabulous, the public relations sitcom starring Jennifer Saunders and Joanna Lumley, could be closer to the truth than even a jaundiced journalist might have thought. A survey of PR professionals published yesterday disclosed that women earn more, drink more and smoke more than their male counterparts.

The survey from the industry trade magazine PRWeek found that from account executive to board director level, women consistently earn more than men doing the same job.

The differential is greatest at middle management level where a female account manager's average salary of £32,500 is 30% higher than that of the average male account manager.

Men in the industry are also struggling to close the gap. The average pay rise for women in PR consultancies over the past year was 11.8% compared to 10.6% for men.

PRWeek editor Kate Nicholas said, however, it was not all good news for women. "The glass ceiling is still far from being completely shattered," she said. "There is still a trend for public relations officers of both sexes to train in agencies and then move on to cosier in-house roles with more comprehensive benefits packages. But women who go down this route may well be in for a nasty surprise as pay disparity is alive and well in PR departments in both the private and public sectors."

The survey found that women in the industry spend more time in the pub and eating out than men. The one thing that PR men can be found doing more of is sitting in front of their PCs surfing the internet.

At account executive level, women earn an average £26,100 compared to £21,300 for men while account directors earn £37,800 and £34,300.

fields.headline: Temptation couple sue
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A Los Angeles couple booted off the unscripted television series Temptation Island because they have a two-year-old child are suing the producers for defamation of character.
fields.body:
A Los Angeles couple booted off the unscripted television series Temptation Island because they have a two-year-old child are suing the producers for defamation of character.

Ytossie Patterson, 34, and Taheed Watson, 29, lodged their case with the superior court in Los Angeles on Wednesday. They were kicked off the show - which is designed to tempt emotionally committed but unmarried couples into being unfaithful - for allegedly hiding the fact from producers.

They claim that Fox Television and Rocket Science Laboratories always knew they had a child but decided it would attract more viewers if the information came out during an episode.

webTitle: TV kids who seek more from Santa

fields.headline: TV kids who seek more from Santa
fields.standfirst:
Children who watch alone more susceptible to adverts

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Children left alone in front of the television are more susceptible to advertising than those who watch with their parents, reports Gerard Seenan.
fields.body:
Children left alone in front of the television are more susceptible to advertising than those who watch with their parents, according to research published yesterday.

Children who watch the most television pester their parents for the greatest number of toys and presents from an early age. Parents who use the set as a baby-sitter are storing up problems.

A team of British psychologists which examined the impact of TV advertising on under sevens discovered an increasing desire to consume from as young as three.

The researchers also discovered that the letters English children write to Father Christmas contain requests for 25% more presents than those in Sweden, where advertising to children is banned.

"Children who watch more television are asking for more things and it seems they are generally becoming greater consumers and more materialistic," said Karen Pine, a psychologist from the University of Hertfordshire who led the study.

Dr Pine analysed the letters written to Father Christmas by 83 children aged between four and six and similar data from 16 nursery children aged between three and five.

Children who watched more television requested more items than those who did not, and more branded toys.

Among the 41% of children who regularly watched television alone, there was a far greater number of requests for the branded toys which were the hot gifts that Christmas.

"This suggests that in the short term parents who leave their children in front of the television may have an easier life, but in the longer term they may be increasing the pester power of their children," said Dr Pine.

In one three-hour Saturday morning television session in the run up to Christmas, Dr Pine found more than 120 adverts aimed at young viewers.

"Parents have got to be aware how much advertising there is and they have to begin educating children with a healthy degree of scepticism from a very early age," she said.

"Children who watch television on their own ask for more branded items, so perhaps with mum and dad being around children are not quite so susceptible to adverts."

Specific rules govern the way advertisers can sell goods to children, and the Independent Television Commission said yesterday it believed the rules were sufficient.

A spokesman said: "The ITC rules on advertising to children are among the most strict in Europe and they are applied assiduously to commercial television. We are confident the protection they offer children is sufficient, but we are always open to new research."

Ian Twinn, of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, which represents the interests of the advertising industry, said it was the duty of parents to educate their children about adverts - and to say no when necessary.

webTitle: TV egg eating stunt is no joke warn dieticians

fields.headline: TV egg eating stunt is no joke warn dieticians
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A stunt for a bizarre television show in which participants are invited to eat quantities of hard-boiled eggs in an effort to be sick has incurred the disapproval of dieticians. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
A stunt for a bizarre television show in which participants are invited to eat quantities of hard-boiled eggs in an effort to be sick has incurred the disapproval of dieticians.

The entertainment network MTV is boasting of the "sickest show on television", as competitors on Jackass line up to throw up. Contestants around the country are filmed eating as many eggs as possible before vomiting.

"If you are faint-hearted, delicately dispositioned or are a regular reader of the Daily Mail, look away now," MTV declares in its promotional material. "The show is sick (as well as immature, shocking, dangerous and irresponsible). But so what? Arrested development can be fun!"

However, dieticians are warning that MTV could be taking things too far. The British Nutritional Foundation said the acid contained in the eggs could have a detrimental effect on the participants, and the British Dietetic Association is concerned that the show could encourage binge eating.

"There are a number of side-affects to eating so many eggs in a short period of time. If you look at a number of people who have suffered with eating disorders such as bulimia, they do not have very nice teeth," a spokesman for the British Nutritional Foundation said. "The acid rots away at the teeth, and seriously damages the look and shape of them. Most people can eat an egg a day and still keep their cholesterol levels at a reasonable level, but when they eat excessive amounts it can be harmful to their health."

MTV is promoting the show in Britain with the Jackass Pukestock Tour, in which passersby in city shopping districts are invited to take part in a replication of the egg eating stunt which has already been undertaken by US contestants. The tour went to Newcastle yesterday, and reaches Glasgow today.

Jackass has become a hit in the US, where it is the most popular cable TV show among 12- to 34-year-olds. The British egg eating will feature in promoting the show's transmission in this country.

MTV yesterday denied that the show, which airs on Friday night and is its top-rating programme in Britain, was irresponsible.

A spokeswoman said: "It's very clearly done as a stunt, as a game. It's not in any way encouraging people to binge. It's just a complete laugh."

And the promotional material concludes: "Jackass features stunts by professionals and/or total idiots.

"MTV insists that neither you nor any of your friends attempt this dangerous rubbish at home."

fields.headline: TV - the extraterrestrial
fields.standfirst:
Government enthusiasm for digital television is not shared by the public. A more rational approach to its introduction may be necessary

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Government enthusiasm for digital television is not shared by the public. A more rational approach to its introduction may be necessary, writes Georgina Born.
fields.body:
This week Patricia Hewitt launched a kitemark scheme to distinguish "genuine" digital televisions (as opposed to those sets only offering, say, digital sound), as part of the government's bid to boost takeup of this latest technology for over-the-air broadcasting. Labour is staking much on forcing us to move to digital in the next decade. The optimistic official projection is shown in the chart.

Digital TV, it is said, can deliver the internet at home. For Labour, converged digital TV-internet technologies are a big part of the solution to a range of social ills including educational failure, political apathy and social exclusion.

But what if the public does not want it and refuses to replace analogue sets? Take up of digitial is at 26% of households with television. Half of older and retired people never want to switch. Even more telling, 50% of "non-adopters" say they will only ever watch the five existing terrestrial channels - in other words are not going to be tempted by the subscription digital channels. To rent a premium package of digital channels for a year costs about £400 for digital satellite and £500 for digital cable, an enormous increase for those used to the £104 licence fee, while a basic cable package costs about £120.

Consumers are confused. How many of us know anything about the relative advantages and longevity of digital terrestrial, digital cable and digital satellite? How many of us realise that mov ing to cable from terrestrial brings a loss in how flexibly we can use our video recorders?

Then there is the execrable quality of many digital channels. Competition for audiences has led to rashes of imitative, low quality and sensational programming across all channels, including terrestrial TV. An idea that might previously have provided one programme or series now has to fill an entire channel - witness the channels devoted to weather, shopping, cookery and cars. Viewers, even when presented with multichannel television, generally return to just five or six. With digital, the six they do watch look set to be immeasurably poorer both economically and culturally.

Television viewing is not changing in the ways predicted by the multichannel merchants. We like our channels to provide a range and mix and to do some of the selection for us. After all, leisure time is the scarcest resource. When Phil Mitchell was shot on EastEnders recently, 17m simultaneously enjoyed the melodrama. Broadcasting creates a kind of common life and even in the age of consumerism the signs are that we want it to continue to do so.

So why is Labour so determined? The government equates more channels with greater choice and diversity, that more competition will liberate television from the former dominance of cartels such as the BBC/ITV duopoly which, in their view, stifled market dynamics. In consequence, the recent white paper rests the protection of quality in broadcasting largely on competition law.

But what we are witnessing is exchange of old cartels for new ones. Even the combined will of the Office of Fair Trading, the Independent Television Commission and the Department of Trade and Industry has been unable to curtail the anti-competitive strategies of Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB television company.

While government has required digital carriers to offer a core of public service channels, Murdoch has been permitted to set inflated prices for access to his digital satellite platform, until now with the effect of keeping ITV off. BSkyB also holds near-monopolistic controls over premium sports rights, causing massive cost inflation which disadvantages public service rivals.

The government makes a second mistake when it rests the health of the television industry primarily on the growth of international markets, which it links with the move to digital. Both are seen to require large conglomerates. In fact quality British television - whether from Granada, the BBC, or smaller independent companies - can sell well abroad. It is a pleasing truth that quality in whichever genre (natural history, comedy or drama) still translates into industrial prowess and international sales. There is a danger of pursuing international markets while neglecting viewers at home.

The government may be minimising digital's riskiness. In technology-led businesses the first into the market does not necessarily end up the winner. Inevitably, the shakedown that follows innovation as technologies standardise means that some of those first in will go bust. The government is rightly letting private enterprise carry those risks, but they still come at a cost. As alarming are the risks to individual consumers, as we are asked to speculate on unproven technologies, and as our viewing habits are toyed with and led in dubious directions. By being the first into digital television we may all end up losing out. Far better to join in the second wave, once digital television has stabilised internationally and become more attractive to consumers.

The thrust of government thinking in this area is reflected in the recent suggestions that the Department of Culture, Media and Sport is abolished as the DTI takes responsibility for broadcasting. What surer way could there be of subordinating the pub lic interest in the cultural quality of broadcasting to misguided industrial and technological policies? In the medium term the main draw of digital TV will be the new free-to-air channels planned by the BBC. Yet perversely, while they will expand the BBC's diversity and offer much needed competition to the impoverished nature of commercial children's television, the BBC's plans are undergoing a tough vetting due to the commercial lobby's cries of unfair trading. Again, competition issues gain greater attention than cultural concerns.

Labour should take a "steady as she goes" approach to digital television. Such a change would be both understandable and wise in the face of technological uncertainty and rational consumer doubts.

 Georgina Born is a sociologist at Cambridge University.

webTitle: Goldman takes tough line on DTI report

fields.headline: Goldman takes tough line on DTI report
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Goldman Sachs is likely to come out fighting today when the Department of Trade and Industry publishes a long-awaited report criticising the bank's role in the final days of Robert Maxwell. By Andrew Clark.
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs is likely to come out fighting today when the Department of Trade and Industry publishes a long-awaited report criticising the bank's role in the final days of Robert Maxwell.

The US investment bank will be accused in the report of bearing "substantial responsibility" for Mr Maxwell's illicit attempt to support the price of shares in Mirror Group, shortly after its flotation ten years ago.

Insiders say Goldman Sachs resents being singled out for greater criticism than other institutions. One source said the bank would issue a response containing "a mixture of humility and some combative elements.

A roll-call of other City institutions will face censure in the report, including stockbroker Samuel Montagu, which is now part of HSBC, and accountancy firm Coopers & Lybrand - now PricewaterhouseCoopers. Investment bank Salomon Brothers and Lehman Brothers, together with law firm Clifford Chance, are all braced for a rough ride.

The report follows a ten-year investigation by two independent inspectors appointed by the DTI, at an estimated cost of £10m.

It concerns Mr Maxwell's abuse of money from Mirror Group pension funds to support his collapsing business empire. He used Goldman Sachs to buy millions of shares in the Mirror in an attempt to support the firm's share price.

Mr Maxwell drowned in November 1991, just as his debts were reaching a crisis point. His son, Kevin Maxwell, who was found not guilty of fraud five years ago, claimed during his trial that the share ramping operation was the idea of Eric Sheinberg, a former senior partner at Goldman Sachs.

The report follows a ten-year investigation by two independent inspectors appointed by the DTI, at an estimated cost of £10m. It concerns Mr Maxwell's abuse of money from Mirror Group pension funds to support his collapsing business empire. He used Goldman Sachs to buy millions of shares in the Mirror in an attempt to support the firm's share price. Mr Maxwell drowned in November 1991, just as his debts were reaching a crisis point. His son, Kevin Maxwell, who was found not guilty of fraud five years ago, claimed during his trial that the share ramping operation was the idea of Eric Sheinberg, a former senior partner at Goldman Sachs.

webTitle: It all hangs on Wim's whim

fields.headline: It all hangs on Wim's whim
fields.standfirst:
Policy should be a breeze for the ECB. Cut rates and bask in the glory. But life's not like that in the Frankfurt eyrie

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Policy should be a breeze for the ECB. Cut rates and bask in the glory. But life's not like that in the Frankfurt eyrie.
fields.body:
The European Central Bank is between a rock and a hard place. Should it keep interest rates on hold while all about are cutting theirs in determined pursuit of the holy grail of price stability? Or should it make a friend of the trend and, in line with other central banks, cut rates as its contribution to the global battle against recession?

Yesterday, despite the hopes which had been building up in the financial markets and which the bank had, arguably, been encouraging, it opted to do nothing. Whether the policy should be put down as masterly inactivity or worried indecision is not clear. Not that such considerations bothered the foreign exchange market. No news was not greeted as good news. Dealers promptly dumped the single currency - pushing it down to its lowest level this year.

Rapid reaction

Nor is the ECB off the interest rate hook. Expectations have simply switched to the pre-Easter meeting on April 11. Yesterday's response from the forex market's rapid reaction force was a warning to the bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, of what will happen if he fails to deliver in two weeks' time.

For the markets and many analysts, the ECB's policymaking should be a breeze. The US has slowed sharply - at best. Japan is mired in recession. Equity markets have a white-knuckled look about them. The numbers from parts of the eurozone don't look too bad but Germany - the biggest bit - is heading for the doldrums.

So, get on with it - cut rates, boost growth prospects and watch the euro rise. Forget inflation. The global slowdown and a stronger currency will take care of that.

Yet as Mr Duisenberg sits in his eyrie in the ECB tower in central Frankfurt, puffing on the inevitable cigarette, the choice is not quite so easy. When the idea of the single currency was sold to both the international investment community and to the citizens of the 12-nation single currency zone, nobody discouraged the belief that the euro would be a clone of that then favourite of the forex market - the German mark.

The snag is that the impression has stuck. When investors want a view on the eurozone they tend to look at Germany. The view is not encouraging.

Little wonder that the euro fell from $1.17 to little more than 80 cents in less than two years. Or that the subsequent 15% rally on the back of a bombing US economy ran out of steam the moment the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates. At not much over 88 cents, the euro is starting to resemble the Grand Old Duke of York's army - marched all the way up to the top of the hill, only to be marched back down again.

Secondly the ECB's central mandate is not to foster growth, it is to keep the lid firmly on inflation. True, interest rates can be set with a view to supporting the general economic policy of the eurozone - but not at the price of jeopardising price stability. Though there is a reasonable expectation that inflation will head down it is still some way north of the ECB's 2% ceiling. The ECB's favourite monetary aggregate, M3, is hardly pointing the way to lower rates either.

"If the decision was a close call, probably the anxiety over inflation levels and the M3 growth number won the day," according to Bernard Walschots at Holland's Rabobank.

The bank has a longer term agenda. It has argued that countries within the eurozone need to embrace structural economic reforms. There are signs some heed is being paid but the pace of change is scarcely break neck and is unlikely to pick up speed if the ECB shows it is prepared to let interest rates, rather than reform, take the strain.

There are political complications, too. The European Commission president, Romano Prodi, yesterday argued: "The ECB must be independent but must not suffer from loneliness. Europe now lacks strong political structures because national states do not want to create them.

"In the United States [Fed chairman Alan] Greenspan feels the vibrant politics that surrounds him. He keeps his independence but has next to him strong political institutions.

"The trouble is that no-one wants to believe that the ECB is independent... and there is a view that the United States is a giant and Europe a dwarf. But future events will dispel this impression."

Quite whether Mr Duisenberg would feel comfortable surrounded by "vibrant politics" is an interesting question. But he would doubtless feel happier if national politicians showed greater willingness to coordinate their fiscal policies with the ECB's monetary one.

There may be arguments for suggesting that Ireland is a special case but the ECB must be looking at some of the promises being made in the Italian election campaign and wondering quite how they square with the eurozone's stability pact which is meant to keep budget debt and deficits in line. But then politicians have elections to win.

Nor do the politics stop there. In nine months' time the 12 countries of the eurozone will have to give up their national currencies in favour of euronotes and coins. The change over must go well. A political generation in Europe has staked its credibility on making the euro work.

Yet as the value of the euro rises, or more often, falls according to the whim of the foreign exchange market, Europe's savers are tending to the sceptical. The ECB needs to be able to demonstrate that it has at least some control over the external value of the single currency.

Harold Wilson's "the pound in your pocket has not been devalued" style of argument cuts little ice even if, in a near closed economy like the eurozone, they have some merit.

Cartoon character

The ECB may be rescued by the dollar, finally losing favour with investors. It seems hardly credible that the greenback can continue to be the world's reserve currency while the US is running a current account deficit of 4.4% of GDP and share values are plummeting. Like the cartoon character who has run over a cliff and doesn't realise he's suspended in midair, sooner or later, the dollar is going to fall.

What matters is whether this will happen soon enough to rescue the ECB from its dilemma and whether the bank can persuade its two constituencies - the world's financial markets and Europe's citizens - that it always knew it was going to happen. In short that it was Wim's whim, not that of the forex market.

fields.headline: Regeneration sexy? It is now
fields.trailText: A few throw-away comments by Lord Rogers has suddenly made urban regeneration sexy, writes Matt Weaver .
fields.body:
A few throw-away comments by Lord Rogers has suddenly made urban regeneration sexy.

An architectural campaign group with the fabulously pretentious name of Transgressive Architecture asked the Labour peer whether he supported prostitution and rough sleeping in public spaces.

"I think public spaces are exactly for these activities," Labour's regeneration supremo Lord Rogers told a packed lecture at the Royal Institute of British Architects.

Lord Rogers cited the Pompidou Centre in Paris, his first major building as an architect, to explain what he meant. "The Pompidou Centre is an example where all these kinds of people can act, including prostitutes. After all, it is part of life."

Lord Rogers' remarks have sparked more media interest than he ever achieved in the two years as chairman of the urban task force. The urban task force report Towards an Urban Renaissance has certainly become more interesting reading in the light of the comments.

The report endorsed "encouraging street facilities that make walking attractive". Now we know why the task force was so keen to go on fact-finding missions to Amsterdam and Barcelona.

Cheap jibes aside, Lord Rogers' remarks do raise some important issues. There are concerns that an urban renaissance will lead to a form of social cleansing in British cities, of the kind that has occurred in New York under the zero tolerance policy of Republican mayor Rudolph Giuliani.

For some the approach of homelessness tsar Louise Casey in London has confirmed these fears. She has lead a campaign to stamp out street begging and attacked charities that provide soup and blankets for rough sleepers because she claims they encourage people to sleep rough in the first place.

The government has the admirable aim of reducing rough sleeping by two-thirds. But the tight timetable for this goal has led to concerns that homeless people are being shoved into hostels with no chance of permanent accommodation in an effort to hit the target and clear the streets.

A spokeswoman for Ms Casey refused to discuss Lord Rogers' comments, but confirmed Ms Casey's rough sleepers unit is on course to meet the 2003 target.

The government does not have a regeneration tsar, but Lord Rogers is the nearest thing. His attitude is obviously very different from Ms Casey's.

"It is no good shovelling activities like this under the carpet. In fact they belong in public space," he told Building Design magazine.

Like apple pie and motherhood everyone approves of regeneration, but Ms Casey and Lord Rogers' views represent very different ways of bringing it about.

A squeaky clean Blairite, Ms Casey wants to stamp out rough sleeping - the most obvious and human sign of urban deprivation. Lord Rogers, represents a more permissive attitude to renewal. He wants to encourage activity in public spaces - but it seems he doesn't mind what kind of activities.

The urban task force claimed new urban developments "should seek diversity; encouraging a mix of activities".

Lord Rogers has now been officially appointed as city architect for London. He'll help mayor Ken Livingstone to implement a new spatial development strategy for the capital. There could be some interesting discussions with Ms Casey in this new role.

The urban task force made more than 100 recommendations about how to bring about an urban renaissance. But it also stressed that in addition to policy, a change of culture was required and called for a debate to help bring this about. The change of culture may be difficult given the differing views that are emerging. But Lord Rogers has at least started a debate.

fields.headline: Let the walking commence
fields.standfirst: Rob Glover, director of the charity Care for Children, sets out on his walk through China's so-called Valley of Death
fields.trailText: Rob Glover , director of the charity Care for Children, sets out on his walk through China's so-called Valley of Death.
fields.body:
The first day of the walk started in the bar. At midnight, the Shanghai crew, the hairdressers from Spalding, the student child psychologist and the Norfolk businessman were waiting up for the international lawyer from Shanghai. Beside them sat Herbie the 4ft teddy bear, named after the president of Care for Children, Lord Laming.

I talked, in part, about Care for Children's work in China. Children need the love, nurturing and place in society that a family can provide. However, not all get the chance. China has many orphans and disabled children, but it has even more families who are only too happy to love them. To achieve the stability and proper care these children need in foster homes requires support and encouragement. I have been working with the Chinese government to develop effective family placement programmes.

In Shanghai, 350 children have been given families over the past three years - the breakdown rate for family placements is 7%. Some children who were initially regarded as disabled are now developing normally with the help of family life.

After six weeks of worrying I wouldn't even make the walk, last week I managed to shake off the sickness I contracted from the water in Chengdu in the Sichuan province. Then it took me several days to find a pair of size 11 walking boots in Shanghai. I hope they will see me through and I can break them in quickly. I will have to rely on my fitness gained before Christmas from playing for Shanghai United - an expatriate football team.

The walk will be a welcome break from the teaming crowds of Shanghai and the tremendous pace at which we have been working over the past three years. It will be a great opportunity to discuss our work and issues in the UK - from people at the sharp end. I believe there is a lot that can be learned about social welfare from our valuable experience in China.

The next morning, the air was sharp. We set off through the rush hour traffic of Beijing travelling north past the construction that is preparing the city for the 2008 Olympic games. As traffic gave way to sheep and donkeys, the extensive, arid plains of north China were ruptured by mountain ranges piercing the clear blue sky.

Walking started at midday with a long rising stretch of uneven mountain path. Concern mounted as we discovered that the first planned toilet stop was closed for renovation. We set off across the melting ice left behind from the freezing winter of northern China, descending through the so-called Valley of Death.

After lunch on an ice pack (and photographs of Herbie the bear fishing for his dinner), we set off again. The walk continued up the mountain, passing some derelict houses - a past hideout for bandits hiding from authorities in Beijing. As the slope grew steeper the walkers spread out.

The way down took us down more paths through a forest with pine needles under foot. After an hour of fast walking we were back on the bus.

During the ride to our hostel, which had been booked for stage two of the walk, I received a call from Shaanxi province on my mobile phone. Following last week's visit to Xian, they are now convinced of the potential of family care for the children of long-term prisoners in western China, and are seeking a meeting before the end of the week to get started.

The day was rounded off in the bar with a refreshing pint of local YanJing beer.

 Rob Glover has been director of charity Care for Children, based in China, since 1996. He specialised in developing foster care in the UK before moving to China to set up the Shanghai fostering project in September 1998.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: army takes 'control and command'

fields.headline: How the brigadier has mopped up chaos and won farmers' support
fields.standfirst:
Officers take 'control and command' in Cumbria

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: In a Carlisle car park, across the road from a farmers' pub, stood a camouflage command truck called Birtie's Battle Wagon. It smelt of pipe smoke.
fields.body:
In a Carlisle car park, across the road from a farmers' pub, stood a camouflage command truck called Birtie's Battle Wagon. It smelt of pipe smoke.

There was a union flag on the bonnet and a makeshift staircase into the back. Inside, stubbing out a cigarette on the side of his boot, was Brigadier Alex Birtwistle, head of the army's foot and mouth operation in Cumbria.

He was mapping the enemy with flags and circles on maps. This was the "deep battle" phase. "It is about how to smack the new outbreaks as they come," he said.

The army has been in Cumbria for 12 days, staying in hotels to put money back into the local economy. Its role is to "command and control" the foot and mouth fall-out. Brigadier Birtwistle must clear the backlog of 50,000 dead sheep and 15,000 dead cattle, carry out the cull of 250,000 healthy sheep and coordinate civilians to keep the diagnosis, slaughter and disposal time to a minimum.

Around 150 soldiers are working all day, every day. They have already had dug the biggest mass burial pit in Britain and buried more than 35,000 animals. They are working on the biggest funeral pyre. They are collating intelligence, giving slaughtermen weapons training, and working out how to shower down vets fast enough to keep the diagnoses ticking over. They are organising themselves from four camouflage trucks on an industrial estate, by mobile phone.

In the car park, men in combat gear and berets strode between lorries, pausing to smoke pipes or cigars and say, "Roger" and "Chop, chop, no pissing about". Most had served in Bosnia, Sierra Leone or the Gulf. They are known in the farming community for their clipped vowels and organisational skills.

Local farmers have held protest meetings in the pub across the road calling the Ministry of Agriculture incompetent and the "ministry of death". But they rally round the soldiers who work in conjunction with Maff. "The army is our only hope," said sheep farmer Geoff Bell.

When the military arrived, they brought a small team of liaison officers who went to farms in pairs by Land Rover to manage logistics. Brigadier Birtwistle arrived with two clean shirts and was due to retire on Tuesday. New shirts and trousers have now been dispatched and retirement postponed, and his four-wheeled headquarters is surrounded by workmen building a "Portakabin city" as a new operations room.

"A week ago we had a tiger by the tail, now we have a tiger by the scruff of the neck, but it could still beat us," said Colonel Paul Baker, head of the army logistics operation.

The army has compared the disease to the enemy in a war. There is a battle to stay ahead.

The men in combat fatigues who travel around "liaising with locals" drive a hard bargain. Around 20 miles south, at Penrith's deserted auction market, the furniture and fine arts store had been turned into an operations room for local valuers to price animals for the army's cull.

Behind rows of unsold pastoral oil paintings, accounts workers who were laid off last week had returned to answer calls from confused farmers and ensure that enough animals are regularly dispatched to the army's slaughter pits to keep the brigadier happy.

Richard Morris, managing director of Penrith Farmers' and Kidd's auctioneers, who own the market, said: "So often the farmers have had contradictory information or misinformation from Maff. The army have brought discipline and organisation. They just make things happen. It is demanding keeping up with their pace, but that is how it should be."

Back at the truck, colour coded flow-charts rolled off the temporary printer and the back doors slammed shut for an emergency logistics meeting.

Around 150 soldiers are working all day, every day. They have already had dug the biggest mass burial pit in Britain and buried more than 35,000 animals. They are working on the biggest funeral pyre. They are collating intelligence, giving slaughtermen weapons training, and working out how to shower down vets fast enough to keep the diagnoses ticking over. They are organising themselves from four camouflage trucks on an industrial estate, by mobile phone. In the car park, men in combat gear and berets strode between lorries, pausing to smoke pipes or cigars and say, "Roger" and "Chop, chop, no pissing about". Most had served in Bosnia, Sierra Leone or the Gulf. They are known in the farming community for their clipped vowels and organisational skills. Local farmers have held protest meetings in the pub across the road calling the Ministry of Agriculture incompetent and the "ministry of death". But they rally round the soldiers who work in conjunction with Maff. "The army is our only hope," said sheep farmer Geoff Bell. When the military arrived, they brought a small team of liaison officers who went to farms in pairs by Land Rover to manage logistics. Brigadier Birtwistle arrived with two clean shirts and was due to retire on Tuesday. New shirts and trousers have now been dispatched and retirement postponed, and his four-wheeled headquarters is surrounded by workmen building a "Portakabin city" as a new operations room. "A week ago we had a tiger by the tail, now we have a tiger by the scruff of the neck, but it could still beat us," said Colonel Paul Baker, head of the army logistics operation. The army has compared the disease to the enemy in a war. There is a battle to stay ahead. The men in combat fatigues who travel around "liaising with locals" drive a hard bargain. Around 20 miles south, at Penrith's deserted auction market, the furniture and fine arts store had been turned into an operations room for local valuers to price animals for the army's cull. Behind rows of unsold pastoral oil paintings, accounts workers who were laid off last week had returned to answer calls from confused farmers and ensure that enough animals are regularly dispatched to the army's slaughter pits to keep the brigadier happy. Richard Morris, managing director of Penrith Farmers' and Kidd's auctioneers, who own the market, said: "So often the farmers have had contradictory information or misinformation from Maff. The army have brought discipline and organisation. They just make things happen. It is demanding keeping up with their pace, but that is how it should be." Back at the truck, colour coded flow-charts rolled off the temporary printer and the back doors slammed shut for an emergency logistics meeting.
