webTitle: No vaccination, cattle farmers tell Blair

fields.headline: No vaccination, cattle farmers tell Blair
fields.standfirst:
Measure to halt disease 'would be devastating'

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Farmers leaders last night resisted a possibly economically devastating vaccine programme among dairy cattle in Cumbria.
fields.body:
Farmers leaders last night resisted a possibly economically devastating vaccine programme among dairy cattle in Cumbria, amid conflicting signs over whether the outbreak was being brought under control elsewhere in the country.

Tony Blair, who met farmers leaders and the chief vet Jim Scudamore at a series of crisis meetings in Downing Street, supports a vaccine programme among dairy cattle in Cumbria representing 8% of the national herd.

He believes it will act as a necessary dampener to slow the spread of the disease at its epicentre, but most farmers' leaders fear it will destroy the meat export industry for 12 months. They also fear that milk from Cumbria will have to be branded as coming from vaccinated cattle and will therefore be unsaleable.

Downing Street said it would make a decision on the vaccination question within 48 hours. Meanwhile Mr Blair is determined to impose a regime whereby all animals detected with foot and mouth are slaughtered with 24 hours. At the same time his scientific advisers say he must ensure all animals on adjoining farms are slaughtered within the subsequent 48 hours.

The move is a clear sign that the government does not have the resources to control the fast moving epidemic in Cumbria. Even with a vaccination programme in place the future looks bleak for Cumbria. Ministers have examined the option of putting some kind of firewall around the county's cattle and sheep, even after the outbreak is ended.

Downing Street yesterday sought to put a gloss on some of the more depressing figures. It pointed out that the 24 hour detection to slaughter target is being met in Devon and Anglesey, in part due to new help from the army. It added that the backlog nationally has fallen by 7,000 animals and that the number of animals slaughtered outpaced the number of new infections. Only 1% of farms had been affected, it stressed.

But despite only 29 new cases being reported yesterday - compared with the record 49 cases on Wednesday - there are now more than 800,000 animals to be slaughtered, almost twice as many as in the whole of the 1967 outbreak.

Ministry of Agriculture figures also show that government confidence that it was bringing the outbreaks under control appears misplaced.

Daily totals on the website show the number of animals awaiting slaughter had risen to 292,000, nearly 20,000 more than the day before and this did not count the 700,000 still waiting to be killed under the government's welfare scheme.

While the army and the government were concentrating on what they termed the hotspots of Cumbria and Devon it was clear the disease was spreading quickly in other areas. There were cases several miles apart in Northumberland and more in parts of Gloucestershire which had been previously free.

Ben Gill, the National Farmers' Union president, said after his 90 minute meeting with Mr Blair: "Vaccination is not the solution in itself. It is part of the policy to take out the animals either infected or on the neighbouring farms. That remains the key objective, it is a means to allow us to deliver that policy."

In a bid to underline the message that Britain remains open for business, the government issued new guidance making clear that where the risk of spreading the disease is low, councils should reopen footpaths, in consultation with landowners and managers.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, is expected to head for Cumbria tomorrow in an effort to make the vaccination case to farmers.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: Euthanasia drug running out

fields.headline: Euthanasia drug supplies running out
fields.trailText: Supplies of a drug needed to kill up to a million lambs and piglets are running out.
fields.body:
Supplies of a drug needed to kill up to a million lambs and piglets are running out and the Ministry of Agriculture's central veterinary laboratory at Weybridge, Surrey, has been looking for new sources after its normal suppliers could not keep up with demand.

The euthanasia drug, pentobarbitone sodium, is used mainly by vets to painlessly put to sleep pets like cats and dogs. It is being used by the Ministry of Agriculture to kill young animals too small to be shot. It is bought in 100 millimetre bottles from normal veterinary suppliers.

Pentobarbitone sodium is in powder form and is bought by the tonne, then mixed in solution in small bottles. A lamb could be killed with a five to 10 millimetre dose but a cow would need a whole 100 millimetre bottle.

Yesterday the ministry was urgently looking for new suppliers after its usual supplier, JM Loveridge, of Southampton, could not keep up with demand. It bought a large quantity from Merial, in Harlow, Essex, for use in Cumbria where thousands of lambs are being killed.

Bert Burns, a spokesman for the company, said: "We were able to supply what they needed for now but we are not clear how much they may want. We could run to 100,000 doses, but I am not sure beyond that."

The ministry has also contacted Vetoquinol, of Bicester, near Oxford, which said yesterday it had supplies.

webTitle: A farmer's diary during foot and mouth

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
No more nature and nurture - new life is being snuffed out by death and destruction

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: No more nature and nurture - new life is being snuffed out by death and destruction.
fields.body:
The ailing little calf I wrote about on Wednesday died at about the same time we heard of further cases in Northumberland. Suddenly, suspected and confirmed cases seem to be popping up all over the county. It is almost too much to cope with as we try to get on with lambing and calving. How can we remain supportive of Maff's policies when, after six weeks, the situation appears to us in the lambing fields to be totally out of control?

The usual practice for a livestock farmer with a dead calf or a lamb, where the cow or ewe has plenty of milk, is to find a replacement. If there is not one available on the home farm then many farmers will buy a calf from a market or dealer to set on. Around here the neighbours usually share out spare lambs - anyone can have one if they need one. The system has always worked well, but this year is different. There is no lamb bank, because the movement of all animals is forbidden. None of us would take the risk of bringing in the disease, even through a tiny lamb.

Other diseases, such as bacterial diarrhoea or a contagious abortion can be brought in through this method, so care should be taken. We stopped buying calves in a few years ago, and only took lambs from our closest neighbours.

Yesterday we heard the Maff epidemiologists were coming to Hexhamshire Moor, site of the first case in the Pennine mountain chain. A confirmed outbreak was found on Wednesday in a flock. Our friends Nick and Julie Howard have a flock which grazes alongside the infected ones so they fear the worst. The two eldest girls have gone to stay with friends so they can continue their exam preparations.

Julie says that at least 20 more farms neighbour the outbreak and the rumours and the counter rumours are not helping anybody to cope. The stress levels are intolerable, and everyone in the area from district councillors upwards is trying to help. Many phone calls about suspected or confirmed cases end up involving major stress counselling. To see our whole industry being destroyed before our eyes is very painful.

John and Carol Brown, whose farm lies next to a confirmed case, are still preparing their lambing pens, just in case: but they know their flock will be killed when Maff finally gets around to it. Yesterday Carol was told it might not be for seven to 10 days, so what is the point? By then the infection might have gone through them and be on the march across yet more farms. She says Maff is having trouble locating the adjacent farms, and that they should just ask a farmer.

I've just had three phone calls. The first one informed me that Nick and Julie's sheep will be killed, and very soon, but no decision has yet been made about their cattle.

The second call was from another farming friend - Annabel Morshead. She is furious. A case of foot and mouth has been confirmed next door to her, and she blames the crass ineptitude of the ministry. It took them more than five weeks to take out a known dangerous contact from sheep in the ring at Longtown Mart.

Annabel's 17-year-old son Harry is home from school for the holidays. He has a show Blackface sheep with excellent bloodlines, and worries for her safety. He asked his mother if they were to lose their flock, would they start again? Annabel told him she had no idea where they or anyone else would start, because the best bloodlines and genes were disappearing with the buried sheep and cattle.

There was a third call from a vet seconded to Maff in Cumbria. He says the ministry is trying to run a major disease outbreak control from the equivalent of a four-bedroom house in Neasden, while Carlisle mart and its purpose-built facilities are unused. The vets are unhappy at the lack of organisation. There are no proper disinfection facilities - just a sink - and vets are carrying out this essential task themselves. He says there should be a team of technicians and a proper department doing this while the vets see to the animals and help the farmers.

Graham, our shepherd, had a run in with someone from the census department. He told the official in no uncertain terms to go away and send the information by post. He had come out to the farms to see if we needed the forms posted. Now where's the sense in that?

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. Her diary appears again next Wednesday.

The vets are unhappy at the lack of organisation. There are no proper disinfection facilities - just a sink - and vets are carrying out this essential task themselves. He says there should be a team of technicians and a proper department doing this while the vets see to the animals and help the farmers. Graham, our shepherd, had a run in with someone from the census department. He told the official in no uncertain terms to go away and send the information by post. He had come out to the farms to see if we needed the forms posted. Now where's the sense in that?  The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. webTitle: Farmer wins court battle over slaughter policy

fields.headline: Organic farmer wins court battle over slaughter policy
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Publishing entrepreneur turned organic farmer Peter Kindersley yesterday won permission to seek high court orders blocking the government's policy of slaughtering healthy animals.
fields.body:
Publishing entrepreneur turned organic farmer Peter Kindersley yesterday won permission to seek high court orders blocking the government's policy of slaughtering healthy animals. In the first action of its kind, Mr Justice Richards ruled that Mr Kindersley, 59, had "an arguable case" that should be heard as a matter of urgency.

His lawyers had argued that the policy adopted by the Ministry of Agriculture of slaughtering animals which were "only suspected of being infected" or might have been exposed to the foot and mouth virus went too far and was unlawful under EU and domestic law.

Mr Kindersley said after wards: "This is not a time for celebration. For weeks, my wife and I and millions of other people have been appalled by the impending slaughter of a million or more animals as part of a policy that has demonstrably failed."

The application for permission to seek judicial review was brought by Mr Kindersley, who was behind Dorling Kindersley books and now owns a 2,500-acre sheep farm in Lambourn, Berkshire. His wife Juliet, 60, and two other farmers, Thomas Scott and Anne Young, have joined the action. They say expert evidence shows vaccination would be more effective.

webTitle: Comment: Bush dumps Kyoto treaty on emissions

fields.headline: Yet more broken promises
fields.standfirst:
The Americans have abandoned the Kyoto treaty on gas emissions

Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Americans have abandoned the Kyoto treaty on gas emissions.
fields.body:
In the 1930s, the Republican party fought to avoid any involvement in the affairs of Europe. As the Nazi threat grew, Republicans, infected by ignorance, selfishness and short sight, tried to stop the United States from supporting democracy and freedom. Today, the greatest threat to world security is man-made climate change. The jobs, homes and lives of millions of people - in the US as well as the rest of the world - are at risk from an ever accelerating rate of climate disasters. We must act now. Yet, as one might miserably expect, Republican isolationism has evolved, first to deny its existence and second to set the US against agreeing any effective international action.

Yesterday, the White House finally confirmed that President Bush has decided to rat on the 1997 Kyoto treaty. At Kyoto, the world's developed countries agreed for the first time to cut emissions of climate changing gases. But White House officials are now taking legal advice on how to pull out of the treaty, which the US signed but which remains unratified by the Senate. This represents a terrible blow to the credibility of Bush's new environment chief, Christine Todd Whitman. She recently advised the new president, in terms even a backward college student should have been able to follow, that climate change was a real and present danger.

The US, with 5% of the world's population, emits almost a quarter of the world's carbon dioxide, the main climate changing gas. It promised to cut emissions by 7% over 1990 levels by 2012 at the latest, but its emissions in fact rose by more than 10% between 1990 and 2000. Bush's campaign for the US presidency was backed by major US oil giants, including Exxon, which also led the campaign in the US against the Kyoto treaty. The Republican presidential campaign even claimed that if Kyoto was ratified, US citizens might have to "walk to work", although why this would be a bad thing in a nation with the highest obesity rate on earth was not explained.

The truth is, as Tony Blair recently pointed out, that Kyoto is only a faltering first step in the right direction. Far more radical targets will be needed over the next 50 years. He must find a way to turn Bush's folly to the world's advantage.

This is not impossible. First, he must stick to the policy agreed by the European Union. There must be no more attempts to split the difference between Europe and the US. Second, he must start urgent talks with other countries, in particular Japan, Russia and the biggest countries in the G7 group of developing nations, to build a consensus for action in the rest of the world. The stronger that consensus becomes, the more likely it is that the Kyoto treaty will have practical effect whatever the attitude of the US. Finally, he must resist the temptation to try to bribe the US back to the negotiating table with concessions on biotechnology, GM food or hormone treated beef.

The EU must also begin to make some credible threats of its own. For a start, there can now surely be no possibility of agreeing new free trade rules through the World Trade Organisation while the US refuses to recognise the principles of sustainable development. The EU is the world's biggest market. It is also rapidly becoming the only part of the developed world that does not face recession. Will Bush and his advisers really want to face a trade war with the EU in such circumstances?

Republican spin doctors claim that the Kyoto treaty is flawed because it does not properly include developing countries. They even pretend that a US economy attempting to cut emissions would suffer in competition with this group of nations. But the truth is that the real competition comes from Japan and Europe. The great US car, oil and manufacturing giants that bankroll the Republican party are frightened because the US economy is the least energy efficient on earth. A statesman might respond to this problem by beginning the shift to energy conservation and renewables. But like an alcoholic dealing with his problem by trying to buy a brewery, Bush and his puppet masters have chosen yet more dependency on oil, with all the environmental damage that will cause. Look next to see the US oil industry desecrating Alaska in the hunt for new reserves.

When the obstructive behaviour of the Clinton administration caused last year's the Hague climate talks to collapse, Friends of the Earth warned that the world would pay the price in tears. With a US president arrogantly refusing to face his responsibility for the safety of his own citizens and the rest of the world, those tears cannot be avoided. But they can be reduced to a minimum, if the rest of the world finds the political will. This could be the greatest challenge to Mr Blair's next government. I hope he will rise to meet it.

• Charles Secrett is director of Friends of the Earth.

comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Leader: Mr Bush has put US credibility on the line

fields.headline: A dirty business
fields.standfirst:
Mr Bush has put US credibility on the line

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Suddenly, in the space of two short months, America, the "indispensable nation", begins to resemble the ultimate rogue state.
fields.body:
Suddenly, in the space of two short months, America, the "indispensable nation", begins to resemble the ultimate rogue state. George Bush's decision to trash the Kyoto global warming treaty is appalling. That it represents an enormous, possibly definitive setback for efforts to mitigate climate change goes almost without saying. America is now confirmed as the unrepentant outlaw, the dirty man of environmental politics.

The decision is doubly appalling for what it says about the new man in the White House. Mr Bush, clinging to his "national interest" credo, seems incapable of seeing the big picture. He does not grasp the basic truth that America's national interest is inextricably intertwined with the global interest. America, for all its dominance, is but a part of the world we share. America's consumers depend for their unsurpassed living standards on shared global resources. America's greenhouse emissions are not confined to American airspace. Nor is the US immune from the negative impact of its national profligacy and international climate change. By this blinkered action, Mr Bush strengthens suspicions that he is just not big enough for his job.

But most appalling of all is the message, taken alongside similarly short-sighted, self-centred actions in the fields of defence and diplomacy, that this Taliban-style act of wanton destruction sends around the world. Instead of leading the community of nations, Bush's America seems increasingly intent on confronting it. Instead of a shining city on a hill, the world sees a dark smokestack belching fumes. From a nation that began by heroically trumpeting its belief in universal values common to all mankind comes a devastatingly different, divisive and nationalistic jingle: we do what we want, for ourselves, regard less of the consequences for you. And if you don't like it, well, tough.

Is this message sent on purpose? In other words, does the Bush administration actually understand what it is doing? For look at the record so far. It has dangerously upset the strategic balance by proposing a new national missile defence system while scrapping another treaty, the key ABM accord with Russia. It has attacked Iraq while signalling elsewhere, notably in the Balkans, that it will reduce its commitment to shared security, especially through the UN. It has gone out of its way to antagonise Russia and done much to convince China that it must ready itself for war. Its economic policy has meanwhile merely stoked fears of a US-exported recession.

Bush's America has all but abandoned, for now at least, its leading role in the Middle East and gone a long way towards scuppering detente on the Korean peninsula. On a range of fronts, not least over Nato and trade, Washington is also shaping up for conflict with the EU. And now, to cap it all, ignoring the Stockholm summit's direct plea, and at the very moment the German chancellor is crossing the White House doorstep, it tells Europe that Peoria's pocketbook comes first, so take your fossil fuel fuss and stuff it.

If Mr Bush does not intend the alarm all this is causing internationally, then he is even more inept than commonly believed. Christine Whitman, his environment agency chief, told him this month that global warming "is a credibility issue for the US in the international community". She is right and he had better believe it. In the end, America, big though it be, cannot go it alone. It needs friends. But that even the oldest friendships have limits is a lesson Mr Bush has yet to learn. Humility is another. Wisdom may be too much to hope for.

webTitle: Stephen Moss suggests sanctions against America

fields.headline: This means war
fields.standfirst:
Now that George Bush has found out the Kyoto agreement is about emissions reduction and might annoy his oil chums back in Texas, he has done what the world had feared: torn it up. But if he thinks there is nothing we can do about it, then he is sorely mistaken. Stephen Moss suggests some sanctions

Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Now that George Bush has found out the Kyoto agreement is about emissions reduction and might annoy his oil chums back in Texas, he has done what the world had feared: torn it up. But if he thinks there is nothing we can do about it, then he is sorely mistaken. Stephen Moss suggests some sanctions.
fields.body:
Arms

Britain should immediately withdraw its Tornado from Iraq and refuse to take part in any further bombing missions, no matter how many shiny new missiles we are promised. Nato should suspend the US, invite Russia to take its place and establish no-fly zones in the north and south of America. (OK, let's say over Nantucket for starters: we don't want to be too ambitious.) Support should be given to any coherent anti-Bush groups that may develop in Washington, though at present there is little evidence of effective opposition groups in the capital. US air bases in the UK should be closed and weedkiller sprinkled on the airmen's golf courses.

Sport

All sporting contacts should cease immediately. Pete Sampras will not be permitted to win Wimbledon for the eighth time, and even Jack Straw will accept that Mike Tyson should not be allowed into the country. Tiger Woods will be allowed to compete in the Open, but will have to play blindfold. He will still win, but we shall have made our point.

Baseball, basketball and American football will be treated as the ludicrous, TV-dominated non-events they are. The term "World Series" to describe a contest between teams from rival American leagues is henceforth banned. We will continue to ignore Nascar racing and the Indianapolis 500. No wrestling will be shown in the UK, no matter how obscure the channel. Continuous coverage of the Ashes will be beamed to the US to demonstrate the historic wrong turning they made by opting for baseball in the middle of the 19th century.

History

It will be pointed out that the US was late arriving for both world wars, and that we had already softened up the oppo. We could have won the American war of independence if we had really been trying, and if our boys hadn't insisted on wearing red coats which made them such easy targets. As for the Spanish-American war, we imagine Spain could have won that too, but we can't be certain as we have no idea when it took place or what they were fighting about. (1) History books will also make it clear that Ulysses S Grant was a drunk with an outrageous name who took an age to subdue numerically inferior forces in the American civil war. Basically, count it as a win for the South, which will (with a bit of assistance from fifth columnists funded by MI6) rise again.

Film and TV

There will be a blanket boycott, except for films by the Coen Brothers, any half-decent new movie by Quentin Tarantino, and anything with Billy Bob Thornton. All references to the Oscars will be banned. Clearly, this will mean newspapers will be very restricted in size, and many supplements will disappear altogether, but these are difficult times and we must all make sacrifices. No US TV will be permitted except the Simpsons, Sex and the City, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Frasier and Friends. All repeats are prohibited. Blockbusters is out of bounds while sanctions are in force.

T*m C***se

No mentions under any circumstances. This is punishable by five years in prison or a fortnight spent watching Eyes Wide Shut, Mission Impossible (I and II), Top Gun, Days of Thunder and Cocktail, whichever punishment is deemed the worse. (2)

Music (pop)

White rap music will be banned. Yes, we know that means Eminem. And, yes, we know that he has been compared to Shakespeare by some respected literary figures. But in any war there are victims. Henceforth the only white American rapper permitted is Vanilla Ice, precisely because he is rubbish. Vanilla's collected works will helpfully confirm to us the complete and utter worthlessness of US culture. English musicians will be discouraged from singing in American accents. Large speakers will be put up along the Mexican and Canadian borders which will broadcast the Clash's I'm So Bored With The USA at regular intervals.

Music (classical)

No more John Adams operas will be produced, especially those staged by Peter Sellers. So what if that means we won't hear Nixon in China or The Death of Klinghoffer? We can sing-a-long with Harrison Birtwistle instead. Barber's Adagio will also be banned, especially that dreadful dance music version by William Orbit. This will mean long periods of silence on Classic FM, but we all have our crosses to bear.

Expulsions

We are sorry that some innocent individuals will be caught up in this imbroglio, but frankly you started this. When that rich bloke appointed ambassador by Bush arrives, he should be detained on arrival, frisked at Heathrow, Diana Ross-style and then sent back on an economy flight via New Delhi. All US embassy staff above second secretary level will be expelled; they're probably just spying on the Russians anyway. Ruby Wax, Paul Gambaccini and Loyd Grossman will also have to go. Madonna can stay as long as she can persuade Guy Ritchie to stop making gangster films (better still, any films). Bob Kiley can definitely stay, ideally becoming mayor of London and/or secretary of state for transport in 2003.

Withdrawals

All of the following will be asked to leave the US: Anthony Hopkins, Michael Caine, Ridley Scott, Catherine Zeta Jones (and Michael Douglas if he wants to leave), Tina Brown, Lisa Snowdon (3), Amanda de Cadenet, Christopher Hitchens and Frank McCourt. Salman Rushdie will be asked to speed up his move and make radio broadcasts on the awfulness of life in New York. (4)

Apparel

Obviously, as the prime minister would say, we will no longer buy anything from Gap, especially those shapeless blue tops that schoolchildren wear instead of uniforms. Tommy Hilfiger is also banned, not that we could afford any of his stuff anyway. Ditto DKNY, whoever they might be. All Calvin Klein clothes are banned with the exception of underwear. Nike trainers are permitted because they are made in the developing world, but people will be encouraged to scrawl graffiti over the company's ads. We will insist on the removal of the Union Jack from all Reebok trainers. Baseball caps may not be worn, especially by prominent political figures. Anyone wearing them back to front will be interned.

Coffee

It is probably too late to stage a boycott of US-style coffee bars as they account for some 40% of British GDP, so we will need to employ guerrilla tactics. When using Starbucks, refuse to say "tall", "grande", "vente", or any of the other silly names. Say small, medium and large in a posh, supercilious voice. If the pony-tailed assistant encourages you to have a good day, push a full-fat blueberry muffin into his/her face. If newspapers are available on the premises, spread the pages over the floor and all the tables. Never under any circumstances buy in-store mugs, games or CDs.

Cars

Vehicles made by Ford and General Motors will be banned. That will have the useful side effect of relieving traffic jams in the UK, showing what really can be achieved to counter pollution.

Restitution

Obviously, we want London Bridge and the Queen Mary back. France insists on the return of all Renoirs. The Netherlands is happy for the US to keep its Van Go's, but it would definitely like its Van Goghs back. Germany says the US can keep its paintings, but can no longer perform Wagner at the Met. Nato should suspend the US, invite Russia to take its place and establish no-fly zones in the north and south of America. (OK, let's say over Nantucket for starters: we don't want to be too ambitious.) Support should be given to any coherent anti-Bush groups that may develop in Washington, though at present there is little evidence of effective opposition groups in the capital. US air bases in the UK should be closed and weedkiller sprinkled on the airmen's golf courses. Sport All sporting contacts should cease immediately. Pete Sampras will not be permitted to win Wimbledon for the eighth time, and even Jack Straw will accept that Mike Tyson should not be allowed into the country. Tiger Woods will be allowed to compete in the Open, but will have to play blindfold. He will still win, but we shall have made our point. Baseball, basketball and American football will be treated as the ludicrous, TV-dominated non-events they are. The term "World Series" to describe a contest between teams from rival American leagues is henceforth banned. We will continue to ignore Nascar racing and the Indianapolis 500. No wrestling will be shown in the UK, no matter how obscure the channel. fields.headline: Princess Margaret resting after stroke
fields.standfirst: Special report: Princess Margaret
fields.trailText: Princess Margaret was resting at home in Kensington Palace yesterday after suffering her third stroke in as many years.
fields.body:
Princess Margaret was resting at home in Kensington Palace yesterday after suffering her third stroke in as many years.

The Queen's 70-year-old younger sister was taken ill at home on Tuesday afternoon and has constant nursing care, a Buckingham Palace statement said. The stroke, officially described as minor, follows a similar illness over Christmas which led to her being treated for several days at the King Edward VII hospital in London.

The statement said: "It will be some while before the extent of her recovery can be determined. She is happy to stay among her own things where she is comfortable and among her family."

The princess had her first stroke in 1998 while on holiday at her former home on the West Indian island of Mustique, where a year later she scalded her feet when stepping into a hot bath.

Over last Christmas the princess was ill while staying with the royal family at Sandringham in Norfolk and was reported to be depressed and confined to her bedroom. The palace eventually conceded that she was thought to have suffered a stroke.

There have been repeated suggestions that she has become confused and reclusive, deeply depressed about her health and that she has even lost the will to live, refusing to eat and often bed-ridden.

Princess Margaret suffered a nervous breakdown in the 1970s and has been treated for depression by Mark Collins, a psychiatrist from the Priory Clinic, which treats wealthy celebrities.

She has been distressed by her slow recovery from the scalding and has undertaken few engagements or public appearances in the past year.

She was most recently seen a fortnight ago, walking with the aid of a stick to attend a private dinner party at a West End restaurant.

The Queen was said to be keeping in touch with her sister's treatment and progress, and her children, Viscount Linley and Lady Sarah Chatto, have visited her.

fields.headline: US public backs green line
fields.standfirst:
Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Bush administration's attitude towards global warming is dictated more by the president's corporate backers than by US public opinion, which is far greener than the White House, surveys suggest.
fields.body:
The Bush administration's attitude towards global warming is dictated more by the president's corporate backers than by US public opinion, which is far greener than the White House, surveys suggest.

Polls have consistently shown majority support for moves to control greenhouse gas emissions. A survey by the Pew Research Centre in Washington, showed that Americans supported US participation in the Kyoto treaty on global warming by 55% to 41%. However, the poll was taken before the severe energy shortages in California and a steep rise in petrol prices.

The initial data suggests that most Americans are not as willing as George Bush to subordinate environmental concerns to the goal of sustaining high economic growth.

Asked by Gallup this month which approach the government should take in tackling power shortages, 33% of respondents said it should concentrate on more production, but 56% said the emphasis should be on conservation.

Asked what issues occupied their minds, 42% said they "thought a great deal" about the quality of the environment, while 35% were as preoccupied by the economy.

On the fate of the Alaska national wildlife refuge, opinions were more divided. In a Los Angeles Times poll, 47% backed Mr Bush's plan to open it up for oil drilling, while 45% disapproved.

After Mr Bush reversed a campaign pledge to limit carbon dioxide emissions, Newsweek magazine asked Americans about his motives: 53% of those asked said that his main motive was "special interest pressure from coal producers and others in the energy industry", rather than doubts about the scientific evidence for such regulation.

fields.headline: Missing, menaced, murdered
fields.standfirst:
The second part of a Guardian investigation into the crimes of the Milosevic era looks at the opponents killed or threatened, or who vanished, under the former president's regime

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The second part of a Guardian investigation into the crimes of the Milosevic era looks at the opponents killed or threatened, or who vanished, under the former president's regime.
fields.body:
On a warm Balkan Sunday morning 18 months ago the Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, his wife Danica, her brother, and five other friends set out from Belgrade for a day in the country.

Their convoy of three cars headed for Ravna Gora, the hilltop shrine of Draza Mihailovic, the second world war Serbian guerrilla leader who is Mr Draskovic's idol. An hour's drive from the capital, near the town of Valjevo, a Mercedes lorry approaching from the opposite direction suddenly lurched into their path.

The collision sent Mr Draskovic's Audi spinning over the verge into a field, the lorry shearing off the driver's side of the car. His brother-in-law, Veselin Boskovic, who was driving, died half an hour later. The BMW behind the Audi crashed head-on into the lorry and the three men in it died instantly.

The lorry driver was unhurt and made a prompt getaway.

"I thought of nothing but surviving," Mr Draskovic says. "It was hell. My friends were dead and I was only slightly injured. Then the reality dawns on you, that you're living in a state of killers, that your country is commanded by monsters."

The crash is now being investigated as an attempted assassination by former president Slobodan Milosevic's regime.Today, six months after Mr Milosevic was deposed, the new Serbian authorities are close to bringing charging Rade Markovic, the regime's secret police chief, and a clutch of others, with murder. The charge carries the death penalty.

Milan Radonjic, head of the Belgrade secret police under Mr Milosevic, is in custody, together with Mr Markovic, Nenad Ilic, a lorry driver and state security employee, and Nenad Bujosevic, another secret police officer, who is said to have been in an escort car directing the lorry to the crash.

Gunned down

It is one of several prominent cases of political murder being laid at the door of the Milosevic regime.

Mr Markovic is also expected to be charged with the murder of Slavko Curuvija, an opposition newspaper editor shot dead outside his Belgrade home in April 1999, two weeks after the Kosovan war began.

Branka Prpa, the journalist's widow, who looked on as her husband was gunned down by her side, was interviewed by detectives last November for the first time, 19 months after the killing.

"It was a farce," she says. "This was a political decision, a political murder. And in that system, Markovic can't decide that on his own. Milosevic is responsible, of course. In that pyramid, he was the peak."

Many in the new Serbian and Yugoslav governments agree, and are scrambling to amass the witnesses and evidence needed to blame the political violence not only on his henchmen, but on the former president himself.

There are several other cases, including Ivan Stambolic, and Zeljko Raznjatovic, better known as Arkan, the notorious warlord and gangster, who was shot dead last year.

Mr Stambolic is a former president of Serbia and was best man at Mr Milosevic's wedding. In August last year, in the run-up to the September elections, he was abducted while jogging in Belgrade. He was bundled into a car and has not been heard of since.

Until 1987, when Mr Milosevic turned ruthlessly on Mr Stambolic, the two men were inseparable, the closest of friends, but by last year Mr Stambolic was a fierce critic of his former colleague.

"It is impossible in this country that Stambolic disappeared and no one high up in the state knew anything about it," says Goran Vesic, a senior official in the Yugoslav interior ministry.

"That case is in hand, but we don't know very much."

Arkan was murdered at the Intercontinental Hotel in Belgrade just over a year ago, allegedly because he knew too much about the regime's nefarious doings in the Croatian, Bosnian and Kosovan wars. New evidence is emerging to support the long-held suspicionthat Arkan was executed on the orders of the state.

But Mr Markovic, the secret police chief, was not arrested until February, and President Vojislav Kostunica kept him in office until January, which would have allowed Mr Markovic more than three months after Mr Milosevic's fall to destroy incriminating files.

"I couldn't understand that - guilty yet still in power," says Ms Prpa. "I was shocked when I saw Markovic on TV, still in office."

Mr Draskovic accuses the new government of reluctance to pursue his alleged assassins to the very top. "Kostunica publicly protected Markovic and he has to explain why. But Markovic saw Milosevic every day. It's ridiculous. They say they can't find evidence against Milosevic. They're throwing sand in people's eyes."

The evidence against the state in the Draskovic and Curuvija cases is growing stronger. The Mercedes lorry was confiscated from its owner in 1996 by Mr Milosevic's customs service and was then included in the pool of civilian vehicles the secret police used for its operations.

Faked documents

Mihalj Kertes, a key figure in the regime who headed Mr Milosevic's secret police before running the customs, then falsified the lorry's registration papers after the crash to make it appear that the vehicle belonged to a Kosovan Serb electricity company.

On the day of the crash, the police, including Belgrade's police chief, were at the scene faster than the ambulances, and the lorry driver was instantly spirited away. Petar Rajic, a state security officer, leaked inside information on the crash to Mr Draskovic before himself being killed in a car crash in November 1999.

The lorry driver has told investigators that he was following Mr Markovic's orders, while Mr Kertes has also admitted faking the vehicle papers on orders from the secret police chief.

And the investigation into the Curuvija murder has produced apparent proof that the editor was under round-the-clock surveillance by three teams of nine state security agents, but the surveillance was called off 15 minutes before he was shot.

Mr Milosevic's key propaganda outlets, state television and the newspaper Politika, effectively announced Curuvija's death sentence a few days before he was murdered, declaring publicly to the nation that the editor was a traitor beholden to the Nato bombers attacking Belgrade at the time.

"The Curuvija case against Markovic is almost complete. We're close to bringing charges," says Mr Vesic. "As for Kertes, we've got enough against him to put him away for a long time. But he will be cooperative on Milosevic."

If Mr Kertes is singing, as they say in Belgrade, Mr Markovic is said to be saying nothing in custody.

He was despised inside his service as a rather dim-witted man who, as a career policeman, became the first outsider to head the secret police in 1998 at the behest of Mr Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic (no relation to Mr Markovic).

"The state security service," she said last week, "is a rather independent institution. It often seems to lack information.

"I had no contact with past state security leaders. But I doubt if the service had anything to do with the Ibarska [Draskovic] road crash or with Slavko Curuvija."

webTitle: Serbian security chief accused of ordering killings

fields.headline: Security chief accused of ordering killings
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Rade Markovic, the 54-year-old head of Serbia's powerful state security service, had been a policeman for 30 years but had spent only two years in the elite secret service when he was arrested last month.
fields.body:
Rade Markovic, the 54-year-old head of the powerful state security service, had been a policeman for 30 years but had spent only two years in the elite secret service when he was arrested last month. Belgrade sources say Slobodan Milosevic's influential wife, Mirjana Markovic, pressed for Mr Markovic (no relation) to be put in charge of the secret service in 1998 when his predecessor, Jovica Stanisic, was sacked.

The son of communist parents - his father an army officer, his mother a fighter with Tito's partisans against the Nazis - Mr Markovic joined the police in 1970 at the age of 24 and had an undistinguished career until he became friendly with people who would rise to positions of prominence under Mr Milosevic.

Mr Markovic's key mentor was Nikola Djuric, a former Belgrade police chief, who became his deputy at state security and was seen as the service's real boss. fields.headline: Chaos as strike cripples tube
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Commuters suffered a day of chaos yesterday as a strike by the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT) crippled London Underground services and forced people to switch to buses, cars, bicycles and walking to get to work.
fields.body:
Commuters suffered a day of chaos yesterday as a strike by the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT) crippled London Underground services and forced people to switch to buses, cars, bicycles and walking to get to work.

The underground network was effectively closed, with few stations open and no trains except on the Metropolitan line and a few shuttles on the outer branches of the Central and District lines.

Queues built up at bus stops from early morning and roads were congested from 5am as travellers took advice to stagger their journeys, according to AA Roadwatch. The main pedestrian routes through the central parks, along the river and across the main bridges turned into walking motorways, as thousands of workers tried to complete their journeys on foot.

More than 1m people a day commute to London and more than 3m journeys are made on the tube every day

The Corporation of London said thousands of businesses were badly affected. It estimated the strike could have cost the capital £100m in lost production and commerce.

The RMT strike was a protest over job security and safety in the government's controversial plans to run the tube through a public-private partnership (PPP).

Members of the train drivers' union, Aslef, had decided against strike action but most members refused to cross the picket lines of the RMT, whose members include 38% of tube drivers as well as signal, station and maintenance staff.

London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, under fire for refusing to criticise the strike, left his home at 7.55am to walk the seven miles to his office in Westminster and took two hours to arrive. He took the opportunity to condemn the PPP plans again. "If the maintenance organisation is broken up, there will be accidents," he said.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: Serbia must first face up to the past

fields.headline: Serbia's first step to recovery will be to face up to the past
fields.standfirst:
It is premature to think everything has changed

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: It is premature to think everything has changed.
fields.body:
The big black and white posters on the main streets of Belgrade ask the question "Who's to blame?" over various striking collages. They show Slobodan Milosevic lighting a cigar with, behind him, war damage, empty supermarket shelves, scenes of police brutality. This evidence that public opinion is moving, and is being moved, toward accepting that Milosevic must go to the Hague is a reminder of how much has changed in the Balkans. One has only to ask the question of what would have happened in Macedonia had Milosevic still been in power in Belgrade to see how critically important his fall has been. Had he still been manipulating events, as a Serbian journalist put it with utter conviction, arms and encouragement would be on its way to one or both sides, and "Macedonia would already be burning".

It would be an exaggeration to say that the country feels it has shot overnight from being on probation to being "America's ally now" as one newspaper headline put it when Serbian troops moved back into a section of the previously demilitarised zone at the junction of the Serbian, Kosovan, and Macedonian borders. But it is undoubtedly true that Serbia has done Nato and, in particular the United States, a sort of favour. Some Serbs relish the fact that this has happened just before an American deadline for cutting off aid comes due this weekend. The Serbian authorities had already moved to meet some of the conditions which the US Congress laid down for continuing aid, although they have refused to be hurried on the arrest and trial of Milosevic, the prelude to his eventual extradition to the Hague. But as they work toward a Milosevic arrest, "Greater Kosovo", whether in Macedonia or in the Presevo valley, has become, for Serbia, an asset in dealing with the west.

As soon as Milosevic went there were those who rightly argued that what had to be avoided was a premature rehabilitation of a Serbia which had changed but which had not changed enough. Western countries, anxious to reduce the military, financial and moral burden they carry in this region, might be tempted to fall on Serbia's neck. It remains true that this would be a development dangerous for two different, but related reasons. First, even a residual or sentimental Greater Serbia policy can still damage the whole region, obstructing changes in the status of Montenegro and Kosovo, and undermining attempts to make Bosnia a more integrated society. This would be particularly the case if western caution coincides with what Serbia might perceive to be its interests. Secondly, Serbia's own future as a normal society would be threatened if it does not part company as completely as possible not just with the methods but with the aims, the personnel, and the mentality of the Milosevic years.

It has to be said, in considering such vital questions, that both President Vojislav Kostunica and Prime Minister Zoran Djindic are, in spite of their admitted virtues, less than ideal leaders - Kostunica because of his own nationalist leanings and Djindic because of his pragmatic tendency to close the books on the mess that is Serbia's recent past without too many questions, judgments, or punishments. Kostunica, president of an imaginary federation, has few powers and thus concerns himself with symbols, railing at the Hague, reaching out to the Serbian Orthodox Church, even to the old monarchy, and to Serbs outside the state, especially those in Bosnia. Wherever anything has some nationalist appeal, Kostunica, an advocate of what is called "moderate nationalism" or "new patriotism", seems to want to annex it to his constituency.

Opinion differs as to whether this amounts to any more than a few last tunes on a broken piano, but it can be damaging. For example, the pact Kostunica organised on trade and aid with the Republika Srpska, while within the letter of the Dayton agreement, was not helpful at a time when Croatia was minimising its links with Bosnian Croats.

Djindic pays less attention to nationalist symbols. In his far more powerful position, he is dedicated to economic transformation above all other objectives, on the grounds that without it nothing can be achieved or consolidated in Serbia. In his pursuit of the necessary western aid he has moved in on Milosevic, and tried to shape a new approach to the Albanians of southern Serbia. But it may be that his team of able ministers and officials is so concerned with making up for the years they lost in the 90s, when other ex-communist states were re-making their economies and political systems, that it tends to lose sight of the need for Serbia to face up to what it actually did do in that decade, which was to ruin itself and its neighbours.

The concentration on Milosevic and a few other villains may reinforce the forgetful tendency. "Once they lauded Milosevic, now they praise Kostunica," the columnist Petar Lukovic wrote of some his fellow journalists, in a recent piece published by the Institute for War and Peace Reporting*. He complains about something not confined to journalism, the survival of compromised men and women in many official positions. Some may continue loyal to the destructive ideas of the past, while others may be no more than cynical dissemblers - but, either way, they must be a bar to real renewal. The other group of dangerous survivors is criminals - not war criminals, although some deserve that name as well, but racketeers and smugglers, beneficiaries of war and social breakdown in Serbia as in other Yugoslav successor states. Lukovic points to another worrying phenomenon, which is that while there is some recognition of war crimes, it is often allied to attempts to question scale and number. He is surely right to argue that a wider purge of the guilty and a deeper examination of recent history are both necessary and connected.

There are diplomats in Belgrade who believe, as one put it, that Serbia has moved from being the problem in the Balkans to being part of the solution. Certainly the latter part of the equation is not yet proven, just as it is not the case that "the problem" is now the Albanians. The problem, it might be hazarded, is rather that western states and Balkan states alike have a less than coherent approach to what remains to be done in former Yugoslavia. Fearful of the consequences of forceful change - toughening up in both Bosnia and Kosovo, the separation of Montenegro, independence accepted as the ultimate goal in Kosovo - they settled instead on a policy of caution and some would say procrastination. Serbia may prefer that policy and have influenced its adoption, but its own future might be better served by the radical approach, which would end with it left alone to face itself without pretensions or pretences.

*Institute for War and Peace Reporting Balkan Crisis Report No 220.

fields.headline: City Diary
fields.trailText: • It is astonishing to think high street banks have a bad reputation. Customers can be so ungrateful - such as Michael Kinsley, who lives in the US but for 26 years kept the Barclays current account he opened as a student. Recently the bank decided to shunt his money into an exciting new account, described as "High Interest Checking Account Plus". In fact, the account pays no interest unless holding more than £2,000, along with a monthly service charge of £10 and £1 per transaction. "This is like the Chinese government's practice of executing people then sending their families a bill for the bullet," fumed Michael. When he wrote to complain, Barclays charged him another £20 for its (inconclusive) reply. There is a happy ending: Barclays yesterday refunded all the charges to "explain" the situation. Which shows that it always helps if you make a fuss. It may also help if (like Michael) you edit an online magazine, Slate, owned by Microsoft. Perhaps not the best customer to piss off? "I quite agree," said Alan White, Barclays' wealth press officer.

 It is astonishing to think high street banks have a bad reputation. Customers can be so ungrateful - such as Michael Kinsley, who lives in the US but for 26 years kept the Barclays current account he opened as a student. Recently the bank decided to shunt his money into an exciting new account, described as "High Interest Checking Account Plus". In fact, the account pays no interest unless holding more than £2,000, along with a monthly service charge of £10 and £1 per transaction. "This is like the Chinese government's practice of executing people then sending their families a bill for the bullet," fumed Michael. When he wrote to complain, Barclays charged him another £20 for its (inconclusive) reply. There is a happy ending: Barclays yesterday refunded all the charges to "explain" the situation. Which shows that it always helps if you make a fuss. It may also help if (like Michael) you edit an online magazine, Slate, owned by Microsoft. Perhaps not the best customer to piss off? "I quite agree," said Alan White, Barclays' wealth press officer.

 I don't know how I (or anyone else) overlooked this press release: "Entrepreneurs tap into the £44bn global valve market". Yes, at last, someone is selling valves over the internet. If that doesn't reignite the flagging e-commerce market, I don't know what will.

 From the Nonsense On Stilts department: a press release from the RAC Foundation for Motoring, with "disturbing new research". According to a survey done on a website, "drug driving is now an everyday event for some motorists". Fascinating, but unlikely to be true given that unmoderated surveys over the internet are as reliable as a chocolate teapot. Especially as the website is in fact a soft porn site, which comes as a surprise to press officer Sue Nicholson. "I'm not aware of that," she says. So is the RAC just doing this for cheap publicity? "No, we are not," says Sue.

 There was good news this week for mag publishers Highbury House who had a good year, according to their figures. It's all thanks to groundbreaking publications such as Bean Bag World Monthly, the March issue of which has fallen into my hands. Sadly, it's not about bean-bag chairs but those little bean-filled toys. "Dear Bean Bag World," writes Lucy, 12, from Kent, "I have to put up with my friends telling me Beanies are stupid and a waste of money." Luckily, Bean Bag World's editor has the answer: "Your friends have obviously not discovered the joys of collecting Beanies."

 Elsewhere in Bean Bag World's letters page, Melissa from Calne in Wiltshire is worried that the resale value of her Beanies may have gone down. Melissa is nine. It's excellent that today's children are taking such a serious, businesslike approach to their toys.

 There haven't been many laughs about foot and mouth, and now comes the news that milk is to be rationed. So here is a joke to lighten the mood of the nation in the coming milk-free days. Two sheep are in a field. "I don't feel very well," says one. "Shut up," the other replies, "or you'll get us all killed."

webTitle: Irish inflation is not a problem after all

fields.headline: Wrong target
fields.standfirst: Irish inflation is not a problem after all
fields.trailText: Irish inflation is not a problem after all.
fields.body:
European finance ministers were wrong to tell off Ireland for its high inflation, which, may not be entirely a bad thing, according to a new view.

Dublin was told by its fellow European Union members to cut spending or raise taxes to rein in growth, in order to get price pressures under control. Ireland is the fastest growing country in the eurozone, but its inflation rate has been more than 5% for more than a year.

So far, Dublin's finance minister, Charlie McCreevy, has refused to amend his budget plans and now academics at the Centre for Economic Policy Research claim he was right to defy Brussels.

In a report published today, the CEPR argues that Irish inflation is not a problem for other members of the single currency. Because it is a relatively poor country which is growing faster than other European countries, inflation is likely to be higher. Eventually higher prices will act as a brake on the economy by reducing Ireland's international competitiveness.

"The Irish economy should be slowed by the rising prices of Irish goods, not by a tightening of the budget," said Francesco Giavazzi, one of the report's authors.

"It's important not to demonise inflation, said Mr Giavazzi. "After convincing citizens that inflation was bad, governments and the ECB must now go to step two, and explain that temporary inflation differentials can be desirable."

Mr Giavazzi said that Brussels had taken a hard line with Ireland as a warning to other countries which might be thinking of defying Commission recommendations on how to run their economies.

Opposition parties in Italy are threatening to cut taxes despite the country's large budget deficit, should they win this summer's election.

Mr Giavazzi said it was a mistake to single out Ireland as many of the eastern European countries queuing to join the EU would also be fast growing, inflation prone economies.

fields.trailText: Dow Chemical, the US chemicals company, yesterday confirmed it had agreed to acquire Ascot, the British chemical engineering firm, in a deal valued at £305m.
fields.body:
Dow Chemical, the US chemicals company, yesterday confirmed it had agreed to acquire Ascot, the British chemical engineering firm, in a deal valued at £305m.

As reported in the Guardian yesterday, Dow said it was offering 400p per share.

Ascot, which was one of Britain's last independent speciality chemicals companies, said it was in talks with an unnamed suitor a week ago. Shares in Ascot, which have risen steadily over the week, and have outperformed the chemicals sector by 20% in the past year, were up 49p, or more than 14% to 393p.

The deal is the latest example of consolidation in the chemical sector.

Ascot also reported operating profits of £46.5m for the year to the end of 2000, up 12.3% from the previous year and said business had been affected by the economic slowdown in the United States.

fields.headline: At this price?  Weston Medical
fields.trailText: Anyone with a phobia for needles will appreciate Weston Medical's technology; the Peterborough-based firm has come up with a hi-tech water pistol to fire drugs through the skin painlessly.
fields.body:
Anyone with a phobia for needles will appreciate Weston Medical's technology; the Peterborough-based firm has come up with a hi-tech water pistol to fire drugs through the skin painlessly.

The company floated almost a year ago, with a market value of £210m. But investors have had a bumpy ride; a deal to put Johnson & Johnson's drugs in its Intraject water pistols fell through last month, sending the shares into a tailspin.

There is little doubt about the potential market for needle-free injection devices. The US has introduced legislation requiring hospitals to seek an alternative to syringes, following a spate of HIV infections from accidental jabs.

However, there are firms developing powder-based systems and rival water pistols, so Weston will have to fight for a share of the market.

There was good news yesterday, as Weston agreed a tie-up with high flying biotech company Cambridge Antibody Technology, which wants to collaborate on treatments for arthritis and allergic disorders. This takes Weston into monoclonal antibodies - one of the fastest growing areas of drug research.

Extra flexibility can only be good for Weston, and monoclonal antibodies are a huge potential market, with annual sales expected to exceed £3.5bn.

Weston's annual results yesterday were on target. Losses doubled to £10.2m, due to higher spending on research and development and an increase in staff from 45 to 100.

The company is ready to make 20m Intraject devices by 2003. It will typically pick up a royalty of 5% on all drugs sold using the system, which could amount to £100m revenue a year.

The shares, up 11p to 186p, peaked at 272p in the autumn. This gives the company a market capitalisation of £230m, which is not excessive, given the potential. Worth a long-term look.

webTitle: Market forces: Telecoms in the tumble drier

fields.headline: Telecoms in the tumble drier
fields.trailText: Market forces: Telecoms in the tumble drier.
fields.body:
Weak telecom and technology shares hit the FTSE 100 once again yesterday.

Investors in the sectors took cover and the blue chip index fell 25.6 points to 5,588.4 as the US Nasdaq index added to Wednesday's 6% drop and the Dow reined back losses. The telecoms sector lopped 20 points off the FTSE.

The index had lost more than 180 points over the past two sessions after another wave of tech company profit warnings rippled out from the US. After the US market closed on Wednesday, JNI Corp and Tech Data warned that future results would fall below expectations due to weakening demand.

European telecom companies led blue chips lower, with Marconi, the telecoms equipment maker, and Spirent leading the retreat.

Marconi, which lost 9.1% on Wednesday after a profits warning from Canada's Nortel Networks, dropped a further 18p to 355p. The shares have fallen more than 50% so far on the year with investors betting on a profit warning to come in the fallout from a weakening US economy. Despite protestations that it is less exposed to the US downturn, the company has not convinced the market that it will not be jolted into issuing a warning.

Deutsche Bank cut its earnings estimates for the group, which further hit the shares. Analysts were said to have reduced earnings per share forecasts to 17.7p from 19.1p for 2001 and to 19.4p from 23.6p for 2002.

Deutsche Bank also cut estimates for Alcatel and Ericsson for the next two years, reflecting the recent stream of bad news for the industry. Spirent, the telecoms test equipment maker, saw its shares drop 21.75p to 362.25p.

Vodafone, the world's largest mobile phone operator, saw its shares drop 7p to 197p despite announcing that its debt was likely to stand at £7bn at its year end next week. The figure compares with £13.2bn at the end of the half year in October and the company's promise to reduce it to £10bn or less by the end of the financial year. The new debt forecast was accompanied by news that Vodafone had completed the sale of Italian operator Infostrada to Enel.

Shares in ARC International, the specialist chip designer, were down 9.5p to 98.5p after analysts at investment bank UBS Warburg revised upwards their loss estimate for the group in 2001 from £20.6m before interest and tax to £27.4m. The increase reflected higher costs in sales and marketing and increased spending on research.

Marks & Spencer took the market by surprise and saw its shares rise 17.5p to 266.5p after announcing it was selling much of its non-core business, cutting more than 4,000 jobs and planning to return £2bn to shareholders by March 2002.

Selfridges, however, saw no change despite announcing it would open its second store in the Manchester area by acquiring half the floorspace in Marks & Spencer's recently rebuilt city centre outlet. Selfridges will pay up to £30m for a long leasehold of floorspace in the M&S store.

Dinkie Heel, the company that makes safety shoes, was not one of the bullish retailers. Shares fell 0.5p to 8.25p after the company reported a widening full year loss.

Po Na Na was also struggling. Shares plummeted 23.5p to 91.5p after the group issued a profit warning due to disappointing trading at its largest venue, the former Hammersmith Palais in west London.

A handful of media stocks were down yesterday on a darker outlook for television advertising revenues. Carlton, which dropped 34p on Wednesday, fell a further 20p to 395p after the Guardian reported talk of a profit warning being on the way.

Aukett, the architectural firm that issued a profits warning this week due to delayed contracts, remained stable yesterday. Expect further positive news for the group in Europe.

fields.headline: Italian manufacturer raises sporting challenge for Nasdaq acronym
fields.trailText: The Nasdaq stock market is facing a legal challenge from a small Italian sports goods manufacturer that has registered the same acronym as a brand name for its products.
fields.body:
The Nasdaq stock market is facing a legal challenge from a small Italian sports goods manufacturer that has registered the same acronym as a brand name for its products.

Rather than the National Association of Securities Dealers Automatic Quotation, the famous letters, it alleges, actually stand for Nuovi Articoli Sportivi Di Alta Qualita (New Sports Items of High Quality), the trade mark of Rome-based Antartica.

The company began seeking trade mark protection for the acronym in 1998, according to it's lawyer, Alessandro Fusillo.

It has already sought to register it in the US, Italy, Canada, Japan and Britain. The stock market has objected to the manufacturer's trade mark registration in the US and the company has responded with a counter-suit in a Rome civil court.

"My clients thought that since their products were so different, there wouldn't be any problem. Now the dispute risks degenerating and spreading throughout the world," Mr Fusillo said.

It has assumed greater urgency, he said, because the "real" Nasdaq recently began marketing gadgets and sports clothes on its website. Antartica has also registered a number of internet sites but has halted construction on them pending a court ruling. "Unfortunately our correct behaviour has not been rewarded and Nasdaq is suing us all over the place."

The Italian lawyer believes his client has a strong case. "We all know the Nasdaq index, but we don't know the brand. The two things are not the same thing in law," Mr Fusillo said.

The Italian Nasdaq, which sponsors the French national women's ski team and two Italian bodybuilding champions, is eager to reach a negotiated settlement.

"If we go to an all-out war, no one will win. My fear is that we will end up with a patchwork result, with different verdicts in different jurisdictions," he said. "We have proposed a negotiation and we think it's the most intelligent way forward."

Given the amount of money investors have lost on Nasdaq of late, there could be many disappointed punters cheering for the upstart Italian acronym.

They might even want to contribute to a legal fighting fund. "It's a nice idea," said Mr Fusillo.

webTitle: And the new name for FI Group is ...

fields.headline: And the new name for FI Group is ...
fields.trailText: FI Group yesterday became the latest large firm to call in the corporate makeover specialists in announcing that it planned to change its name to Xansa.
fields.body:
FI Group yesterday became the latest large firm to call in the corporate makeover specialists in announcing that it planned to change its name to Xansa.

Chief executive Hilary Cropper said that FI had been forced to choose a name that does not exist in the English language because 98% of the names in the English dictionary have already been registered as a dot.com and it was vital that the renamed FI had a web presence.

The move, subject to shareholder approval, is likely to cost the IT services firm around £1.5m.

Corporate rebranding is the height of fashion following several high-profile name changes in recent months from firms including Arthur Andersen, Tarmac, British Gas and the Post Office.

The initials FI come from Freelancers International, a name introduced when the company was founded in the 1960s and largely employed freelance women who worked from home.

Chief executive Hilary Cropper insisted the move was about delivering "stakeholder value" and emphasising how the business has evolved since its early days into a global business.

"We are rebranding for long-term gain not short-term expediency," she said. "We are doing so in direct response to feedback from our clients and our staff. Over the past few years we have ... inherited a multitude of company names and brands and no existing name emerged with the right attributes and strength to carry the company forward internationally. "Rebranding is a critical commercial step to ensure we punch our full weight as an international force."

The Hertfordshire-based firm plumped for the name Xansa after a nine-month search that involved four outside consultancies, Ms Cropper said. Xansa was chosen because it "is easy to say and read in all major market places and has clear phonetic links with 'answer'."

The other inspiration was the Sanskrit word Sanskar which "refers to culture and values which are internalised from past experience and determine future actions".

One branding expert said he was "gobsmacked" by the makeover and its cost. "One and a half million quid for that? Nice work if you can get it," said Tim May, chairman of branding agency The Design House. "Inventing new words is a much more easy way of registering names which is becoming very difficult at the moment. But Xansa? Pretentious, moi? And I can't believe it is readily pronounceable in every language.

"There appears to be a joint tyranny of bland globalisation and what still appears to be a web driven global frenzy affecting companies at the moment."

Shareholders get the chance to vote on the new name at a special meeting on April 26 and, if it gets approval, FI plans to start rebranding everything from stationary to email systems from May 1.

Separately, London-based web integrator Revolution said that it would rebrand as Ion Global. "An ion is defined as a charged element that never rests, that dynamically seeks balance and completion - the perfect name for a company whose mission is to help clients deliver pragmatic business solutions that drive change and produce results."

Revolution said it took 12 months to develop the Ion brand.

The moniker mongers

FI Group is far from the only victim of the name-change fad. The IT business joins the not-so-select company of quite a few formerly famous firms...

What it was... and now

Arthur Andersen Accenture

British Gas Centrica/Lattice

British Steel/Hoogovens Corus

BTR/Siebe Invensys

GrandMet/Guinness Diageo

National Power Innogy/npower

The Post Office Consignia

Scottish Power (telecoms) Thus

Sketchley Semara

Tarmac Construction Carillion

Thomson CSF Thales

Unigate Uniq

webTitle: US car parts maker cuts 11,500 jobs

fields.headline: US car parts maker cuts 11,500 jobs
fields.trailText: The world's largest car parts manufacturer, Delphi Automotive Systems, yesterday announced that 11,500 jobs must go for it to cope with falling car sales in the US and Europe.
fields.body:
The world's largest car parts manufacturer, Delphi Automotive Systems, yesterday announced that 11,500 jobs must go for it to cope with falling car sales in the US and Europe.

About 100 manufacturing jobs are to be lost in Britain after the company decided to close its steering-gear plant in Southampton. Steve Gaut, a spokesman for the US com Hampshire plant would be transferred to Poland.

The cuts are the largest since the early 1990s, when a downturn in the US prompted a similar wave of redundancies. Several other large companies have announced layoffs in the past few weeks.

Dow Jones, the media company, said that it intended to cut some of the 250 jobs at WSJ.com, the website for its flagship newspaper, the Wall Street Journal. A spokeswoman for the company said that the redundancies at one of the few subscription-based websites would be limited.

Delphi said that the slowing US market, which accounts for 70% of the company's sales, had been the biggest cause of the retrenchment.

General Motors, Delphi's biggest customer and former parent, has also announced layoffs and plant closures in recent months.

Delphi, which has 190 manufacturing plants in 31 countries, also issued a profits warning yesterday, forecasting a net loss of up to $50m in the first quarter before a $400m restructuring charge. Forecast first-quarter revenues are between $6.4bn and $6.5bn, about $150m below expectation.

About $900m of the company's businesses are to be closed following a company-wide review. Three factories are to be closed or sold in the US as part of a restructuring that involves six more in France, Germany, Italy and Brazil as well as the UK.

JT Battenberg, Delphi chairman and chief executive, said: "This restructuring is necessary to strengthen Delphi both in the uncertain near-term environment and to compete and prosper for the long-term."
