webTitle: M&S tries for a recovery on classic lines

fields.headline: M&S tries for a recovery on classic lines
fields.standfirst: Vandevelde's aspirational plan
fields.trailText: When Luc Vandevelde announced his latest recovery strategy for M&S yesterday he described it as "one of the most important announcements in the history of Marks & Spencer".
fields.body:
When Luc Vandevelde announced his latest recovery strategy for M&S yesterday he described it as "one of the most important announcements in the history of Marks & Spencer".

It was certainly one of the most important announcements in the history of Mr Vandevelde. If this latest plan backfires, the man so many investors hoped would be the muscles from Brussels will be queuing for the check-out come Christmas.

The recovery strategy has its good points. The stores group is going to focus its energies on its British operations without the distractions of loss-making European operations and US businesses. Marks is going to focus on quality "classically stylish" clothes which are a good fit and a good price. "We will deliver aspirational quality accessible to all," promised Mr Vandevelde.

Splendid. One problem: M&S has been promising to deliver clothes that will appeal to its target customers at sharper prices for a couple of years now and has completely failed to do so - hence like-for-like clothing sales sliding by double digit percentages.

M&S would answer that it has recruited new talent to ensure it gets the right clothes on its rails. Maybe, but Yasmin Yusuf, the store's new creative director, has come from Warehouse and has little experience of "classically stylish" womenswear and no experience at all of menswear. M&S also promises closer relationships with suppliers - which it promised two years ago when it dropped one of its British suppliers to build better links with the other three.

The closure/sell-off of the overseas business was long overdue, and while the restructuring will add £50m to profits, it will not get more customers walking through the doors and waving their wallets in glee at the goodies on offer.

The mail order catalogue - which was never a patch on the quality of Next Directory - is being axed, but the e-commerce business retained. Yet Next reckons the bulk of its internet sales come from Directory customers who browse the book and use the internet only to place orders.

M&S has also refused to acknowledge that it now has too much space, and insists that the acres of underperforming shopfloor give it flexibility. Meanwhile the competition is getting tougher - and Philip Green's revamped Bhs will not help when it relaunches in the autumn.

For the moment Marks & Spencer is still largely viewed as a recovery waiting to happen, but an increasing number are seeing it as a terminal decline already under way. The shares have been buoyed by the prospect of the £2bn to be returned to shareholders, but there is still no good reason to buy.

Screen idles

In terms of advertising revenue, the TV industry is facing outright recession this year, according to those in the City paid to goggle the box. Analysts have been falling over each other to produce ever more bearish pronouncements in the wake of last year's dot.com fest and, naturally enough, we have seen the effect on the share prices of Granada Media and Carlton Communications, which have fallen 5% and 12% respec tively in the past two days. The latest estimates from media buyer Optimedia published yesterday said ITV revenues were £158m in March against £175m last year. For April it's even worse: £157m against £182m last year. The headline figures are worrying enough, but they also obscure some underlying trends which should create real fretting in the industry.

It is all about the short-term greed so prevalent during the internet boom. Such was the clamour for space on the telly among dot.com companies and associated high-spenders last year that the price of ITV airtime rocketed, by up to 20% for certain slots.

While media such as newspapers were able to expand in order to entertain all that foolish venture capital last year (and are now contracting), the ITV companies remained under strict limits on advertising minutes in peak hours.

With slots limited, the effect was to squeeze out the bulk advertisers which had kept the commercial TV industry in silk suits for so many years - names such as Procter & Gamble, Nestlé and Unilever. These old proponents of fast-moving consumer goods were driven into other media, trying out everything from shopping trolleys to stadium hoardings to get their brands across.

Predictably, much of this money has been slow to return to ITV despite the price of airtime rapidly returning to earth and a better performance from the network in gaining audience share. The talk among advertisers is all about television being a fragmented medium, cluttered with channels which have split target audiences.

We should not expect the bluey white Persil family or the corny Nescafe couple to become a thing of the past, but a shift has taken place. Firms such as Granada and Carlton could be paying for the dot.com excesses for a long time.
fields.bodyText: When Luc Vandevelde announced his latest recovery strategy for M&S yesterday he described it as "one of the most important announcements in the history of Marks & Spencer". It was certainly one of the most important announcements in the history of Mr Vandevelde. If this latest plan backfires, the man so many investors hoped would be the muscles from Brussels will be queuing for the check-out come Christmas. The recovery strategy has its good points. The stores group is going to focus its energies on its British operations without the distractions of loss-making European operations and US businesses. Marks is going to focus on quality "classically stylish" clothes which are a good fit and a good price. "We will deliver aspirational quality accessible to all," promised Mr Vandevelde. Splendid. One problem: M&S has been promising to deliver clothes that will appeal to its target customers at sharper prices for a couple of years now and has completely failed to do so - hence like-for-like clothing sales sliding by double digit percentages. M&S would answer that it has recruited new talent to ensure it gets the right clothes on its rails. Maybe, but Yasmin Yusuf, the store's new creative director, has come from Warehouse and has little experience of "classically stylish" womenswear and no experience at all of menswear. M&S also promises closer relationships with suppliers - which it promised two years ago when it dropped one of its British suppliers to build better links with the other three. The closure/sell-off of the overseas business was long overdue, and while the restructuring will add £50m to profits, it will not get more customers walking through the doors and waving their wallets in glee at the goodies on offer. The mail order catalogue - which was never a patch on the quality of Next Directory - is being axed, but the e-commerce business retained. Yet Next reckons the bulk of its internet sales come from Directory customers who browse the book and use the internet only to place orders. M&S has also refused to acknowledge that it now has too much space, and insists that the acres of underperforming shopfloor give it flexibility. Meanwhile the competition is getting tougher - and Philip Green's revamped Bhs will not help when it relaunches in the autumn. For the moment Marks & Spencer is still largely viewed as a recovery waiting to happen, but an increasing number are seeing it as a terminal decline already under way. The shares have been buoyed by the prospect of the £2bn to be returned to shareholders, but there is still no good reason to buy. Screen idles In terms of advertising revenue, the TV industry is facing outright recession this year, according to those in the City paid to goggle the box. Analysts have been falling over each other to produce ever more bearish pronouncements in the wake of last year's dot.com fest and, naturally enough, we have seen the effect on the share prices of Granada Media and Carlton Communications, which have fallen 5% and 12% respec tively in the past two days. The latest estimates from media buyer Optimedia published yesterday said ITV revenues were £158m in March against £175m last year. For April it's even worse: £157m against £182m last year. The headline figures are worrying enough, but they also obscure some underlying trends which should create real fretting in the industry. It is all about the short-term greed so prevalent during the internet boom. Such was the clamour for space on the telly among dot.com companies and associated high-spenders last year that the price of ITV airtime rocketed, by up to 20% for certain slots. While media such as newspapers were able to expand in order to entertain all that foolish venture capital last year (and are now contracting), the ITV companies remained under strict limits on advertising minutes in peak hours. With slots limited, the effect was to squeeze out the bulk advertisers which had kept the commercial TV industry in silk suits for so many years - names such as Procter & Gamble, Nestlé and Unilever. These old proponents of fast-moving consumer goods were driven into other media, trying out everything from shopping trolleys to stadium hoardings to get their brands across. Predictably, much of this money has been slow to return to ITV despite the price of airtime rapidly returning to earth and a better performance from the network in gaining audience share. The talk among advertisers is all about television being a fragmented medium, cluttered with channels which have split target audiences. We should not expect the bluey white Persil family or the corny Nescafe couple to become a thing of the past, but a shift has taken place. Firms such as Granada and Carlton could be paying for the dot.com excesses for a long time.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Vodafone debt cut to £7bn | £450m water deal for UU | Ofwat agrees rise in bills | Greek blow to Eurofighter | Share options for Corus chiefs
fields.body:
Vodafone debt cut to £7bn

Vodafone said its borrowings have fallen to about £7bn after the sale of Italian operator Infostrada to Enel, confirming it as one of the least indebted of the leading telecoms companies. The world's largest wireless company, which borrowed heavily to buy Germany's Mannesmann and pay for third-generation licences, has slashed its debt from £13.2bn at the end of its half year in October.

The sale of Mannesmann's non-wireless subsidiaries has helped it beat its target of £10bn or less by the end of the financial year this month. Its borrowings compare with debts of 60bn euros (£36bn) at Deutsche Telekom and £30bn at BT. Enel paid 8.55bn euros for Infostrada.

£450m water deal for UU

United Utilities yesterday won a contract worth £450m over four years to provide operations and maintenance services to Welsh Water.

Welsh Water's US-owned parent Western Power Distribution (WPD) tendered the contract after Severn Trent won a court battle objecting to a private arrangement between WPD and UU. WPD has since agreed to sell Welsh Water to a not-for-profit body called Glas Cymru.

Ofwat agrees rise in bills

Water and sewerage bills in England and Wales will rise by an average of 2.3% in the year from Sunday, the regulator, Ofwat, said yesterday. The below-inflation increase comes after an 11.3% cut in bills last year. Ofwat said the average metered bill for water and sewerage would be £194 compared with £189 in 2000-2001 while unmetered bills would rise from £227 to £233.

Greek blow to Eurofighter

The Greek government yesterday dealt a blow to hopes of export orders for the four-nation Euro-fighter. Prime minister Costas Simitis said the government was postponing until after 2004 the purchase of fourth generation aircraft. In February Greece signed an initial deal to buy 60 Eurofighters for about 5bn euros (£3bn).

Share options for Corus chiefs

Corus, the steel firm likely to make up to 6,000 people redundant, yesterday awarded 1.6m share options to four senior directors. Executive director Tony Pedder and finance director David Lloyd, are among those receiving the grants at 55.3p per share. Corus shares closed down 0.25p at 59.25p last night.

fields.headline: Shire denies dragging its feet
fields.trailText: Shire Pharmaceuticals was accused of dragging its feet after failing to meet its deadline yesterday for the completion of its £5bn merger with Canada's BioChem Pharma.
fields.body:
Shire Pharmaceuticals was accused of dragging its feet after failing to meet its deadline yesterday for the completion of its £5bn merger with Canada's BioChem Pharma.

The Hampshire-based drugs firm announced that the deal had been held up by Canada's industry minister, Brian Tobin, who is not satisfied the merger will be of "net benefit" to his country.

Mr Tobin wants assurances that the combined company will protect jobs in BioChem's home state of Quebec, and that the area will benefit from future research and development investment.

The delay infuriated arbitrageurs, who have been pushing down Shire shares over a 10-day pricing period, to try to ensure that the company issues as much stock as possible for BioChem. These arbitrageurs hurriedly unwound their positions yesterday, sending Shire's shares up 33p to £11.33.

Some suggested that Shire was happy with the delay, because it felt its shares had fallen too low. One City source said: "There are a lot of conspiracy theories going round - people are not at all pleased."

Others, however, said those complaining had failed to do their homework, with one pointing out that BioChem is based in the politically sensitive province of Quebec: "People in Quebec are going to be very sensitive about their companies disappearing to foreign owners, who could take away jobs."

A Shire spokesman said it was "preposterous" to suggest that Shire was not hurrying with the deal. He said the firm remained confident of completing the transaction after further negotiations with the minister.

A source close to Shire said the company had dispatched several senior executives to handle negotiations with the Canadian authorities: "The company's been very keen to close the deal - it hasn't been shy of resources."

webTitle: Michael and Bernadette Sands McKevitt arrested

fields.headline: Dissident couple arrested
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Police in the Irish Republic arrested leading republican dissidents Michael and Bernadette Sands McKevitt yesterday, according to a security source.
fields.body:
Police in the Irish Republic arrested leading republican dissidents Michael and Bernadette Sands McKevitt yesterday, according to a security source.

Gardai would not officially name the husband and wife, who are key members of the 32-County Sovereignty committee, believed to be the political wing of the Real IRA.

But a source said police seized the couple and two other men, in Dundalk, Co Louth, just south of the border. They can be held for up to 72 hours without charge under anti-terrorist laws.

They were taken to Balbriggan and Drogheda police stations, where they were interrogated by officers from the national bureau of criminal investigation and the special detective unit (the equivalent of special branch).

A police spokesman said the arrests were part of an investigation into paramilitary activity.

Local people ran Mr and Mrs McKevitt, the sister of hunger striker Bobby Sands, out of their T-shirt printing business in Dundalk shortly after the Real IRA bomb, which killed 29 people in Omagh in August 1998. The couple have strongly denied having anything to do with the atrocity.

The Real IRA, which opposes the Good Friday agreement and the Northern Ireland peace process, has been increasingly active in recent months, and is now believed to be concentrating on English targets. The latest attack was a car bomb outside BBC headquarters in west London on March 4.

webTitle: Daddy goes Diddy as star stakes name on fresh start

fields.headline: Daddy goes Diddy as star stakes name on fresh start
fields.trailText: After a torrid few months in which he was cleared of weapon charges and broke up with his film star girlfriend, the artist formerly known as Puff Daddy has decided that his name has run out of steam.
fields.body:
After a torrid few months in which he was cleared of weapon charges and broke up with his film star girlfriend, the artist formerly known as Puff Daddy has decided that his name has run out of steam.

Sean Combs, the rap impresario who built a music and clothing empire as Puff Daddy, is to change his name in an attempt to make a fresh start. "No more Puff Daddy," he told viewers of an MTV music show. "I'm not doing it as serious as Prince [but] I just want something fresh." Prince revived his original name last year after a brief foray as an unpronouncable symbol.

The artist formerly known as Puffy has already decided on a new, more user-friendly name: P. Diddy. Lest anyone suspect that the choice reflects an appreciation, or even knowledge of, Ken Dodd and his little men, Combs credited the late rapper Notorious B.I.G. for the new moniker. "I'm rocking with P. Diddy now - my man Biggie gave me that name," he said.

In his first interview since being acquitted of all charges two weeks ago, Mr Combs said he intended to hold an official name-changing ceremony in June. He suggested the former president Bill Clinton as a master of ceremonies. "Clinton is probably going to change my name. I like his style," he said. "He is a survivor - they went at him, he is still standing."

Wearing the huge gold earrings and dark glasses that were his trademark before the court case, Combs suggested that he was not willing to give up all parts of his former life. Speaking of Jennifer Lopez, his former girlfriend, he said: "I'll always love her. When the time is right, we're gonna meet again."

Before taking up his new persona, the multi-billionaire intends to take a long holiday. He said: "I gotta take a break. I'm going to take a leave of absence just to be Sean Combs, [to] have time to think about what's the next level I want to play on."

fields.headline: Bomber 'driven mad' by Israelis shelling
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: To the Tawils, a not particularly religious family of middle class professionals, the news that their son Dia, 19, was the Hamas suicide bomber who blew himself up in Jerusalem on Tuesday came as a shock.
fields.body:
To the Tawils, a not particularly religious family of middle class professionals, the news that their son Dia, 19, was the Hamas suicide bomber who blew himself up in Jerusalem on Tuesday came as a shock.

Yesterday, in a block of flats in Ramallah, West Bank, draped in huge banners of his likeness and the green flags of the Islamic militant group, his weeping mother sat receiving a long line of mourners.

"He was going to be 20 on April 26. He didn't see anything in life yet," his sister Nida' said. "I never knew how serious he was. Sometimes he said, 'I adore these people who do these bombs for their country and give their souls to God', and I would say, 'Do you have the courage?'"

To his family's grief, but also pride, he did.

After becoming increasingly religious in his last year in secondary school, he secretly joined Hamas and gave up his aim of completing his course in electrical engineering at Bir Zeit University to become a suicide bomber.

The only hint of change was his increasing agitation at the daily battles being fought outside the family's home near the City Inn hotel, a junction that has produced some of the intifada's highest casualty figures as Israeli army snipers have shot stone throwers and Palestinian gunmen have fired from half-built high rise blocks.

"We could see everything from our house, and he would get so mad if he saw someone shot," Ms Tawil said. "That nine-year-old kid who was killed just sitting in a room - when he saw that on TV he broke down and cried for an hour. He said: 'I don't want to get mad but they are forcing me to get mad.'"

On Tuesday her brother strapped on a belt of explosives, walked to a number six bus at French Hill, a Jewish settlement in northern Jerusalem, and blew himself up. Another suicide bombing in central Israel on Wednesday killed two schoolboys and gravely wounded another, but Tawil succeeded only in killing himself, although he injured more than 30 people.

But in his hometown Tawil was a hero yesterday, his image adorning the city hall of neighbouring al-Bireh, and his farewell video broadcast on Palestinian television.

He was at the forefront of a new wave of suicide bombings planned by Hamas's armed wing, which claims to have seven would-be martyrs waiting to follow him. Israeli officials say the bombers are sent on their last journey with utter cynicism - often there is a back-up detonator should they lose their nerve.

Nida' Tawil, who studied in Florida for two years, can understand why outsiders might regard Tawil's last act with loathing. But she says he was driven to kill civilians by the events of the past six months.

"When people say why did he kill civilians, I say: they also kill civilians. So why is it that what we do is a crime, and what they do is not a crime?"

fields.headline: McVeigh brushes aside deaths
fields.trailText: The 19 children killed in the bombing of an Oklahoma City government building six years ago were "collateral damage", Timothy McVeigh, the worst home-grown terrorist in US history told the the authors of a new book about the attack.
fields.body:
The 19 children killed in the bombing of an Oklahoma City government building six years ago were "collateral damage", Timothy McVeigh, the worst home-grown terrorist in US history told the the authors of a new book about the attack.

McVeigh, 32, who is due to be executed by lethal injection on May 16, said his only regret was not to have levelled the entire building, in which 168 people died, and expressed pride in having carried out the bombing on his own.

Lou Michel and Dan Herbeck, two US journalists who interviewed him extensively in prison, said yesterday that McVeigh had claimed not to have known that there was a child-care centre in the Alfred P Murrah building before he parked a lorry full of explosives on the road outside and walked away on April 19 1995.

"I recognised that someone might be bringing their kid to work," they quoted him as saying. "However, if I had known there was a day-care centre, it might have given me pause to switch targets. That's a large amount of collateral damage."

But an FBI investigator Danny Defenbaugh said that McVeigh must have seen the brightly coloured children's pictures in the windows.

In any case, it does not appear to have caused McVeigh much remorse. His main concern appeared to be that the child deaths dampened the galvanising effect he had hoped the bomb attack would have on the US far-right.

"I understand what they felt in Oklahoma City," he said. But "I have no sympathy for them."

This picture of an unrepentant killer emerges from American Terrorist: Timothy McVeigh and the Oklahoma City Bombing, due to be published next month.

Michel told ABC News that McVeigh said that a friend from his army days, Terry Nichols, had helped him to build the bomb, but that the attack was his own idea.

"You can't handle the truth," McVeigh said, quoting a character played by Jack Nicholson in the film A Few Good Men. "Because the truth is I blew up the Murrah building and isn't it kind of scary that one man could reap this kind of hell?"

McVeigh said the attack was in revenge for the killing of the wife and child of a white separatist in a gun battle with the FBI at Ruby Ridge in Idaho in 1992, and the FBI raid on the Branch Davidian religious cult in Waco, Texas, in 1993.

The bombing occurred on the second anniversary of the Waco raid.

fields.headline: Italians hunt illegal GM seed
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: The Italian agriculture minister, Alfonso Pecoraro Scanio, ordered checks on 21 Italian seed companies yesterday after seizing soya bean and maize seed imported by the US biotech company Monsanto on the grounds that it contained traces of genetically modified material.
fields.body:
The Italian agriculture minister, Alfonso Pecoraro Scanio, ordered checks on 21 Italian seed companies yesterday after seizing soya bean and maize seed imported by the US biotech company Monsanto on the grounds that it contained traces of genetically modified material.

Mr Pecoraro Scanio has also asked the regional authorities in Milan to suspend Monsanto's seed import licence.

"The possible illegal emission of genetically modified organisms in the fields could cause very serious environmental and economic damage," said Mr Pecoraro Scanio, a Green party member and an opponent of GM foods.

"To prevent is always better than to repair damage."

Officials of the Italian Seed Association, whose members will be subjected to the checks ordered yesterday, which will be made by farm police and fraud investigators, wrote to Mr Pecoraro Scanio in October saying it was impossible to guarantee seeds free of GM material.

Jean-Michel Duhamel, managing director of a Monsanto subsidiary in Lodi, said that if the authorities found traces of genetic material in deposits of rival seed firms, they too could be threatened with having their import licences suspended.

On Wednesday the Italian police began seizing 300 tonnes of soya seed suspected of containing genetic material which Monsanto had distributed to retailers.

They had already seized 112 tonnes of maize from Monsanto's warehouse in Lodi.

Testing of maize from Monsanto revealed the presence of the banned GM Monsanto strain Mon 810, a health ministry official said.

Mr Duhamel said the maize could contain minimal traces of Mon 810, but it conformed with the regulations.

An official familiar with the seizures of Monsanto grain said EU laws were unclear on how to tackle cases where grain was found to contain genetic material. It was up to individual governments to decide how to proceed in such cases, he added.

"The possible illegal emission of genetically modified organisms in the fields could cause very serious environmental and economic damage," said Mr Pecoraro Scanio, a Green party member and an opponent of GM foods. "To prevent is always better than to repair damage." They had already seized 112 tonnes of maize from Monsanto's warehouse in Lodi. Testing of maize from Monsanto revealed the presence of the banned GM Monsanto strain Mon 810, a health ministry official said. webTitle: Arafat defies pressure to call off Palestinian uprising

fields.headline: Arafat defies pressure to call off Palestinian uprising
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Yasser Arafat faced new international pressure to call off the Palestinian uprising yesterday as he toured the site of Wednesday night's Israeli rocket attack on the headquarters of his personal team of security guards.
fields.body:
Yasser Arafat faced new international pressure to call off the Palestinian uprising yesterday as he toured the site of Wednesday night's Israeli rocket attack on the headquarters of his personal team of security guards.

The helicopter gunship attack on Force 17 in Ramallah has confirmed the unit's reputation as the most elite of the dozen or so security organisations in the West Bank and Gaza.

Underlining the point, Mr Arafat left his helicopter yesterday and marched directly toward a Force 17 honour guard, clad in olive uniforms and black berets. As he saluted, a ban played the Palestinian anthem.

Mr Arafat said that the intifada would continue "until the Palestinian flag is raised on the walls, churches and mosques of holy Jerusalem".

In recent days the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has regularly blamed Force 17 - and by extension Mr Arafat himself - for drive-by shootings at Jewish settlers, and indirectly for the bombing attacks in Israel which have been claimed by militant groups such as Hamas and Islamic Jihad.

Earlier this month Israeli army officers said they had established a link between the commander of Force 17 in the West Bank, and the roadside ambushes which killed eight Jewish motorists along the main route between Jerusalem and Ramallah.

In the Gaza Strip, the Israelis accuse Force 17 of mounting mortar attacks.

On February 14 Israeli helicopter gunships fired a volley of rockets at a the car of a Force 17 colonel in the Gaza Strip, the second member of the force to be assassinated. Another member of the force was shot dead by Israeli forces in clashes in the Gaza Strip yesterday in which two Palestinian teenagers also died.

Force 17 emerged in the mid-1970s and takes its name from the telephone extension of its founder, Ali Hassan Salameh, in the Palestinian headquarters in the Fak'hani district of west Beirut.

To Palestinians, Salameh was a legendary figure. Married to a Lebanese beauty queen crowned Miss Universe, he inspired a character in the John Le Carré novel The Little Drummer Girl. But Israelis regard him as one of their most dangerous enemies: the man responsible for the attack on their athletes at the Munich Olympics in 1972.

He was assassinated by an Israeli car bomb in 1979. But the force he created survived: a commando unit with unquestioned loyalty to Mr Arafat and other leaders of his Fatah movement.

After three months of physical and arms training, members of Force 17 are routinely stationed away from their hometowns and isolated from their families to assure undivided loyalty to the Palestinian leader.

When Mr Arafat returned to Gaza in 1994, 300 Force 17 fighters came too, and this nucleus of battle-hardened veterans from Lebanon remains the core of the militia, believed to number 3,500.

Mahmoud Damara, the low-profile chief of Mr Arafat's presidential guard in Ramallah, describes his men as the "first circle of defence around the Palestinian leader".

"The Israelis have clearly targeted President Arafat and Force 17," Mr Damara said yesterday as he stood besides the unit's flattened buildings.

"But we expect anything from them. This is a war government."

In return, the Israeli army claims that Mr Damara has supplied his force's members with arms and defined the policies for terrorist attacks.

Mr Damara denies any such role. "Our duty is to defend the president," he told the Associated Press news agency.

But, despite Force 17's reputation, many of the new recruits are of a far lower calibre than Israel imagines.

Outside a branch office of Force 17 in neighbouring Beituniya yesterday, there was a single sentry: Ibrahim al-Nafar, a scrawny 18-year-old in plain clothes.

The Gazan youth, who is paid £160 a month plus room and board, said he was left behind when his comrades were told to disperse for fear of Israeli follow-up attacks.

Mr Arafat, whose appearances in the West Bank have been rare since the uprising began, was in defiant mood yesterday. But he faced a new call from President George Bush to condemn the suicide bombs which provoked the air attacks on Ramallah and Gaza.

"The Palestinian leader needs to speak out publicly and forcefully in a language the Palestinians can understand to condemn the violence and terror," Mr Bush said.

But a threat of a further violence was made by Ahmad Helles, Fatah's secretary general in Gaza. "If they hit our cities and civilians, then every place in Israel is a legitimate target for our fighters," he said.

webTitle: Two jailed for Fenice opera arson

fields.headline: Two jailed for Fenice opera arson
fields.trailText: A Venetian court convicted two electricians yesterday of starting the fire which gutted La Fenice opera house five years ago, but acquitted the former mayor and other administrators charged with negligence and complicity in the blaze.
fields.body:
A Venetian court convicted two electricians yesterday of starting the fire which gutted La Fenice opera house five years ago, but acquitted the former mayor and other administrators charged with negligence and complicity in the blaze.

The electricians, Enrico Carella and Massimiliano Marchetti, were sentenced to seven and six years in prison, respectively.

The prosecutor said they had deliberately started the fire on the night of January 29 1996 in order to avoid paying a fine for delays in their rewiring work.

The court, which had been considering its verdict since Tuesday, acquitted Massimo Cacciari, the former leftwing mayor, and seven other people of negligence in connection with the blaze.

The prosecutor had asked for Mr Cacciari, a philosophy professor and one of Italy's best known intellectuals, to be jailed for nine months for failing to react to warnings sent him by the city fire department.

He also sought prison sentences for theatre and city administrators, the director of the restoration work being carried out at the time of the fire, and the theatre doorman, whose absence held up the firefighters during the initial stages of the blaze.

The 200-year-old theatre, designed by Antonio Selva, was considered one of Venice's more modern architectural jewels and prized by opera buffs for its perfect acoustics. The fierce conflagration continued all night, leaving only the outer walls of the theatre standing.

It is expected to rise again from the ashes in 2003.

webTitle: Glacier plan for drought in Pakistan

fields.headline: Glacier plan for drought in Pakistan
fields.trailText: The military regime in Pakistan is considering melting glaciers in the northern mountains to help the country through its worst drought for 30 years.
fields.body:
The military regime in Pakistan is considering melting glaciers in the northern mountains to help the country through its worst drought for 30 years.

It has asked the meteorological department to examine the technique of spraying charcoal on to the glaciers to melt the ice and provide much needed water for crops.

Engineers have already ruled out the idea of melting them with lasers.

Riaz Ahmed Khan, chairman of the federal flood commission, said the charcoal survey was in its early stages.

"We have to see that it does not destabilise the glaciers," he added.

The Hindu Kush, Karakoram and Himalayan mountain ranges, which meet in northern Pakistan, are the greatest concentration of high mountains in the world. Pakistan has five 8,000m (26,246ft) peaks, including K2, the world's second highest mountain.

With little rainfall in the past three years and its biggest reservoirs virtually dry, Pakistan will have only half the amount of water it normally uses for crops and drinking until June.

Across the border in Afghanistan drought has pushed 1m people to the brink of starvation and forced more than 500,000 to leave their homes in search of water.

Pakistan has already tried to avert the crisis by cloud seeding. "The drought is much worse than last year, and that is why we have taken these contingency plans," Mr Khan said.

Farmers have been told to switch to crops that need less water and, in some areas, rice farming has been banned.

The sugarcane, rice and cotton crops have been badly affected, and more than a third of this year's wheat crop has beenlost. Economists believe the poor wheat crop alone could badly reduce economic growth this year. Pakistan is still heavily reliant on agriculture.

The government estimates that the drought will cost £1bn in lost revenue this year, but many economists think it will be much more.

In the arid Baluchistan province 2m animals have died. In Sind, 76 people were arrested this week for trying to organise a strike in protest at water shortages. Sindi farmers accuse the Punjab government of monopolising water from the Indus.

fields.headline: Nuclear cargo ends its journey
fields.trailText: The German police wrong-footed nuclear energy protesters early yesterday by rushing the shipment of radioactive waste they had harried across the country for two days to its final destination.
fields.body:
The German police wrong-footed nuclear energy protesters early yesterday by rushing the shipment of radioactive waste they had harried across the country for two days to its final destination.

Six lorries carrying the first waste returned to Germany from France since 1997 took just over an hour to cover the 12 miles from the rail terminal in Dannenberg to Gorleben, south-west of Hamburg.

Police and border guards kept the protesters at bay with a final massive show of force, using armoured car escorts and unmuzzled dogs to thwart their planned blockades.

The dash allowed the government to enter two crucial parliamentary debates with the operation completed. At the end of one debate, the Green environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, survived a vote of no confidence.

Earlier protests delayed the cargo's arrival by 24 hours and tied down 20,000 police officers along the 375-mile route. The police estimated the cost of the security at £35m. The protesters said their operation was a success.

The vitrified waste from recycled fuel rods will be kept in a Gorleben warehouse until the government decides how it should be stored permanently, possibly in a nearby salt mine.

fields.headline: Pitcairn rape case expands
fields.trailText: The investigation of a single rape allegation on Pitcairn Island has widened to take in 15 sexual assault allegations among the island's population of 44 people, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The investigation of a single rape allegation on Pitcairn Island has widened to take in 15 sexual assault allegations among the island's population of 44 people, it emerged yesterday.

A New Zealand investigator specialising in sexual assaults has joined the British detectives who opened the rape investigation last year, according to the Evening Post in Wellington.

the New Zealand police confirmed that their investigator had been posted to the island, and the island's New Zealand-based deputy-governor, Karen Wolstenholme, said the investigation was continuing.

If charges are brought, they will pave the way for only the second trial on the island, which was settled by the group of English sailors who became famous for staging the mutiny on HMS Bounty 200 years ago.

The island is a dot in the Pacific half way between New Zealand and Peru. British police officers have been investigating the alleged December 1999 rape for nearly a year.

fields.headline: Oil slick threatens Denmark
fields.trailText: Oil slicks approached the Danish coast yesterday after a tanker collided with a freighter in the Baltic, creating one of the biggest oil leaks ever to foul Danish waters.
fields.body:
Oil slicks approached the Danish coast yesterday after a tanker collided with a freighter in the Baltic, creating one of the biggest oil leaks ever to foul Danish waters.

Coastguards were optimistic of preventing the oil polluting the shoreline, despite reports of heavy weather in the area. Ships from Denmark, Germany and Sweden were trying to contain the spill, they said.

"Things are progressing and we are optimistic," a spokesman said.

The environment ministry in the north-east German state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern warned Denmark to expect "serious pollution" as slicks up to 200 metres long and spread across 15 nautical miles were blown towards its coastline.

The 30,000-tonne Baltic Carrier was en route to Gothenburg, Sweden, when it collided with a freighter carrying sugar anchored off the German port of Rostock.

More than 1,500 tonnes of heavy heating oil leaked from the tanker, 20% of which was expected to evaporate before hitting land.

Officials said oil was no longer leaking from the tanker, which was at anchor in rough seas near the site of the collision and not in danger of sinking.

fields.headline: Comfort women lose reparation
fields.trailText: A Japanese court has nullified the only legal victory won by comfort women who were forced into sexual slavery by the army during the second world war.
fields.body:
A Japanese court has nullified the only legal victory won by comfort women who were forced into sexual slavery by the army during the second world war.

Overturning an April 1998 ruling, the Hiroshima high court said yesterday that the government was not liable to pay compensation to three South Korean women who were confined in frontline brothels between 1937 and 1945.

A lower court awarded the women 300,000 yen (£1,700), but they appealed on the grounds that the settlement was too low.

The government also appealed, on the grounds that all claims on the state were settled in postwar peace treaties.

Yesterday the presiding judge, Toshiaki Kawanami, ruled in favour of the government, saying it had no legal obligation to pay compensation to individuals. Groups representing Korean comfort women said the ruling was based on a "monstrous way of thinking".

"All victimised countries in Asia will fight to the end until the day will come for the Japanese government to pay damages", the Chongdaehyop coalition said in a statement.

About 10 similar cases are still pending, including one by British former PoWs.

fields.headline: East Timor leader 'will not stand'
fields.trailText: The day after resigning as leader of East Timor's interim legislature, the charismatic independence leader Jose Alexandre "Xanana" Gusmao said yesterday that he would not stand in the territory's first presidential election.
fields.body:
The day after resigning as leader of East Timor's interim legislature, the charismatic independence leader Jose Alexandre "Xanana" Gusmao said yesterday that he would not stand in the territory's first presidential election.

Mr Gusmao, 54, a former guerrilla commander previously thought to be the only candidate suitable to lead the fledgling state, said that it was time for others to take up the mantle of national leadership.

"I will not run for president," he said. "I believe that if I could do something for this country and these people it was in a different stage of the process, the liberation struggle."

Other East Timorese politicians and foreign observers, however, believe that his withdrawal from the race will not be final; he resigned as national council leader last November, only to change his mind the next day, caving in to popular pressure.

The UN's transitional administrator, Sergio Vieira de Mello, said that he had accepted Mr Gusmao's resignation from the council but hoped he would change his mind about the presidency.

"I do hope he will stand for elections," Mr De Mello said. "I believe he is key to stability in East Timor during the transitional phase, and particularly after independence."

fields.headline: Meals on wheels
fields.standfirst: Dodgy, germ-ridden and greasy. Burger vans do not enjoy a good reputation. But a new report says that they are just as good as - maybe even better than - certain high-street eateries.  Stephen Moss investigates
fields.trailText: Dodgy, germ-ridden and greasy. Burger vans do not enjoy a good reputation. But a new report says that they are just as good as - maybe even better than - certain high-street eateries. Stephen Moss investigates.
fields.body:
What a madeleine cake was to Proust, a bacon roll is to me. It always summons up the A11 on Saturday mornings: a brief stop on the way to the north Norfolk coast; a chill in the air; lowering skies with just a suggestion of a break in the cloud; pleasure at leaving London behind and being in open country; bacon sizzling on the hotplate in the little white van that always used to be parked in a convenient layby; then the hot, slimy bacon roll to thrill the senses. Bliss.

Sadly, the A11 was "improved" a couple of years ago and turned into a dual carriage way, making the bacon roll stop inaccessible to Norfolk-bound travellers. The layby is still there, but when I last looked there was no sign of the white van. These days, we stop on the edge of Thetford Forest, along with cars and lorries and coachloads of OAPs who queue 10-deep for burgers, egg and bacon sandwiches and industrially produced coffees. Somehow it isn't quite the same.

Nothing beats eating in the open air. But even as you savour the fatty delights of the roadside vans, you can't help wondering about them. Mobile food vans - and no slight is intended here to the good burghers of Thetford - have a pretty grisly reputation. Their offerings have generally been assumed to be of low quality, made palatable only by the freedom of the open road, the persuasive properties of late-night alcohol, or the fact that your team have just won 6-1.

But banish those fears. A survey this week by trading standards officers in West Sussex has produced the startling finding that burgers from food vans are as good as - and sometimes better than - those sold by mainstream high-street retailers. Small, truculent men in grubby white aprons will be dancing in the streets.

The West Sussex officers undertook the survey because theirs is a major tourist area awash with vans serving fast food, and they were worried about the quality of the food being served to gullible visitors. They took samples from 11 roadside outlets and compared them with burgers from three unnamed high-street chains, checking the type and quality of the raw meat used, and the overall nutritional value of the finished article. "Roadside catering chuck wagons are often portrayed as the typical greasy spoons, with everything swimming in fat," says trading standards officer Chris Tinley. "Our project was organised to see if that image was true, and we are pleased to say that it is not the case as far as West Sussex is concerned."

"The survey revealed that all the burgers met the minimum compositional standards for this product," says the euphoniously named Patrick Bligh-Cheesman, the area's head of trading standards. "From the nutritional analysis, which compares protein and fat content, we can tell that the quality of the roadside burger was often as good as that from the high street. In the fat test, six out of the 11 roadside burgers gave a lower fat reading than the best high-street burger."

Price was also to the advantage of the vans. The average cost of the roadside burgers was £1.64, with prices ranging from £1.40 to £2.40. The average cost of the high-street burger was £2.31, with prices from £1.90 to £2.59. "In terms of the cost of providing protein, the average roadside burger was more than 33% cheaper than its high-street competitor," says Bligh-Cheesman.

The leading high-street chains found all this hard to digest. Wimpy refused to comment; McDonald's dismissed the report as "generic and non-specific"; and Burger King pretended the survey had never taken place. "Burger King chooses only the freshest, best-quality ingredients and is rightly famous for having the best-tasting flame-grilled burgers at great value for money," it insisted. This response emerged after a high-level pow-wow lasting several hours. We dismissed it as "generic and non-specific" after a low-level pow-wow lasting several seconds.

Sadly, the survey may have come too late for many of these romantic roadside eateries. They are virtually impossible to find in central London - Westminster council bans them and Camden only allows them on private land - and their natural habitat, the A road, has been eaten away by the growth of the motorway network.

Councils dislike them because, being mobile, they are hard to police, and the tradition of pottering along A roads has been undermined by the absurd notion that the whole point of travel is rapid transit from A to B. Bacon rolls eaten in laybys are part of a glorious vanished past.

Follow that van: some roadside favourites

Ilkley

The Rasta-run burger bar just outside Ilkley, West Yorkshire, in the first layby on the Addingham road. If not there, it is usually in the first layby after the Addingham roundabout. The speciality is Afro-Caribbean jerk chicken but there are plenty of burgers too.
MW

Bradford

The Canal Road burger bar, just by Dickenson's caravans is there most days, catering mostly for trucks (ample parking) and very busy on Bradford City home match days. Excellent burgers and fry-ups of all descriptions are served from a counter on a big trailer. Fantastic value.
MW

Glasgow

There's a van run by an old guy at the top of Lynedoch Street that's been there for donkey's years. From the outside, the dilapidated blue transit van does not inspire confidence. But one breakfast was all it took to convert me: two of the classic sausage and egg rolls with brown sauce and a cup of scalding hot strong tea - a reminder of what good Scottish cuisine should be about.
SM

Oxford

Most traffic hurtles past my favourite roadside fry-up stand at 70 or more, leaning into the sudden bend that rushes them up this last stretch of dual carriageway before the M40 and the big roundabout for the Oxford road. It has got the lot, this, underneath its hinged awning: eggs any way, sausage, old-fashioned burgers and builders' tea. There is camaraderie here that I would miss if it went: a kind of On The Road/full leather jacket feel you just do not get at the Little Chefs and Happy Eaters. It is a part of the fabric of an alternative English landscape, and I hope it stays.
JG

Leeds

There's a burger famine until September at Leeds University because building work has squeezed out the Uni Burger Van which always lurks outside the student union on gig nights. Regulars say its chips are worth waiting five months for. Meanwhile, try the van on Woodhouse Lane between Leeds Metropolitan University and the Drydock pub-in-a-barge.
MW

Cambridge

Its official title is Mister Burger, but the burger van run by husband and wife Nick and Angela in the centre of Market Square in Cambridge goes by many names. Depending on your opinion of the food it is also called The Van of Life, The Mobile Death Van or Not The One Run By The Armenians On The Other Side Of The Square. Staff focus on the personal touch, greeting customers by name and remembering their usual order. The culinary highlight is the Pound Burger Challenge, which involves trying to beat the speed-eating record of a monster burger made up of four quarter pound patties.
JC

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: I'm depressed by my miserable pedant of a husband - should I leave?
fields.trailText: I'm depressed by my miserable pedant of a husband - should I leave?
fields.body:
I can't decide whether to divorce. I'm 45, have been married 20 years and have children of 16,13 and five. I care for but don't love my husband - as he has aged he has become miserable and pedantic. He is an excellent father, loves me, is 100% supportive of my ideas and he thinks the marriage is good.

I want to meet someone I feel passionate about and give us both the chance for a new start. I've spent years dithering about whether to go. I'm nervous about being lonely, hard up, unable to cope and unable to find a new partner, and fear I'll regret leaving. He says he'd fight for custody. Neither of us could bear to lose the children. I feel guilty but the prospect of growing old with a man who irritates more than excites me fills me with depression.

Take a lover or two

No woman of 45 is still excited by her husband - we are all bored to death by them. However, how many exciting men do you suppose are waiting to meet you and your three lovely kids? My advice: take a lover or two. You would be surprised how much a miserable, pedantic, middle-aged man will tolerate when he stands to lose his live-in head cook and bottle-washer.
Maggie Swan, Cambridge

Don't chase dreams

You are tired, aren't you? Tired of three demanding children and an unexciting husband. Are you, however, really proposing to chicken out of helping these young people at very demanding moments of their lives: A-levels, subject choices, starting school?

I was 10 years older than you, but mildly menopausal (are you?) when I faced a similar decision. My husband of 30 years - intelligent, caring, trustworthy - was sexually inadequate and refused to consider counselling. I could not face causing devastation to our two adult children. I also decided that I had contributed so much to the partnership that I was entitled to some of the retirement benefits.

Don't chase dreams unless you are strong enough to endure possible failure, poverty and loneliness. Look what you and your husband have enjoyed doing together - or find new activities - and settle for a companionship which may prove very rewarding.
Name and address withheld

Try separation

To divorce or not is really not the question. To separate, to try life apart, including sorting out an equitable arrangement with the children, would seem to be the first step. Your situation mirrors my own 20 years ago. I did not do it this way but waited for the inevitable lover to turn up, thereby adding all the complications of a new relationship to the situation. The lover did not last; meantime I had given my then husband grounds for divorce and there were times when I was all the things you most dread.

You should negotiate a period of time away from your partner and stick to it - see how you get on.
Name and address withheld

Give him a chance

You don't seem to have given your husband a chance to understand your position. Tell him how you feel and give him a chance to resolve these problems. Relate could be helpful. If he is willing to work with you to save your marriage, allow at least six to 12 months before deciding to leave.

A close friend of mine was on the verge of leaving her husband when he found a letter revealing her dissatisfaction with him and an affair with a work colleague. Her husband was horrified and bewildered, but his discovery allowed them to address the issues which concerned her and led them, eventually, to a happy new life together. He often says that his wife's worst betrayal was her lack of openness.

If after counselling and time, you continue to feel the way you do now, you will be able to look your children in the eyes and tell them that you did everything you possibly could to save your marriage.
Anne Atkinson, Herts

Think of the family

My parents divorced when I was the age of your middle child, and my brother was two years younger. It was not an amicable split, and my parents did not support me through the process - we get on now but are not close. I was not emotionally mature enough to cope, and did not know how to find help. My brother and I are independent, we have all survived and rebuilt our lives. This year my mother is marrying a new partner she found later in life.

By no means are you confined to life with your husband. But you risk damaging your relationship with your children (and husband) if you choose to leave and they are not helped through the process. You may find it easier to go once your children are independent. In the meantime you could enjoy seeing them grow and find satisfaction in other parts of your life.

It comes down to a trade-off between short-term upheaval for all the family and the possibility of finding long-term happiness for yourself. It's a risk and only you know if it is worth it.
Name and address withheld

Next week

When our son died in a car accident his own son was only two months old. His wife remarried 18 months later and is pregnant. We have always had a good relationship and see a great deal of our two-and-a-half year old grandson but she wants her new husband to adopt him (he agrees). She says she'll talk to the boy about his father but would like her children to share the same surname. I've always supported her, even when she met someone else not so long after my son's death. She was young and had a right to rebuild her life. But this is a betrayal of his memory and a denial of his role in his son's life. My husband is as upset as I am.

We remember how happy and proud our son was at becoming a father and it feels as if he is being killed a second time.

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.headline: On Hotspur's trail
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland.
fields.body:
Restricted from moor and woodland, I took the opportunity to visit our wonderful medieval castles. This is Harry Hotspur's county, an all-time great hero whose battlefield courage is legendary. Unfortunately, he seems to have been a "Gazza" of the Middle Ages. Like our Geordie footballer, he was flawed by an impetuous temperament which sometimes made him take disastrous decisions. It was from Warkworth Castle that Harry set out on his last adventure.

Yesterday was a cold day, a bitter wind coming off the North Sea and ripping through the castle's arrow slits. Walls loomed above me, but in the castle entrance I could easily imagine huge fires blazing in the hearths, and minstrels playing on the raised stone dais where the Earl of Northumberland's table stood. This was where the family with two of everything lived. Two dining halls, two wine cellars, two kitchens and two castles.

Alnwick castle is only 8 miles north west from here, and another Percy stronghold. There were other smaller castles at Prudhoe and Langley, but the family preferred Warkworth. It was more easily defended and had access to the sea through the port of Amble.

In 1174, Warkworth was the scene of a massacre, with many locals who took refuge there being murdered by invading Scots. The river Coquet winds around two sides of the hill on which the castle stands and gulls, pigeons and curlew dipped and called. The castle is in the care of English Heritage and its custodian, Jeremy Coles, told me that a badger lived in the keep recently for five months before being evicted. A fox took up residence in the Montague tower and for the last 10 years, pied wagtails have nested safely in the well shaft.

fields.headline: Marcia Gay who?
fields.standfirst: She was the shock winner at Sunday's Oscars, beating Judi Dench, Frances McDormand and Kate Hudson. So where has Marcia Gay Harden been for the last 10 years?
fields.trailText: She was the shock winner at Sunday's Oscars, beating Judi Dench, Frances McDormand and Kate Hudson. So where has Marcia Gay Harden been for the last 10 years?
fields.body:
Marcia Gay Harden's boxy apartment, overlooking the ocean in Venice, California, looks like a dressing room on opening night. Four days after she being nominated as best supporting actress for her performance in the film Pollock - as Lee Krasner, artist wife of Jackson Pollock, the crazed American abstract expressionist painter who died in a car crash in 1956 - the phone never stops trilling. Every available surface is crowded with floral arrangements from producers, agents and industry honchos. The bowl of beautiful pink roses and lavender sweet peas is from Winona Ryder, whom Harden doesn't even know. Taped to the front door and over the mantel are full-colour trade-paper ads congratulating her.

In a few weeks' time, Harden will beat Kate Hudson, Judi Dench, Julie Walters and Frances McDormand to the Academy award. But at this stage, with the ceremony looming, she is preoccupied with the wall art. She gets up from her brown leather couch and begins pulling down the makeshift banners. "Thad? Honey?" Harden called out to Thaddaeus Scheel, her husband of six years. "I'm taking my shrine down."

Apparently, the presence of the altar has something to do with Harden's busy schedule. When she first heard the big news, she was by herself in a hotel room in Denver on a promotional tour for Pollock. With wet hair and clad in just a bathrobe, she managed to extract a hug from an impassive room service waitress bearing breakfast. Other than that, Harden hasn't had a real chance to celebrate. So Scheel put up the appropriate "Go Marcia!" decorations the night before and gave a party, not just for his wife but also for her many close neighbourhood friends, several of whom are seeing to it that everyone within 20 miles of their beach community knows that a potential Oscar winner is in their midst.

"One of my girlfriends here told me, 'Marcia Gay, every person I meet, I just have to tell them - the checkout girl, everybody!'" says Harden. Suddenly, her husky voice tightens and tears well in her brown eyes. "As you can probably tell, I'm feeling overly sentimental. There have been so many people from the past, from the present, who are calling, and it's as if they're celebrating a personal victory for themselves."

A quick look at 41-year-old Harden's filmography helps explain her elation. In 1990, her feature-film debut as a two-timing floozy in the Coen brothers' Prohibition-era gangster drama Miller's Crossing was so silkily confident and original, she seemed destined to land on top of the Hollywood A-list. Instead, she went on to a television movie called Kojak: None So Blind, did a lot of babysitting and found out how hard it is for people to separate buzz from reality. "Everyone thinks offers are always pouring in," she says. "Offers have never poured in. Never. I was auditioning a lot, but I didn't get the jobs. I had to pay off my school loans, you know?"

Since then, Harden's career trajectory has repeated the highs and lows of her first year. Often, you'll find her offering brief rays of light in mainstream duds like Desperate Measures and Meet Joe Black. Or she'll pop up in an indie gem like The Daytrippers and turn a five-minute cameo as a gin-gulping lonely heart into a highlight. Then, every couple of years, she'll play an ancillary character in a big-budget movie - like in Space Cowboys, where she was the flirty, tech-talking scientist who threw herself at Tommy Lee Jones's ageing astronaut - and all the depth and authenticity she can bring to a part is seen in all its glory.

It was an inspired bit of casting to put an actress as talented and underused as Harden in the role of the richly complex Lee Krasner, who was tough and opinionated but who always put the demands and needs of her tormented genius husband before her own. Asked to cite an early indication of a theatrical tendency, she thinks for a while, then recalls hamming it up for the neighbours when she and her three sisters and brother staged front-porch plays. "I was always an exhibitionist," Harden says. "I liked it when everyone laughed. But I didn't do plays in high school. I was too nervous."

She grew up in Japan, Greece, Germany and all over the United States, forever a new kid in a new town. "It was horribly embarrassing," Harden says. "My sisters and I wore out-of-date clothing and matching dresses. It was a very strict family, and we were very mindful of our parents' wishes. So what happens is you go to college and then all hell breaks loose."

At the time, Harden was studying acting as a graduate student, even though she had already done so at the University of Texas, had done years of summer stock and was rapidly approaching 30. "I was old to be in grad school," Harden says. "But I wanted to have resonance. I felt like I could get a reaction from an audience, but it didn't feel like anything I did came from deep inside of me."

Last December, Harden rode an elevator to the top of the World Trade Centre in New York, where she accepted a best supporting actress award for Pollock from the New York Film Critics Circle. "I loved it!" Harden says. In 1993, she received a Theatre World award for her performance in Angels in America, and her speech did not go according to plan. "I was thinking I'd thank people, that it'd be over in two minutes," she said. "But I was so profoundly moved, I started crying. I think it's because my journey has been so tough, you know?"

Seconds later, a nanny appears, carrying a child-shaped, blanket-wrapped bundle. Harden lifts the cloth and peeks in at her dozing three-year-old daughter. webTitle: Spike Lee's Bamboozled and the trade in Black Americana

fields.headline: Black market
fields.standfirst: Spike Lee's Bamboozled unearths degrading black caricatures such as the Jolly Nigger Bank - objects that are now collectors' items. But why are African-Americans the key buyers? By David D'Arcy
fields.trailText: Spike Lee's Bamboozled unearths degrading black caricatures such as the Jolly Nigger Bank - objects that are now collectors' items. But why are African-Americans the key buyers?
fields.body:
In Spike Lee's new media satire Bamboozled, Damon Wayans plays Pierre Delacroix, a television producer who creates a minstrel show that exploits racial stereotypes that were shamed off the stage decades before. As the ratings and the money roll in, Delacroix is haunted by a machine from the minstrel era, a late-19th-century "Jolly Nigger Bank", in the shape of a grinning black boy, whose metal arm swings backward to deposit a coin in his mouth. The audience may be more haunted by the minstrel show's central stage prop, a huge portal in the form of a thick-lipped, bug-eyed bellboy; performers in black-face enter from backstage through the gaping mouth.

Bamboozled's props are dramatic devices intended to shock, deployed to demonstrate Lee's point that African-Americans still suffer from the weight of these stereotypes. Yet these caricatures are hardly products of Lee's imagination. The bank was once a popular toy. The gaping-mouth door was the signature entrance to a chain of "family" restaurants in the Pacific Northwest - Coon-Chicken Inn, which flourished for three decades until the late 1950s. Degrading or not, toys like the Jolly Nigger Bank and Coon-Chicken Inn memorabilia (plates, menus, placemats, even straws) are being sought out by avid collectors, most of whom are African-American.

No one knows the full extent of the trade in what is termed Black Americana, but prices are soaring. Banished from the consumer market, these once-everyday objects are scarce. Gone is the general disdain for mammy cookie jars, Aunt Jemima dolls and pencils in the form of alligators eating black children - a motif used to promote the early tourist trade in Florida. During the Civil Rights movement, African-Americans felt these objects carried a painful stigma. Yet a decade after Martin Luther King was shot in Memphis in 1968, dealers say black Americans were already beginning to buy the objects that caricatured them.

The image of Aunt Jemima, the elephantine mammy figure whose image was emblazoned on a pancake mix, seems to be the most frequently reproduced icon. Paul Jeromack, an art critic and occasional dealer, has dozens of Aunt Jemima cookie jars and similarly themed salt- and pepper-shakers lined up in his storage room just a block from Central Park. Jeromack, who is white, is a minority in this collecting field. He remembers when prices were low. "In the early 1980s I found a cookie jar in a Madison Avenue gallery and paid the dealer 85 dollars !" His voice reaches a shriek as he recalls parting with so much money for a object considered just kitsch. "It was an insane price, and the dealer knew it," he says.

Today, cookie jars from the now-closed Abington Pottery works in Ohio can sell for $12,000 and rise to twice that. Terracotta-hued Aunt Jemima pitchers from Weller Pottery - Jeromack has at least 10 - can command $1,000 each.

Most of the "authentic" objects in this field are functional, rather than decorative. Besides pitchers modelled after Aunt Jemima, salt- and pepper-shakers show the full range of old degrading stereotypes. One common variant is the two-sides shakers, which show the lessons of life - on one side of the shakers, a husband and wife are a handsome, well-dressed bride and groom. On the other side, the groom is fat and disgruntled, and the wife is a shrew with a rolling pin. Often the pepper-shaker is a watermelon on the lap of a child ("piccaninny") which is the salt-shaker. Another version of the shakers has a young boy for pepper and a white toilet on which he sits for salt. Yet another common product is the mammy peg-board - a wall board with a picture of a mammy, hand to her head, announcing "I gots to Git" and the pegs indicating which groceries need to be bought.

These household objects "didn't really become a souvenir market until the late 20th century," according to Kenneth W Goings, a professor at Memphis University and author of Mammy and Uncle Mose: Black Collectibles and American Stereotyping. "When these first emerged, they were objects that you would use, like a pencil, a glass, or a plate. All these objects actually do something. And I believe that it's a way to symbolically own black people, to symbolically have black servants. I think that gave people who owned them a psychic boost, using these objects," says Goings, who is black and estimates that blacks now comprise between 70 and 80% of collectors.

At a recent visit to the Triple Pier Expo, a weekend market on three vast piers that extend from Manhattan into the Hudson River, an ebony art-deco carving of a slave in relief, reminiscent of the Dying Gaul, was attached by a gold chain to a pipe rack. The price was $275. Flannel and felt mammy dolls at a booth nearby were priced $900. Around the corner, George Darrow, a dealer specialising in antique toys, was selling a Jolly Nigger Bank, a statue of a newsboy and a wind-up celluloid and tin dancing figure attached to a sign with panels that read "125th Street/Lenox Avenue" - the historic crossroads of Harlem. "That came from occupied Japan, 1945," says Darrow. "It's very special." And, for what it was, very expensive, at $550.

Asked who collects these objects, Darrow winks: "People who have money." Most recently, those people with money have included Oprah Winfrey, Whoopi Goldberg, Bill Cosby, Michael Jackson and even the conservative US Supreme Court justice Clarence Thomas. Spike Lee himself has a collection, out of which he provided pieces for Bamboozled.

An urban legend holds, without evidence, that these black collectors buy up the racist Americana in order to destroy it. But it's beyond doubt that prominent black collectors do send buyers to rake through markets around the country. "They've got pickers," said Joe Canada, a dealer in Upper Marlborough, Maryland.

Kenneth Goings, who laments that he's priced out of the market now, discovered Black Americana when a friend's father gave him a pair of Aunt Jemima and Uncle Mose salt- and pepper-shakers as a gift. "Even though I was a historian already teaching African-American history, I never really even knew about the collectibles until I got that pair, and a smoke screen lifted off my eyes. I began to see them everywhere."

The memorabilia had indeed been everywhere, reaching its height between the 1880s - the end of the post-Civil War Reconstruction era, when Union troops withdrew from the South - and the outbreak of the second world war. In these decades, the image of the bumbling or cheerful or fearful or lazy "negro" was used to sell a wide variety of products in the United States. Cigarettes, soap, shoe polish, Uncle Ben's rice and "Cream of Wheat" cereal used clownish black characters and "black" grammar in their advertising. Gold Dust Twins Washing Powder featured two "piccaninnies", arm in arm, on its box. Sheet music for jazz and blues music was published with illustrations of characters much like those who perform in Bamboozled. As late as 1989, Colgate-Palmolive was producing a toothpaste for sale in Asia called "Darkie", which bore the image of a smiling black man. Under pressure, the firm changed the name to "Darlie" and the racial characteristics of the man on the box were made ambiguous. "The buying started in the late 1970s. In the 1980s, it picked up; in the 1990s it caught fire, and now it's out of hand," says Joe Canada.

The publicity about the collectibles, which came about, in part, because celebrities were buying them, gave a new generation the knowledge that these objects existed, says Kenneth Goings. "After that, some African-Americans began collecting them as object lessons for their sons and daughters. They wanted to be able to demonstrate to them how previous generations of African-Americans have been treated."

"They also want to own a part of their own history - anything depicting people of African descent," said Larry Vincent Buster, author of the newly published Art and History of Black Memorabilia.

Goings agrees. "If you look around, there just aren't a lot of objects addressed to African-Americans to start with, in terms of decorative arts. So the black middle class is looking for these objects. A lot of people decorate their homes with them. I can hardly believe that they do. The cookie jars are very, very popular, and like all the members of the middle classes with disposable income, some African-Americans are just into collecting," adds Goings. "A lot of African-Americans are buying reproductions, although they think they're buying originals. They're being bamboozled, they really are." He cites the internet as a prime source of such bamboozling.

A click on to eBay, the online auction site, shows the range available. Bidding on a mammy memo-holder, a large board with a picture of a mammy holding a pencil, with a memo-pad apron, had risen to $14. Bidding for a wooden dancing figure from the 1940s was starting at $20. A late 19th-century card depicting a black woman washing clothes in an ad for laundry soap was at $515.

"The internet is keeping prices down now," said George Darrow. "You used to have to wait to trip into a barn and knock over a box and find a nice piece. Now you just go online and start hacking."

So far, concerns about reproductions creeping on to the collectibles market seem greater than any worries about the reintroduction of objects that resurrect old, despised stereotypes. Officially, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People - one of the country's oldest black organisations - has criticised the trade in racist memorabilia. Calls to the NAACP's headquarters in Baltimore failed to get a response about the group's current policy.

Bamboozled ends with a credit sequence in which the names of those credited for working on the film are flashed, first over footage caricaturing blacks and then over close-ups of Black Americana. Like it or not, Lee seems to be saying, the objects are part of history. Denying or destroying them would be pointless, says the acerbic African-American cultural critic Stanley Crouch, who wants to preserve all historic depictions of blacks. "The memorabilia gives you a much better understanding of how one set of images of black people was constantly reinforced - the lazy sleeping darkie, the eternal laughter, and on and on."

Crouch has other candidates for the scrapheap in mind. "I hope they collect all these rap-music videos and destroy them. These are much more degrading images of black people than any of this other stuff, especially because the videos are made by black people who claim they're the real 'us'. The rappers are the minstrels of today, and nobody seems to be worried about that. That's where Spike Lee copped out in his movie."

 Bamboozled is released on April 6.
