I began to see them everywhere." The memorabilia had indeed been everywhere, reaching its height between the 1880s - the end of the post-Civil War Reconstruction era, when Union troops withdrew from the South - and the outbreak of the second world war. In these decades, the image of the bumbling or cheerful or fearful or lazy "negro" was used to sell a wide variety of products in the United States. Cigarettes, soap, shoe polish, Uncle Ben's rice and "Cream of Wheat" cereal used clownish black characters and "black" grammar in their advertising. Gold Dust Twins Washing Powder featured two "piccaninnies", arm in arm, on its box. Sheet music for jazz and blues music was published with illustrations of characters much like those who perform in Bamboozled. As late as 1989, Colgate-Palmolive was producing a toothpaste for sale in Asia called "Darkie", which bore the image of a smiling black man. Under pressure, the firm changed the name to "Darlie" and the racial characteristics of the man on the box were made ambiguous. "The buying started in the late 1970s. In the 1980s, it picked up; in the 1990s it caught fire, and now it's out of hand," says Joe Canada. The publicity about the collectibles, which came about, in part, because celebrities were buying them, gave a new generation the knowledge that these objects existed, says Kenneth Goings. "After that, some African-Americans began collecting them as object lessons for their sons and daughters. They wanted to be able to demonstrate to them how previous generations of African-Americans have been treated." "They also want to own a part of their own history - anything depicting people of African descent," said Larry Vincent Buster, author of the newly published Art and History of Black Memorabilia. Goings agrees. "If you look around, there just aren't a lot of objects addressed to African-Americans to start with, in terms of decorative arts. So the black middle class is looking for these objects. A lot of people decorate their homes with them. I can hardly believe that they do. The cookie jars are very, very popular, and like all the members of the middle classes with disposable income, some African-Americans are just into collecting," adds Goings. "A lot of African-Americans are buying reproductions, although they think they're buying originals. They're being bamboozled, they really are." He cites the internet as a prime source of such bamboozling. A click on to eBay, the online auction site, shows the range available. Bidding on a mammy memo-holder, a large board with a picture of a mammy holding a pencil, with a memo-pad apron, had risen to $14. Bidding for a wooden dancing figure from the 1940s was starting at $20. A late 19th-century card depicting a black woman washing clothes in an ad for laundry soap was at $515. "The internet is keeping prices down now," said George Darrow. "You used to have to wait to trip into a barn and knock over a box and find a nice piece. Now you just go online and start hacking." So far, concerns about reproductions creeping on to the collectibles market seem greater than any worries about the reintroduction of objects that resurrect old, despised stereotypes. Officially, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People - one of the country's oldest black organisations - has criticised the trade in racist memorabilia. Calls to the NAACP's headquarters in Baltimore failed to get a response about the group's current policy. Bamboozled ends with a credit sequence in which the names of those credited for working on the film are flashed, first over footage caricaturing blacks and then over close-ups of Black Americana. Like it or not, Lee seems to be saying, the objects are part of history. Denying or destroying them would be pointless, says the acerbic African-American cultural critic Stanley Crouch, who wants to preserve all historic depictions of blacks. "The memorabilia gives you a much better understanding of how one set of images of black people was constantly reinforced - the lazy sleeping darkie, the eternal laughter, and on and on." Crouch has other candidates for the scrapheap in mind. "I hope they collect all these rap-music videos and destroy them. These are much more degrading images of black people than any of this other stuff, especially because the videos are made by black people who claim they're the real 'us'. The rappers are the minstrels of today, and nobody seems to be worried about that. That's where Spike Lee copped out in his movie."  Bamboozled is released on April 6.

fields.headline: Rude law
fields.standfirst: Erin Brockovich was oscar nominated and won, but its real life characters aren't having such a smooth ride.
fields.trailText: Erin Brockovich was oscar nominated and won, but its real life characters aren't having such a smooth ride.
fields.body:
One nominee who didn't show up on Sunday night was Albert Finney, nominated for his supporting role as Erin Brockovich's real-life boss, Ed Masry. But Masry did don his tuxedo for the ceremony despite an unflattering item in the LA Times that morning. The real people behind Erin Brockovich have made several headlines since the movie's release. Brockovich and Masry were blackmailed last year by Brockovich's ex-husband and ex-boyfriend, who allegedly threatened to expose the pair's supposed sexual relationship. Lesson one: never blackmail a lawyer. Masry tape-recorded the pair's demands and their trial is currently under way.

The Times's Masry story looked into how the 68-year-old attorney is doing in his new role as a city councilman for the San Fernando Valley suburb of Thousand Oaks, a position he won decisively last November. Masry's popularity with the voters isn't shared by his fellow politicians, one of whom said, "Ed Masry... you're no Albert Finney." "He's a disaster," said Alex Fiore, a 30-year former councilman now considered mayor emeritus. "He's dense, has no understanding of how government matters are handled, and he's crude. He should resign." Masry called city attorney Mark Sellers a "deaf-mute" and said cross-examining him was like dealing with Charles Manson. His penchant for melodrama is trying his peers' patience. "This cloak-and-dagger stuff, if it weren't serious, would be humorous," muttered one.

No one doubts that Masry is a brilliant trial lawyer, and he puts in steady hours at council meetings, despite three sessions of kidney dialysis a week. "If people don't like what I'm saying, I really don't care. No one has ever called me more names than Erin Brockovich [so] I've been called the worst by the best, but at the end of the day I can still go have a beer with them." Steady on there, dialysis-boy.

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: Depp, dope and a drug war

fields.headline: Depp, dope and a drug war
fields.standfirst: Traffic's Oscar says something tragic and pathetic about Washington's war on drugs
fields.trailText: Traffic's Oscar says something tragic and pathetic about Washington's war on drugs
fields.body:
I 'm glad Steven Soderbergh got his Oscar for Traffic and that he kept his speech short and didn't pontificate about drugs to his huge captive audience. Still, somewhere in the applause, you could sense Hollywood puffing up its collective chest and proudly thinking that here was a movie that would make a difference, that addressed the fate of the nation's children.

Perhaps it did make a difference. Traffic's marketing blitz took on some characteristics of a public-awareness campaign once the buzz- furnace had reached a sufficient temperature. It was discussed on the political chatshows, covered on the news pages as often as in the movie section, and generally treated as the serious-minded film it is. The marketing included great slabs of earnest prose extolling the film's "courage" and "urgency". Screenwriter Steve Gaghan came clean about his days on the needle and the cast members, in interviews, always looked very serious indeed, as if they'd mistakenly wandered from MTV into Meet the Press.

The fact that Traffic's sensible, uncontroversial view of drugs was greeted in political circles as something novel, even daring, says something tragic and pathetic about the sterile, intellectual monoculture underpinning Washington's war on drugs. This extends downwards from the national drug tsar through police and quasi-military forces into the workplace and schools via random drug- testing, through a judiciary loaded down with mandatory drug-sentencing guidelines, and into a penal system long bloated with non-violent drug offenders. Like prohibition, the solution may have depraved more people and institutions than the problem ever did.

Awareness and imagination work at a glacial pace throughout this huge bureaucracy, which needs nightmare scenarios about drugs - and evil, smelly foreigners importing them - in order to justify their continued existence and funding. (Can you imagine the DEA just disbanding itself quietly?) The mindset is fraught with fantasy and paranoia, with jingoistic scapegoating and displaced racial animosity, and the conduct of the war on drugs often exhibits the irrationality and rabid singlemindedness of a crusade.

At the very least, Traffic should be thanked for trying to shift the debate from the foreign to the domestic sphere, and suggesting that huge domestic demand is as big a problem as foreign suppliers.

While Traffic is making its serious contribution to the debate, Johnny Depp's new movie Blow, directed by Ted Demme, makes the case for drugs as one of America's favourite national pastimes, a proxy national dish for the questing, pioneering American head.

Like Traffic, it looks at the drug business from top to bottom, this time through the rise, one rung at a time, of George Jung, a trailblazing real-life drug smuggler of the 1960s and 70s. A smalltown boy from Massachusetts, Jung moved to southern California in the late 60s, developed a taste for marijuana, and through his stewardess girlfriend (Run Lola Run's Franka Potente) started smuggling large quantities to the pot-starved east coast. After a while, he cuts out his middleman, finds a Mexican supplier and buys his own plane to take it across the border.

Like Howard Marks, Jung was in at the dawn of the modern drug trade, working with friends and without guns at a time when methods were comparatively primitive and sentences relatively light. Unlike Marks, he moved from benign marijuana to soul-stealing cocaine at a time when people simply didn't yet know what would happen if you shoved it up your snout for years on end. The film manages to capture what it must have felt like to be young and successful in a business that, briefly, seemed more like a public service than a crime.

Hollywood's more baroque stylists are powerfully drawn to drugs as a subject-matter; think of GoodFellas, Boogie Nights or the Hughes brothers' Menace II Society. Demme, hitherto a fairly restrained director, has here busted loose and done what half the male film-makers in the world wish they could do. He has made a movie that combines the excess of Boogie Nights with the energy of the "last day" sequence in GoodFellas, two movies without which Blow couldn't exist.

He even hired Boogie Nights' costume designer and his swaggering cinematic style is heavily indebted to Scorsese's frenzied construction of that exhilarating finale. None of which detracts from Blow's ability to entertain, but the scale of the debt undermines Demme's achievement considerably. Thankfully, like most intelligent modern drug movies - from Drugstore Cowboy and Trainspotting to Jesus' Son - the film doesn't preach. The drugs are there: we have to make up our own minds about them. The war on drugs renta-mouths claim that this amounts to encouraging, even glamourising drugs. It doesn't - it just means audiences are smarter than they think we are.

fields.headline: Thank heavens for little girls
fields.trailText: Little Women
fields.body:
Pop songs are signposts to the landmarks of your youth. The first single you ever bought, the song that accompanied your first slow dance at a disco, the music that served as a prelude to losing your virginity: everyone's life has a soundtrack. Take it from someone who can't hear Johnny Hates Jazz's "You've given me, given me/Nothing but shattered dreams, shattered dreams" without shuddering at the thought of a particularly traumatic school disco. (Thankfully, Johnny Hates Jazz don't get much airplay these days, even on radio stations with "gold" in their names).

Indeed, if songs weren't so evocative, there would be nothing on BBC2 and Channel 4 on a Saturday night, no Nostalgia TV and remembrance of times past.

Now, as a grown-up, I should be of the opinion that music isn't what it used to be, real singers sang real songs back then and today's pop is pap. I should be disdainful of today's youngsters mapping out their existence to Britney Spears and S Club 7. Of course, I'm not. But more of that later.

As the exceptional documentary Little Women (BBC2) followed a group of 7 to 12-year-old girls around while they applied glittery make-up, shopped for glittery tops and attempted to replicate the dance moves of popstars in similarly glittery make-up and glittery tops, it examined not just its subject - the media-savvy, choosy and powerful consumers who make up the demographic known as tweenagers - but a change in the whole of society.

You could just about guess the ages of Georgia and Leigh, Lauren and Kayleigh, Alex and Jade from their names (it was a bit of a surprise not to find a Kylie among them), but their exploits, attitudes and demeanour were quite misleading, and not to say a bit shocking - presuming you don't know any 10-year-old girls in real life. The girls in Little Women bought clothes in Harrods, watched WWF wrestling on Sky Sports and attended a birthday party at which they demonstrated their duplicated dance moves. One said she was going for a "biker babe" look as she donned her leather jacket, another showed off a poster of Luke from Hollyoaks and explained casually how he had been raped, while a third showed the camera her boob tube saying "It's only fashion, innit." Out of the mouths of babes.

From a younger and younger age, these girls are being groomed as consumers and, through the likes of Britney, are being fed images to nurture their neuroses and thus their penchant for shopping. Puberty may be impinging on their lives earlier but there is little doubt how much the market is to blame in the ageing of these girls. Resistance to the notion of one's children growing up may be futile, but it nonetheless leaves a sour taste that seven-year-old girls are being sexualised for the benefit of some multi-national cosmetics company.

As much as Little Women raised that spectre, it also inadvertently illustrated another fundamental cultural shift. It showed that youth is no longer wasted on the young. As the girls followed S Club 7's prompting and reached for the stars, or discussed make-up and boys, the realisation dawned that in 10 or 20 years time, they will be doing exactly the same thing, albeit clasping a Bacardi Breezer instead of a McDonalds milkshake. (Come to think of it, they probably drink diet Coke.) And the reason I can't ridicule S Club7 is that they are as much one of my cultural references as they are 11-year-old Lauren's.

The explosive growth in pop culture has caused a collapse in the differentiation between kid and adult realms of interest. I know 13-year-olds and 45-year-olds who watch Buffy The Vampire Slayer with the same feverish dedication. When Alex says, "Chocolate and clothes make me happy", she sounds v Bridget Jones. She is 10 years old.

If we're not tweenagers, many of us are kidults. And as kidults, we have the disposable income to indulge childish whims, be they scooters, body glitter or video box sets. Like Kayleigh and friends, we are the perfect consumers. It's all very postmodern.

Little Women also co-opted some adult talking heads, including parents, psychologists and the editor of Cosmo Girl. Their contributions were interesting enough, but Little Women was at its best when it simply documented these tweenagers' lives. Do you know what it feels like for a girl?

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: You say it best when you say nothing at all
fields.trailText: Paul Weller's Vinyl Classics | Crossing Continents
fields.body:
Despite the title of the new series Paul Weller's Vinyl Classics (Radio 2), you half expect his dad to be presenting. So notoriously unseeking of public attention is Weller that he has in the past sent Pops to collect awards on his behalf. But Weller Jr it is, barely, linking life-affirming jazz, soul and R'n'B tunes from his mammoth vinyl collection.

Taking a letting-the-music-do-the-talking approach to this presenting malarkey, Weller sounds a bit grumpy to be talking at all. "Those screams at the end say it all for me, really", he murmurs after a Wilson Pickett tune, as if he wishes they could.

There's no doubt about Weller's passion for the music, though. It might be hard to imagine him "jumping round the living room" to these tunes as he says he does, but he does reveal his love affair with vinyl in other, quietly endearing ways. He alliteratively embellishes his favourites - "the wicked Wilson Pickett", "the mighty Curtis Mayfield" - and finds himself in a relative flood of words mid-anecdote. Mayfield, "like a little Buddha" when Weller met him, was "one of the few people who when he said 'Peace and Love' to you, actually meant it."

But best of all, and Weller knows this, are the tunes themselves, short slivers of emotion with titles such as What My Baby Needs Now Is A Little More Lovin', We Must Be In Love and Let's Do It Again. They suggest a world in which love can repair all, where Gs can be left off of the end of words; a world, frankly, that is nothing nastier than a great big onion.

Across the miles and decades, in contemporary South Africa, more intractable problems present themselves. In Crossing Continents (Radio 4), Tim Whewell packed three strong stories into 30 minutes, looking at inter-racial adoption, and new no-frills banks for the majority of South Africans not served by traditional ones.

Whewell visited new mixed-race comedy clubs, too, talking to comedians confronting stereotypes in the belief that a nation that can laugh together can live together. You could hear comedy creaking under the pressure to do good, to heal rather than divide as jokes tend to. An exception was Marc Lottering and his act based on life in the Cape Flats shantytowns. Commonalities rather than differences are his target and that means doilies (yes, doilies).

Whewell goes to meet the Doily Queen, Lottering's mother, who fills her humble home with these universal symbols of suburban respectability. One is so big, "we had no choice but to call it The Doil", says Lottering in his act. "It's a massive piece of crochet-work," Whewell gasps, with an audible enthusiasm Paul Weller could learn from.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Jimmy Young | Johnny Walker | Ramblings With Clare Balding | The Arrangers
fields.body:
Radio 2 wraps up its Working Wise campaign with two final sessions. Sarah Veal, who works for the TUC as its senior employment rights officer, joins Jimmy Young (12noon, Radio 2) to talk about the complications surrounding the rights of part-time workers. She also discusses wrongful dismissals, redundancy, and holidays. Later, the occupational psychologist Dr Sandi Mann talks to Johnny Walker (5.0pm, Radio 2) about coping with office politics and the boss.

The foot-and-mouth crisis has attacked Broadcasting House, stopping at least one presenter in her tracks. Ramblings With Clare Balding (3.0pm, Radio 4) has been hurriedly transferred from its usual habitat to the relatively safe urban acreage of Wimbledon Common. Fortunately the nature trail there has been designed with a hard-surfaced path for townies. Moreover, the creatures in the common's 900 acres of special scientific interest are guaranteed virus-free, mainly 80-odd bird varieties and an abundance of harmless invertebrates.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Ice Cold In Alex | The Big Lebowski | Live Football
fields.body:
Films

Ice Cold In Alex
(J Lee-Thompson, 1958)
9am, Carlton

Doughty John Mills leads the way across the desert in enemy-occupied North Africa: he and Sergeant Harry Andrews are escorting nurses Sylvia Sims and Diane Clare to Alexandria. The main hazards - apart from Rommel - are the heat, the sand, the ambulance's temperamental engine and shifty South African Anthony Quayle. But the hardy bunch will go through a lot for a cold beer.

The Big Lebowski
(Joel Coen, 1998)
10pm, FilmFour

A wonderful, wacky Coen brothers comedy that filters a noir plot - complete with kidnap, mistaken identity, greed, a severed toe - through the confused consciousness of hippy throwback the Dude (Jeff Bridges), aka Lebowski. Helping him navigate the dangerous world of his rich, objectionable namesake (played by David Huddleston), when he'd rather be smoking weed and going bowling, is the hilarious double act of John Goodman's cracked Viet vet Walter and Steve Buscemi's dopey Donny: but stealing the show is John Turturro's stunning cameo as Jesus, the lilac-clad bowler.

Christine
(John Carpenter, 1983)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Christine is a gleaming, red-and-white 1958 Plymouth Fury, possessed of a malignant spirit: Herbie with attitude. In Carpenter's vivid recreation of the Stephen King story, the car disposes of young owner Keith Gordon's enemies, revving up for a final demolition derby against an earth-mover; and all to a neat selection of 50s rock'n'roll on Christine's radio.

Armageddon
(Michael Bay, 1998)
10.20pm, Sky Premier

Doomsday scenario: an asteroid the size of Texas is headed for earth: send for top driller Bruce Willis and his bunch of lovable roughnecks to save the day. Among them Ben Affleck, in love with Brucie's daughter, Liv Tyler. They may be the wrong stuff, but Nasa man Billy Bob Thornton has them make like astronauts, land on the rock and bore nuclear-bomb holes into it. Awesome effects, incredibly loud (EVERYONE SHOUTS. ALL THE TIME), presided over by Willis, playing it so straight he must be kidding. Isn't he?

The Driver
(Walter Hill, 1978)
10.45pm, The Studio

They don't have names: Ryan O'Neal is the (getaway) Driver, Bruce Dern the Detective, and the one is after the other. That conceit and the sparse dialogue add existential tones to Hill's revved-up thriller. The whole point of it is the series of shrieking car chases, brilliantly executed; however, seven years on from The French Connection, the thrill of the chase was wearing a bit thin.

Sports

Live Football
7pm, Sky Sports

2 It's top against bottom in the First Division as Tranmere Rovers, still reeling from the resignation of their manager John Aldridge, host Premiership-bound Fulham. Whatever the league table says, Tranmere have proved they can cause an upset and Fulham have wobbled on occasion this season, including a defeat at Tranmere's relegation rivals Stockport.

fields.headline: Darrell Posey
fields.standfirst: Anthropologist who championed the rights of Amazonian tribes
fields.trailText: When the anthropologist Darrell Posey, who has died of a brain tumour aged 53, was offered the opportunity to do field work for his PhD with the Kayapo tribe, in the Brazilian Amazon, he jumped at the chance.
fields.body:
In 1977, when the anthropologist Darrell Posey, who has died of a brain tumour aged 53, was offered the opportunity to do field work for his PhD with the Kayapo tribe in Para, in the Brazilian Amazon, he jumped at the chance.

In the village of Gorotire, he found a people with a vast knowledge of their forest and savannah environment, based on the complex relationships between plants, animals, people and the soil. It was an ancient tribal culture of exuberance and complexity, with rituals linked to the forest and the cosmos. But it was also a culture under threat - from logging, dams and the queimadas, the vast infernos used to clear forests for conversion into cattle ranches.

Darrell realised that, while still an academic, he could not stand by and watch this world being destroyed. He felt compelled to participate in the Kayapo's battles to protect their rainforest home.

In one instance, the Gorotire Kayapo acquired a share in a gold mine, and were suddenly in a position to acquire a plane, trucks and a diesel generator. But Darrell was closest to the village traditionalists, the shamans Beptopup and Kuruka, who had taught him Kayapo cosmology, forest management and the use of medicinal plants. He had a deep reverence for these two men, who, he said, taught him more than anybody ever did at university.

In 1987, Darrell made his most audacious move, taking two young Kayapo chiefs to the World Bank in Washington to campaign against a series of hydro-electric dams that would flood their land. The visit became headline news. The Brazilian government was not amused, and, on their return, detained all three. But Darrell was only slightly shaken, and continued investigating whether tribes like the Kayapo could make more efficient use of rainforests than modern cattle ranchers.

The research concluded that the Kayapo enriched, rather than impoverished, their rainforest habitat by introducing food plants and fruit trees into their forest gardens. He and his co-researchers concluded that some of the great plant variety of the Amazon rainforests was, in fact, put in place by the Amazonian tribes.

Born on a farm in Kentucky, Darrell studied at Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, taking a BSc in entomology and agriculture, and later a master's degree in geography and anthropology. His PhD was awarded in 1979 from the University of Georgia.

Despite his academic credentials, he was sometimes criticised by colleagues who frowned on his involvement with the people he was meant to be studying as a detached observer.

Ethno-ecology, the study of the knowledge and traditions of tribal societies in relation to the environment, was, at the time, a new research focus; and academics still find it hard to cope with the idea that tribal people can teach us much about some of the world's most diverse environments, and more specifically, about their food and medicinal plants.

In contrast to this approach, Darrell argued that Brazil's strategy for developing the Amazon - primarily by removing the forests wholesale - was one of extraordinary folly.

During his years in Brazil, he was largely based at the Amazon research centre at Museo Goldi, Belem, where he continued his ethno-ecological work. In 1989, he founded the International Society for Ethnobiology, which has grown into a major international forum for both indigenous peoples and academics. Its aim is to enable tribal cultures from across over the world to draw attention to their ecological knowledge, and to ensure that this knowledge is protected by intellectual property rights agreements.

Darrell played a central role in having these perspectives included in the Biodiversity Convention, agreed at the 1992 Rio summit. There, he also instigated the Earth Parliament, bringing together tribal peoples from all over the world to speak about their plight and the significance of their cultures.

After Rio, Darrell made his home in Oxford, as an associate fellow at Linacre College, and research associate at the Oxford Forestry Institute. His most important work was as director of the programme for traditional resource rights at the Oxford Centre for Environment, Ethics and Society, at Mansfield College. But his time there was not easy, and his views were often felt to be a threat by other academics more concerned about their own professional advancement than scientific innovation.

Darrell Posey was a truly great man. Many have been influenced by his conference lectures, some 150 papers and the 10 books he wrote and edited. He won a United Nations Global 500 Award for Outstanding Environmental Achievements in 1993, and the US Sierra Club Chico Mendes Award for Extraordinary Courage in the Defence of Nature in 1989. His most recent book, Cultural And Spiritual Values Of Biodiversity, edited for the UN Environment Programme in 1999, is testimony to the extraordinary breadth of his interests and his contacts. He also completed a collection of his writings, which will be published soon. Sadly, his autobiography remained unfinished.

Darrell was such great fun, too. I will always recall his ringing laughter, enjoying his own (very good) jokes, and those of others. Even in dark moments, he could come up with wonderfully zany anecdotes. He was never self-important, yet he knew about the importance of his work.

He is survived by his parents and a brother.

 Darrell Addison Posey, anthropologist, born March 14 1947; died March 6 2001

fields.headline: Sir Kenneth Alexander
fields.standfirst: Economist whose dynamism enriched Scotland's academic, industrial and cultural life
fields.trailText: Economist whose dynamism enriched Scotland's academic, industrial and cultural life.
fields.body:
With the death of the economist Sir Kenneth Alexander at the age of 79, Scotland has lost one of its modern heroes; his contribution to its academic, business and cultural life went far beyond his daunting list of chancellorships, directorships and chairmanships.

One of the many robust academics who left the Communist party after the Hungarian uprising of 1956, he became a pillar of the Scottish establishment, without ever acting as though he thought he had risen. His appointments often looked like poisoned chalices, but so surefooted was he that he left every organisation in better shape than he found it in.

Born in Edinburgh, Alexander was a scholarship boy at George Heriot's school and, after second world war service in the RAF, attended the Bonar School of Economics in Dundee, where he was the first economics student to get first-class honours in the London University external examinations (1949).

Research at Leeds University (1949-51), and lectureships at Sheffield (1951-56) and Aberdeen (1957-62), led, in 1963, to the chair of economics at Strathclyde and the chance to establish, from scratch, a department in a brand new faculty.

In his inaugural lecture, Alexander likened his fellow economists to "drunk men staggering from one static equilibrium to another"; his own path was to set up the first economics degree in Scotland based on mathematics and the modelling of continuous processes. He was no ivory-tower scholar, and used to advise young members of staff that the important thing was not to get it "right" but to get it "wrote".

In line with this practical approach, he believed in close links with industry, so, when the industrialist Ian Stewart suggested a bold experiment, Alexander was ready. By 1966, the Fairfields shipyard in Govan was in dire straits. To bring the sit-in led by Jimmy Reid to a close, Stewart and Alexander got the workers to give up restrictive practices in return for guaranteed employment. Though there was a certain amount of cheating, Fairfields survived; indeed, of the 30 yards once on the Clyde, it is one of the tiny handful still in operation.

Thus Alexander became a director of Fairfields (1966- 68) and of Upper Clyde Shipbuilders (1968-71), and chairman of Govan Shipbuilders (1974-76). The experience bore fruit in his books The Economist In Business (1967), Productivity Bargaining And The Reform Of Industrial Relations (1969), and, with CL Jenkins, Fairfields: A Study Of Industrial Change (1971).

He took on another tough task as chairman of the Highlands and Islands Development Board (1976-80), a body not expected to survive Thatcherism. But it is still there, and the highlands have even developed some momentum.

When Alexander moved to Stirling University as principal and vice-chancellor (1981-86), it was reeling from the notorious foul-mouthing of the Queen Mother by some drunken students - and was everyone's favourite to fall victim to the surplus of university places. But under him, it recruited the Wang computer company, and grabbed a distinctive role in new subjects and approaches to education. It has gone from strength to strength.

From 1986-96, Alexander was chancellor of Aberdeen University, where, in its quincentenary year, he saw the realisation of his long-held dream, the foundation of the Elphinstone Institute for the study of the culture of the north-east of Scotland.

His one notable defeat came in 1990. When British Steel threatened to close the remains of the Scottish steel industry, he was put forward as a potential workers' director. His platform was that he would go along with closure as Ravenscraig if the accounts confirmed that it was making a loss. But, at the AGM, the redoubtable Sir Robert Scholey saw him off; despite waving hard, Alexander was unable to catch the chairman's eye, and was thus unable to deny the charge that he was a wrecker come to save the Scottish steel industry at any cost.

His directorships included Scottish Television and the Stakis Organisation, and he held a wide array of public-sector posts. He was particularly proud of the Alexander Report (1973), the guiding light for community learning in Scotland, which marked the culmination of his three years as chairman of the Committee on Adult Education in Scotland. In the cultural field, he was chairman of the Edinburgh Book Festival (1987-91), and piloted the Scottish National Dictionary Association safely into the electronic age.

As a teacher, he was still receiving manuscripts from students 40 years after they graduated, and as a man, he was utterly lacking in pomposity. He could light up a room with his presence, had a tune composed in his honour by the legendary accordionist Jimmy Shand, and was proud of following the distinguished literary academic David Daiches, poet Norman McCaig and composer and ethnologist Hamish Henderson as the fourth life member of the Scottish Malt Whisky Society.

He is survived by his wife Angela, whom he married in 1949, a son and four daughters.

fields.headline: Glenn Hughes
fields.trailText: Glenn Hughes, who has died of lung cancer aged 50, was a member of the Village People, whose camp innuendo and humour made them one of the most popular disco groups of the 1970s.
fields.body:
Glenn Hughes, who has died of lung cancer aged 50, was a member of the Village People, whose camp innuendo and humour made them one of the most popular disco groups of the 1970s.

A native New Yorker, he was working as a toll collector at the Brooklyn tunnel when he answered an advertisement seeking "gay singers and dancers, very good-looking and with moustaches". The group - its name a reference to Greenwich Village - was formed by French record producers Jacques Morali and Henri Belolo. They put together a male sextet dressed in the styles then in vogue in New York gay clubs - the cowboy, red Indian, policeman, biker, builder and GI.

Hughes became the leather-clad biker, with a luxuriant walrus moustache and hairy chest criss-crossed with chains. Under Morali's tutelage, the sextet worked out dance routines to accompany lead singer Victor Willis.

Neil Bogart's disco label, Casablanca, released the Village People's first record, San Francisco (You Got Me) in 1977, followed by the million-selling Macho Man. Their first international hit - and British number one - was YMCA, whose lyrics brought protests from the Young Men's Christian Association, but appealed to an audience for whom the group were "gay goofs to those who got the joke, and disco novelties to those who didn't", according to Rolling Stone magazine.

They donned nautical outfits for their next hit, In The Navy, whose exhortations to young men to go to sea led the US navy to consider its use in a recruitment campaign. The group's final big hit was Go West, further homage to San Francisco and its reputation as the US gay capital.

As the disco boom faded, the Village People made a film appearance in Nancy Walker's Can't Stop The Music (1980). Poorly received at the time, it has since achieved cult status. Willis was replaced by Ray Simpson, and the group briefly switched image to record the album Renaissance and pose as British-style new romantics, complete with satin jackets and heavy eye make-up. This made little impact, however, and Morali returned to camp innuendo with the song Sex Over The Phone, which became a 1985 British hit.

The group split from Morali in 1988, forming their own management company, Sixuvus. Subsequently, they capitalised on their image through international tours and an unexpected popularity among sports fans. They recorded Far Away In America with the German world cup football squad in 1994, and later provided the half-time entertainment for the rugby grand finals in Australia.

Hughes retired in 1995, but remained a partner in Sixuvus. He made a final recording with the Village People as a featured singer on Gunbalanya, a song inspired by the group's meetings with native Australian tribes. His final request was to be buried in his leather stage outfit.

fields.headline: Leonardo may make £3.5m
fields.trailText: An early Leonardo da Vinci masterpiece, which gives the first inkling of his lifelong obsession with making massive equine statues, could make £3.5m when it goes on sale in London in the summer.
fields.body:
An early Leonardo da Vinci masterpiece, which gives the first inkling of his lifelong obsession with making massive equine statues, could make £3.5m when it goes on sale in London in the summer.

The silverpoint drawing Horse and Rider, a preparatory study for his first great composition, the unfinished panel, Adoration of the Magi, is the most important work by the renaissance genius still in private hands. It is being sold by the American connoisseur, J Carter Brown, a former director of the US National Gallery in Washington.

Leonardo spent a large part of his life attempting to surpass the large-scale equine statues built by the Romans and Greeks. His failure to realise this ambition was one of his major disappointments.

Noel Annesley, of Christie's, who will auction the drawing in July, described it as an exquisite masterpiece.

fields.headline: ENO's Coliseum to get £41m facelift
fields.standfirst: First refit in nearly a century at People's Opera will give buyers of cheap seats more comfort and views over London
fields.trailText: First refit in nearly a century at People's Opera will give buyers of cheap seats more comfort and views over London.
fields.body:
The English National Opera yesterday unveiled a dramatic £41m overhaul of its London home, which it hopes will not repeat the disastrous mistakes of its rivals at the Royal Opera House.

The Coliseum - London's biggest theatre - will not be shut, as Covent Garden was, during the three-year refurbishment, and as befits the "People's Opera", the biggest winners will not be the wealthy but those who buy the cheapest £6 seats in the gallery.

They will no longer have to use a separate entrance and will be treated to one of the best views in London from the new gallery bars and roof garden, which will overlook Trafalgar Square. That vast arched glass roof and a spinning illuminated ball on the top of the Coliseum tower, all part of the original plans of its master architect, Frank Matcham, will be the most spectacular alterations to the landmark building.

However, the biggest changes will be in the theatre's slightly tatty interior: its often pokey foyers will expanded by almost a half, there will be more and bigger bars, air conditioning will improve comfort in the auditorium, and there will be a complete recreation of what the ENO's director, Nicholas Payne, called "Matcham's remarkable decorative confection", including a new wildly flamboyant Edwardian proscenium.

Mr Payne said he was determined that the company's programme would not be curtailed by the building work. "We may have to open a month later than usual next year, and we may stage a few things outside the building along the lines of the arena operas the impresario Raymond Gubbay has proved can be so successful, but we will have a full programme at the Coliseum."

Responding to criticism of ENO's orchestra and chorus, he admitted the strain of being one of the busiest opera company's in the world sometimes did take its toll. "It is possible on one or two occasions they have seemed tired. But it would be inhuman to expect otherwise sometimes; maybe there is too big a workload."

Mr Payne said although there would be changes backstage - like solving the problems around the Coliseum's hole-in-the-wall stage door, and taking all the offices out of the building - most of the refurbishment "has been concentrated on making things better for the audience".

Surtitles, which appear above the stage so the audience can follow what is being sung, may be replaced if "a new form of more personalised technology" was available.

Most of the money for the refit - the first since the theatre was built 97 years ago - will come from the Arts Council and the lottery, which has yet to rubber stamp its precise contribution.

webTitle: Pill to beat fat on way

fields.headline: Pill to beat fat on way
fields.trailText: A "fat pill" to help control obesity could be a step nearer. Genetic engineers in Texas have designed a mouse that eats up to 40% more - but weighs up to 15% less - than normal mice.
fields.body:
A "fat pill" to help control obesity could be a step nearer. Genetic engineers in Texas have designed a mouse that eats up to 40% more - but weighs up to 15% less - than normal mice.

Obesity is rapidly becoming a huge problem in the western world. Pharmaceutical companies know that a safe drug to limit weight gain could earn billions.

For a decade, the race has been on to understand the personal biochemistry that allows some people to stay thin while others balloon. Laboratory mouse experiments have begun to reveal more about the mechanisms of appetite.

The latest trick, a team from Baylor College of Medicine in Houston reveal in the US journal Science today, is to shut down a gene that controls an enzyme called acetyl-CoA carboxylase 2 or ACC2.

"This enzyme ACC2 could be a target for generating drugs that could regulate the burning of fat," said Salih Wakil, a biochemist at Baylor.

ACC2 is one of two bits of bodily machinery - the other is called ACC1 - involved in the formation of fatty acids and in burning off fat in the cells of the human body.

Dr Wakil and his colleagues engineered two kinds of mice. One was conceived without ACC1, the other without ACC2. The first group died as embryos, confirming that fat was important in development.

"However, the mice genetically engineered to lack ACC2 seem very happy, live and breed well," he said.

They ate more, weighed less and accumulated only about half the fat of normal mice.

webTitle: Men who were small babies less likely to marry

fields.headline: Bachelor boys weigh in light
fields.trailText: Men who were small babies are less likely to marry and may even have had their chances of wedlock determined in the womb, researchers say today.
fields.body:
Men who were small babies are less likely to marry and may even have had their chances of wedlock determined in the womb, researchers say today.

As many as one in five of those who weighed around five and a half pounds or less at birth did not marry, while that figure dropped well below one in 10 as soon as birthweight was much over 7lb, according to two studies of more than 5,000 men born between the two world wars.

Even in later life it was shown that single men were on average two centimetres shorter than those who were married.

The research into generations for whom marriage was a social norm led one of the team, David Phillips, to suggest the impact of stress, size and hormonal changes before and after birth may play a part in dictating sexuality, personality and emotional responses.

"There is an obvious animal precedent for this. We know that if you stress animals during pregnancy, you affect the sexual development of their offspring," said Professor Phillips, of the medical research council's environmental epidemiology unit at Southampton general hospital. It was also known that those who are small at birth may have stress problems later in adult life and that they are more prone to diabetes.

"It would be amazing if this did not affect personality. We don't know what is going on, but it is intriguing us," he said.

Previous research has shown that unmarried men have higher levels of heart disease than married men and do not live as long. This could either be because healthier men tend to marry or that the support of wives is protective.

The latest researchers in England, Finland and Australia checked on the records of more than 3,500 men born in Helsinki between 1924 and 1933 and those of more than 1,600 born in Hertfordshire between 1920 and 1930, to establish whether small babies married less often.

Their report in the British Medical Journal today shows that this was the case, and that single men were in later adult life about 2cm shorter on average than those who were married.

The reseachers concluded that factors that lead men to marry are complex and include both biological and social ones.

Prof Phillips has teamed up with a sexologist to see if they can widen their understanding of what is happening.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: People smuggler jailed for 9 years | Baptism of legal fire | Champion of war 'cowards' dies
fields.body:
People smuggler jailed for 9 years

The head of a "family business" in people smuggling was jailed for nine years yesterday. Stephen Hobbs, 43, was convicted at Canterbury crown court, Kent, of smuggling in 96 people.

His brother John Hobbs, 44, was sentenced to seven-and-a-half years; and his nephew, Darren, 25, and friend Warren Charge, 29, were sentenced to three years. All were found guilty of roles in the business.

Baptism of legal fire

Security adviser Robert Podesta, 51, who hid in Dornoch cathedral, Sutherland, to film the star-studded christening of Madonna's son, Rocco, was yesterday fined £1,000 at Dornoch sheriff court. Podesta, of Garway, Herefordshire, admitted conducting himself in a disorderly manner.

Champion of war 'cowards' dies

Tom Stones, a driving force behind the campaign to rehabilitate the names of 306 young soldiers shot for alleged cowardice in the first world war, has died of cancer in Stafford aged 60.

N-waste action fails in court

Anti-nuclear campaigners yesterday failed in a high court attempt to block the discharge of radioactive waste into the air at nuclear sites - at Aldermaston and Burghfield in Berkshire - involved in the production of Trident warheads.

Briton accused of air attack

A Briton was due to appear in court in Los Angeles yesterday accused of hitting a steward while drunk on a flight from Sydney to the US. Fraser Alexander Thomas Lonie, 34, was arrested by an FBI agent.

fields.headline: The sweet smell of failure
fields.trailText: It has long been believed that success carries a sweet smell. Now scientists have proved that failure too carries a smell - although it may not necessarily be acrid.
fields.body:
It has long been believed that success carries a sweet smell. Now scientists have proved that failure too carries a smell - although it may not necessarily be acrid.

Psychologists investigating the role of scent in human behaviour discovered that people can be driven to fail merely by exposure to a particular odour, the society heard.

A study by psychologist Simon Chu, from Liverpool University, revealed that the success rate of volunteers in brain-teasing tasks was powerfully influenced by exposure to various smells.

Dr Chu gave participants a three-minute blast of a particular odour while they were attempting a maze puzzle. The volunteers were told most people found their way through the maze in 25 seconds when, in fact, it was impossible.

The participants came to associate their failure with the smell and when exposed to it during subsequent, easier, tests did not do as well as expected.

Dr Chu said: "It's an incredibly powerful finding .. their performance was severely affected."

It made no difference what kind of odours were involved: incense and essential oils were used, including bergamot, which is normally associated with relaxation.

Dr Chu said it was possible that smell could be associated with success as well as failure, although this would be more difficult to demonstrate.

The implication is that we can use odours to manipulate human behaviour in different ways. Possibly it could be used to reinforce good behaviour when individuals are not aware they are behaving in a certain way - problem children, for instance, Dr Chu said.

fields.headline: Hammer attack man detained indefinitely
fields.trailText: A paranoid schizophrenic who hammered to death his mother, aunt and grandfather after hearing "voices" was ordered to be detained indefinitely when he appeared at Birmingham crown court yesterday.
fields.body:
A paranoid schizophrenic who hammered to death his mother, aunt and grandfather after hearing "voices" was ordered to be detained indefinitely when he appeared at Birmingham crown court yesterday.

Stuart Michael Hall, 25, denied three counts of murder but admitted manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. He "ambushed" his mother Susan Hall, 43, aunt Lynda Hall, 46, and grandfather Clifford Hall, 76, striking them several times with a hammer at the family home in Coventry last October.

Mr Justice Hughes told Hall: "It is now clear that you were, have been, and still are, mentally ill with a form of paranoid schizophrenia."

The court was told that Hall began hearing voices from the age of 15 and gradually became virtually housebound. He began to hear a "thing" in his head which instructed him to kill his family on a specified day and then commit suicide.

Prosecuting, Philip Parker QC said Hall used "considerable force" in killing his victims with a hammer. He blud geoned his aunt and grandfather in the morning before waiting for his mother to return from work in the evening.

Mr Parker said: "He struck them several times over the head. His grandfather was also attacked with a knife."

It was not until two days later, with the bodies still in the house, that police were called after a neighbour smelt the gas which Hall had turned on in the kitchen. He had also drunk whisky and taken tablets.

Hall dropped a television set on his grandfather's head after he saw a hand flicker after the attack. And after he had repeatedly struck his mother with the hammer he placed a pillow over her face and stood on it for about 30 minutes.

The following day he attempted to commit suicide after the "thing" in his head said it was angry because he was not dead, the court heard.

For Hall, Anthony Palmer QC said he was "not without intelligence" and had been tormented by voices in his head. Early treatment "may have prevented the tragedies".

fields.headline: Composite Briton unveiled
fields.trailText: Boiling down the faces of 2,000 males and females into a single image, an artist has created a digital representation of the average 21st century Briton: youthful, attractive, olive-skinned, dark-eyed - and anonymous.
fields.body:
Meet the population of Britain. Boiling down the faces of 2,000 males and females into a single image, an artist has created a digital representation of the average 21st century Briton: youthful, attractive, olive-skinned, dark-eyed - and anonymous.

Chris Dorley-Brown's spooky, gender-free image is created from photographs of 1,000 females and 900 males, aged six months to 80 and covering 50 ethnic groupings, taken over a three-month period in Haverhill, Suffolk, last summer.

Although the project was designed to produce a virtual representation of Haverhill's population, the photographic artist believes it captures the entire country just as well. "No doubt I would have got different results if I had done it somewhere like Botswana or Mexico," Mr Dorley-Brown said. "It is not a woman or a man, it is like a robotic creation which has more to do with the way software and computers behave.

"I am not surprised that it is beautiful. I am glad it is because it reinforces my belief in the attractiveness of the human race."

He admitted, however, that the beauty of the final image cannot be taken as evidence of Haverhill residents' superior aesthetic qualities. "The process of merging pictures tended to iron out the little blemishes which make people into individuals."

Mr Dorley-Brown photographed his volunteers - about 10% of the town's population of 20,000 - by setting up portable studios in local shops.

He also took his camera to schools, playgroups and clubs for the elderly so he could get a cross-section of the population, although securing snaps of under-fives proved a problem.

After photographing about 70 people a day, he then had to go through the difficult process of merging the pictures into each other, a pair at a time, until only one was left. With each pairing requiring 40 individual facial features to be morphed together, the process took over four months.

The idea came from Haverhill council's arts and leisure manager, Nick Keeble. He had seen one of Mr Dorley-Brown's earlier projects, creating a giant ceramic mural from the morphed photographs of 300 people taken in a Cambridge nightclub. Mr Keeble approached the artist and they agreed to work together, securing a £25,000 lottery grant from the Millennium Festival Fund.

Mr Keeble said: "Haverhill has a population which is 48% under the age of 25, so the final picture reflects the youthfulness of the town."

fields.headline: Pas de crumpets, pas de scones. Paris mourns end of a way of life
fields.trailText: "I can't believe it," said Nicole Crawford, standing outside the shuttered shopfront of Marks and Sparks' flagship Paris store on the boulevard Haussman yesterday. "I just can't believe this is happening. It's a slice of England that's disappearing from France.
fields.body:
C'est fini, alors. Pas de crumpets, pas de scones, pas de smoked bacon ni de clotted cream, pas d'extra strong tea, pas de chicken tikka sandwiches. No more mature cheddar, no more - 'ow you call them? - salt 'n' vinegar crisps, no more individual pork pies. Pas de knickers.

"I can't believe it," said Nicole Crawford, standing outside the shuttered shopfront of Marks and Sparks' flagship Paris store on the boulevard Haussman yesterday. "I just can't believe this is happening. It's a slice of England that's disappearing from France. I'm half French, half English and totally depressed."

Throughout yesterday, grieving shoppers of all nationalities stood silent and open-mouthed before the printed notices taped to the windows of the first store M&S opened in France, way back in the mid-seventies: We inform our loyal customers that the shop is exceptionally closed.

"Oh my God, the eclairs - what am I going to do without the eclairs?" cried Gabriela Ascencio-Lane, half Mexican, half English and not in the least happy. "They cost Fr13 for four here. Go to a French patisserie and you'll be lucky to get away with Fr13 for one."

All 18 Marks and Spencer's stores in France were closed for most of the day yesterday as the 1,700 staff absorbed the news, announced to them just before opening time, that the company's continental European operation was to be wound up by December 31.

"We're in a state of shock, you have to understand it," said Sylvie, an assistant in the children's wear department. "We knew the company wasn't doing well, but we always thought our jobs would be safe - see that scaffolding there, up to the end of the road? That was the new extension."

Ms Ascensio-Lane was also worried about her future underwear needs. "They always have it in my size, it's affordable, gorgeous lacy underwear, very comfortable and it lasts for ages," she said.

The wailing of the Paris expat community was more than matched by the woe of some of Marks and Spencer's French customers. Staring longingly at a maroon woollen twin set in the window, Marcelle, 58, and Jacqueline, 56, declared themselves desolated by news.

"I've been shopping here for 15 years," said Marcelle. "The style suits me, it's good quality at a reasonable price. And there's always that little English touch."

Jacqueline said you could buy silk jumpers here for Fr300 that would cost Fr600 elsewhere. Another regular customer, Celine, said she would miss the tea and the custard creams, but that she'd stopped buying M&S clothes two or three years ago.

(Georges Zurbach, Marks and Spencer's French marketing director, confirmed Celine's astute analysis on the radio: the company's food sales were outstanding in France, he said, but clothes - 70% of turnover - were in real trouble.)

David Flitterman, who lives in Grenoble but drops in to M&S "for crisps and biscuits" whenever he's in Paris, summed it up. "So many people, French and English, are so devoted to this store. The company should try to make it work. But of course, these days it's only the shareholders who count."

Throughout yesterday, grieving shoppers of all nationalities stood silent and open-mouthed before the printed notices taped to the windows of the first store M&S opened in France, way back in the mid-seventies: We inform our loyal customers that the shop is exceptionally closed. "Oh my God, the eclairs - what am I going to do without the eclairs?" cried Gabriela Ascencio-Lane, half Mexican, half English and not in the least happy. "They cost Fr13 for four here. Go to a French patisserie and you'll be lucky to get away with Fr13 for one." All 18 Marks and Spencer's stores in France were closed for most of the day yesterday as the 1,700 staff absorbed the news, announced to them just before opening time, that the company's continental European operation was to be wound up by December 31. "We're in a state of shock, you have to understand it," said Sylvie, an assistant in the children's wear department. "We knew the company wasn't doing well, but we always thought our jobs would be safe - see that scaffolding there, up to the end of the road? That was the new extension." Ms Ascensio-Lane was also worried about her future underwear needs. "They always have it in my size, it's affordable, gorgeous lacy underwear, very comfortable and it lasts for ages," she said. The wailing of the Paris expat community was more than matched by the woe of some of Marks and Spencer's French customers. Staring longingly at a maroon woollen twin set in the window, Marcelle, 58, and Jacqueline, 56, declared themselves desolated by news. "I've been shopping here for 15 years," said Marcelle. "The style suits me, it's good quality at a reasonable price. And there's always that little English touch." Jacqueline said you could buy silk jumpers here for Fr300 that would cost Fr600 elsewhere. Another regular customer, Celine, said she would miss the tea and the custard creams, but that she'd stopped buying M&S clothes two or three years ago. (Georges Zurbach, Marks and Spencer's French marketing director, confirmed Celine's astute analysis on the radio: the company's food sales were outstanding in France, he said, but clothes - 70% of turnover - were in real trouble.) David Flitterman, who lives in Grenoble but drops in to M&S "for crisps and biscuits" whenever he's in Paris, summed it up. "So many people, French and English, are so devoted to this store. The company should try to make it work. But of course, these days it's only the shareholders who count."

fields.headline: 4,390 jobs cut at M&S
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer yesterday announced 4,390 job losses, the closure of its European stores, and axed its mail order division, in a radical overhaul designed to put the emphasis back on its core British high street retail business.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer yesterday announced 4,390 job losses, the closure of its European stores, and axed its mail order division, in a radical overhaul designed to put the emphasis back on its core British high street retail business.

The group's chairman Luc Vandevelde described the plan as a "dramatic, urgent thorough correction" to halt M&S's dramatic decline, particularly in the clothing sector.

fields.headline: Divided over Liz Davies
fields.trailText: There must be so many of us, like Liz Davies, who are no longer members of the Labour party (Labour pains, G2, March 29).
fields.body:
There must be so many of us, like Liz Davies, who are no longer members of the Labour party (Labour pains, G2, March 29). All, especially women, have stories to tell about our experiences. As a member and activist for 37 years, a councillor for nearly 20 and candidate in Westminster and European elections, I believe that, in the run-up to the election, the party should seriously reflect on why so many of us refuse to rejoin.

Recently I was sent an appeal to rejoin. It said the party "stands for fairness, social justice and opportunity for all". This is blatantly no longer true. Like so many others, I shall still have to vote Labour - my MP still believes in socialist principles, I have harangued so many people for not exercising their democratic right and, most depressing, because there is no alternative. How sad Labour is likely to win for negative reasons.
Shirley Haines
Leeds

 As someone who voted for Liz Davies and her colleagues to help them become NEC members, I would say please come back soon. There is no doubt the Labour government of 1997 was a severe shock to many members and indeed took some decisions even Mrs Thatcher would have shrunk from. But over the last four years they have changed, possibly because of the energies of Liz Davies and others.

Mr Brown's Budget was a masterpiece even Denis Healey at the height of his powers would have been proud of. It gave a massive priority to children and their education and still took account of the needs of pensioners. What more could true socialists realistically ask for? Politics requires patience.
Barry Martin
Chadlington, Oxon
barry@chadlington.fsnet.co.uk

 I had difficulty recognising the 1999 Labour party conference from the image projected by Liz Davies. Certainly, and not before time, inexperienced delegates were afforded whatever help they needed in getting their points across in a succinct and lucid way. Getting up be fore the nation's media in a crowded hall is not easy. And from my soundings, as a constituency delegate, first-time speakers appreciated the support they were given.

I spoke in the Northern Ireland debate. No one told me what to say or how to say it. How could they? Once a delegate gets to the rostrum, the floor is his or hers. And short of publicly slandering the chair, it's difficult to shut them up within their allotted time.

My recollection of comrades Davies, Willsman and Seddon was of three kids sulking around the nursery refusing to play with the other children because they didn't like the game. The game is called government and the great majority of us in the Labour party like it.
Cllr Nick Nolan
Leader, Coventry council
nick.nolan@coventry.gov.uk

 It is tiresome for NEC members to be lectured for failing to be sufficiently critical of the government. One compelling reason for a degree of inhibition about debating issues was the reluctance of many members to have their comments and questions leaked to the press and provide material on which to base allegations of damaging splits. Grassroots alliance members were frequently reminded that their propensity to provide colourful accounts of NEC meetings were in this sense counterproductive.
Cllr Jeremy Beecham
Leader, Labour group, Local Government Association

 Perhaps Liz Davies now understands how many of us felt when the party we loved was taken over by the Militants and Bennites in the 70s and 80s. We stayed, we won, we were elected.
Michael Kilcoyne
Horwich, Lancashire

webTitle: Letters: God does a better job

fields.headline: God does a better job
fields.trailText: Jeremy Rifkin's thoughtful article (Shopping for humans, March 29) outlines the dangers cloning poses to our humanity.
fields.body:
Jeremy Rifkin's thoughtful article (Shopping for humans, March 29) outlines the dangers cloning poses to our humanity. To that needs to be added the potential danger to the whole of the future of the human race in the potential loss of creativity. Humanity has developed in all its riches because of the random effects of the fusing of two sets of genes producing totally unique people who have never existed before. Human beings unfortunately, can only envisage what the limits of their brains allow, whereas nature is greater than that and brings surprises. The loss of potential creativity is playing God when we don't have the the vision of the original creator.
Trish Ruddock
Stockport
trishruddock@cwctv.net

 Usually, I read your newspaper to better familiarise myself with what I regard as the vanguard of socialism and the dangers thereof. However, I found Jeremy Rifkin's article quite compelling, well reasoned and laced with humanity. Certainly, you blithely wiped away the religious aspects (which are as primeval as sexuality) of this issue, as I would have expected. But the issues you raised were poignant ones - which all ethical human beings will be quickly forced to deal with. We are entering the unknown and, I agree, a turning point in human history. What comes to my mind is the movie Coma, where people were put in that state for the sale of body parts. It was a good little story then, but I now realise that there are enough intelligent sociopaths in the world to put this into reality through cloning. I hope your voice will continue to ring the bell of conscience, over and over again.
Stanley Gwizdak
Fairbanks, Alaska

fields.headline: Redwood in the wrong
fields.trailText: John Redwood sees political advantage in foot and mouth and the collapse of the travel industry (Labour's grim spring, March 29). What matter if hoteliers are ruined if it gets the Conservatives back into government?
fields.body:
John Redwood sees political advantage in foot and mouth and the collapse of the travel industry (Labour's grim spring, March 29). What matter if hoteliers are ruined if it gets the Conservatives back into government?

But his glee gets the better of his judgment when he accuses the government (and the Germans) of smashing the telecoms industry. I never realised that auctioneers could force hard-headed buyers to pay more than they could afford.
John Lodge
Lancaster
John@lodge33.freeserve.co.uk

 Am I alone in wondering exactly how Chinese food came to be blamed for the current outbreak of foot and mouth disease? Have condemned pigs confessed to having gobbled down a sneaky chop suey? Is there a special strain of foot and mouth which is only found in conjunction with five spice powder and soy sauce?

Or has the press, encouraged by the government, leapt to blame this epidemic on an ethnic minority (single mothers, presumably, being unavailable)?
Richard Brown
London

 We are often told that if we were to see the inside of a slaughterhouse, we would turn vegetarian. Now that we see farmers so deeply affected by witnessing their animals being slaughtered, is it possible that many will turn to arable farming or even turn vegetarian?
M Pooley
Ropley, Hants

fields.headline: Rich tapestry
fields.trailText: Re your leader (March 27), I am happy to confirm that Reading would consider loaning sections of our Bayeux tapestry replica to Leek, subject to appropriate arrangements being made.
fields.body:
Re your leader (March 27), I am happy to confirm that Reading would consider loaning sections of our Bayeux tapestry replica to Leek, subject to appropriate arrangements being made. We could begin this process as soon as an approach isreceived from Moorlands council. But there can be no permanent return. The tapestry was bought by Alderman Hill for the people of Reading at a time when no one else appeared to want it. It has been carefully preserved, at the expense of local people, for over a 100 years and is a popular exhibit in Reading's recently expanded museum.

Anyone from Leek who visits the museum will be made welcome and will be able to read the acknowledgements to the ladies of Leek who sewed the tapestry. The museum remains entirely free to all visitors and free guided tours of the tapestry are available.
Cllr Jon Hartley
Lead councillor for cultural services, Reading council
catrin.john@reading.gov.uk

fields.headline: How Talisman oils peace
fields.trailText: We at Talisman Energy share the concern of those seeking an end to the poverty and fighting in Sudan. However, the cause of peace was not furthered by your publication of the inaccurate, incomplete and one-sided articles published on March 15.
fields.body:
We at Talisman Energy share the concern of those seeking an end to the poverty and fighting in Sudan. However, the cause of peace was not furthered by your publication of the inaccurate, incomplete and one-sided articles published on March 15. Guardian readers would have been better served if your reporters had contacted our company for comment before repeating the numerous factual errors and misrepresentations contained in the Christian Aid "report". Since we invested in Sudan two years ago, Talisman has built and equipped five medical clinics and three schools in our area of operation. The clinics now provide free medical care to hundreds of people daily and have vaccinated about 15,000 people for protection from six communicable diseases.

We provide medical staff at the clinics and ship them 1.5 tonnes of vaccines, serums and other medical supplies each month. Our company has also drilled high-capacity water wells in four communities and repaired wells in 28 oth ers, bringing urgently needed fresh water to thousands of people. These improvements and new employment opportunities have resulted in an increase in the population of our operating area, not a decrease as alleged by Christian Aid.

Talisman is an ethical company that has adopted the international code of ethics for Canadian business. At our urging, our partners in the Sudanese oil project have adopted a similar code protecting human rights that governs all their operations in Sudan as well as our own.

Those who suggest western companies should withdraw from Sudan should consider the value of economic development as an incentive to peace. The fighting in Sudan began nearly 50 years before we invested there. Our withdrawal would not end the war, but it would end our extensive community development work and effective advocacy of expanded human rights. Jobs, prosperity and dialogue encourage peace.
Dave Mann
Talisman Energy Inc

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Alan Titchmarsh

fields.headline: No 1850: Alan Titchmarsh
fields.standfirst: Alan Titchmarsh
fields.trailText: Alan Titchmarsh
fields.body:
Phwoar! I can feel a real Ground Force coming on, if you catch my drift. Not for much longer.

What? It's true. Alan Titchmarsh, gap-toothed sex symbol to a million housewives, is set to quit the BBC's top-rated gardening show at the end of the next series.

But why? He claims that the format is getting tired. "When we got to 50 programmes, I thought it was time to stop, but they were desperate to carry on," he says. "I agreed to do another 16, then go." But cynics are pointing to tensions between Titchmarsh and his co-presenters.

How do you mean? Dark rumours are circulating that our Alan felt eclipsed by the enormous popularity of bra-less co-host, Charlie Dimmock, who burst out of a Hampshire garden centre to outstrip Titchmarsh as the nation's favourite TV horticulturalist.

A case of the green-fingered monster? Maybe. After an onscreen row with the show's builder, Tommy Walsh, last year, Alan muttered: "One good thing was that it silenced Charlie Dimmock."

Sounds like Gro-bags at 50 paces. I'll say. Titchmarsh accompanied his announcement to quit the show with a swipe at "these gardeners in skirts".

So is this really the last we'll see of the corduroy Casanova? Unlikely. Titchmarsh, recently voted the world's second sexiest man (narrowly beaten by George Clooney since you ask), is a chap of many talents. He's got his columns in the Express and Radio Times to keep him going, as well as lucrative side-line as an author. On top of his presenting duties he has found the time to write more than 30 books on gardening, as well as a series of steamy novels. He was immortalised last month in Madame Tussaud's, and was awarded an MBE in 1999.

So he comes with the royal seal of approval? Oh yes. The Queen is said to have remarked as she presented the gong: "You have given a lot of ladies a lot of pleasure."

Not to be confused with: Alan Partridge; Dave Dee, Dozy, Beaky, Mick and Titch.

webTitle: Cancer rise 'led by changes in lifestyle'

fields.headline: Cancer rise 'led by changes in lifestyle'
fields.trailText: The sexual revolution of the 1960s, together with less cautious behaviour during the two world wars when death appeared ever imminent, are behind the rise in cervical cancer, just as smoking has caused the lung cancer epidemic, according to research chronicling the last century of the disease.
fields.body:
The sexual revolution of the 1960s, together with less cautious behaviour during the two world wars when death appeared ever imminent, are behind the rise in cervical cancer, just as smoking has caused the lung cancer epidemic, according to research chronicling the last century of the disease.

In Victorian times, relatively few people died of cancer. Now it is responsible for a quarter of the deaths in the UK. More than 150,000 people die of it every year. The alarming increase in the death rates has caused many people to point the finger of accusation at the changing environment, fearing that pollution, our diet or nuclear power must be to blame.

But most common cancers that are identified today have other origins, according to Anthony Swerdlow, of the Institute of Cancer Research, and colleagues. One is our increasing lifespan - in past centuries, infectious diseases carried people off long before they were likely to develop cancers.

Lifestyle has played a big part in the increase of some cancers, most notably lung cancer. Professor Swerdlow and colleagues, who yesterday launched their research in book form (Oxford University Press), published data correlating the enormous rise in smoking from the 19th century with the rise and now fall in the epidemic as a result.

Cervical cancer is now thought to be caused by a sexual infection.

Higher cancer rates followed both world wars and also the arrival of the contraceptive pill in the 1960s which launched new sexual freedom. There has now been a sharp downturn in cervical cancer and gonorrhoea which are thought to be connected to barrier contraception and reduced promiscuity once people became aware of the risk of HIV/Aids.

Cheap package holidays which began in the 1950s and the quest for a deep tan have been a direct cause of increased cases of malignant melanoma, or skin cancer, the research shows.

However, the data do not support any link between either mobile phone use and brain cancer or electricity and childhood leukaemia, says Prof Swerdlow.

There is as yet no explanation for breast cancer, which increased apparently inexorably for 100 years until the 1980s. Since then, however, screening, better diagnosis and powerful treatments have brought the death rates steeply down.

Prof Swerdlow says that the book gives cause for optimism. "We examined the trends in cancer in this country over a long period and the factors that may have caused them. Because the research to find the causes of cancer and to improve treatments has been a long process, often the results are only apparent over several decades.

"When viewed with this perspective, there are many encouraging signs."

Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, which funded the research, said: "For me, it illustrates how changes in the way we behave and the fashions and fads that influence us can impact later in life, and how with most cancers we can make informed choices on prevention, screening and early diagnosis."

He added: "We now have more knowledge to be masters of our own destiny."

 A hospital was yesterday accused of "carelessness" after two patients died from cancer and a third was left terminally ill because of alleged misdiagnosis, writes James Meikle.

A fourth patient who was at first told his cancer was inoperable has now had an operation and is fit and well, according to a solicitor who called for tighter procedures at Rotherham general hospital, south Yorkshire.

The NHS executive is scrutinising actions at the hospital, which has apologised to relatives of the pair who died but said one would have died even if his cancer had not been missed.

Terry Regan, of the Sheffield law firm Russell Jones and Walker, representing the families, said: "There is a pattern of carelessness emerging here. There were signs that should have been spotted but weren't."

A hospital trust spokesman said: "The issues have to be put into the context that in a single year the trust undertakes 90,000 x-rays, 25,000 ultrasound examinations, and 42,000 CT scans and that we treat 46,000 in-patients and 210,000 outpatients."

The regional office of the NHS said that it did not think its intervention was warranted at this stage.
