A fourth patient who was at first told his cancer was inoperable has now had an operation and is fit and well, according to a solicitor who called for tighter procedures at Rotherham general hospital, south Yorkshire. The NHS executive is scrutinising actions at the hospital, which has apologised to relatives of the pair who died but said one would have died even if his cancer had not been missed. Terry Regan, of the Sheffield law firm Russell Jones and Walker, representing the families, said: "There is a pattern of carelessness emerging here. There were signs that should have been spotted but weren't." A hospital trust spokesman said: "The issues have to be put into the context that in a single year the trust undertakes 90,000 x-rays, 25,000 ultrasound examinations, and 42,000 CT scans and that we treat 46,000 in-patients and 210,000 outpatients." The regional office of the NHS said that it did not think its intervention was warranted at this stage.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Billy Elliot | Hollow Man | Ring | The Little Vampire
fields.trailText: Billy Elliot | Hollow Man | Ring | The Little Vampire
fields.body:
Billy Elliot
Rental and DVD rental Universal Cert 15

The most-loved British film of the last year, Billy Elliot is pitched half-way between Kes - still very much the template for the grim-oop-north drama - and well-meaning old Hollywood films like How Green Was My Valley. It's effective if a bit overrated, but there's no denying a stupendous performance by Jamie Bell, just 15. To be this good as a novice actor would be impressive; to be this good as a dancer too seems miraculous. And it's the dancing scenes - especially one in the tight, claustrophobic brick surrounds that recalls East is East's exuberance - that stay with you, and more than cancel out some of the more sentimental views of northern life, as well as the uncertain plotting. It's set in Durham, 1984, a virtual war zone in the midst of the bitter miners' strike, and uses dance as an expression of frustration, something to lose yourself in, to hit back at the ugliness, strife and claustrophobia surrounding a young life. Bell makes it more than just The Full Monty with pliés.

Hollow Man
Retail and DVD rental Columbia Cert 18

Kevin Bacon discovers the secret of invisibility and, like any self-respecting mad film scientist, gets a God complex, with a wide streak of devil to go with it. From a promising start, Paul Verhoeven's film winds up with a pretty routine Old Dark House/ Alien plot: it's mad, bad Kev vs the world. But, plot be damned, the point of Hollow Man is its effects, and they are a spectacular entrée into the world of blood, bones and tissue. Bacon goes through elaborate stages of visibility which work as a fantastic anatomy lesson as well as showing invisibility underwater or in the rain. You can't help feeling body-meister David Cronenberg would have found better uses for all this technology, but where Verhoeven's superior predecessor, Starship Troopers, had no DVD extras at all, this uses the medium properly, explaining its conception in great detail and showing the frenetic Dutchman at work, acting out each part with abandon. As Bacon says: "I have to play a mad scientist, so it's good to have one around."

Ring
Rental, retail (£15.99) and DVD (£19.99) Tartan Cert 15

Japanese horror has had a boom year with Audition and this first film from the Ring trilogy; both this and Ring 2, the sequel, had a recent cinematic release. It's like The Blair Witch Project - thematically but not stylistically - fused with Cronenberg's Videodrome. Its scariest moments top both, but it uses subtle suggestion more than shock effects for the most part, putting flesh on the bones of a silly story about a cursed video which is followed by a phone call giving the viewer one week to live. The combination of old folk tales and new technology provides a lot of its distinctive feel. It certainly leaves you wanting to see Ring 2, shown as part two of a double bill in the east, where it was a smash-hit. If you find yourself in the horror section, you'd do far better with this than the crass, depressing Scary Movie.

The Little Vampire
Retail (£14.99) and DVD (£15.99) Icon Cert U

At the age of 10, Jonathan Lipnicki seems to have a monopoly on good kid comedy roles. He was brother to a mouse in Stuart Little and here, showing the same winning combination of puzzlement and determination, he is a kid obsessed by vampires in another enjoyable, cheerful comedy ideal for multi-generational viewing. For kids, there's a strong identification figure in a bullied child letting his imagination run wild in Scotland, where his parents are working. For oldies, there's a lovely running joke about a herd of vampire cows, Jim Carter as a vampire slayer who is more roughie than Buffy, and Richard E Grant who always has looked vampiric, wrapping his perfect elocution round lines like "We need darkness, dampness and decay" ("and the finest wines available to humanity," you half-expect him to add since this is a medieval close relative of Withnail). The Little Vampire throws in a few film references without nudging you in the ribs too much and this is jolly stuff by Uli Edel, once the grim realist director of Christiane F and Last Exit to Brooklyn.

fields.headline: 2001: A Space Odyssey
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: If any film deserves to be called a work of authentic genius, it is this one.
fields.body:
The ambition and epic conceit of Kubrick's great sci-fi adventure of 1968 are still breathtaking: perhaps the only work whose great spaces and silences can satisfactorily absorb the Master's tendency to redundancy and longueurs . If any film deserves to be called a work of authentic genius, it is this one: designed, produced, directed and co-written by a moviemaker who combined a thrilling sense of scale with a miniaturist's eye for detail.

Famously, Kubrick remarked to Alexander Walker that this was a "fable, not a prediction", but it's easy to forget the extraordinary excitement and rate of technical progress in the Space Race Sixties, and how the year 2001 didn't then seem that implausible for what was shown on screen. Since then, we've lost interest in dreaming about the stars, and this movie's towering humanism and optimism are a devastating rebuke to our dull, incurious attitude to the universe.

fields.headline: Save the Last Dance
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Thomas Carter delivers a well-crafted movie acknowledging the tough realities of race more frankly than you might expect.
fields.body:
Julia Stiles is Sara, a sensitive Wasp ballet-loving girl with Issues, who gets into a bit of a kids-from-Fame situation down at "Steps", the local hip-hop nightspot. Here, she learns how to loosen up and dance - and to love - with Derek (Sean Patrick Thomas) a luscious black guy from the ghetto who, conveniently, happens to be as aspirational as Sarah, combining street cred with a letter of acceptance from Georgetown medical school.

As ever, Stiles gives an attractive and intelligent performance, and she can obviously dance a bit, too, though there's a body double in long shot for the trickier moves, and it's someone else's feet going up on points. Sean Patrick Thomas does an honest job as well, and director Thomas Carter delivers a well-crafted movie acknowledging the tough realities of race more frankly than you might expect. But in the end it sinks under the weight of starcrossed clichés.

fields.headline: The Monkey's Mask
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: McGillis was always a class act and she brings a stately sort of worldliness to the movie.
fields.body: Kelly McGillis has come a long way from her Amish reticence in Witness. Here she is in this Australian lesbian detective thriller, directed by Samantha Lang, playing Diana, a middle-aged bisexual poetry lecturer who gets it on with Susie Porter, a randy gay investigator. McGillis was always a class act, and she brings a stately sort of worldliness to the movie, in particular giving her nude scenes with Porter a queenly magnificence. But the plot and the script are more than faintly absurd and you don't have to be the sharpest implement in the shed to suss the culprit.

fields.headline: Uneasy Riders
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Sinapi triumphantly overcomes any sense of defeat to produce a film of unassuming charm.
fields.body:
A sweet French comedy that owes something to Lars von Trier in its use of digital video, hand-held camerawork, and indeed its subject matter: the sexual lives of disabled people. But the debt is not that great; where von Trier's treatment amounted to shallow and fatuous provocation, Jean-Pierre Sinapi's movie has a desire to illuminate the real lives of real individuals - those with disabilities and their carers.

Originally conceived for television, but extensively garlanded at European festival screenings last year, its theatrical distribution here is richly deserved. Olivier Gourmet is an actor already familiar from the Dardennes brothers' Rosetta; his portrayal of the disabled René is a cauldron of rage and abuse. Finally, he confesses to his nurse Julie (Nadia Kaci) that he needs to get laid - and so she sets out to persuade the roadside prostitutes of Nationale 7 to oblige. Sinapi triumphantly overcomes any sense of defeat to produce a film of unassuming charm.

fields.headline: Damnation
fields.standfirst:
Bela Tarr's 1988 is utterly miserable, but that doesn't
prevent it from being remarkable, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Miserabilist though its theology might be, there is a weird and mesmeric quality in Damnation.
fields.body:
Peter Cook recast St Paul's Letter to the Ephesians like this: "Dear Ephesians, stop enjoying yourselves; God's about the place. Love, St Paul." If he had seen this film, he might have re-phrased it: Stop enjoying yourselves, Bela Tarr's about the place. Such is the severity, the terrible gloom and the uncompromising focus on an eternity of despair - leavened with dyspeptic moments of comedy - with which this remarkable Hungarian director is ready to assail us.

Damnation, made in 1988, is only the first of Tarr's films to gain UK distribution: a black-and-white document of political and existential pessimism. Set in the late Soviet era of filth, disillusion and industrial decay, the movie takes place in continuous, driving rain: rain that gets everywhere, rain that adds a millimetre or two of mucky slop to the floor of bars and cafes, rain that we see in the process of staining and eroding the ubiquitous concrete. It is a rain in which there will be no singin'.

Tarr's first shot is of a cable-car arrangement of great industrial-sized buckets being carried joylessly along the lowering central European skyline. They contain coal perhaps, or sludge, or waste matter, probably without the safety treatment that would prevent its eventual disposal from despoiling the already extensively ravaged environment or seeding the population with a million different cancers. Or perhaps, in the manner of Mike Hodges' Get Carter, one contains a dead body to be dumped some way far off.

Whatever the truth, Tarr's camera stays on it for a long time, the first of many lugubrious takes that facilitate the unending sense of an inexorable fate grinding onwards. We pull back to see Karrer (Miklos B Szekely), a man who spends a lot of time brooding and watching those cable-cars - whose jaundiced figure, bowed with anxiety and weariness, we are to see trudging about like a lost soul in hell.

Karrer is actually the locus of what in any other movie would be a racy and engaging plot. He is hopelessly in love with a nightclub singer; he is threatened by her husband and hangs about outside her abysmal apartment building, begging for admittance, and is at one stage successful. Furthermore, he is privy to a reasonably lucrative smuggling scam - a parcel which must be delivered and returned - which he senses could get the husband out of the way. But any conceivable drama or furtive eroticism latent in all this is entirely passed over in favour of a dark and general assessment of the futility of it all. It is as if Tarr has disengaged from these preposterous local activities and stepped back to inspect the bigger picture.

And what a picture it is. Immobile faces, crumbling slag heaps, desperately sad knees-ups in the local bar - somehow more desperately sad when the music is frenziedly upbeat: an earnest rock number or a jigging, jerking waltz. The black-and-white photography transforms banal reality into painterly beauty and endows the ugly, lined faces with an unearthly glow, as if they have become phosphorescent with decay and defeat.

It is a grim panorama which Tarr differentiates, moreover, with cruces of spiritual disintegration. Karrer confesses that nothing scares him more than children with their bright eyes and cute little faces, because they swindle mankind into going on with this charade and condemn us all to an eternity of horror. Further, he confesses that he drove his late wife to suicide by telling her that he never loved her, out of a pure Beckettian sense of wanting to know "if it made sense to speak at all". These moments are counterpointed by bizarre flourishes of comedy: Karrer turns on a dog that has been tormenting him and gets down on his hands and knees and growls until it goes away.

So who needs it? Do we not, as John Osborne said in another context, get enough of this at home? I can only say that miserabilist though its theology might be, there is a weird and mesmeric quality in Damnation. It induces a floating trance-like sensation like something to be found in Tarkovsky. This is not a film that will have you whistling a happy tune on your way out of the theatre. In fact, a responsible manager will demand your tie and bootlaces on the way in. But it is arresting cinema.

fields.headline: Blow Dry
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Young American actor Josh Hartnett gives the worst British accent ever recorded on celluloid, sounding like Dick Van Dyke's Yorkshire lovechild.
fields.body:
Blow Dry is supposedly "based on a screenplay by Simon Beaufoy". But the rewrites are uncredited and Beaufoy has understandably distanced himself from this idea he once had for a ropey, unfunny underdog comedy of loveable British littleness. The premise is the World Hairdressing Championships held in Keighley, Yorkshire - something that can only remind us of The Big Tease, Craig Ferguson's 1999 comedy on the same subject.

Alan Rickman plays a once-brilliant hairdresser now in grumpy semi-retirement after his wife ran off with his (female) model. His face is permanently set in an expression of frosty hauteur as if he's thinking about the script, or just wondering what the hell he's doing there.

The distinctly heterosexual-looking Natasha Richardson and Rachel Griffiths are woefully miscast as his missus and her squeeze, and the young American actor Josh Hartnett, playing Rickman's teenage son, gives the worst British accent ever recorded on celluloid. "Eeeeee, me dad's gaaawwwwn ter do soom cuttin'," he says, sounding like Dick Van Dyke's Yorkshire lovechild.

fields.headline: Shower
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Yang Zhang has made an impressive debut with this charming and engaging tale.
fields.body: Yang Zhang has made an impressive debut with this charming and engaging tale. Master Liu, played by Chinese screen veteran Xu Zhu, is the proprietor of a traditional Beijing bath-house, frequented now only by old-timers who have the leisure and temperament for a daily, unhurried visit. For Liu, the bath-house is a vocation, a bucolic way of life, about to be destroyed by the new imperatives of commerce, epitomised by his go-getting businessman son Da Ming (Quanxin Pu), who has come home in a panic after receiving a postcard from his handicapped younger brother Er Ming (Wu Jiang), with a child-like drawing of their father asleep - but looking as if he is dead. The consequent tensions illuminate not merely family drama, but also an epochal moment in Chinese urban society.

fields.headline: About Adam
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Slight, but entertaining stuff.
fields.body: A genial, undemanding sex comedy exec-produced by Harvey Weinstein under the banner of HAL, Miramax's now defunct British arm. Adam (Stuart Townsend) is the cute Dubliner of the title; with his ingenuous charm and E-type Jag he seduces three sisters played by Kate Hudson, Frances O'Connor and Charlotte Bradley, with Irish accents of varying plausibility (only Bradley's is the real deal). Is Adam a disturbing enigma, or is he a sphinx without a secret, who simply likes spreading a little sexual happiness? Writer-director Stembridge keeps us guessing until the end. Slight, but entertaining stuff.
